Genetic variation in the 3′ untranslated regions (3′UTR) of mRNAs is known to influence gene expression, but the role of 3′ end processing in this variation remains poorly understood. We conducted a genome-wide survey of 3′ ends in human lymphoblast cells from genetically distinct individuals and mapped the cis-regulatory architecture of 3′ ends. We found that 3′ ends did not fall randomly in 3′UTRs, but rather preferentially flanked 3 regulatory elements, including microRNA (miRNA) sites. The usage of 3′ ends and motifs varied across individuals and polymorphisms in polyadenylation signals and 3′ motifs were significant predictors of expression of genes in which they lay. Single-gene experiments confirmed the effects of polyadenylation on steady-state expression of respective genes and validated the function of 3 cis-regulatory elements in expression of these RNA forms. We focused on the immune regulator IRF and established the effect of variation in 3′ processing on response to antigen. Our results underscore the importance of mechanisms in genetics of 3′ variation: usage of distinct 3 signals and effects of 3 elements on transcript fate. We suggest integrating 3 positions with 3 motifs will be a tool in continued efforts to interpret human variation.
SIVΔne is one of the most effective vaccines in inducing protection against wild-type lentiviral challenge. We used deep sequencing and CD8 T cell epitope mapping to deconstruct the CD8 T response in SIVne-infected animals. In the acute phase of SIVne infection, the CD8 response is predominantly against variable epitopes, followed by sequence evolution and viral escape. Epitope escape expands the CD8 repertoire that targets conserved epitopes and generates de novo responses to escaped variants during vaccination. These findings correlate SIVne-induced protection with expanded conserved specificity and increased response.
Oral mucosal infections caused by Candida albicans are one of the most frequent forms of fungal diseases. The host protection against these infections is conferred by cellular immunity, but the induction of antifungal immunity is not well understood. We used a mouse model of oropharyngeal candidiasis (OPC) to show that interleukin-1 receptor (IL-1R) signaling is critical for fungal control at the onset of infection through its impact on neutrophils at two levels. We demonstrate that the recruitment of circulating neutrophils to the site of infection and mobilization of newly generated neutils from the bone marrow depended on IL-1. IL-deficient mice displayed impaired chemokine production at site and defective secretion of granocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) in circulation in response to C. alb. Strikingly, endothelial cells were identified as primary source of G-CS during OPC, which responded to IL-α released from keratinocytes in infected. The IL-dependent crosstalk between different subsets of hematopoietic compartment confirmed in vitro using murine-derived kerocyte line and endothelial line.
Between 2000 and 2007, the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (GPELF) delivered more than 1.9 billion treatments to nearly 600 million individuals via mass drug administration (MDA) of anti-filar drugs (albendazole, iverectin, diethylcarazine) to at-risk for 4–6 years. The economic benefits of this achievement were quantified by calculating the number of clinical manifestations averted and the associated savings with disease prevention in the context of direct costs, indirect labor, and health care for affected individuals. Multiple sources were reviewed, including literature and databases from the World Organization, International Fund, and Labour. Estimated US$21. 8 billion in economic benefits will be gained over the lifetime of 31.4 million treated during the first 8 years of GPE. Of this, US$2.3 is realized by protection of nearly 3 million and individuals from LF as a result of being born in areas of transmission. Additionally, more than 28 million benefit from GFLF halting progression of disease, resulting in US$19.5 lifetime benefit.
Gaucher disease (GD) is the most common lysosomal storage disease caused by homozygous mutations in the glucocerebrosidase (GBA) gene. Recent studies have shown that GB mutations also confer a strong risk for sporadic Parkinson’s disease (PD). To investigate how GB mutations cause PD, we generated GB mutant mice that are completely deficient in glucocerebrosidase (GCase) activity. In contrast to humans and mice lacking Case activity, GB mice survived for months, enabling analysis of pathological progression. GB mice displayed pathological phenotypes resembling human neuronopathic GD, including infiltration of Gaucher-like cells into brains, progressive neuronal loss and gliosis. Detailed findings revealed lysosomal abnormalities in neurons and α-syn accumulation in axonal swellings containing autophagosomes. Unexpectedly, disruption of α-s did not improve life span, axonal swellings, neuronal loss or neuroinflamm in GB mice.
Listeria monocytogenes is a facultative intracellular pathogen that induces a robust cell-mediated immune response following sublethal infection. To induce long-lived CD8 T–mediated immunity, Listeria monocogen must escape the phagosome and enter the host cytosol. We show that the cell response to phag-confined Listeria monocogen is not due to inefficient antigen presentation, but direct suppression of the adaptive response. This suppression affects not only the response to vacuole-confined Lister monocogen, but also the response to cytosolic L monocogen. Co-infection with phag-conf and cytos L monocogen prevents the generation of acquired immunity and expansion of antigen-specific T cells relative to cytos L monocogen alone. Bacteria confined to phag suppress the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and lead to rapid MyD-dependent IL-10 production. Block of IL-10 receptor or absence of MyD during infection restores protective immunity.
Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is a leading cause of blindness worldwide and the most common subtype of glaucoma is a complex trait with multigenic inheritance. Genome-wide association studies have previously identified a significant association between PO and the SIX locus (rs104827, OR=1.32, p=3.87×10−11 ). SIX plays a role in ocular development and has been associated with the morphology of the optic nerve. We sequenced the SIX coding and regulatory regions in 262 PO cases and 256 controls and identified six nonsynonymous variants, including five rare and one variant AsnHis (rs12345 ), which was associated with PO (OR=1.27, p=4.2×10−10 ) in the NEIGHBOR/GLUGEN datasets. These variants were tested in an in vivo Danio rerio (zebrafish ) complementation to evaluate ocular metrics such as eye and optic structure. Five variants found in PO cases were hypomorphic or null, while sixth found in controls was benign. One in SIX enhancer increased expression SIX and disrupted its regulation. We identified a feature in PO patients dependent upon SIX genotype: patients homozygous for SIX risk allele (His ) have a thinner retinal nerve layer than homozygous for SIX non-risk allele (Asn ). Our results, in combination with SIX work, lead to hypothesize that SIX variants disrupt the development of retina leading to reduced retinal ganglion, thereby increasing glcoma vision loss.
Clostridium difficile is an intestinal pathogen that adheres to epithelial cells via flagella. Flagellar gene expression indirectly impacts glucosyl toxin production, which is essential for diarrheal disease. We report the identification of a “flagellar switch” that controls flagellar and glucosyl toxin production. The flag switch is a 154 bp invertible sequence flanked by 21 bp inverted repeats, located upstream of the flB operon containing early flagellar genes. Bacteria with the switch in “ON” orientation express flagellum, produce flagella, and secrete toxins. Bacteria with the switch in “OFF” orientation attenuate flagellar gene expression, areflagellate, and show decreased toxin secretion. The switch orientation is reversible in vitro. We show that flagellar regulation occurs post-transcription and requires a C difficile-specific factor to destabilize early flagellar mRNA when the switch is OFF. We also show that tyrosine recombinase RecV, which catalyzes inversion at cV, is responsible for flagellar inversion in both directions. Phase flagellar motility and toxin are important virulence factors that have both advantageous and detrimental effects during infection.
Clostridium difficile is an obligate anaerobic pathogen that produces highly resistant endospores that are central to its infectious cycle. We have studied the function and regulation of the sporulation sigma factors in C. difficile, an organism that deviates from the paradigm established in Bacillus subtilis. In C. difficile, the main periods of activity of the sigma factors are conserved, but we show that σE activity is partially independent of σ, σ activity is dependent on σ, and σ activity does not require σ. We also show that σ is not strictly required for heat resistant spore formation. Our results indicate reduced temporal segregation between the activities of the early and late sigma factors and reduced requirement for σ-to-, σ-, σ-to-, and σ-to cell signaling. In contrast to B. subtilis, σ is not strictly required for heat spore formation. We also show that σ activity is partially independent of σ. Our results support the view that the level of the sporulation network is conserved in evolution, with sigma factors acting as key regulators of the pathway established 2. 5 billion years ago at the base of the Firmicutes Phylum.
Allosteric multisite proteins are proteins that undergo conformational changes in response to phosphorylation at multiple sites. We present a framework to model the dose response of alloster multisite proteins using a single variable. This framework closely replicates the steady state behavior of multisite systems such as the Monod-Wy-Change alloster model or Hill-based models. Optimal ultrasensitivity is obtained when alloster protein activation by individual sites is concerted and redundant. This makes the framework useful for modeling and analyzing biochemical systems where multisite proteins interact. We apply this framework to a newly discovered signaling pathway in yeast that monitors cell growth by signals at the plasma membrane. We show that components of this pathway form a hysteretic switch. This system incorporates a signal proportional to growth, a mechanism to read the signal, and an-or response only when the signal reaches a threshold indicating sufficient growth has occurred.
Quorum sensing (QS) is a mechanism by which allows bacteria to communicate with each other and gain a selective advantage. While switching phenomena are common, the mechanistic underpinnings have remained elusive. We employed a combination of experimental and mathematical approaches to study the autoinducer-2 (AI-2) quorum sensing system in E. coli. coli. The network was separated into sub-networks to examine negative and positive feedback mechanisms. A new negative feedback interaction was hypothesized and tested via a simple model. The importance of the Lsr regulator and its role in the E. coli QS “switch” was revealed, normally masked by regulatory loops. Our model provided a mechanistic understanding of the interplay among substructures and their contributions to the native network.
Malaria remains a major public health problem in sub-Saharan Africa where helminthiasis are common and children are often infected with both Plasmodium falciparum and Schistosoma haematobium. The effect of helminthias on malaria infection is evident, but the impact of co-infection is not clearly elucidated and findings are conflicting. This study investigated the effect of schosiasis, soil-transmitted helth (STH) on prevalence and incidence of Plmod falciparum infection in school-age children living in rural Gabon. Thick smear microscopy, urine filtration and Kato-K technique were used to detect malaria, S haobium and STH eggs, respectively. P falcum carriage was assessed at inclusion and incidence of malaria and time to first event recorded in correlation with Schosia status. Stratified multivariate analysis was used to assess risk Plmod infection considering STH and survival to malaria. Overall prevalence at enrolment was 30% for S haobium, 23% P falcum and 9% co-infection with both parasites. Our results showed schosias increased risk of Plmod infection when combined with Trichiuris trichi or hook infection (OR = 3.9 [CI 1.7–2.9]. Malaria incidence 0.51[.45–0.57] per-year was higher in Schia-infected compared to non-infected (0.61 vs.43 p.02) with significant delay first-malaria only in children 6–10-old infected Schia.
Leishmania donovani infection induces an inflammatory response that is mainly mediated by the transcription factor IRF5. IRF-5 is responsible for the activation of genes encoding pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6 and TNF. We investigated the role of IRF-5-mediated inflammation in regulating antigen-specific CD8+ T cell responses during L. donani infection. Our data show that the inflammatory response induced by IR-5 limits CD+ T cell expansion and induces HIF-1 in dendritic cells. Deletion of HIF-1 in dendritic cells resulted in a higher frequency of short-lived effector cells ( SLEC ) CD+ T expansion and increased IL-12 expression by splenic dendritic cells. Moreover, mice with deletion of H-1 in dendritic cells had a lower splenic parasite burden, suggesting that induction of H-1 may represent an immune evasion mechanism adopted by Leish parasites to establish persistent infections.
American visceral leishmanias (VL) is associated with high fatality rates in Latin America. This systematic review aims to identify prognostic factors for patients at risk of unfavorable outcomes. We analyzed 14 studies conducted in Latin America to identify predictors of adverse evolution despite treatment and death. We examined methodological quality using a tool and synthesized prognostic variables using meta-analysis. Variables were grouped by strength of evidence, heterogeneity, and multivariate analyses. The strongest predictors were jaundice, thrombocytopenia, hemorrhage, HIV coinfection, diarrhea, age <5 and >40 years, neutropenia, dyspnea, and bacterial infections. Edema and low hemoglobin were also associated with unfavorable outcomes.
During the last 30 years, the treatment of visceral and cutaneous leishmaniasis ( VL and CL ) in Algeria has been based on antimonial drugs. It is suspected that high drug pressure might favor the emergence of chemoresistant parasites. Although treatment failure is frequently reported during antimonial therapy of both CL and VL, antimonial resistance has never been investigated in Algeria. We determined the level of antimonial susceptibility amongst Leishmania in Algeria. We analyzed 106 isolates including 88 collected between 1976 and 2013 in Algeria from humans, dogs, rodents, and phleomines and 18 from dogs in France. All Algerian isolates were collected in 14 localities leishiasis endemic. We determined the 50 inhibitory concentrations ( IC ) of antimony tarate ( Sb III ) and sodium stibogluconate ( Sb ) in promastigotes and intramacroph amastigotes, respectively. The epidemiological cutoff allowed to differentiate Leish species causing CL or VL that were susceptible ( ) or insusceptible ( ) to Sb III. The IC values were 23. 83 μg/mL and 15. 91g for VL and CL, respectively. We report a trend of Sb in VL isolates during the period. In contrast, an increase in frequency of isolates causing CL was observed during the same period. Our results provide insight into spatiemporal of Leish Sb in Algeria.
Crohn’s disease (CD) is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease with a complex etiology. Infection with foodborne pathogens causing acute gastroenteritis increases the risk of developing CD in the post-infectious period, but the mechanisms underlying this relationship are unknown. We developed two models to study the comorbidity of acute gastroenteritis caused by Salmonella Typhimurium or Citrobacterium in mice colonized with adherent-invasive Escherichia coli (AIEC), a bacterial pathogen linked to CD. We show that disease activity in the post-infect period after gastroenteritis is driven by the tissue expansion of the AIE pathogen, accompanied by an increase in immunopathology defects, barrier defects, and mucosal restitution delays following pathogen clearance. These features require AIE resistance to host defense peptides and amin inflammatory response to enteric pathogen. Our results suggest that individuals colonized by AIE at the time of infectious gastroenter may be at risk for CD. Importantly, we identify AIE as a tractable disease modifier, a finding that could be exploited in the development of interventions following infectious gastroenter in at-risk individuals.
In flowering plants, the female gametophyte of Arabidopsis consists of two gametic cells, the egg and central cell, which are flanked by five accessory cells. Both gametic and accessory cells are essential for fertilization. However, the mechanisms that underlie the formation of accessory versus gametic cell fate are unknown. In a screen for regulators of egg cell fate, we isolated the lach ( lis ) mutant which forms supernumerary egg cells. In lis mutants, accessory cells differentiate into gametic cells, indicating that LIS is involved in a mechanism that prevents accessory cells from adopting gametic fate. LIS is expressed in gametic cells and is homologous to yeast splicing factor PR4, suggesting that components of the splice apparatus participate in cell fate decisions.
Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) are a major public health problem in rural Ethiopia. The role of footwear in protecting against NTDs is gaining attention, but little is known about the factors that influence its use. We used the PRECE-DE-PROCEED model to assess the social, behavioral, educational, and ecological factors that influence whether children wear shoes in a highland Ethiopian community endemic for podoiosis. We gathered information from 242 respondents using focus groups, semi-structured interviews and case studies. We found that shoe-wearing is changing, with going barefoot increasingly seen as shameful. Shoes are thought to confer dignity as well as protection against injury and cold. However, practical and social barriers prevent the desire to wear from being translated into practice. Limited resources mean people are unable to purchase more than one pair of shoes to ensure longevity or afford of quality. As a result, shoes are preserved for special occasions and not provided for children until they reach a certain age. While some barriers ( e. g. fit, fear of labeling of certain shoe type ) may be specific to certain diseases, underlying barriers related to poverty ( e. g. price, unsuitability for daily activities, low perception ) are likely relevant to a range of NTDs. We identified several barriers to shoe-wearing amenable to intervention that will benefit those considering NTD prevention through shoe distribution.
Pseudorabies virus (PRV) is a neurotrophic alphaherpesvirus that replicates in the nervous system. The Us9 protein plays a central role in targeting viral glycoproteins to axons of infected sympathetic neurons. However, it is unclear how Us promotes axonal sorting of viral proteins. In this report, we show that Us is associated with lipid rafts and this association is critical for Us-mediated sorting of structural proteins. We used polarized PC12 cells, a ratheochromocytoma line that acquires characteristics of sympathetic neurons in presence of nerve growth factor (NGF). In these cells, Us is enriched in detergent-resistant membranes (DRMs). Moreover, reducing Us affinity for lipid rafts inhibited anterog transmission from neurons to epithelial cells in vitro.
In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, a form of nongenic heterogeneity in growth rate correlates with susceptibility to acute heat stress at the single-cell level. We show that heterogeneity in intracellular cyclic AMP ( cAMP ) levels through the conserved Ras/cAMP/protein A ( PK ) pathway and its transcription factors M2 and M4 underlies thisongenic heterogeneity. Lower cAMP levels correspond to slower growth, as shown by direct comparison of cAMP in subpopulations enriched for slower vs faster cells. An endogenous reporter of this pathway’s activity correlates with growth in cells. The paralogues M2 and M4 differ inongenic heterogeneity in a way that demonstrates slow growth and stress are not linked. Heterogeneity in rate requires M4, whereas M2 is required forenic heterogeneity of T1, a subunit trehalose synth that contributes to acute-stress. Perturbingongenic heterogeneity by mutating in this pathway or culturing wild-type with cell-perable cAMP 8romoAMP or PK inhibitor H89 significantly impacts acute stress.
Chikungunya virus (CHV) is an alphavirus of the Togaviridae family that causes severe febrile disease in humans. In December 2013, the Asian lineage of CHV spread from the Old World to the Americas, rapidly spreading throughout the New World. To understand how CHV may have evolved during this outbreak, we studied the genetic diversity present in infected individuals in Guadeloupe and Martinique, two islands in the center of the epidemic. We used deep-sequencing and bioinformatics to characterize the variants present in CHV infected individuals. We observed changes in the consensus sequence as well as a range of minority variants at various levels in the population. Furthermore, diversity was dramatically reduced after single passages in cell lines. We constructed an infectious clone from this outbreak and identified a novel 3’ untranslated region ( UTR ) structure not found in nature that led to increased replication in cells. We performed intrahostasis analysis of the new CHV outbreak in the Caribbean. We identified variants present in individuals as well as new 3UTR structure suggesting CHV has evolved in short time once entered naïve population.
UOR is a previously unannotated gene that regulates cell growth and mTOR signaling. We show that UOR depletion promotes neurite outgrowth in cultured hippocampal neurons and PC12 cells by activating mTOR signaling and promoting cell growth. In contrast, UOR overexpression suppresses colony formation in cancer cell lines. We also show that UOR inhibits mTOR signaling by stabilizing the mTOR component DEOR in cultured cells and zebraf, and that UOR depletion results in higher mTOR activity and aggravates HRAS (12 ) induced neoplas in zraf. Furthermore, UOR promotes tumor growth and mTOR signaling in a xenraft mouse model.
Trypanosoma bruce, the protozoan parasite responsible for human African trypanosomias, is poorly understood in terms of its biology and pathogenesis due to the unknown functions of the majority of its proteins. Here, we present a global map of protein-protein interactions in the procyclic life stage of T. brucei. Using biochemical fractionation, we identified 128 high-confidence complexes encompassing 716 protein groups, including 635 previously uncharacterized proteins. These complexes correlate with known pathways and coexpressed proteins across the T. bri life cycle, providing potential functions for a large number of uncharacterized proteins. We validated functions of novel proteins associated with RNA-editing machinery, identifying a candidate involved in post-transcriptional regulation of T. bruce. Our results provide an unprecedented view of the protein map of T. bruce and serve as a resource for further characterization of tryosid proteins.
Lymph nodes are among the most common sites of extrapulmonary Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection in humans, and thoracic LNs are frequently infected. However, the dynamics of Mtb infection in LN and its effect on LN structure and function are relatively unstudied. We analyzed thoracic LNs from M-infected cynolgus rhes macques using PET scans, bacterial burden, LN structure, and immune function. FDG avidity correlated with presence of bacteria in LNs at necropsy. We show that LNs have different trajectories ( increasing, decreasing in activity over time ) even within same animal. Rhes macques are more susceptible to M infection than cynolg macques due to extensive LN pathology. Mtb grows to same level in cynolg and rhes mac LNs, however cynolg mac control Mtb later post-infection while rhes do not. Notably, compared to granulomas, LNs are poor at killing M, even with treatment. Granulomas in L lack B-rich structures, disrupt LN by pushing T and B cells, introduce macrophages that serve M niches, destroy vasculature. Our data show L are not only sites of antigen and immune activation during infection, but also important for persistence of M bacilli.
Microsporidia are a group of intracellular pathogens that infect a wide range of animals, but are poorly understood. The nematode Caenorhabis elegans has been used as a model to study microidia through the identification of its natural pathogen Nematida paris. However, it was unclear how widespread and diverse microidia are in C. elegans and other nematodes in the wild. Here we describe the isolation and culture of 47 nematodes with microidian infections. Nematida was found to be the most common microidian infecting C elegans in the wild. In addition, we describe six new species in the Nematida genus. Our phylogenetic analysis identify two subclades distinct from Nematida and name them Enteropra and Ptospora. Unlike Nemat, these genera belong to the clade of microidia that includes human pathogens. All microidia are horizontally transmitted and specifically infect intestinal cells, except Ptos that replicates mostly in epidermis of C elegans host.
Chemokine receptors are a subclass of G-protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) that play important roles in the human immune system and are involved in cancer metastasis as well as HIV infection. A number of studies have shown that homo- and heterodimers of the chemokine receptors CXCR4, CCR5, and CCR modulate receptor function. In addition, membrane affects chemine receptor activity. Here, we report homo and heterodimer configurations of the chemine receptors CXCR, C5 and C2 at atomic detail, obtained from molecular simulations. The homodimer patterns were similar for closely related chemine receptors, yet differed between the receptors CX4. Despite high identity, modulated the homimer in a subtype manner. Chemine heterodimers display dimer patterns for CX4/5 and CX4/2. Furthermore, between CX and C5 reveal increased compared to CX/2 heterodimer patterns.
Systemic leishmaniasis is a disease known to present with fever, hepatosplenomegaly and wasting. In addition to the classical form, a sub-clinical form has been identified with one or two of the above symptoms missing and other findings such as lymphadenopathy and anemia. We report a third form which we refer to as “atypical”. Patients suspected to be immune-deficient were referred to immunology laboratory to study aspects of immune functions not covered in general. Multiple tests were performed including microscopic examinations and cultures of biopsies on specialized media. 19.4% of 160 patients had normal laboratory profiles but macrophages laden Leish parasites. Findings allowed us to uncover atypical systemic leishias. It presents with masquerading condition in which immune is non functional. This predisposes patients to recurrent infections with clinical signs and symptoms. Findings alert us that leishias presents wider spectrum than suspected and more common than diagnosed. Among 31 patients was number of adults. This proves that leishias not limited to pediatric group. We recommend diagnosis atypical leish in patient with unexplained immunity and no obvious immunologic defect.
Genome-wide analysis of human disease-causing alleles reveals that their locations are correlated in paralogous proteins. Millions of mutations and polymorphisms occur in human populations are potential predictors of disease, reactions to drugs, predisposition to infections, and age-related conditions such as impaired brain and cardiovascular functions. However, predicting the phenotypic consequences and clinical significance of a variant is not an easy. Computational approaches have found perturbation conserved amino acids to be useful for identifying likely variants with phenotyp consequences. We have assembled a collection of known disease-causing variants from OMIM and Human Mutation Database ( HG ) and identified pairs of variants that occur homologous within paralog human proteins. Our analyses demonstrate that locations are correlated in paralog proteins. Moreover, if one member of a variant-pair is disease-causing, its partner is likely disease-causing as well. Thus, variantairs can be used to identify disease-causing, extend procedures for prioritization and provide candidates for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes.
Malaria is caused by the parasite Plasmodium falcum is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in tropical regions. The parasite is exposed to multiple pressures within the human host, but the extent to which it responds or is selected by this environment is unclear. Previous studies have shown that parasites causing severe malaria have increased expression of a subset of PfEMP1 variant antigens, which are major targets of protective immunity. Here, we used RNA sequencing ( RNAseq ) to study gene expression in 44 isolates causing severe and uncomplicated malaria in Papua New Guine patients. We found that the transcriptomes of parasites causing severe malaria had decreased glycolysis without activation of compensatory pathways; altered chromatin structure and transcriptional regulation through histone methylation; reduced Pf1 surface expression; and downregulated multiple chaperone proteins. We also identified novel associations between disease and Pf1 transcripts, domains and smaller segments and confirmed previously reported associations between Pf1 sequences and disease. These findings will inform efforts to identify targets for severe malaria and indicate how parasites adapt or are selected by the environment in severe malaria.
Long-term delivery of broadly neutralizing antibodies is a promising approach for the prevention of HIV-1 infection. In this study, we used an adeno-associated virus (AAV) vector to intramuscularly deliver anti-SIV monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) in IgG form to rhesus monkeys. We achieved persisting levels of delivered mAb as high as 270 μg/ml. However, host responses to the delivered antibody were observed in 9 of the 12 monkeys and appeared to limit the concentration of delivered antibody that could be achieved. This is reflected in the range of delivered mAb that were achieved: 1–270g. Following repeated, dose intravenous challenge with the difficult-to-neutralize SIVmac, the six in the AAV-Ig1 m group showed protective effects despite absence of detectable neutralizing activity against the virus. The effects included lowering of viral load at peak; lowering of load at point; delay in time to peak load from time of the virus exposure. All were statistically significant. In addition, the with the highest level of m completely resisted successive SIVmac i. challenges, including final with dose i. units.
Proteins are traditionally assumed to respond linearly to thermal or structural perturbations, such as ligand binding or detachment. Conformational motions in proteins are analyzed in terms of normal modes and thermal fluctuations in macromolecules are interpreted as excitation of normal modes. However, we have found that the linearity is deficient for lig-induced conformation motions and even for thermal fluctuations. The deficiency is pronounced in KIF1 where normal description fails to describe mechanochemical motions.
Caveolins and Caveolae Regulate Clathrin-Independent Endocytosis: A Novel Mechanisms of Crosstalk between Endocytic Pathways  
Caveolins and caveolins are crucial components of caveolae, microdomains that also constitute an endoc route. Here we show that specific caveolar proteins are negative regulators of clath-independent endocyt. Cavin-1 and Cavin-3, but not Cavin-2 or Cavin-4, inhibit the clath-independent/GPIAP enriched endosomal (CL/GEE ) endytic pathway in a process independent of cave formation. Caveolin-1 (C1) and Cavin-3 also inhibit CL/GEE upon overexpression. Expression of caveolar leads to reduction of CL/GEE carriers as detected by quantitative microscopy. The CLEE pathway is upregulated in cells lacking Cavin-1/Cavin or reduced Cavin-3. Inhibition by caveins can be mimicked by isolated caveolin scaffolding and perturbed diffusion of lipid components as revealed by fluorescence after photobleaching (FRAP). In absence of caveins and caveol C1 is endocyted through CLEE but loses polarization and sorting with consequences for membrane and endytic in migrating cells and tissue.
Aspartate-Less Receiver (AL) Domains: Distribution, Structure, and Function. Two-component signaling systems are ubiquitous in bacteria and Archaea and play important roles in sensing and responding to environmental stimuli. To propagate a signaling, a typical system employs a histidine kinase that phosphorylates a Receiver (REC) domain on a conserved aspartate (Asp) residue. We have compiled all REC domains missing this residue, renamed aspartate-Less (AL) domains. Our data show AL are common and enriched when attached to rare effector outputs. Analysis of informatics and AL structures, combined with biochemical and genetic data of AL archetype Rit from Streptococcus pneumonia, suggest AL have reorganized active pockets to take constitutive role or accommodate signals other than phosphorylation, while retaining post-phosphorylation mechanisms and dimer interface.
Herpes simplex viruses (HSVs) are a type of oncolytic virus that have shown efficacy in clinical trials. Most of them are attenuated by deletions/mutations that counteract the host response and selectively grow in cancer cells defective in anti-viral response. We developed next-generation HSVs that carry no deletions/mutations and are specific to tumor receptors, e. g. HER2 ( human epidermal growth factor 2 )—are fully virulent in cancer cells. We report the first study of HER2-retargeted, fullyirulent HSVs in immunocompet mice. Both unarmed and IL-12-armed HS inhibited the growth of HER2-Lewis lung carcinoma-1 ( HER-LL1 ) tumor, with IL-12 being more efficacious. All mice that did not die of primary tumors were protected from growth of contralateral tumors. Long-term survivors were protected from secondal tumor, providing evidence of absc immunotherapeutic effect.
Vaccine-induced CD4 T cells have been shown to be susceptible to HIV infection, raising concerns about the safety of adenovirus (Ad)-based HIV vaccines. We investigated the susceptibility of Ad5-specific CD4 cells from the RV144 trial and ALV-specific CD4 cells from the RV144 trial. While Ad5-specific CD4 cells were readily infected by HIV, ALV-specific CD4 cells were less susceptible to both R5 and X4 HIV in vitro. The lower susceptibility of ALV-specific CD4 cells was associated with reduced expression of HIV co-receptors CCR5 and CXCR4. Phenotypically, ALV-specific CD4 cells displayed a Th1 phenotype with higher IFNγ and CCL4 (M-β) but little IL-17. ALV and Ad vectors induced distinct profiles of vector-specific CD8 vs CD4 T-cell proliferative responses in PBMC, with ALV inducing CD8 proliferation and Ad CD4. Depletion of AL-specific CD8 cells in PB led to a modest increase in HIV infection of AL-specific CD4 cells, suggesting a role of AL-specific CD8 cells in protecting AL-specific CD4 cells from HIV.
X-chromosome inactivation is a universal among therian mammals, where one X chromosome is transcriptionally silenced in each female somatic cell. However, the choice of which X chromosome to silence varies among species. X-chromosome inactivation strategies range from paternal X inactivation (PX), which renders females haploid for paternal alleles, to random X inactivation (RX), equalizing maternal and paternal allele expression in each tissue. We present a population genetic analysis of X inactivation evolution, considering conditions of dominance, linkage, recombination, and sex-differential selection. Our results indicate a critical interaction between allelic dominance and sexifferential can select a broad range of inactivation strategies, including unequal rates between maternal and paternal X-chromosomes. RX is favored over PX as long alleles deleterious to females are recessive, and criteria for RX evolution is more restrictive when variation is sexually antagonistic. Evolution from PX to RX generally increases female fitness at expense of male.
ZAP is a host protein that restricts the infection of many viruses by degrading viral RNA, inhibiting translation, and inducing innate immune responses. So far, only yellow fever virus has been reported to be ZAP-resistant. Here, we investigated the antiviral potential of human ZAP isoforms Z-L and Z-S against flaviviruses Japanese encephalitis (JEV), dengue (DENV) and Zika (ZIK). We found that Z overexpression of Z blocked JEV but not DENV or ZIK infection, and depletion of endogenous Z enhanced JEV replication. Z hampered JEV translation and targeted viral RNA for 3′-5′ exosome degradation. The zincinger motifs of Z were essential for RNA targeting and anti-JEV activity. JEV 3′-UTR, especially the region with dumbbell structures and high content of dinucleotide, was mapped to Z and confer sensitivity to Z. We identified JEV as the first Z-sensitive flavivirus. Z may act as intrinsic antiv factor through RNA binding against J infection.
Rift Valley fever virus (RVV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes severe hemorrhagic fever and encephalitis in humans and animals. It is endemic in Africa and the Arabian Peninsula, but has the potential to be introduced into non-endemic regions with devastating effects on livestock and concurrent human infections. We investigated the host response to infection with wild-type Z501 and vaccine strain MP12 in C57BL/6 mice. Mice infected with live-attenuated MP12 survived productive infection with minimal disease and cytokine response in tissues. In contrast, Z501 infection was lethal with lymphocyte and platelet depletion and a strong systemic cytokine response correlating with high virus titers and tissue pathology. Lymphopenia and platelet depletion indicated disease onset with lymphocyte recovery correlating with G-CS production. RVV is hepatotropic with significant clinical and histological data supporting these findings; however, a significant pro-inflammatory response in the liver was not apparent. Rather, infection resulted in chemokine response with neutrophil infiltration supported by histological data. In brains of Z501 infected mice, chemine and pro-inflammatory response was evident with little pathology. These data suggest that RVV pathogenesis in mice is associated with liver function loss due to necrosis and hepatitis and long-term disease is neurologic in nature supported by human and BAL/c mouse observations.
Chemoresistance in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a major obstacle to improving patient survival. Chemoresistance mechanisms in TNBC are not well understood. Our results show that C motif chemokine ligand 20 (C20 ) is significantly elevated during taxane-containing chemotherapy in TNBC patients with no pathologic complete response. C20 promotes self-renewal and maintenance of breast cancer stem cells (BCs) or cancer stem cells through protein Cζ (PK ) or 38 mitogen-activated protein (MAP )-mediated p65 nuclear factor B (NF- ) activation, increasing tax resistance of BCs. Moreover,20 promotes NF activation ATP-binding subfamily member 1 (ABCB1)/multidrug 1 (DR ) expression, leading to extracellular efflux of taxanes. These results suggest chemotherapy-induced20 mediated chemores via upregulation of CB1. In addition, NF activation20 increases20, forming positive feedback between NF and20 pathways which sustains chemores in cancer cells. Our results suggest20 can be novel marker for taxane response and blockade of20 or downstream might reverse tax resistance in breast patients.
Toxoplas gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that infects virtually all nucleated cells in warm-blooded animals. The ability of Toxoplas tachzoites to infect and manipulate its host is dependent on its ability to transport GRA proteins from unique secretory organelles called dense granules into the host cell. These proteins have diverse roles in Tooplas’s intracellular lifecycle, including co-opting host functions such as cell cycle and p38 MAP kinase. Some GRAs, such as GRA16 and GRA24, are secreted into the parasitoph vacuole ( PV ) where Tooplas replicates and transported across the PV membrane ( PVM ) into host. However, the translocation process and machinery are not well understood. We previously showed that TMY1, cleaved by T5 into two fragments, localizes to PVM and is essential for GRA transport into host. To identify additional proteins necessary for effector transport, we screened Tooplas mutants in c-M upregulation for ability to export GRA and GRA to host. Here we report that MY2 and MY3 play crucial role in translocation of subset GR into host. MY and MY are secreted into PV and co-localize with PVM. Consistent with predicted transmembrane domains, all are membrane-associated and MY3 but MY stably with MY1 whose N and C-terminal are disulf-linked. We show that intrinsically disordered effectors to structured DH domain blocks transport consistent with translo-based model effector.
Human papillomavirus (HPV) and bovine papillomavirus (BPV-1) E2 proteins bind to the origin recognition complex (ORC) component ORC2. However, OR2 is not detected at the viral origin. Depletion of OR2 enhances PV replication in a transient replication model in keratinocytes and maintains viral episomes, while there is no effect on copy number in a line with integrated HPV genomes. Consistent with this, occupancy of E1 and E at the origin increases following OR2 silencing. These data imply that OR2 is not necessary for activation of the origin by E and E but instead suppresses replicative function. Furthermore, we observed that over-expression of HPV2 decreases OR2 at known mammalian origins of replication, suggesting that restricts pre-OR assembly that otherwise competes for host complexes necessary for viral amplification. We infer that OR2 with E restricts viral in the maintenance phase of the program and elevated levels that during differentiation subvert OR loading and synthesis at cellular origins.
Brucellos is one of the most common zoonoses globally, and Central Asia remains a Bruc hotspot. The World Health Organization classifies bruclos as a neglected zoonotic that is rarely in the spotlight for research and mainly affects poor, marginalized people. This study investigates the presence of Bruc DNA in bovine milk in the urban and periurban area of Dush, Tajikistan. Bruc DNA was detected in 10. 3% of 564 cow samples by IS-based real-time PCR. This is concerning because consumption of unpasteurified dairy products is common in the region. Furthermore, Bruc DNA was detected in the milk of seropositive cows, but 8.3% of seronegative cows also showed Bruc DNA. In addition, analysis of the rB gene suggests one cow was infected with B. abortus and another was likely infected B. melensis.
Chromosome and genome stability are crucial for normal cell function, and their instability often correlates with disease and dysfunction of DNA repair mechanisms. The pathogenic fungus Zoseptoria trici has eight accessory chromosomes that are highly unstable during meiosis and mitosis, transcriptionally repressed, and enriched with repetitive elements and heterochromatin marks, e. g. trimethylation of H3 lysine 9 and 27 ( H3K9me3, H3me27 ). To elucidate the role of heterochatin on genome stability in Z. trici, we deleted genes encoding methyltransferases responsible for H3me and Hme, k1 and k6, respectively, and generated a double mutant. We used experimental and genomic analyses to determine the impact of deletions on chromosome and genome stability in vitro and in planta. Whole genome sequencing, ChIP-seq, and RNA-seq were used to compare changes in genome and chromatin structure and differences in expression between mutant and wildtype strains. Analyses of genome and ChIP data in H9-deficient strains revealed dramatic chromatin reorganization where Hme is mostly localized in regions enriched in wildtype. Many rearrangements and formation of new chromosomes were found in absence H9, accompanied by activation of transposable elements. In contrast, loss increased stability of chromosomes under normal conditions in vitro without large changes in expression. We conclude H9 is important for maintenance because it disallows Hme in constitutive heterochatin. This reduces overall stability of, generating “metastable” for quasiessential regions.
Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is an essential for preventing the onset of rabies in individuals exposed to the virus. Unfortunately, life-saving rabies vaccines and biologicals are often inaccessible and unaffordable, particularly to the poorest sectors of society who are most at risk and bear the largest burden of rabies. We analyzed different P vaccination regimens and evaluated their relative costs and benefits for victims and healthcare providers. We found P to be an extremely cost-effective intervention ( $200 less than $60/death averted ). Switching from intramuscular (IM) to equally efficacious intradermal (ID) regimens resulted in significant savings in vaccine volume required to treat the same number of patients, mitigating shortages and reducing costs of P. We present mechanisms to make P more affordable and accessible, subsidize cost for those in need, and support new and existing rabies prevention programs.
Toxoplas gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite that replicates in mammalian cells within a parasitophorous vacuole (PV) that does not fuse with host organelles. One of the parasite’s mechanisms for nutrient acquisition is the attraction of host organelles to the PV. Here, we show that Toxoplas exploits host lipid droplets (LD), ubiquitous fat organelles, for nutrient acquisition. Toxoplas replication is reduced in host cells depleted of LD or impaired in lipolysis or fatty acidolysis. In infected cells, the number of host LD and expression of LD-associated genes (ADRP, DG2) increase until onset of parasite replication. Throughout infection, PV are surrounded by LD. Toxoplas accesses lipids in LD and incorporates them into its membranes and LD. Exogenous oleic acid stimulates LDogenesis in host and results in accumulation of lipids in large LD inside parasite. To access LD-derived lipids, Tooplas intercepts and internalizes LD within PV, some associated with Rab7, wrapped by intravacolar network (IV). Mutant parasites impaired IV display diminished lipid uptake from LD. Moreover, parasites lacking IV-localized phospholipase2 are less proficient in salvaging lipids from LD in PV.
The liver flukes Fasciola hepatica and Fasciola gigantica cause fasciolosis, an emerging zoonotic disease of cattle and sheep. Chemotherapy is the main control measure and tricendazole is the preferred drug since it is effective against both juvenile and mature parasites. However, resistance to tricendazole has been reported in several countries, prompting the search for new chemical entities to control fluke infections. We screened a library of flavonoid derivatives for inhibitors of Fasciola hepatica cyste proteases Fh3 and Fh1. Chalcones with phenyl and naphthyl groups emerged as good cathein inhibitors, interacting with two putative sites within the active site of the enzymes. One compound C34 binds juvenile Fh3 with an IC50 of 5. 6 μM. C34 is a slow-reversible inhibitor that interacts with Cys catalytic dy and S2 S3 residues, determinants of substrate specificity of this cystine protease family. C induces reduction in ability to migrate through gut and loss of motility leading to death in vitro, while not cytotoxic to bovine cells.
Visual information about fast and slow changes in light intensity is transmitted through the retina by separate neural pathways. We used in vivo imaging to investigate how bipolar cells transmit these signals to the inner retina. We found that the volume of the synaptic terminal is an intrinsic property that contributes to different temporal filtering. Individual cells transmit through terminals of varying size, but smaller terminals generate faster and larger calcium transients to trigger vesicle release with higher gain, followed by more adaptation. Larger terminals transmitted lower frequencies more effectively. Modeling calcium dynamics triggering vesicle release indicated that variations in volume of presynaptic compartments directly contribute to these differences in response.
Fluorescence microscopy (FM) and electron microscopy (EM) are used to study the brain’s vast synaptic networks, but each has limitations. FM offers high speed and low cost, but discrimination between synaptic and non-synaptic signals is challenging. In contrast, EM is reliable for synapse identification, but offers limited molecular discrimination and is slow and costly. To overcome these limitations, we developed a novel probabilistic method to detect synapses from multiplex FM (mux) data. We used datasets from correlative array tomography (cAT), which provides voxel-conjugate FM and EM images of the same synapses. Our method accepts molecular-morphological synapse models as queries and delivers a volumetric map of the probability that each voxel is part of a syn. We show that our algorithm detects synapses from mux data as well as human annotators seeing only mux, and reproduces known features of cortical syn distributions.
Zinc is a trace element that is essential for the proper functioning of approximately 3, 000 proteins. It is required for physiological processes such as nucleic acid metabolism, gene regulation, signal transduction, cell division, immune and nervous functions, and wound healing. Impairment of zinc homeostasis results in various pathologies. In mammals, zinc transport occurs via two transporter families, ZnT and ZIP. However, the mechanism of action of ZnT, responsible for vesicular zinc accumulation and secretion into milk during lactation, is unknown. Here we modeled the mechanism of action of ZnT computationally and experimentally, using zinc transport assays. We show that ZnT is a proton-coupled zinc antiporter. Bafilomycin A, a specific inhibitor of vacuolar ATPase, abolished Zn-dependent transport into intracellular vesicles. Using Lyso Red and Ly-pfluorin, we show that upon ZnT overexpression in intracellular vesicles and addition of exogenous zinc, vesicles underwent alkalization due to proton-zinc antiport. This was reversed in the presence of TP, a specific chelator. We propose that Zn functions as an antiporter with a stoichiometry 2+/Zn+. Hence, Zn is a motive-driven, electrutral ves zinc exchanger, concentrating zinc in vesicles on expense of proton to cytoplasm.
Replication fork integrity is essential for maintaining genome stability and is monitored by checkpoint-mediated phosphorylation events. 14-3 proteins are able to bind phosphorylated proteins and have been shown to play a role in DNA replication stress. Exonuclease 1 ( Exo ) processes stalled forks in checkpoint-defective yeast cells. Here, we identify 14-3 proteins as in vivo interaction partners of Exo, in yeast and mammalian cells. Yeast 3–deficient cells fail to induce Mec–dependent Exo hyperphosphorylation and accumulateo–dependent ssDNA gaps at forks, as revealed by electron microscopy. This leads to persistent checkpoint activation and recovery defects. Moreover, we show that 3 proteins promote progression under limiting nucleotide concentrations using DNA electrophoresis. We propose that 3 proteins assist in phosphorylation of Exo and additional targets, promoting fork stability and restart in response to replication stress.
Plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDC) play a complex role in the pathogenesis of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV) infection. In a humanized mouse model, HIV infection leads to persistent infection and immunopathogenesis, including induction of type I interferons (IFN), immune activation and depletion of leukocytes, including CD4 T cells. We developed a monoclonal antibody that depletes pDC in lymphoid organs of humanized mice. When p were depleted prior to HIV infection, induction of IF and interferon-stimulated genes (ISGs) were abolished during acute HIV infection with either a highly pathogenic CCR/CX4-tropic HIV or standard C5ropic HIV isolate. Consistent with anti-viral role of IF, HIV replication was upregulated in p-depleted mice. Interestingly, cell death induced by highly pathogenic HIV was reduced in p-de mice. During chronic HIV infection, depletion p also reduced induction of IF and IS, with elevated HIV replication. Surprisingly, HIV depletion of human cells in lymphoid, not blood, was reduced despite increased replication. The number in lymphoid was associated with reduced HIV-induced death human leukocytes including CD cells. We conclude p play opposing roles in suppressing HIV replication and promoting immunogenesis.
Sulforaphane (SF) Inhibits HIV Infection of Macrophages through Nrf2 Activation  
Sulforane (SF) is a compound found in cruciferous vegetables that mobilizes nuclear erythroid 2-related factor 2 (Nrf2) to reprogram cellular gene expression. Here we show that SF blocks HIV infection in primary macrophages but not in primary T cells. SF also blocks infection in PMA-differentiated promocytic cell lines but not in other cell lines. siRNA-mediated depletion of Nrf boosted HIV infectivity in macrophages and reduced anti-viral effects of SF treatment. This supports a model in which anti-viral activity is mediated through Nrf after is mobilized by SF. SF blocks infection after entry but before formation of 2-L circles. Neither SAM1 nor MX were upregulated.
Ascaris lumbricoid, hookworm, and Trichuris trichi are common geohelth infections among pregnant women in rural western Kenya. In a community-based cross-sectional study, 390 pregnant women were interviewed and asked to provide blood and fecal samples. Among them, 76. 2% were infected with at least one geelth, 52.3 with Ascaris lumicoid, 39.5 with hookworm, and 29. with Trichuris trichi. Infection with at least geel was associated with use of unprotected water source (OR 1.8, 95% CI 1.–.3 ) and lack of water treatment (OR 1.8, 95 CI.–.1 ). Geelth infections were not associated with clinical symptoms or body mass index. Hook infection was associated with lower upper arm circumference (mean 0.7,95 CI.–.2 ). Hook infection with egg count ≥100/gram was associated lower hemoglobin (mean 1.5,95.–. ) Among gravid 2 and 3, Ascaris lumicoid was less likely to have malaria (OR 0.,95.–. ) compared to others.
Mycolone is a macrolide produced by the pathogen Mycobacterium ulcerans with anti-inflammatory, analgesic, and immunomodulatory properties. Here we investigated whether mycolone affects the inflammatory responses of nervous cell subsets involved in pain perception and transmission. We also investigated the effects of mycol on neuroinflammation associated with chronic pain in vivo. We isolated sensory neurons, Schwann cells and microglia from mice for ex vivo assessment of myone cytotoxicity and immunomod activity by measuring production of pro-inflammatory cytokines and chemokines. Myone induced cell death at concentrations >10ng/ml within 48h, but suppressed production of pro-inflammatory mediators at nanomolar concentrations without affecting viability. Myone prevented pro-inflammatory polarization of microglia, which contribute to neuroinflammation. We tested myone impact on this process in vivo using a rat model of neuropathic pain induced by sciatic nerve constriction. Myone was injected daily in the spinal canal for 3 days. This failed to prevent injury-induced neuroflamm but decreased local production of inflammatory cytokines without cytotoxicity.
African trypanosomias (AT) is a lethal disease caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambense that has a range of clinical outcomes in its human host in West Africa. In order to test if this diversity is influenced by host genetic determinants, the association between candidate gene polymorphisms and AT was investigated in populations from AT foci in Guinea. Samples were collected from 425 individuals, comprising 232 AT cases, 79 subjects with lasting positive specific serology but negative parasitology and 114 endemic controls. Genotypes of 28 SNPs in eight genes passed quality control were used for association analysis. We found that IL6 rs1819 allele was associated with lower risk of progressing from latent to active disease (p = 0.000, OR = 0.39, CI [.24–.63, BF 0.003 ). MIF36071 allele was associated with increased risk (p = 0.023, OR 1.65, CI [1.–2.53, BF 0.669 ) but did not remain after Bonferr correction. MIF459 allele was associated with latent infections ( =.007, OR 1.86 CI [.–.95, BF.215 ). We confirmed earlier observations that AP1 G allele ( ) was associated with higher risk and AP1 polymorphism with lower of developing AT. No associations were found with other genes. Our data show that genes are involved in modulating Tryosoma bruce gambense infection in individuals from Guinea.
The genetic diversity of South Asians is considerable due to differences in culture and language. Previous studies on the genetic structure of Indians have mostly relied on microarray genotyping or targeted sequencing of mitochondria and Y chromosomes. In this study, 38 individuals from the Singapore Indian population underwent whole-genome sequencing with a coverage of 30X as part of the Singapore Sequencing Indian Project ( SSIP ). The genetic diversity of these samples was compared against samples from the Sequencing Malay Project and Phase 1 of the 1, 000 Genomes Project ( KGP ). The SS samples exhibited greater intra-population genetic diversity and higher heterozygous-to-homozyous genotype than other Asian populations. When compared to a panel of well-defined Indians, the genetic of SS samples was closely related to South Indians. However, the SS samples clustered distinctly from Europeans in global structure with autosomal SNPs. Eight samples were assigned to mitochondrial haplogroups predominantly present in Europeans and had higher European admixture than remaining samples. Analysis of relatedness between SS and archaic homins ( Denis, Neander ) identified higher admixture in East populations than SS.
Burkholderia pseudomallei is an intrinsically resistant to aminoglycosides and macrolides due to the expression of the AmrAB-OA efflux pump. We investigated the molecular basis of aminoglyide susceptibility in Thai clinical isolates 708, 218a, and 379a. Quantitative reverse transcription PCR ( qRT-PCR ) revealed the absence of amr transcripts in 708 and greatly reduced levels in 218 and 379. Serial passage on increasing gentamicin concentrations yielded 218 and 379 mutants that became simultaneously resistant to aminoglyides and macrolides, whereas mutants could not be obtained with 708. Transcript analysis showed the resistance of 218 and 379 mutants was due to upregulation of amr-opA expression by unknown mechanisms. Use of PCR walking revealed the amr-opA operon was missing in 708 and this was associated with deletion of more than 70 kb genetic material. Rescue of the amrB region from 708 fosmid and sequencing showed a large chromosome deletion of 131 and 141 kb compared to K43 and 10, respectively. This deletion removed the amr operon and entire clusters for malleactin and cobal synthesis. Other deleted genes included anaerobic arginine deaminase, putative type fimbria and secreted chitinase. Whole genome and PCR confirmed absence of these from 708. Despite missing putative virulence genes 708 was fully virulent in murine model.
T helper cell differentiation is a complex process by which naive CD4 T cells differentiate into Th1 or Th2 lineages. This process is typically driven by lineage-specific transcription factors and repressed by alternative lineages. We investigated the differentiation of naive CD4 T cells into Th1 versus Th states by quantifying transcripts and immunofluorescence in individual cells. Contrary to mutually exclusive expression of antagonistic transcription factors, we observed their co-expression in individual cells at high levels distinct from basal co-expression during priming. We found that cytokines are expressed in a small subpopulation of cells independent of transcription factors in these cells. This cell-to-cell variation in cytokine expression during early T cell differentiation is larger than in fully differentiated state. Upon cytokine inhibition, we observed antagonistic transcription factors, revealing intracellular network otherwise overruled by extracellular signals. These results suggest early CD T cells acquire mixed Th/Th state instructed by extracellular cytokines. The interplay between extracellular and intracellular components unveiled Th differentiation may be common for mammalian cells against noisy cytokine expression.
C. elegans PAQR-2 is a homologous to the insulin-sensizing adiponectin receptors in mammals and is essential for adaptation to 15°C, a low temperature that is usually lethal for this organism. By screening for paqr-2 suppressors, we identified genes involved in phosphatidylcholine synthesis ( ce-1,cy-1 and s-1 ) and fatty acid metabolism (ech-, hac- m- n- hr- sb-1 ). We show that pa-2, phosphatidcholines sb- and Δ-desaturases form a cold adaptation pathway that regulates the increase in unsaturated fatty acids necessary to retain membrane fluidity at low temperatures.
Herpesviruses are among the most prevalent and well-characterized human pathogens. However, much remains to be learned about the structure of the genome packaging and release machinery in the capsids of these large and complex double-stranded viruses. The machinery is well characterized in bacteriophages, which share an evolutionary origin with herpesviruses. In bacterophages, the genome exits the particle through a portal and is transferred into the cell by a complex ( i. e. the tail ) located at the vertex. Here we use cryo-electron microscopy of human simplex-1 ( HSV-1 ) virions to reveal a previously unsuspected feature at the vertex, which extends the HSV tegument to form a connection between theid and the viral. The location suggests it plays a role in release into the nucleus and also for virion.
Schistosoma mansoni soluble egg antigen (SEA) and recombinant Omega-1 modulate CD4+ T-lymphocyte responses and HIV-1 infection in vitro. Schistosoma mansoni is a parasitic helminth that evades and dampens the human immune response through numerous mechanisms, which may have consequences for HIV-1 transmission and disease progression. Here we analyzed the effects of SEA on HIV-1 infection and cytokine/chemokine production in vitro. We found that SEA, specifically kappa-5, potently binds to DC-SIGN and blocks DC-S mediated HIV-1 transfection (p<. 0.05 ) whilst not interfering with cis-infection. DC exposed to SEA under Th2 conditions induced a T-cell population that was less susceptible to HIV-1 R infection (p<.0.05 ) compared to DCs unexposed, whereas HIV- X virus was unaffected. This was not observed for DC exposed under Th1 or Th1/2 conditions. T populations induced by SEA exposed DC demonstrate reduced capacity to produce IF-γ and M-β. The profile of T infected with HIV R was not associated with downmodulation of C5 surface expression. We further show that DC exposed to recombinant omega-1 (r-1), similar to natural-1, induced T populations were less susceptible to HIV R (p.05 ) but not X virus. This was associated with reduction in IFγ and Mβ, but correlated with C5 expression. We have shown that SEA and r-1 modulate HIV infectivity with potential to influence disease in coinfected individuals.
Neuronal stimulation causes a 30% shrinkage of the extracellular space (ECSF) between neurons and astrocytes in grey and white matter under experimental conditions. We present a dynamic model that accounts for experimental data related to the shrinkage in wild-type as well as gene knockout individuals. We find that neuronal release of potassium and uptake of sodium during stimulation, astrocyte uptake of potassium, sodium, chloride, and passive action of the Na+/K pump and osmotically transport through the astrote membrane seem sufficient for shrinkage. However, taking into account ECS and astrote ion concentrations with neuronal stimulation, the Na+/Cl and NaH cotransporters appear critical for observed shrink.
Transposons and repetitive DNA elements are abundant in eukaryotic genomes and can be detrimental to the organism if transcribed. In Arabidopsis thalian, these elements are silenced by the siRNA-mediated transcriptional silencing pathway, where noncoding RNAs (ncRNAs) produced by RNA Polymerase V (Pol V ) guide ARGONAUTE (AGO ) to chromatin and attract enzymes that establish repressive chromatin modifications. We show that SPTLTF1, a silencing factor and homolog of SPT elongation factors, binds chromatin at loci subject to transcription silencing. Chromatin binding of SPTLTF occurs downstream of RNAse V but independently of the presence of 24-nt siRNA. We also show SPTLTF and AGO are recruited to chrom in parallel and independently of each other. Using methylation restriction enzymes, binding both AGO and SPTTF is required for DNA methylation and repressive histone modifications of loci.
Borrelia burgdorferi, the causative agent of Lyme borreliosis, has a complex life cycle that involves transmission between ticks and mammals. While the roles of the rpoB and rpo genes have been extensively studied in the mammalian host, the contribution of the Rpo regulon to the tick phase of the Borrelia burgdferi life cycle has not been examined. Here, we show that Rpo-dependent gene expression is required for spirochete transmission by nymphs. In the absence of Rpo, spirochetes are confined to the midgut lumen where they transform into an unusual morphotype called round bodies during the later stages of the blood meal. We show that round body formation is reversible and appears to be, in part, due to reduced Coenzyme disulf reductase, which also provides NAD for glycolysis. Our data suggest that spirochet default to an Rpo-independent program for round body formation when transmission energetics are unfavorable.
Deficiency of gibberellin (GA) and jasmonate (JA) causes male sterility in Arabidopsis thaliana. GA triggers DELLA degradation to promote stamen development, but little is known about the relationship between GA and JA in stamen development. We show that MYB21, MY24, and MY57 are GA-dependent stamen-enriched genes. Loss-of-function of DELLA1 and DEL2 restores expression of these MY genes with stamen growth in GA-deficient plants. Genetic analysis shows myb21my24my57 triple mutant confers short stamen leading to sterility. Further studies show GA suppresses DELLA to mobilize DAD expression, a key JA biosynthesis gene. This is consistent with lower JA content in young buds of GA-deficient ga3gai2r1r1 compared to WT. We conclude GA promotes JA biosynthesis to control MY21 MY24 and MY57.
Hypoxia inducible factor-1 (HIF-1 ) is a transcription factor that plays key roles in oxygen homeostasis, tumor formation, glucose metabolism, cell survival, and inflammatory response. It is one of the targets of the target of rapamycin (TOR ) pathway, a conserved kinase that regulates growth and metabolism in response to nutrients and growth. Here, we describe a novel role for HIF-1 in modulating lifespan extension by dietary restriction (DR ) in Caenorhabditis elegans. We find that H-1 deficiency results in extended lifespan, which overlaps with inhibition of the RSK-1/S6 kinase, a component of the TOR pathway. H-1 modulates longevity in a nutrient-dependent manner using a modified DR method based on variation of bacterial concentrations on solid plates. We find that h-1 loss-function extends lifespan under rich conditions but fails to show extension under DR. Conversely, egl-9, which increases H-1 activity, diminishes lifespan under DR. This is rescued by tissue-specific expression ofegl-9 in neurons and muscles. Increased lifespan byh-1 is dependent on the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress regulatorinositol-requiring-1 (I-1) and associated with lower ER stress.
Transcription factors and chromatin modifications are known to play a key role in cell differentiation and lineage commitment. However, little is known about chromatin changes in transient states such as cell migration. Here we show that human keratinocyte progenitors either differentiating or migrating have unique enhancers and super-enhancers for each state. These super-enhancers are linked to expression of genes associated with the respective state and are enriched for disease variants. GR3, a transcription factor that promotes differentiation and migration, binds to super-enh in differentiating keratinocytes and to promoters in migrating cells with REST, repressing expression of migration inhibitors. Key epidermal differentiation factors, including GR3, are within super-enh and many bind and regulate super. GR3 represses formation of progenitor and nonkeratin super in differentiating keratinocytes.
Endogenous retroviruses (ERVs) are remnants of ancient retroviral infections of the germline transmitted vertically from generation to generation. It is hypothesized that ERVs are used by the host as factors to block the infection of pathogenic retroviruses. Indeed, ERVs efficiently interfere with the replication of exogenous retroviruses. However, data that these mechanisms have influenced the coevolution of endogenous and exogenous retroviruses and their hosts have been difficult to obtain. Sheep are an interesting system to study retrovirus coevolution because of the coexistence in this species of exogenous ( i. e., horizontally transmitted ) oncogenic retroviruses, Jaags sheep retrovirus and enzoot nasal virus with related and biologically active endogenous retrovir (enRVs ). We isolated the evolutionary and molecular history of 27RVs. RVs have been in the genome for 5–7 y. Two RVs (RV1 andRV-20 ) entered the genome within 3 y before and during speciation the genus, acquired tempor distinct G poly resulting a transdom phenotype block replication exogenous. Both transdom RV became the genome before or sheep ( ∼, y ). Interestingly RV escaping transdom RV has emerged recently, likely last. We determined events during are indicative evolutionary antagon between endogenous exogenous retrovir. This strongly that endization and selection ERVs acting factors mechanism host fight retroiral.
Schistosomiasis is a parasitic disease caused by Schistosoma mansoni and S. haematobium. The standard diagnosis relies on microscopic detection of eggs in stool or urine samples and serological assays. However, the sensitivity of standard microscopic procedures is poor, making molecular methods of interest. This study evaluated two in-house real-time Schos PCRs targeting S. mansoni and S. haematium in stool, urine, biopsies, and sera to diagnose active infections and monitor treatment efficacy. Schos PC were performed on 412 samples (124 urine, 86 stools, 8 biops, sera ) from patients with suspected schosiasis before treatment. Results were compared to microscopic and serological assays ( ELISA, HA, WB ). Compared to microscopy, PC increased sensitivity from 4% to 10.5% and 33.7 to 48.8% for Sh in urine and Sm stools, respectively. Serum PC sensitivity was 72.7% and 94.1 in patients with positive microscopy. Specificity was 98.9. After treatment, serum positivity declined from 93.8 at 30 to 8.3 at 360 whereas antibodies remained positive 1 year. Schos PC clearly outperformed microscopy on stools and urine and could be part of methods with WB-based serology, which remains standard for diagnosis. When serology is positive and microscopy negative, PC provides information for further exploration.
Machine learning has been used to speed up molecular simulations of small systems by estimating potential energy surfaces. We demonstrate that this approach is feasible for larger, structurally complex molecules. We take the natural product Archazolide A, a potent inhibitor of vacuolar ATPase from myxobacterium Archigephyra, as an example. Our model estimates new conformations by exploiting information from previous calculations via Gaussian regression. Predictive variance is used to assess if a conformation is in interpolation, allowing a trade-off between accuracy and speed.
In Central Africa is a hotspot for emerging infectious diseases (EIDs) of global and local importance, and the current outbreak of ebolavirus is affecting multiple countries simultaneously. Ebavirus is suspected to have caused recent declines in great apes. While ebavirus vaccines have been proposed as an intervention to protect apes, their effectiveness would be improved if we could diagnostically confirm Ebola virus (EVD) as the cause of die-offs, establish ebavirus distribution, immunologically naïve populations, and whether apes survive virus. Here we report the first non-invasive detection of antibodies against ebavirus (EV) from ape feces. Using this method, we have been able to identify gorillas with antibodies EV with an overall prevalence of 10%, demonstrating EV exposure or infection is not uniformly lethal in this species. Furthermore, evidence was identified in gorillas previously thought to be unexposed EV (protected by topological barriers of transmission ). Our approach will contribute to a strategy to protect apes from EV by early detection of incidence, identifying immunologically naïve at-risk as targets for vaccination, and providing means to track efficacy if intervention is appropriate.
Bacterial pathogen Xanthomonas campestris pv. vesicatoria secretes a novel type III effector protein Xop, which exhibits E3 ubiquitin ligase activity in vitro and in planta. This activity is associated with the C-terminal region of Xop, which interacts with E ubiquitin conjugating enzymes and mediates K11-linked polyubiquitin formation. The crystal structure of the Xop C-terminal domain revealed a novel fold termed XL-box, not present in previously characterized E3 ligases. Mutation of amino acids in the XL-box disrupts E ligase activity and prevents Xop-induced plant death. The XL-box lacks cysteine residues, suggesting a non-thioester ubiquitin-E ligase mechanism. The N-terminal of Xop contains a leucine-rich repeat ( LRR ) domain, which may serve as a protein-protein module for target recognition. While E3 activity is required for plant death, suppression of PAMP responses depends on the N-terminal LRR.
Human Immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection is a major cause of global morbidity and mortality worldwide. The role of T follicular helper (Tfh) cells in HIV infection is not well understood. We investigated the function of circulating Tfh cells in HIV-infected individuals and the impact of early antiretroviral treatment (ART) on Tfh and B cell function. We used the RV cohort of HIV-infected individuals in early (stage 1 and 2 ) and late (stage 3 ) to study Tfh responses. We found impaired Tfh function in stage 3 compared to stage 1/2. Tfh/B cocultures showed lower B cell survival and Ig secretion in stage 3 compared to stage 1/2. This coincided with lower IL-10 and increased RANT and TN-α suggesting inflammation altered Tfh and B responses. Elevated viral load in stage 3 correlated with Tfh-mediated B Ig production, indicating increased viremia in Tfh impairment and humoral response. We also found phenotypic perturbations in the B compartment, notably decreased memory cells in stage 3 compared stage 1/, coinciding with viremia. Our coculture suggested intrinsic B defects could contribute to impaired response at lower level. Overall, Tfh B responses are significantly altered stage 3 compared stage 1, coinciding increased inflammation and reduction B. These data suggest early ART for HIV-infected individuals could prevent dysregulation while preserving Tfh function and B memory.
Schistosomiasis is a parasitic disease that affects over 200 million people worldwide and is currently treated with a single drug, praziquantel, which has several shortcomings. The need for next generation anthelmintics is underpinned by the process of validating physiologically relevant targets and pharmacologically profiling them is challenging. We have pharmacologically profiled a schosome serergic GPCR ( Sm.5TR ) as a downstream modulator of PZ efficacy in a miniaturized assay compatible with high screening. This employs a luciferase based biosensor sensitive to cellularAMP that resolves proximal kinetics of GPCR in intact. Data evidence divergent pharmacological signature between paras serergic receptor and closest human homolog ( H.5TR ) supports optimizing parasitic pharmacores. New ligands and series with potency and selectivity for Sm.5TR over H.5TR are identified in vitro and validated in vivo against schosules and adult worms. Sm.5TR also displayed irreversible inactivation phenomenon at H.5TR. These data underscore feasibility of flatworm GPCRs in screening to resolve classes of modulators. Further, these data promise Sm.5 as chemotherapeutic node for next generation anthelmics.
During embryonic development, the formation of the germ layers (ectoderm, mesoderm, and endoderm) is essential for the organization of the metazoan body. In some organisms, such as flies, fish, and amphibians, the ectodermesoderm boundary not only separates the germ layers, but also serves as a substrate for mesoderm migration. We show that cell detachment at the boundary, resulting from contact-induced signals, is the core of ectodermeserm segregation. Cells alternate between adhesion and detachment, requiring ephrin/Eph signaling. Multiple ephrin ligands and Eph receptors are expressed on each side of the boundary, and separation depends on forward signaling across the boundary in both directions, involving partially redundant ligands and receptors and activation of Rac and Rho.
Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with increasing prevalence over the last four decades; however, the underlying pathophysiology remains unclear. Diagnosis is currently based on behavioral observations and psychometric tools. This study aims to incorporate biochemical data into diagnosis by analyzing metabolite concentrations of folate-dependent one-carbon metabolism and transulfuration pathways in blood samples of 83 ASD participants and 76 age-matched neurotypical peers. Discriminant Analysis enables multivariate classification of participants as ASD or neurotypical, resulting in 96. 1% correct identification of neurotyp and 97.6% of ASD. Furthermore, Partial Least Squares is used to predict adaptive behavior, measured by Vineland Adaptive Composite score, where five metabolites of pathways are sufficient to predict Vineland score with R2 0.45 after cross-validation.
Leishmanias is a vector-borne disease endemic in 98 countries with approximately 350 million people at risk and 2 million cases annually. Brazil is one of the most affected countries.
