We applied Bayesian geostatistical negative binomial models to analyze incidence of cutaneous and visceral leishiasis in Brazil from 2001–2010. We used integrated Laplace approximations for fast Bayesian inference and variable selection to determine the most important climatic, environmental, and socioeconomic predictors of cutaneous and visceral leishias. For both types of leishias, precipitation and socioeconomic proxies were identified as risk factors. We predicted 30,189 ( SD 7,676 ) cases for cutaneous leias and 4,889 ( SD 288 ) for visceral leias in 2010. Our maps predicted highest numbers of infected in Minas Gerais and Par for visceral and cutaneous leias, respectively. Spatial maps identified priority areas for leishias control to reduce incidence.
Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral infection that is spreading to new regions and changing the force of infection in endemic areas. Clinical experience suggests that adults have a different pattern of complications than children, but few reports have described the age-related spectrum of disease in contemporaneous groups of patients at the same location. We compared clinical and laboratory features, management, and outcome of 647 adults and 881 children with deng admitted to a hospital in southern Vietnam. We found that signs of vascular leakage and shock were more frequent and severe in children than adults, while bleeding and organ involvement were more common in adults. Adults had significantly more thrombocytopenia. Infection but not serotype was independently associated with thromocytopenia, with smaller effect than age. The effect of age on platelet count was apparent several weeks after recovery, indicating adults have intrinsically lower counts than children.
SIV infection of sooty mangabeys (SM), a natural host of SIVsm, is non-pathogenic despite robust virus replication. In contrast to HIV in humans and SIV in macaques. We identified a novel CCR5 allele in SM, Δ, encoding a truncated molecule that is not expressed on the cell surface and does not support SIV entry in vitro. This allele was present at 26% frequency in a large SM colony, along with 3% for CCRΔ24 allele that also abrogates surface expression. Overall, 8% of animals were homozygous for CCR alleles and 41% were heterozygous. The allele was also present in wild SM in Africa. CD+ and CD+ T cells displayed a gradient of C5 expression across groups, which was highly significant for CD cells. The prevalence of SIVm infection was not different in animals lacking C5 compared to heterozygous and homozygous wild-type animals. Furthermore, lacking C5 had robust viral loads that were only modestly lower than wild-type animals. SIVm isolates infected homozyg mutant and wild PBMC in C5-independent in vitro and Envs from C-null and wild animals used CX6, G15 and G1 in addition to5 in transfected cells.
The role of the transcription factor MEF2 in tumorigenesis is complex and can be either pro-oncogenic or tumor suppressive depending on its interaction with coactivators or co-repressors. MEF can supervise histone modifications associated with activation or repression, such as H3K methylation and H3 acetylation. Class II histone deacetylases (HDACs) are critical for the generation of a MEF repressive environment. In leiomyosarcoma (LMS), the dual role of MEF is relevant for tumor aggressiveness. Class II HDs are overexpressed in 22% of LMS, where high levels of HD4 and HD9 inversely correlate with overall survival. The knock out of HD9 suppresses the transformed phenotype of L cells by restoring transcriptional proficiency of MEF-target loci. HD9 coordinates the demethylation of H3me at the promoters of M-target genes. We show that II HDs do not bind all regulative bound by M. Hence, M-target genes can be both transcribed and repressed. However, repressed M-targets are poised in chromatin. Our results suggest II HD and HD9 as druggable targets for intervention in L.
Hydrophins are a class of proteins produced by filamentous fungi that play a crucial role in their interaction with their environment and have potential applications in biotechnology. In this study, we used a combination of docking, molecular dynamics, and cryo-electron microscopy to investigate the atomic structure of films composed of two class II hydrophins: HFBI and HFB produced by Trichoderma rei. Our results suggest that the film is composed of six proteins, with a unit cell size of 56 Å. However, our computational and experimental results show different symmetries: P6 and P3, respectively. We propose an alternate structure with a unit cell size and P symmetry, and use Monte Carlo simulation to show that this metastable structure may increase the rate of coverage of hydrophin films. This may have implications for both biology and nanotechnology.
Leishmania donovani is a protozoan parasite that causes visceral leishiasis. Aminoacyl tRNA synthases are enzymes required for protein synthesis and are known drug targets in bacteria and fungi. Here, we report the first characterization of Leishmaniaov ThrRS ( LThr ), the ThrRS of Leishmania. Recombinant LThr ( rThr ) was expressed in E. coli and purified. The kinetic parameters of rThr were determined. The subcellular localization ofThr was done by immunofluorescence. Heterozyg mutants ofThr were generated in Leish promastigotes. These genetically manipulated parasites were checked for proliferation, virulence, aminoacylation activity and sensitivity to Thr inhibitor borid. The 3D model of LThr was compared to human Thr. RecombinantThr displayed aminoacylation activity and is possibly localized to cytosol and mitochondria. Hetergotes showed restrictive phenotype and attenuated infectivity. These parasites were more susceptible to inhibition by borid. Several attempts to obtain Thr null mutants were not successful, indicating Thr is essential for Leish parasite. Borid showed strong affinity forThr ( KD:0.04 μM ) and inhibited aminoacy activity of rThr (IC:0.06 μM ). Borid inhibited promastig (IC:21M ) stage parasites. Our data show thatThr is essential for Leish survival and likely binds small molecules with strong affinity, making a potential drug target.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) RNA is recognized as non-self by the innate immune receptor RIG-I through the presence of a 5′- triphosphate (5′-pp ) on viral RNA in association with a 3′ poly-UUC tract. Here we define the HCV pathogen associated molecular pattern (PAMP) and criteria for R-I non discrimination of HCV by examining RNA structure-function attributes that impart AMP to poly-UUC tract. We found that the 34 nucleotide polyuridine core of this tract was essential for R-I activation and that interspersed ribosine nucleotides between poly sequences in RNA were required for optimal R-I induction. Importantly, 5′pp-polyU RNA variants that stimulated R-I efficiently bound purified R protein in vitro and interaction with both repressor and helicase domains of R-I was required for signaling. When appended to ′pp RNA lacking AMP activity, polyU-core conferred non recognition of RNA and innate signaling by-I. Importantly, HCV polyU variants that activated-I triggered potent responses in vitro and hepatic immune responses in vivo using mouse model of AMP signaling.
Eosinophils and IL-4 Promote Nematode Growth Coincident with Innate Response to Tissue Injury. Eosinophils are known to have functions beyond host defense and allergy to tissue regeneration. In this study, we investigated the mechanism by which eosophils promote Trichinella spiralis larvae growth in skeletal muscle. Our results indicate that IL-4 and eosophils are necessary for normal larval growth and eosoph from IL-4 mice are sufficient to support growth. The eosophil effect operates in the absence of adaptive immunity. Following invasion by larvae, host expression in muscle was compatible with a regenerative response and shift in source of energy in infected. The presence eosoph suppressed local inflammation and influenced nutrient homeostasis in muscle. Redistribution of glucose 4 ( GLUT ) and phosphorylation of Akt were observed in cells, consistent with enhancement of glucose and glycogen by larvae. Our data are consistent with a mechanism in which eosoph promote larval by IL- dependent that limits interferon-driven that alter metabolism in muscle.
Genome-wide studies have suggested that mammalian chromosomes consist of megabase domains of coordinated origin firing separated by large originless regions. However, we report a genome-wide analysis of replication kinetics in human cells that contradicts this view. In HeLa cells, replication origins are spaced at 40 kb intervals and fire in small clusters whose synchrony increases during S phase. Replication velocity (0.7 kb/min, 2.0 kb ) remains constant and narrowly distributed through S. However, multi-scale analysis of genome-wide timing shows a broad distribution of replication gradients with regions larger than 100 kb replicating less than 2/min. He cells lack large regions of unidirectional progression. Temporal regions are replicated by sequential activation of origins at a rate increasing during S and timing gradients are set by the delay and spacing between origin firings rather than the velocity of forks. Activation of internal origins in a temporal region is demonstrated by analysis of the IGH locus in He cells. Analysis of origin maps in He cells and published timing data in other cells corroborate these findings with the exception of embryonic cells where regions of unid progression are more abundant.
The ability of the nervous system to recognize objects in spite of changes in contextual variables such as perspective or lighting is thought to be learned by exploiting the fact that object identities change more slowly than contextual variables. Here, we study how this “temporal stability” or “slown” approach can be implemented within biologically realistic spike-based rules. We show that slow analysis, an algorithm based on slown, can be implemented in continuous neurons by a modified Hebbian rule. This provides a link to trace, another implementation of slown learning. We then show that for Poisson neurons, slown can be implemented by spike-timing-dependent plasticity (STDP) with a specific window. We study the learning of STDP and show that for interpretations of ST, it is not the window that is relevant but the convolution of the window with postsynaptic. We derive ST windows that implement slow analysis and trace. The resulting windows are compatible with data in shape and times. We show that the window can be split into functionally different components that are sensitive to reversible and irreversible aspects of input. Our analysis indicates that irreversible are not favor stable distributions but generate weight dynamics.
Non-small cell lung cancer (NSCL) is a leading cause of cancer death worldwide, and chemotherapy resistance to therapy is a major cause of treatment failure. While genetic and phenotypic heterogeneity within tumors contribute to resistance, it is not understood how tumor subclones interact with each other to withstand therapy. Here, we report a previously unrecognized behavior in heterogeneous tumors: cooperative adaptation to therapy (CAT), in which cancer cells induce resistant phenotypes in neighboring cells exposed to therapy. We engineered phenotypically diverse NSCL cells by conferring mutations in Dicer, a type III cytoplasmic endonuclease involved in noncoding RNA genesis. We monitored three-dimensional growth of fluorescently-labeled mutant and wild-type cells in co-culture using a substrate-free NanoCulture system under stimulated or drug conditions. By integrating flow cytometry, we characterized growth of mono- and co-cultures using a mathematical model of intra and interspecies competition. Leveraging cytometry data, we estimated model parameters to reveal combination of WT and mutants co-cult allowed beneficial growth in drug-sensitive cells via induction of cell transitions described by cooperative game-theoretic change in fitness. We used an ex vivo human model to predict clinical response through drug analyses and determined that cellular heterogeneity correlates to failure of clinically-approved and off-label drugs in NSCL samples.
Rickettsial diseases are endemic in sub-Saharan Africa, but the burden of disease and risk factors of transmission are sparsely described. We conducted a cross-sectional seroprevalence study to estimate the serreval of Ig antibodies against Spotted Group ( SFG ) ricketiae and assess socioeconomic and environmental risk factors in the Mbeya region, South Tanzania. We randomly selected 1, 228 persons above 5 years from nine communities stratified by age, altitude and ownership of domestic mammals. Serology was performed at a dilution 1:64. SFG-serositivity in the cohort was 67.9% ( range 42.8–91.4% ). Multivar analysis revealed association with age ( PR 1.08; 1.–1.10 ), warmer temperatures ( 1.38; 1.11.71 ), gender (1.08;.00.16 ), and low density (.96.94.99 ). At higher elevations, cattle density was associated with higher serreval.
Monounsaturated fatty acid oleate plays a previously unknown role in the innate immune response of the nematode Caenorhabdis elegans. We identified two stearoy-co A desaturases that synthesize oleate in C. elegans and show that oleate is necessary for the pathogen-mediated induction of immune genes. C elegans deficient in ole production are hypersusceptible to infection with diverse pathogens, which can be rescued by addition of exogenous oleate. However, ole is not sufficient to drive immune activation.
Riboswitches are regulatory elements that modulate gene expression in response to specific metabolite binding. Riboswitch agonists have been reported to exhibit antimicrobial properties by binding to the ribos domain. Guanine ribwitches are involved in the regulation of transport and biosynthesis of purine metabolites, which are critical for the cellular nucleotide pool. Upon guanine binding, ribwitches stabilize a 5′-translated mRNA that causes attenuation of the downstream reading frame. We have identified a pyrimidine compound (PC1) binding guanine ribwitch that shows bactericidal activity against a subgroup of bacterial species including nosocomial pathogens. This killing is only achieved when guA, a gene for G synthase, is under ribwitch control. Several clinical strains with multiple drug resistance were inhibited, suggesting PC targets a different pathway. We used a mouse model to show direct correlation between PC administration and reduction of Staphlococcus aureus infection in mammary glands.
In this study, macaque monkeys were trained to navigate a virtual reality maze to find a reward while their behavior, visual exploration, and hippocampal activity were recorded. We found that cells in the hippocampus responded to one or more variables like direction of head, point of gaze, or context. Many cells fired at the sight of a single landmark in a viewpoint-dependent manner, encoding the animal’s situation within a set of actions leading to the goal. Overall, hippocamp activity was best fit by a fine-grained state comprising current position, view, and context.
During vertebrate development, the midbrain and hindbrain are separated by the midbrain boundary (MHB), which is characterized by a well-defined pattern of restricted gene expression. This pattern is established and maintained by a regulatory network of transcription and secreted factors, but the details of this network are not yet fully understood. Here, we show that a Boolean analysis of the characteristic gene expression at the murine MHB reveals key interactions in this network. Our analysis employs computational techniques for minimization of Boolean functions, allowing us to predict the interplay of various interactions. In particular, we predict a maintaining rather than inducing effect of Fgf on Wnt expression, an issue that remained unclear from published data. Using anterior neural plate/tube explant cultures, we provide evidence that F8 in fact maintains but does not induce ectopic Wnt in these explants. In combination with previously validated interactions, this allows the construction of a network between key transcription and secret factors at M. Analyses of Boolean differential and reaction-diff models this network confirm that it is able to explain the maintenance of M as well as timecourses of patterns under wild-type and knock conditions.
Theileria annulata is an apicomplex parasite that infects host cells and induces uncontrolled proliferation of the parasitized cell population. Shortly after sporozoite entry, the host cell membrane is dissolved and an array of host microtubules ( MTs ) surrounds the parasite, which develops into a transforming schizont. The schizont remains tethered to host MTs during mitosis and cytokinesis and engages the cell’s astral and central MTs to secure distribution between daughter cells. The molecular mechanism of schizont recruitment of host MTs is unknown. MT minus ends are anchored at the MT organizing center while plus ends explore cellular space, constantly switching between growth and shrinkage phases ( dynamic instability ). We report that schizont recruits end-binding protein 1 ( EB ), a component of MT plus end protein network and key regulator of host MT dynamics. Using in vitro experiments, we show that T. annata104, a polymorphic antigen on schizont surface, functions as EB-binding protein and recruits EB in absence of other parasite proteins. Binding depends on consensus Sx motif in highly disordered C-terminal of 104. We show parasite interaction with host EB is cell cycle regulated. This is first description of pathogen protein to interact EB via bonaide Sx motif.
Telomeres are the protective caps at the ends of eukaryotic chromosomes that shorten with each cell division. Telomere shortening is a hallmark of aging. Telomeres are maintained by telomerase, a reverse transcriptase that adds nucleotides to the 3’ end of telomeres. Telomeres are also maintained by homologous recombination repair ( BIR ) of broken replication forks. In budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the replicase Cdc9 is necessary for BIR. In cdc9-1 cells, a population of cells with persistent DNA damage, likely due to broken forks, constitutively activates the DNA damage checkpoint and leads to longer teleres. Telom length requires telerase, the DNA signaling cascade Mec1-Rad-Rad53, and BIR components Rad51, Rad52,32, and P1. Mec-Rad53 phosphorylates P1, which inhibits telerase at double strand breaks, is also important for P1 in BIR and telom elongation in c9-1 cells. Two other mutants, c44 and r3, similar to c9, have long teleres dependent on P1 phosphorylation. We propose that B forks passing through telomeres promotes telerase and leads to telom length.
Onchocercias, caused by the filarial nematode Onocerca volulus, is a major public health concern due to its debilitating symptoms and concerns about recrudence in areas of previous onocercias control. We investigated whether luciferase immunrecipitation systems (LIPS) may be used as a rapid, specific, and standardized assay for Onoc volulus infection. We tested four recomantly produced Onoculus antigens (OvAR-1, API-1, A-MS-1 and CPI-1 ) by IPS on a large cohort of sera comprised of uninfected controls and patients with proven parasitic infection including Onoculus (O), bancrofti (W), loa (L), stercoralis (S), and other crossreactive infections. Antibody responses to the four antigens allowed unequivocal differentiation between infected and uninfected sera with 100% sensitivity and 100 specificity. Analysis of antibody titers to each antigen in infected sera revealed they were markedly different and did not correlate with each other. Compared to infected sera, patients with W, L, S, and other had markedly lower geometric antibody titers to each antigen (P<0.000 for each ). A mixture of the four antigens in standard or 15-minute IPS showed 100% sensitivity and specificity distinguishing infected from unected sera. The 15 IPS had best performance with 76%, 84, and 93 for distinguishing from W, L, S-infected sera.
Iron deficiency anemia and soil-transmitted helth infections are major public health problems in women of reproductive age in resource-constrained settings. However, few studies have assessed the effectiveness of long-term population-based interventions. This study evaluated the impact of weekly iron-folic acid supplementation and deworming on hemoglobin, anemia, iron deficiency, and soil helth infection in a rural Vietnamese population over 54 months. A total of 389 women were enrolled prior to intervention. After 54 months, 76% were taking ironolic acid and 95 had taken dewing treatment. Mean hemoglobin rose from 122 g/L to 131 g and anemia fell from 38% to 18. However, results differed between ethnic groups. Iron deficiency fell from 23 to 8 and iron anemia from 4. Hookworm infection fell from 76 to 11 and moderate or heavy helth infestation to less than 1.
Herpesviruses, such as Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), are able to persist in the face of primed immunity by exploiting immune evasion strategies, including reduction of antigen expression and escape from antigen presentation pathways. We show that EBV encodes a novel immunoevas, gp150, expressed during the late phase of replication. gp150 inhibits antigen presentation by HLA I, H II, and non-class lipid-presenting CD1 molecules. The mechanism of gp150-mediated escape does not depend on degradation of antigen-presenting molecules nor does it require gp’s cytoplasmic tail. Through abundant glycosylation, gp creates a shield that impedes antigen presentation. This is an unprecedented immune evasion mechanism for herpesviruses. Importantly, cells infected with a gp-null EB displayed rescued levels of antigen presentation by H I, II, and CD, supporting an important role for B cells next to classical T in fighting EB infection.
Chlamydiaeae are obligate intracellular pathogens that cause a wide range of diseases in humans and animals. Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of sexually transmitted chlamydia in humans. Chlamydiae are able to invade host cells by inducing actin dependent endocytosis. Chytoplasmic actin plays a key role in this process. Chytoplasm actin is a cytoskeletal protein that polymerizes into actin filaments. Chytopl actin filaments are important for cell motility and shape. Chytopl actin filaments are also involved in endocytosis. Chtoplasmic actin filaments can be nucleated by actin binding proteins. Chytopl actin nucleation is important for chlamial invasion. Chytopl actin nucleation is mediated by the actin recruiting protein ( Tarp). Tarp is conserved among all pathogenic chlamial species. Previous studies have shown that the actin binding and proline rich domains of T are required for T mediated actin nucleation. In this study, we generated an antiserum specific for the act binding domain of T. This antiserum inhibited actin polymerization in vitro and chlam entry in vivo, indicating an essential role for T in chlamial pathogenesis. Our findings indicate that T mediated actin binding and nucleation is conserved among chlamial species and plays a critical role in bacterial invasion of host cells.
Schistosomiasis japonica is a zoonotic disease with a number of mammalian species acting as reservoirs, including buffaloes, which contribute to 75% of human transmission in the People’s Republic of China. Determining prevalence and intensity of Schosoma japon in mammalian hosts is important for calculating transmission and environmental contamination. A new procedure, formal–ethyl acetate sedimentation–digestion ( F–SD ), for visualization of S japon eggs in bovine feces is described. This technique is effective for identifying and quantifying S japon eggs in fecal samples from naturally infected Chinese buffaloes and carab water buffalo in the Philippines. The procedure involves filtration, sedimentation, hydroxide digestion and centrifugation prior to microscopy.
Mutations in the genes encoding cartilage-associated protein (CRTAP) and proly 3-hydroxylase 1 (P3H1, encoded by LEP1) were first identified as causes of recessive osteogenesis imperfecta (OI. These proteins, together with cyclophilin (by PPI), form a complex that 3-hydroxylates a proline on the α1(I) chain (Pro986) and has cis-trans isomerase Pase activity for proper collagen folding. Recent data suggest proly 3ydrolation of Pro986 is not required for collagen structural stability; however, absence of this post-translational modification may disrupt protein-protein interactions for proper collagen folding and lead to collagen overmodification. PH and CRTAP stabilize each other and absence results in degradation of other. Hence, hypomorphic or loss of function of either gene causes loss of complex and associated functions. The contribution of this complex’s 3ydrolation versus Pase and collagen chaperone activities to OI phenotype is unknown. We generated knock-in mice carrying single amino acid substitution in catalytic site of PH (Lep1H662). This abolished PH activity but retained ability form complex CRT and collagen chaper function. Knock mice showed absence proly 3ydrolation Pro of α(I) and α(II) collagen but significant overmodification other residues. They were normal appearance, no growth defects normal cartilage plate histology but decreased trabecular mass.
In Drosophila simulans, a species closely related to Drosophila melanogaster, has been found to be invaded by the P-element, a selfish genetic element that causes hybrid dysgenesis, a syndrome of abnormal phenotypes including sterility. The P-element invaded D. melanogaster in a few decades ago, causing hybrid dysgenesis, but D simul remained P-element free until recently. Here, we show that around 20% of D simul strains induce dysgenesis, and that this phenotype is associated with the invasion of the P-element. We surveyed 631 D simul strains on three continents over 27 years for the presence of P and find that the invasion occurred rapidly and nearly simultaneously in regions, with P-elements being rare in 2006 and common by 201. Importantly, strains from the latter phase of invasion have adapted to suppress the effects of the-element, evidenced by resistance to dysgenesis.
Male mosquitoes of the species Aedes aegypti were marked with the fluorescent dye rhodamine B by feeding them sugar solutions containing 0. 1, 0. 2, 0.4, or 0.8% rhodamine (w/v in 50% honey during flight. All concentrations produced >95% transfer to females and successful marking after 4 days of feeding, with 0.4 and 0.8% solutions producing the longest body marking. Importantly, rhamine marking had no effect on male competitiveness. Proof-of-principle releases demonstrated transfer of marked seminal fluid to females under field conditions and recapture of marked males.
Bacterial superantigens are a family of toxins that induce an inflammatory cytokine storm that can lead to lethal shock. We show that superantigens must bind to the CD28 homodimer to elicit inflammatory cytokine gene expression and lethality. CD28 is a homodimer expressed on T cells that functions as the principal costimulatory ligand in the immune response through interaction with its B coligands. We show that preventing superigen access to CD28 suffices to block lethality. Mice were protected from superigen challenge by peptide mimetics of the CD28 interface and peptides that compete with superigen for binding to CD. Superigens use a conserved β-strandinge/α-helix domain to engage CD28. Mutation of superigen domain abolished cytokine induction and lethality. Structural analysis showed that superigen binds to T cell receptor and major histocompatibility class II on antigen-presenting cell, CD can accommodate as superigen receptor in ternary complex with CD28 oriented towards β-stringe/α-helix superigen. Our findings identify CD homimer as critical target for superigens.
Wnt/β-caten signaling controls the cell cycle of embryonic stem cells (ESCs) through the transcriptional activation of the Ink/arf locus. This is mediated by the recruitment of the Wnt-effector Tcf1 to the Inkarf promoter. Tcf1, but not Tcf3, is responsible for the Wnt-dependent anti-proliferative effect in mESCs. Tcf1 is recruited to palindromic motifs in the promoter of cell cycle repressor genes, such as p15Ink4, p16k4a and p19f, which mediate the Wnt anti-proliferative effect in mES. Consistently, ablation of βaten or T1 expression impairs W-dependent cell cycle regulation. The Wnt pathway, known to be mitogenic in somatic tissues, restores the G1 phase and reduces proliferation of mES without perturbing pluripency.
Dengue Virus Activates Membrane TRAIL Relocalization and IF-α Production by Plasmacytoid Dendritic Cells In Vitro and In Vivo  
Plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) are innate immune cells that respond to virus exposure by secreting IF-α and expressing membrane TRAIL (mTR). We aimed to characterize DC activation in deng patients and their function under DENV-2 stimulation in vitro. Flow cytometry analysis revealed that pDC of mildeng patients exhibit higher frequencies ofTR compared to severe or healthy controls. Plasma of IF-α and TR are increased in mild compared to severeeng patients, correlating with DC activation. In vitro exposure to D-2 induced TR expression on pDC, and microscopy highlighted TR was relocalized from intracellular to plasma. Chloro treatment inhibited D-2-induced TRlocalization and IFα by p. Endosomal degradation by chloro allowed viral detection inside p. Data favor endocyt pathway activation by in pDC. Coculture p/D-2-infected monocytes revealed antigen reduction by. This was also observed after exogenous IFα treatment. Thus, DC effect was mainly dependent onα production.
The immune response to Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection is a complex. Experimental evidence has revealed that tumor necrosis factor (TN) plays a major role in host defense against Mtb in both active and latent phases of infection. TN-neutralizing drugs used to treat inflammatory diseases have been reported to increase the risk of tuberculosis (TB) in accordance with animal studies. This study takes a computational approach toward characterizing the role of TN in protection against the tuble bacillus in both active and latent infection. We extend previous mathematical models to investigate the roles of soluble (TN) and transmembrane TN (TN). We analyze the effects of anti-T therapy in clinical trials by simulating two commonly used therapies, anti-T antibody and TN receptor, predicting that explain differences in TB reactivation rates. Our findings are that bioavailability of TN following anti-T therapy is the factor for reactivation of latent and thatTN—even at low—is for control of infection. Using a model, it is possible mechanisms of action of anti-T treatments and insights into the role of TN in control and pathology.
Recent studies have shown that the presence of at least 208 retroduplication (RD) variations, a class of polymorphisms in which a retrocopy is present or absent from individual genomes. The majority of these RD resulted from recent retroduplication. This study used the results from the 100 Genomes Project to investigate variation in loss of ancestral ( i. e. shared with other primates ) retrocopies among human populations. We also examined retrocopy levels using RNA-Seq data from the Human Body project as well as data from lymphoblast cell lines provided the Geuvis Consortium. We developed a new approach to detect retro absent from the human genome. We experimentally confirmed the existence of detected retro and their presence in human of 17 different populations. We were able to detect 193 RD; the majority from retro deletion. Most had not previously been reported. We experimentally confirmed expression of 11 retro that underwent deletion in individuals. The frequency of deletion, exception one, is low. The expression and rate of remaining may suggest functionality.
Infection of the central nervous system by Taenia solium cysticerci causes neurocysticercosis (NCC), a pleomorphic disease. Inflammation around the cysterci is the major cause of disease but is variably present. The location and characteristics of the brain tissue adjacent to the cysterci may modulate the inflammatory responses. We analyzed the inflammatory responses to cysterci located in the parenchyma compared to those in the meninges or partially in contact with the parenym and meninges. Histological specimens of brain cysterci ( n = 196 ) from 11 pigs naturally infected with Taenia solium cystic were used. Four pigs were sacrificed after 2 days and 5 days of praziquel treatment; three did not receive treatment. All were intravenously injected with Evans Blue to assess blood-brain barrier disruption. The degree of inflammation was estimated by histological score (ISC) based on extent of inflammation in pericyst areas assessed in composed photomicrographs at 40 ampl. Parenymal cysterci provoked significantly higher ISC after antiparas treatment compared to meninge and cortingeal cysterci. ISC of meninge cysti was not affected by treatment. Cortinge cysti increase ISC correlated to extent of cyst adjacent to parenym. Disruption of blood-brain was associated treatment in parenym tissue. Inflammatory to cysti in meninges was decreased compared to parenyci.
Yaws is a disease caused by Treponema pallidum subspecies perten and is endemic in Ghana. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends mass azithromycin distribution as the cornerstone of the yaws eradication campaign. Previously, azithrom was distributed at a lower dose in two regions of Ghana to control trachoma. However, reporting of y raises the possibility that resistance may have emerged in T. pallum perten or alternative infections may be responsible for some cases. We conducted a cross-sectional survey in thirty communities in two districts of Ghana where mass drug administration for trach had been conducted. Children aged 5–17 with ulcerative lesions compatible with y were enrolled. Samples for treponemal serology and PCR were collected from all children.90 with 98 lesions were enrolled. Syphilis serology was negative in all of them. PCR T. pallumsp pertue was negative in children but Haemophilus duyi DNA was detected in 9. In communities previously treated trach, we found no evidence of ongoing y transmission. H.duyi was associated with proportion of lesions but majority remain unexplained.
Despite the success of antiretroviral therapy (ART) in treating HIV infection, HIV persistence remains a major challenge. A key driver of persistence is cell homeostasis, which is regulated by cytokines that trigger the Jak-STAT pathway in memory T cells, the hub of the HIV reservoir. We evaluated the ability of two FDA-approved Jak inhibitors, tofacitinib and ruxitin, to block HIV seeding and maintenance of the reservoir in vitro. We provide evidence for the involvement of the Jak-STAT pathway in HIV persistence in vivo, ex vivo, and in vitro; STAT5 correlates with increased levels of integrated viral DNA in vivo and in vitro. Jak inhibitors reduce the frequency of CD4 T cells harboring HIV DNA. We show that Jak block viral production from infected cells, inhibit IL-15-induced viral reactivation from latent stores thereby preventing transmission to bystander T cells. These results show dysregulation of the JakSTAT pathway is associated with persistence in vivo and that inhibitors target key events downstream IL-2, IL-7, and IL-15 ligation to their receptors, impacting the HIV reservoir in all CD T subsets in vitro and vivo.
Infection of Spodoptera exigua larvae with the baculoviruses SeNPV and AcNP leads to a complex transcriptional response. In contrast to the expected transcriptional shut-down during baculovirus infection, S. exig cells show a balanced number of up- and down-regulated genes during the first 36 hours following infection. Many immune-related genes, including pattern recognition proteins, signalling and immune pathways as well as immune effectors involved in the melanization cascade are down-regulated after baculirus infection. The down-regulation of immune genes is confirmed in the larval gut. The expression of immune genes in the gut affects the status of gut microorganisms, many of which are responsible for growth and development. We hypothesize that the downregulation after baculirus infection affects the amount of gut microbiota. An increase in gut load is observed and hypothesized to be a consequence of viral infection. Subsequent experiments in the presence and absence of gutota reveal that bacteria enhance baculirus virulence and pathogenicity.
Apomixis, a form of asexual reproduction through seeds, is of great interest in agriculture due to its potential applications. One element of apomix is apomesis is the deregulation of meiosis that results in a mitotic division. We have isolated a novel gene that directly controls entry into the second meiotic division. By combining a mutation in this gene with others that affect meiotic processes, we created a genotype called Mi in which meiosis is replaced by mitosis. The plants produce diploid gametes that are genetically identical to their mother.
In the post-genomic era, prioritization of disease-causing genes is a major challenge. Current methods exploit protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks for this task. These methods are based on the observation that genes causing similar diseases lie close to one another in a P network. However, these methods use a static picture of human PIs, while disease-specific tissues in P networks may be dramatically different. Here, we assess the contribution of tissue-specific information to prioritization. We integrate tissue gene expression with P information to construct tissue-specific PIs for 60 tissues and investigate their power. We find that tissue PIs considerably improve results compared to those using a generic network. Furthermore, they predict novel-disease associations, pointing to subclinical effects that may escape detection.
Vector-borne diseases such as malaria are a major public health problem in many parts of the world. Mosquitoes that transmit these diseases are becoming increasingly resistant to insecticides that are used to control them. We develop a mathematical model that describes the evolution of resistance to insecticides in mosquito populations. The model allows for differences between males and females in their exposure to insecticides and selection pressures, depending on the concentration of insecticide encountered. We use the model to compare two strategies for deploying insecticides: using them sequentially or as a mixture. Our results show that mixtures of insecticides are more likely to delay the spread of resistance than sequential use, but this depends on the effectiveness of the insecticides and the proportion of mosquitoes that encounter them. If the insecticides are not very effective against susceptible mosquitoes, sequential use may be more robust. Although mixtures slow the spread of resistance, they may not always outperform sequential use. For example, a mixture may last 5 years while individual insecticides last 3 and 4 years, giving an overall lifespan of 7 years for sequential use.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, is transmitted by triatomine bugs, including Rhodnius neglectus. The saliva of these hematophagous insects contains bioactive molecules that counteract host hemostasis, inflammation, and immune responses. In this study, we used next generation sequencing and mass spectrometry to investigate the content of Rhodnius neglectus saliva. We deposited 4, 230 DNA sequences in GenBank. A set of 636 proteins of putative secretory nature was extracted from assembled reads, of which 73 were confirmed by proteomic analysis. We characterized the saliva of Rhodni neglectus and detected serine protease transcripts. The presence of ubiquitous protein families was revealed, including lipocalins, ser protease inhibitors, antigen-5 metalloproteases, disintegrins, and odorant binding proteins.
The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans is a model organism used to study the interaction between nematodes and bacteria in soil. In this study, we used transcriptional profiling to identify genes that are differentially expressed in response to bacteria isolated from grassland nemodes and grassland soils. We found that many of these genes are involved in metabolism and innate immunity, suggesting they could influence nemode community dynamics in natural systems. We then used mutations to inactivate 21 of these genes and showed that most contribute to lifespan and fitness in a given bacterial environment. Although these bacteria are not a natural food source for C. elegans, we show that changes in food source, as can occur in environmental disturbance, have a large effect on gene expression with consequences for fitness. We also used regression to demonstrate that for many genes the degree of differential expression between bacterial environments predicts the magnitude of effect of loss of function on life traits in those environments.
Development of the mammalian blastocyst is a complex process that involves the formation of an inner cell mass surrounded by a trophoectoderm, a shell of cells that will form extraembryonic structures. We used multi-scale modeling to investigate the principles responsible for the robust establishment of these structures. Our results make three predictions, supported by quantitative imaging. First, stochasticity in the expression of critical genes promotes plasticity and has a role in organizing the mouse blastocyst. Second, asymmetry in the levels of variation ( fluctuation ) of Cdx and Oct4 provides a means to gain the benefits of noise-mediated plasticity while amelioring the detrimental effects of stochasticity. Finally, by the timing and pace of cell specification the embryo modulates plasticity and creates a window during which can continually read its environment and adjusts its fate.
Antibodies encoded by the germline genome have the ability to bind to a wide range of antigens due to structural flexibility in the germl gene. The affinity and specificity for a particular epitope increases as the antibody acquires somatic mutations in antigen-stimulated B cells. We investigated whether germl-encoded antibodies are optimal for polyspecificity by determining the basis for recognition of diverse antigens by antibodies encoded by three VH gene segments. We computationally redesigned antibodies encoded by a common VH gene but binding to different antigens to engage multiple antigens at once. The Rosetta multi-state process predicted antibody sequences for the entire heavy chain region, including framework, CDR, and CDR. The predicted sequences matched germl gene to a remarkable degree, revealing residues that enable polysity, i. e., binding many antigens with common sequence. In contrast, designing to bind a single antigen similar to mature sequence was returned, mimicking maturation. We demonstrated that Rosetta captures aspects of antibody/igen recognition. The hyperviable CDR often mediates much of mature specificity, but VH CDR, CDR, and immunoglobulin framework are critical for polyspecific germl. We computationally designed antibodies binding multiple antigens may retain polyspecific for diverse epitope.
Locusts exhibit two interconvertible behavioral phases: solitar and gregar. While solitar individuals are repelled by other locusts, gregar insects are attracted to conspecifics and form large aggregations such as marching hopper bands. At the individual level, crowding biases locusts towards the gregar form. To understand the formation of marching locust hop bands, we study phase change at the collective level, in a quantitative framework. We construct a partial integrodifferential model incorporating interplay between phase and spatial movement at the individual level to predict hopper formation at the population. Stability of our model reveals conditions for an outbreak, characterized by large transition to gregar. The model enables quantification of temporal dynamics of each phase, proportion of population that will gregarize, and time for this to occur. Numerical simulations describe aggregation structure and traveling clumps gregar.
Viral membrane fusion is a complex process that involves a series of conformational changes of viral envelope glycoproteins, called fusion proteins. Although high-resolution structures of viral proteins in their prefusion and postfusion states are available, the intermediate structures of the fusion pathway have been difficult to define because of their transient nature. Flaviruses have a class II fusion protein (E) that mediates fusion at acidic pH, which is converted from a dimer to trimer with a hair-like structure during fusion. Here, we show that tick-borne encephalitis virus virions exposed to alkaline instead of acidic pH are trapped in an intermediate conformation where E dimers dissociate and interact with membranes via fusion peptide without proceeding to membrane merger. Further treatment to low pH leads to fusion, suggesting that monomers correspond to elusive intermediate required to convert prefusion dimer into postfusion trimer.
Biodiversity hotspots, such as the Cape of South Africa, harbor a disproportionate number of plant species. However, our knowledge of plant extinctions and vulnerabilities lags behind that of vertebrates. Here, we investigate the drivers of extinction risk in plants, focusing on the Cape. By comparing Red List data for the British and South African floras, we show that the taxonomic distribution of extinction risk differs between regions, inconsistent with a simple, trait-based model of extinction. Using a comprehensive phylogenetic tree for the Cape, we find a phylogenetic signal in the distribution of plant risks, but most threatened species cluster at the tips of the phylogeny, opposite to trends in mammals. Analyzing the distribution of threatened species across 11 exemplar clades, we suggest mode of speciation best explains the phylogenetic structure of risks in plants of the Cape. Our results demonstrate that explanations for elevated risk in plants of the Cape differ from those recognized for vertebrates. In the Cape, risk is higher for young and fast-evolving plant lineages and cannot be explained by correlations with simple traits. Critically, we find that most vulnerable species are marching towards extinction at a rapid pace independently from anthropogenic effects.
Candida albicans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that is phagocytosed by the innate immune system to prevent infection. Dectin-1 is the major phagoc receptor involved in anti-fungal immunity. We have identified two new proteins that interact with Dect-1 in macrophages, Bruton’s Tyrosine Kinase (TK) and Vav. TK and Vav are recruited to phagosomes containing C. albicans yeasts or hyphae but are absent from mature phagosomes. TK and Vav localize to the cuff surrounding hypha while Dect-1 lines the length of the phagosome. TK and V colocalize with PI (3, 4, 5)P3 and Fynin at the phagosome but not diacylglycerol (DAG) which marks mature phagosomes. Using a TK inhibitor, we show TK contributes to DAG at the phagosome and the recruitment of PKε TK or Vav-deficient peritoneal macrophages display a defect in C. alb phagytosis. Bone-derived macrophages lacking TK or Vav show reduced C. alb uptake comparable toect-1 deficient. TK or Vav-deficient mice are more susceptible to systemic. alb infection than wild mice.
Rift Valley fever (RV) is a vector-borne disease affecting ruminants and humans. Madagascar was heavily affected by RV in 2008–200, with evidence of large spread of the disease. To optimize available resources by RV surveillance in Madagascar, it is essential to identify at-risk environments. This study aimed to identify environmental factors favoring RV transmission in cattle and humans, as well as human behaviors favoring human infection in Malag contexts. We characterized Malag environments using Multiple Factor Analysis (FA) and analyzed cattle and human serological data at national level using Generalized Mixed Models, with serological status (cattle or human ) as response and FA, as well as other risk factors (density, behavior) as explanatory variables. We found that cattle and human seroprevalence were positively associated with humid environments (p<.001). Areas with high cattle density were at risk (p<.01; OR=2.6), and frequent contact with raw milk contributed to human infection (OR=1.6). Our study highlighted eastern, western, and northwestern parts as high-risk for RV transmission in cattle.
Prions are self-propagating protein conformations that can be transmitted between non-identical proteins, e. g. between homologous proteins from different species. However, transmission of the prion state is frequently inefficient and the underlying mechanisms are not clear. Here, we use a yeast Rq1PIN]-based experimental system to explore the nature of transmission barriers. We show that Rq encompasses multiple prion determinants that can independently drive amyloid formation in vitro and transmit the PIN prion state in vivo. Subsequent analysis of PIN transmission between Rq fragments with different pr determinants established that ( i ) one Q-rich region is required and usually sufficient for transmission; ( ii ) despite identical sequences of QNs, transmissions are impeded by barriers of strength.
Inference of complex population genetic models from genomic data is often infeasible due to the high dimensionality of the data. We introduce a novel likelihood-free inference framework that employs deep learning, a powerful machine learning technique, to circumvent this problem. Deep learning makes use of multilayer neural networks to learn a feature function from input ( e. g., hundreds of summary statistics ) to output ( e. g. genetic parameters of interest ). We demonstrate that deep learning can be employed for population inference and learning features from data. We focus on the problem of jointly inferring natural selection and demography in form of population size history. Our method separates demography from selection without sequential steps for these factors. Demography and selection are studied jointly motivated by Drosila, where selection confounds demographic analysis. We apply our method to 197 Drosila melanogaster genomes from Zambia to infer demography and regions of genome under selection. We find regions that have experienced sweeps and under selection ( soft or balancing ) sweeps. Sweeps and balancing occur more frequently closer to chromosome centre. Demographic inference suggests previously bottlenecks for Dila melanaster are too extreme.
Human papillomavirus (HPV) oncogenes are necessary for the development of anogenital and orophngeal cancers. We show that E6/E7-expressing cells are hypersensitive to cisplatin, a DNA crosslinking agent, and have defects in repairing interstrand crosslinks (ICL). We elucidate how E7 attenuates the Fanconi anemia (FA) DNA repair pathway. E7 activates the pathway by increasing Fanc2 monoubiquination and foci formation, but inhibits completion of repair by multiple mechanisms.7 impairs F2 localization with double-strand breaks (DSB), hindering Rad51 recruitment to DS. Further,7 causes delayedanc2 deubiquination, important for ICL repair. Delayedanc2 deubination is associated with chromatin retention ofanc, hindering US1 deubitinating activity and persistently activated ATR/CHK-1/p565anc signaling.7 mediated p53 degradation does not hamper cell cycle processanc modifications but abrogates repair by disruptinganc deubination. Further7 reducesanc expression and foci of Pal2, a downstreamanc repair protein. These findings uncover mechanisms by which HPV oncogen contribute to genomic instability and response to cispl therapies.
Transmission of Onchocerca volulus has been interrupted in the Southern Chiapas focus of Mexico, one of the major onchocerciasis foci in Latin America. Since 1998, all 559 communities in this focus have undergone semi-annual treatment with ivermectin. In 2003, iverectin frequency was shifted to twice a year in 50 communities, and an additional 113 communities were added to quarterly treatment in 2009 to achieve rapid suppression. Epidemiologic and entomologic assessments were performed in six sentinel communities with 2 rounds ofiverect treatment per year and three extra-sent communities with 4 roundsiverect per year. In the dry season 2011, none of 67,924 Simulium ochum collected from this focus were found to contain DNA by PCR-ELISA, resulting in an upper bound of the 95% confidence interval (95%-CI) of infective rate in vectors 0.06/2,000 examined. Serologic testing for Onocerca volulus exposure on 4,230 children 5 years old of a total 10,280 in this group revealed 2/4,230 were exposed (0.05%; one 95%CI=0.08% ).
Listeria monocytogen is a Gram-positive facultative intracellular pathogen that invades mammalian cells and escapes from membrane-bound vacuoles to replicate in the host cytos. PrA is a transcriptional activator required for intracellular bacterial growth and spread to adjacent cells. However, the signal that activates Pr has not been defined. We show that L monocogen secretes a small peptide pherone, pA, which enhances escape from host vacoles and may facilitate Pr activation. The pherone is generated by proteolytic processing of lipoprotein signal. The lipoprotein is dispensable for pathogenesis, but bacteria lacking pher are attenuated for virulence in mice and have reduced escape efficiency from vacoles of nonphagocytic cells. Mut activation restores virulence and eliminates need for pher signaling. The pher may signal L monocogen presence within vacole, stimulating expression of products that contribute to escape and Pr to promote growth in cyol.
Vibrio cholera, the causative agent of cholera, is a highly adaptable pathogen that is able to colonize host intestines and combat host-produced reactive oxygen species ( ROS ) during infection. To understand the molecular mechanisms by which V. cholera overcomes ROS in vivo, we performed a whole-genome transposon sequencing ( T-seq ) by comparing gene requirements for colonization in mice with and without treatment of the antioxidant N-acetyl cystine. We found that mutants of the methyl-directed repair ( M ) system, such as MutS, displayed colonization advantages in untreated, ROS-rich mice but not in N-treated mice. Further analyses suggest that accumulation of catalase-producing and rugose variants in N- mice was the cause of Mut mutant enrichment by oxidative stress during infection. We also found that rugose variants revert to smooth colonies upon aerobic in vitro. Moreover, the mutation rate of wildtype colonized in N mice was higher than in mice.
Mutations in the MLH3 gene in baker’s yeast alter meiotic recombination outcomes by increasing non-crossover events genome-wide. The MLH3 protein is an endonuclease that is hypothesized to act in meiosis to resolve Holliday junctions into crossovers and also plays a minor role in eukaryotic DNA repair ( MMR). We analyzed 60 new ML3 alleles in baker’s yeast, five of which specifically disrupted MMR and one (MLH3-32) disrupted meiotic crossing over. We purified and characterized ML3-32 (MR+, crossover-) and ML3-45 (MR-, crossover-), both of which displayed wild-type endonuc activities in vitro. ML2SH, an SH complex that acts with ML3 in MMR, stimulated the enduc activity of ML-32 but not ML-45, suggesting ML-45 is defective in SH interactions. We constructed whole-genome recombination maps for wild-type MR+, MR-, MR+, enduc defective and ML3 mutants in S288/Y789 background. Compared to wild-type, all ML3 mutants showed increases in the number of non-crossover events consistent with recombination intermediates being resolved through alternative pathways.
The evolution of drug resistance in bacterial populations is a major concern in the treatment of diseases such as tuberculosis, malaria, Staphylococcus aureus and gonorrhea. The use of antibiotics has led to rapidly increasing levels of drug resistance, necessitating the switch to new drugs and discontinuation of older ones. However, resistance often persists or declines slowly after treatment is stopped. This is usually ascribed to low fitness costs of resistance in the absence of drug. We show that host population structure, in particular heterogeneity in number of contacts, also plays an important role in reversion dynamics. During treatment, host structure leads to non-random distribution of resistant strains among the population. After drug discontinuation, it affects competition, resulting in mitigation of fitness advantages. As a consequence, we observe lower rate of reversion and lower probability of reversion to sensitivity on population level after treatment is stopped. Our simulations show impact of heterogeneity in structure is maximal in biologically plausible range, when costs of resistance are small.
Autism spectrum disorders (ASDs) are highly heritable and characterized by deficits in social interaction and communication as well as restricted and repetitive behaviors. Although a number of highly penetrant ASD variants have been identified, there is growing evidence to support a role for combinatorial effects arising from contributions of multiple loci. By examining synaptic and circadian phenotypes resulting from dosage of unique human-fly orthologs in Drosophila, we observe synergistic interactions between pairs of informatically-identified candidate genes orthologs that are jointly affected by de novo copy number (CN) variants. These CNs were found in the genomes of individuals with autism, including one carrying 22q11. 2 deletion. We demonstrate that dosage of the Drosila orthologs of candidate genes de novo CN that only display single gene neurological defects similar to previously in Drosila models of ASD variants. We considered dosage within the set of ortholog candidate genes affected by same human novo CN. For three CN with complete ortholog relationships, we observed synergistic effects following simultaneous change of gene pairs from single CN. The phenotyp variation atrosila that results from these genetic supports concordant outcome all gene following direction human copy change. We observe specificity and transitivity between interact, within and CN candidate sets supporting distinct aetiologies. We show different interactions divergent processes demonstrating moleculareti.
Cerebral malaria (ECM) caused by Plasmodium berghei AN infection of C57/6 mice is associated with the accumulation of brain-infiltrating CD8 T cells. However, the mechanisms through which they mediate pathogenic activity remain poorly understood. Utilizing intravital microscopy and flow cytometry, we show that brain-infiltrating T cells accumulate in the perascular spaces of mice infected with ECM-inducing ( P berg AN ) and non-inducing ( berg NK ) infections. However, perascular T cells displayed arrested behavior during berg AN infection, despite brain-accumulating CD+ T exhibiting activation phenotypes during both infections. We observed T forming long-term interactions with CXCR1-bearing antigen presenting cells within brains during berg AN, but abation failed to prevent ECM. Pathogenic CD+ T colocalized with apoptotic CD31-expressing endothelial cells within brain during ECM. However, apoptosis was rare and did not result in loss of vasculature or extensive disruption to its integrity during ECM.
Tungias is a parasitic disease caused by the sand flea Tungaans (also known as jigger flea) that affects communities living in precarious conditions in tropical and sub-Saharan countries. This study aimed to determine the burden of tungias in Viga County, Kenya. This was a cross-sectional study conducted in 21 villages in 3 sublocations of Viga, western Kenya. A total 437 participants aged ≥5 years were clinically examined for tungias after consenting to the study. Diagnosis was made following standard methods. A semi-structured questionnaire was administered to assess socio-demographic factors, housing, presence of animals, and knowledge related tungias. Data were analyzed using bivariate and multivariate analysis. GIS was used to map the geographic distribution of tungias in the area. The overall prevalence was 21.5% (95% CI 17.7–25.3 ). Cases were visualized in a map. Multivariate analysis suggested that tungias was associated with variables indicating low economic status: monthly income ≤ Ksh 100 (OR 27.85; 95% CI 4.13–187.59 ), floor 0.36 (0.13–1.024 ), lack of toilet (4.27 0.82–22.34 ), age ≤14 (27.414 10.–74.99 ), no footwear (1.98.987.97 ) and resting inside house (.93.96.89 ).
Auxin patterning in the root tip of Arabidopsis thaliana depends on a mutual feedback between auxin and cytokinins. This feedback is mediated by the PIN class of auxin efflux transporters and AHP, an inhibitor of cytokinin signalling. We developed a parsimonious computational model of aux transport that considers regulation of auxin transport within a spatial context, taking into account cell shape and polarity and cell walls. Our analysis shows that an informative cytokin pattern generated by diffusion is unlikely and not required for correct auxin patterning. Instead, aux-dependent modifications of cytokin response rather than variations in cytokin levels allow necessary feedbacks that can amplify and stabilise auxin. Our simulations demonstrate importance of hormonal regulation of auxin efflux for robustness. We predict and experimentally verify a role of AUX and LAX/1 aux influx transporters in vascular patterning. We show that polarisation of PIN generates an aux circuit that stabilises accumulation of aux within xylem axis and provides mechanism for aux to accumulate in xylem-pole cells, an early step in lateral root initiation.
Neuropeptide F (NPF) and nitric oxide (NO) signaling plays a regulatory role in phase-related locomotor plasticity in the migratory locust Locusta migratoria. We report that the conserved transcription factor cAMP response element-binding protein B (CRE-B) is a key mediator in the signaling pathway from NPF to NO in the migratory locust, triggering locomotor activity between solitary and gregarious phases. CRE-B directly activates brain nitric oxide synthase (NOS) expression by interacting with the NOS promoter. Phosphorylation at serine 110 of CRE-B changes in response to population variation and is negatively controlled by N2. CRE-B involvement in N2-regulated locomotor plasticity is validated by RNA interference (RNAi) and behavioral assay. Protein kinase mediates the effects of N on CRE-B phosphorylation and OS transcription.
In Drosophila melanogaster, the earliest stages of development are driven by maternally deposited proteins and mRNAs. The maternal-to-zyotic transition ( MZ ) occurs hours after fertilization, when the zotic genome is transcribed. We used chromatin immunoprecipitation coupled with high-throughput (IP-Seq ) to map regions bound by the zinc-finger protein Zelda ( ZLD ) before, during, and after the MZ. We identified thousands of regions bound by ZLD in cycle 8 embryos, most of which remain through cycle 14. Early Z-bound regions include the promoters and enhancers of genes transcribed at this stage. We also observed Z bound cycle 8 to the promoters of genes first transcribed during the MZ and virtually all known enhancers bound cycle 14 by transcription factors that regulate gene activation during the MZ. The association between Z binding and MZ activity is so strong that Z can be used to identify promoters and regulatory sequences with specificity.
Protein-protein interactions (PPIs) are essential for virtually all biological processes. The timing of these interactions is critical for proper function. Circadian clocks, which operate on a 24-hour cycle, regulate important physiological processes. However, the dynamics of PIs on this timescale are largely unknown. We identified 109 novel PIs among circadian proteins using a yeast-two-hybrid approach. The interaction between phosphatase 1 and CLOCK/BMAL resulted in BMAL destabilization. We constructed a dynamic circadian PI network predicting PIs using circadian expression data. Systematic circadian phenotyping (RNAi and overexpression ) suggests a crucial role for components in dynamic interactions. Analysis of a dynamic network in liver revealed that interacting proteins are expressed at similar times to restrict interactions to specific phases. We predict that circadian PIs dynamically connect important processes (signal transduction, cell cycle, etc. ) contributing to temporal organization of physiology in an unprecedented manner.
Nematode protein allergens (NP) are a class of lipid-binding proteins found in nematodes. They are synthesized as large, tandemly repetitive proteins that are post-translationally cleaved into multiple copies of small lipid-binding proteins with identical fatty acid and retin (A)-binding characteristics. These proteins are central to transport and distribution of hydrophobic compounds between nematode tissues, and may play roles in nutrient scavenging, immunomodulation and IgE antibody responses in infection. In some species, repeating units are diverse in amino acid, but in ascar and filarial nemodes, many are identical or near-ident. A-1 is the most repeating unit of NP of Ascaris su, similar to Ascar lumicoid, the large roundworm of humans. Immune responses to NP have been associated with acquired resistance to infection in humans, and immune to them is under genetic control. The structure of A-1 was determined by nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy. The protein adopts a novel seven-helical fold comprising a central helix that participates in two four-hel bundles either side. Discrete hydrophobic ligand-binding sites are in N-terminal and C-terminal bundles, and amino sidechains affected ligand ( acid ) were identified. Recombinant A1 contains tightly-bound ligand of bacterial origin one site.
Between 1998 and 2008, there were 39,677 reported cases of ciguatera poisoning in 17 Pacific Island Countries and Territories (PITCs), with a mean annual incidence of 194 cases per 100,000 people. This represents a 60% increase in annual incidence compared to the 104 cases per 100,000 reported between 1973 and 1983. Taking into account underreporting, it is estimated that 500,000 Pacific Islanders may have suffered from cigater poisoning in the last 35 years. The incidence of cigater in the Pacific is higher than reported globally and locally. Ciguater poisoning is characterized by acute neurologic, gastrointestinal, and cardiac symptoms, with chronic neurologic symptoms lasting weeks to months.
Trypanosoma cruzi is the causative agent of Chagas disease, a chronic disease characterized by the persistence of the parasite and impairment of the cellular immune response. In this study, we investigated the impact of benznidazole treatment on the functional response of Trypanosoma cruzi-specific CD4CD8+ T cells in Chagas patients. Thirty-eight Chagas patients (20 asymptomatic and 18 symptomatic ) and twelve healthy controls were enrolled. Peripheral blood mononuclear cells were stimulated with soluble T cruzi antigens to analyze the production of cytokines and cytotoxic molecules by CD4CD+8 cells before and after benidazole treatment. Additionally, expression and co-expression of five inhibitory receptors in patients after treatment were studied using multiparameter flow cytometry. The frequency of CD4CD+ cells was higher in Chagas patients compared to healthy donors. Furthermore, a higher ratio of CD4CDlowCDhigh was observed in Chagas patients than healthy. CD4CD+ cells expressed and co-expressed higher levels of inhibitory receptors in proportion to the severity of pathology. Benidazole reduced the frequency of CD4CD cells and decreased the ratio CDCDlowCDhigh. Co-expression of inhibitory was reduced after treatment with enhancement of multifunctional capacity CD4CD. After, increase in frequency T cruzi-specific CD4CD expressing IL-2 and TN-α was observed. CD4CD could play important role in control cruz infection since able to produce effector molecules for parasite. Benidazole partially reversed exhaustion caused by cruz in cells with improvement of T cruz-specific CD4CD.
Arabidopsis PLC2 is a phosphoinospecific phospholipase involved in phosphoinid metabolism and the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) stress response. Phosphoinides are important lipid signals in plant development and stress, but multiple isoforms of the phosphoin biosynthetic genes hamper our understanding of the enzymes in each step of the pathway and their roles in growth. We report that phosphoin-specific phospholipase 2 (PLC2) is the primary phospholip in phosphoin metabolism and is involved in seedling growth and ER responses in Arabidopsis thalian. Lipid profiling of plc mutants showed plc-1 increased levels of phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate and phosphatidyositol 4,5-bisphosphate, suggesting the phosphoin metabolic pathway is impaired.PLC displayed distinct expression and localized at the plasma membrane in different cell types where phosphoin signaling occurs. The plc-1 mutant showed growth defect was complemented by heterologous expression ofPLC, suggesting phosphoin phospholipase activity byPLC is required for growth. Moreover, plc-1 showed hypersensitive response to ER as evidenced by phenotypes and gene profiles.
In this article, we challenge the reductionist assumption that causation in the physical world occurs only at the micro level by employing a principled, well-defined measure of intrinsic cause-effect power–integrated (Φ). We show that according to this measure, it is possible for a macro level to “beat” the micro. We evaluate simple systems for Φ across different spatial and temporal scales by considering all possible black boxes, which are macro elements consisting of one or more micro elements over one or more updates. We evaluate cause power based on inputs and outputs of the black, ignoring internal elements that support their input–output function. We show that black elements can have more inputs and outputs than corresponding micro, revealing emergence of high-order mechanisms and constraints not apparent at micro. As a consequence, a black system can have higher Φ than its constituents by having more mechanisms that are more interconnected. We also show that for a given system, one can identify maxima Φ across spatiotemporal scales. We demonstrate this framework on a biological system, the Boolean model of fission yeast cell cycle, and identify maxima during its simulated function. These maxima correspond to levels of organization where emergent cause properties come into focus, providing a natural point for scientific inquiries.
Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are produced in the mitochondrial respiratory chain (RC) play a dual role in modulating cellular adaptation to the environment and causing damage under conditions of hypoxia/reoxygenation relevant to various diseases and transplantation. To investigate the role of ROS in cell survival, we extended our model of complex III to account for electron transport in the RC coupled to proton translocation, transmembrane electrochemical generation, TCA reactions and substrate transport to mitochondria. We measured electron fluxes in rat mitochondria fueled by succinate or pyruvate malate and dynamics of NAD reduction by reverse transport through succinate complex I. Our analysis revealed association of ROS production with specific electron transporters and their combinations in complexes I and III. We found that bistability, a property of complex III, remains for the whole RC. Conditions for switching to a state with high free radicals in III were predicted and confirmed.
Transport of intracellular cargo is essential for eukaryotic cells and is facilitated by motor proteins that convert chemical energy into kinetic energy. Motor proteins work in teams to enable unidirectional and bidirectional transport of intracellular cargo over long distances. Disruptions of the underlying mechanisms, caused by mutations that alter motor characteristics, are known to cause neurodegenerative diseases. For example, phosphorylation of the kines motor domain at serine is implicated in Huntington’s disease. We report the effects of mutations on transport properties of cargo carried by wild-type and mutant motors. Results indicate that mutants with altered stall forces determine average velocity and run-length even when outnumbered by wild motors in the ensemble. Mutants gain a competitive advantage and increase run-length when the load is near the mutant’s stall force or a multiple of its stall. We develop a semi-analy method to analyze transport by multiple motors of types. The technique determines transition rates between various configurations of motors carrying cargo using rates between absolute configurations. This enables computation of biologically relevant quantities like velocity and run-length without Monte Carlo. Our method is implementable and provide software for use.
CAC1 is a gene that encodes a subunit of high-voltage-gated Ca2+ channels, which are central to synaptic plasticity and have been associated with learning and psychiatric disorders. We investigated the role of Cna1 in learning by selectively ablating the gene in mice and analyzing their behavior on an operant discrimination task. We used a detailed analysis of individual learning in terms of behavioral strategies combined with computational models to show that Cna knockout does not impair learning in general, but has a specific effect: most knockout mice increased reward across trials by adapting an outcome-based strategy, while most controls adopted the intended cue-association rule.
Aedes aegypt mosquitoes infected with Wolbachia bacteria are being released to suppress arbovirus around the world. Their ability to invade and persist in the field will depend on their interactions with environmental conditions, as larvae are often exposed to fluctuating and extreme temperatures. In this study, Ae.egypt larvae were infected with different types of Wolia ( wMel, wAlB and wPopCLA ) and reared under diurnal cyclical temperatures. We found that wMel and wPopCLA-infected larvae reared at 26–37°C had reduced expression of cytoplasmic incompatibility, a reproductive manipulation induced by Wolia. We also observed a reduction in Wolia density in adults. Furthermore, w and wPopCLA were not transmitted to the next generation when exposed to 26–37 across all stages. In contrast, wB was maintained at high density, exhibited cytoplasm incompat, and transmitted to offspring with high fidelity under this cycle.
Adenoviruses are important human pathogens that have been developed as vectors for gene therapies and vaccines. Previous studies indicated that infections with adenoviruses are self-limiting in immunocompetent hosts with evidence of persistence in adenoid tissue. We sought to understand the natural history of adenirus infections in non-human primates and discovered that healthy populations of great apes (chimpanzees, bonobos, gorillas and orangans ) and macques shed substantial quantities of adeniruses in stool. Shedding from asymptomatic humans was much less frequent. We purified and sequenced 30 adeniruses from apes and 3 adeniruses from macques. Analyses of ape adenirus sequences as well as chimpanzee adenirus we previously reported together with 22 adenirus available from GenBank revealed that ape adeniruses could be classified into species corresponding human adenirus B, C, E. There was evidence intraspecies recombination adenirus and high phylogenetic relatedness adenirus across primate provided evidence for species transmission occurred in history B E viruses.
Chromatin, the fundamental unit of eukaryotic genome packaging, is a protein-DNA complex called the nucleosome, where 146–147 base pairs of DNA are wrapped 1.75 times around a histone core. To function in cellular processes, nucleosomal DNA must be unwrapped. Although unwrapping has been experimentally investigated, details at the atomic level are not well understood. Here, we used molecular simulation with enhanced sampling to calculate free profiles for unwrapping the outerhelical turn of nucleosomal DNA. We found a free change of about 11. 5 kcal/mol for unwr, in agreement with single molecule experiments. The simulation revealed a variety of conformation states, indicating many paths to superhelical unwr, but the dominant is likely asymmetric. At one end of DNA, first five b unwrap, then second five at same end with increase free. Unwrapping then starts at other end, ten unwrap. During further unwr 15, advances at one end, then other unwr to complete superhel turn.
Lipocalin Apolipoprotein D (ApoD) is a secreted by astrocytes in the nervous system to protect neurons from oxidative stress. It is known to optimize autophagy and prevent neurodegeneration, but the mechanism is unknown. Here, we show that Apo is endocytosed and targeted to vulnerable lysosomes in a stress-dependent manner. Apo is stable in acidic environment and necessary for lysosomes to recover from oxidation-induced alkalinization in astrocytes and neurons. This is accomplished by preventing lysosomal permeabilization. Two lysosomal processes, myelin phagocytosis by astrocytes and neurodegeneration-triggered autagy in Drosophila, require Apo-related lipocalins.
The sandfly Phlebotus orientalis is the main vector of visceral leishmaniasis (VL) caused by Leishmania donovani in East Africa. Here, we report on the biology and susceptibility to L. donani of P. orient colonies from two geographically distant localities in Ethiopia: a non-endemic site in the lowlands Melka Wer (MW) and an endemic of VL in the highlands Addis Z (AZ). We found marked differences in life-cycle parameters between the two colonies, including distinct requirements for larval food and humidity during pupation. However, genetic analyses using Random Amplified Polymorphic (RAP) PCR and DNA sequencing of cytB and COI genes did not reveal any genetic differences between the two colonies. F1 hybrids developed higher fecundity than the parental colonies. We studied susceptibility of P. orient to L.ani by experimental infections. Even the lowest infective dose (2×103/ml) was sufficient for successful establishment of L.ani in about 50% of P orient females. Using higher infective doses, infection rates were around 90% for both colonies. Leish development in P orient was fast, with presence of metacylic promastigotes in thoracic midgut and colonization of stomal valve hapt by homonads recorded in P orient females by five post-blood. Both MW and AZ of P orient were highly susceptible to Ethiopian Lani strains.
Schistosomiasis japonica is a major public health priority in China due to its serious health and economic impacts. However, it has not been included in the Global Burden of Disease ( GBD ) study. Therefore, the quality of life and disability ( DW ) for advanced schosomias japonica cases need to be taken into account in the estimation of schosias burden. A patient-based quality-of-life evaluation was performed for schos japon suspected or confirmed cases in a schos japon-hyperemic county of the People's Republic of China ( P. R. China. ) using a short questionnaire and physical examination.
