Disability and morbidity were assessed in confirmed cases using the European quality of life questionnaire with additional dimension ( EQ-5D ), ultrasonography and laboratory. The age-specific DW for schos japon was estimated based on patients' self-rated scores on the analogue scale. The relationships between health, morbidity and DW were explored using multivariate models. Of 506 candidates, 215 were confirmed schos japon and evaluated. Most patients reported impairments in at least one dimension such as pain (90. 7% ), activities (87.9 ) and anxiety or depression (80.9 ). The DW was 0.447 and age-specific ranged from 0. among 30–44 years to 0. among ≥60. DW were associated with loss capacity, abnormal, ascites and hepatitis B, while splenectomy and albumin were protective for life.
Sleeping sickness, also known as African trypanosomias, is a highly prevalent parasitic vector-borne disease in sub-Saharan Africa. Humans acquire the disease following the bite of a tset fly infected with the protozoan Trypanosoma brucei. Over the last decade, diagnostic capacity to estimate sleeping sickness prevalence has improved in active-finding areas but passive surveillance is lacking in much of sub-Saharan Africa. This study examined the use of national census data ( 1999 ) to estimate vulnerability and disability in Kenya's tse belts. A multilevel study estimated the likelihood of disability in individuals, nested within households, within tse fly of varying levels of poverty. Residents and recent migrants of working age were studied. The study conceptualised tse's impact on disability via two pathways: directly from the bite of pathogenic tse resulting in sleeping infection or indirectly, as potential takes out of agricultural and diseased livestock leads to morbidity and mortality, contributing to nutritional and poverty. The study identified tse belts with increased prevalence and evaluated direct and indirect pathways. Incorporating reports from the census is a promising tool that may enhance sleeping programs in sub-Saharan. The burdens of sleeping and takes and opportunity of production in areas are contributors to disability tse-infested.
Hexamethylene bisacetamide (HMBA) is a potent inducer of cell differentiation and HIV production in chronically infected cells. In this study, we demonstrate that HMBA transiently activates the PI3/Akt pathway, which leads to the phosphorylation of HEXIM and subsequent release of active transcription elongation factor (PTEF) from its transcriptionally inactive complex with HEXIM and 7 small nuclear RNA (snRNA). As a result, PF is recruited to the HIV promoter to stimulate transcription and viral production. Despite continuous presence of HM, released PF rapidly reassociates with 7snRNA and HEXIM. In contrast, mutant HEXIM that cannot be phosphorylated and released PF and 7sn via PI/Akt pathway antagonizes HM-mediated induction of viral production.
Cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL), caused by New World Leishmania (Viannia) species, is associated with the risk of developing mucosal (ML) or disseminated cutaneous leishmanias (DCL). After the formation of a primary skin lesion at the site of the bite by Leish-infected sand fly, the infection can disseminate to form secondary lesions. This metastatic phenotype causes significant morbidity and is associated with a hyper-inflammatory response leading to destruction of nasophary tissues in ML and appearance of numerous ulcerated skin lesions in D. Recently, this aggressive phenotype was connected to the presence of Leish RNA (LRV) in L. guyanensis, showing LRV responsible for elevated parasitemia, hyper-inflammation and overall exacerbation of disease. Further studies of this relationship and LRV in other Leish strains would benefit from improved methods of detection and quantitation, especially not dependent on prior LRV sequence. This study reports various techniques, including anti-dRNA monoclonal antibody (J) for specific and quantitative recognition of LRV in sequence-independent fashion. Applications of J include immunofluorescence, ELISA and dot techniques complementing arsenal of other tools such as nucleic acid purification and real-time PCR. We evaluate each method and demonstrate LRV detection by J in several strains, freshly isolated patient sample and lesionops of infected mice.
Enteropathogenic and enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EPEC) and enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) are closely related pathogens that attach to intestinal epithelial cells and promote cytoskeletal rearrangements into protrusions called actin pedestals. PEC employs the tyrosine phosphorylated transmembrane receptor Tir, while EHE relies on the multivalent scaffolding protein EspFU. The formation of these pedestals correlates with bacterial colonization in animal models, but the precise function of pedest in infection remains unclear. We characterized the colonization of PEC and EC during polarized epithelial cells. Both PEC and EC formed distinct bacterial communities or “colonies ” that encompassed multiple cells. Tir and EspFU as well as the Arp2/3 complex were critical for colony expansion over time. Unexpectedly, EspFU accelerated colony formation compared to PEC, as Esp-mediated actin assembly drove bacterial motility to junctions, where bacteria formed a pedestal on a neighboring cell and divided, allowing one daughter to disengage and infect second. Collectively, these data reveal Esp enhances epithelial colonization by actin-based motility and efficient cell-to-cell transmission.
Extracellular vesicles (EVs) play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of helminth pathogens, and their purification is necessary for downstream studies and applications. The most widely used method for EV purification is differential centrifugation (DC), but size exclusion chromatography (SEC) has been used for EV from other pathogens. This study compares DC and SEC for EV purification from Fasciola hepatica, a helminth pathogen. EVs were collected from culture media and purified by DC or SEC. Transmission electron and atomic force microscopy showed that SEC EVs were smaller and less diverse than DC EVs. Protein quantification and Western blotting showed that SEC had a higher EV to excretory-secretory protein (ESP) yield ratio than DC, with reduced soluble cathepsin proteases in SEC EV. Proteomic analysis showed DC contamination with ESP, with increased protein identifications and peptide hits in DC EV compared to SEC EV. SEC EV contained less tegument proteins than DC EV. These results suggest that DC and SEC do not isolate equivalent EV populations and caution should be taken in choice of purification method, with DC including free proteins and tegument artefacts. We propose that SEC should be used prior to downstream studies.
Reverse engineering of post-transcriptional regulation of gap genes in Drosophila melanogaster. In this study, we use a systems biology approach to infer regulatory mechanisms of the gap genes Krüpp, knir, and giant in Drosila melanogaster. We use detailed, quantitative datasets of mRNA and protein expression to fit a model of postcription regulation and establish its structural and practical identifiability. Our results demonstrate that postcription is not required for patterning in this system, but is necessary for proper control of protein levels.
Rotavirus is a major cause of diarrhea worldwide and exhibits a pronounced tropism for the intestinal epithelial cells (IEC) of the small intestine. Both infants and neonatal mice are highly susceptible to infection, whereas adults remain asymptomatic and shed only low numbers of viral particles. Here, we investigated the age-dependent mechanisms of the intestinal epithelial innate immune response to rotavirus infection in an oral mouse model. We found that the expression of the innate receptor for viral dsRNA, Toll-like receptor 3 (TLR3) was low in the epithelium of suckling mice but strongly increased during the postnatal period inversely correlating with rotavirus susceptibility, viral shedding and histological damage. Adult mice deficient in TLR3 (TLR3−/−) or the adaptor molecule TRIF (TRIFL2) exerted significantly higher viral shedding and epithelial expression of proinflammatory and antiviral genes compared to wild-type animals. In contrast, neonatal mice deficient in TLR or TRIF did not display impaired stimulation or enhanced rotavirus susceptibility. Using chimeric mice, a contribution of the non-hematietic compartment in TRIF-mediated antiral response was detected in adult animals. Finally, a significant increase of TLR expression was detected in human intestinal biops. Thus, upregulation of epithelial TLR during infancy might contribute to age-dependent rotavirus susceptibility.
Autism spectrum disorder (ASD) is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by impaired social interaction, communication, and repetitive behavior. The etiology of ASD is not fully understood, but genetic factors are thought to play a major role. In this study, we report results from whole-exome sequencing (WES) of 1, 039 subjects with ASD and 870 controls from the National Institute of Mental Health (NIH) repository with similar ancestry to cases. We used two sequencing methods to produce variant calls and compared the distribution of rare variants between centers. We filtered variants by fraction of missing data, read depth, and balance of alternative reads. We evaluated seven samples sequenced at both centers and found similar results. We addressed how to combine data and results from centers. Gene-based association was an obvious choice, but should we combine statistics across centers (meta-analysis) or combine data then analyze (mega)? We showed that mega-analysis has better power than meta-analysis for gene-based tests. We explored the impact of population structure on rare variant analysis and found that it can confound case-control studies by clustering variants in ancestry. However, principal component analyses were sufficient to control for ancestry and produce appropriate distributions. We used gene-based tests and mega-analysis and found no new risk genes for ASD in this sample. Our results suggest that gene tests require larger samples before being effective for discovery, even for a disorder like ASD.
Mycetoma is the most common causative agent of eumycoma in Sudan and is characterized by the formation of grains. Many people are exposed to the causative agent, but only a small number develop infection. Mycetoma contains chitin in its cell wall, which can trigger the human immune system. We investigated the association between polymorphisms in the chitin-degrading enzyme genes chotidase and AMCase and the incidence of myetoma in a Sudanese population. We studied polymorphisms in 112 eycoma patients and 103 controls, including a 24-b insertion in the chotidase gene (rs1317 ) and single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) in AMCase (617 ). We also studied SNP (41292 ) and 10-b insertion in the 5’UT region of AMCase (143088 ). DNA was isolated from blood and genotypes were determined using PCR-RP. Histological staining proved the presence of chitin in the grain. We found that polymorphism in chidase was associated with increased odds of eoma (OR 2.9; p.004 ). No association was found for polymorphisms in AMCase (all>.05 )
Herpes simplex virus (HSV) is a prototype for viral latency with well-defined lytic and latent phases. However, the quiescence of latency has been questioned with evidence that ly genes can be transcribed in this state. Here we show that lytic and latent phases are less clearly defined in two ways. First, half of HSV spread to latently infected sites occurred beyond initial infection. Second, we show that ly promoters drive protein expression during latency.
Prion Strain Differences in Accumulation of PrPSc on Neurons and Glia Are Associated with Similar Profiles of Neuroinflammatory Genes: Comparison of Three Prion Strains.
Chromosome organization is essential for regulating gene expression and cell function. Chromosomes are long, densely packed, topologically constrained polymers, making it challenging to develop models that capture their multi-scale dynamics. We propose a strategy to develop coarse-grained models for self-avoiding polymers on a lattice, accounting for entanglement and volumic density. Our scheme captures steady-state and dynamical properties and tracks dynamics at different coarse-graining, offering a power-law gain in efficiency and a systematic way to define coarse-grained models for chromosomes. We use this formalism to investigate the 3D organization of chromosome 3R 20bp in Drosophila during one cell cycle. We show that combining coarse-graining with a one-parameter copolymer model integrating epigen-driven interactions reproduces experimental data at chromosome-scale and predicts chromatin is dynamic during the cycle.
Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) mapping have been used to analyze complex traits and diseases in humans. GWAS tag non-coding SNPs with small effects, and these SNPs exert phenotypic control by modifying gene expression. To interpret GW associations using eQ data, we need to understand the genetic and causal mechanisms of cell specificity of eQs. We performed eQ analysis in three parts: (1) identified eQs from eleven on seven cell types, (2) integrated eQ with cis-regulatory element (CRE) data from ENCODE, and (3) built classifiers to predict the type of e. We found that e are associated with e SNP overlap hundreds of type CRE, including enhancer, promoter, repressive chromatin, open chrom, and DNA protein classes. These associations provide insight into the mechanisms of e and mode of corresponding. Using a classifier with CRE-SNP as features, we demonstrate the feasibility of predicting e. We also show that CRE from a trait type can be used to annotate GW in absence of e for that type.
The development of broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (bNAbs) to the HIV-1 envelope (Env) protein gp120 has been an important area of research over the last decade. Many of these bNAbs recognize epitopes consisting of both amino acid and glycan residues. Moreover, the glycans required for bNAb binding are intermediates in the N-linked glycosylation pathway. This type of glycosylation alters the mass and charge of Envs compared to molecules with the same amino sequence but with mature, sialic-containing carbohydrates. Since cell lines for biopharm production that limit N-glycosylation to mannose (Man5) or intermediates are not readily available, production of vaccineogens displaying glycan-dependent epitopes has been challenging. Here, we report the development of a suspension-adapted Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) line that limits glycosylation to Man5 intermediates. This line was created using the CRISPR/Cas9 system and contains a mutation inactivating the MG1 gene. Monomeric gp120 produced in the MG1 CHO line exhibit improved binding to protic glycan-dependentNAbs to V1/V (PG9) and V3 (PGT and 10–107) while preserving structure of gly-independent (RC01). The MG CHO line limits glycos to intermediates without impairing doubling or ability to grow at high densities, suggesting it will be useful for biarm production of HIV-1 immunogens.
Lymphatic filariasis is a major cause of permanent and long-term disability in many of the world’s poorest populations in tropical and developing nations. Parasitic nematodes are responsible for this devastating disease. Proteins essential to nematodes that do not have mammalian counterparts represent targets for therapeutic discovery. Trehalose-6-phosphatase (TPP) from Brugia mal is a promising target. In the nematode Caenorhabdis elegans, TP is essential for survival due to toxic effects of trehal 6-phosphate accumulation. TP is also essential in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. We determined the X-ray structure of TP from B. mal. The structure revealed a stabilizing N-terminal MIT domain and catalytic C-terminal C2-type H phosphatase fold. Structure-guided mutagenesis combined with kinetic analyses using competitive inhibitor trehal 6-sulf identified residues important for binding and catalysis. This structure-function analysis along with computational provided the basis for proposed TP-trehal 6-phosphate model. The model indicates substrate mode wherein complementarity and van der Waals interactions drive recognition. This mode is in contrast to hom sucrose-phosphatase where extensive hydrogenond interactions are made to substrate.
Cancers are characterised by spatially heterogeneous vascular architectures across samples and patients, which contribute to suboptimal treatment efficacy. We present a novel computational framework to simulate blood and interstitial fluid transport in silico for validation against in vivo imaging. Our model couples Poiseuille and Darcy descriptions of vascular and interstitial flow, and incorporates spatially heterogeneous vessel and interstitial permeabilities to predict tumour fluid dynamics. We apply our framework to orthopic murine glioma ( GL261 ) and human colorectal carcinoma ( LS174T ) and perform sensitivity analysis to understand key mechanisms determining tumour transport. We mimic vascular normalization by modifying parameters, such as vessel and interstitial permeabilities, and show that realistic vasculature is key to contrasting fluid response between tumours. We show that reducing tumour interstitial pressure is not essential to increase interstitial perfusion and therapies should develop interstitial pressure gradient. We hypothesise that stabilising vessel diameters and permeabilities are key responses following normalization and may alter interstitial conductivity. Finally, we suggest normalising interenvironment may increase perfusion within tumours.
HIV-1 is known to spread through both cell-free and cell-to-cell transmission, but the relative importance of cell-to-cell transmission in natural infection has not been resolved. Likewise, the extent to which cell-to-cell transmission is vulnerable to inhibition by neutralizing antibodies and entry inhibitors remains to be determined. Here we report on neutralizing antibody activity during cell-to-cell transmission using specifically experimental strategies that enable discrimination between the two routes. We demonstrate the activity of neutralizing monoclonal antibodies ( mAbs) and entry inhibitors during cell-to-cell transmission varies depending on their mode of action. While gp41 directed agents remain active, CD binding site (CDbs) inhibitors, including the neutralizing mAb VRC01, lose potency during cell transmission. This implies CDbs mAbs act preferentially block free transmission while allowing HIV to spread through cell contacts. This provides a plausible explanation for how HIV maintains infectivity and escapes potent broadly active CDbs antibody responses in vivo.
Visual attention is known to have a profound effects on neural responses in the visual system, producing changes in firing rates as well as in the structure and size of receptive fields in both spatial and feature space. Previous models of attention suggest that these effects arise from selective modulation of neural inputs. However, anatomical and physiological observations suggest that attention targets higher levels of the system such as V4 or MT rather than input areas such as V1. Here, we propose a mechanism that explains how top-down attentional modulation on higher areas can produce observed effects on neural responses. Our model requires the existence of feedback connections between areas and short lateral inhibition within each area. Feedback redistributes top-down to lower areas which in turn alters inputs of higher cells including those did not receive initial. This produces rate modulations and receptive shifts. Simultaneously, short lateral between neighboring produce competitive that are scaled to field in any area. Our reproduces observed effects on rates ( response gain input, gain, competition scaled field ) and structure ( shifts and resizing fields spatial feature ) without modifying. Our also makes novel that effects should shift from gain to as focus away from cell.
In Drosophila, the posterior signalling centre (PSC) is a group of cells that controls blood cell homeostasis in the larval hematopoietic organ, the lymph gland. SC acts in a non-autonomous manner to maintain janus tyrosine kinase/signal transducers and activators of transcription (JAK/STAT) signalling in hematietic progenitors (proocytes, preserving their multipotent character for differentiation into lamlocytes, a cell type required to fight specific threats such as wasp parasism. We show that the short I cytokine receptor CG142/Lat is required to switch off J/STAT signalling in proocytes, a prerequisite for lamlocyte differentiation upon waspism. In vivo and cell assays indicate that Lat forms heteromers with Dome, the Drosila I cytokine receptor related mammalian GP130, and antagonises Dome in a dose-dependent manner. Primary response to waspism is a decrease in cytok mRNA in the gland followed by increase in Lat/Dome ratio. We propose this sequence culminates in inhibition of J/STAT by Lat.
Genetic recombination is an important for the evolution of begomoviruses, a family of single-stranded DNA viruses. In begoviruses, recombination is not random and is influenced by factors such as sequence similarity between recomb genomes, nucleic acid structure and sensitivity to nuclease breakage. The viability of recombinant genomes could be influenced by protein-protein and nucleotide interactions. We investigated recombination patterns in begovir Tomato leaf curl virus and Tomato leaf Comos virus over 120 days in tomato plants. We show that recombination between these viruses is complex and influenced by sequence similarity but not structure. Selection against recombinants with disrupted intra-gen interactions such as protein and nucleic folding is strong. We find that selection preserves co-evolved protein-protein and DNA interactions so strongly that we can identify sequence tracts involved in these interactions.
Nucleosomes are the basic units of eukaryotic chromatin that have been suggested to influence the evolution of eukotic genomes by altering the propensity of DNA to mutate and acting to maintain or exclude nucleosomes in particular locations. In contrast to the idea that nucleosomes are unique to eukotes, histone proteins have been found in archaeal genomes. However, archaeal nucleosomes differ from eukotic nucleosomes in many respects, including assembly into tetramers rather than octamers from histone proteins lacking N and C-terminal tails. Here we show that despite these differences the association between nucleosome footprints and sequence is conserved between humans and the archaeon Haloferaxii. We examine whether selection or mutation can explain concord substitution patterns in the two. Unexpectedly, we find that neither mutation nor selection are sufficient to explain the association between nucleosomes and sequence. Instead, we show that nucleosome substitution patterns are consistent with a model where sequence results in reposition of nucleosomes during evolution. We demonstrate that nucleosome reposition is both necessary and sufficient to explain the association current nucleosome and substitution patterns.
Protein conformational diversity of the native state plays a central role in modulating protein function. The paradigm sustains that different ligands shift the conformation equilibrium through binding to high-affinity conformers. Intramolecular vibrational dynamics associated with conformation guarantee conformation transitions, which could be associated with evolutionary conserved traits. We present a novel procedure to identify key positions sustaining conformation associated with ligand binding. The method is applied to a refined dataset of 188 paired protein structures in bound and unbound forms. Normal modes most involved in conformation change are selected according to overlap with structural distortions introduced by ligand. The subspace defined by modes is used to analyze effect of point mutations on conformation of protein. We find negative correlation between effects of mutations on normal subspaces associated with ligand and position evolutionary conservations from multiple alignments. Positions found to alter these subspaces are defined as key, important mediating ligand conformation change. These are conserved, mostly buried aliphatic residues in structural regions like β-sheets and α-helix.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) is an intracellular pathogen that uses multiple metabolic pathways to establish and maintain infection. We investigated the role of fructose-1, 6-bisphosphate aldolase (FBA), an enzyme involved in glycolysis and gluconeogenesis. We engineered an Mtb strain in which FBA levels were regulated by anhyrotetracycline and found that depletion of F resulted in clearance of M in both acute and chronic phases of infection in vivo and loss of viability in vitro when cultured on single carbon sources. Consistent with M's ability to coatabol multiple carbon sources, loss of F could be overcome when cultured on mixtures of glycol and gluogenic carbon sources. We generated an F knockout (Δfba) strain and found that lack of F could only be compensated by specific balance of glucose and butyrate in growth and metabolism of butrate was determined by M's ability to coatab glucose. These data evaluate F as a drug target in both replicating and persistent M and expand our understanding of conditions that define F in vivo.
Trypanosomatids, such as Leishmania, lack catalase and selenium-glutathione peroxidases, which are enzymes involved in peroxide removal. In this study, we investigated the role of mitochondrial 2-cys peroxin ( mTXx ) in the Leishmania life cycle. We generated mpx null mutants by gene replacement and found that they were avirulent in a murine infection model. Unexpectedly, the avirulence was not due to lack of peroxidase activity, as mpx behaved like controls when exposed to exogenous oxidants or generated by macrophage phagocytosis in vitro. mpx were also avir in hosts unable to mount an oxidative phagocyte response ( B.47ox−/− and B.AG−−/−IF− mice ). We conclude that perase activity is not required for survival in mice by showing that peraseinactive mpx rescued the nonfective phenotype ofpx. We propose a novel function for mpx as a molecular chaper, which may explain impaired infectivity ofpx. This is based on ability to suppress aggregation of citrate synth in vitro.px were more sensitive than controls to temperature shift from 25°C to 37°C, reminiscent of lacking chaper genes.
Histoplas urine (HAg) is the preferred method for diagnosing progressive disseminated histoplasis (PDH) in HIV patients. In 2007, ALPHA-Histoplas E was approved for clinical use outside the United States. We evaluated the diagnostic accuracy of ALPHA-HAg. We conducted a multicenter, prospective diagnostic study in secondary and tertiary-care facilities in Mexico. We included HIV patients with PD suspicion and evaluated ALPHA-HAg accuracy using Histlas capsulatum growth on blood, bone, and tissue cultures or histopathologic exam (PD–proven) as reference. We evaluated 288 patients, 29.5% (85; 95% CI 24.–.35 ) had PD. ALPHA-HAg sensitivity was 67.% (95 CI 56–.76 ) and specificity 97.5% ( CI 94–99. ). The likelihood ratio was 27. (11–74. ) In PD–pro patients, 10.5% had co-infections, mostly disseminated Mycobacterium complex. We observed high specificity but low sensitivity of ALPHA-HAg. The test may start antifungals but culture is necessary since co-infections frequent and negative result does not rule PD.
Diarrhea is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in children worldwide, responsible for approximately 1. 8 million deaths annually and millions of episodes of nonfatal cases. In up to 40% of cases, the etiologic agent remains unidentified. The advent of metagenomics has enabled the systematic characterization of microbial populations, and metagenomics has the potential to define the spectrum of viruses, including novel, present in stool during episodes of diarrhea. This study employed a metagenomic approach to characterize the viral communities present in stool specimens from 12 children employing a “microassay” strategy that requires minimal sample (100 mg ), minimal purification, and sequencing ( reads per sample. This approach detected known enteric viruses as well as sequences from putatively novel viruses with limited similarity to GenBank.
Zika and deng outbreaks in the Dominican Republic were studied using national surveillance data to compare the two flaviviruses. Retrospective datasets were used to collect information on populations at risk and descriptive statistics were used to describe the outbreaks on a national scale. The data showed that 75% of deng cases were reported in those <20 years old, while Zika infections were more dispersed among the population. Dengue rates were higher among males (25.9 per 10,000 population) compared to females (21.5 per 10,000 population). Zika was highly clustered among females (73.8% (95%CI 72.6,75.%; p<0.05) ; age-adjusted rates were 7.64 per 10,000 among females and 2.72 per 10,000 among males. Stratification by sex showed higher rates among females (1.84 (1.82,1.87; p<0.05) compared to males (1.72 (1.69,1.75; p<0.05). However, GBS rates stratified by sex showed higher risk in males vs females (0.62 vs 0.57 per 10,000). Little impact of existing deng immunity on Zika attack rates was found at the population level. Confounding of R and risk by sex-specific reporting can alter reliability of metrics, which can be addressed using proxy syndromes or conditions to explore sex-skewed incidence.
Poly(ADP-ribose ) polymerases (PARs ) are enzymes that catalyze the transfer of poly (ADP-ri ) units onto target proteins. In Arabidopsis thaliana, we have found that PAR2 (Atg023 ) rather than PAR1 (Atg20 ) makes the greatest contribution to PAR activity and organismal viability in response to genotoxic stresses caused by bleomycin, mitomycin C or gamma-radi. PAR2 carries DNA binding motifs rather than the zinc finger domains common in plant and animal PAR1 proteins. PAR2 makes stronger contributions than PAR1 to plant responses including restriction of pathogenic Pseudomonas syringae growth and reduction of infection-associated DNA-strand break. For poly (AD-ri )glycohydase (PARG ) enzymes, we find Arabidopsis P1 not P2 is the major contributor to (AD-ri ) removal from acceptor proteins. The abundance of PAR2 is influenced by PAR1 and PARG. PAR2 and PAR interact with each other, with PARG and P2, suggesting direct interactions among mediators of the balance of (AD-rib.
In Caenorhabditis elegans, RPM-1 is a conserved intracellular signaling protein that regulates synapse formation and axon termination. RPM-1 acts as a ubiquitin ligase to inhibit the DLK-1 and MLK-1 MAP kinase pathways. We have identified a new MAP kinase pathway that suppresses synapse defects but not axon defects in mechanosensory neurons of rpm-1 mutants. This pathway includes M-15 ( MAPK ), NS-1 ( MAPK ), KK-1 ( MAPK ) and JNK-1 ( MAP ). These kinases are likely to form a new MAP pathway that opposes RPM-1. Transgenic overexpression of M-15/J-1 kinases impairs synapse in wild-type animals. M-15/J-1 functions autonomously in mechanensory neurons and localizes to presynaptic terminals. Loss of M-15/J-1 suppresses defects in habituation to repeated stimuli in rpm- mutants, a behavioral that likely from impaired glutamatergic synapse.
In Caenorhabditis briggs, the sex-determination protein TR-1 (TRA-1) is a bipotential transcription factor that can activate or repress the same target gene in response to changing signals from upstream genes. Here, we show that TR-1 is required for spermatogenesis and that it works as part of the Tip60 Histone Acetylase complex. TR-1 promotes the expression of C-f-3, a gene needed for spermatogenesis. TR-1 also works through TR-1 to activate C-f-3 and control the sperm/oocyte decision. Since TR-1 can repress C-3 as well, these observations demonstrate it is bipot. TR-1 regulates the development of the male tail. Since C-tra C-tr- double mutants resemble C-tra null, these two branches control TR- activity. However, differences in the relationship between these branches have arisen during evolution. brigae TR- null prevent hermaphrodite spermat, but C-f null, which disrupt the other half of the switch. On the other hand, C null prevent spermat, but C-tr null. Synthetic interactions confirm both halves exist each species.
Integrated information is a measure that quantifies the extent to which a system generates more information than the sum of its parts as it transitions between states, possibly reflecting levels of consciousness generated by neural systems. However, it is only defined for discrete Markov systems, which are unusual in biology. As a result, it can rarely be measured in practice. Here, we describe two new measures, Φ and Φ, that overcome these limitations and are easy to apply to time-series data. Φ is a measure of integrated information that can be applied to continuous systems, while Φ is a measure of integrated that can be applied to time-series data. We use simulations to demonstrate the practical applicability of our measures and explore their properties. Our results provide new opportunities for examining integration in real and model systems and carry implications for relations between integrated, consciousness, and neurocognitive processes. However, our findings pose challenges for theories that ascribe meaning to measured quantities.
In Uganda, the prevalence of Rhodesian human African trypanosomiasis (HAT) has increased in recent years, raising concerns that it may overlap with the Gambian form of the disease. Recent studies have focused on environmental and climatic factors that control the distribution of the disease. Here, we extend a previous study that used logistic regression to explore the relationship between Rhodesian H and social, environmental, and climatic variables in the most affected districts, suggesting the disease spread was due to movement of infected, untreated livestock. We use Bayesian geostatistical analysis to account for spatial autocorrelation, uncertainty in data and parameters, and undertake predictive mapping of high H prevalence in the future. In a generalised linear model, we account for spatial autocorrelation and uncertainty in data and parameters, resulting in more accurate parameter estimates and increased predictive accuracy. This allows assessment of the validity of the livestock hypothesis and assessment of covariate effects. Our analysis supports that Rhodesian H was imported via movement of untreated, infected livestock from endemic areas. The effect of health care on the distribution of Rhodesian H and the link between disease and minimum temperature have been confirmed. Predictive mapping indicates increased risk of high prevalence in areas surrounding livestock markets, demonstrating the importance of trading for disease spread. Adherence to policy to treat livestock at sale is essential to prevent spread of sleeping sickness in Uganda.
The concept of equilibria in large ecosystems is a neglected in the complexity-stability debate. In the 1970s, the consensus that complexity leads to stability in ecosystems was challenged. Recently, this was extended to ecologically inspired networks. These approaches assume the existence of a feasible equilibrium, i. e. positive abundances. However, this assumption has not been tested. We provide analytical results complemented by simulations which show that equilibrium vanishes in species rich systems. This leaves us in an uncomfortable situation in which the existence of a equilibrium assumed in stability is far from granted. We extend our analyses by changing interaction structure and intensity, and find that feasibility and stability is irrespective of species with weak interactions. Interestingly, we find that the dynamical behaviour of ecologically inspired architectures is very different and richer than of unstructured. Our results suggest that a understanding of ecosystem requires the interplay between strength and architecture.
Coxiella burnetii, the causative agent of Q fever, is a zoonotic pathogen with a near global distribution. This study aimed to assess the epidemiology of C burnii in humans and cattle in Western Kenya. We conducted a cross-sectional survey of 204 humans and 955 cattle in 416 homesteads in Western and Nyan Provinces, Kenya. Serum samples were tested for C burnii antibodies and questionnaires collected demographic, socio-economic and husbandry information. Data were linked to environmental datasets based on geographical locations. Correlation and spatial analyses were applied to assess the link between cattle and human seropreval. Multile regression was used to assess relationships between socio-economic, demographic and environmental factors and ser-positivity in humans and animals. The overall ser-prevalence of C burnii was 2. 5% in humans and 10.5 in cattle. We found no evidence of correlation between cattle and human serpreval within households or spatial proximity to other households. Multile modelling indicated that cattle obtained from market had higher serpreval than those bred in homestead and residing in areas with lower precipitation. For humans, the youngest group had highest odds of seros, variations observed between ethnic groups and frequent livestock contact ( grazing and dealing material ) was a risk factor.
Schistosoma mansoni is a parasitic flatworm that causes schistosomiasis, a major neglected tropical disease. Schistosoma japonicum and S. haematobum are close relatives of S. mansoni, and their genomes have been sequenced. To understand the role of S. mansoni genes, functional approaches are being developed. Transgenesis in S. mansoni can be achieved using RNA interference and insertional mutagenesis. However, culturing germ cells in S. mans is difficult. Vasa is a DEAD-box helicase that marks primordial germ cells in animals. In S. mans, 33 DEAD-box helicases were identified, three of which are vasa-like: Smv1, Sm2, and Sm3. Phylogenetic analysis confirmed Smv1, Sm2, and Sm3 belong to the vasa/10 subfamily. Smv1, Sm2, and Sm3 are transcribed in adult S. mans with high expression in sporocysts, females, eggs, miracidia, and undeveloped eggs. Whole mount in situ hybridization revealed Sm1, Sm, and Sm3 transcribed in the ovary where oocytes.
Cardiac valve disease is a major clinical problem worldwide. Cardiac valve development and homeostasis need to be precisely controlled. Hipp signaling is essential for organ and tissue homeostasis, while its role in valve formation and morphology remains unknown. We found that VGL4, a transcriptional cofactor in vertebrates, is mainly expressed in valve interstitial cells at the post-embryonic (EM) stage and maintained till adult stage. Tissue specific knockout of V4 in cell lineages revealed that only loss of V4 in endothelial lineage led to valve malformation with expression of YAP targets. We semi-knock Y in V4 ablated hearts and found hyperproliferation of valve interstitial cells significantly constrained.
Many studies have sought to identify patterns of positive selection on standing genetic variation in natural populations. Recent large-scale analyses have argued that soft sweeps are common in humans, Drosophila, and HIV. However, others have questioned the relevance of these models to natural populations and the identifiability of sweeps relative to other processes, arguing that sweeps are likely rare. Here, we evaluate three recent studies and their methodologies using population theory and simulation. We find that all are prone to high false-positive rates, identifying sweeps under both hard and neutral models. Furthermore, we show that demographic histories combined with hard sweeps serve as more parsimonious explanation.
Female mosquitoes of the species Aedes aegypt are the principal vectors of dengue fever, causing 50–100 million infections per year. They inhibit host-seeking behavior for three days following a blood meal due to a hemolymph-borneal humoral factor. Headptide is a candidate mediating this suppression, but the mechanism is unknown. We identified eight Neurope Y ( NPY )-Like Receptors ( NLRs ) in the Ae. aegypt genome and screened them in a cell-based imaging assay against a panel of peptides. Four Ae.egi NLRs responded to one or more peptide ligands, but NLR1 responded to Headptide as well as Neurope-Fs. Two NLR homologues in the Lyme disease vector Ix scularis were also sensitive to Headptide. Injection of synthetic Headptide and Neurope-F3 inhibited host-seeking in non-fed females, whereas control buffer or inactive Headptide had no effect. We used zinc-fingerases to generate five independent NLR null strains and tested for behavioral abnormalities. NLR mutants displayed normal locomotion, egg, sugar feeding, blood feeding, host, and host inhibition after meal. We identified four Aeeg NLR and NLR1 as candidate Neurope receptor sensitive to Headptide. NLR alone is not required for host inhibition and we conclude other receptors, peptides, or both regulate this behavior.
Schistosomiasis is a parasitic disease whose distribution in space and time can be influenced by environmental factors such as rivers, elevation, slope, surface temperature, land use/cover, and rainfall. This study aims to identify areas with conditions suitable for schosomiasis transmission based on physical environmental factors derived from satellite imagery and spatial analysis in Akure Local Government Area ( LGA ) of Ondo State, Nigeria. This was done through multicriteria evaluation (CE) using Sa’s Analytical Hierarchy Process (AHP). AHP is a multicriteria method that uses hierarchical structures to represent a problem and make decisions based on priority. In this study AHP was used to obtain the weight importance of each schosiasis factor. The study focused on temperature, drainage, elevation, rainfall, and land use/cover as factors controlling schias incidence in the area. These factors were reclassified and overlaid to identify areas vulnerable to schias. Weighted analysis was done after each factor was given appropriate weight through hierarchical process. The prevalence of schias in the area was determined by parasitological analysis of urine samples collected through random sampling. Results showed varying schias risk with larger portion of area (82%) falling under high and very risk category. Study showed one community (O I) had lowest schias while risk increased in four communities (I, Igoba, It, Ogb and Oese). Predictions by model correlated with observations from study.
Pneumococcal meningitis is a bacterial infection of the brain caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae. The cholesterol-dependent cytolin pneumolys is a virulence factor that determines the neuropathogenic potential of pneumoc. Here, we show that pneumoc meningitis leads to selective loss of synapses in the superficial layers of the neocortex of post-mortem brain samples from individuals with pneumoc meningitis. A similar effect is observed in mice with pneumoc meningitis when the bacteria express the pore-form cholesterol-dependent cytol pneumolys. We also show that exposure of mouse brain slices to pore-compet pneumys at disease-relevant, nonlytic concentrations causes dendritic swelling, dendritic spine elimination and synaptic loss. This pathology is reduced by NMD glutamate antagonists MK801 and DAP5. Pneumolys increases glutamate levels in brain slices. In astrocytes, pneumol initiates glutamate release in a calcium-dependent manner. We propose that pneumol plays a synap and dendotoxic role in pneumoc meningitis by initiating glutamate release from astrocytes, leading to glutamate-dependent synaptic damage.
Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are DNA viruses that are associated with major human cancers. To develop new means of prevention, such as vaccines and microbicides, it is necessary to understand the life cycle of HPVs. The life cycle of HPVs is closely linked to the state of the stratified epithelium it infects, with progeny virus only made in the terminally differentiating supasal compartment. It has been recognized that HPVs first establish infection in the basal layer of stratified epithelium, but this has not been understood. We used chemical approaches to reveal that cell progression through mitosis is critical for HP infection. We used HPV16 containing the viral genome, synchronized human keratinocytes as hosts, and viral expression as read for infection. We learned that the cell must enter phase for infection to take place. phase inhibitors had no effect, whereas,,,, and phase inhibitors prevented. We conclude that cells need to pass for successful of the encapsated genes. These provide reason why HPVs establish in the compartment of stratified epithelia. Only this of the epithelium cells through the cycle, and it is in these that HPVs can establish.
Penicillium marffei is an important dimorphic fungus that causes systemic mycoses in China and Southeast Asia. While miRNAs are known to regulate gene expression in animals and plants, miRN in fungi are less studied and their roles in dimorphism are largely unknown. We hypothesized that mi-like RNAs (milRN) are expressed in P. marffei and attempted to identify them in mycel and yeast phases using high-throughput sequencing. Small RN were more abundant in mycel than yeast. We identified 24 mil candidates, 17 in mycel and 7 yeast. Two genes, d-1 and d-2, encoding Dicer-like proteins and q- encoding Argonaute, were identified in P. marff. Phylogen analysis showed d-2 was more related to homologues in other dimorphic fungi than Penillium chrysenum Aspergillus. d demonstrated higher expression in mycel than yeast. Northern analysis confirmed two milRN, PMil-M and PMil, only in mycel. Using dKO dKO dKO qKO we showed biogenesis dependent on d but not d or q. mRNA levels of predicted targets PMil were upregulated in PMilKD, supporting function.
Zika virus (ZIK) emerged in French Polynes in 2013 and spread through the Pacific between 2013 and 2017. Several Aedes mosquitoes may have contributed to ZIK transmission, including Aedes aegypt, the main vector in the region, and Aedesynensis, vector of lymphatic filariasis and secondary vector dengue. This study aimed to analyze the ability of these vectors to transmit ZIK at a regional scale. We compared the competence of wild Ae.egypt and.ynensis populations from Pacific for ZV which circulated in 2013–2017. We collected Ae.egpt ( three populations ) and.yn ( two ) from the region. Female mosquitoes were exposed to ZV ( TC/mL ) isolated in 2014. At 6, 9, and 21 post-infection, bodies ( thorax and abdomen ), and heads were analyzed to measure infection, dissemination, and transmission rates, respectively. Our results showed ZV rates were heterogeneous between Aeeg populations, but dissemination rates were moderate and homogenous between these. For.yn, rates were less heterogeneous between the two tested populations. Transmission efficiency revealed low competence for ZV of Ae populations under study. Our results indicated low Z transmission by Aeeg andyn from the region.
Xist is a long non-coding RNA (lncRNA) that regulates X-chromosome inactivation in mammalian cells. The function of Xist and other lncRNAs depends on their thermodynamically stable secondary and higher-order structures that can form in the context of a cell. To study the structure of Xist in cells, we developed Targeted StructureSeq, which combines chemical probing of RNA in cells with target-specific massively parallel sequencing. Targeted StructureSeq enriches for signals from the RNA of interest, achieving high coverage of the RNA with relatively few reads, providing a targeted and scalable approach to analyze conformation in cells. We applied Targeted StructureSeq to the full-length Xist ncRNA and developed new models for functional elements within Xist, including the A element in the 5’end of X. This analysis also identified structural elements X that are evolutionarily conserved, including a proximal to the repeats that is important for X function.
Genome-wide association studies have identified a large number of genetic variants associated with complex diseases. However, the clinical utility of risk prediction based on genomic profiles is controversial. To evaluate the performance of genetic risk models, appropriate statistical measures are required. Previous studies have mainly used the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (ROC), AUC, to judge the predictive value of genetic tests. However, AUC has limitations and should be complemented by other measures. We develop a novel statistical framework that connects a variety of predictive indices. Given the overall disease probability and the level of variance in total liability (heritability) explained by genetic variants, we can estimate analytically a variety of prediction metrics, for example AUC, mean difference between cases and non-cases, net reclassification improvement to reclassify into high and low categories, proportion explained by specific percentile of population at highest risk, variance of predicted, and risk at percentile. We demonstrate how to construct graphs to visualize performance of models, ROC, density of risks, and predictiveness (disease plotted against risk ). Results match well with theoretical. We apply to nine complex diseases evaluating predictive of genetic tests on known variants for each trait.
Trypanosoma brucei gambiense is the causative agent of human African trypanosomiasis (HAT). Diagnosis and treatment are key elements of control strategies. Serological screening is the first step in diagnostic algorithms. The Card agglutination Test for Trypanosomiasis (CATT) has been the most used screening test for decades. However, it has practical limitations. Rapid diagnostic tests (RDT) were introduced, but are manufactured using native antigens, which are challenging to produce. This study evaluated a new DT using recombinant antig (SDOLINEAT 2. 0) in comparison with DT using native antigens (OLINEAT) and ATT. A total 57,632 individuals were screened in the Democratic Republic of Congo, either passively at health centres or actively by mobile teams, and 260 H cases were confirmed by parasitology. The highest sensitivity was achieved by OLAT 2. 0 (71. 2%), followed by ATT (62.5%) and OLAT (59.%). The most specific was ATT (99. 2%), while specificity of OLAT and OLAT 2.0 were 98.9 and 98.1, respectively. All tests were more sensitive in passive than active screening. Combining tests resulted in increased sensitivity: when OLAT was combined with OLAT 2. 0, sensitivity reached 98.4 in passive and 83. in active. The recomant-based DT was more sensitive and specific than OLAT. It was as sensitive but less specific than ATT.
Chagas disease is a neglected tropical disease that affects millions of Latin Americans and has been effectively controlled in Guatemala after multiple rounds of indoor insecticide spraying. However, a few foci with persistent Triatoma infestation remain. In the municipality of Comapa, Department of Juti, southeastern Guatemala, control interventions appear less effective. We carried out three cross-sectional entomological and serological surveys in Comapa to evaluate a decade of vector activities. Baseline serological (1999 ) and entological (2002 ) surveys were followed by three rounds of insecticide applications (2005 ) and intermittent spraying of infested houses until 201. Household inspections to determine entom indices and materials were conducted 1, 7 and 11. Serological surveys were conducted in school children 199, 7 and 201, and women of child-bearing age 15–44 in 201. After multiple rounds of indoor sprayings, the infestation index decreased from 39% to 27. Household materials alone predicted <10% infested houses. Chagas seropreval in Comapa declined in school children by 10, from 10% to 1. However, serreval in women of child age remains >10. After a decade of control in Comapa, there is evidence of reduced transmission. However, continued vector-borne and congenital transmission pose a threat to Chagas elimination goal.
Citrobacterium is a natural mouse pathogen that causes attaching and effacing (A/E) lesions and shares virulence strategies with clinically significant human pathogens such as enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) and enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC). We previously reported the complete genome sequence of C. rodium ICC168, which displayed characteristics of a newly evolved pathogen. In this study, we found that the genome of C. rodium is unstable as a result of repeat-mediated large-scale recombination and active transposition of mobile elements such as prophages. We sequenced an additional C. rodium strain EX-33 to reveal that the reference ICC168 is representative of the species and most inactivating mutations were common to both isolates and likely occurred early in the evolution of this pathogen.
Stochastic fluctuations in gene expression give rise to distributions of protein levels across cell populations. We propose a method for inferring sets of biochemical constants that govern chromatin modification, transcription, translation, and RNA and protein degradation from stochasticity in expression. We derived analytical solutions for the first four moments of the protein distribution and found that these moments capture the shape of protein distributions. We developed an efficient algorithm for inferring expression constants from the moments of distributions. Using this algorithm we find that protein distributions are consistent with a number of different biochemical constant sets. Despite degeneracy, the solution of constants always informs underlying mechanism. We distinguish between regimes of transcriptional bursting and constitutive production. Our method agrees with current approach in restrictive regime and identifies constants not obtainable without assumptions. We estimate biochemical constants or ratios in 91% of cases and identify all underlying constants in some cases.
Monkeypox virus (MPV) is the causative agent of monkeypox (MPX), an emerging orthopoxvirus zoonosis endemic in tropical rain forests of Africa and sporadic in West Africa. It is a neglected disease in rural areas where human population interacts with wildlife, and human-to-human transmission is possible. Smallpox vaccination provides cross-protection against MPX; however, vaccination ended in Africa in 1980, leaving a large population unprotected against MPV. Disease control relies on deterring zoon exposure and interrupting person-to-person spread. There are no FDA-approved therapies against MP and current vaccines are limited due to safety concerns. New studies on pathogenesis, prophylaxis and therapeutics are of interest for scientific and governments concerned MPV could be bioterror. In this study, a new vaccination strategy based on recombinant bovine herpesvirus 4 (HV-4) vectors expressing MPV glycoproteins A29, M1 and B6 was investigated for protection from lethal MPV challenge in STAT knockout mice. Three recombinant HV-4 vectors were constructed and demonstrated to express their transgene. A small study showed all recom HV-4 safe following intraper administration. Further, HV-E1-MR alone or in combination with HV-C-A29 and HV-E6 was able to protect 100% and 80% against mortality and morbidity in STAT mice. This demonstrated efficacy of HV-4 vectors and use as vaccine platform.
Trypanosomes lack homologues to the subunits of the decapping complex, while deadenylation and 5’-3 degradation are conserved. Here, I show that trypanosomes use an ApH-like phosphatase TbPH1 as their major mRNA decapping enzyme. TbPH1 was recently identified as a trypanosome stress granule protein and involved in mRNA binding. A fraction of Tb1 co-localises with the tryosome 5’-3 exibonuc X to a granule at the posterior of the cell, indicating a connection between the enzymes. RNA depletion of Tb1 is lethal and causes a massive increase in mRNAs that are deadenylated but not yet 5-3 degraded. These data suggest Tb1 acts downstream deadeny and upstream of mRNA, consistent with a function in decapping. In vitro experiments show recombin, N-terminally truncated Tb1 protein but catalytically inactive sensitises the tryosome spliced RNA to yeast X1, only if an 5 polyosphatase is included. This indicates the decapping of Tb differs the decapping of D2 by more than one group at mRNA’s. This is the first function of eukotic ApH phosphatase, a bacterial-derived class present all phylogen super of eukotic.
Inhibition of the Arx gene in pancreatic α-cells is sufficient to promote the conversion of α-cells into β-like cells at any age. This is achieved through the continuous mobilization of ductal precursor cells to an endocrine fate, glucagon cells, which are subsequently converted into β-like cells upon Arx inhibition. The generation of Arx and Pax4 double mutants indicates that Pax4 is dispensable for these processes, suggesting that Ar is the main trigger for α-mediated β cell neogenesis. Importantly, loss of Ar in α-cells is sufficient to regenerate β-cell mass and reverse diabetes-induced β depletion.
Eukaryotic cells use a battery of mechanisms to reduce the probability of re-initiation from the thousands of origins in their genome because re-init can generate genomic alterations with high frequency. It has been presumed that all origins are inhibited identically. However, origins initiate with diverse efficiencies when these mechanisms are disabled, and this cannot be explained by differences in the efficiency or timing of initiation during S phase. We have identified genetic elements that are necessary for preferential initiation of two origins and sufficient to confer preferential initiation on heterologous origins when control is partially deregulated. These elements do not enhance S timing or efficiency of adjacent origins and are acting as initiation promoters (RIPs). We mapped RIP to ∼60 bp AT rich sequences that act in distance and sequence-dependent manner. During induction, Mc2 reassociates with origins that preferentially initiate and that do not, suggesting RIP can overcome block imposed by. Our findings identify a level of control to initiation. This creates a complex landscape of potential that revealed when mechanisms are compromised.
Invasive amebias caused by Entamoeba histolytic are increasing among men who have sex with men and co-infection ameba and HIV-1 is emerging in East Asian countries. In this study, the clinical and epidemiological features of invasive amebias in HIV-1 patients were characterized. The medical records of 170 coinfected cases were analyzed and E. histoly genotype was assayed in 14 cases. The clinical presentation of invasive amebias in HIV-1 patients was similar to that in normal hosts, with fever, leukocytosis and high CRP associated with extralinal amic diseases. Two died from amic colitis ( intestinal perforation and gastrointestinal bleeding ) and three from causes unrelated amias. Treatment with metronidazole or tinazole was successful in 165 cases. Luminal treatment was provided to 83 following metronazole or tinazole treatment, but amias recurred in 6, similar to those who did not receive luminal. Recurrence was more frequent in HCV-antibody positive and those acquired syphil during follow-up. Various genotypes E. hist were identified but no correlation between genotype and clinical features. The outcome of metronazole and tinazole treatment uncomplicated amias was excellent in HIV-1 individuals. Luminal following metronazole tinid treatment does not reduce recurrence amias in high risk probably due amic re-infection.
Sleeping sickness or African trypanosomiasis (HAT) is a neglected tropical disease caused by Trypanosoma brucei gambi and transmitted by riverine tset species. The World Health Organization aims to eliminate the disease as a public health problem by 2020 and stop transmission by 203. In South Chad, the Mand area is a persistent focus of sleeping sickness where around 100 cases were diagnosed and treated annually until 2013. We assessed whether adding vector control to detection and treatment could further reduce transmission and consequently reduce incidence of sleeping in Mand. We investigated the impact of deploying tiny targets which attract and kill tset. Before control, a census of the population was conducted and their settlements mapped. A pre-intervention of tset distribution was implemented in November 2013 and 260 targets were deployed in riverine habitats in 2014,201 and 2016. Impact onset and sleeping was assessed through nine surveys and medical of the population in 201 and 201. Modelling was used to assess the impact ofset on incidence compared to active and passive screening. The population of 74 inhabitants lived in the vicinity of Mand. In November 201, the vector Glossina fipes fipes and mean of tse from traps was 0.7/trap (0–26 ). The of tse from sentinel traps declined after deployment with only being caught in surveys giving a mean of 0.005/trap. Modelling indicates 70.4% (51–95 ) of the reduction between 201 and 201 can be attributed to vector with the rest to medical. Tiny are estimated to have reduced dramatically with 62.8% (59–66 ) due toset and 8.5 (8–9 ) to passive.
Strongyloidiasis is a parasitic disease caused by the nematode Strongyloides stercoralis that is increasingly being diagnosed in non-endemic areas. This study describes the epidemiological, clinical and microbiological characteristics of patients with strongyloidias in Spain. The study included 124 cases of strongyloidis registered in the +IV Collaborative Network from 2009 to 2017. Most patients were immigrants (66.9% ) and South America was the most frequent area of origin. Detection of larvae in stool samples was observed in 21.9% of patients and serological tests made the diagnosis in the rest of cases. Eosinophilia was present in 82.2% of cases. Treatment withivermectin compared to albendazole was the most strongly associated factor to achieve cure (OR 2.34 ).
Vaccination is an effective method to protect against infectious diseases. An important consideration in vaccine formulation is the inoculum, i. e., amount of antigen or live attenuated pathogen that is used. Higher inoculum levels generally lead to better immune stimulation but might cause more side effects and allow less coverage in presence of vaccine shortages. Determining optimal inoculum is important component of rational vaccine design. We illustrate concept using mathematical models and data to inoculum determination, by fitting model to influenza A virus (IAV) infection in mice and human parainfluenza (HPV) in rats at different inoculum. We use model to map inoculum to protection and morbidity and explore how framework might be used to determine optimal inoculum. Our framework combines models with data to study inoculum impact on important outcomes such as protection and morbidity. We show that inoculum impact protection and morbidity depend on pathogen and protection and morbidity do not necessarily increase with inoculum. Once protection and morbidity goals are specified, our framework can be used to design vaccines and determine optimal inoculum.
In multicellular filaments of the cyanobacterium Anabaena undergo a process of differentiation in response to nitrogen deprivation, resulting in a one-dimensional pattern of nitrogen-fixing heterocysts separated by photosynthetic vegetative cells. We studied the expression of hetR, a transcription factor essential for heteroc differentiation, using a chromosomally translational hetR-gfp fusion. Statistical analysis of fluorescence at the individual cell level in wild-type and mutant filaments demonstrates that fluctuations of het in nearby cells are coupled, with a spatial range of circa two to three cells, setting the scale for cellular interactions along filament. Correlations between cells arise from intercellular molecular transfer and less from division. Fluctuations after nitrogen deprivation can build on those under nitrogenplete conditions. We found that under nitrogen-rich conditions, basal expression of Het is influenced by the septal protein Sep and positive Het auto-regulation, while under nitrogen-poor conditions, Het is influenced by HetN and Sep/Fra. A comparison between het-gfp under nitrogen and nitrogen highlights differences between HetN and Het, as well as between Sep and Fra/Fra.
Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) genotype has shifted from genotype III (GIII) to I (GI) in China, as demonstrated by molecular epidemiological surveillance. To confirm this shift at the seroepidemiological level, we performed a serological survey in JEV-nonvaccinated pigs and found an average GI/GIII infection ratio of 1.87, suggesting co-circulation of GI and GIII infections with GI being more prevalent in pigs. To understand the reasons for this shift, we compared the replication of seven recently-isolated JEV isolates, including three GI and four GIII strains, in C/36 cells, chicken fibroblast (DF-1) and porine iliac endothelial (PIE) cells. GI strains replicated more efficiently than GIII in DF-1 and PIE cells, particularly in DF-1 with titers 22.9–225.3 higher than GIII. This shows enhanced efficiency of GI in avian cells. To examine this efficiency in vivo, young ducklings were inoculated with GI and GIII at day post-hatching. GI-inoculated ducklings developed higher viremia and displayed longer vmic duration than GIII-inoculated ducklings. These results support the hypothesis of enhanced efficiency for GI in birds. There are 36 amino differences between GI and GIII, some of which may be responsible for the efficiency of GI in birds.
Candida albicans biofilm formation is a key aspect of its pathobiology and is regulated by an integrated network of transcription factors (CRZap1, Brg1,EFG1,N80,ROB1, and TEC1. We used a systematic genetic approach to generate all possible double heterozygous mutants of the network and quantitatively analyze the genetic interactions between them. The network is highly susceptible to perturbation with six heterozygous mutants showing alterations in biofilm formation (haploinsufficiency). In addition, many heterozygous mutants are as severely affected as homozygous deletions. The network shows properties of a highly interdependent ‘small’world’ that is efficient but not robust. Genetic data indicate that TEC is a component whose expression is sensitive to perturbations of other TFs. We also found that RO is dependent on auto-regulation and cooperative with other TFs. Finally, heterozygous N80 mutant is hyperfilous under bio and hypha-inducing in TEC-dependent.
Leishmania infantum Asparagine Synthase Is Dispensable for Parasite Survival and Infectivity. Asparagine synthase (AS) is an enzyme responsible for converting aspartate into aspar in an ATP-dependent manner using ammonia or glutamine as a nitrogen source. There are two structurally distinct forms: strictly ammonia-dependent AS-A and glutamine-dependent AS. In humans and trypanosomes, AS-A is absent, but present in trypanosomes and Leishmania donani, making it a potential drug target. Here, we demonstrate that Leishmania infantum AS uses both ammonia and glutamine as nitrogen sources. We generated AS null mutants by gene replacement in Leishmanium and observed no significant growth or infectivity defects. However, severe growth impairment was observed in aspar limiting conditions. Our results show that despite being important under aspar limitation, AS is not essential for parasite survival or infectivity in normal in vitro and in vivo conditions. Therefore, we exclude AS as a drug target against Leishium parasites.
Toxocara seropositivity is associated with an increased risk of epilepsy: a systematic review and meta-analysis. A systematic review was conducted to investigate the association between Toocara serositivity and epilepsy. The review included 11 case-control studies from 13 countries, involving 1,474 subjects (215 with epilepsy and 1,259 without epilepsy ). The pooled odds ratio ( OR ) was 1.69 ( 95% CI 1.42–2.01 ), indicating a positive association between Tooc seropositivity and epilepsy. Meta-regression showed no significant association between covariates and outcome. The association was consistently reported in restricted analyses ( confirmatory, diagnostic, younger, and population-based studies ). The meta-analysis provides epidemiological evidence of a positive association between Tooc seros and epilepsy.
ATM-dependent miR-335 targets CtIP and modulates the DNA response to DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs). ATM is a protein that plays a critical role in the cellular response to DSBs. We describe a new ATM-mediated DSB-induced DNA damage response pathway involving microRNA (miR) : ionizing radiation (IR)-induced DSBs activate ATM, which leads to the downregulation of miR-335, a miRNA that targets CtIP, a protein important for DNA end resection in homologous recombination (HR) repair. We show that CREB is responsible for a large portion of mi-335 expression by binding to the promoter of mi-335. CRE binding is greatly reduced after IR, corroborating previous studies that IR-activated ATM phosphorylates CRE to reduce its activity. Overexpression of mi-335 in HeLa cells results in reduced CtIP and post-IR survival and BRCA foci formation. Further, in patient-derived lymphoblastoid cell lines with post-IR survival “radiosensitive” phenotype we demonstrate elevated mi-335, reduced CtIP, and BRCA foci formation. Colony, BRCA foci, and CtIP are partially rescued by miRNA antisense AMi-335 treatment.
Mentalizing is the process of attributing mental states such as beliefs and emotions to others is a fundamental aspect of human social cognition. In this study, we tested whether sophisticated mentalizing, captured by the depth of recursive beliefs such as “I think you think I think”, influences learning in a social context. Participants played repeated games against artificial mentalizing agents with different levels of sophistication and were led to believe they were either playing against other humans or gambling in a casino. We found that participants won against the sophisticated mentalizing agents in the social framing and lost in the non-social framing. Importantly, participants’ choices were best explained by sophisticated mentalizing models only in the social framing. This is the first demonstration of the added value of mentalizing on learning in social interactions.
Biological networks are increasingly used to analyze diseases beyond traditional single variable analysis. The Gaussian Graphical Model (GM) is a probability model that characterizes the conditional dependence of a set of random variables by a graph and has applications in biological network analysis, such as inferring or comparing networks. However, existing approaches are either not statistically rigorous or inefficient for high-dimensional data with tens of thousands of variables. We propose FastGM, an efficient algorithm to estimate GM and obtain p-value and confidence for each edge in the graph. FastGM is based on a recent proposal by Ren et al. (2015). We demonstrate that FastGM is faster by several orders of magnitude than the current algorithm by Ren et. without losing accuracy. We apply FastGM to two data: transcriptomic from a childhood asthma study and proteomic from Alzheimer’s disease. We estimate gene or protein networks for disease and healthy samples. The networks reveal interactions and differential between cases and controls show relevance to diseases. FastGM is a computationally fast and statistically sound procedure for GM and high-dimensional data. It has been implemented in R package “FastGM”.
Striatal medium spiny neurons (MSNs) in the basal ganglia are important for learning and executing movement sequences. Their population activity varies on slow timescales relevant to behaviour. In a model of a MS network, activity emerges only at realistic connectivities and IP sizes. We investigate how MS population activity interacts with temporally varying cortical activity, as in a task. We find that unrealistically high connectivity leads to a winners-take regime, where activity separates into stimulus dependent firing and quiescent components. In this regime, only a few components interact with cortical variations. Around a transition to a more active regime occurs, where cells switch between activity and qucence. In this regime, components wander and are independent of cortical variations. Only in this regime do changes interact with many components, so sequential assemblies are reproducibly activated for hundreds of milliseconds after onset and peri-stim time display strong and specificity. We show that this is maximized at realistic connectivities and IP sizes. Thus, the MS network has optimal characteristics. It is neither too stable to respond dynamically to variations nor too unstable to respond consistently. Rather, it is optimized to generate activity for periods after cortical excitation.
Polarized exocytosis and endocyt are two transport pathways that maintain cell polarity by transporting membrane components to specific locations on the cortex and retrieving them before they can diffuse away. We show that the Rab GTPase Sec4 couples polar exocyt with cortical actin polymerization, which induces endyt. After polar exocyt to the plasma membrane, Sec4 binds Las/Bee1 ( WASp) in complex with Sla and Sla during actin assembly. Mutations in Sec4 or its GEF Sec2 inhibit actin formation, whereas activating Sec4L accelerates assembly. In vitro assays of Arp3-dependent actin polymer established GTP-Sec4 overrides Sla inhibition of Lasp actin nucleation. These results support a model in which Sec relocates from polar exytic sites to endytic sites. Activated Sec then promotes actin polymer and triggers endyt.
Acetamin-induced liver injury in mice is a model for drug-induced liver injury in humans. Acetamin hepatotoxicity is characterized by necrosis that begins adjacent to the central vein (CV) of the hepatic lobule and progresses outward. The mechanism of this phenomenon is not well understood, but evidence suggests that differences in NAPQI (reactive metabolite ) formation within hepatic lobules are necessary and sufficient to account for it. We call this mechanism the NZech hypothesis. To challenge this hypothesis, we employed virtual hepatocytes configured to exhibit peri-portal-to-CV gradients and achieved quantitative targets for acetamin clearance and metabolism but failed to achieve the phenomenon. We posited that at least one additional feature must exhibit zonation in the CV direction. We explored two alternatives: 1 ) glutathione depletion diminishes in CV and 2 ) ability to repair diminish in CV. Inclusion of one failed to achieve the phenomenon, but inclusion of both enabled it. This merged mechanism provides a multile, multiscale explanation of key features of acetamin hepatotoxicity in mice. We discovered that variants of this mechanism provide plausible explanations for considerable variation in necrosis among 37 diverse mouse strains following a single acetamin dose.
Trypanosoma cruzi congenital infection diagnosis in infants relies on detection of parasites by microscopy and/or persistence of specific antibodies at 10–12 months of age. Parasite levels were quantified by PCR in T cruzi-infected children grouped according to one-year follow-up diagnosis: (1) Neonates diagnosed first month after delivery by microscopy (n=19) had median parasitemia 1,700/mL; (2) infants required second parasitological diagnosis at six months (n=10) showed parasitemia around 20/mL and 500/mL at 1 and 6 months; (3) babies undetectable parasitem by blood but diagnosed by specific T cruz serology at 1 year (n=22) exhibited parasitem around 5/mL 800/mL and 20/mL 6 and 12 months. Parasites were isolated by hemoculture from congenitally infected children 19 of which were genified DT Tc (former TId) and only T. This is the first to quantify parasitemia in more than 50 congenitally infected. Our results show parasite in 22 out of 51 below detection microscopy limit.
The work presents a coarse-grained biophysical model of Escherichia coli that predicts growth rate and cellular composition from an effective representation of its genome. The model assumes E coli is in a state of balanced exponential growth in a temporally and spatially constant environment with rich resources. We apply this model to measurements of growth and r-to-protein ratio for seven coli strains with rRNA copy number ranging from one to seven. These measurements show growth decreases for strains with fewer copies. The model reproduces these measurements and suggests that the fraction of macromolecules inside coli is not fixed when rRNA copy is varied. Moreover, it predicts that increasing beyond seven results in cytoplasm densely packed with ribosomes and proteins. Assuming overcrowding weakens binding affinities, it predicts growth will not increase beyond wild-type rate, consistent with experiments. Our model suggests that changing rRNA copy of coli in constant environment does not increase growth. Other observations with altered copy, such as compaction and feedback, are qualitatively consistent.
The Arabidopsis thaliana MYB transcription factor R1 (R1SM1) is a member of the MYB-related subfamily and has been implicated in plant development and stress responses to biotic and abiotic stresses. However, the molecular mechanisms of R1 action in response to abiotic stresses remain obscure. We show that downregulation or upregulation of R1 expression alters sensitivity of seed germination and cotyled greening to abscic acid ( ABA), NaCl and mannitol in Arabidopsis. The expression of R1 is dynamically regulated by ABA and NaCl. Transcription factors ELONG HYCOTYL 5 (HY) and HYHOMOLOG (HY) regulate R1 via binding to R1 promoter. Genetic analyses reveal R1 mediates multiple functions of HY in responses seed germination postgermination to ABA and abiotic, and seedling to salinity tolerance. Pull-down and Bi assays show R1 interacts with HYHY in vitro and in vivo. R1 and HYHY may function as a module in responses A and abiotic stresses. R1 binds ABI5 promoter thereby regulating its expression, while R1 interaction stimulates HY binding to ABI.
Mitochondrial complex I is the largest and most complicated proton pump of the respiratory chain. It transfers electrons from NADH to ubiquinone and pumps four protons from the matrix into the intermembrane space. In humans, defects in complex I are involved in a wide range of degenerative disorders. Recent structural analysis of proary and eukotic I confirmed that redox reactions are confined to the hydrophil peripheral arm and take place at a distance from the domain. This implies that the pumping within the membrane arm is driven via long conformation coupling. However, the mechanism, number, and localization of pumpites remain unclear. We report that deletion of the gene for a small subunit of the complex, a stable sub ( nbm ) is formed that lacks the distal part of the domain. Single analysis revealed that nb lacks the distal part of the domain. Our results provide evidence that the arm harbours two functionally distinct modules connected by a helical element recently identified.
