In this study, we investigated the effect of fever on the binding affinity of antibodies to malaria antigens in vitro. We used isothermal titration calorimetry and ELISA to measure the binding of monoclonal antibodies to malaria antigens at 37°C, 40°C, and 42°C. We observed a marked increase in the affinity of the antibody-antigen complexes at 40°C compared to 37°C and 42°C. We also found that thermal equilibration of the protein partners at these temperatures in vitro prior to measurements increased their binding.
Actomy-based cortical flow is a fundamental for cellular morphogenesis. Cortical flows are generated by cross-linked networks of actin filaments and myosin, which produce stress by motor activity is opposed by resistance to network deformation. Continuous flow requires local remodeling through cross unbinding and/or filament disassembly. Here, we study a model for cross-linked network with motors based on minimal requirements for production and dissipation of contractile stress: Asymmetric compliance, spatial heterogeneity of motor, reversible-links and filament turnover. We characterize production and dissipation of network depend individually on cross dynamics and filament, and how these combine to determine cortical flow. Our model predicts that turnover is required to maintain stress against resistance and steady flow in response to external stress. Steady stress increases with lifetime up to τ, then decreases above τ. Effective increases with lifetime up τ, then becomes independent of lifetime and dependent on cross dynamics. These dependencies of stress and viscosity define multiple regimes of flow. Our model predicts that when lifetimes are shorter both τ and τ, dependencies of viscosity and stress on turnover cancel, such that flow is insensitive to turnover and shows simple on activity and dynamics.
Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings are sensitive to high levels of glucose and fructose in the growth medium. We identified a quantitative trait locus ( QTL ) GS11 that confers resistance to high sugar using natural variation analysis and selection. GS11 was mapped through genotyping and confirmed in near-isogenic lines in Col and C24 backgrounds. Allelism and transgenic tests showed that GS11 lies within the AN060 gene. The AN060 allele confers sugar insensitivity and is dominant over the sugar-sensitive C24 allele. Genomic and mRNA analyses showed a single-nucleotide polymorphism ( SNP ) in AN060 affects splicing such that 20 additional nucleotides are present in mRNA. This creates a stop codon resulting in a truncated AN060 lacking the transmembrane domain ( TMD ) present in C060. The absence of T results in nuclear localization of AN060. The short version of AN060 is found in ∼% of natural Arabidopsis accessions. Glucose induces GS11AN060 in a process requiring abisic acid (ABA ) signaling. Chromatin immunoprecipitation-qPCR and transient analysis showed ABI directly binds GS11AN060 to activate transcription. Interestingly, AN060 reduced ABA sensitivity and Gl-induced ABA, and ABI was also reduced in AN060 lines. Thus, sugar-ABA induces AN060, but truncated AN attenuates ABA and signaling.
Cyclic guanosine monophosphate (c-di-GMP) is a bacterial second messenger that regulates a wide range of behaviors, including the transition of planktonic cells to biofilm communities. In Pseudomonas aeruginosa, we show that c-di-G signaling gains specificity by rewiring into the Hpt regulatory cascade, which controls biofilm formation and motility. This rewiring relies on the interaction between the c-di-G synthase Hsb and the anti-sigma factor Hsb, and the dynamic localization of Hsb at the cell poles.
Visuomotor learning is the ability to learn and store multiple mappings between visual stimuli and motor responses. However, little is known about how this learning generalises to novel conditions. In this study, participants performed a rapid pointing task while visual feedback was presented with different offsets depending on the target shape. They needed to use different visomotor mappings depending on the shape to hit the target. Shapes were morphed between spiky and circular. After training, we tested performance without feedback on novel shapes. We compared two hypotheses. First, we hypothesised that participants could extract the relationship between shape and visomotor and generalise. Second, we developed a Bayesian model that predicts generalisation is consistent with categorisation. The results show that learning requires awareness of cues, but participants apply the mapping to the shape most similar to the current. The Bayesian model predicts learning slows with increased training pairs, which was confirmed. We found correspondence between the model and results, indicating it poses a mechanism for multiple visomotor learning.
Climbing fibers are one of the two main inputs to the cerebellum and are generally believed to be involved in the timing of motor commands and motor learning. Climbing fiber activation leads to all-or-none action potentials in cerebellar Purkin cells, silencing them for a brief period afterwards. Climbing fibers can transmit a burst of spikes as a result of an olivary cell spike, potentially increasing the information transferred to the cerebellum. The size of the climbing fiber burst is related to the phase of the ongoing subthreshold membrane oscillation of the oliv cell, i. e. the phase of the oscillation is reflected in the size of the fiber. We used a three-compartment model of an oliv cell to investigate the factors determining the size of the fiber. Our findings suggest that the phase dependency of the size is present but that flow between soma and dendrite is a major determinant of the fiber.
Iron is essential for all living organisms due to its redox properties. However, these properties can also lead to toxicity through the production of reactive species. The liver is the main site of iron regulation. Iron misregulation is implicated in many diseases and our understanding of metabolism improves the list of iron-related disorders. Recent developments have led to knowledge of the fate of iron in the body and a detailed map of its metabolism. However, a quantitative understanding of how components interact to produce regulation remains elusive. Here, we present a mechanistic computational model of human iron metabolism that includes core components. It was constructed on mechanisms and kinetic obtained from several publications. The model was quantitatively validated by comparing results with previously published data and was able to reproduce multiple findings. A simulation following an oral dose was compared to a clinical study and was found to recreate the dynamics and scale of the response to challenge. A disease simulation of haemochromosis was created by altering a parameter that mimics a haemromosis gene mutation. The provides a quantitative of the that arises in this disease. This model supports the role of the liver as an sensor and a framework for further modelling to identify targets and design experiments to improve this system.
Transport of molecules across the nuclear envelope (NE) is regulated by the nuclear pore complex (NPC). Selective transport occurs on a timescale of milliseconds and length of tens of nanometers; however, the mechanism remains elusive. Central to the process are hydrophobic interactions between karyopherins (kaps) and P-G (FG) domains. We have established a coarse-grained model of the NPC that mimics nucletoplasmic transport, taking into account the polymeric nature of FG-repeats on the NPC structure and kap-F hydrophobic affinity. The model predicts the first-passage time of a 15 nm cargo is about 2.6±.13 ms with an inverse distribution for statistically independent Brown dynamics. The cargo is primarily attached to the wall where it interacts with FG as it passes the channel. The kap-F hydroobic is highly dynamic and fast, ensuring efficient through the NPC. Almost all hydrophobic spots on are occupied during transport. In contrast, filaments-deficient NPCs show high permeability to, implying filaments in the barrier.
Determining the optimal infectious dose of a pathogen for nonhuman primate (NHP) models is a critical for testing interventions against human pathogens such as HIV, tuberculosis, and malaria. The NHP model is the best experimental model for testing designed to block infection by these pathogens. However, the model requires the use of a limiting dose of the infectious agent, where only a fraction of animals become infected upon given challenge. Determining the challenge dose of pathogen in experiments is critical to the success of the experiment: using too-high or too-low a dose may lead to false results and excessive use of animals. Here, I define a protocol for determining the dose of pathogen that infects 50% of the time (ID50%); other doses, e. g. ID80, can be easily calculated from same data. This protocol minimizes number of animals as well as resources, while providing estimate of ID50 within 1.5 of true.
Adaptation and Selective Transmission in the Auditory Neuron AN2 of Crickets: A Novel Mechanism of Sensory Adaptation in the Auditory Neuron AN2 of Crickets: A Novel Mechanism of Sensory Adaptation in Prions are infectious proteins that cause neurodegenerative diseases such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) and Bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE). Previous studies have shown that the mammalian prion protein (PrP) polybasic domains bind the disease-associated prion PrSc, suggesting that these domains of cellular prion protein (PC) serve as docking sites for PrSc during prion propagation. To examine the role of polybasic domains in the context of full-length PC, we used prion proteins lacking one or both polybasic domains expressed from Chinese hamster ovary (CHO) cells as substrates in serial protein misfolding cyclic amplification (PMCA) reactions. After ∼5 rounds of PM, PrSc lacking the central poly domain (Δ) were formed. Surprisingly, in contrast to wild-type prions, Δ-PrSc prions could bind and induce conversion of the poly domain mutant substrates into PrSc molecules. Remarkably, Δ-PrSc and poly domain PrSc displayed diminished or absent biological infectivity relative to wild Pr, despite ability to seed PM reactions of mouse brain homogen. These results suggest that Δ-Pr prions interact with PC through a novel mechanism, yielding expanded substrate and efficient Pr propagation. Furthermore, poly domain deficient Pr provide the first example of dissociation between brain homogen PM seeding from biological infectivity.
Animals are able to reach a desired state in an environment by controlling various behavioral patterns. To understand how animals make decisions and how the nervous system processes information, it is important to identify the behavioral strategies used for control. However, methods to quantify such strategies have not been fully established. In this study, we developed an inverse-learning ( IRL ) framework to identify an’s strategy from behavioral data. We applied this framework to C. elegans thermactic behavior after cultivation at constant temperature or without food, fed worms preferred, while starved worms avoided temperature on a thermal gradient. Our IRL revealed that fed worms used both temperature and its derivative and their involved two strategies: directed ( DM ) and isothermal ( IM ). DM efficiently reached specific temperatures explaining thermactic behavior when fed. IM moved along constant reflecting isothermal well-observed in previous. In contrast, starved worms escaped temperature using only, not the derivative of. We investigated the underlying strategies by applying to thermens neuron-deficient worms. Our I-based is useful in identifying from behavioral data and could be to a range of, including in other.
Chrychromina tobin is a species of alga that belongs to the order Prymiales (Haptophyceae ). It is an important player in aquatic ecosystems due to its role in carbon sequestration, formation of harmful blooms, and as a food source of fatty acids for a wide range of species. Chrychromina to is a mixotrophic alga, meaning it can obtain nutrients from both photosynthesis and heterotrophy. Despite its importance, the nuclear genome of only one alga, Emilian hleyi (Isochryales ) has been sequenced. Here, we report the draft genome of Chrychromina and transcript data collected over 24 hours. The genome is 59 Mb in size, 40% of which is protein coding and encodes 16, 777 genes. Genes involved in fatty acid synthesis, modification and catabolism show distinct expression patterns over the circadian photoperiod. The genome encodes a hybrid polyketide synth/nonribosomal synthase complex, anti-microbial peptides, and proteins involved in multidrug and toxic compound extrusion. A new alga xorhodopsin was identified together with two RuBisCOases shared across algal lineages.
Breast cancers that lack estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) are classified as triple-negative and belong to the Basal molecular subtype. Basal-like breast cancers are associated with mutations in the BRCA1 and TP53 genes. Our studies in mice show that inactivation of BRCA1 and TP53 is sufficient to suppress normal cell death in the mammary epithelium. Furthermore, concomitant inactivation of all three pathways in the mammary epithelium has an additive effect on tumor latency and predisposes highly penetrant metastatic adenocarcinomas. These tumors are poorly differentiated and have histologic features common to human BRCA-mutated tumors, including heterogeneous morphology, metaplasia and necrosis. Gene expression analyses show that these tumors share attributes of both Bas-like and Claudin-low signatures, two subtypes encompassed by the broader triple-negative class defined by clinical markers.
Aedes aegypt (L.) is the primary vector of dengue virus, the most important arboiral disease globally. Until an effective vaccine is licensed and rigorously administered, Ae.egypt control remains the principal tool in preventing and curtailing deng transmission. Accurate predictions of vector populations are required to assess methods and develop effective reduction strategies. Aeegy develops primarily in artificial water containers. Release studies indicate that adult Aeegy do not disperse over long distances. Therefore, containers in an area of high development density are likely to be ovip sites and frequently used ovip than that are relatively isolated from other sites. After accounting for container characteristics, frequently used ovip are likely to produce mosquitoes at a higher rate. Most studies Aeeg populations ignore the density of larval sites. Pupal surveys were carried out from 2004 to 2007 in rural Kameng Phet, Thailand. In total, 84, samples of water containers were used to estimate parameters. Regression was used to assess the effect of lar development density, access to water, and seasonal variation on productivity. A varying model was employed to account for differences between container types. A two modeling, called hurdle, accounts for zeroes and overdispersion in counts. The number of sites and their density were primary determinants of Aeeg distribution and abundance. Productivity increased as density. An ecological accounting for density is appropriate for Aeeg levels and programs.
In the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, the conserved Target of Rapamycin complex 2 ( TOR2 ) mediates gut-to-brain signaling in the regulation of phenotypic plasticity. TOR2 acts in the intestine to regulate the expression of daf-7 and daf-28 peptides, which reflect bacterial-dependent feeding status. These peptides promote a binary decision between growth and entry into the dauer larval stage in response to pherom, food, and temperature. In the adult, TOR2 acts in the intestine to modulate food-regulated foraging via the PDF-2/PDF-1 neuropeptide pathway. We find that genetic variation affects food-dependent larval and adult phenotypes, and identify quantitative trait loci ( QTL ) associated with these traits. These results suggest that TOR2 acts as a hub for communication of feeding information from the gut to the brain, thereby modulating neuronal function by state.
Understanding the transcriptional regulation of embryonic stem (ES) cells is fundamental for efforts to direct their differentiation and reprogramming. We analyzed the transcriptional profiles of mouse ES cells and primordial germ cells, identifying genes upregulated in pluripotent cells in vitro and in vivo. These genes are involved in transcription, chromatin remodeling, cell cycle, and DNA repair. We developed Compoby, a novel algorithm combining aligned and non-aligned sequences with a probabilistic segmentation model to predict short DNA motifs regulating expression. Compoby was used to identify conserved motifs in pluripotent genes. We show these motifs are active in undifferentiated ES and embryonic germ cells in a sequence-specific manner, acting as enhancers with an endogenous promoters. Importantly, their activity is conserved in human ES. We show transcription factor NF-Y binds one motif, differentially expressed during ES differentiation, required for ES proliferation.
Vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) is a non-segmented negative-strand RNA virus that replicates through the continuous supply of nucleoprotein (N) in the form of a complex with phosphoprotein (P). Here, we present the structural characterization of a soluble heterodimer complex between a variant of SV lacking its N-terminal residues (ΔN21) and a peptide of 60 amino acids (P60) encompassing the molecular recognition element (RE) of P that binds RNA-free N. The complex crystallized in decameric form was solved at 3.0 Å resolution, revealing how RE folds upon binding to N and competes with RNA binding and polymerization. Small-angle X-ray scattering and NMR spectroscopy on the complex confirm binding of RE and indicate its flanking regions remain flexible. The structure of this complex suggests a mechanism for initiation of viral RNA synthesis.
In the fly visual system, the vertical system (VS) is a network of cells that plays a key role in processing visual information. These cells primarily connect to each other via axonal gap junctions, a type of electrical synapse. This provides a unique opportunity to explore the role of gap junctions in sensory processing. Our analysis of a realistic VS model shows that within 10 ms of visual input onset, gap junctions enable the system to efficiently encode the axis of rotation, θ, of the fly’s motion. This efficiency is near-optimal with respect to physical limits determined by the input’s statistical structure. The network is connected to downstream pathways via a subset of VS cells; we found that gap junctions make this subpopulation’s encoding of θ superior to the whole network and robust to a range of signal to noise ratios. This subpopulation’s efficient encoding is necessary for the fly’s visually guided behavior, such as banked turns in evasive maneuvers. Because gap junctions are among VS axons, they only impact the system’s readout while maintaining dendritic input. Our study shows how specific connectivity leads to efficient encoding of stimuli.
Enterovirus 71 (EV) is a major causative agent of hand, foot, and mouth disease, a common febrile disease in children. EV has also been associated with severe neurological diseases including fatal cases in large EV outbreaks in Asia. Recently, PSGL-1 was identified as a cellular receptor for entry and replication of EV in leukocytes. PS-1 is a sialucylated on the surface of leukocytes and serves as a high affinity counterceptor for selectins, mediating leukocyte rolling on endothelium. The PS-1–select interaction requires sulfation of at least one of three tyrosines and adjacent O-gcan sial Lewis in N-terminal of PS-1. To elucidate the molecular basis of PS-–71 interaction, we generated PS- mutants and identified postlational modifications critical for PS binding to EV. We expressed PS- in 293 cells and transfected cells were assayed for their abilities to bind EV by flow cytometry. We found O-glycosylation T, critical for PS–select interaction, is not necessary for PS binding to EV. On the other hand, site-directed mutagenesis one or more tyrosine sulfation in N-terminal PS significantly impaired PS binding to EV. Furthermore, inhibitor of sulf, sodium, blocked PS–EV interaction and PS-mediated replication EV in Jurkat cells in dose-dependent manner.
Leishmanias is a global health problem that affects millions of people worldwide. Current treatments for leishiasis are limited by toxicity and the emergence of drug-resistant strains. Inhibitors of the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) have been shown to exert anti-parasitic effects. This study tested the therapeutic efficacy of mTOR inhibitors in controlling Leishmania major infection. Rapamycin, G-2128 and K-379 were administered to BAL/c mice that received an intrafoot injection of the parasite. Foot swelling and parasite burden were assessed, and cytokine production by splenocytes and phenotypic changes in draining lymph nodes were evaluated. Treatment with clinically relevant doses of rapycin or G-212, but not K-379 dramatically lowered foot swelling and parasite burden in draining nodes. Importantly, rapycin did not kill promastigotes in vitro. Moreover, IL-4 production of splenocytes from mice treated with rapycin was reduced. Consequently, IFNγ:IL-4 ratio was elevated, suggesting a Th1-skewed cytokine profile. Finally, expression of CD, an activation marker on splenic and node CD+ CD+ T cells was enhanced in rapycin-treated mice. Our findings suggest mTOR inhibitors may be used in leishias management. We propose beneficial effects stem from immunomodulatory properties.
Natural transformation is the process by which competent bacteria take up free DNA and incorporate it into their genomes, becoming genetically transformed. To prevent deleterious transformation by foreign DNA, several species preferentially take up their own DNA containing specific DUS (DNA uptake sequence) marks. We show that ComP is the long sought D receptor in Neisseria species, enabling functional analysis of the D-Com interdependence. In Neisseria meningidis, abolishing ComP enhances transformation in the presence of DUS and controls transformation in absence of D. Peripheral DUS bases are less important, while inner bases are essential since single mutations dramatically impair interaction with Com and transformation. Strikingly, naturally occurring D variants in Neisser commals differing from D by one or two bases are similarly impaired for transformation. We show Com from N sub commal binds cognate D variant and mediates D-enhanced transformation in com mutant N meningidis, confirming similar mechanism used by Neisser to promote own or closely related DNA.
In fission yeast, cell division requires the coordinated closure of the contractile actomyos ring (CAR) and formation of the septum, a specialized cell wall structure. While many CAR proteins have been identified, how they interact with septum enzymes to form the septum remains unclear. Our study shows that cooperation between the paxillin homolog Pxl, required for CAR integrity, and Bgs, the enzyme responsible for linear (1, 3) glucan synthesis and septum formation, is required for stable anchorage of CAR to the plasma membrane before septation and cleavage. We show that lack of Pxl in combination with Bgs depletion causes failure of ring contraction and cell overgrowth towards the lumen without sept formation. We also show that Pxl concentration at CAR increases during cytokinesis and this depends on the SH domain of the protein Cdc15. Bgs depletion in cells carrying cdcΔ3 allele causes ring disassembly and sept block, as in cells lacking Pxl. On the other hand, Pxl absence is lethal when C15 function is affected, generating large CAR with septum deposition along the cortex. Our findings indicate that CAR anchorage to plasma through C15 and Pxl, conitant Bgs activity are necessary for CAR and sept formation in yeast.
Glanders is a highly infectious zoonotic disease caused by the gram-negative bacterium Burkholderia malle that can cause severe disease in animals and humans. Although eradicated in many countries, it has recently emerged in Asia, the Middle East, Africa, and South America. We investigated a recent outbreak of glanders in Bahrain by applying high resolution genotyping ( multiple locus variable number of tandem repeats, MLVA ) and whole genome sequencing to B. malle isolated from infected horses and camels. The results were compared to samples from an outbreak in the United Arab Emirates in 2004 and placed into a broader phylogeographic context based on previously published B. malle data. The samples from the outbreak in Bahrain separated into two distinct clusters, suggesting a complex epidemiological background and involvement of multiple B. malle strains. The samples from Bahrain were more closely related to B. malle isolated in the UAE in 2004 than other. malle, suggesting repeated importation to the region from similar sources.
American cutaneous leishmaniasis (ACL) is a disease that causes approximately 67,000 new cases per year. The severity of the disease depends on the parasite; however, in the majority of cases confirmation is not feasible. The World Health Organization (WHO) suggests that ACL is produced by Leishmania braziliensis, and the first line treatment are pentavalent ant derivatives (Glucime or Stibogluconate ) under systemic administration. According to authors, pentavalent ant derivatives treatment for ACL show a healing rate of 75% and reasons for treatment failure are not known. In order to characterise the clinical and parasitological features of patients with ACL that did not respond to Glucime, a cross-sectional study was carried out in a cohort of 43 patients recruited in three Colombian National reference centers for ACL. Clinical and paraclinical, epidemiological and geographic information were recorded for each. Parasitological, histological and PCR confirmation were performed. Glucime IC50 and in vitro infectivity for isolated were estimated. Predominant infecting Leish species was L brazili (95% ) and 35% of parasites showed significant decrease in vitro Gluc susceptibility associated with administration medic. Lesion and infect of parasite are negatively correlated with Gluc susceptibility (Spearman: -0,548 and -0,726; ) A negative correlation between lesion and parasite is documented. brazili was main species associated with patients that underwent treatment failure or relapse.
In this study, we investigated the interplay between the biosynthetic pathways of siderophores and colactin in Escheria coli. Siderophores are iron-scavenging molecules and colactin is a genotoxin. Both pathways require 4′-osphopantin transferase (PTase). Only two PTases have been identified: Ent and Clb. Ent is part of the core genome, whereas Clb is encoded on a pathogenic island. The island is associated with the pathogenic island (PI) in highly virulent strains. PI carries genes for yiniactin synthesis except the cognate PT. We demonstrated that Clb can contribute to siderores synthesis. Inactivation of both Ent and Clb abolished virulence of extra-intestinal pathogenic E coli (Ex) in mouse sepsis model. Either Ent or Clb is required for Ex survival in vivo. This is the first report of multiple PT pathways leading to distinct metabolites in a microorganism. We hypothesize that association of island with PI has been selected in highly virulent coli because Clb is promisc PT that contributes to genotoxin and siderores. The data highlight complex interaction of virulence with functions.
Probabilistic Phylogen Inference with Insertions and Deletions is a probabilistic model for phylogenetic inference that accounts for insertions and deletions in addition to substitutions. The model is based on a continuous-time Markov process and a non-reversible birth–death evolutionary model for insertions and deletions. The model assumes that insertions and deletions occur one residue at a time. The model is applied to phylogen inference by extending the program dnaml in phyl.
Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) infects the skin by initially infecting the mucosal epidermis prior to entering nerve endings. In the skin, epidermal Langerhans cells (LCs) are the first dendritic cells (DCs) to encounter HSV, but it is CD103+ dermal DCs that carry viral antigen to lymph nodes for presentation, suggesting DC cross-talk in the skin. In this study, we compared topically HSV-1 infected human skin explants with biopsies of human genital herpes lesions to show that LCs are initially infected and emigrate into the dermis. Here, LC bearing markers of maturation and apoptosis formed large clusters with BD3+ dermal DC (thought to be equivalent to murine CD+ dermal DC ) and DC-S+ DC/macages. HSV-expressing LC were observed inside dermal DC/macages and BD3 dermal DC had upregulated damaged uptake receptor CLEC9. No other epidermal cells interacted with dermal DC. Correspondingly, LC isolated from skin and infected with HSV-1 in vitro underwent apoptosis and were taken by BD3 dermal DC and DC+ cells. Thus, we conclude a viral relay takes place where infected LCs undergo apoptosis and are taken by dermal DC for antigen presentation. This provides rationale for targeting these cells with mucosal or intradermal immunization.
Leishmania parasites are obligate intracellular protozoan pathogens that cause leishmaniasis in humans and animals. In this study, we investigated the biogenesis of parasitophorous vacuoles ( PVs ) in mouse bone marrow-derived macrophages infected with Leishmania major or L amazonensis amastigotes. We found that PVs housing one or two L. major amastotes are small and tight-fitting, while PVs housing many L amazon amastotes are large and giant. We used multidimensional imaging of live cells to compare PV biogenesis in macrophages infected with L. major or L amazon amastotes and loaded with Lotracker, a lysosotropic fluorescent probe. Three features of L major PVs were documented: i ) entry of Lotr into tight-fitting L major PVs; ii ) decrease in number of macrophage vesicles during major PV fission; iii ) PV remodeling after homotypic fusion. In contrast, amazon PVs were characterized by ii ) decrease in number of macroage vesicles during PV enlargement; iii ) PV remodeling after homotyp fusion. Multidimensional imaging allowed us to update our understanding of Leish species-specific differences in PV biogenesis and could be useful for study of other intracellular microorganisms.
Chromatin Structure Regulates Homologous Recombination and Gene Conversion. Homologous recombination is a powerful mechanism for maintaining and altering genomic structure. We investigated how chromatin contributes to the use of homologous sequences as donors for repair in the chicken DT40 cell line. Immunoglobulin genes undergo sequence diversification by gene conversion templated by pseudogene donors. We found that immunoglobulin V pseudogene is characterized by histone modifications associated with active chromatin. We demonstrated the importance of chromatin for conversion using a regulatable system in which heterochromatin protein HP1 (Drosophila melanogaster Su), expressed as fusion Escheria coli repressor, is tethered to polymerase integrated within pseudoλ array. Tether HP diminished histone acetylation within pseudoλ, and altered outcome V diversification so templated mutations rather than templated predominated.
The cerebellum plays a crucial role in adjusting motor behavior in response to changing situations. It has been assumed that cerebellar motor learning is guided by the difference between desired and actual behavior, i. e., by error. Not only immediate but also future behavior benefits from error because it induces lasting changes in parallel synapses on Purkin cells ( PCs ), whose output mediates behavioral adjustments. Olivary climbing fibers, connecting PCs, are thought to transport information on errors for synaptic modification but do not contribute to memory. In this study, we tested monkeys in a saccadic learning paradigm that challenges this concept. We demonstrate a clear spike signature of error at time of occurrence and a reverberation of this signature later before new behavior manifestation to improve.
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease characterized by selective loss of motor neurons and inclusions containing the RNA binding protein TDP-43. In this study, we used a yeast model of ALS exhibiting T-43 dependent toxicity to show that overexpression of T-43 dramatically alters cell shape and reduces ubiquitin dependent proteolysis of a reporter. Furthermore, we show that overexpression of the chaperone S1 reduces T-43’s effect on toxicity and proteolysis. The strength of these effects was influenced by the presence of the endogenous prion [+]. Overexpression of S1 altered T-43 pattern, but we did not detect association of S1 with T-43, suggesting indirect effects on T- aggregation. Overexpression of the mammalian S1 homologue DNA1 relieved T- mediated toxicity in rodent cortical neurons, suggesting S1 and homologues may have neuroprotective effects in ALS.
Chagas disease is a major public health issue in many Latin American countries. Chagas disease is caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi ( T. cruzi ) transmitted by triatomine bugs. In this study, we investigated the parasite load and molecular diversity of T. cruzi in patients with chronic Chagas disease from different regions of Brazil. We used multilocus PCR and quantitative real time PCR ( qPCR ) to perform molecular typing and parasite quantification from blood specimens of 65 patients. All patients were recruited at the same health center, but from different geographic regions of Brazil. Of 35 ( 53. 8% ) patients presented positive amplification by qPCR, 20 ( 30. 7% ) had indeterminate form and 15 ( 23. 1% ) cardiac form. The median parasite load for all positive patients was 2.54 [ 1.43–11.14 parasite/mL, ranging from 0.12 to 153.66. Notably, parasite load was higher in patients over 70 years (20.05 [18–86.29 parasite/mL ). We genotyped T cruzi in spiked blood samples with reference strains from six DTUs to 0.5 parasite/mL with high specificity. Of positive qPCR patients, we identified T cruz DT in 28 (80% ). Remaining 20% had partial result. Specimens showed Tc, TII and mixed Tc prevalence equal 40%,17.1% and 14.3% respectively. Two patients were infected Tc and one coinfected TIIIc+VI. These patients were in chronic chag cardiomyopathy (CCC ) and from Bahia northeast Brazil. T cruz genotypes were compared with load, elevated loads in TII (7.56 parasite/mL ) compared to TVI (2.35/mL ). However, CCC was 50% in TII and only 16.7% TII evolved CCC.
Between 2009 and 2011, enhanced rabies surveillance was conducted in Guatemala as part of a larger pathogen detection program. A total of 672 bats from 31 species were sampled and tested for rabies. The prevalence of rabies virus (RV) among collected bats was 0. 3%. Viral antigens were detected and virus isolated from the brains of two common vampire bats (Desmodus rotus). RV was also isolated from oral swabs, lungs, and kidneys of both bats, whereas viral RNA was detected in all tissues by hemi-nested RT-PCR except the liver of one. Sequencing of the nucleoprotein showed both viruses were 100% identical, whereas sequencing the glycoprotein revealed one nonsynonymous (302S). The vampire RV isolates in this study were phylogenetically related to viruses associated with vampire bats in eastern Mexico and El Salvador. Additionally, 7% of sera from 398 bats demonstrated RV neutralizing antibody. The proportion of seropositive bats varied across troph guilds, suggestive of intraspecific compartmentalization of RV perpetuation.
Lamin A is known to play a role in the regulation of chromatin structure and transcriptional activity. In this report, we show that lamin also plays a role in the downregulation of heterochatin and gene activation. Herpes virus initiates replication near the edge of the nucleus and histones are excluded from these structures. We examined HSV infection in wild-type and lamin-deficient murine embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs). In lamin-deficient cells, viral compartments are reduced in size and fail to target the periphery as in wild-type cells. Chromatin immunoprecipitation and immunofluorescence studies show that HSV is associated with heterochatin in lamin-deficient MEFs. These results argue for a role of lamin in viral expression, replication, and growth. Lamin is required for targeting viral genome and reduction of heterochatin on viral promoters during lytic infection. The lamin can serve as scaffold for DNA and protein that regulate both euchatin and heterochatin modifications.
Mitochondria originated from proteobacterial endosymbionts and their transition to organelles was tightly linked to the establishment of protein import pathways. The initial import of proteins is mediated by the transloc of the outer (TOM). Although TOM is common to all forms of mitochondria, unexpected diversity of subunits between eukotic lineages has been predicted. Here we analysed the TOM in hydrogenosomes, a metabolically anaerobic form of mitochond found in the excav Trichomonas vaginal. We demonstrate that highly divergent β-bar T vaginal TOM (Tv)40 forms translocation channel to hydrogenosomal import. Tv40 is present in high weight complexes and analysis revealed presence of tailored (TA) proteins. Two of them Tom36 and Tom46 with heat protein (H) and tetratopeptide (PR) domains bind hydrogenosomal proteins and likely function as receptors. A third unit Tom22 protein has short domain and conserved transmembrane but lacks domain The fourth protein hydrogenosomal outer protein19 (Hom) has no homology. Our data indicate TvOM associated sorting assembly (SAM) that in β-bar assembly. Visualisation TvOM by microscopy that forms three and has shape.
Autoimmune diseases are often result from inappropriate or inadequate activation of CD4 and CD8 T cells. Genetic studies of disease-associated polymorphisms have highlighted the importance of biological context for regulatory variants in understanding the immune system and its cellular phenotypes. Here, we show cell-specific regulation of transcript levels of genes associated with autoimmune diseases in CD4 and CD8 T cells, including a trans-acting locus at chr12q13. 2 containing the rs1017 SNP in R26 gene. We also identify a missense variant in IL27 associated with type 1 diabetes that results in decreased protein activity and expression of downstream IR1 and STAT in CD T cells. Our results indicate eQ mapping in purified cells provides novel insights into polymorphisms and pathways with autoimmune.
In the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis, HAT) is a major public health problem. In the provinces of Bandu and Kasa Oriental, which are lagging behind in HAT elimination efforts, we conducted a qualitative study to understand the socio-economic and cultural barriers to H screening and treatment. We interviewed current and former H patients, as well as healthcare providers and program managers of the national H control program. Our results show that community members and health workers quote a number of taboos that must be respected for six months after H treatment: no work, no sex, no food, and no sun. Violating these taboos is believed to cause serious and sometimes deadly complications. These taboos are well-known by the community and lead people to avoid H screening for fear of observing them in case of diagnosis. The tabos were originally aimed to mitigate the adverse effects of the melarsop regimen, but are not evidence-based and obsolete with new drugs.
Since December 2009, Médecins Sans Frontières has diagnosed and treated patients with visceral leishmaniasis (VL) in Tabarak Hospital, eastern Gedare State, one of the main foci of VL in Sudan. We conducted an exhaustive door-to-door survey in 45 villages of Alure locality to estimate VL incidence. The survey was conducted between 5th May and 17th June 2011. All deaths were investigated by verbal autopsies. Individuals with (i) fever at least two weeks, (ii) VL diagnosed and treated in previous year, (iii) clinical suspicion post-kala-azar der leishiasis (PKDL) were referred to medical teams for ascertainment. A new VL case was clinical with positive rk39 rapid test or direct agglutination test (DAT). In 45 villages screened, 17,702 households were interviewed for population 94,369. The crude mortality over mean period 409 days was 0.13/10 people per day. VL was possible probable cause for 19% deaths. VL mortality was estimated 0.9/100 per year. The teams examined 551 individuals for fever at least weeks. Of these,16 were diagnosed primary VL. The incidence over year was 7.0/100 persons or 7.9 when deaths possibly due were included. Overall 12.5% (11,943,609) reported past VL episode.
Bacterial chromosomes are compacted into a supercoiled structure by the enzyme gyrase in an ATP-dependent reaction. The supercoiling density ( σ ) of prokaryotic DNA occurs in two forms: diffusible (D ) and constrained (C ). Diffible supercoils move freely around the chromosome in 10 kb domains, while constrained supercoils result from abundant proteins that bend, loop, or unwind DNA at many sites. Diffible and constrained supercoils contribute equally to total in vivo supercoiling in wild-type cells, so σ=σ+σ. Unexpectedly, Escherichia coli has a 15% higher σ than Salmonella enterica. We analyzed Salmonella strains using a 9 kb supercoil sensor inserted at ten positions around the genome. The sensor contains a Lac operon flanked by resolvase binding sites and monitors supercoiling and elongation in WT and mutant strains. Transcription causes supercoiling to increase upstream and decrease downstream of highly expressed genes. Excess supercoiling is relaxed by Top I and gyrase replenishes superco to maintain equilibrium. Strains with gyrase mutations at permissive exhibit superco varying from 30% WT to total σ at most locations. Supercoils are influenced by transcription because rifampic causes superco to rebound throughout chromosome. Gyrase mutants cause superco also reduce elongation throughout genome.
Leishmania amazonensis is an intracellular protozoan parasite that replicates in parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs), which share features with late endosomes/lysosomes. During infection, PVs expand but the impact of PV size on parasite intracellular survival is unknown. We show that host cells infected with L. amazon upregulate LYSTBe, which regulates lysosome size. Mutations in LYSTBe caused PV expansion and enhanced L amazonensis replication. In contrast, LYSTBe overexpression led to small PVs that did not sustain parasite growth. Treatment of LYSTBe overexpressing cells with vacolin reversed this phenotype, expanding PV and promoting growth. The opposite was seen with E-64, which reduced PV in LYSTBe mutant and inhibited amazonensis. Enlarged PV protect parasites from oxidative damage since inhibition of nitric synth had no effect on amazon within PV, but enhanced within LYSTBe-induced smalls.
Mutations in the monocarboxylate transporter 8 (MCT) gene are associated with Allan-Herndonudley syndrome (AHDS), an X-linked disorder characterized by delayed development, severe intellectual disability, hypotonia, spastic paraplegia, and disturbed thyroid hormone (TH) parameters. In order to determine the pathophysiological mechanisms of AH, we generated M8 mutant zebraf using zinc-finger nuclease (ZFN)-mediated gene editing. Elimination of M8 decreased TH expression; however, it did not affect expression of other TH-related genes. Similar to patients, M8− larvae exhibited neurological and behavioral deficiencies. High-throughput behavioral assays demonstrated M− larvae exhibited reduced locomotor activity, altered response to light and dark transitions and increased sleep. These behavioral deficiencies were associated with expression myelin genes and neuron deficiencies in circuit formation. Time-lapse imaging of single-axon arbors and synapses in M− larvae revealed reduction in filopodia and axon branching in sensory neurons and synaptic density in motor neurons. These phenotypes enable assessment of therapeutic potential TH analogs that enter cells in absence M8. TH analogs restored myelin and axon outgrowth in− larvae. These findings suggest mechanism by which M regulates neural assembly mediating sensory and motor behavioral performance.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a ubiquitous virus that causes disease in newborns and immunocompromised or immunosuppressed patients. The virus infects a variety of cell types using different entry pathways that involve forms of the g/g glycoprotein: g/gL/g and g/gUL-131 as well as the fusion glycoprotein g. However, the minimal core machinery for cell fusion is g/g and g. Here, we demonstrate that CMV g and g/g form a stable complex after synthesis in the absence of other proteins. g/g can interact with mutants unable to mediate cell fusion. The g/g complexes as much as 16–50% of total g in CM virus particles. In contrast, small amounts of g/g and gUL-131 complexes found with. All herpesviruses express g and g/g molecules. Most herpesviruses suggest g/g interacts to mediate fusion, although there is no evidence. For herpes simplex (HSV-1) has suggested that after binding g/g binds to either before or coincident with fusion. Our results have implications for these models demonstrating that CM g and g form g complexes are incorporated virions without receptor or fusion.
Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is known to segregate in a tissue-specific manner, but the underlying mechanisms remain unknown. The segregation of pathogenic mtDNA is a major determinant of the onset and severity of disease. Here, we demonstrate that Gimap, an outer membrane GTPase, is a critical regulator of this process in leukocytes. G3 is important for cell development and survival, suggesting that leukocyte survival may be a factor in the regulation of mtDNA variants and modulation of mitochondrial diseases.
Buruli ulcer (BU) is a geographically restricted infection caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans. The incubation period of BU is difficult to estimate globally as most patients reside in endemic regions. However, in Victoria, Australia, a significant proportion of people acquire BU are visitors to endemic regions. We estimated the incubation period of BU on the Bellarine peninsula to be 4. 5 months. Since then, cases on the Bellarine have declined but a new endemic has developed on the Morning peninsula. We retrospectively reviewed 443 cases of BU in Victoria between 2013 and 2016. Telephone interviews were performed to identify cases with a visit to endemic or multiple visits within one month. The incubation was defined as time between exposure and symptom. Data were combined with cases from 2002 to 201. Among 20 cases in short visitors, the incubation was 143 days (4.8 ), similar to 135 (4.5 ). This was despite predominant location shifting from Bell to Morning. We found no association between incubation and age, sex, exposure, duration or location lesion. Our study confirms incubation of BU in Victoria to be 4–5 months.
Toxoplas is an intracellular parasite that possesses a protein containing the phylogenetically conserved sterol-sensing domain (SSD). We investigated the role of this protein in lipid regulation in the parasite. The protein is a Niemann-Pick type 1-related protein (NPC1) with significant identity to human NPC1 and contains residues implicated in human disease. We named this protein TgCR. TCR localizes to flattened vesicles beneath the plasma membrane of Tooplas and lacks endosomal targeting signals. When expressed in mammalian NPC mutant cells and addressed to endo-lysosomes, TCR restores cholesterol and GM1 clearance from these organel. We genetically disrupted TCR in Tooplas. Quantitative lipid analyses reveal normal cholesterol but overaccumulation of cholesteryl esters, sphingomyins and ceramides. ΔCR parasites are characterized by abundant lipid storage bodies and membranous tubules from parasitoph vacoles. They generate multiple daughters per mother at high frequencies and are more virulent in mice than parental.
Ophthalmic syndrome, also known as Waardenburg anophthalmia, is a rare congenital disorder characterized by bilateral anophthalmia and postaxial oligodactyly. We report the identification of homozygous mutations in SMOC ( SPARC-related calcium binding 1 ) in eight unrelated families. The mutations include four nonsense, two frameshift, and two missense. The missense mutations are located in the Thyrogulin-1 ( T1 ) domain of the protein. The mouse ortholog, Smoc, shows stage-specific expression during eye, limb, craniofacial, and somite development. We also report a targeted gene-trap of Smoc ( Sm1tm1 ) that reduces mRNA to ∼10% of wild-type levels. This results in highly penetrant hindlim postaxial oligodactly in homozyg mutant ( Sm1tm1/t1 ) animals. Eyeformations, most coloma and cleft palate occur in a proportion of Sm1tm1/t1 embryos and pups. Loss of SM-1 results in a convincing phenocopy of the disease. SM-1 is a mammalian paralog of Drosophila Pentone, an inhibitor of decapentapleg. The ortholog in Xenopus, Sm- also functions as BMP antagonist in early embryogenesis. Loss of BMP antagon during mammalian development provides a plausible explanation for both limb and eye phenotypes in humans and mice.
Type 1 interferons inhibit HIV replication by inducing the tripartite motif protein TR22 (TR22). TR22 is one of the most strongly upregulated genes in cells treated with interferon. TR22 inhibits HIV replication as shown in previous studies. To assess the role of TR22 under natural conditions, we compared the effects of interferon in cells depleted for TR22 using RNAi and found that HIV release was significantly increased in knockdown, indicating TR22 acts as a natural antiviral effector. TR22 inhibited budding of virus particles containing Gag only, indicating G was the target of TR22. TR did not block release of MLV or EIA G particles. Inhibition was associated with diffuse cytoplasmic staining of G rather than accumulation at the plasma, suggesting TR disrupts proper trafficking. Mutational analyses of TR22 showed that catalytic amino acids Cys and Cys of the R domain are required for TR22 antiral activity.
Mutualisms are interspecific interactions in which both players benefit, but explaining their maintenance is problematic because cheaters should outcompete cooperative conspecifics, leading to mutualism instability. In figs ( Ficus ) are pollinated by host wasps (Agonidae), whose larvae gall in their fruits (syconia). Female pollinating wasps ovip directly into Ficus ovules from inside receptive sycon. Across Ficus species, there is a documented segregation of pollinators in inner ovules and seeds in outerules. This suggests wasps, or are prevented from ovipiting, and this results in mutualism. However, mechanisms preventing was from exploiting outerules remain unknown. We report that Ficus rubosa offspring in outerules are vulnerable to parasitic wasps ovip from outside sycon. Parasism decreases towards centre of sycon, innerules provide enemy-free space for pollinator offspring. We suggest that resulting in viability likely contributes to selection pollin to avoid outer, and was to focus on subset, reduces galling.
Plant growth is a complex trait that is influenced by both genetic and environmental factors and has a significant impact on plant architecture and biomass. We performed six controlled experiments on an interspecific Setaria italica x Setaria viridis recombinant inbred population to assess how plant architecture is influenced by developmental time, water availability, and density. Plant height was measured non-destructively throughout the life cycle in both field and controlled environments. We found that height is reduced under water limitation and high density and affected by environment ( field vs. chamber ). The results support a model where height is a heritable, polygenic trait and major loci that influence height independent of environment. The contribution of loci that influence height changes throughout development and reduction in water environments is a consequence of delayed progression of the program that establishes height in Setaria. In this population, alleles from the weedy S. viridis parent increase height early, whereas a number of small alleles from domesticated S. itica increase height later in development.
Ilus Isolation of Ilus Virus in the Pantanal, West-Central Brazil. The Pantanal wetlands in western Brazil are home to a large number of species of wildlife and hematophagous arthropods, which favor the circulation of zoonotic arboviruses. A previous study in the Nhecolând sub-region of Pant reported serological evidence of flaviviruses, including West Nile virus and Ilus virus ( ILHV ). According to seropositive horses, at least three flaviruses, including ILHV, circulated in the Pant between 2005 and 2009. To extend this study, we collected 3, 234 adult mosquitoes of 16 species in 2009 and 201 in the same region. Mosquito homogenates were assayed for virus on C/36 and Vero cellolayers and tested for flaviral RNA by group-specific real-time RT-PCR. One pool of 50 non-enged female Aedes aegypti tested positive for ILHV by culture and for IL RNA by real RTPCR, indicating a minimum infection rate of 2.5 per 100. Full genomic sequence exhibited 95% identity to only genome available ILHV.
Scabies is one of the most commonest dermatological conditions worldwide and a major public health burden. Current treatments with topical agents and oral ivermectin (IVM) are insufficient and drug resistance is emerging. Moxidin (MO), with advantageous pharmacological profiles, may be a promising alternative. In this study, 12 pigs were randomly assigned to receive oral MO (0. 3mg/kg once ), IV (0.2mg twice ) or no treatment. We evaluated efficacy by mite count, clinical lesions, pruritus and ELISA-determined anti-S. scieiG antibodies. Plasma and pharmacokinetic profiles were determined. At 14 post-treatment, all MO-treated but only IV-treated were mite. MO efficacy was 100% and unchanged until study-end (47 ) compared 62% (26–100 ) for IV, with IV-treated remaining until47. Clinical scabies, pritus and anti. scieiG had disappeared all MO-treated only 75% IV-treated. MO persisted ~9 longer IV in plasma and skin, thereby mite entire cycle and long-lasting.
Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive pathogen that is renowned for its resistance to many antibiotics and prevalence in hospitals. Its genome encodes a low number of proteins with peptoglycan ( PG ) synthesis activity compared to other model organisms. We deleted seven of the nine genes encoding PG enzymes from the S. aureus genome without affecting normal growth or cell morphology, generating a strain capable of PG synthesis catalyzed by only by penicillin-binding proteins PBP1 and bi-functional PBP2. However, PBPs are important in clinically relevant environments as bacteria with minimal synthesis machinery became highly susceptible to cell-target antibiotics and lytic enzymes and displayed impaired virulence in Drosophila infection dependent on peptogcan receptor, PGRP-SA.
Burkholderia pseudomallei is a saprophytic bacterium that can infect humans and cause meloidosis, a difficult-to-manage disease. Even with proper diagnosis and treatment, mortality rates range from 20% in Northern Australia to 40% in Thailand. Little is known about how B. pseudalle infects, invades and survives within hosts, and nothing about the contribution of nutrients such as iron to the bacterium pathogenesis. It was assumed B pseudalle used iron-acquisition systems found in other bacteria, such as siderophores. However, a clinical isolate carrying a chromosomal deletion of the malleactin cluster encoding major-affinity siderore was still virulent in murine meloid model. Here, we deleted major siderore malleactin ( m ) and pyelin ( ) clusters in 171b and revealed residual siderore activity unrelated to known Burkia siderores such as cepactin and cepachel, not increased secretion of chelators such citrate. Deletion of hem uptake loci h and showed h required utilization of hem and hemoglobin and could not complement h deficiency. Prolong incubation h mutant in hemoglobin medium yielded able to utilize hemoglobin and hemin suggesting alternate pathways for these sources. Utilization was dependent on mactin, not pyelin synthesis/uptake. A pchmu h mutant could use ferritin as source and intranasal infection lethal in murine meloid model. These data suggest Balle may employ ferritin-iron pathway to sustain in vivo.
Genome-scale constraint-based metabolic models (GSMs) provide comprehensive representations of cellular function. However, their usability is often hampered by inconsistencies between models, particularly for concurrent models. To address this issue, we developed COMM, a tool for Consensus Metabolic Model GENeration. COMM automatically identifies inconsistencies between models and semi-automatically resolves them, thereby contributing to knowledge consolidation of metabolic function. We tested COMM for four organisms and showed that automatically generated models were predictive and substantially increased coherence of representation. COMM is particularly useful for scenarios in which manual curation does not scale, such as eukaryotic organisms, microbial communities and host-pathogen interactions.
Chondrocytes interact with their extracellular environment by embedding in a proteoglycan (PG)-rich matrix, then undergo a developmental transition termed “maturation” when they express genes to induce bone in the overlying tissue, perichond. Here, we ask whether PGs regulate chrocy and perond interactions. Using zebraf mutants, we reveal that cartilage PGs inhibit chro maturation, dictating the timing of perichral bone development. In a mutagenesis screen, we isolated a class of mutants with decreased cartilage and increased perichral bone. Position cloning identified two genes, famb and xylosyltransferase1 (xt1), which encode PG synthesis enzymes. Mutants failed to produce wild-type levels of chroit sulfate PGs, normally abundant in cartilage, and perichral bone formed earlier than wild-type siblings. Primary chro defects induce the phenotype secondarily because chrotes initiated mat prematurely, showing increased expression of run2, collagen 1a, andh coorths, andha suppressed perichral bone in mutants. Ultrastructural analyses demonstrated aberrant matrix and early chro hypertrophy in mutants.
Topoisomerase II Is Required for Proper Separation of Heterochromatic Regions during Drosophila melanogaster Meiosis.
Visceral leishmanias (VL) is a zoonotic disease of great importance. Limitations in current control measures indicate the need for new strategies. This study evaluates the effectiveness of deltamethrin-impregnated collars as a public health measure to prevent canine leishmaniasis (CVL). An interventional study was implemented in two areas of Monteordo, Bahia, Brazil: an intervention area with collared dogs and a control area with conventional CV measures. At baseline, seropositive dogs were removed and seronegative included. Dogs were reevaluated every 7–8 months for two years. In the intervention area, serone dogs received new collars and serone were included. Local authorities were notified of seropitive dogs in both areas, marked for euthanasia by the Ministry of Health. In the first serological survey, serreval was similar. The second evaluation showed significant reductions in serre in both areas, with 6. 0% in the intervention and 11. 0% in control. The relative risk (RR) indicated protection against CV in the intervention. CV incidence did not differ between areas, but increased in control, possibly due to low serconversion or loss.
The X chromosome is unusual because of its non-random gene content, which is commonly discussed in the context of sexual antagonism and avoidance in the germline. We examine the notion that, at least in some taxa, functionally biased gene content may be shaped by limits on expression due to haploid expression of the X. We test this hypothesis using ENCODE and FANT5 data. As predicted, human X-linked genes have lower maximal expression than autosomal genes: on average, maximal expression is three times lower on X than autos. Autosome-to-X retrogenes have lower maximal expression on X than X-to-autosome retrogenes on autos. X genes have lesser increase in expression than autosomal compared to human-Chimpanzee ancestor if highly expressed, but not lowly expressed. The traffic model explains lower breadth of genes on X and Z as broad genes are, on average, highly expressed. Highly expressed genes are rare on X and broadly expressed on X tend to be low. Highly tissue-specific genes are rare on X and broadly expressed on X tend to be low, indicating trend shaped by maximal level not breadth. Importantly, maximal level explains biased tissue profiles of X-linked genes. Tissues highly expressed ( e. g. secretory, structural ) are in which expression is rare on X. These cannot be accounted for in biased models.
Helicobacter pylori is a gastric pathogen that originated in Africa and has been associated with humans for at least 100,000 years. Seven geographically distinct H pylori populations exist, three of which are indigenous to Africa: hp1, hpAfrica, and hpAfrica. The oldest and most divergent population, hpAfrica, evolved within hunter-gatherers who represent one of the deepest branches of the human tree. We investigated the prevalence and population structure of H pyl within Baka Pyies in Cameroon. Gastric biopsies were obtained from 77 Baka from two geographically separated populations and 101 non-B from neighboring agricultural populations and cultured for pyl. Unexpectedly, Baka showed a lower pyl infection rate (20. 8%) than non-B (80.2%). We generated multilocus haplotypes for pyl by DNA sequencing, but were unable to identify B-specific lineages and most were assigned to hpAfrica or hp1. hpAfrica was divided into East and West African subpopulations, and hp1 mainly among Cameroonians supports eastern and western Bantu expansions. An age-structured model shows pyl prevalence among Baka is achievable within a few hundred years. Demographic factors such as small size and low life expectancy can lead pyl eradication from human populations. Baka were either pyl-free or lost lineages during past fluctuations. Using simulations and phylogenetic inference, we show B almost certainly acquired pyl through contact with agricultural neighbors.
Dengue virus (DENV) NS5 is the most conserved amongst the viral non-structural proteins and is responsible for capping methylation and replication of the flavivirus genome. Although replication occurs in the cytoplasm, a characteristic of DENV NS is that localizes to the nucleus during infection with no clear role in replication or pathogenesis. We examined NS of DENV1 and 2, which exhibit the most difference in nuclear localization, employing a combination of functional and structural analyses. Extensive swapping between DENV and 2 NS identified the C-terminal 18 (C18 ) was sufficient to direct the protein to cytoplasm or nucleus, respectively. The lowmic affinity between NS C18 and the nuclear receptor importin (Imp ) allowed their complex to be purified and visualized at 2. Å using x-ray crystallography. Structure-guided mutational analysis of this in GFP-NS clones D1 or 2 and a D2 infectious clone reveal important for NS subcell localization. Notably the transformation by Pro884 allows presentation for Imp and mutating this to, present in D1 results in mislocalization of to cytoplasm without compromising virus. In contrast, mutation at position 888, conserved in all flavivir, resulted in completely virus and the mutation led severely attenuated phenotype, though was in nucleus.
Neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) control and elimination programs can be successful in reducing prevalence and intensity of infection, but many endemic countries lack the necessary data for planning and advocacy. Each NTD has its own guidelines for data collection. We developed and tested an integrated NTD mapping protocol, the Integrated Mapping (ITM) Methodology, for lymphatic filariasis (LF), trachoma, schistosiasis, and soil-transmitted helminths (STH). The protocol is resource-efficient and aims to determine if a threshold for public health intervention has been attained. It relies on World Health Organization (WHO) indicators in disease-specific age groups. We tested the protocol by comparing it to WHO methodologies for each disease in one district each in Mali and Senegal. Results were compared in public health, feasibility, and cost. The IT methodology reached same conclusions as WHO regarding initiation of public interventions for trach, LF, and STH, but more targeted recommendations for schosias. It was practical and cost-effective compared to standard, non-integrated WHO methodologies.
In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the conserved phosphatase Cdc is required for exit from mitosis. Cdc is anchored to nucleolar chromatin by C1/Net until anaphase, at which time it is released into nucleoplasm. We report here a novel requirement for ubiquitination of histone H2 by Bre1 ubiquitin ligase in cell–dependent release ofdc from nucleolar chrom when MEN is inactivated. This function is mediated by activation of histone H methylation on lysines 4 and 79 (H3K4 and H3K79 ), but not by histone deetylase (HD)2, which associates withdc on nucleolar chrom as part of RENT. We also observed defect indc release in cells lacking H3 lysine methylation (H36 ) and cells lacking HD recruited by this modification.
The development of computational methods to identify programs of co-expressed genes that orchestrate normal or pathological processes is an important problem in biology. GeneProgram is a new unsupervised framework that addresses challenges in expression compend data, including cellular heterogeneity, genetic variation, and temporal behavior. Gene uses Hierarchical Dirichlet Processes to simultaneously organize tissues and genes into overlapping programs with consistent behavior, producing maps that are sorted by generality scores. We showed Gene outperformed several methods on synthetic and real data. Gene was applied to a compend of 62 time-series expression datasets of human responses to infectious agents and immune-modulating molecules. Gene produced a map of 104 programs, a number of which were enriched for genes in key pathways or bound by NF-κ transcription factors. Gene also discovered programs implicating surprising pathways in response to infection, including Wnt and neurotransmitter receptors.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) drives epigenetic imprinting of the IFNG locus in NKGChi natural killer (NK) cells. NK cells play a crucial role in the defense against CMV and represent the main source of interferon (IF)-γ. Recently, it was shown that memory-like features can be observed in NK subsets after CM infection. However, the mechanisms underlying NK adaptive properties have not been completely defined. In this study, we show that NKGChi NK cells in CM seropositive individuals underwent epigen remodeling of the IF conserved non-coding sequence (CNS)1, similar to CD8+ T or TH1 cells. The accessibility of NS1 was required for IF- transcription in response to NKG2 and 4, leading to IF production in NK cells. Our data identify epigen imprint of IF locus as hallmark and mechanism driving stable IF in CM NK expansions, providing basis for regulation in cells.
Legionella pneumophila exploits the host proteasome to temporally regulate the function of a cognate effector protein. The pathogen secretes numerous effector proteins into eukaryotic cells to coordinate cellular processes important for infection. Temporal regulation is important for modulating distinct activities of effectors at different stages of infection. Here we provide the first evidence of a metaeffector, an effector that regulates the function of another effector within the host. The Legionella effector Lub functions as an E3 ubiquitin ligase that hijacks the host proteasome to target the bacterial effector Sid for degradation. Delayed delivery of Lub to the host cytoplasm leads to shutdown of Sid within the host at later stages of infection.
Viral diversification in newly infected individuals provides information about the host and immune responses experienced by the transmitted virus. We investigated the diversification of HIV-1 env sequences in 81 early infections that resulted from transmission of a single virus (n=78) or two related viruses (n=3). The infecting virus can be estimated, enabling inference of substitutions as well as distinction between insertion and deletion events. We find evidence of adaptive evolution of HIV-1 env and a subset of codons that diversified more than can be explained by neutral evolution. Of 24 rapidly diversifying codons, 14 were either in CTL epitopes or in nucleotide indicative of APOEC-mediated G-to-A substitutions, despite excluded hypermutated sequences. In several, a site was embedded in APOEC and CTL, suggesting APO may facilitate early escape. Ten diversifying codons could not be explained by CTL or APO, including most mutated in gp41. We examined the distribution, extent and sequence of insertions deletions and provide that variation in hyperviable regions is a consequence of selection not mutational hotspots.
The role of multiple epigenetic marks in silencing and the emergence of a bivalent chromatin state. We introduce a minimal model of epigenetic silencing in budding yeast that incorporates known biomolecular interactions in the system. The model identifies epigen marks essential for bistability of epigen states and explores the presence of multiple marks leading to qualitatively different behavior. We find that both H4 acetylation and H3 methylation are important for robust ep silencing. Besides silenced and transcriptionally active chromatin, our model leads to a novel bivalent state with both marks under certain perturbations. The bivalent state appears under perturb and results in patch silencing. We show that titration of silencing proteins can result in counterintuitive responses.
Severe acute malnutrition (SAM) is a major health problem in many developing countries and manifests in two forms: oedematous and non-oemat. The pathogenesis of both forms is largely unknown, but gut microbiota (GM) dysbiosis has been linked to oemat malnutrition. This study aimed to assess whether GM composition differed between Ugandan children with oedemat or non-oemat malnutrition. Children aged 6–24 months with SAM were included in an observational study. Fecal samples were collected at admission. Total DNA was extracted from fecal samples, followed by PCR and Denaturing Gradient Electrophoresis (DGGE) and 16S rRNA-targeted high-throughput sequencing. Alpha and beta diversity were determined with ANOVA mean abundance and test. Of 87 children, 62% had oemat mal, 66% were boys and mean age 16.1 months. GM differed between groups by DG (p=0.031) and high-throughput sequencing. Non-oemat children had lower GM diversity (p=0.036). However, beta diversity did not differ between oemat and nonemat SAM (ANOS weighted UniR=-0.008 p=0.584; unweighted UniR=0.9 p0.011).
Telomere length varies among wild-type Saccharomyces sensu stricto isolates and is controlled by multiple loci. We screened 112 wild-type isolates and found extensive variation in telom length. Telom length correlated with geographic origin: European isolates had short telomeres (<150 bp ) and American isolates had telomeres approximately three times longer (>400 bp ). Insertion of the URA gene near telom allowed analysis of individual telom lengths and telom position (TPE). Crossing American and European isolates resulted in F1 progeny with a continuum of telom lengths consistent with many quantitative trait loci (QTL) involved in length. Variation in TPE was weakly correlated with telom length. Genotyping F1 progeny indicated several QTL associated with telom length and silencing variation. These QTL include candidate genes and map to regions with no known telom properties. We detected transgressive segregation for both phenotypes. We validated by reciprocal hemizygosity that YU80 and TLC1 are telom-length QTL in two S paradox subpopulations. Furthermore, we propose that divergence within Ku80 generates negative epistasis in one allelic combinations (American-YU and EuropeanU ) resulting in short telom.
Decision making is a complex process that involves not only how people choose, but also when they choose. Traditional models of decision making, such as sequential sampling models ( SSMs ), assume that decisions emerge from a bounded accumulation of evidence and that response times ( RTs ) become predictable. However, we show that SSMs fail when people are not forced to respond immediately but are allowed to sample sequentially: the decision maker might decide to delay choice and terminate the process, a scenario not accounted for by standard SSM. We developed SSMs predicting RTs from electroencephalography ( EEG ) and functional magnetic resonance imaging ( fMRI ) data. In these studies, participants bought or rejected fictitious stocks based on sequentially presented cues and were free to respond at any time. Standard SSMs did not describe RTs adequately, but adding a mechanism for postponing decisions to the model obtained an accurate fit to data. Time-frequency analysis of EEG data revealed alternating states of de- and increasing oscillatory power in beta-band (14–30 ) Hz, indicating responses were repeatedly prepared and inhibited. This supports the existence of a decision to not decide. The extended model accounted for results of an adapted paradigm in which participants had to press button for more information.
Hereditary nasal parakeratosis (HN) is a monogenic autosomal recessive skin disorder in Labrador Retrievers characterized by crusts and fissures on the nasal planum. We performed a genome-wide association study (GWAS) using 13 HN cases and 23 controls and obtained a strong association signal on chromosome 2 (p=4.4×10−14). Haplotype analysis defined a critical interval of 1.6 Mb with 25 genes. We resequenced the genome of one case at 38 coverage and detected 3 nonsynonymous variants in the interval with respect to the reference assembly. We genotyped these variants in larger cohorts and only one was associated with HN in more than 500 dogs. This candidate variant is a missense in SUVH2 encoding histone lysine 9 (HK) methyltransferase, which mediates chromatin silencing. The c.972G>T is predicted to change conserved asparagine to lysine in catalytically active domain (p.NK). We studied histopathological alterations in epidermis in vivo. Our data suggest HN is not caused by hyperproliferation but delayed differentiation of kerocytes.
Influenza A viruses (IAVs) are a major public health concern due to their ability to cause seasonal epidemics and pandemics. Swine are considered a “mixing vessel” for generating reassortants of avian and mammalian IAVs that could be transmissible to mammals, including humans. However, the emergence of transmissible reassortants in swine is not well understood. In this study, we investigated the emergence of reassortants during co-infection of swine with avian and sw IAVs. A total of 571 isolates were recovered from nasal samples and respiratory tissues of a group of co-housed pigs (influenza-negative, avian H1N1 IAV-infected and sw H3N2 IAV-infected pigs) and 30 distinct genotypes of reassortant viruses were identified. Reassortants from lower respiratory tissues had the largest genomic diversity, while those from turbinate and nasal fluids had the least. Reassants from lower tracts had the largest variations in growth in respiratory epithelial cells and temperature in sw nasal cells seemed to select the type of reassant shed by pigs. One reassant was consistently identified in upper, middle and lower respiratory tissues and was efficiently transmitted between pigs. Our findings suggest that during co-infection of av and sw IAVs, reassort are likely to occur in the lower respiratory tract and tissue tropism is an important for selecting transmissible reassant.
Schistosoma mansoni is a parasitic worm that causes schistosomiasis, a major public health problem in endemic areas. Children born to mothers with schosomiasis may be sensitized in utero, which may influence their immune response to schosomiasis and morbidity. We examined the effect of prazantel treatment of S mansoni during pregnancy on the risk of S mans infection and immune response among offspring at age five. In a trial in Uganda, offspring of mothers treated with prazantel or placebo were examined for S mans infection and cytokine and antibody responses to SW and SEA, as well as T cell expression of FoxP at age five. Of 134 children examined, 32 ( 2. 4% ) had S mans infection at age five based on single sample. Infection did not differ between children of treated or untreated mothers. Cytokine ( IFγ, IL-5, IL-10 and IL-13 ) and antibody (G, Ig and IgE ) responses to SW and SEA, and FoxP expression were higher among infected than uninfected. Prazant treatment S during pregnancy had no effect on responses, except IL-10 to SW which was higher in offspring of mothers that received prant than did not.
Following an infectious challenge, macrophages are activated to allow for the efficient clearance of infectious pathogens. However, how macrophage activation is coupled to clearance remains largely unknown. Here we describe that inflammatory stimuli induce the reprogramming of the macrophage endocytic machinery from receptor-mediated phagocytosis to macinocytosis, allowing the transfer of internalized cargo to lysosomes in a receptor-independent manner. This reprogramming occurs through protein C-mediated phosphorylation of the macrophage protein coronin 1, thereby activating phosphoinositide 3-kinase ( PI3K) activity for macinocytic uptake. Expression of a phosphomim form of coronin 1 is sufficient to induce PIK activation and macinocytosis even in the absence of inflammatory stimuli.
In the West Nile region of Uganda, there is a renewed effort to eliminate sleeping sickness (African trypanosomiasis or HAT ) by deploying insecticide-treated targets over an area of ∼500 km2. The effectiveness of the targets depends on their acceptance by the local community. We assessed knowledge and perceptions of tset baits ( traps ) in villages where they had not been previously used. We conducted sixteen focus group discussions with male and female participants in eight villages across Arua District. Despite being less than 10 km apart, community members perceived baits differently. Villagers who had never seen traps before expressed fear and anxiety, related to associations with witchcraft and “ghosts from the river”. By contrast, villagers in areas where traps had been used had positive attitudes and were aware of their purpose and benefits. The latter reported similar negative perceptions when tse control started a decade ago.
