Our results suggest that despite proximity, acceptance varies between villages and is related to duration with tse programs.
Recombination is a fundamental biological process with profound evolutionary implications. Recombination increases the effectiveness of selection in natural populations. However, direct tests of this prediction have been restricted due to the lack of characterization of recombination variation across genomes and species. Here we report the first high-resolution description of genomic recombination variation in Drosophila melanaster. We characterized 5, 860 female meios by genotyping 139 million SNPs and mapped 106,964 recombination events at 2 kilobases. This allowed us to generate whole-genome CO and GC maps as well as description of variation in recombination among individuals. We describe levels of variation in recombination. At large scale, CO exhibit highly punctuated variation along chromosomes with hotspots and coldspots. We show intra-specific variation in CO that is associated with hotspots low frequency. GC are uniformly distributed than CO and detect in regions absent. At scale re are associated with numerous motifs and occur within transcript, suggesting chromatin favors double-strand breaks.
ID2 is a component of the RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdDM) machinery in Arabidopsis thaliana, but its function in RDM remains unknown. By purifying ID2, we co-purified two ID paralogs, ID1 and ID2 ( ID2AL 1 and 2 ). The coiled domain between the XS and X domains of ID2 is required for ID homodimerization, whereas the ID2-terminal X domain but not coiled domain is required for ID interaction with ID1 and ID2. By introducing wild-type ID2 and its derivatives into the id2 mutant for complementation, we demonstrated that the previously uncharacterized ID X domain is required for ID-ID1/ID2 formation as well as ID function. ID is required for de novo methylation, siRNA accumulation and transcriptional silencing, whereas ID has overlapping roles with ID. Unlike ID, ID and ID are incapable of binding-stranded RNA, suggesting the roles ID and ID are different from ID in ID-ID and that ID and ID are essential for functioning RDM.
Neutrophils are the first line of defense against invading pathogens and are rapidly recruited to the sites of Leishmania inoculation. During Leishmania braziliensis infection, depletion of neutrophils significantly increases the parasite load. However, co-culture of neutils and L braziliensis has an opposite effect. Here we investigated the interaction between neutils and Lili, exploring activation and apoptotic fate. Inoculation of serum-opsonized Lili promastigotes mice neutil accumulation in vivo, peaking at 24 h. In vitro exposure of thylycoll-elic inflammatory bone neutils to Lili modulated expression of surface molecules such as CD18 and CDL and induced oxidative burst. Using mCh-expressing Lili, effects were mainly observed in infected and not bystander neutils. Neutil activation following Lili was confirmed by release of TN-α and neutilase. Neutils infected Lili but not L major displayed markers of apoptosis. We show Lili induces neutil recruitment in vivo and neutils exposed the parasite in vitro through activation and release of inflammatory mediators.
Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a major disease of cattle that causes significant economic losses to the livestock industry. In the EU, vaccination is not currently used to control bTB, but new diagnostic tests that differentiate infected from vaccinated animals (DIV) offer the potential to introduce vaccination within eradication programs. We used historical data from Great Britain (GB) to explore the feasibility of using vaccination as a supplementary control tool. The economic impact of bTB on farmers is dominated by testing costs and restrictions on animal movements. Farmers will adopt vaccination if it not only reduces the burden of infection, but also the risk of restrictions. We find that in GB, the specificity of the DIV test, rather than sensitivity, is the greatest barrier to a herd benefit of vaccination. The negative effects of vaccination could be mitigated by relaxing testing, but this could increase the burden of infection in officially TB-free herds. We explore the range of DIV characteristics necessary to see a protective benefit of vaccination. We estimate that a DIV specificity of at least 99. 85% and sensitivity >40% is required to see a benefit with no increase in risk of infection. Data from infected animals suggest that this specificity could be achieved using a cocktail of DIV antigens while maintaining sensitivity of 73. 3% (61.9, 82.9 ) relative to post-mortem detection.
Trichuris trichi is a parasitic worm that infects around 500 million people worldwide, causing physical and educational damage to those infected. Current treatments are limited and lack efficacy against the parasite, preventing eradication. To develop new treatments, we screened a library of 480 drug-like compounds for activity against Truris in vitro. We identified a class of dihydroben[e][1, 4]azin-2 ( 3 )one compounds with activity against Tis. Further screening of structurally related compounds and synthesis of the most potent led to the identification of 20 dihydrozazepones, a class not previously implicated in nematode control. The most active against Tis with EC values around 25–50μM, comparable to existing levamis. The best from this class show low cytotoxicity against murine epithelial cells, demonstrating selectivity for the parasite. Developing a novel treatment for a neglected disease and deploying via mass administration is challenging. Interestingly, dihydrozepone O029 reduces ability of embryated Tis to establish in mouse in vivo. Complementing development as an, this supports an alternative to develop that acts in, via to interrupt lifecycle.
Protein-protein interaction networks have been studied using the concepts of “date” and “party” hubs. Date hubs are characterized by low co-expression with their partners, whereas party hubs have high co-expression. It was proposed that party hubs are local coordinators and date are global connectors. However, we show that the importance of date hubs to network connectivity can be attributed to a small subset of them. These extremely central hubs do not display low correlation with their partners, undermining the link between quantity and function. The date/party distinction was motivated by a bimodal distribution of hub-expression, but we show this is not robust to methodological changes. Additionally, topological properties do not correlate with co-expression. However, we find correlations between centrality and similarity of interacting proteins.
Pathogen genome sequences can be informative of transmission events in infectious disease outbreaks, but only if there is sufficient genetic diversity among the sampled genomes. This is because the position of individuals in a transmission tree can only be resolved by genetic data if mutations have accumulated between pathogen genomes. We introduce the concept of ‘transmission’, defined as the number of mutations separating genome sequences from transmission pairs. Using literature values, we simulate outbreak scenarios alongside sequence evolution models to describe transmission of major outbreak-causing pathogens. We find that mean transmission varies between pathogens, but is generally low, with many outbreaks characterised by genetically identical pairs. We describe the impact of transmission on reconstruction using outbreak tools R and, and demonstrate that genetic data of rapidly evolving pathogens can provide information on individual events. Conversely, data of pathogens with lower transmission, including Streptoccus, Shigella and Clostrid, provide little to no information on individual events.
X chromosome inactivation (XCI) is a process that silences most genes on one of the two X chromosomes in female mammals. However, some genes escape this silencing. To identify genes that escape CI in vivo, we analyzed allele-specific expression and chromatin structure of X-linked genes in mouse tissues and cells with skewed CI based on single nucleotide polymorphisms. We used a binomial model to assess allelic expression and demonstrated a continuum between complete silencing and expression from the inactive X (Xi) chromosome. The validity of RNA-seq was verified using RT-PCR with species-specific primers and Sanger sequencing. We identified both common genes that escape CI and genes with significant differences in CI between tissues. Such genes may be candidates for tissue-specific sex differences. Overall, few genes (3–7%) escape CI in any of the mouse tissues examined, suggesting stringent silencing and escape controls. In contrast, an in vitro system represented by embryonic kidney-derived Pki cell showed higher density of escape genes (21%), representing kidney-specific genes and cell-line escape. Alle-specific RNA polymerase II occupancy and DNase hypersensitivity at the promoter of genes on Xi correlated with levels of escape, consistent with open chromatin structure at escape genes. Alle-specific CTCF binding on Xi at escape genes was denser in brain compared to Pki cell, possibly contributing to more compartmental structure of Xi and fewer genes in brain compared to cell where larger domains were observed.
Plasmodium vivax is a protozoan parasite that infects erythrocytes and causes vivax malaria. The parasite requires cystine proteases for maintenance of metabolic homeostasis and egress from the erythrocyte. In this study, we characterized a novel cystine protease of P. viv, VX-4, which appears to have evolved differently in Plasmodia with strong affinity toward rodent Plmod. VX-4 has dual substrate specificity depending on the microenvironmental pH. Its hydrolytic activity against benzyloxycarbonyl-Le-Arg-4-methyloumaryl-7-amide (Zu-ArgCA) and Z-P-Arg-MCA was highest at acidic pH 5.5, whereas against Z-Arg-MCA was maximal at pH 6.5–7.5. VX-4 preferred positively charged amino acids Gln at P1, with less specificity at P3 and P4. P2 depended on pH (Le at 5.5 and Arg at 7.5 ). Three amino that deline the S pocket were substituted in VX4 compared VX2 and VX3 (Ala, Gly and Glu180 ). Replacement Gl180 abolished activity Z-Arg-M at pH, indicating importance this acid in pH-dependent preference. VX4 was localized in foodoles and cytoplasm of erythro stage P. VX4 showed activity at pH and against P viv plasm 4 and hemoglobin at neutral/acidic and acidic, respectively.
Acetogens are microorganisms capable of fermenting a wide range of substrates, making them ideal candidates for biotechnological production of commodity chemicals. Their ability to grow on H2/CO or H2/CO makes them ideal for sustainable biop. However, design of acetogens is hampered by incomplete knowledge of their physiology and inability to accurately predict phenotypes. Here we describe a genome-scale model of metabolism and macromolecular synthesis (ME) of Clostridium ljungahli, the first ME of a Gram-positive bacterium. The model captures major metabolic, amino, nucleotide, lipid, cofactor, and vitamin pathways as well as RNA and protein synthesis necessary to catalyze reactions. This broadens the scope of predictability. The model reveals how protein and media influence metabolic pathways and energy in acetogens and predicts secretion of multiple products. Predicting overflow is of interest since it enables new strategies, e. g. formation of glycerol, a product for C. ljungli, broadening its metabolic capability. Furthermore, prediction and validation of secretion based on metal availability opens window into fermentation and provides knowledge of proteome and carbon utilization in acetogens.
Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) are moving towards the use of large cohorts of primary cell lines to study diseases of interest and assign biological relevance to genetic signals. We used a panel of human osteoblasts (HOBs) to carry out a transcriptomic survey similar to recent studies in lymphoblastoid cell lines (Ls). OBs and Ls are distinct by preferential grouping of cell–specific genes within biologically and functionally relevant pathways to each type. We performed cis-association with SNP genotypes to identify genetic variations of transcriptforms and our analysis indicates differential expression of transcriptforms in OBs is partly controlled by cis-regulatory genetic variants. Theseforms are regulated by variants in tissue-specific and tissue-independent fashion and have been confirmed by RT–PCR. Our study suggests multiple transcriptforms are present in tissues and genetic may affect the expression of oneform to another rather than all-or effect. Examination of SNPs from GW of bone density show overlap probeset associations in this study. Top corresponding to FAM gene was tested in additional studies revealing novel transcriptform.
Saccharomyces eayan is the non-S. cerevisiae parent of the lager-brew hybrid S. pastus. In contrast to most S. cerevis and Froberg S pastus strains, S eayan cannot utilize α-tri-glucide maltose, a major carbohydrate in brew’s wort. In Sacomy yeasts, utilization of maltose is encoded by the subtelomeric MAL gene family and requires transporters for maltose uptake. While eayan CBS 57 harbors SeALT genes enabling α-di-glucide maltose uptake, it lacks maltose genes. In contrast, S cere sequence indicates maltose and maltose transporters likely evolved from a shared gene. To study maltose utilization in eayan CBS57, maltose-assim mutants obtained after UV mutagenesis were subjected to evolution in carbon-limited chemostat cultures on maltose-enriched wort. An evolved strain showed maltose and maltose fermentation in 7 ferment experiments on industrial wort. Whole-genome sequencing revealed a novel SeALT gene resulting from repeated introgress by non-recipro translocation of at least SeALT. The predicted structure SeT was comparable to original transporters but overexpression sufficed to enable maltose, indicating neofunction had occurred.
Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Timely and accurate assessment of its impact on human health is essential for planning but presents a challenge. Current approaches rely mostly on intensive surveillance. This study proposes a novel host-virus interaction model and establishes a positive correlation between excess mortalities caused by viral strains and their antigenic distances to previous strains for each type of seasonal influenza virus. Based on this relationship, a method is developed to rapidly estimate mortality of influenza A H1N virus by predicting antigen distance between H1 strains. This should help formulate cost-effective response for control and prevention.
The Asian soybean fungus Phakora pachyri is an obligate biotrophic pathogen that causes severe soybean epidemics. The molecular mechanisms by which P. pachyri and other fungi interact with their host plants are poorly understood. Here, we present the characterization of Pachy effector 23 (PEC), a small secreted cysteine-rich protein that suppresses plant immunity. We show that PEC interacts with the soybean transcription factor GS12 and that soybean in which GS12 is silenced have constitutively active immunity, thereby identifying GS12 as a negative regulator of soybean defenses.
Chlamydia trachomatis is an obligate intracellular bacterium that invades host cells to replicate inside a membrane-bound vacuole called an inclusion. Multiple host proteins are recruited to the inclusion and functionally modulated to support chlamial development. We identified the cell surface tyrosine kinase EphA receptor (Eph2 ) as a chlamial adherence and invasion receptor that induces PI3 kinase (PIK ) activation, promoting chlamial replication. Interfering with C. trachatis serar2 (C ) binding to Eph2, downregulation of Eph2 or inhibition of Eph significantly reduced C infection. C interacts with and activates Eph on the surface resulting in receptor internalization. During chlamial replication, Eph remains active around the inclusion and interacts with the p85 subunit of PIK to activate the PIK/Akt pathway required for chlamial development. Overexpression of full Eph, but not mutant lacking the intracellular domain, enhanced PI activation and C infection. Despite depletion of Eph from the surface, C induces upregulation of Eph through the ER pathway keeping infected cells in an apoptosis-resistant state.
Active Dendrites Enhance Neuronal Dynamic  
Neurons have long been known to exhibit dendritic excitability through the expression of voltage-gated ion channels. However, the role of this excitability in dendritic computation has remained elusive. We show that the average output of an active dendritic tree is a highly non-linear function of afferent rate, attaining large dynamic ranges above 50 dB. The model yields double-sigmoid functions experimentally observed in retinal ganglion cells. We claim that enhancement of dynamic is the primary role of dendritic conductances. We predict that neurons with larger dendritic trees have larger dynamic and blocking of conductances lead to decrease dynamic.
Inference of Quantitative Models of Bacterial Promoters from Time-Series Reporter Data is a study that aims to improve the inference of regulatory and quantitative models of gene expression from time-series transcriptomics data. Current methods are based on assumptions that mRNA abundance is representative of protein concentrations and changes in expression are solely due to transcription factors and regulators. However, these assumptions are often not valid and bias the reverse engineering process. Here, we investigate the importance of this bias and possible corrections using a combination of models and experiments. We measure the activity of genes involved in the Fli-FlM module of the E. coli motility network and estimate protein concentrations and physiological effects by kinetic models of expression. Our results show that correcting the bias improves the quality of models from data. Moreover, we demonstrate that these improvements are expected to be stronger for systems with longer protein half-lives and varying expression machinery activity than the Fli-FlM module.
Oligoryzomys fulcens is an important mammalian reservoir of zoonotic pathogens in Central America. This study characterizes the spatio-temporal distribution of O. fulcens in the Agua region, Panama, using a longitudinal dataset of rodent populations collected between April 2006 and December 2009. The study area was divided into a 0.09 km2 grid, with a total area of 6.43 km2 ( 2.39 x 2.69 ). The temporal dataset was divided into four periods: the dry season, rainy season, and two transitional months between seasons ( April and December ). The study found heterogeneous patterns in population densities and dispersion of O. fulens across seasons and years. The species was typically absent during late transitional months and re-established in subsequent years. Populations reoccurred in the same area during first three years but re-established further south in final year. Spatial autocorrelation analyses indicated populations encompassed approximately 300–600 m. Suitable and unsuitable habitats were sharply demarcated over short distances. O fulens showed a well-defined spatial pattern evolving over time, leading to a pattern of changing aggregation. Hot spots of abundance showed a shifting pattern explaining intermittent transmission by this species. This was associated with seasonality and anthropogenic pressures from agricultural activities.
Influenza A (H3N) viruses are a major cause of seasonal epidemics and pandemics in humans. Understanding the antigenic evolution of these viruses is important for the development of efficient vaccines. Antigenic evolution is driven by amino acid changes in the hemagglutinin protein, the major surface antigen of the virus. However, distinguishing between mutations that determine the phenotype and those that do not is a challenge. We have developed a method to infer antigenic trees for the hemagglutinin protein. Antigen weights are assigned to all branches in the tree, allowing us to determine the antigen impact of amino acid changes. Our method is comparable to antigen cartography and identifies both known and novel amino acid changes with antigen impact in evolution of A (3) viruses from 1968 to 2003.
Human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV) infection is a major risk factor for cervical cancer and other anogenital cancers. To identify host factors required for HPV infection, we performed a genome-wide RNA interference (RNAi) screen in human cells. We found that a cluster of mitotic genes were required for HPV infection, and identified a novel mechanism for viral DNA import into the nucleus. In interphase cells, viruses were endocytosed and routed to the perinuclear area, but failed to enter the nucleus. Upon nuclear envelope breakdown in interphase, HPV infection occurred. During mitosis, viral DNA was associated with host chromatin on the metaphase plate. We propose that HPV requires nuclear envelope breakdown during mitosis for DNA access to the nucleoplasm. Our results highlight the value of RNA screens for viral infections and provide a resource for future virus-host interaction studies.
Black Sigat or black streak disease, caused by the Dothideomyc fungus Pseudocospora fiji (synonym: Mycoserella fiji ), is the most significant foliar disease of banana worldwide. Due to the lack of effective resistance, disease management requires frequent fungicide applications, which greatly increase the economic and environmental costs of banana production. Weekly fungicide applications in banana plantations lead to rapid evolution of fungicide-resistant strains, causing disease failures throughout the world. To combat this threat, two strains of P. fiji were sequenced and assembled with the aid of a genetic map. The 74b genome of P. fiji is expanded by L retrotransposons, making it the largest within Dothideyc. Mel-curve assays suggest the genomes of closely related Sigat disease members, P eusae and mus, are also expanded. Electrophoretic kary and molecular analyses of markers in P fiji populations showed chromosome polymorphisms and genetic diversity. Genetic differentiation was detected using neutral markers, suggesting strong selection with limited flow at the geographic scale. Frequencies of fungicide in fung-treated plantations were higher than in untreated Piji populations. A homologue of Cladospor fulum Avr effector Pf4 was identified in Piji genome. Infiltration of purified PfAV4 into leaves of resistant variety Calcut resulted in hypersensitive response. This suggests Calcut could carry unknown gene recognizing Pf4.
The evolution of lineage-specific transcription factor binding sites is thought to be a major contributor to the evolution of species-specific traits. However, most computational approaches to study regulatory elements focus on conserved sites and rely heavily on sequence alignments. In this paper, we describe a novel framework that uses a birth-death model to trace the evolution of lineage-specific sites without detailed cross-species alignments. Our model was applied to ChIP-seq data for six transcription factors ( GATA, SOX, CTC, MY, MAX, ETS ) along the human-mouse lineage. We estimate that 58–79% of binding sites for each factor have origins since human-mouse divergence. Over 15% of all sites are unique to homin. Such elements are enriched near genes associated with specific pathways and harbor more SNPs than older sites in human.
In zebraf, light is the principal environmental signal for entraining the endogenous circadian clock. Unlike mammals, most of its tissues are exposed to light, leading to local entrainment of the clock. Importantly, light induces expression of a set of genes including clock genes in zraf cell types in vivo and in vitro. To elucidate the mechanism linking light to gene expression, we focus on light regulation of zraf period2 (per2). Using transgenic fish and stably transfected cell–based assays, we define a Light Module (LRM) within per2 promoter. The LRM lies proximal to start site is necessary and sufficient for light-driven expression and light circadian regulation. Curiously, LRM is conserved in vertebrate per2, even species lacking light-sensitive peripheral clocks. We reveal that human LRM substitutes zraf L to confer light-regulated inraf cells. LRM contains E and D elements critical for function. E directs circadian regulation by mediating BMAL/CLOCK, D confers light-driven. zraf hom thyrophonic factor binds LRM D and transactivates expression. We demonstrate t mRNA are lightible and knockdown attenuates light from per in vivo.
The actin filament-binding protein coronin regulates motility in Plasmodium berghei sporozoites, the highly motile forms of the rodent malaria parasite transmitted by mosquitoes. Parasites lacking coronin show motility defects that impair colonization of the salivary glands but not migration in the skin, yet result in decreased transmission efficiency. Non-motile sporozoites have low concentrations of actin and mediate coronin localization to the periphery. Engagement of extracellular ligands triggers intracellular release of calcium followed by act-dependent localization of coron to the rear and initiation of motility. Mutational analysis and imaging suggest coron organizes actin filaments for motility.
Leishmania parasites are the causative agents of leishmaniasis, a major public health problem in many tropical and subtropical regions. Amphotin B is an important drug for the treatment of leishiasis, but the potential for resistance to this drug is considerable. Here, we characterised four amphotin-resistant Leishmania mexicana lines, which exhibited altered sterol biosynthesis and hypersensitivity to pentamidine. Whole genome sequencing revealed a mutation in the sterol biosynthesis gene sterol5-desaturase in one line, while RNA-seq demonstrated loss of expression of sterol24-ethyltransferase ( SMT ) in three out of four lines. SMT is responsible for drug resistance and altered sterol biosynthesis. Loss of milteine transporter was also associated with one line. SMT is encoded by two gene copies with different expression levels. In all cases, reduced expression was associated with loss of 3’ untranslated region of dominant copy, resulting from structural variations at locus. Local sequence homology between copies and presence of SIDER retrotransposons promote these variations. In one case, loss SMT was not associated with loss virulence in macrophages in vivo.
Predictive coding theory suggests that the brain optimizes the encoding of sensory information by using two processes: prediction and attention. Prediction is thought to guide the interpretation of forthcoming events, while attention prioritizes events according to their relevance. Despite their contributions to perception and cognition, it is unknown how they interact to modulate information in the brain. A recent extension of predictive theory suggests that attention optimizes the precision of predictions by modulating the gain of prediction units. Because prediction errors code the difference between predictions and sensory, this would suggest that attention increases selectivity for information in the response to surprising stimuli. Alternatively, predictive models suggest that attention increases the activity of prediction neurons and therefore that attention and prediction synergistically modulate selectivity for information in the brain. Here, we applied predictive models to neural activity recorded via EEG as observers performed a visual task to test the effect of attention on both mismatch and information in response to surprising stimuli. Participants attended or ignored a stream of gratings, orientations which could be predictable, surprising, or unpredictable. We found that surprising evoked responses were encoded according to the difference between predicted and observed features and attention facilitated encoding of this information in the brain.
Trypanosoma brucei gambense is a pathogen of sub-Saharan Africa that causes sleeping sickness in humans and animals. There are three sub-species of T. brucei: T. brucei, T. rhodesense, and T. gambense. T. bruce is unable to infect humans due to sensitivity to trypanolytic factors ( TLF ) 1 and 2 found in human serum. T. rhodesense and. gambense are able to resist lysis by TLF. There are two sub-groups of T. gambense that differ genetically and human resistance phenotypes. Group 1 T gambense have an invariant phenotype whereas group 2 show variable. Previous data indicated group 1 gambense are resistant to TLF-1 due to reduced uptake of T-1 mediated by reduced expression of T- receptor the haptoglobinemoglobin (Hb ) gene. Here we investigate if also in group 2 parasites. Isogenic resistant and sensitive group gambense were derived and compared to bruce parasites. Both express Hb gene similar and internalized fluorescent labeled T- similar to bruce. Both resistant and sensitive group 2, as well as group gambense, internal recombinant AP1 but sensitive group are lysed. Our data indicate group gambense avoiding T-1 is to main lytic AP1. Similarly group gambense innately to AP1 which be same mechanism. However group gambense variably phenotype and expression does not appear correlate change expression or Hb. Thus differences in human resistance between gambense 1 and 2.
DNA methylation of the HIV-1 5′ long terminal repeat (LTR) is considered to be a mechanism of transcriptional suppression that allows retroviruses to evade host immune responses and antiretroviral drugs. However, the role of DNA methylation in the control of HIV-1 latency has never been unambously demonstrated. Here, we show that CpG methylation of the HIV-1 5′LTR is an epigenetic mechanism that controls resistance of HIV-1 to reactivation and determines the stability of HIV-1 latency. In an in vitro model of reable latency, Cp methylation acts as a late event during establishment of HIV-1 latency and is not required for initial provirus silencing. The latent reservoir of avire patients contained high proportions of nonethylated 5LTR. The latency controlled by transcriptional interference and chromatin mechanisms in absence of significant DNA methylation tends to be leaky and reactivable. In latent HIV-infected individuals without detectable viremia, we found HIV promoters and enhancers to be hypermethyl and resistant to reactivation, opposed to hypomethyl 5LTR in vire patients. However, methylation of HIV-1 5LTR did not confer complete resistance to reactivation of latent HIV with histone deacetylase inhibitors, protein C agonists TN-α, and combinations 5-aza-2oxycytidine.
Genomic variation in Drosophila melanogaster is a key to understanding the relationship between genetic and phenotypic variation. We present a nucleotide catalog of single-nucle, multiucle, and structural variants in 39 Dophila melanogaster Reference inbred lines. We identify more than 3. 6 million variants, including more than 800, 000 insertions, deletions ( indels ) and complex variants (1 to 6, 000 bp ). We find that variants are not mutagenic nor are regions with high variant density mutation-prone. Rather, elevated SNP density around variants is due to population-level processes. We provide insights into the architecture of gene expression variation in adult flies by mapping cis-expression trait loci (cisQTL ) for more 2, 000 genes. Indels comprise 10% of all cisQTL and show larger effects than cisQTL. We find more associations in males than females and most cisQ are sex-specific, revealing decoupling of genomic architecture between sexes and importance of factors mediating sex-based expression. Finally, we perform RNA-seq-based allelic imbalance in offspring between sequenced lines and find that most cisQ can be validated in heterozygous.
The amplitude of the rectified electromyogram (EMG) signal is commonly used as an estimator of the neural drive to muscle and synaptic input to motor neurons. However, the loss of EM amplitude due to overlap of motor unit potentials (cancellation ) may distort the spectrum of the rectified EM and its correlation with the drive. This study investigated the impact of cancellation on correlation using analytical and computational models of motor activity, force, and EM signal. We analytically demonstrated that rectified EM without cancellation (EMnc ) is superior to rectified EM as estimator of neural drive. This was confirmed by simulations, as the coefficient of determination ( ) between neural in 1–30 Hz and EMnc (0.59±.08 ) matched the correlation between rectified EM and drive when cancellation was low (<40% ) at contraction (<5% maximum voluntary force; MVC ). However, correlation decreased with cancellation (–.83 ) to values <0.2 at cancellation (>60% ) contraction (>15 MVC ). Simulations showed that stronger neural implied stronger correlation between rectified EM and drive and cancellation distorted mainly low-frequency (<5 Hz ) of drive.
In Arabidopsis thaliana responds to aluminium (Al) stress by inhibiting root growth, and auxin is necessary for this response. However, the molecular mechanism is largely unknown. We show that YUC, which encodes flavin monooxygenase-like proteins, regulates auxin biosynthesis in the root transition zone (TZ) in response to Al stress. Al upregulates YUC3/5/7/9 in the root TZ, resulting in aux accumulation in the TZ and root inhibition during stress. These changes are dependent on ethylene signalling. Disruption of eth signalling causes enhanced or reduced upregulation of Ys in TZ in response to Al. Moreover, eth enhanced root inhibition under Al was alleviated in y mutants or by co-treatment withucas, an inhibitor of Y activity, suggesting a role in this process.
Natural killer (NK) cell responses in primates are regulated by interactions between killer-cell immunoglobulin-like receptors (KIR) on NK cells and major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules on target cells. We show that certain simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) peptides stabilize the interaction between the MHC class I molecule Mamu-A*002 and the inhibitory receptor Mamu-K3DL05, but not others. We investigated the functional implications of these interactions by testing SIV peptides bound to Mam-A*002 for their ability to modulate Mam-K3+ NK cell responses. Twenty-eight of seventy-five SIV peptides bound to Mam-A002 suppressed the cytolytic activity of Mam-K3 NK cells, including immunodominant CD8 T cell epitopes previously shown to stabilize Mam-A002 tetramer to Mam3. Substitutions at C-terminal positions changed inhibitory peptides into disinhibitory, and vice versa, without altering binding to Mam002. The effects of these variants on NK responses corresponded to their effects on Mam002 tetramer to Mam. In assays with mixtures of inhibitory disinhib peptides, low concentrations of inhib peptides suppressed NK responses. Consistent with inhibition of Mam-K cells by epitopes presented Mam002, SIV replication was higher in Mam002 CD+ lymphocytes co-cultured Mam-K cells than Mam-K cells.
Bacterial pathogens must be able to sense and adapt to a variety of environmental stresses in order to survive. We hypothesize that strains adapted to survive nutrient deprivation are more adept at colonizing and persisting in the host. In this study, we detected microevolution in response to nutrient limitation in Haemophilus influenza ( NTH ). We observed a mutation in 3',5-cyclic adenosine monophosphate phosphodiesterase activity in the ic strain. In a preclinical model of NTH-induced otitis (OM), we observed a decrease in recovery of effusion from ears infected with the ic strain. Clinically, resolution of OM coincided with clearance of middle ear fluid. In contrast, the ic strain formed significantly more intracellular bacterial communities (IBCs) than the parental strain during OM. The number of IBCs formed by the parental strain was low at early stages of OM, but increased at later stages coinciding with absence of recoverable effusion, suggesting a mucosal reservoir following resolution of disease.
Bacterium Burkholderia pseudomalle, the causative agent of meloidosis, modulates host iron homeostasis to facilitate intracellular survival. Infection of primary macrophages with B. pseudalle results in downregulation of the iron exporter ferroin, leading to increased iron availability within macrophages. Exogenous modification of ferroport function by hepcin or supplementation with ferric ammonium citrate increases intracellular iron and stimulates B pseudalle growth, whereas iron chelation by deferoxamine reduces bacterial survival. Iron-loaded macrophages exhibit lower expression of NADPH oxidase, iNOS, lipocalin 2, cytokines and activation of caspase-1. Infection of mice with the pathogen causes diminished ferport expression, higher iron retention in the liver and lower levels in serum (hypofermia ). In vivo administration of ferric ammonium cit tends to promote bacterial growth and inflammation, whereas limitation of availability significantly ameliorates bacterial clearance, attenuates cytokine levels and improves survival of infected mice.
Proteins accomplish their biological functions through collective atomic motions. However, the identification of collective motions related to a specific protein function from a molecular trajectory is non-trivial. We propose a novel technique termed “functional analysis” that detects collective motion directly related to a protein function. This technique is based on an ensemble of structures and a “functional” quantity that quantifies the protein’s functional state. It detects the collective motion maximally correlated to the quantity. The functional quantity can correspond to geometric, electrostatic, chemical, or any variable relevant to the protein. In addition, the motion most likely to induce a change in the quantity is estimated from the ensemble. Two correlation measures are applied: the Pearson coefficient that measures linear correlation and mutual that assesses any interdependence. Detecting maximally correlated motion derives a model for the state in terms of a single coordinate. This approach is illustrated with proteins including polyalanine-helixase, T lysozyme, Trpase and leucine-binding.
Eukaryotic genes of Euglena gracilis and other marine diatoms harbor nonconventional introns that are not found in other eukaryotes. These nonconventional introns do not have the conserved borders of spliceosomal introns or complementary U1 snRNA at the 5’ end. They form a stable secondary structure between exon/intron junctions, but do not resemble self-splicing introns. Nonconventional introns are frequently inserted at new positions, whereas conventional introns are conserved or lost. We examined the order of intron removal from Euglena gracilis transcripts of the tubA and gap genes, which contain both nonconventional and spliceosomal introns. We compared the order of intron excision for pairs of intr belonging to different types and analyzed intermediate splicing products using PacBio Next Generation Sequencing. We found that nonconventional introns are removed later than spliceosomal introns. We also observed accumulation of transcripts with conventional introns removed and noncon present, suggesting a gap between the two splicing types.
Coxsackievirus B (CV) is an enterovirus that commonly causes self-limited febrile illness in infants. However, cases of severe infection can manifest in acute myocarditis. The consequences of mild CV infection are unknown, though there is an epidemiologic association between subclinical infections and late heart failure, raising the possibility of subtle damage leading to late-onset dysfunction or chronic injury due to inflammatory reactions during latent infection. Here, we describe a mouse model of juvenile infection with subclinical dose coxsievirus B3 ( CV3 ) which showed no symptoms either immediately following infection or in adult. However, following physiological or pharmacological cardiac stress, juvenile-infected mice underwent cardiac hypertrophy and indicative of progression to heart failure. Evaluation of vasculature in hearts of mice subjected to cardiac stress showed compensatory increase in CD31+ vessel formation, though this was suppressed in juvenile-infected mice. Moreover, CV3 efficiently infected c-kit+ cells, cardiac progenitor numbers were reduced in hearts of juvenile-infected mice.
Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of melioidosis, regulates IL-1 and IL-18 production via NOD-like receptor NLRP and pyroptosis NLRC. However, the role of B. pseudalle in inflamome activation and other cell death mechanisms during infection are not well defined. We show that caspase-1 and pyptosis are exclusively dependent on NLRC, not NLRP in early macrophage infection, whereas later casase-1 activation is NLRC-independent. In the early phase, we identified a pathway involving casases-9, -7 and PAR downstream NLRC and casase-1. In casase-1-deficient macrophages, apoptosis is strongly induced, dependent on apoptotic initiator and effector casases. Early casase-1 activation in macrophages is reduced or abolished after B. pseudalle flagellin F or TSS3SA mutant infection. TSS effector protein BE activates casase-1. TSS inner protein BK mutant fails to activate casase, reveals higher intracellular counts, reduced death and IL-β during early but not late macroage infection. Intranasal infection of BAL/c mice with BK mutant displays decreased mortality, lower bacterial loads, IL-β, myeloperoxidase and neutrophils in bronchoalveolar lavage. Our results indicate a major role for TSS in NLRC casase-1 activation pyptosis and contribution of casase-dependent death in B pseudalle pathogenesis.
The Arabidopsis thaliana KINγ is a subunit of the SNF1-related kinase complex plays a role in plant development. We show that KINγ is a cytoplasm and nucleus-localized protein in vegetative cells of Arabidopsis pollen. Kγ mutant pollen does not germinate on stigma, but germinates normally in vitro. Further analysis shows that hydration of Kγ mutant pollen on stigma is compromised. However, adding water to stigma promotes germination of mutant in vivo, suggesting that hydration of mutant leads to defective germination. Kγ mutant pollen mitochondria and peroxomes are destroyed and numbers are significantly reduced compared to wild type. We find that Kγ mutant has reduced reactive oxygen species (ROS) in pollen. Addition of H2O2 in vitro partially compensates for reduced hydration of mutant, and ROS in Arabidopsis CATAL 3 overexpression compromises hydration on stigma. These results indicate Arabid Kγ is critical for ROS regulation by mediating biogenesis of mitochond and perox in pollen required for pollen–stigma interactions.
RNase III is a class of enzymes that cleaves double-stranded RNA in many biological systems. In bacteria, RNase III is involved in ribosomal RNA maturation and mRNA turnover. In eukaryotes, Drosha and Dicer are RNase homologs that play critical roles in miRNA and siRNA production. However, RN III is not essential in most bacteria, except in Bacillus subtilis. We show that RN III is essential in B. subtilis to silence toxin genes borne by two prophages, Skin and SP, through antisense RNAs. Unlike many organisms that use RN III or homologs as part of viral defense, B. subtil requires RN for survival. We identify txA and yT as toxin-encoding mRNAs of Skin and SP sensitive to RN III. We explore mechanism of III-mediated txA mRNA decay when paired to antisense Rat, both in vivo and in vitro.
The filarial nematode Brugia mal is the causative agent of Lymphatic Filariasis, a parasitic nematode that modulates host biology by releasing extracellular vesicles ( EVs ) containing bioactive proteins and RNA. EVs are secreted by all life stages of B. mal (microfilar, L3, L4, adult male and female ) and are internalized by murine macrophages by phagocytosis, suggesting a conserved mechanism for effector trafficking. Proteomic profiling of adult male and female EVs revealed quantitative and qualitative differences in the EV proteome, defining Brug EV biogenesis and sexual dimorphism in immunomodulatory cargo. Iverectin was found to rapidly inhibit EV release by all B. mal life stages. This effect was also observed in the filarial nemode Dirofilar imitis, but not in iverect-unresponsive isolate, suggesting a mechanism of action for this drug and new platforms for anti-filar drug development.
In the Western Province of the Solomon Islands, the prevalence of scabies and impigo was investigated in a population-based survey. Ten rural villages were included in the study and 190 residents were enrolled. The total prevalence of scabies was 19. 2% (95% CI 17.–21. ) and age and gender prevalence 19.2% (95CI 16.–21. ). The prevalence of scabies in adults was 10.4% (95CI 8–13. ) and highest in infants <1 year (34.%, OR 3.2–.6 ) and children 1–4 years (25., OR 2.–3. ) Scabies affected two or more body regions in 80% of participants and 4% classified as severe. The total prevalence of impigo was 32.7 (95CI 30–.8 ) and age and gender 26.7 (CI 24–.5 ) The highest in children 1–4 (42., OR 2–5.8 ). Sc infestation was associated with impigo (OR 2., 1–.6 ) and 41% of impigo also had scabies.
Neurogenesis in the adult hippocampus continues to occur in the subgranular zone of the dentate gyrus of the hippocampus in mice. However, the function of this process remains unclear. In this study, cellular proliferation in the hippocampus was measured in 719 outbred stock mice and revealed a significant correlation between the proportions of CD8+ and CD4 T lymphocyte subsets. This correlation reflected shared genetic loci, with the exception of the H-2a locus that had a dominant influence on T cell subsets but no impact on neurogenesis. Analysis of knockouts and repopulation of Tα-deficient mice subsets of T cells confirmed the influence of T on neurogenesis, indicating that CD+ T cells mediate the effect.
Chagas disease is a major public health problem in Latin America and an emerging disease in the US. We previously screened the Trypanosoma cruzi database by computational/bioinformatics and identified antigens that exhibited characteristics of vaccine candidates. We investigated the protective efficacy of a multi-component DNA-prime/protein-boost vaccine (TVac2) constituted of selected antigens and cytokines (IL-12 and GM-CSF) expression plasmids in a murine C57/6 mice model. Mice were immunized with antigen-encoding plasmids plus cytokines, followed by recombinant proteins and weeks later, challenged with T cruzi trypastigotes. ELISA and flow cytometry were employed to measure humoral (antibodyotypes ) and cellular (ymphocyte, CD+ and CD+ T phenotype and cytokine ) responses. Myocard pathology was evaluated by H&E and Masson trich staining. TVac induced a strong antigen-specific response (Ig2>Ig1 ) and moderate lymphocyte proliferation in mice. Upon challenge, TVac-vaccinated mice expanded Ig2/Ig1 and elicited a CD+ T response with type cytok (IF- and TN- ) that resulted in control of parasite burden. During phase, response persisted, splenic activation CD+ cells and IF-/-TN cytokines subsided and IL/- cytok became dominant in vaccinated. The parasitism, inflammation, androsis in heart and muscle TVac-vacc chronic were undetectable by techniques. In, mice injected vector or cytok only responded T cruz by elicitation of mixed (1/type ), cell and cytok response and persistent burden in myocardium.
Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have been successful in identifying genetic loci associated with complex diseases. However, a remaining question is whether disease risk can be quantified based on genotype to facilitate prevention and treatment. Previous studies have failed to achieve satisfactory performance due to use of limited susceptibility loci. Here, we propose that machine learning approaches with a large number of markers may improve disease assessment. We applied a Support Vector Machine (SVM) algorithm on a GWAS dataset generated on Affymetrix genotyping for type 1 diabetes (T1D) and optimized a risk model with hundreds of markers. We tested this model on an independent Illumina-genotyped dataset (1,008 cases, 1,000 controls ) and a separate Affetrix-genotyped dataset (1,529,1,458 ), resulting in area under curve (AUC) ∼0.84 in both datasets. In contrast, poor performance was achieved when limited to dozens of known loci in the model or logistic regression. Our study suggests that disease assessment can be improved by algorithms taking into account interactions between a large of markers. We are that genotype-based risk may be feasible for diseases where proportion of risk has been captured by arrays.
Memory CD8 T cells are a type of immune cell that rapidly infiltrate non-lymphoid tissues, such as the skin, to provide protective immunity against viral infections in an antigen-specific manner. However, the fate of memory CD8 T cells after entering non-lymphoid tissues, such as the skin, during a secondary infection is largely unknown. CD62 is often used to identify the central memory ( TCM ) CD8 T subset, but the requirement for CD62-mediated lymph node homing versus other attributes of TCM CD8 T remains unresolved. We show that memory CD8 T cells traffic into the skin independent of CD62-mediated lymph node reactivation and provide robust immunity against Vaccinia (V) infection. TCM, but not effector (TEM ) CD8 T differentiated into functional CD69+/103 tissue residents following viral clearance, which was dependent on local antigen recognition in the skin microenvironment. We found that memory8 cells expressed granzyme after trafficking the skin and utilized cytoly to provide immunity againstV infection. Collectively, findings demonstrate that TCM8 cells become cytoly following infiltration the skin to protect against infection and differentiate into CD69 tissue residents.
Myosin VI is a minus-directed motor protein that has been shown to play a role in the enrichment of proteins on the surface of axons in neurons. In contrast to Myosin Va, a plus-directed motor that has been shown to target proteins to dendrites, Myos VI is involved in targeting proteins to the axonal surface. Myos VI mediates the enrichment of proteins on the axonal surface at least in part by stimulating dendrite endocytosis, a mechanism that has been shown to underlie the localization of many axonal proteins. In addition, a version of Channelrhodopsin 2 that was engineered to bind to Myos VI is concentrated at the surface of the axon of cortical neurons in vivo, suggesting it could be useful for probing circuit and function.
Sex determination in the branchiopod crustacean Daphnia magna: Conservation of a doublesex gene in the sex-determining pathway. Daphnia magna is a freshwater crustacean that parthenogenetically produces males in response to environmental cues. We report the identification of two doublesex (Dsx) genes, DmaD1 and Dma2, which play important roles in controlling sexual dimorphism. DmaD1 is responsible for male development when expressed during environmental sex determination. The DmaD1 domain is similar to Dsx from insects, which are thought to be sister group of branchiop crustans. However, the molecular basis for sexually dimorphic expression of DmaD1 is different from insects.maDma1 exhibits sexually dimorphic differences in transcript abundance rather than sex-specific pre-mRNA splicing in the coding region. During embryogenesis, Dma1 is increased only in males and transcripts are primarily detected in male structures. Knockdown ofma1 in males results in female traits including ovary maturation, whereas ectopic expression ofma in females results in male-like phenotypes.ma2 expression patterns are similar toma1 but silencing and overexpression do not induce clear phenotypic changes. These results establishma1 as key regulator of male phenotype. Our findings reveal how environmental sex is implemented by selective expression of fundamental component conserved in genetic sex. We infer previously unidentified link between genetic and sex.
Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV-2) is a sexually transmitted virus that causes genital herpes, neonatal herpes, and increases the risk of HIV transmission. A vaccine is urgently needed to prevent pain and suffering. We evaluated a trivalent HSV-2 subunit vaccine in rhesus macques and guinea pigs. The vaccine contains glycoproteins C, D, and E ( g2,D, g2,E ) to block virus entry and immune evasion. In rhes macques, the trivalent vaccine induced plasma and mucosa neutralizing antibodies that block immune evasion and stimulated CD T cell responses. After intravaginal challenge, a brief infection was detected in naïve but not immunized macques. We evaluated vaccine efficacy in guinea pigs. Animals were mock, immunized with g2, trivalent or trivalent followed by booster g2 trivalent. The trivalent and trivalent g2 groups were 97% and 99% efficacious in preventing lesions and outperformed g2. As marker of transmission, vaginalabs were evaluated for HSV-2 DNA and replication between five and seven weeks after challenge. HSV-2 DNA was reduced in all compared with mock. Shedding of replication virus occurred fewer days in trivalent than g2 immunized while trivalent g2 had no shedding replication virus. Overall, trivalent had lesions <1% and shedding replication virus 0.2%.
Chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by high-throughput sequencing (ChIP-seq) is a powerful tool for genome-wide profiling of protein-DNA interactions. However, mapping protein-DNA interactions in segmental duplications and highly repetitive regions of genomes is challenging because short reads (50–100 base pairs) map to multiple locations in the reference genome. Standard methods discard multi-mapping reads and those that can accommodate are prone to false positive and negative rates. We developed Perm-se, a prior-enhanced read allocation method for ChIP-se that can map multiapping reads in repetitive regions with high accuracy. We comprehensively evaluated Perm-se and found that our approach significantly improves multi-read allocation over methods that do not utilize additional data. Our statistical framework facilitates multi-read allocation with a variety of data including histone Ch-seq. We applied Perm-se to 64 ENCODE ChIP-se datasets from GM78 and K562 cells and identified novel protein-D interactions in segmental regions.
Schistosomiasis is a parasitic infection that affects approximately 218 million people worldwide, mostly in Africa. Previous studies suggest that people with chronic schosomiasis may have a higher risk of HIV-1 acquisition and impaired ability to control HIV-1 replication once infected. We conducted a nested case-control study within a population-based survey of HIV-1 transmission in Tanzania to investigate the effects of schosiasis on HIV-1 susceptibility and HIV-1 viral load at HIV-1 serconversion. Approximately 40% of the population was infected with Schosoma mansoni and 2% with S. haobium. We tested schosoma antigens in pre- and post-HIV-serconversion blood of HIV-1 serconverters and matched controls who did not acquire HIV-1. Analysis was stratified by gender. We compared 73 HIV-1 serconverters with 265 controls. Women with schosias had higher odds of HIV-1 acquisition than without (OR 2.8 [ 1.–.6, p 0.019 ). Schos-infected men did not have increased odds HIV-1 acquisition (OR 0. [.3–.8, p.42 ). We compared HIV-1 RNA in post-serconversion blood HIV-1 serconverters with schosias versus without. The median HIV-1 RNA in 15 HIV-converters with schos was higher than 22 without schos: 4. [.–. log copies/mL versus 3.–., p.017. We confirm that pre-existing schos infection increases HIV-1 odds in women and HIV-1 viral load at HIV- serconversion. This is the first study to demonstrate schos effect on HIV-1 susceptibility and control and to differentiate by gender.
Ribosomal DNA (rDNA) is one of the most variable regions in the human genome with respect to copy number variation. Despite its importance for cellular function, virtually nothing is known about what governs rDNA copy number and sequence stability in the mammalian genome. We applied computational and droplet PCR to measure rDNA copy in normal and cancer states in human and mouse genomes. We find that rDNA copy and sequence can change in cancer genomes. Counterintuitively, human cancer genomes show loss of rDNA copies accompanied by global copy number variation. The sequence can also be more variable in cancer genomes. Cancer with lower rDNA have mutational evidence of mTOR activity. The PTEN phosphatase is a tumor suppressor that is critical for genome stability and negative regulator of mTOR pathway. Surprisingly, consistent with human cancer, hematopoietic stem cells from PTEN-/- mouse leukemia have lower rDNA than normal, despite increased rRNA and protein synthesis. Loss occurs early and is with hypersensitivity to DNA. Therefore, loss is recurrent in cancers with mTOR.
Infection with Salmonella Typhimurium (S. Typhimurium ) is a major cause of disease in humans and animals worldwide. The dynamics of bacterial growth, death, and spread within mammalian hosts are not fully understood. Here, we used a novel approach to study the spatiemporal dynamics of S. Tyimium during infection in mice. We infected mice with wild-type and isogenic strains of S. Tyium, which are phenotypically identical but can be distinguished by quantitative PCR. This allowed us to estimate the death rate of bacteria based on the disappearance of strains over time. We found that shortly after infection, concom death and rapid bacterial replication lead to the establishment of independent bacterial populations in different organs, controlled by host antimicrobial mechanisms. Later, decreased mortality leads to an increase in the number of bacteria that spread locally, with mixing of bacteria between organs via bactemia and further selection. Our approach provides an unprecedented view of the pathogenesis of S. Tyim, illustrating the complex and stochastic effects that drive infectious disease.
Binocular 3D motion perception is the process by which the brain interprets the motion of objects in 3D space based on information from the two eyes. The inverse problem of binocular 3D motion is the process by which the brain recovers the 3D motion of an object from 2D retinal images. Current theories of binocular 3D motion are based on interocular velocity difference, changing disparity over time, and joint encoding of motion and disparity. However, these theories do not provide a general solution to the inverse problem of binocular 3 motion. Instead, we propose that local velocity in combination with binocular disparity and other cues provide a more flexible framework for the solution of the inverse problem. In the context of the aperture problem, we derive two plausible strategies: (1) the normal prefers slow motion in 3D and (2) the cyclopean based on slow in 2. Predicting motion for ambiguous motion provides an opportunity to distinguish between these strategies of 3D processing. Our results suggest that velocity and disparity from tracking are needed to solve the inverse of 3 motion. It is plausible that motion and disparity are processed in parallel and integrated in the hierarchy.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa secretes anionic O-acetylated exopolysaccharide alginate during chronic infection in the lungs of cystic fibrosis patients. Four proteins have been implicated in alginate O-acetylation: AlgJ and AlgX. We determined the structure of Alg to 1. 83 Å resolution. Alg is a SGN hydrolase-like protein with a conserved catalytic triad composed of D190, H192 and S288 and exhibits acetylester activity in vitro. Alg exhibits a distinctly different electrostatic surface compared to the N-terminal of AlgX. We identified residues in Alg that form an extensive network of interactions critical for alginate O-acetylation in vivo. We compared the abilities of Alg and Alg to bind and acety alginate using electrospray ion mass spectrometry (ESI-MS). Alg exhibits weak or no binding to polymuronic acid while Alg binds polymuronic in a length-dependent manner. Additionally, Alg utilizes acetyl-donor 4-nrophenyl acetate to catalyze alginate Oetylation. Our results suggest Alg and Alg have separate roles in alginate Oety. Our model places Alg as terminaltransfer and provides rationale for variability in proteins required for polyschar Oety.
Candida albicans is one of the most common causes of human fungal infections and a major source of mortality. It is able to evade detection by the innate immune system by masking its cell wall with a heavily glycosylated outer layer of mannan. However, mutations or drugs that disrupt the cell wall can lead to exposure of β 1, 3 -glan ( unmasking ) and detection by innate cells through receptors like Dectin, C-type lectin. We previously showed that the pathway synthesizing phospholipid phosphatylser ( PS ) plays a role in β 1 3 -glan masking. The homozygous PS synthase mutant, choΔ, exhibits increased exposure β 1 3 -glan. The MAPK pathways and upstreamho small Gases are important for cell biogenesis and remodeling. In choΔ, both C1 and M1 are constitutively activated and act downstream of smallases C42 andho, respectively. In addition, C42 is upregulated inΔ. It was hypothesized that activation of C42ho orho and their kinases cause unmask. Disruption of M1 does not decrease unmask inΔ and hyperactivation ofho in wild increases unmask and activation of C1 and M. Moreover, hyperactivation of kinase in wild cells leads to C1 activation and β 3 -an exposure. Upregulation of C1 pathway causes unmask and may be responsible for unmask inΔ.
Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and related dementias are major public health challenges that require additional insight into their molecular pathogenesis. We performed a genome-wide association study of known genetic loci for AD using neuropathologic data from 4, 914 brain autopsies. Neuropath data were used to define clinico-path AD or controls, assess neuropath features of AD ( neuritic plaques, NPs; neurofibr tangles, NFT ) and evaluate coorbid neuropath changes: cerebral amyloid angiopathy ( C ), Lewy disease ( L ) hippocal sclerosis of the ( HS ) and brain injury ( V ). We observed genome-wide significance for clin-path AD, NPs, NFT, C and L with variants in apolipoprotein E ( APO ) Galc transfer 7 ( GAL7 ) ATPinding Subfamily G Member 1 (WHITE ) and intergenic on chromosome 9 for NP; Potassium Conductance Subfamily M Beta 2 (KCMB ) for HS. Twelve non-APO genetic loci for clinically AD were confirmed in our sample: CR, BIN, CL, MS, PICAL, ABC, CD, PTK, SOR, MEF, ZW, and C with 9 of these showing larger odds ratio in our sample. Correlation effect sizes for AD with NFT or NPs showed positive, while for V showed negative. Other coor neuropath features only showed nominal association with known loc. Our results discovered new associations with neuropath and aligned genetic for AD with neuropath in the largest AD and dement study.
The role of urea in the unfolding of proteins at the proteome scale is still not fully understood. We have analyzed 30 representative proteins of all native folds using molecular dynamics simulations with a range of force fields. We derived rules for urea unfolding that are valid at the proteome level. Irrespective of fold, presence or absence of disulfide bridges, and secondary structure, urea concentrates in the first solvation shell of native proteins with lower density than the unfolded. Urea does not alter spontaneous protein vibrations, but reduces their magnitude, slowing atomic motions that oppose unfolding. Urea stick and diffusion is crucial for unfolding. Long urea around hydrophobic core stabilizes partially open structures generated by thermal fluctuations. Our simulations indicate ure does not favor open microstates, but is not a spectator of unfolding that displaces the folded→unfolded equilibrium. On the contrary, ure actively unfolds: selects and stabilizes partially microstates, driving conformation far from native and sampled during unfolding.
Dengue fever is a major public health problem in Colombia. Between 2000 and 2011, deng fever was characterized by a stable annual number of cases with major outbreaks in 2001–2003 and 2010. The majority of deng cases were among those <15 years of age. Most of the country was affected by the 201 outbreak.
Leishmaniasis (TL) is a disease of the skin and mucosal tissues caused by Leishmania parasites. In addition to Leishiasis, patients may concurrently carry other pathogens that can influence the clinical outcome of the disease. This review focuses on the frequency of coinfections in human populations, interactions between Leishmania and other pathogens in animal and human subjects, and implications for clinical practice. TL is defined as all forms of cutaneous ( localised, disseminated or ) and mucocutaneous leishias. We searched MEDLINE and other databases and included 73 records: 21 studies in animals and 52 in human subjects ( mainly cross-sectional and case studies ). Several reports describe the frequency of Trypanosoma cruzi coinfection in TL patients in Argentina ( about 41% ) and frequency of helminthias in TL in Brazil (15% to 88% ).
Genetic variation in the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) affects CD4:CD8 lineage commitment and MHC expression. However, the contribution of specific genes in this gene region has not been resolved. Here we assessed the impact of genetic variation on MHC expression and CD4:8 commitment using two rat models. We mapped Quantitative Trait Loci (QTL) associated with variation MHC I and CD4:8 cell ratio in outbred heterogeneous rats. We identified 10 QTL across the genome and found QTL for individual colocalized within a region spanning MHC. We generated a panel of M-recombinant congenic strains and refined QTL to two intervals ∼0. 25 Mb in M-I and II regions. An interaction between intervals affected M class expression as well as selection commitment of CD8-positive (SP) thymocytes. We mapped effect to transporter associated antigen 2 (Tap) in M-II and classical M class (RT-A) in-I. This was revealed by recombination between RT-A and Tap, which occurred 0.2% of rats. Variants Tap have been shown to influence antigenicity M class by altering ligand. Our results show a restricted repertoire M class leads to negative CD8 cells.
Chagas disease is a major public health problem in Spain due to the large number of migrants from Latin America. We analyzed the Spanish National Hospital Discharge Database ( CMB ) to describe the disease’s evolution from 1997 to 2011. We performed a retrospective study using CMB information on hospitalizations for Chagas. Data was divided into two periods: 199-2004 and 2005-201. We calculated hospital rates and described clinical characteristics. We used multivariable logistic regression to calculate odds-ratio (OR ) for association between conditions and hospitalization with organation. A total 172 hospitalizations were identified. Hospital rates were 18 and 242.8/000 population. The median age was 35 (0-87 ), 74% were female and the 16-45 age group was mostly (69.8 ). Overall 23.4 hospitalizations included Chagas with complications. Being male [OR 1.3 (1.00.77 ), aged 45-64 [OR 2. (1.42.71 ] and hospital cost above 3,065 [OR 2. (.73.86 ] were associated with organation. Since 2005, infections increased in Spain. Patients were mostly asymptomatic women of fertile age and conditions with organation underline the need for early detection of cruz.
Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified hundreds of genetic markers associated with complex diseases. However, the “missing heritability” remains elusive. Combinatorial interactions may account for a substantial portion of this missing heritability, but have been impeded by computational complexity and genetic heterogeneity. We present Blocuster, a systems-level approach that constructs genome-wide, allele-specific networks that segregates homogenous combinations of genetic factors and tests associations with the phenotype. Blocuster employs a correlation measure customized for single nucleotide polymorphisms and captures genetic heterogeneity. We applied Blocuster to psoriasis, discovering a combinator pattern with odds ratio 3.64 and Bonferr-corrected p-value 5.01×10−16. This was replicated in independent data, reflecting robustness of method. Blocuster improves prediction of disease and broadens understanding of psoriasis pathogenesis.
Rare and de novo copy number variants (CNVs) are more prevalent in agenesis of the corpus callosum (ACC) than in cerebellar hypoplasia (CH) or polymicrogyria (PM). We conducted a large-scale CNV discovery effort in 255 ACC, 220 CH, and 147 PM patients, and 2,349 controls. Compared to controls, significantly more ACC but not CH or PM patients had rare CNVs over one megabase (p=1.48×10−3; odds ratio [OR]=3.19; 95% confidence interval [CI]=1.89–5.39 ). Rare CNVs impacted at least one gene less 1% of combined patients and controls. More ACC but not CH or PM patients had CNVs over genes (p=.01;OR=2.95%CI=1.69–5.18 ). Independent PCR confirmed 9.4% ACC had de novo CNVs, in comparison to inherited CN. These preferentially overlapped de novo CN previously in patients with autism spectrum disorders (p=3.06×10−;OR=7.95%CI=2.–23.72 ). We also confirmed and refined known CN, including 8p.1–p.1 present 2% current ACC. We found novel CN, each single patient likely deleterious deletions 1.–.31.,1,1.–.31.3,5.–., and duplications 2–.– and 14.–. One patient microcephaly had paternally deletion 16. that included N1. Exome sequencing revealed recessive matally inherited nonsense in non-deleted N1 allele. This is first systematic CN in congenital brainform, shows higher large CN in ACC than CH and PM.
Regeneration in planarians is a complex process that requires the integration of proliferation, differentiation, and patterning of tissues to the proper size and scale. However, the integration of these processes with wound responses remains relatively unknown. Here, we investigated the role of the effector of the Hippo signalling cascade, Yorkie, during planarian regeneration and its role in restricting injury responses. We used RNA interference ( RNAi ) to deplete Yorkie in planarians and found that wound responses were hyperactivated, with both stem cell proliferation and transcriptional wound programs heightened and prolonged. We also uncovered novel wound-induced genes by RNAseq that were repressed in Yorkie RNAi animals compared to controls. Additionally, we found that Yorkie RNAi animals had expanded epidermal and muscle populations, which we hypothesize are sources of wound-induced genes. Finally, we found that Yorkie RNAi animals could not sense the size of an injury by the eyes, pharynx, brain, and midline, and could not remodel or scale to the size of the regenerating fragment. Our results suggest that Yorkie functions as a key molecule that integrates multiple aspects of injury including proliferation, apoptosis, injury transcription, and patterning.
Exosomes secreted by enterovirus 71 (EV71)-infected cells contain viral RNA and miR-146 that facilitate viral replication in recipient cells by suppressing type I interferon response. EV71 infection results in increased exosome secretion and differential packaging of viral RNA and mi-146 into exosomes. We show that mi-146 is preferentially packaged in exosomes while viral RNA is not. Exosomes contain replication-competent EV71 RNA complex with mi-146, Ago2, and GW182 and mediate EV71 transmission independent of virus-specific receptor. Exosomal RNA is transferred to and replicates in new cell while exosomal mi-146 suppresses type I interferon response in cell, facilitating viral replication. Exosomal mi-146 suppresses IFN-stimulated gene (ISGs) BST2/tether, involved in EV71-induced exosome secretion. In vivo study, exosomal RNA accumulates in tissue compared to free virus.
Parkinson’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by the loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the brain. PTEN-induced kinase 1 ( PINK ) is a protein required for mitochondrial homeostasis and is mutated in early-onset Parkinson’s disease. Parkin is another protein mutated in early-onset Parkinson’s disease and has been suggested to function downstream of PINK based on genetic studies in Drosila. PINK is a serine/threon kinase with a predicted mitochondrial sequence and probable transmembrane domain at the N-terminus, while Park is a RING finger protein with ubiquitin ligase activity. However, how PINK and Park regulate mitochondrial activity is largely unknown. Here we report that PINK binds to a mitochondrial protein, PG5, which modulates the PINK pathway. Loss of PG5 in Drosila suppresses muscle degeneration, motor defects, and shorter lifespan resulting from PINK inactivation and can be attributed to mitochondrial degeneration. However, PG5 inactivation fails to modulate phenotypes of Park mutant flies. Conversely, ectopic expression of PG5 exacerbates PINK and Park phenotypes. These results suggest PG5 negatively regulates PINK related to maintenance of mitochondria, and further that PG5 acts between PINK and Park, or independently of Park downstream PINK.
Mycobacterium ulcer is the causative agent of Buruli ulcer (BU), a chronic necrotizing skin disease associated with the production of the cytotoxic macide exotoxin mycolone. Despite extensive research, the type of immune responses elicited against this pathogen and effector functions conferring protection against BU are not fully understood. Histopathological analyses of BU lesions have demonstrated mainly extracellular localization of toxin producing acid fast bacilli, but there is evidence for an early intracellular growth phase of M ulcerans. We investigated whether interferonγ might play a role in containing M ulcer infections. In a Buruli mouse model we found that interferγ is a critical regulator of host defense against ulcer infections. Interferγ knockout mice displayed faster progression of infection compared to wild-type mice. This was reflected in faster and more extensive tissue necrosis and oedema, as well as higher bacterial burden after five weeks infection, indicating mice lacking interferγ reduced capacity to kill intracellular bacilli during early intracellular growth of ulcer.
Reactive oxygen species (ROS) production in the mitochondria is a major factor in many diseases. However, the mechanism of hypoxia-induced ROS production is not fully understood. We developed a new methodology to mathematically analyze this mechanism, taking into account all possible redox states in the electron transport chain. This allowed us to identify two steady modes of operation (bistability) of respiratory complex III at the same conditions. Various perturbations could induce transition from one mode to another. Normally, complex III is in low ROS mode, but anoxia can switch it to high ROS mode, which persists after oxygen return. We qualitatively validated this prediction experimentally, explaining anox-induced cell damage.
Drosophila melanogaster embryos are used as a model to study the role of genes in pattern formation. The gap gene network is the first regulatory tier in the hierarchy of genes involved in specifying body segment position. Here, we investigate the effect of the terminal gene huckin ( hkb ) on gap expression using an integrative, systems approach. We present Hkb protein expression data to include it in gap gene models. Gap models are used to extract regulatory information from spatial data by fitting to expression patterns and obtain estimates for parameters. Our models are in agreement with earlier results and extend them in two respects: Hkb is required for the anterior shift of the posterior hunch ( hb ) border, which is reproduced in our models. Our models are able to reproduce mutants of terminal genes while published models were unable to reproduce any correctly. Our models capture the expression of all posterior genes and variational properties of the system.
Brucellos is an important zoonotic disease that causes significant economic losses worldwide. Currently, there is no effective immunotherapy for Bruclos or biomarker to monitor the efficacy of therapy. Treatment is ineffective and animals remain lifelong carriers. We report the successful immunotherapy of bovine Bruclos by phage lysates of RB51 ( RL ) and S19 ( SL ). RL induced strong antibody response and stimulated cell mediated immunity ( CMI ). In vitro restimulation of leukocytes from immunized cattle induced interferon production. A single subcutaneous dose of 2 ml cocktail of lysate ( RL and SL ) eliminated virulent Brucella from Bruclos affected cattle with undetectable level of Bruc specific amplicon by RT-PCR and negative for Bruc by culture 3 post-immunization. This is the first report on minimally invasive monitoring of antibacterial therapy employing RNA specific for bacteria as biomarker and use of RB51 phage lysate for immunotherapy Bruclos in cattle.
Cell cycle progression is regulated by cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs), which are also involved in the response to DNA damage. However, it is difficult to assign precise functions to specific CDKs in maintaining genomic integrity. In mammals, CDK2 is active during S and G2 phases, but CD2 is dispensable for survival due to compensation by other CDKs. To uncover a requirement for CD2 activity in human cells, we replaced wild-type CD2 with a mutant sensitive to inhibition by adenosine analogs. We show that transient inhibition of analog-sensitive CD2 after ionizing radiation enhances cell killing. CD2 phosphorylates the Nijegen Syndrome gene product N1—a component of the conserved MRN complex required for DNA repair and checkpoint—on a CD recognition site at Ser432. In vivo, inhibition of CD2 delayed N1-Ser phosphorylation during S and mutation of Ser to Ala or Asp increased IR sensitivity.
Genome-wide association (GWA) studies have identified many genetic variants associated with hematological traits, coronary artery disease, and myocardial infarction. However, it is challenging to turn these findings into biological mechanisms. We applied the formaldehyde-assisted isolation of regulatory elements (FAIRE) method in megakaryocytes and erythroblasts to map active regulatory elements at loci associated with these traits. We found that the two cell types exhibit distinct patterns of open chromatin and that open chromatin guides the finding of functional variants. We identified an open chrom region at 7q22. 3 in megaryocytes but not erythroblasts that harbors the non-coding variant rs342 known to be associated with platelet volume. Resequencing this region in 643 individuals provided strong evidence that rs342 is the causative variant. We showed that C and G differentially bind transcription factor EV1 affecting PIKCG expression in platelets and macrophages. A protein interaction network in Pikcg knockout mice indicated PI3 is associated with pathways in platelet biogenesis and thrombus formation. Thus, rs342 is the functional variant at this locus.
Respiratory rhythm generation in the pre-Bötzinger complex (preötC ) is thought to be generated by a persistent sodium current (INa ). However, the effects of pharmacological blockade of INa are often assumed to be equivalent, regardless of the mechanism of the blocker.
