Using computer simulations, we demonstrate that this assumption may not always be correct. We simulated the blockade of INa via two pharmacological mechanisms: (1 ) pore obstruction by tetrodotoxin and (2 ) altered inactivation by ruzole. The effects of tetroxin and ruz in respiratory circuits are diverse and have led to debate about the role of INa in respiratory. Our results match experimental data from preöt neurons to the respiratory network and generate experimentally testable predictions. We provide a mechanistic explanation for seemingly contradictory results in vitro INa block, show that INa block in vitro is not equivalent to intact preparations, explain why ruz fails to block INa in the network, and predict that low tetroxin will stop respiratory rhythm in the network.
MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are known to play important roles in tumor metastasis. Here, we describe the regulation and function of mi-218 in gastric cancer (GC) metastasis. We found that mi-218 expression is decreased along with the expression of its host gene Slit in metastatic GC. However, Rob1, one of several Slit receptors, is negatively regulated by mi-218, thus establishing a negative feedback loop. Decreased mi-218 levels eliminate Rob1 repression, which activates the Sl-Robo pathway through interaction between Rob1 and Slit2, thus triggering metastasis. The restoration of mi-218 suppresses Rob1 expression and inhibits tumor invasion and metastasis in vitro and in vivo.
Transcriptional Profiling Uncovers a Network of Cholesterol-Responsive Atherosclerosis Genes: Atherosclerosis is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in coronary artery disease and stroke. Despite the well-documented effects of lipid lowering therapies on atherosclerosis, the transcriptional response in atherosclerotic lesions has not been carefully investigated. We performed transcription profiling in atherosclerosis-prone mice with hypercholesterolemia and genetic lowering of plasma lipoproteins. Atheroscler lesions progressed slowly, then rapidly, and plateaued after advanced lesions formed. Analysis of expression indicated accumulation of lipid-poor macrophages led to rapid expansion with foam-cell formation and inflammation, supported by histology. Lowering plasma cholesterol prevented formation of advanced plaques and profiling identified 37 cholesterol-responsive genes mediating this effect. Validation by siRNA inhibition in macrophages incubated with ac-LDL revealed a network of eight cholesterol-responsive atherosclerosis genes regulating cholesterol accumulation. We have identified a network of atheros genes in response to cholesterol preventing formation of advanced plaques. This should be of interest for development of atherosclerosis therapies.
The envelope of Gram-negative bacteria is a formidable barrier that is difficult for antimicrobial drugs to penetrate. Thus, the list of effective treatments against these organisms is small and the rise of new resistance is rapidly shrinking. We developed a simple, quantitative, high-throughput assay for mutants with envelopeogenesis defects and used to screen an ordered-gene library of Escherich coli. The screen was robust and correctly identified mutants known to be involved in assembly. Importantly, the screen implicated 102 genes of unknown as factors that likely impact biogenesis. As proof of principle, one of these, Ely, was characterized and shown to play a role in metabolism of the lipid used for biogenesis of wall and other bacterial polysacides.
Multivariate dynamical processes in biological systems are increasingly studied using a variety of techniques, each revealing unique features of the system. One of the challenges is developing systematic approaches to fuse heterogeneous datasets into an integrated view of multivariate dynamics. We demonstrate that heterogeneous data can be successfully fused within a semi-supervised learning framework that exploits the geometry of high-dimensional data. We illustrate our approach using a dataset from studies of pattern formation in Drosophila. The result is a continuous trajectory that reveals joint dynamics of gene expression, subcellular localization, protein phosphorylation and morphogenesis.
Snake venom hemorrhagic metalloproteinases (SVMPs) of the PI, PII and PIII classes were compared in terms of tissue localization and their ability to hydrolyze basement components in vivo, as well as by proteomics analysis of exudates collected in injected tissue with these. Immunohistochemical analyses co-localization of these SVs with type IV collagen revealed that PII and III SVs co-localized with IV collagen in capillaries, arterioles and postillary vles to higher than PI SV, which showed more distribution in tissue. The patterns hydrolysis by these SVs of lamin, type collagen and nidogen in vivo differ, whereas three showed similar pattern of IV, supporting concept hydroly of this is critical destabilization microessel leading hemorrhage.
In Drosophila melanogaster, the homeotic genes are located on the chromosome in the order of the body segments they affect. The more posterior genes repress the anterior genes. However, this rule is qualified in the case of abdominal-A ( ab-A ) by abdominal-B ( Abd ). Abd mutants show ectopic expression of ab-A in the epidermis of the eighth segment, but not the central nervous system. Repression in these cells is accomplished by a 92 kb noncoding RNA, “iab-8”. This RNA produces a micro to repress ab-A and has a second redundant mechanism that only acts “in. Transcription interference with ab-A promoter is most likely.
Focal seizures are episodes of pathological brain activity that arise from a localised areas of the brain and have been distinguished into two types: low-amplitude fast oscillations (LAF) and high-amplitude spikes (HAS). Here, we explore whether these patterns arise from fundamentally different mechanisms. We use a previously established model of neocortical tissue and validate it using clinical recordings of focal seizures. We reproduce the two patterns in their defining properties and investigate the mechanisms underlying different seizure patterns in the model. We find that LAF is initiated by independent patches of local activity which invade surrounding tissue and coalesce over time. In contrast, HAS is a global transition to a seizure state triggered by a local event. This transition is enabled by an increase in excitability of surrounding tissue which itself does not generate seizures but can support activity when initiated. In simulations, the difference in excitability offers a simple explanation of clinically reported outcomes. Finally, we demonstrate how changes in excitability could be elucidated using stimulation. Our results suggest that excitability of surrounding the seizure core plays a role in onset as well as outcome.
Defensin-like ZES4 Mediates Pollen Tube Burst via Opening of the Potassium Channel KZ1 in Maize. In flowering plants, pollen is transported to the female gametophyte via the pollen tube. Upon arrival at the female gamophyte, two sperm cells are discharged into the synergid to execute fertilization. The players involved in gametophyte signaling to pollen tube arrest have been identified. However, the mechanisms leading to pollen burst and sperm discharge remained unknown. Here, we describe the role of defensin-like cyste-rich protein ZES4 ( Zea mays embryo ) in pollen growth arrest, burst, and sperm release. ZES4 is exclusively expressed in female gamophyte cells. Z4-GFP proteins accumulate in secretory vesicles of syner cells and are released during fertilization. Using RNAi knockdown and Z4 proteins, we found Z4 induces pollen burst in species-preferential. Pollen plasma depolarization occurs after Z4 application, as well as channel experiments point a role of K+-flux in tube rupture. Finally, we discovered the rectifying K channel K1 as direct Z4 target. Following Z4, K1 opens at physiological potentials and closes after wash. We suggest that Z4-containing vesicles are released from syner upon male-female signaling. Subsequent interaction Z4 and K1 results channel opening and K influx. We suggest K influx leads to water uptake and culminates osmotic tube.
Herpes simplex virus (HSV) has been engineered to selectively infect and kill cancer cells expressing the HER2 protein, which is overexpressed in ovarian and breast carcinomas. In this study, we assessed the efficacy of systemically delivered HSV against disseminated ovarian and breast carcinomas in mouse models that recapitulate the spread to the peritoneum in women. Human ovarian SKOV-3 cells implanted intraperitoneally in immunodeficient mice gave rise to progressive peritoneal carcinomatosis mimicking the fatal condition in patients. Intraperitoneal administration of HSV strongly inhibited carcinomatosis, with 60% of mice free from peritone diffusion and 95% reduction in total neoplastic nodules. Intraperitone metastases are common in breast cancer: intraperitoneal administration of HSV inhibited growth of ovarian metastases in HER2+ MDA-MB-453 cells. Brain metastases were also reduced. Cumulatively, intraper administration of HER-redirected oncolytic HSV reduced growth of ovarian and breast disseminated to peritone cavity.
Centrosome duplication is essential for bipolar spindle formation and genome maintenance and is regulated by cyclin-dependent kinases (Cdks). Our study identifies Sfi, a conserved centrosomal protein, as the first Cd substrate required to restrict centome duplication to once per cycle. We found that reducing Cdk phosphorylation of Sfi by changing phosphorylation sites to nonphosphorylatable residues leads to defects in separation of duplicated spindle bodies (SPBs, centomes) and inappropriate SP reduplication during mitosis. These cells display defects in bipolar assembly, segregation, and growth.
Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) is a major cause of acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). The role of Vpr, an HIV-1-encoded protein, in HIV-1 infection and AIDS remains unclear. Previous studies have shown that V causes G2 cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in HIV-1-infected cells in vitro. V is conserved in transmitted/founder HIV-1s and primate lentiviruses, which are evolutionarily related to HIV-1. Here, we show that V causes G2 cycle arrest and apoptosis in proliferating CCR+ CD+ T cells, mainly consisting of regulatory T cells (Tregs), resulting in T depletion and enhanced virus production during acute infection. V-dependent replication and T depletion are observed in C5-tropic but not CX4ropic HIV-1-infected mice, suggesting these are dependent on coreceptor by HIV-1. Immune is observed in C5ropic wild-type but V-deficient HIV-1-infected humanized mice. When mice were treated with denileuk difoxin (DD) to deplete Tregs, DD-treated mice showed activation/proliferation of memory cells compared to untreated. This activation/proifer enhanced C5 in memory CD+ cells and rendered them more susceptible to5ropic wild-type HIV-1 than V-deficient virus. These results suggest V takes advantage of proliferating C5 CD+ cells enhancing viremia5ropic HIV-1. Tregs exist in higher state than other subsets T, appear more vulnerable to V during HIV-1 infection.
Malaria was eliminated in South Korea in the late 1970s, but re-emerged in 1993. To control malaria and evaluate the effectiveness of controls, it is important to understand the genetic structure of the parasite. We analyzed microsatellite markers of the P. viv genome from 163 isolates collected 199 to 2008. We used 14 microsatellite loci to analyze linkage disequilibrium ( LD ), genetic differentiation, and population structure to estimate temporal change in the parasite. The analysis showed a decrease in LD and genetic differentiation between successive years. The population structure based on Bayesian suggested a drastic change in Korea during 200 and 200. Although relapse and asymptomatic carriage might influence the structure, our results suggested continual introduction of P. viv into Korea through other sources. One source, particularly 200 and 200, is Korea.
Transcription by a splicing-competent introns is an evolutionarily conserved feature among eukaryotes. We show that the intron is an important regulator of promoter direction. In the presence of an intr, transcription of mRNA is favored over upstream antisense transcripts (uaRNA) initiating from the promoter. Mutation of the 5′ or 3′ splice site results in reversal of promoter direction, suggesting it is not the 5′ splice site but the entire splicing-competent intr that regulates direction. ChIP analysis reveals recruitment of termination factors near the promoter in presence of intr. Removal of intr or mutation of splice sites affects localization of termination factors. The intr-mediated enhancement of transcription is dependent on gene looping. We show that looping is crucial for recruitment of termination factors in promoter-prox region of intr-containing gene. In looping-defective, despite splicing, promoter factors for poly (A)-dependent termination are compromised. This is accompanied by loss of direction.
Domestic pigs carrying a single nucleotide mutation in the intron 3 of the IGF2 gene exhibit a 3-fold upregulation of IGF expression in skeletal muscle. This results in major effects on muscle size, heart, and fat deposition. We have identified the repressor of IGF expression and named ZBED, a novel transcription factor previously unknown in placental mammals. ZBED is derived from an exapted DNA transposon. Silencing Zbed in mouse C2C myoblasts affects Igf expression, cell proliferation, wound healing, and myotube formation. Chromatin immunoprecipitation ( ChIP ) using C2C cells identified 2,500 ZBED binding sites in the genome. The deduced consensus motif matches the established site in IGF. Genes associated with ZBED sites show significant enrichment for Gene Ontology classifications including development and transcription.
The RNA editome of the rhesus macaque, a close relative of human, has been comprehensively characterized by combining genome and transcriptome sequencing of multiple tissues from the same animal. We identified 31, 250 editing sites, of which 99. 8% are A-to-G transitions. We verified 96. 6% of sites in coding regions and 97. 5% in non-coding regions by multiple means, demonstrating the feasibility of our paradigm. We found that adenosine deamination is associated with the mac editome, with A-to-G sites flanked by ADAR substrates, and the context and expression of ADs are relevant in determining the variance of editing across sites and tissue types. We detected decreased divergence around editing sites, suggesting evolutionary constraint in maintaining these substrates with double-stranded structure.
Perceptual bias reveals suboptimal population decoding of sensory responses in two-altern visual discrimination tasks. In these tasks, observers integrate noisy neural responses into a more reliable representation of the likelihood that the stimuli under consideration evoked the observed responses. Importantly, an ideal observer should be able to evaluate likelihood with high precision and only the likelihood of the relevant stimuli involved in the discrimination. We report a perceptual bias suggesting that observers read the likelihood with remarkably low precision when discriminating spatial frequencies. Using spectrally filtered noise, we induced asymmetry in the likelihood of spatial frequency. This mainly affects the likelihood of spatial that are irrelevant to the task. Nevertheless, we find a significant in grating frequency, that observers evaluate likelihood of a range of irrelevant and discard knowledge of stimulus when performing two-altern discrimination.
Piwi-interacting RNAs (piRNAs) play a conserved role in defending the genome against foreign genetic elements. In C. elegans, piRNAs are derived from a long polycistronic RNA. Here, we show that C. elegans piRNA is a tiny, autonomous transcriptional unit. The minimal C. eleg piRNA cassette requires a 21 nucleotide (nt) piRNA and ∼50nt upstream motif with limited genomic context for expression. We demonstrate that this motif is necessary for expression of gerine-enriched, Pi-dependent piRNA. We show that a single nucleotide within this motif directs gerine enrichment. Over 70% of C eleg piRNAs are selectively expressed in male or female gerine and comparison of their targets suggests they have evolved independently. Our results indicate that C eleg piRNA motifs act as promoters to specify which sequences are piRNAs, how abundantly they are expressed, and in gerine.
Brucella species replicate within host cells in the form of endoplasmic reticulum (ER)-derived vacuoles. During Bruc infection, the IRE pathway of the unfolded protein response (UPR) is activated in a time-dependent manner, while the PER and ATF pathways are not activated. This is accompanied by the upregulation of COPI vesicle components Sar, Sec23, and Sec24. We identified a novel host factor, YipA, responsible for activation of the IRE pathway in response to tunicamycin treatment and Bruc infection. YA is responsible for phosphorylation of IRE through high-order assembly of Ire molecules at ER exit sites (RES) under UPR conditions. InipA-knockdown cells Bruc fail to generate ER-derived vacoles and remain in endosomal/lysosomal compartments. These results indicate that activation of theRE pathway and formation of ER-derived vacoles are critical foruc to establish a safe niche, and is indispensable for these processes.
Tomato bushy stunt virus (TBSV) and carnation Italian ringspot virus (CV) are positive-strand RNA viruses that depend on host factors and cellular pathways to support replication. We show that both viruses recruit the cellular V34 phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) into the viral replication compartment. The function of V34 is critical for TV replication, suggesting that PI3 phosphoinoside is utilized by TV to build the replication compartment. We observed increased expression of V34 and higher abundance of PI3 in the presence of tombusiral proteins, leading to efficient TV replication. Overexpression of PI phosphatase in yeast or plants inhibited TV replication on peroxomal membranes and CV on mitochondrial membranes. Moreover, purified phosphatase reduced TV assembly in a cell-free system. Detection of PI with antibody or probe revealed enrichment of PI in replication compartment. V34 is recruited into replication through interaction with p33 protein. Gene analysis in yeast unraveled that TV requires vesicle function of34. In absence of34, TV cannot efficiently recruit Rab-positive endosomes which provide PE-rich membranes for TV compartment biogenesis. We found V34 and PI needed for stability of33 protein which is degraded by 26 proteasome when PI abundance was decreased by inhibitor34.
Dengue virus (DENV) transmission from humans to mosquitoes represents a critical component of deng epidemiology. However, examinations of this process have been hampered by a lack of methods that adequately represent natural acquisition of DENV by mosquitoes. In this study, we assessed artificial and natural feeding based rates of DENV infection and dissemination within mosquitoes for use in field-based epidemiological study in Iqu, Peru. Participants 5 years and older with 5 days of fever were enrolled from clinic and neighborhood studies deng in Iqu. Wild, laboratory Aedes aegypt mosquitoes were fed on febrile individuals or blood collected that was untreated or treated with EDTA. Mosquitoes were tested after days of extrinsic incubation for D infection and dissemination. A total 58 participants with virem ranging 1.3 ×102 to 2.9 ×106 per mL participated one or more methods. DENV and dissemination rates were not different following direct and indirect-ED feeding; however, they were lower for that fed on blood no additive. Relative direct infection rates showed greater indirect-ED than indirect-no feeding. Dissemination rates were across all methods. No differences in D or dissemination in fed participants with different deng illness. Our study demonstrates direct and indirect methods for field studies vector. Direct is preferable in terms of ease, security, and reliability.
Topoisomerase II poisons are a class of chemotherapeutic drugs that target the enzyme topoisomerase II, which is involved in DNA replication and transcription. However, patients vary in their response to these drugs, and the causes of this variability are not well understood. Here, we show that the nematode Caenorhabitis elegans varies in its sensitivity to topois II poisons, and use an unbiased approach to demonstrate that this variation is due to a single amino acid substitution in topomerase II (TOP-2). We show that the presence of a non-polar methion at this residue increases hydrophobic interactions between TOP-2 and etoposide, compared to a polar glutamine. This results in increased genomic instability in strains that contain methion. The affected residue is conserved from yeast to humans and is one of the few differences between human topomerase isoforms (methion in hTOIα and glut in hIβ). We show that this difference influences cytotoxicity of topois poisons in human cell lines.
Long-lived rodents, such as naked mole-rats, have life expectancies that are multiple times higher than those of their phylogenetically closely related short-lived rodents. To gain insights into the genetic mechanisms determining mammalian lifespan, we obtained genomic and transcriptomic data from 17 rodent species and scanned for evolutionary branches associated with the evolution of longevity. We identified 250 positively selected genes (PSGs ) in the liver of long-lived naked-rats and short-lived rats that fit the antagonistic pleiotropy theory of aging. PSGs were enriched for genes related to cellular respiration, ion homeostasis, as well as processes regulated by the mTOR pathway: translation, autophagy and inflammation. PSGs included RHE, a regulator of mTOR, IGF, central components of aging-relevant pathways, as well as genes unknown to be aging but convincing candidates, e. g. RBL,HR,SM1PG andGER. Exempl protein modeling suggests functional consequences for amino changes under selection.
Aedes albopictus is a major vector of several important arboviruses, including chikungunya, dengue and Zika. The endosymbion Wolbach is a bacterium that can be used to induce sterility in Ae. albictus and reduce its vector competence. In this study, a new Ae. albict line ( ARP-M ) was generated by introducing wMel Wolbach in the ARP line, which had previously been established by replacing wAlA and wB Wolbach with wip. The infection and fitness of ARP, ARP and wild-type Ae. albict were compared. AR-M showed 100% maternal inheritance of w and wip Wolbach. Survival, fecundity and fertility did not differ between Ae. albict lines. Crosses between AR-M males and wild Ae alb females were unfertile regardless of male age, while egg hatch increased from 0 to 17% with wild males from 3 to 17 days. When competing with wild males for females, AR-M induced sterility higher than expected ( Fried index 1.71 instead of 1. Wolbach density in AR females was about 15 fold higher than AR, mostly due w infection. This corresponded to reduced competence for chikunya andeng viruses (5 and 0% transmission at 14 and 21 post ) with AR females.
Many biological responses to intra- and extracellular stimuli are regulated by complex networks of transient protein-protein interactions, where a globular domains of one protein recognize linear peptides from another at a relatively small interface. These peptide stretches are often found in unstructured regions of proteins and contain a consensus motif complementary to the surface of their binding partners. Current methods for de novo discovery of motifs exploit their tendency to occur in disordered regions, but our work focuses on another observation: upon binding to their partner, motifs adopt a well-defined structure. We analyzed peptide-mediated interactions of known high-resolution 3D structures and found that the structure of the peptide may be characteristic of the consensus, helping to identify peptides that do not match established patterns. Motifs tend to have a stretched and elongated structure unlike other peptides of same length. We implemented a strategy based on Support Vector Machine that uses these features along with structure-encoded information about interfaces to search known 3D protein interactions and identify peptide-mediated among them. We also derived consensus for interactions whenever information available and compared with linear patterns and domains. Finally, we cross-validated our strategy by scanning interactomes of four organisms with derived to see if any occurred more expected. We found significant overrepresentations for 64-motif interactions, 46 not described, involving 6,000 interactions.
Environmental enteropathy (EE) is a condition associated with malabsorption of micronutrients and impaired responses to oral vaccines. We studied 49 adults with EE in Zambia using confocal endomicroscopy (CLE), histology, immunohistochemistry, and mRNA sequencing of intestinal biopsies. We correlated these with plasma lipopolyscharide (LPS) and zinc uptake. CLE images showed small intestinal epithelial defects at the tips of villi. Histology and claudin immunostaining corresponded with CLE images. Circulating LPS was correlated with shedding (β=0.83; P=0.035) and serum glucagon-like peptide-2 (β=-0.13;P=0.007). Zinc uptake was attenuated in 30/47 (64%) and reduced by HIV but correlated with GLP-2 (β=2.72;P=0.03). There was a U-shaped relationship between L and villus area. Transcript analysis identified 23 differentially expressed genes in EE, including peptides and proteins.
Viral superinfection is the process by which a virus infects a host cell that is already infected by the same or a similar virus. This is a common phenomenon that is not well understood. Here, we show that superinfection of turnip crinkle virus (TCV) is blocked by p28, one of the two proteins encoded by this virus. p28 is expressed from the TCV genome and blocks superinfection by a different TCV replicon. When p28 is expressed transiently delivered with or ahead of TCV replicon, it recapitulates this blocking activity. p28-mediated superin is enhanced by C-terminal epitope tags but weakened by N-terminal modifications and inversely correlates with p28 ability to complement p-defective TCV replic. Strikingly, p28-positive cells form large punctate inclusions that transaggregate non-superfective yet replication-compet p mutant. These results support a model that TCV superinfection is caused by p28 multimer formation capable of intercepting fresh p monomers from superector genomes, abolishing superector. This model could be applicable to other RNA viruses and offer novel antiviral targets.
Immunization of mice with the Trypanosoma cruzi transsialase (TS) gene using a plasmid DNA adenoviral vector and CpG-adjuanted protein has proven to be highly immunogenic and protective against acute lethal challenge. However, long-term protection by TS vaccines has not been reported. Here, we tested whether co-administration of plasm encoding IL-15 (pIL-15) could improve the duration of protection achieved by genetic vaccination with plasm encoding TS (pTS) alone. We immunized BALB mice with TS in the presence or absence of IL-15 and studied immune responses with TS-specific IF-γ ELISA, serum IgG ELISA, intracellular cytokine staining IF-γ, TN-α and IL-2, tetramer staining and CF dilution assays and protection against lethal challenge at 1 to 6 months post-vaccination. Mice receiving TS alone developed TS-specific IFγ responses and survived lethal challenge within first 3 months following immunization. Addition of IL to TS vaccination did not significantly alter T responses or protection during early postacc period. However, mice with TS and IL challenged 6 postacc were more protected against lethal T cruzi than TS alone (P0. 05). Improved protection correlated with higher TS-specific IFγ producing and CD+ T cells detected postimmunization Also, TS-specific T were better expand in vitro-stimulation. Addition IL during vaccination greatly improved long T survival cell, T expansion and long-term against important parasite T cruzi.
Trypanosoma brucei is a parasitic protozoan that causes sleeping sickness in humans and nagana in animals. It has a complex life cycle with two stages in the mammalian host and insect vector. The flagellum and basal body are essential for its motility and infectivity. Here, we show that the Cullin-RING ubiquitin ligase composed of Cull4, the DNA-binding protein 1 homolog TbDB1 and the WD-repeat protein WDR controls the abundance of the Polo-like kinase TbK in the flagum and basal. WDR binds to TbK through its C-terminal PEST motif and to TbDB1 through its N-terminal WD motif. Depletion of WDR inhibits flagum duplication and basal segregation, disrupts the new flagum attachment filament and detaches the new flagum. Consistent with its role in TbK degradation, WDR depletion causes accumulation of TbK in the flag and basal, leading to phosphorylation of Cent2 in the flag at late cycle stages.
The DEAD-box helicase DDX3 plays a crucial role in the innate immune system as a mediator of antimicrobial immunity. We show that the sex-specific isoforms of DDX3 are important in the immune system. Mice lacking DDX3 have an altered leukocyte composition in bone marrow and spleen and are unable to combat Listeria monocytogenes infection. This results from decreased effector cell availability and impaired cytokine synthesis. Our data provide further evidence for a non-RIG-like helicase contribution to innate immunity and suggest it may contribute to sex differences in resistance to microbes and inflammatory disease.
A computational model of the insect pherone transduction cascade in the male moth olfactory neuron is presented. The model takes into account all pre-effector processes, including pherone translocation from air to sensillum, deactivation and interaction with receptors, and G-protein effector activation, and focuses on post-effector processes. These involve production and degradation of second messengers ( IP3 and DAG ), opening and closing of ionic channels ( IP-gated Ca2+, DAGated cation, Ca+-gated Cl−, and Ca+-voltage K+ ), and Ca+ extrusion. The network is regulated by modulators ( kinase and Ca+-modulin ) that exert inhibition on effector channels. The evolution of chemical species and currents and membrane response to pulse stimulation of various intensities were simulated. Parameters were fitted by comparison to amplitude and characteristics ( rising and falling ) of experimentally measured receptor at pherone. The model captures features of dose–response: wide range with amplitudes as experimental, short rising, and long. It also reproduces second kinetics.
Doxorubicin (DX)-treated human lymphoblast cells were used to elucidate how p53 sequences and chromatin interact to affect p53 binding and transactivation. We mapped p53 and H3K4me3 genome-wide binding in untreated and DX-treated cells and examined the relationships among p53 occupancy, gene expression, H3K4, chromatin accessibility (DNase hypersensitivity DHS ), EN chrom states, pRE, and evolutionary conservation. Inducible p53-regulated genes were associated with steady chromatin status. Highly inducible p-regulated genes were suppressed at baseline and marked by repressive histone modifications or CTC binding. pREs residing in different chrom contexts were compared: weaker pREs were in promoters, stronger pRE in enhancers and repressed chrom. p occupancy was correlated with similarity to pRE consensus but inversely correlated with DHS and conservation at pRE. Occupancy of pRE that overlapped transposable element (TE) repeats was higher and correlated with stronger pRE relative to non-associated pRE. Occupied pRE in L-like TEs were unique displaying negative Phylo scores and associated with altered H3me and DHS.
Synthetic biology aims to design and reengineer biological systems, with most efforts focused on transcriptional circuits. However, reengineering signaling circuits is hampered by limited understanding of their dynamics and experimental challenges. Bacterial two-component systems offer a rich diversity of sensory systems that are built around a phosphotransfer reaction between histidine kinases and response regulators, and are a good target for reengineering. Here, we explore the signal-response arising from a motif in two-component signaling. In this motif, a histidine ( HK ) phosphotfers reversibly to separate response ( RR ) proteins. We show that this motif allows rapid signal termination, whereby one RR acts as a sink towards the other ( i. e. the output ) and implements a sigmoidal signal relationship. We identify conditions on parameters that are necessary for sigmoid relationships and define parameters that control levels and sensitivity of the curve. We confirm findings by reconstitution of the HK RR motif in Sinorhizium meli chemaxis and measuring the resulting curve. We find that level of sigmoid in this can be controlled by the presence of RR and an auxiliary that binds HK ( Hill coefficients above ).
Single-cell RNA sequencing is used to quantify transcript heterogeneity in Saccharomyces cerevisiae cells treated with and without salt to explore population variation and identify cellular covariates that influence the stress transcriptome. We found significant variation in individual cells, both before and after stress. A subset of cells decouples expression of ribosomal genes from the stress response in a manner correlated with cell cycle but unrelated to yeast metabolic cycle. Live-cell imaging of cells expressing fluorescent regulators, including transcription factor Msn2 with Dot, Sfp, or kinase Hog, revealed coordinated and decoupled nucleoplasmic shuttling.
Trypanosoma brucei, the parasite responsible for African trypanosomiasis, accumulates in large numbers in various organs and tissues, including the male reproductive organs of mice. We show that parasites can be detected in the male reproductive system by fine needle aspiration cytology. Histological analysis reveals that T. brucei accumulates in the stroma of the epididymis, epididymal adipose tissue and fibrous tunics of the testis, but not in the lumen of epididymal ducts or semiferous tubules of the test. This indicates that the majority of parasites are not located in immune-privileged sites. Instead, parasites are associated with inflammatory cell infiltration, degeneration and tissue rupture of epididymal ducts, which may be related to reduced fertility. Overall, T. bruce is exposed to a strong immune response in the male organs, similar to the bloodstream and other tissues.
In Drosophila melanogaster, chemosensation is critical for survival and is mediated by large families of chemoreceptor proteins whose expression must be appropriately tuned to changes in the chemical environment. We investigated whether expression of chemoreceptor genes that are clustered in the genome would be regulated independently, whether expression of chemceptor genes would be especially sensitive to environmental changes, whether groups of chemceptor genes undergo coordinated expression and how plasticity of chemore genes would be with regard to sex, development, reproductive state and social. We used Drosila melanogaster because chemosens systems are well characterized and the genotype environment can be controlled.
Meiotic Recombination in Human Oocytes  
Meiotic recombination in human oocytes is associated with nondisjunction at maternal meiosis I or II. Studies of trisomies indicate that failure to recombine or recombination events near or far from centromeres are linked to origin of trisomies. Immunofluorescence can identify abnormal crossover configurations. We studied crossover proteins ( e. g. ML1 ) in human oocytes to analyze nondjunctionone chromosomes and characterize genome-wide recombination. Our analyses indicate ML1 foci are lower than predicted, but pattern conforms to crossover protein. In individual chromosomes, we provide evidence for “vulnerable” crossover in oocyte, consistent with nondjunction in adult.
Many vector-borne diseases, such as malaria, leishmaniasis, and arboviral fever, are transmitted by blood-feeding arthropods like mosquitoes, sand flies, and ticks. These arthropods inject saliva containing immunogenic compounds that facilitate feeding. The immune response elicited by pre-exposure to arthrop saliva can alter disease progression if the host later becomes infected. Such preensitisation of the host has been reported to both exacerbate and limit symptoms depending on the system in question, with implications for recovery. We develop a general model of vectororne disease to explore how preensit alters the effects of control. We show that the abundance of preensised hosts increases when control moderately increases vector mortality. If preensit leads to rapid clearance of infection, increasing mortality may achieve greater than expected control. However, preit prolongs the duration of infection, e. g., through symptomatic cases unlikely to be treated, control can increase the number of infected. Infections may go unnoticed unless active surveillance is used to detect subclinical individuals who provide long reservoirs for transmission and suffer long-term consequences of subclinical infections.
Leishmanias is an important disease that affects 12 million people in 88 countries, with 2 million new cases every year. Leishmania amazonensis is an important in Brazil, leading to clinical forms varying from localized ( L ) to diffuse cutaneous leishiasis ( D ). In this study, we investigated the effect of host immune response on Leish phenotype and virulence. We compared proteomes of amastigotes from BAL/c and BAL nude mice. athymic nude mice resemble patients with diffuse cutaneous leishias, considered T-cell hyposensitive to Leish antigens. We identified 44 differentially expressed proteins, including those related to oxidative/nitrosive stress and proteases, and known virulence factors such as oligopeptase and tryparedin peroxidase. Specific isoforms of these proteins were increased in parasites from nude mice, suggesting T cells restrain postl modifications in BAL mice. On the other hand, an iso of H70 was increased amast from BAL mice. Our study may allow identification of virulence factors and ways regulating expression.
AID (Activation-Induced Deaminase) is an enzyme that initiates immunoglobulin gene diversification by deaminating cytosines in DNA and reprogramming CpG methylation in early development. However, AID is highly mutagenic and causes genomic instability and translocations in B cell malignancies. Here, we show that AID is cell cycle regulated. Using high content microscopy, we demonstrate that AID is degraded more slowly in G1 phase than in S or G2/M phase, and that mutations affecting phosphorylation or catalytic activity alter A stability and abundance. We directly test the role of cell regulation by fusing A to tags that destabilize protein outside G1 or S2 phases. We show that nuclear localization of A in G1 accelerates somatic hypermutation and class recombination and is tolerated, while A in S2 phase compromises viability. We identify A derivatives that accelerate hypermutation with minimal impact on viability, useful for engineering iterative mutagenesis and selection.
Microbial degradation of plant polysaccharides is an important for carbon cycling, nutrition, and industrial processes based on cellulosic bioconversion. Here, we describe a broadly applicable method to analyze how microbes degrade plant polysacides that integrates carbohydrate-active (CAzyme) assays, RNA sequencing (RNA-seq), and anaerobic screening. We apply this method to study the bacterium Clostridium phyfermentans, which ferments biomass components including glucans, mannans, xylans, galact, pect, and arabin. These polysacides are fermented with variable efficiencies and diaux prioritize metabolism of preferred substrates. Strand RNA-seq reveals how this bacter responds to polysides by upregulating groups of CAymes, transporters and enzymes to metabolize constituent sugars. Fifty CAymes were purified and their activities show polysides are degraded by multiple enzymes, often from same family but divergent specificities and localizations. CAymes were tested in combination to identify synergies between enzymes on same substrate different catalytic mechanisms.
In Sierra Leone, onchocerciasis was endemic in 12 of 14 health districts (HDs) and lymphatic filariasis (LF) was endemic in all 14 districts between 2005–2008. Three annual mass drug administrations (MDAs) were conducted in the 12 endemic districts between 2008–2010 with good geographic and drug coverage. A mid-term assessment was conducted in 201 to determine the impact of MDAs on LF in these districts. The prevalence of microfilariae (mf) in the 12 districts was determined using the thick film method and compared with baseline data from 200–2008. Overall mf prevalence fell from 2.6% (95% CI 2.3–3.0 ) to 0.3 (95% CI 0.19–.47 ), a decrease of 88.5% (p=0.000 ); prevalence was 0.0 (100.0% ) in four districts: Bo, Moyamba, Kenema and Kono (p=.001.025.085.000 ) and seven districts had reductions in mf prevalence between 70.0 and 95.0 (p=.000.060.001.014.000..002 Bombali Bonthe Kail Kambia Kadugu Portokolili respectively. Pehun had baseline prevalence 0.0 which was maintained. Bomb still had mf ≥1.0 (.58.80–.09 ) and was the district with highest baseline 6.9 (95 CI5.–8.8 ). Overall mean mf after MD was 17 mf/ml (95 CI 15–19/ml ) among mf individuals 65.4 from baseline 50/ml (95 CI40–61/ml; p=.001 ) and 0/ml (95 CI0–08 ) for entire population 96.2 from 1/ml (95 CI1–1; p=.000 ).
Many high-throughput sequencing techniques, such as 16S rRNA profiling, have the potential to elucidate the inner workings of microbial communities. A key step in exploring such data is the identification of dependencies between community members, which is commonly achieved by correlation analysis. However, compositional data generated by such techniques can produce unreliable results since they take the form of relative fractions rather than absolute abundances. We show that compositional effects can be widespread and severe: many correlations can be artifactual and true correlations may appear opposite. Community diversity modulates the acuteness of such effects. We develop a new approach, Spar, capable of estimating correlation from compositional data. Using Spar, we infer a rich network connecting hundreds of species across the human body. The standard approach yields 3 spurious species interactions and misses 60% of true interactions in the human microbiome. Most erroneous links are found in samples with lowest diversity.
Streptococcus pneumoniae colonizes the upper respiratory tract by evading the antimicrobial effects of lysozym, a mucosal enzyme that hydrolyzes peptoglycans. Lyso has both muridase and antimicrobial activities. We show that the antimicrobial effect of lyzym is due to its muridase activity and that peptogly modifications are required for pneumoc resistance to lyzym in vitro. To examine the contribution of lyzym and peog modifications during colonization, we competed wild-type and pgAadr mutant pneumocci in lysoe-sufficient (LM+) and -deficient (LM−) mice. The wild-type outcompeted the mutant in LM+, but not LM− mice, indicating the importance of resistance to lyzym murid activity during mucosal colonization. In contrast, strains containing single mutations in pgA or Adr prevailed over the wild-type in LM+ and LM− mice. Our findings demonstrate that peog modifications diminish fitness during colonization. The competitive advantage of wild pneumocci in LM+ but not LM− mice suggests that the combination of peog modifications reduces fitness, but is outweighed by the benefits of resistance to peog degrading lyzym activity.
Dengue is the most important arthropod borne viral disease in the world in terms of morbidity and mortality. It is caused by any of the four serotypes of deng virus (DENV-1 to 4). Brazil is responsible for approximately 80% of deng cases in the Americas. Since the introduction of deng in 1986, a total 5, 944, 270 cases have been reported, including 21,596 deng hemorrhagic and 874 fatal. The goal of this study was to investigate the usefulness of NS1 capture as an alternative to detect DENV in tissue from previously deng fatal cases (n=23) that occurred in 200 in Brazil. A total 74 tissue specimens were available: liver (n=23), lung (n=14), kidney (n=4), brain (n=10), heart (n=2, skin (n=1, spleen (n=15, thym (n=3 and lymph (n=2. We evaluated three tests for NS1 capture: Deng Early ELISA (Pan Diagnostics), Platelia NS (Bio Laboratories) and the test NS1 Strip (Bio Laboratories). Overall deng fatal diagnosis based on tissues by Deng ELISA, Platelia and NS Strip was 34.7% (8/23), 60.8% (14) and 91.% (21, respectively. Deng ELISA detected NS1 in 22.9% (17) of specimens and Platelia in 45.% (34. The highest sensitivity 78.% was achieved by Strip and differences in sensitivities were statistically (p0.05. Strip was most in liver 91. (21, lung 71. (10, kidney 100 (4, brain 80 (8, spleen 66 (10 and thym 100. This study shows DENV1 capture as rapid approach to postmortemeng confirmation.
Multiple myeloma (MM) is a plasma cell malignancy with significantly higher incidence and mortality rates among African Americans (AA) compared to Caucasians (CA). This study aimed to elucidate differences in molecular alterations in MM as a function of self-reported race and genetic ancestry. We utilized somatic whole-exome RNA-sequencing and clinical data from 718 MM patients in the Multiple Myeloma Research CoPass Interim Analysis 9. Somatic mutational analyses based on self-reported race corrected for ancestry revealed significant differences in mutation frequencies between groups of interest. BCL2A, BR3 and AUT2 demonstrated higher mutation frequencies among AA cases. These genes are involved in translocations in B-cell malignancies. Moreover, we detected a difference in mutation frequency of TP53 and IR4 with higher among CA cases.
Most mutations in the exome of cancer cells are passengers, which do not affect the reproductive rate of the cell. Passengers provide important information about the history of an individual cancer and serve as molecular clock. Passengers also become targets for immunotherapy or confer resistance to treatment. We study the expansion of a population of cancer cells describing the growth of primary or metastatic lesions. We analyze the process looking forward in time and calculate the probabilities and frequencies of successive mutations ordered by time of appearance. We compute the likelihood of evolutionary trees informing phylogenetic reconstruction of cancer in individual. Next, we derive looking backward for a subclonal we estimate the number of cells present when mutation arose. We derive formulas for subcl of any frequency. Fitting to data leads to estimate of birth and death during early stages.
Polyglutamine (Q) expansion in exon 1 (X1) of the huntingtin protein is linked to Huntington’s disease. When the number of glutamines exceeds a threshold of approximately 36–40, X1 can form amyloid aggregates similar to those associated with the disease. The misfolding of monomeric X1 plays an important role in length-dependent aggregation. To elucidate the misolding of X1 can determine the molecular mechanism of X aggregation and help develop strategies to inhibit X aggregation. The flanking sequences surrounding the Q region play a role in determining structural rearrangement and aggregation of X. We perform molecular simulations on monomeric X with full flanking regions, variant missing polyline regions hypothesized to prevent aggregation and isolated Q. For each we study glutamine lengths 23, 36, 40 and 47. We find Q peptides have positive correlation between probability to form β-rich state and expansion. The flanking of X affect probability to form β state compared isolated Q. Particularly, polyline regions form helices decrease probability Q to β state. By length Q, first-terminal residues more likely adopt conformation rather conformation.
The CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Palindromic Repeats) loci, together with CRIS-associated genes, form the CRIS/Cas adaptive immune system, a defense strategy used by bacteria and archaea to protect against foreign nucleic acids, including phages and conjugative plasmids. CRIS loci consist of short spacer sequences separated by repeats derived from foreign DNA that direct interference future infections. The availability of hundreds of shotgun metagenomic datasets from the Human Microbiome Project (HMP) enables us to explore the distribution and diversity of CRPRs in human-associated microbial communities and discover new CRs. We propose a targeted strategy to reconstruct CRPR arrays that whole-genome assemblies fail to identify. For each CR type identified from reference genomes, we use its repeat sequence to recruit reads from HMP and assemble into CR loci; unique spacers can be extracted for analysis. We identified novel CRs in whole-genome assemblies and targeted to comprehensively identify CRs across samples. CRs are largely body-site specific. We provide analysis of CR loci, including novel CRs. For example, streptoc CRs were identified in oral microbiota, ∼8,000 spacers; samples from same site shared most spacers; different sites from same shared fewer, while individuals almost no sp, indicating niche differences on CR defenses. We demonstrate CR to trace species and virus exposure. This work indicates importance of CR to study microbiome ecology.
Most organisms have an endogenous circadian clock that is synchronized to environmental signals such as light and temperature. Although circadian rhythms have been described in the nematode Caenorhabdis elegans at the behavioral level, these appear to be relatively non-robust. Moreover, in contrast to other models, circadian transcriptional rhythms have not been identified. Thus, whether this organism contains a bona fide circadian remains an open. Here we use genome-wide profiling to identify light and temperature-entrained transcripts in C. elegans. These exhibit rhythmic expression with temperature-compens 24 periods. In addition, expression is sustained under constant, suggesting they are circadian regulated.
The Saccharomyces cerevisae RAD3 gene is a homolog of the human XPD gene, which encodes a DNA helicase of the TFIIH complex involved in nucleotide excision repair (NER) and transcription. Mutations in the RAD3 gene, such as rad-101 and rad-102, result in defects in DNA repair and a hyper-recombination (hyper-Rec) phenotype. Previous studies showed that the hyper-Rec phenotype of rad-101 and rad-102 can be explained by persistent single-stranded DNA gaps converted to recombinogenic double-strand breaks (DSBs) by replication. We further characterized the hyperRec phenotype of rad strains using a system that recovers reciprocal products of mitotic recombination. Both rad-101 and rad-102 elevate the frequency of reciprocal crossovers about 100-fold. We mapped these events and found that three-quarters of crosso reflect DS formed at same positions in sister chromatids (double-chromat breaks, DSBs). The remainder reflect DS formed in chromatids (singleid breaks SCBs). The ratio DSBs to SC is similar to observed for spontaneous events in wild-type cells.
Helicobacter pylori is a gastric pathogen that requires optimal expression of virulence factors to adapt to the changing host environment during persistent infection. The bacterium has a large number of simple sequence repeats (SSRs) that generate heterogeneous populations through slipped mispairing, facilitating adaptation. We present a model explaining how an intergenic SSR, via slipped mispair, operates as a rheostat to fine-tune expression of the sialic acid binding adhesin (SabA) promoter. Using Ttract variants in an isogenic strain, we show that SSR length generates multiphas output from sab promoter. This alters H. pylori binding to sial-Lewis receptors on gastric mucosa. Analysis of post-infection clones shows SSR length is highly variable in H. pylori. This mirrors host-pathogen interplay where bacterium generates clones with best-fit phenotypes selected in host. In silico and in vitro analyses show SSR length affects DNA structure and RNA polymerase binding through axial alignment between promoter and UP elements. We identified additional H. pyl genes with SSR similar to sab, and variations likewise modulate cognate output. We propose this mechanism mediated by promoter-prox SSR provides alternative transcriptional regulation in bacteria with limited transacting factors.
Human papillomavirus (HPV) must evade the innate immune response to establish persistent infections and amplify its genome upon epithelial differentiation. The JAK/STAT pathway is important for the innate response and HPV downregulates STAT1 to maintain viral episomes. STAT5 is another member that modulates the inflammatory response and controls cell cycle in response to cytokines and growth factors. Our studies show that HPV7 activates STAT5 phosphorylation without altering total levels. Inhibition of STAT5 phosphorylation by pimide abolishes genome amplification and late expression in differentiating keratinocytes. In contrast, undifferentiated that maintain episomes has no effect on replication. Knockdown show STAT5 isoform is mainly responsible and this is mediated through ATM damage. A downstream STAT5, peroxisomeactivated receptor (PARγ) contributes ATM pathway members.
Salmonella enterica serotype Typhi is a bacterium that can colonize and persist in the biliary tract of infected individuals, resulting in a state of asymptomatic chronic carriage. Chronic carriers may act as persistent reservoirs of infection within a community and may introduce infection to susceptible individuals and communities. Little is known about the interaction between the host and pathogen in the biliary of chronic carriers and there is currently no reliable assay to identify asymptomatic S. Typhi carriage. To study host-pathogen in the biliary during S. Ty carriage, we applied immunoscreen technique called in vivo-induced antigen technology (IVAT), to identify biomarkers unique to carriers.IV identifies humorally immunogenic antigens expressed uniquely in vivo, we hypothesized S Ty surviving the biliary of humans may a distinct antigen profile. Thirteen S Ty antigens were immunactive in carriers but not in healthy from tyoid endemic were identified. The antigens included number of putative proteins, liproteins and hemys-related.nc (ST147), uncharacter protein an ATP-binding gave responses in our screen The response in patients biliary contained Ty was compared responses patients biliary did not Ty, patients tyoid fever and healthy tyoid endemic. Seven (70%) carriers, (0%), (0%), (0%) and (12.5%) had detectable-YE Ig blood. Ig were also present Further evaluation and other antigens identified IV could lead improved assays identify asymptomatic Typhi.
Transcriptional Reactivation of Silenced Genes: A New Epigenetic Phenomenon Revealed by Homologous RNA.
Boophil is a multifunctional serine protease inhibitor expressed in the midgut of the tick Rhipphalus microplus, a vector of Babesiosis. It targets thrombin, elastase, and kallikrein, enzymes involved in the coagulation and complement cascades. Boophil was expressed in HEK cells and purified to homogeneity. Using amidolytic assays and surface plasmon resonance experiments, we demonstrated that Boophil behaves as a classical noncompetitive inhibitor of thrombin with respect to chromogenic substrates by a mechanism dependent on both exosite and catalytic sites. Inhibition is accompanied by blockade of platelet aggregation, fibrin formation, and clot formation in vitro. Boophil is also a noncompetitive inhibitor of FXa, preventing FIX activation. In addition, Boophil inhibits kikrein activity and reciprocal activation, indicating it targets the contact pathway. Furthermore, Boophil abates cathepsin G and plmin-induced platelet aggregation and affects elastase cleavage of Tissue Pathway Inhibitor ( TFPI ). Finally, Boophil inhibits carotid occlusion in vivo by FeCl and promotes bleeding in mice.
Inflammation plays a significant role in the pathogenesis of many gastrointestinal diseases and is the most important factor governing the maintenance of mucosal architecture. The mucosa of the intestinal tract is a finely tuned system where structure influences and is influenced by function as an absorptive surface and defensive barrier. Mucosal architecture plays a key role in diagnosis and characterization of pathophysiology of a host of gastrointestinal diseases. We propose that characterization of the role of inflammation as controller of enteric mucosal pattering requires understanding of cellular and molecular dynamics that determine epithelial cryptillus architecture across a range of conditions from health to disease. We have developed the Spatial General-purpose Model of Enteric Tissue (SEMT ) to represent the behavior of enter epithelial tissue influenced by inflammation with ability to generate a variety of pathophysiological processes within a platform and common base. SEMT reproduces healthy mucosal dynamics as well as a series of morph knock-inhibition experiments. SEMT provides insight into clinically relevant cellular-molecular mechanisms such as the role of PTEN/PIK as point of crosstalk between inflammation and morphogenesis, the role of enterocyte slough in enter ischemia-reper and low inflammation as driver of colonic metaplas. SEMT can serve as platform for study of inflammation in gastrointestinal disease.
Aedes aegypti populations are difficult to control using traditional methods such as source reduction and insecticide spraying. Wolbachia, an endosymbion of Ae.egypti, has been proposed as a tool to mitigate arbovirus transmission and has been deployed worldwide. Models predict a rapid increase in frequency of Wolia-positive Ae.egypt in local settings, supported by cytoplasmic incompatibility ( CI ) and high maternal transmission associated with wBr strain. Wolia wBr was released for 20 weeks in Tubanga, Rio de Janeiro, reaching 87% of households. wBr frequency peaked at 65% but dropped as releases stopped. A 97. 56% maternal transmission was observed. Doubling releases and deploying mosquitoes with large length and low mortality produced no effects on trend. By investigating lab procedures, pyreth resistant genotypes wBr decreased from 68 to 3.5% after 17. Initially released mosquitoes were highly resistant to pyre which jeopardized Wolia invasion. A new strain wRio was produced aftercrossing wBr females with field males to introduce pyre resistance. w increased survival but produced negative effects on Aeegypt traits, reducing egg size and hatch. Despite fitness wRio established whereBr failed, revealing matching local genetics, especially insecticide background is critical to invasion.
Poxviruses are complex pathogens that have evolved to modulate cellular defense mechanisms while ensuring proper expression of viral factors. For example, the vaccinia virus B protein plays a role in in inactivating the antiviral factor B and likely orchestrates other pathways. In this study, we generated a B1 deletion virus to search for suppressor mutations and novel pathways involving B. After several passages of the Δ1 virus, we observed a robust increase in titer of the adapted virus. Characterization of the adapted viruses reveals that mutations correlating with loss of function of the vaccinia B pseudokinase provide a fitness enhancement to the virus. We present multiple lines of evidence that expression of full B leads to a reduction in viruses with a defect in B, but no impact on wild-type or other poxviruses. These data suggest that B possesses a potent inhibitory activity masked by the presence of B kinase. Further investigation of B attributes that it localizes to the nucleus, a rare among poxiral proteins. Surprisingly, B phosphorylation is reduced when B is present in cells without B, indicating B may function by enhancing antiral activity of B.
In this study, we use molecular dynamics simulations to analyze the conformation behavior of two synthetic amphipathic peptides, LKKKLLKKLLKL ( L ) and EAAEALAEALAE ( E ), with built-in secondary structure forming an alpha-helix. We find that these peptides are neither random coils in bulk nor fully formed helices, but adopt multiple conformations and secondary elements with short lifetimes. These provide a basis for conformation and population-shift upon environmental changes. Differences in peptides’ response to macroscopic and molecular interfaces presented by aggregation can be linked to their alphaelical tendencies in bulk. We find that peptides’ aggregation is strongly affected by presence or absence of interface and subtly depends on surface and hydrophobicity.
Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) is a ubiquitous betaherpesvirus that infects humans within the first years of life and establishes latency in various cell types. Both HH-6A and HH-6B can integrate their genomes into the telomeres of host chromosomes in latently infected cells. The molecular mechanism of viral integration remains elusive. Interestingly, HH-6 and HH-6 harbor arrays of telomeric repeats (TMR) identical to human telomeres at the ends of their genomes. The HH-6 and HH-6 genomes harbor two TMR, the perfectMR (pMR) and imperfectMR (impMR). To determine if TMR are involved in integration, we deleted pMR and impMR in HH-6 genome. Upon reconstitution, TMR mutant replicated comparable to wild type (wt) virus, indicating T are not essential for HH-6 replication. To assess integration properties of recombinant viruses we established in vitro system that allows assessment of integration and genome in latently infected. Integration HH-6 was impaired in absence of T and virus was rapidly lost, suggesting integration crucial for maintenance of genome. Individual of pMR and impMR revealed pMR play major role in HH6, impMR only minor, allowing to establish model HH6 integration. Taken, data that HH-6 are dispensable for replication but crucial for integration of genome in latently cells.
Poxviruses are a family of enveloped viruses that do not acquire their internal lipid membrane by budding from cellular compartments. Instead, they are generated from crescent-shaped precursors whose architecture and composition are not well understood. Here we report the 2. 6 Å crystal structure of vaccinia virus D13, a key component of the outer scaffold of viral crescents. D13 folds into a jellyroll decorated by a head domain of novel fold and assembles into trimers homologous to double-barrel capsid proteins of adenoviruses and lipid-containing icosahedral viruses. We show that when tethered onto artificial membranes, D forms a honeycomb lattice structurally similar to viral crescent and immature particles. The architecture of the D honeycomb and lipid-remodeling abilities of D support a model that exhibits similarities with mimivirus. Overall, these findings establish that the first step of poxirus morphogenesis utilizes a lipid-remodeling strategy common to icosahedral viruses infecting all kingdoms of life. Furthermore, D is the target of rifampicin and its structure will aid the development of poxirus inhibitors.
In Arabidopsis thalian, auxin biosynthesis via indole-3-pyruvic acid ( IPA ) is essential for root development and requires TRYOPHANIN AMOTANSFER OF ARIDOPSIS ( T1 ) and T1-RELATED ( TAR ) genes. In contrast, the monocot Brachodium distyon ( Brachodium ) has a different auxin biosynthesis pathway. A promoter-DNA insertion in the Brachodium TAR-LIKE ( BdARL ) gene severely downregulates expression, suggesting reduced tryophaninotransfer activity in the mutant, which represents a hypomorphic BdARLhypo allele. However, BdLypo mutants display dramatically elongated seminal roots due to enhanced cell elongation. This phenotype is also observed in a stronger BdL allele and can be mimicked by treating wild type with L-kyunine, a T1/TAR inhibitor. Surprisingly, Lkyine-treated as well as BdL display elevated rather than reduced auxin levels. This does not result from compensation by alternative auxin biosynthesis pathways. Rather, expression of YCCA genes, which are rate-limiting for IPA to auxin conversion, is increased in BdL mutants. Consistent suppression of Bdypo phenotypes upon application of ethylene precursor 1-aminoclopropane-1-carboxylic ( ACC ), YCCA are downregulated upon ACC. Moreover, they are upregulated in downstream ethylene-signaling component homolog, ethylene 2-like 1 which also displays BdL root.
The organization of the promoter region of a gene, known as the nucleosome, has been shown to influence the rate of evolution of gene expression in species of the budding yeast. Genes lacking a nucleosome-free region, denoted as Occupied Proximal Nucleosomes ( OPN), vary widely in expression between species, while those containing nucleosomes, denoted as Depleted Proimalucleosomes (DPN), have largely conserved expression. To examine the role of early evolution in this difference, we artificially selected for high expression of GFP-tagged proteins. Surprisingly, selection was successful for both OP and DP genes, with ∼80% of each group increasing expression by a similar amount. Notably, the two groups adapted by distinct mechanisms: DP-selected strains duplicated genomic regions, while OP-selected favored mutations not involving duplications. When selection was removed, DP but not OP genes rapidly reverted to wild-type expression, consistent with lower diversity between species. Our results suggest that nucleosome organization constrains early evolution and biases the path of long-term evolution.
Human T-lymphotropic virus 1 (HTLV-1) is a retrovirus that causes adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATL). The HT-1 transactivator/oncoprotein, Tax, is thought to promote cell proliferation and transformation by activating Iκ kinases (IKs) and nuclear factor-κB (NF-κ). Paradoxically, expression of Tax in most cells leads to upregulation of cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitors p21IP/W1 and p27IP, causing p53/pR-independent cellular senescence. Here, we show that p21IP/W1/p27-mediated senescence constitutes a checkpoint against IK/NF-κ hyperactivation. Senescence induced by Tax in HeLa cells is attenuated by mutations that reduce IK/NF activation and prevented by blocking NFκ using a degradation-resistant mutant Iα. Small hairpin RNA-mediated knockdown indicates that Rel induces senescence by acting upstream of anaphase complex and to stabilize p27IP and p21 mRNA. Finally, we show that downregulation of NFκ by HT-1 anti-s protein HB delays onset of Tax-induced senescence. We propose that balance between Tax and HB expression determines HT-1 outcome. Robust HT-1 replication and Tax drive IK/NF hyperactivation and senescence. HB, however, modulates Tax-mediated replication and NF activation, allowing HT-1-infected cells to proliferate persist and evolve. Finally, inactivation senescence can facilitate persistent NF activation and leukemogenesis.
The human brain’s frontal lobe plays a crucial role in decision-making and executive functions, including the selection and coordination of goal-directed behaviors. However, current models of executive function do not explain decision-making in everyday situations that are uncertain, changing, and open-ended. We propose a computational model of executive function that clarifies this issue. Using behavioral experiments, we show that our model predicts human decisions and variations across individuals in natural situations. The model reveals that the frontal lobe monitors up to four concurrent behavioral strategies and infers their ability to predict outcomes: whenever one appears more reliable, this strategy is chosen to guide selection and learning of actions that maximize rewards. Otherwise, a new strategy is tentatively formed from long-term memory, probed and confirmed to drive action. The frontal has a capacity to monitor four strategies. This is compensated by the structure of control in ambiguous situations that promotes exploration and creation of new strategies. Our results support a model of frontal function that integrates reasoning, learning, and abilities in decision and adaptive behavior.
Pharmacological treatment of diseases is a challenging due to the lack of understanding of long-term effects and potential side effects. We present a new modeling approach called Analysis of Dynamic Adaptations Parameter Trajectories (ADAPT) to study the long-term effects of pharmacological treatment. A time-dependent evolution of model parameters is introduced to study the dynamics of molecular adaptations. The progression of these adaptations is predicted by identifying dynamic changes in parameters to describe the transition between experimental data during different stages of treatment. This approach provides insight into the underlying biological systems and identifies molecular events to be studied in detail to unravel the mechanistic basis of treatment outcome.
Spinal cord and cerebellar neurons are capable of processing both sensory and motor signals. These signals are combined in the neurons of the spinocerebell pathways and granule cells receive this input with respect to their output. In this paper, we synthesize findings into a hypothesis for spinocerebell and cerebellar interaction to support coordination of multi-segmented limbs and bodies. We propose that recombination of signals to spinerebell neurons can approximate spatial and temporal dependencies between segments, necessary for coordination. However, recombination of sensory and motor signals is not a good strategy since granule cells limit the number of recombinations. Instead, we propose that spinal circuit provides useful recombinations, described as linear projections of multi-dimensional sensorimotor input. Granule cells, with aid of Golgi cells, enhance utility of these projections allowing Purje to establish piecewise-linear approximations of non-linear functions. Our hypothesis provides novel view of spinal and cerebell gran layer, illustrating cerebell functions supported by spinere recombinations.
Chikungunya virus (CHIKV) is a viral pathogen transmitted by the mosquito vector Aedes albopictus. In this study, we investigated the role of host microRNAs (miRNAs) in CHV infection in Ae. albictus. We identified 88 known and 79 miRNAs in uninfected and CHV infected Ae. albict cell lines, respectively, and nine novel miRNAs in Ae. We compared the two libraries and found differential expression of 77 miRNAs between them. CHV infection altered the miRNA profile of eight miRN. We identified putative targets of these miRN and classified them into pathways. Our study identified and described miRNA profiles upon CHV in Ae. This provides insight into cellular modification by miRN during CHV and leads to potential candidates for vector based antiviral strategies.
Cysticercosis (CE) is a parasitic disease affecting both humans and animals. It is a significant public health and economic problem in many developing countries, including Iran. However, the economic impact of the disease in endemic countries is not fully understood. This study aimed to determine the economic burden of CE in Iran. Epidemiological data, including prevalence and incidence of CE in humans and animals, were obtained from hospitals, literature, and official reports. Economic data relating to human and animal disease, including treatment costs, productivity, and production losses were obtained from national and international datasets. Monte Carlo methods were used to represent uncertainty in parameters. The number of surgical CE cases per year 2000–2009 was estimated at 1, 295. The number of asymptomatic individuals in the country was estimated at 635,232 (95% CI 149,466–1,120,998 ). The overall cost of CE in Iran was estimated at US$232.3 million (95 CI US$103.–397.8 million ), including direct and indirect costs. The cost with human CE was estimated US$93. million (95 CI$6.–222.7 ) and the cost with CE in livestock estimated US132 million (95 CI$61.–246.5 ) The cost per human was US1,539. CE has considerable impact on Iran, with cost approximated at 0.03% country's gross product.
Polyomavirus (MPV) is a highly oncogenic virus that infects rodents and transforms cells in culture. In this study, we used deep sequencing to follow MPV infection of mouse NIH3T cells at various times after infection and analyzed both viral and cellular transcriptomes. We found that MPV transcribes both early-strand and late-strand RNAs at all times after infection. These studies revealed novel insights into MPV gene expression, including widespread RNA editing of viral transcripts late in infection. By late in infection, 359 genes were upregulated and 857 downregulated. Gene ontology analysis showed that transcripts involved in translation, metabolism, RNA processing, DNA methylation, and protein turnover were upregulated, while those involved in extracellular adhesion, cytoskeleton, zinc binding, SH domain and GTP activation were downregulated. We also found that levels of many noncoding RNAs were altered. The noncoding RNA MALAT, involved in splicing and used as marker in late cancers, was downregulated, while other noncoding RNAs were upregulated.
Hundreds of thousands of runners attempt to complete a marathon each year, but more than two-fifths experience severe performance-limiting depletion of physiologic carbohydrate reserves, known as ‘hitting the wall, and drop out before reaching the finish. Analyses of endurance physiology have suggested that glycogen reserves are insufficient to fuel a marathon or that maximal glycogen loading is required to complete without ‘hitting the wall. However, the present study demonstrates that energetic constraints on runners are subtle and depend on physi variables including muscle mass, liver glycogen density, and running intensity as a fraction of aerobic capacity. The study estimates the distance at which runners will exhaust glycogen as a function of intensity and provides a basis for optimizing performance by setting appropriate paces and prescribing midrace fuel to avoid ‘the wall.
Toxoplas gondii is a protozoan parasite that causes toxoplasis in humans and rodents. The parasite is divided into three clonal lineages (I, II, and III) in Europe and North America, but in South America a variety of other strains are found. These strains differ in virulence, persistence, oral infectivity, migratory capacity, cytokine expression, and host gene expression. We hypothesize that besides host and environmental factors, parasite genotype plays a major role in toxoplasis outcome. Macrophages are essential in early immune response against T. gondii and are preferentially infected in vivo. We infected murine macrophages with 29 Toxoplas strains representing global diversity and used RNA-sequencing to determine host and parasite transcriptomes. We found large differences between strains in expression of known effectors and chromosomal variation in some. We identified novel strain-specific regulated pathways, including regulation of type I interferon response by atypical strains. IFβ production by infected cells was associated with parasite killing independent of interferon activation and dependent on endosomal Toll-like receptors in macroph and cytoplasmic receptor retic-inducible gene 1 ( RIG ) in fibroblasts.
Recombination in enteroviruses is an evolutionary mechanism for acquiring extensive regions of novel sequence that has been suggested to have a role in genotype diversity and is known to have been key to the emergence of novel neuropathogenic poliovirus variants. We investigated heterologous recombination using a novel genetic approach that resulted in the isolation of chimeric interic poliruses bearing genomes with duplicated sequences at the recombination junction. Serial passage of viruses with imprecise junctions yielded progeny with increased fitness that lost the duplicated sequences.
White adipose tissue (WAT) is a promising target for metabolic disease treatment through norepinephrine (NE)-mediated signaling. Previous studies report NE clearance via SLC6A in sympathetic neurons or proinflammatory macrophages in adipose tissues (AT), but SLC2’s low catechamine capacity limits efficiency. Here, we report that organic cation transporter 3 (Oct;Slc22a3) is highly expressed in W and displays the greatest NE uptake as a non-neural route in white adipocytes, differing from known routes such as neurons or macrophages. We show adipocytes express high NE degradation enzymes Mao, Maob, and Com, providing molecular basis for NE clearance by adipocytes with reuptake Oct3. NE administration ablation of Oct induces higher thermogenesis and lipolysis compared to littermates. After cold challenge, inginal WAT in Oct-deficient mice shows stronger browning and elevated thermogenic genes than littermates, involving β-adrenerg receptor (βAR)/protein kinase (PK)/cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)-responsive binding (Cre) pathway. Glycolytic genes are reprogrammed to compensate for loss in Oct-deficient mice, indicating glucose role during beig. Inhibition β largely abolishes lipoly and therm activities in Oct-def W, indicating NE in Oct KO adipocytes. Reduced alleles in OCT are associated with increased basal metabolic rate (BMR). Collectively, Oct governs βAR as NE transporter in adipocytes, offering applications for metabolic disorders.
HP proteins are a family of heterochromatin-enriched proteins that play a critical role in the regulation of transcription. They contain two related domains: the chromo and chromadow. The chrom-domain binds to histone H3 tails that are methylated on lysine 9. However, in vivo and in vitro experiments have shown that HP proteins have poor affinity for methylated chromatin and that opening of chrom during DNA replication facilitates their binding to nucleosomes. We show that the chromadow-domain interacts with histone H in a region located inside the nucleosomal at the entry/exit of the nucleosome. This region is also contacted by the catalytic subunits of the SWI/SNF complex. In vitro, SW/SNF requires this contact and is inhibited by HP proteins. The antagonism between SW/SNF and HP is also observed on a series of interferon-regulated genes. Finally, we show that SWNF favors loading of HP to chrom both in vivo and vitro.
Self-containment is a property of modular RNA structures that distinguishes microRNAs from other types of RNAs. It is the tendency of an RNA sequence to robustly adopt the same secondary structure regardless of whether it exists in isolation or as a substring of longer sequence. We measured self-containment using self-containment index and found that miRNAs exhibit high self-containment, consistent with requirement for structural invariance imposed by miRNA biogenesis pathway. Most other structured RNAs do not exhibit self-containment. Further analysis revealed trend toward higher self-containment among conserved miRNAs suggesting that self-containment may be characteristic of miRN acquiring new genomic contexts.
