We found miRN display enhanced self-containment compared to other functional RNAs and trend toward selection for self-cont in most functional classes. Self-cont may arise from selection for robustness against perturbations, invariance during biogenesis and modular composition of function.
In this study, we have identified four transcription factors (TFs) in Arabidopsis that limit the spread of necrotrophic fungal pathogens. We found that Arabid mutants defective in any of these TFs are more susceptible to Botrytis cinerea and Plectphaella cucumeria. These mutants also show a general activation of non-immune host processes that contribute to disease. We found that the mutants share a common transcriptional signature of 77 up-regulated genes. We characterized several of the up-regulated genes that encode secreted peptides, which we named PROIR ( provirulence factors ). We found that many of the PROIRs are important for susceptibility of the host to necrophic fungal pathogens.
Successful implantation of an embryo in the uterus requires a receptive endometrium. Poor uterine receptivity is a major cause of implantation failure in women who experience recurrent pregnancy loss or multiple rounds of unsuccessful in vitro fertilization cycles. Here, we show that the transcription factor Forkhead O1 ( FOX1 ) is a critical regulator of endometrial receptivity in vivo. We demonstrate that uterine ablation of Fox1 using the progesterone receptor ( Pgr ) Cre mouse model results in infertility due to altered epithelial cell polarity and apoptosis, preventing the embryo from penetrating the luminal epithelium. The utine transcriptome analysis after Fox1 ablation reveals alterations in gene expression of transcripts involved in cell invasion, transport, apoptosis, β-caten ( CTN1 ) signaling, and increased P signaling. The increase in P signaling is due to P expression retained in the utine epithelium during the window of recept. Constitutive expression of epithelial P during this period inhibits expression of FOX1 in the nucleus of utine epithelium. The reciprocal expression of P and FOX1 is conserved in human endrial samples during proliferative and secretory phase.
Dengue fever is a major public health problem in Bangladesh, but many cases are not reported. We developed a statistical model to study the spread of deng in the country. The model accounted for the fact that many cases are not reported. We used data from 2000 to 2009 on deng cases at the district level (64 districts ). We found that temperature and its interaction with temperature range were associated with deng incidence. We also found that rainfall was associated with deng incidence. We found that densely populated districts and those bordering India or Myanmar had more deng than others. We estimated that 92% of deng cases occurred between August and September. We found deng cases across the country, with 94% in the capital Dhaka. We found that less than half of d cases were reported from surveillance data. The proportion of reported cases varied by month, with more in high-incidence districts but less towards the end of transmission season.
Mice are attracted to places with high path tortuosity when introduced into a novel environment. These places are characterized by the highest number of visits and cumulative time spent. Examination of exploratory behavior in these places reveals important features of their organization. We term these places “knots” and the behavior performed in them “knotcrib”. Knots have distinct boundaries and are maintained within and across sessions. They are mostly situated in the place of introduction into the arena, away from walls. Knots are characterized by high speed during inbound and low speed during outbound paths. The establishment of knots is enhanced by injecting mice with saline and placing in an exposed portion of arena, suggesting that stress and arousal consolidate a long-term contingency between locale and knotcrib. In an environment devoid of proximal cues, mice mark locale associated with arousal by twisting and turning. This creates a self-generated, centrally located landmark. The tortuosity of path during knotcrib implies multiple views of the environment. Knotcrib could function to obtain an overview of environment and re-calibrate locale and compass.
Invasive fungal infections are responsible for more than 1. 9 million deaths worldwide each year. We report the discovery of NG04, an antifungal compound with selectivity for fungal cells over mammalian cells. Using high-resolution chemogenomics, we identified Secp, a lipid transfer protein, as the target of NG04. NG04-resistant mutations in Secp define compound interactions in the binding pocket of the protein. Secp is essential for lipid transfer in a variety of pathogenic fungi and for secretion of virulence determinants in pathogenic fungi such as Cryptococcus neoformans, making Secp an attractive antifungal target. We demonstrate that NG04 inhibits growth of two clinical isolates of C. neoans and NG04-related compounds have even higher potency against C. neo. Furthermore, NG04 analogues show fungicidal activity against fluconazole-resistant C. neo. We present genetic evidence that NG04 inhibits Secp and data supporting NG04 as a novel antungal starting point.
Schistosomiasis is a neglected tropical disease that exacerbates poverty and is often treated with a single drug called praziquant. However, the large-scale use of prazant might select for drug-resistant parasites, hence there is a need to develop new antischosomal compounds. Here, we report that the antimal drug mefloquine possesses promising antischosomal properties in mice. Mice infected with adult Schistoma mansoni or S japonicum were treated with a single dose of mefloquine (200 or 400 mg ) orally, resulting in 72.3–100% total worm burden reductions. Importantly, worm reductions were also observed for young developing stages of S mansoni and japon in mice. Both mequine enantiomers resulted in comparable worm reductions when given to mice with subpatent or patent S mans infection. Our findings hold promise for a novel antosomal drug based on aminoal functionality.
Podoconiasis is a non-filarial elephantias characterized by massive swelling of the lower limbs. It was identified as a neglected disease by WHO in 201. This study maps the distribution of podoiosis in Cameroon using parasitological, serological, and clinical evidence to exclude other causes of lymphedema. We used a multi-stage sampling design with stratification of the country by environmental risk of podoiosis. We sampled 76 villages from 40 districts in 10 regions of Cameroon. All individuals 15 years or older were surveyed and screened for lymphema. A clinical algorithm was used to diagnose podoiosis excluding filarial lymphema. Individuals with lymphema were tested for Wuchereria bancrofti antigen and IgG using Alere Filasis Strips ( F ) and Standard Diagnostics ( ) BIOLymphatic filariasis Ig4 ( W123 ), in addition to thick films. Presence of W bancft DNA was checked on blood using qPCR. Overall, 10,178 individuals from 4,603 households participated. Of 83 with lymphema were identified, two were F positive and negative W123. No bancft were found in blood of any with lymphema. None were positive bancft usingPCR. Two F positive were positive Mansonella perst and Loa loa. Overall 52 podoiosis were identified applying algorithm. Prevalence was 0.5% (CI 0.–.7 ). At least one case found every region except Adamawa. Of 40 districts, 17 had no cases; 15 between 0.2 and 1.%; eight between 1.2 and 2.7.
Notch Signaling Mediates the Age-Associated Decrease in Adhesion of Germline Stem Cells to the Niche. Stem cells have an innate ability to occupy their cell niche, which is optimized to house stem cells. Aging is associated with reduced stem cell occupancy in the niche, but mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we report that Notch signaling is increased in Drosophila female germline stem (GSCs), and results in their removal from niche. Clonal analysis revealed Gs with low Not signaling exhibit increased adhesion to niche, thereby outcompeting neighbors with high Not; adhesion is through E-cadherin expression. Experimental Notch in Gs hastens age loss from niche, and is least mediated lethal. However, Notch in Gs does not delay loss during aging, nor does it BMP, which promotes Gs. Finally, we show in contrast Gs, Notch in niche maintains niche, and mediates G retention is reduced with age, indicating Notch regulates niche both intrinsically and extrins.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) encodes a protein kinase called UL97 that phosphorylates the retinoblastoma (Rb) tumor suppressor and lamin A proteins, which are also substrates of cyclin-dependent kinases (Cdks). A functional complementation assay has shown that UL97 has Cdk-like activity. The seven human herpesviruses encode a kinase with sequence homology to UL97, termed conserved herpesvirus kinases (CHPs). To determine if Cdk activities of UL were shared by all CHPs, we expressed epitope-tagged alleles of each protein in human cells to test R phosphorylation, U2 cells to monitor lamin disruption and phosphorylation, and S cerevisiae to assay Cdk. We found that all CHPs from beta and gamma-herpesvirus families phosphorylated R and lamin and disrupted nuclear lamina, while alpha-herpesirus homologs did not. Similarly, all beta and gamma CHPs displayed Cdk activity in S cerevis, while alpha did not. We identified virally Cdk kinases, abbreviated as vdk. We found that non-C related activities of UL ( dispersion of promyocytic leukemia protein bodies and cytoplasmic nuclear aggres ) showed weak conservation among CHPs, not segregating to viral families. Our data indicate these kinases likely serve overlapping and non-overlapping functions during infections.
Burkholderia pseudomallei is a Gram-negative bacillus that causes melioidosis and is present in the environment in many tropical countries. The global distribution of B. pseudalleli underpins efforts to prevent infection and is dependent upon robust sampling methodology. Our objective was to review the literature on detection of environmental B. pseudalle, update the map for meloidosis, and propose international guidelines for sampling. We formed the Detection Environmental Burkholder pseudalle Working Party (DEBP) during the VIth Meloidosis Congress 2010. We searched PubMed (1912–2011) using MeSH terms: pseudalle or meloidosis and hand-searched bibliographies for references. The geographical distribution of B pseudalle in the environment was mapped as definite, probable, or possible. The methodology for detecting B pseudalle was extracted and collated. We found global coverage was patchy with lack of studies in areas where meloid is suspected. Sampling and bacterial methods were highly variable and not robust. We developed guidelines to reduce probability of false results and provide low-tech applicable in both countries. The guidelines provide basis for global map B pseudalle.
Peptide Inhibitors of Dengue Virus Entry Target a Late-Stage Intermediate of the Fusion Mechanism of Class II Viral Membrane Fusion Proteins. The mechanism of membrane fusion by class II viral proteins follows a pathway that involves large domain rearrangements of the envelope glycoprotein E and a transition from dimers to trimers. The rearrangement is believed to proceed by outward rotation of the ectodomain after loss of dimer interface followed by reassociation into trim. The ∼55-residue membrane proximal stem can then zip along domain II bringing the transmembrane segments of Cterminus and loops of domain II. We find that peptides derived from the stem of deng-virus E bind stem dimer, a conformation intermediate. In vitro assays demonstrate these peptides block viral fusion. The peptides inhibit infectivity is proportional to affinity for conformation intermediate even free is removed from preincubated inoculum before infecting cells. We conclude peptides bind virions before are carried into endosomes compartment which initiates fusion. Binding depends on dynamics there is no inhibition if preincation and separation at 4°C rather 37. We propose two-step mechanism for fusion inhibition.
Cholera is a major public health concern worldwide, with an estimated 4 million cases and 95, 000 deaths annually. Recent outbreaks in Haiti and Yemen are a reminder that cholera is still a global threat. Cholera can rapidly overwhelm health facilities, especially in remote or areas of unrest. Recent studies have shown that stool specimens on paper can be used for molecular analysis of Vibrio cholera in limited settings. Specimens can be preserved in a low-cost, safe and sustainable manner, providing new data on circulating cholera strains. This may inform policy on cholera control and elimination. Whole genome sequencing ( WGS ) recovered a complete sequence of the V. cholera O genome from stool enriched in alkaline peptone water ( AP ) and V. cholera culture, both spotted on paper. The minimum V cholera DNA to produce genomic information was 0.02 ng/μL. The data confirmed presence or absence of genes of interest, including chol toxin and pilus loci. WGS identified a variety of diarral pathogens from AP-enrich specimen filter, highlighting the potential to explore the gut microbiome and co-infections. These may impact disease severity. WGS fit the current cholera phylogenetic tree, identifying as the 7th pandemic El. W allowed mapping of reads from AP-enrich specimen and isolate filter papers. This provided molecular information on V cholera strains from remote settings. These identified co-infecting pathogens while providing insight into specific cholera strains in choleraemic areas.
Dyne Regulates Epithelial Polarity and the Apical Localization of Stard A mRNA  
    Dyne, a cytoplasmic motor protein, has been identified as an essential regulator of epithelial polarity in Drosophila follicle cells. Through a genetic screen for epithelial defects, we found that Dyne is required for ap–basal polarity. Our data suggest that Dy acts through the cytoplasmic scaffolding protein Stardust ( Sdt ) to localize the transmembrane protein Crumbs at the apical surface. This is achieved through the ap targeting of specific Sdt mRNA isoforms. We have mapped the Sdt mRNA localization signal to an alternatively spliced exon. The presence or absence of this exon corresponds to a developmental switch in S mRNA localization, where ap transcripts are found only during early stages of epithelial development and unlocalized transcripts predominate in mature epithelia. This is the first demonstration that Dy is required for epithelial polarity and suggests that mRNA localization may have a role in regulating ap–bas organization.
Leishmania infantum, the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis, has been thought to reproduce clonally. However, recent studies have proposed the existence of a sexual cycle in the extracellular stage of the parasite within the sand fly vector. Here, we provide evidence for intraclonal genetic exchange in L. infantum. We developed transgenic L. infant lines expressing drug resistance markers linked to green and red fluorescent reporters. We hypothesized that cells with identical genotype could recognize each other and mate. We fed sand flies with a mixture of parental clones and found that both markers were exchanged within the midgut of the vector Phlebotus periciosus. Using the yellow and drug markers, we provide evidence for genetic exchange in L.um. Hybrid progeny were triploid based on DNA analysis. The hybrid was stable throughout the parasite cycle. Infections by the hybrid in BAL/c mice caused a reduction in loads in spleen and liver, and weight similar to uninfected mice. Sple arginase was also reduced to parental strains.
Leishmanias (VL), caused by Leishmania donovani, is a major health problem in Ethiopia. Parasites in different regions are transmitted by different vectors and cluster in distinctive genotypes. Recently, strains from VL and HIV-VL co-infected patients in north and south Ethiopia were characterized as part of a longitudinal study on VL. Sixty L donani strains were examined by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) targeting three regions: internal transcribed spacer 1 (ITS), cystine protease (cp) and HASPB (26). ITS and cp PCR identified strains as L donani. Interestingly, 26 PCR amplicon size varied depending on patient's origin. Most from north Ethiopia (36/40) produced 290 bp product with minority (4/40) giving 410 amplicon. All latter were isolated from patients with HIVL co-infections, while former contained VL and HIVL co-infected. Almost all (23) from Ethiopia produced 450 amplic with smaller (290 or 360) observed for three. Sudanese strains amplicons identical (290) to north Ethiopia; Kenyan gave larger products (500 650). High-resolution (HR) analysis distinguished products. Sequence showed 26 region in donani comprised polymorphic 13 and 14 amino motifs. 13 amino prevalent in donani rare inum The and order varies between regions donani.
HIV-1 recombination is a major source of diversity in the HIV/AIDS pandemic. Recombinant HIV-1 genomes may have novel properties that contribute to their prevalence, particularly in the case of circulating recombinant forms (CRFs). We hypothesize that regions of the HIV-1 genome where recombination confers a selective advantage will deviate from the null distribution of breakpoints. To test this, we generate a probabilistic model of HIV-1 recombination and compare it to the distribution of breakpoints from the HIV/AIDS pandemic. We find that much of the HIV-1 genome is accurately predicted by our model. This indicates that a probabilistic model dependent on local identity is sufficient to explain breakpoints. In regions with significant over- or underrepresentation of breakpoints, we infer natural selection influences recombination. The paucity of breakpoints in the envelope gene indicates recombinants are less likely to be successful. Breakpoints at higher than predicted are at either side of the envelope, indicating selection for these recombinants as a consequence of this region. Our findings provide the first indication of a portion of the genome deviating from a probabilistic model. This suggests only a minority of recombination events are significant to HIV-1 evolution.
Computational modeling plays an important role in modern neuroscience research. Much of the previous research has relied on separate statistical methods to address two interdependent problems. First, given a particular model, Bayesian techniques have been used to estimate individual variation in parameters over a population of subjects, leveraging population distributions. Second, candidate models are compared, and variation in the model expressed according to the fits to each subject. We propose a Bayesian inference framework for concurrent model comparison and estimation at the population level, combining previous approaches. This framework has advantages for both estimation and model comparison theoretically and experimentally. The estimated parameters show smaller errors compared to other methods. Model comparison is robust against outliers and not biased towards simplistic. Furthermore, the approach enables inference on group parameters by t-test.
The development of the auditory circuitry in the brainstem is a complex process that involves the coordination of rhombomeres and their associated Hox genes. Here we show that rhomere 4 (r4) contributes to the development of functionally linked sensory and motor components of the auditory circuit, including the ventral nucleus of the lateral lemniscus, ventral cochlear nuclei ( VCN ) and olivocochlear neurons. The assembly of r-derived auditory components is involved in sound perception and depends on interactions between Hox1 and H2. In the absence of Hox1 and H2, transmission of low-level auditory stimuli is lost and hearing is impaired. On the other hand, H2 regulates the Rig1 axon receptor and controls contralateral projections from the VCN to the medial nucleus of the trapezoid, a circuit involved in sound localization.
The genome of the marine bacterium Saccharagus degradans strain 2-40 (S2-40) has been completely sequenced. This bacterium is a member of a recently discovered group of marine and estuarine bacteria that degrade complex polysaccharides. The genome encodes an unusually large number of enzymes that degrade >10 polysacchar. These enzymes exhibit a range of catalytic and substrate architectures, including novel combinations of catalytic and substrate modules. We hypothesize that these features facilitate depolymerization of polyschar in the marine environment. This is the first sequenced genome of a marine bacterium that degrades plant cell walls, an important component of the carbon cycle not well-characterized in the marine.
Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV) is a zoonotic flavivirus that is the most common cause of viral encephalitis in children in Asia. In the last 20 years, JEV genotype has shifted from genotype III (GIII) to genotype I (GI), but the mechanism of this shift is still unknown. Culex pipiens mosquitoes are the most common mosquito species in China and play a key role in JE transmission. We used Cx pipiens mosquitoes from China as an in vivo model to explore if they played a role in J genotype shift. We exposed female Cx pip mosquitoes to GI or GIII JEV and collected midgut, organs and saliv glands at 7 and 14 days post infection. We measured infection rate, replication, dissemination, and transmission of JEV in C pip mosquitoes by 50 tissue infective dose assay. Cx pip was competent for both GI and GIII infection with similar rates and kinetics. After infection, C pip disseminated both genotypes to organs at similar rates. GI-infected saliv glands were positive at 16.2%, whereas GIII was undetectable at 7 dpi, but 29.4% and 36.3% were positive at 14 dpi. No difference in transmission rate between GI and G-infected was detected. Our data show GI and GIII have similar infectivity in C pip, suggesting C pip may not play a role in J shift.
Dengue is the fastest spreading mosquito-borne viral disease affecting people in tropical and subtropical countries. In Malaysia experienced large deng outbreaks in recent years. We conducted a retrospective review of deng deaths that occurred between 2013 and 2014 to study demographics and clinical characteristics associated with deng deaths. We extracted data from mortality reports and investigational forms and categorized cases into children (15 years ), adults (15–59 ) and elderly ( ≥60 ) to compare clinical characteristics. A total 322 deng deaths were reviewed. The mean age was 40.7±19. years, half were females and 72.5 were adults. The durations of first medical contact and hospitalization were 1 and 3 days, respectively. Diabetes and hypertension were common co-morbidities among adults and elderly. The most common signs reported were lethargy and vomiting, with letharg being more common in children (p = 0. 038 ) and abdominal pain in adults (p = 0.040 ). 22.4 did not have any signs. Only 34 were suspected deng at initial presentation. More adults developed plasma leakage (p = 0.018 ). More than half suffered multi-organ involvement and 20 were free any organ. Deaths occurred at 3 days post-admission. Dengue shock syndrome (DSS) contributed >70% deaths, followed by organ (69 ) and bleeding (29.7 ). In Malaysia, deaths primarily occurred in adults. SS was cause of death regardless groups.
Female fruit flies (Drosophila melanogaster) choose their mates to maximize reproductive success. One component of this choice is assessing mate quality, but little is known about traits used for this assessment or how they reflect quality. We show that insulin signaling, a nutrient-sensing pathway affecting survival versus reproduction, affects female attractiveness. This effect is due to insulin signaling in fat and ovarian follicle cells, whose signals are integrated by pherone-producing oocytes. Ovaries are required for insulin effects on attractiveness and manipulations of insulin in follicle cells recapulate global manipulations. Modulation of insulin in fat produces opposite effects on attractiveness, suggesting a competitive relationship with ovary. Tissue-specific insulin manipulations change attractiveness and fecundity in the same direction, pointing to insulin activity as a link between fecity and attractiveness. Cues, cuticular hydrocarbons respond to fat and follicle manipulations, indicating readouts of pathway from these tissues. We describe a system in which attractiveness results from connection between attractiveness and fecity, both created by insulin in fat and follicle.
During the 2013–2015 Ebola virus disease (EVD) epidemic in Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone, the disease spread of EVD was heterogeneous across the three countries. To understand the dynamics of EVD transmission at the district level, we estimated the basic reproduction number ( R0 ) for each district and country using weekly incident numbers of cases. We calculated growth rates during the early phase of the outbreak using exponential regression of case counts on the first eight weeks since onset. To account for heterogeneity between countries, we fitted a mixed model and calculated R0 based on predicted growth rates and serial interval distribution. At the district level, R ranged from 0. 36 ( Dubka ) to 1.72 ( Bey ) in Guinea, from 0.53 ( Maryland ) 3.37 ( Margibi ) in Liberia and 1.14 ( Koinugu ) 2.73 ( Rural ) in Sierra Leone. At the national level, we estimated R of 0.97 ( 95% 0.77–1.18 ) for Guinea,1.26 (95%.98–1.55 ) for Liberia and 1.66 (95%1.–2.00 ) Sierra. Socio-demographic factors such as high population density and wealth were positively associated with R.
Proteins are the building blocks of all living organisms, and their evolution is a fundamental to life. However, the factors that determine the rate of protein evolution are not well understood. In particular, it is unclear whether the intrinsic properties of a protein, such as its structure, or historical factors, such as its age, determine its rate of evolution. Here, we study the interplay between structure and age as determinants of protein evolution. We use a large set of one-to-one orthologs between human and mouse proteins, with PDB structures. We find that previously observed relationships between structure and rate also hold within each group, including between solvent accessibility, designability, and rate. However, age also plays a role: it modulates the relationship between solvent and rate. Younger proteins, despite being less designable, tend to evolve faster than older ones. We show that previously relationships between age and rate cannot be explained by structural biases among groups. Finally, we introduce a knowledge-based function to study stability of proteins through large computation. We find that older proteins are more stable in their native structure and robust to mutations than younger ones.
Polycomb-like 3 (PCL) is a component of the Polycomb repressive complex 2 (PRC2) that promotes embryonic stem cell (ES) self-renewal. We identified CL as a Suz12 binding partner by mass spectrometry and confirmed CL interactions with PR2 core components by co-immunoprecipitation. Knockdown of CL in ES cells increases spontaneous differentiation, yet does not affect early differentiation as assessed in teratom and embryoid bodies, indicating CL has a role in regulating ES selfnew. Consistent with CL promoting PR2 function, decreasing CL reduces H3K27me levels while overexpressing CL increases H3me levels. Chromatin immunoprecipitation and sequencing (IP) reveal CL co-localizes with PR core component Suz, and depletion of CL decreases Suz binding at 60% of PR2 targets. Mutation of conserved residues within CL Tudor domain, implicated in recognizing methylated histones, compromises H3me formation, suggesting CL Tud domain is essential for function. CL and its paralog CL2 exist in different PR complexes but bind many of same PR targets, particularly CpG regulated by CL. CL is critical for ES selfnew, histone methylation, and PR recruitment to subset genomic sites.
Chemoreceptor gene expression in Caenorhabditis elegans is regulated by both cell-autonomous and non-cellautonomous mechanisms. We show that the MEF-2 transcription factor acts together with basic helix-loop-helix (HL) transcription factors to regulate the expression of the feeding-dependent chemoreceptor gene sr-234 in the AD sensory neuron of C. elegans. We identify a cis-regulatory MEF binding site that is necessary for starvation-induced downregulation of sr-234, while an E-box known to bind HL factors is required to drive sr-234 expression in AD. We show that HL-2, HL-3, and HL-4 act in AD neurons to regulate sr-234. We further demonstrate that expression of sr- in AD neurons is regulated by MX-3 and HL-30 acting in the intestine, which is dependent on insulin signaling in AD neurons. We show that this intestine-to-neuron regulation of sr- involves a subset of insulin peptides.
Buruli ulcer (BU) is a destructive skin condition caused by infection with the bacterium Mycobacterium ulcerans. The mode of transmission of M. ulcerans is not completely understood, but several studies have explored the role of biting insects. This study tested the association between detection of M ulcer in mosquitoes and the risk of disease in humans in an endemic area of southeastern Australia. Mosquitoes were trapped in seven towns on the Bellarine Peninsula, Victoria, Australia, from December 2004 to December 2009 and screened for M ulcer by real-time PCR. The number of laboratory-confirmed BU cases in residents of these towns during the same period was tallied to determine the cumulative incidence in each location. Pearson correlation was calculated for proportion M ulcer-positive mosquitoes per town with incidence per town. We found a strong relationship between detection of M ulcer in mosquitoes and risk of disease ( r 0.99; 95% CI 0.92–.99; p0.001. Results strengthen the hypothesis that mosquitoes are involved in transmission of M ulcer in southeastern Australia. This has implications for development of strategies to control and prevent BU.
Mutations in the gene encoding the mitochondrial Mg2+ channel MRS2 result in demyelination in rats. The dmy mutation is a unique model to study the maintenance of myelin because it causes severe myelin breakdown in the central nervous system (CNS) after normal completion of myelination. We report the molecular characterization of this mutation and discuss the pathomechanisms underlying demyination. By positional cloning, we found a G-to-A transition 177 bp downstream of exon 3 of the MRS2 gene generated a novel splice site resulting in functional inactivation of the mutant allele. Transgenic rescue with wild-type M2DNA validated our findings. M2 encodes a component of the Mg2 influx system in mitochondria of yeast as well as human cells. We show that dmy rats have mitochondrial deficits with elevated lactic acid in cerebrospinal fluid, 60% reduction in ATP, and increased mitochondria in swollen oligodendrocy cytoplasm. M2-GFP recombin B transgenic rats show M2 dominantly expressed in neurons rather than oligodrocytes and ultrastructurally observed in inner mitochondria.
Microarray-based gene expression signatures have the potential to improve diagnosis and prognosis of diseases. However, current documentation of signatures does not allow for unambiguous application to external studies. This hinders independent evaluation, delaying use in clinical practice. We analyzed eight publicly available clinical microarray studies and evaluated consistency of study-internal with studyexternal diagnoses. Studyexternal classifications were based only on documented information. Documenting a signature is conceptually different from reporting a list of genes. We show that exact specification of classification alone does not define signature unambiguously. Discrepancy between studyinternal and studyexternal can be as frequent as 30% ( worst ) 18% ( median. By proposed documentation strategy, which documents quantitative information, was reduced to 1%.
Bacteria of the genus Enterobacteriaceae secrete curli amyloid fibrils that mediate cell adhesion and contribute to biofilm formation, thereby promoting resistance to environmental stress. We present the crystal structures of amyloidogenic segments from the major curli subunit Csg, revealing a steric zipper of tightly mated β-sheets. These structures demonstrate a link between curli and human amyloids. We show that anti-amyloid peptides, originally developed to interfere with Alzheimer’s amyloid-β, inhibit Csg fibrillation and biofilm formation in Salmonella typhimium. Moreover, we show that Csg fibr cross-seed amyloidβ, supporting the proposed resemblance and potential for cross-species amyloid interactions. These findings provide structural insights into amyloid regions important for curli formation and suggest a novel strategy for disrupting amyloid biofilms.
Japanese encephalitis (JE) is an important cause of encephalitis in Asia with high fatality rates and significant neurologic sequelae among survivors. The epidemiology of JE in the Philippines is not well defined. We conducted a systematic review of JE surveillance data from 2011 to 2014 to support consideration of JE vaccine introduction into the national schedule in the Philippines. We searched JE and the Philippines in four databases and one library. Data from acute encephal syndrome (AES) and JE surveillance from the national laboratory from 2011 to 2014 were tabulated and mapped. We identified 29 reports on JE in the Philippines, including 5 serologic, 18 clinical, and 8 studies including both clinical and animal. The 18 studies reported 257 laboratory-confirmed JE from 1972 to 2013. JE was the causative in 7% to 18% of cases meningitis and encephitis combined and 16 to 40% enitis. Predominantly affected under 15 years and 6 to 7% resulted in death. Surveillance from 201 to 201 identified 73 laboratory JE out of 497 tested. This review demonstrates endemic and extensive JE in the Philippines and supports use of JE in the country. Continued surveillance with confirmation is needed to quantify JE burden, provide information for prioritization of high areas in the country and determination of age and schedule of introduction, and measure of preventive measures against this important health.
Since the evolutionary origins of genetic robustness are still under debate, it is unclear whether it arises as a consequence of environmental requirements or intrinsic factors such as metabolic requirements, or as an adaptive selection of genes that allow species to endure perturbations. Here, we conduct the first large-scale study of the level of robustness of metabolic networks of hundreds of bacterial species across simulated environments. We find that variations in their level of robustness reflect ecological adaptations. We decouple robustness into two components: environmental, responsible for 20% of non-essential reactions and associated with species’ lifestyle (generalist/specialist ), and environmental, associated with intrinsic capacities of species—robustness observed in fast growers or with extensive production of secondary metabolites. Finally, we identify reactions uniquely susceptible to perturbations in pathogens, serving novel drug targets.
Schistosoma mansoni infection is associated with immune modulation that can influence responses to non-schosome antigens. We investigated the effects of S. mansoni infection on responses to childhood measles catch-up immunisation and prazantel treatment on this outcome in a randomised trial. The Immune Modulation and Childhood Immunisation (IMChI) study was conducted in Enteb, Uganda. Children aged 3–5 years (193 S mansoni-infected and 61 uninfected ) were enrolled. Infected children were randomised in 1:1 ratio to receive prazant 2 weeks before, at time, or 1 after measles immunisation. Plasma-meas Ig was measured at enrolment,1 and 24 weeks after immunisation. Anti-meas Ig levels increased following immunisation, but 1 post-immun S mansoni-inf compared to uninf had lower levels (adjusted mean 0.4 [0–.7] ) and percentage with protective levels also lower (adjusted 0–0.9 ). Among mansoni-inf, antias Ig post-immun was higher treated prant than not treated before immun (adjusted 2.1–4.8); at immunadjusted 1–3.5. 24 postimmun Ig did not differ between groups, but tended lower among previously-inf who still mans-positive than who became-negative. Our findings suggest S mansoni infection among pre-school is associated with reduced response to measles immunisation and prant improves response. S mans may contribute to impaired responses in endemic; schos control may be beneficial for vaccine efficacy.
Bacterial population evolution has become better understood in recent years due to large-scale sequencing of samples. It has become clear that DNA from a multitude of genes, as well as broad coverage of target population, is needed to obtain unbiased view of genetic structure and patterns of ancestry of strains. However, traditional methods for evolutionary inference, such as phylogenetic analysis, are associated with difficulties under extensive sampling, in particular when considerable recombination is anticipated. To meet needs of large analyses of population for bacteria, we introduce several tools for detection and representation of recombination between populations. Also, we introduce model description of shape of population in space, in terms of molecular and affinity towards populations. Extensive data from Neisseria are utilized to demonstrate potential of approach where population tools are combined with phylogen analysis.
Top-Down Beta Rhythms Support Selective Attention via Interaminar Interaction: A Model  
    Cortical rhythms have been thought to play important roles in cognitive functions. Recent studies have shown that rhythmic activity in the beta frequency band, around 20 Hz, is associated with neural correlates of attention, indicating that top-down beta rhythms generated in higher areas and delivered to sensory areas can support attentional modulation. To elucidate functional roles of beta and underlying mechanisms, we built a computational model of cortical areas. Our results show that top beta can activate ascending projections from L5 to L4 and L2/3, responsible for competition in layers. In the simulation, inhibitory interneurons are shown to resonate 20 Hz and modulate activity in layers in attention-related manner. These roles provide a mechanism by which cholinergic can support selective attention.
Stochastic compartmental epidemic models are useful for studying the emergence of novel pathogens, especially when the number of infectious individuals is small. However, methods for parameter estimation and prediction of these models remain limited. We describe a calibration and prediction framework for stochastic compartmental models. The proposed method, Multiple Shooting for Stochastic Systems ( MSS ) applies a linear approximation to describe fluctuations and uses each observation to update the epidemic state. We evaluate MSS for real-time estimation and prediction using simulated outbreaks of a novel pathogen. We assume weekly counts of new cases serve as a proxy for incidence. MSS produces accurate estimates of key parameters ( duration of infectiousness, R0, and Reff ) and the number of infectious during an epidemic. MSS also predicts future hospitalizations and attack rate. We compare MSS to three benchmark methods: 1 ) Poisson approximation; 2 ) particle filtering; 3 ) Kalman filter. MSS outperforms each in most scenarios. MSS is a promising for calibration and prediction of stochastic models.
Visual perception is shaped by two opposing forces: sensory adaptation and decisional history. In a series of experiments, we used multilevel modeling and cross-validation to investigate the impact of previous stimuli and decisions on behavioral reports during adjustment and forced-choice tasks. Our results show that perceptual reports are biased by a hierarchy of serial processes: low-level adaptation repels perception away from previous stimuli, whereas decisional attract perceptual reports toward recent. This hierarchy of serial dependence arises from decisional inertia, not low sensory processes. This is consistent with a Two-process model of dependence where decision persistence compensates for adaptation, leading to attractive biases in perception. We propose a unified account of serial dependence where functionally distinct mechanisms promote differentiation and integration of information over time.
In Drosophila, the Clock (CLK)–CY heterodimer is a key component of the circadian transcriptional complex. CY has a DNA-binding domain but lacks an activation domain. Most of the transcriptional activity of CLK–CY is derived from the glutamine-rich region of its partner CLK. To investigate the role of CY in circadian timekeeping, we analyzed the effects of a CY–viral 16 (VP) protein in Dophila. The addition of the potent transcriptional activator VP to CY enhances CLK–CY activity. This is manifested in flies expressing CY–16 as well as in S2 cells. These flies have increased levels of CLK–CY target mRNAs as well as period, implicating CY in circadian period determination. A detailed examination of reporter expression in CY–expressing flies suggests the period is at least in part due to rapid transcription. Importantly, behavioral effects require period (per) promoter and are unlikely to be a consequence of generally higher levels. This indicates CLK–VP effects are a consequence of transcription.
Horizontal gene transfer is a process by which genes are acquired by an organism from a different species. These genes can function as autonomous units, conferring new traits. However, we show that pre-existing proteins in an organism can constrain the functionality of a horizontally acquired gene if it operates on an ancestral pathway. Here, we determine how the horizontally acquired pmr gene activates the ancestral Pmr/PB two-component system in Salmonella enterica but not in closely related Escherichia coli. Salmonella pmr protein binds to phosphorylated Pmr protein (mr-P), protecting it from dephosphorylation by mr. This results in transcription of mr-dependent genes, including polymyxin resistance. We show that E coli pmr can activate mr/Pmr in Salmonella even though it cannot in coli, suggesting species differ in additional controlling mr levels. We establish E coli mr displays higher phosphatase activity mr-P than Salmonella mr, and identified mr subdomain responsible for this. Replacement coli mr with Salmonella was sufficient to render coli resistant polymin under mr-inducing conditions.
Embryonic stem cell differentiation is a complex process initiated by the gradual loss of pluripotency-associated transcripts and the induction of differentiation genes. Identifying differentially expressed genes at the early stages of differentiation is crucial for understanding the causal genes that promote or inhibit differentiation. Previous methods of identifying differentially expressed genes by comparing cell types include a large portion of genes that respond rather than regulate the process. Here, we demonstrate the use of biological replicates and a novel statistical approach that gene expression data without separation of cell types is informative for detecting differentially expressed at early differentiation. Applying this method to murine embryonic stem cells, we identified Smad1 as a novel regulator of pluripotency and self-renewal.
Functional clustering of gene variants is a common in next-generation sequencing studies. However, the function of many genes is unknown and their classification to pathways is scant. Associations between genes are often inferred from large-scale omics data, such as protein–protein interactions and gene-expression networks. Statistical significance is assessed by comparing the interconnectedness of mutated genes with random gene sets. However, interconnectedness can be affected by confounding, resulting in false positives. We show that genes implicated by de novo variants are biased in coding length and tend to cluster, leading to inflated p-values in functional studies. We present a method that addresses this bias. We inferred associations between genes from diverse data and assessed with a phenotype-based method. Examining de novo variants, we control confounding in coding length. We test different networks and find disease genes cluster more significantly in phenotypic-link than other networks. We present a tool to identify functional mutated genes in disease after sequencing bias and demonstrate suitability to cluster genes polygenic disorders.
In January 2014, the Mexican government implemented an 8% tax on nonessential foods with energy density ≥275 kcal/100 g and a peso-per tax on sugar-sweetened beverages ( SSBs ). This study examines changes in volume of taxed and untaxed packaged food purchases in response to these taxes in the sample stratified by socioeconomic status ( SES ). We analyzed data from 6, 248 households that participated in Nielsen’s Consumer Panel ( CPS ) from 2012–2014. We used a longitudinal, fixed-effects model to test whether the post-tax trend was different from the pre-tax trend. We controlled for household and contextual factors like salary and unemployment. The volume of taxed foods in 2014 changed -25 (95% CI = -46–11 ) per capita per month, a 5. 1% change from expected based on pre (2012–201 ) trends, with no change in untaxed foods. Low SES purchased 10.2% less taxed foods (–44–16 g capita per month ), medium SES 5.8 less taxed (28–11 g capita month ), whereas high SES did not change.
Neurons are the building blocks of the nervous system. They are responsible for transmitting and processing information in the brain. In the visual system, there is a type of neuron called the Lobula Giant Detector Neuron ( LGD ), which is sensitive to motion. In the past, its properties were explained by a model that used a power law for inhibitory input. However, this model did not account for the fact that neurons integrate information across a large part of the visual field. Here, we present a biophysically plausible model of LGD-like neurons. We assume that each channel is noisy and has a threshold. We then obtain an approxim power law as a result of pooling these channels. We show that this mechanism can predict many characteristics of LGD. Moreover, results depend on noise in inhibitory pathway but are robust against noise in excitatory.
Buruli Ulcer in Cameroon: The Development and Impact of the National Programme  
Buruli ulcer (BU) is endemic in Cameroon and institutional control began in 2002. The National Buruli Control Programme (NBPUC) was established to describe the evolution, achievements and challenges of the programme and make suggestions for scaling up. We collated data from 2001 to 2014 and reviewed BPUC reports in Cameroon. Case-detection and key control indicators were plotted on a scale to determine trends in performance. A linear analysis of detection from 200–2014 was done. The coefficient was tested for significance. In 14 years of control, 370 cases were notified. The rate dropped from 3.89 to 1.45 per 100,000. The number of endemic districts rose from two to 64. Five centres are functional and two are planned for 2015. The system has been strengthened and education has gained interest in Cameroon.
Metacognitive confidence is the ability to correctly estimate the probability of one’s choices being correct. It is fundamental for re-evaluating previous choices and arbitrating between decision strategies. However, it is susceptible to numerous biases. We investigated the effect of outcome valence ( gains or losses ) on confidence while learning stimulus-outcome associations by trial-and-error. In two experiments, participants were more confident in choices when learning to seek compared to avoiding, despite equal difficulty and performance between contexts. Computational modelling revealed that this bias is driven by context-value, a dynamically updated estimate of average-value of options necessary to explain performance in both gain and loss domains.
Alphaviruses are a family of positive-strand RNA viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm of the host cell. Among the four non-structural proteins of alphaviruses, the function of ns3 is the least understood. The ns3 protein is a component of the viral replication complex and is composed of a conserved amino-terminal macrodomain implicated in viral RNA synthesis and a poorly conserved carbox-terminal domain. Despite the lack of overall homology, we noted a carbox-terminal proline-rich motif shared by many alphavir ns3 proteins and found to serve as a preferred site for Src-homology 3 (SH) domain binding by amphiphin-1 and amphin-2. The SH domains of amphin-1 and amph-2 bind to the carbox-terminal motif of ns3 of Semli Forest (SF), Sindbis (SINV), and Chikunya viruses with high affinity. Upon alphavirus infection, the intracellular distribution of amphin was dramatically altered and colocalized with ns3. Mutations in ns3 disrupting amphin SH binding as well as RNA-mediated silencing of amphin-2 expression resulted in impaired RNA replication in HeLa cells infected with SINV or SF. Infection of Bal/c mice with SF carrying SH binding-defective ns3 was associated with decreased mortality.
Chromoblastycosis is a human disease caused by members of the fungal order Chaetothyales. We studied 123 clinical strains of the disease in Brazil by sequencing the rDNA internal transcribed spacer and partial β-tubulin genes. The strains were divided into three clusters within the family Herpotiaceae, which comprises agents of the disease. The Fonca cluster contained the most agents, with Fonsepi being the most prevalent at 80% of strains, followed by Fmonora 13%, Fnica 3% and Fpnac 1. In addition, two novel species were found among Rhinadiella and Cyphora with frequencies 3% and 1, respectively.
Listeria monocytogenes dampens the DNA damage response. The DNA damage response (DDR) is a signaling pathway that detects DNA lesions caused by endogenous or exogenous assaults and maintains genome integrity. Infection by an invading pathogen is such as Listeria monocogen is one such an assault, but how bacteria impact the DDR is poorly documented. Here, we report that infection with Listeria monocogen induces host DNA breaks. Strikingly, the response to these breaks is only moderately activated. We uncover the role of the listerial toxin listeriolysin (LLO) in blocking the response to DNA breaks through degradation of the sensor Mre11. Knocking out or inactivating proteins involved in DDR promotes bacterial replication showing the importance of this mechanism for control of infection. Together, our data highlight that bacterial dampening of DDR is critical for listerial infection.
Human herpes simplex viruses 1 and 2 (HSV-1 and HSV-2) are common pathogens that cause a range of diseases in humans. Although both viral and host factors are involved in HSV infection, the mechanisms are not fully understood. Here, we show that bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) plays a critical role in HSV infection by screening a chemical library of epigenetic compounds. We found that treatment with a pan-BD inhibitor enhanced HSV infection. Using JQ as a probe, we found that JQ, a BRD1 inhibitor, acts through BR4 since BR4 knockdown ablated JQ effect on HSV. BR4 regulates HSV replication through a complex involving CDK and RNAP II; JQ promotes HSV-1 infection by allocating the complex to viral promoters. BR4 suppression or CD9 inhibition impeded HSV. Our data support a model that JQ enhances infection by switching BR4 to regulation of viral expression from chromatin since transient BR4 or BR1/2 expression had similar effect to JQ treatment. In addition, BR4 is a modulator for J action on HSV and has an essential role in infection.
Noma is a devastating disease that causes severe facial disfigurement in over 140,000 malnourished children every year. The cause of noma is still unknown, but a mix of microbial infection, oral hygiene and weakened immune system likely contribute to the development of oral lesions. These lesions are plausible entry points for unidentified microorganisms that trigger gangrenous facial infections. To catalog bacteria in noma and identify noma-triggering organisms, we performed a cross-sectional study of 16S rRNA amplicons from samples of gingival fluid from twelve healthy children, twelve suffering noma ( and healthy sites ), and twelve suffering Acute Necrotizing Gingivitis ( AN ) ( and healthy sites ). Relative to healthy, samples from diseased were enriched with Spiroetes and depleted for Proteobacteria. Samples from healthy of diseased had proportions of Spiroetes and Proteob similar to healthy individuals. Samples fromoma did not have higher of Fusobacter, casting its role as causative ofoma. Microbial sampled fromoma and AN were dominated by Prevotella OT, much less in healthy sampled from same. Multivariate analysis confirmed communities healthy and sites were different. Several OTUs in Erysotrichales, Cloidales, Bacterales, Spiroeta identified as indicatorsoma, suggesting one or microbes these associated developmentoma.
In Bacillus thuringiensis is an insect pathogenic bacterium that uses quorum sensing to coordinate sporulation and survival in the insect cadaver. Quorum sensing is mediated by regulators belonging to the RNPP family and regulated by internalized signaling peptides. One such regulator, Npr, acts as a transcription factor in the presence of its cognate peptide Npr, regulating genes involved in survival in the insect cadaver. We show that Npr inhibits sporulation in the absence of Npr, independently of its transcriptional activator function, by preventing SpoA-regulated gene expression via Kin-dependent phosphorylation of phosphotransferase SpoF, thus delaying sporulation initiation. Npr displays similarities with Rap proteins, also belonging to RNPP, devoid of DNA-binding and controlling expression via protein-protein interactions. Conservation of residues interacting with SpoF suggests common inhibition of sporulation. The structure of N confirms N displays a Rap-like structure. We propose a regulatory mechanism in which residues of N are alternatively involved in its functions. N binding switches N from dimer inhibitor of sporulation to tetramer transcriptional activator in necrotrophic lifestyle. N thus coordinates sporulation and necrophism, ensuring survival and dissemination during infection.
HIV infection cannot be cured, but can be controlled by treatment with multiple antiretroviral drugs. However, different viral genotypes exist for each patient, raising the question of which drug to use for effective treatment. With genotypic and phenotyp data, computational models can be created to predict optimal treatment for patient. Current models are based on genotypic data only; chemical drug similarity is not considered. We applied proteochem models, combining chemical and protein properties in a single bioactivity model. Our dataset was a large clinical database of genotyp and phenotyp information ( ca. 300,000 drug-mut bioactivity points, 4 NNIs, 8 NIs or 9 PIs, 10,700 NNIs 10,500 NIs or 27,000 PIs ). Our models achieved a prediction error below 0.5 Log Change. Compared to published sequence models, PCM performed better in resistance prediction and classification (0.76 versus 0.91 ). We identified known and unpublished resistance-conferring mutations of Reverse Transcriptase ( e. g.102,216 ) and Protease (. e.18,88 ) from our dataset. We applied models to public HIV database obtaining a correct prediction rate 84% compared 80%.
Chemotaxis, the process by which cells move towards or away from chemical stimuli, remains poorly understood despite extensive study. Chemotaxis is thought to occur when chemoattractants cause actin polymerization, leading to pseudop formation and cell movement. However, we have proposed an alternative mechanism supported by several lines of evidence that pseudop are made by a self-generated cycle. Chemoatants modulate the cycle rather than directly causing actin polymerization. Here, we test the explanatory and predictive powers of pseudop-based models of chemotaxis. We developed a computational model of cell movement and chemaxis based on pseudop autocatalysis. The model reproduces a wide range of existing data on cell movement and chemaxis. It simulates cell polarization and persistence without chemotaxis stimuli and accurate pseudod selection when chemoatants are present. It predicts pseudod position in chemoant gradients and pseudod initiation in gradients. To test the model, we looked for untested predictions. One prediction is that the angle between successive pseudods at the front of the cell will increase with the difference between the cell direction and the chemoant gradient. We measured pseud angles in Dictyostel cells under different conditions and results agreed with the model. Our model and data suggest that pseud cycle lies at the heart of cell motility in rapidly moving cells like Dictyostel and neutrophils. This implies that chemaxis relies on modification of pseudod behaviour more than generation of pseud or actin polymer by chemoants.
Yersinia pestis is transmitted by fleas through two mechanisms: early-phase transmission (EPT) and biofilm-dependent transmission (BDT). However, the efficiency of transmission varies among flea species and results from different studies have not always been consistent. One complicating variable is the species of rodent used for the infectious blood meal. To gain insight into the mechanism of E and the effect of host blood on, fleas were fed bacteremic mouse, rat, guinea pig, or gerbil blood and the location and characteristics of infection in the digestive tract and transmissibility of Y. pest were assessed 1–3 days after. Surprisingly,–28% of rodent fleas fed bacteremic rat or guinea blood regurgated a portion of the infected meal into the esophagus within 24 h. We term this phenomenon post-infection esophageal (PIER). In contrast, P was rarely observed in rodent fleas fed bacteremic or gerbil blood. P correlated the accumulation of dense aggregate Y. pest, red cellroma, and oxyoglobin that filled proventulus. At next feeding fle with P were 3–25 more likely to appear blocked with blood within esagus than fle without P. days after feeding bacter rat blood groups Oropsa montana transmitted significantly CF than groups using mouse blood and this enhanced was biofilm. Our support a model in which E results from regurg of pest from obstructed foreut and E and B can temporally overlap.
Positive correlations in the activity of neurons are widely observed in the brain. Previous studies have shown that these correlations to be detrimental to the fidelity of population codes or marginally favorable compared to independent codes. However, we show that positive correlations can enhance coding performance by astronomical factors. Specifically, the probability of discrimination can be suppressed by many orders of magnitude. Likewise, the number of stimuli—the capacity—can be enhanced more than tenfold. These effects do not necessitate unrealistic correlation values and can occur in populations with few neurons. We show that both effects benefit from heterogeneity seen in activity. Error and capacity rest upon a pattern of correlation. Tuning of one or several parameters can yield a limit of coding: the pattern of positive correlation to a ‘lock’ response that eliminates variability in subspace for discrimination.
Cholera is a severe diarrheal disease caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholera. Protection against cholera is serogroup specific and defined by the O-specific polyscharide ( OSP ) component of lipysaccharide ( LPS. Here, we describe a cholera conjugate vaccine prepared via chemical conjugation of the OSP of Vibrio cholera O1 Inaba strain O1 with a recombinant fragment of tetanus toxin heavy chain (OSP:rTH ). We assessed a range of vaccine doses based on OSP content (10–50 μg ), varying molar ratio of OSP:rTH (3:1, 5:1,10 ), adjuvant, and route of immunization. Immunized mice developed antiOSP and antiT serum IgG, as well as vibriidal and memory cell responses following intramuscular or intrader vaccination. Intestinal IgA responses targeting OSP occurred following intrader vaccination. We found comparable immune responses in mice immunized with variations, although memory and vibidal responses were blunted in mice receiving highest dose (50 μ ). We found no appreciable change in responses when conjug vaccine was administered with or without adjuvant. Administration ofOSP:rTH resulted in 55% protective efficacy in mouse cholera model. We report an OSP:rTH conjugate vaccine that induces responses and protection against cholera in mice.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a neglected tropical disease caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and Loa loa and Mansonella perst. In Cameroon, the distribution of LF has been mapped using immunochromatographic cards (ICT) to detect circulating filarial antigen (CFA). This study investigated the cross-reactivity of ICT in areas with contrasting levels of Loa and Mansonella endemicity in Cameroon. A cross-sectional study was conducted in 42 villages across three regions (East, North-west and South ) of the rainforest domain. Blood was collected from 219 participants to detect CFA by ICT and microfilaria (M) by thick smear. Clinical manifestations of LF were also assessed. Overall, 24 individuals were positive by ICT with prevalence ranging from 0% in South-west to 2.1 in North. Lymphedema was diagnosed in 20 with majority in North (11 ) and none were positive ICT. No microf W bancft were found in positive ICT or lymphedema. Positive ICT was strongly associated with Loa M intensity (odds ratio 15.4; 95CI 6.–39.0; p.001 ) and Lo prevalence (Spearman rho.900 p.037). In contrast, no association was found between ICT and perans prevalence (Spearman rho.200 p747) and Mf (odds 1.8;95CI.–.2 p192). This study confirmed association between ICT and Lo intensity (M/ml) at individual level. Furthermore, ICT was strongly associated with Lo prevalence. These results suggest main confounding factor for ICT results are Lo levels. Findings indicate bancft is less prevalent in Central region than assumed and accurate re-mapping would be useful for shrinking LF map.
SARS-CoV replication is supported by a reticular network of modified endoplasmic reticulum. Positive-strand RNA viruses, such as SARS-CoV, replicate in the cytoplasm of host cells. Their replication complexes are commonly associated with modified cell membranes. We have applied electron tomography of cryixed cells for three-dimensional imaging of coronavirus-induced membrane alterations at high resolution. Our analysis defines a reticular network of modified endoplasm reticulum that integrates convol membranes, numerous double-membr vesicles ( DM ) and “ves packets” arising from DM merger. Convoluted membranes were abundantly immunolabeled for viralase subunits. Double-stranded RNA, presumably the site of viral synthesis, localized to DM interior.
Root suberin is a key component of the plant cell wall that has been proposed to act as a chemical barrier to water and solute transport in roots. However, the role of suberin in water and solute transport has not been supported by direct genetic evidence. Here, we show that suberin plays a critical role in controlling water and solute transport in Arabidopsis thaliana roots. The suberin1 ( es1 ) mutant, characterized by increased suberin in the root, had reduced transpiration rates and increased water-use efficiency during vegetative growth. These changes in suberin and water transport were associated with decreased accumulation of Ca, Mn, and Zn and increased accumulation of Na, S, K, Se, and Mo in the shoot.
The kinetics of rhodopsin deactivation plays a crucial role in regulating the reproducibility of the single photon response (SPR) in vertebrate phototransduction. The dynamics of rhops during its lifetime, including the number of phosphorylations, catalytic activity, and sojourn time at each phosphorylation level, contribute to the variability of electrical responses. However, the SPR is highly reproducible. To understand the mechanisms that confer such low variability, the kinetics of rhops deactivation was investigated using a Continuous Time Markov Chain (CTMC) model based on the biochemistry ofops activation and deactivation, interfaced with a spatio-temporal model of phototransduction. The model parameters were extracted from photoresponse data of wild type and mutant mice with variable numbers of phosphorylation sites. The model reproduced both wild type and mutant responses. The sources of variability were dissected into components to determine whether random number of turn steps, random soj time between, or both give rise to variability. The model shows that only randomness of soj times in phosphorylated states contributes to Coefficient Variation (CV) of response, whereas number of turn steps has negligible effect.
In this work, we develop a mathematical framework to uncouple the dynamics of a stochastic reaction network from its fluctuating environment. This is achieved by incorporating the environment's effect onto the network into a new decoupled model. We show how fluctuating extrinsic components ( e. g., chemical species ) can be marginalized to obtain this decoupled model. We derive the corresponding process and master equations for the decoupled model and show how stochastic simulations can be performed. We demonstrate the significance of the approach using several case studies.
Brain-machine interfaces (BMI) have been developed using decoders such as Kalman filters and closed-loop decoder adaptation (CLDA). However, current decoders do not model spikes directly and may limit processing-scale BMI and adaptation. We develop a novel closed-loop BMI architecture that allows processing, control, and adaptation using spike events. The architecture incorporates an infinite-hor feedback (OFC) model of the brain’s behavior in closed BMI, and a point model of spikes. The OF model infers user’s intention during CL—a termed estimation. OF is also used to design autonomous and assisted training. The process allows neural, control and adaptation with every event at a faster-scale than current decoders; also enables spike-based adaptation unlike methods that use slower adaptation. We conducted experiments in a non-human primate over days to dissociate the effects of these components. OF estimation improved performance compared with techniques. OF assisted the subject to achieve proficient. Spike-based resulted in faster and consistent compared methods and was robust initialization. The architecture extended to tasks beyond training.
Retinal ganglion cells respond to a wide range of stimuli, from natural movies to white noise. We investigated the effect of stimulus structure on correlations between ganglion cell responses and found that they were modestly correlated for spatio-temporally structured stimuli, such as movies, but less than predicted by a non-adting model. For stimuli with purely spatial correlations, ganglion responses were consistent with a static non-adting receptive field and nonlinearity. We found that ganglion cells responding to spatio-temporally correlated stimuli had faster temporal kernels and stronger surrounds than those responding to uncorrelated stimuli. These properties, along with changes in effective contrast at ganglion input, explained pairwise correlations across receptive field measurements.
Genetic interactions occur when a combination of mutations results in a surprising phenotype. These interactions capture functional redundancy and are important for predicting, dissecting complexes into functional pathways and exploring the mechanistic underpinnings of common diseases. Synthetic and sickness are the most studied types of interactions in yeast. However, only a small proportion of gene pairs have been tested for interactions due to the number of possible gene pairs. To expand the set of synthetic lethal ( SL ) interactions, we have devised an integrative multi-network for predicting interactions that improves upon existing approaches. We defined a number of features characterizing relationships between genes from data. These features are independent of known interactions, in contrast to previous approaches. Using these features, developed a non-parametric multi-classifier for interactions that enabled simultaneous use of multiple procedures. Several experiments demonstrated SL features in conjunction with classification led to improved performance compared to current method. Using this, derived the first transcription factor genetic network, supported by literature. Also used this to interactions between non-essential yeast ( http://sage. fh.downloads/predict_yeast_interactions. ).
The BRCA Challenge is a long-term data-sharing project initiated by the Global Alliance for Genomics and Health (GAH) to aggregate BRCA1 and BRCA2 data to support collaborative research. The project aims to generate an informed understanding of the impact of genetic variation on cancer risk across the iconic predisposition genes BRCA1 and BR2. Initially, BRCA and BR2 variants from public databases were integrated into a single site, www. brcaexchange. org. The BR Exchange provides the community with a reliable and easily accessible record of interpreted variants for high-penetr phenotype. More than 20, 000 variants have been aggregated, three times the number in the largest public database at project outset, approximately 7, 250 have classifications. The data is based on information from clinical databases—Breast Cancer Core (ICBIC), ClinVar and Leiden Variation (LOD) as well as population databases linked to single access.
Malaria, caused by the apicomplex parasite Plasmodium, is a major threat to human health and leads to about one million deaths annually. Plmod is a rapidly multiplying unicellular organism with a complex life cycle in man and mosquito that requires adaptation to various environments. In order to deal with reactive oxygen species and maintain redox processes and pathogenicity, Plmod depends on adequate redox balance. By studying subcellular localization of antioxidant and redox proteins, we obtained the complete map of red compartment in Plmodium falcum. We demonstrate targeting of Plmod peroxiredoxins and putative glyal system to apoplast, a nonphotosynthetic plastid. We obtained complete picture of compartment of thiorexin and glutaredin-like proteins. Notably, major redoxenzymes glutathione reduct and thioreduct Plmod use alternative-initiation ( ATI ) to achieve differential localization.
The intrinsically disordered protein (ID) PUM binds to its partner Mcl-1 through its BH3 motif, which folds into an α-helix upon binding. We used a structure-based coarse-grained model with an explicit Debye-Hück charge to investigate the role of electrostatic interactions in the coupled folding and binding process. The model was calibrated with experimental data on helical content and binding affinity and shown to be consistent with previously published data on binding changes with respect to ionic strength. We found that intramolecular electrostatic interactions influence unbound PUM only marginally. However, intermolecular electrostatic interactions, particularly non-native electrostatic interactions, are involved in the formation of the initial complex. Our results reveal the binding mechanism in more detail than possible with experimental data alone and uncover the role of non-native electrostatic interactions.
Polycomb group (Pc) proteins are conserved chromatin factors that maintain the silencing of key developmental genes outside their expression domains. Recent genome-wide analyses have shown that Polycomb proteins bind to discrete Polycomb response elements (PREs). Within the nucleus, Poly proteins localize in structures called Polycomb bodies that contain Poly-silenced genes, and it has been shown that PREs form long-range networks. Here, we studied the nuclear distribution of two Poly proteins, Polyhomeotic (PH) and Polyhomeotic (PC). Using a combination of immunostaining, immuno-FISH and live imaging of GFP proteins, we analyzed the formation and motion of Poly bodies during fly embryogenesis as well as their behavior compared to the condensed fraction of euchromatin. ImmunoISH experiments show that Poly bodies correspond to 3D counterparts of linear domains identified in genome-wide studies. During embryogenesis, Poly and PH progressively accumulate in Poly bodies, which form structures localized on euchatin domains containing histone H3-methylated on K27. Time-lapse analysis indicates two types of influence the displacement of Poly bodies and chromatin containing H2-G. First, chromatin and Poly bodies undergo long-range motions that correspond to the movement of chromosome territories. Second, each Poly body and chromatin has its fast highly constrained motion. In this regime, Poly move within volumes larger than chromatin domains. Moreover, both types move volumes much smaller chromosome, restricting their interaction with other structures.
Somatic mutations in the mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) have been implicated in the aging process, but there is no universally accepted method for their quantification. We have used ultra-deep sequencing to study the genome-wide mtDNA load in the liver of normally-aging and prematurely-aging mice that are homozygous for an allele expressing proofreading–deficient mtDNA polymerase (mtDNA mut mice ). We found that mt mut mice have 10–times higher mutation loads than their wildtype siblings. In addition, mt mice have increased levels of truncated mtDNA, resulting in decreased coverage in deleted regions. In contrast, mt molecules with deletions occur at extremely low frequencies in mt mice and therefore do not drive premature aging. Sequence analysis shows that the proportion of mutations in heterozygous mt mice and wildtype siblings is inherited from heterozygous mothers consistent with germl transmission. We found no increase in mutations or deletions in wild C57/6 mice with increasing, thus questioning causative role these in aging. In addition, there was no frequency transversions with time in any genotypes, arguing against damage as major mt mutations.
The Na+-driven ATP synthase of the anaerobic bacterium Fusobacterium nucleatum uses glutamate decarboxylation to generate a transmembrane Na+ gradient. We demonstrate that this ionotive force is directly coupled to ATP synthesis via F1FoATP synthase with a novel Na+ recognition motif shared by human pathogens. Molecular modeling and free-energy simulations of the c-ring indicate Na+ specificity in physiological settings. Consistently, activity measurements show Na+ stimulation of either membrane-embedded or isolated enzyme and ATP synthesis is sensitive to Na ionophore monens. Furthermore, Na has a protective effect against inhibitors targeting ion-binding sites in both ATPase and c-ring. Definitive evidence of Na coupling is provided by two crystal structures of c-ring solved at 2. 2 and 2. 6 Å resolution at 5. 3 and 8.7, respectively. Na+ occupy all sites, coordinated by amino acids and water. Intriguingly carboxylates mediate ion binding. Simulations and experiments demonstrate this implies a proton is bound all sites although Na drives mechanism. The structure reveals new ion coupling in ATPases and provides basis for drug efforts against opportunistic pathogen.
T cell activation is a key event in the initiation of adaptive immunity. T cells recognize foreign peptides bound to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules on the surface of antigen presenting cells. In vitro, high-affinity and long-lived interactions between T cell receptors (TCR) and MHC correlate with high potency T activation. However, little is known about the influence of TCRM interaction on cell responses in vivo. We studied the influence of TCRM characteristics on cell immunity by tracking CD4+ cell activation, effector, and memory responses to immunization with peptides exhibiting a range of TCRM half-lives and in vitro activation potencies. We found that optimal in vivo cell responses occur to ligands with intermediate TCRM halfives. This is contrary to predictions from in vitro studies. In vivo responses to ligands with longest TCRM halfives were associated with attenuation of intracellular signaling, expansion, and function over a range of time.
Ascomycous fungus Nria haematocca, a member of the Fusarium solani complex, is a highly diverse species that can cause disease in >100 plant genera and opportunistic infections in humans. The most studied member of this complex, N. haematocca mating population VI ( MP ) has 17 chromosomes ranging from 530 kb to 6. 52 Mb and a genome size of 54. 43 Mb and 15, 707 predicted genes, the largest in ascomycetes. Two classes of genes contribute to expansion: those not found in other fungi, including its relative Fusarium gramineum, and those commonly single in other fungi but multiple in N. haematca MP. Some may have resulted from duplication, others from horizontal transfer. Supernumerary chromosomes 14, 15, and 17 were confirmed absent in pulsed gel electrophoresis experiments lacking chromosome-specific sequences on ends. These have more repeat sequences, unique genes, and lower G+C content than others.
Herpesviruses are enveloped viruses that egress from infected cells through a dynamic process involving the host secretory pathway and viral components. To elucidate the location, dynamics, and molecular mechanisms of herpesvirus egress, we developed a live fluorescence microscopy method to visualize the transport and exocytosis of pseudorabies virus ( PR ) particles in non-polar epithelial cells. This method is based on total reflection ( TIR ) microscopy to image virus near the plasma, and takes advantage of a virus-encoded probe to visualize the precise location of exytosis. We performed single-particle tracking and squared analysis to characterize particle, and imaged a panel of proteins to identify spatially and dynamically associated with exyt. Based on our data, individual particles travel to the plasma inside acidified secretory vesicles. GTPases Rab6, Rab8, and Rab11, regulators of the membrane secretory pathway, are present on the vesicles. These vesicles undergo fast directional transport to the site of exyt, which is frequently near LLβ, part of a complex that anchors microtubules to the plasma. Vesicles are docked at the site exyt for seconds and fusion occurs, displacing the virion across the plasma. After exyt, particles remain confined on the outer surface.
Infection with Enterobius vermicularis and treatment with mebendazole has a significant impact on the intestinal microbiota and immune response in children. In this study, we recruited 109 first grade school children in Taich, Taiwan, 30 pin-negative and 79 pin-infected, to examine the effect of meendazole on gut microbiota and immune responses. We collected fecal samples from pin-infected individuals at 2 weeks after meendazole treatment. We found that Enterob infection increased gut diversity and peaked after meend treatment.
