At the phylum level, pin and meend were associated with decreased abundance of Fusobacteria and increased Actinobacteria. At genus level, relative abundance of probiotic Bifobacterium increased after Enterob and meend treatment. Intestinal SIg level was lower in pin-inf group and elevated in meend-treated. Higher pre-treatment Salmonella was associated with increased SI after meend dewing.
Genome-wide association analysis of root length in Arabidopsis thalian reveals epist cancellation of additive genetic variance. We examined the genetics of root length in Arabidopsis thalian and found that the narrow-sense heritability for this trait in the examined population was statistically zero. The amount of additive variance that could be captured by genome-wide genotypes likely explains why no associations to length could be found using standard additive-based genome-wide association (GWA) approaches. However, the broad-sense herit for length was larger and primarily due to epist. We performed epist GWA to map loci contributing to epist genetic variance. Four pairs of loci were revealed, involving seven chromosomal loci that passed a standard-testing threshold. The genotype-phenotype for these pairs revealed epist that cancelled out genetic, explaining why loci were not detected in WA. We estimated the risk of false positives using a new approach and suggested that half the pairs were true associations. Our evaluation of candidate within the loci suggests this estimate is conservative; we identified genes that affected root in four loci were part of three pairs. The epist analyses were indispensable for confirming and identifying genes for length in this population of wild-collected A. thaliana accessions.
Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) mutations are a common cause of human disease and have been found to occur multiple times in the world population. The clinical presentation of disease-causing mtDNA mutations is strongly associated with mtDNA haplogroup, but it is not clear whether this is limited to a few examples or a general phenomenon. We determined the characteristics of 30,506 mtDNA sequences globally. After quality control, we established a pathogenic score for each allele. The pathogenic score for disease-causing mutations was significantly different between mtDNA haplogroups. Several mutations were observed in all haplogroups, whereas others only in specific clades. In some, this was a founder effect, but others recurred in same phylogenetic cluster. Sequence diversity showed disease-causing were more frequent in young sequences and genomes with two or more disease-causing were more than expected by chance.
Cells are able to coordinate their motion to achieve collective motility in processes such as cancer metastasis, embryonic development, and wound healing. To study cell-cell interactions, including contact inhibition of locomotion ( CIL), micropatterned substrates are used to restrict cell migration to linear, quasi-one-dimensional paths. In these assays, polarized cells frequently collide with only a few possible outcomes: reversing direction, sticking to one another, or walking past one. Using a phase field model of collective motility that includes cell mechanics and a minimal CIL model, we reproduce all outcomes in two-cell collisions. A balance between cell polarization, C and cell adhesion governs the outcome. We identify parameters that control transitions between outcomes: cell adhesion strength, propulsion, and C rates. These suggest why different cell types have different collision behavior and effect interventions that modulate outcomes. To reproduce heterogeneity in outcomes observed in neural crest cells, we must either tune parameters or assume significant variation in key parameters like adhesion.
Thioredoxin (Tr) mixed disulfide dissociation has been a topic of debate for more than twenty years. The role of the nucleophilic cysteine in the dissociation of the complex has been controversial. We used the complex between Tr and its endogenous substrate arsenate reductase (ArsC) as a model. In this complex, a CysTr-CysArs disulfide is formed by nucleophil attack of CysTr on exposed CysArs-CysArs in oxidizedArs. We studied Tr disulfide dissociation by theoretical analysis, molecular simulations and biochemical experiments with cysteine mutants. We observed conformation changes around the disulfide bring Cys in contact with Cys. Cys is activated for nucleophil attack by hydrogen, andys is more reactive thanysArs. Additionally,ys directs nucleophil attack on moreys thanysArs. This multidisciplinary approach provides insights into universal thiol/disulf exchange mechanism in reduced and oxidTr.
People’s preferences are not fixed and can be influenced by the preferences of others. We hypothesise that people are uncertain about their tastes and can learn about them by considering the preferences of others and updating their beliefs. If a person’s choice reflects uncertainty, then the degree of taste change should correlate with their choice variability. Temporal discounting is an example of taste-for-patience. We examined discount preferences in a large study of 14–24 year olds. We assessed discount behaviour, including variability before and after observing another’s choices. We found evidence for taste uncertainty and Bayesian updating. First, decision variability was better accounted for by random-taste than response-noise model. Second, taste shifts were described by Bayesian taking into account uncertainty and social information.
In the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, filamentous growth is a complex process that is regulated by multiple signaling pathways. We used a novel approach called secretion profiling to measure the release of the extracellular domain of Msb2, a mucin that functions at the head of the filamentous growth ( FG ) MAPK pathway. Secretion profiling of a genomic collections showed that many pathways that regulate filamentous growth ( AS, RIM, O1, and RT ) were also required for FG pathway activation. This sensitized the pathway to multiple stimuli and synchronized it to the global network. Several regulators were required for MS2 expression, which identifies MS2 as a target where multiple signals converge. Accessibility to MS2 was regulated by histone deacetylase Rpd3L, which positively regulated pathway and filament growth.
Fruiting body development in filamentous fungi is a complex process that has been shaped by changes in gene expression during evolution. In this study, we tested the hypothesis that changes in gene expression are important for the evolution of divergent morphologies. We examined five species of Sordarcomycetes in a common environment and measured gene expression at five developmental stages. We reconstructed ancestral expression phenotypes and identified genes with the largest increases in expression during development. We then conducted knockouts and phenotypic analysis in two divergent species and found altered fruiting development in the species with increased expression. Our approach was more efficient than other studies that targeted whole genomes or gene families. Combining expression with phenotypes refined Bayesian networks underlying fruit body regulation, which is one of the least understood processes in multicellular development.
Schistosome eggs are an attractive targets for transgenesis because they have a high ratio of germ to somatic cells and can be propagated by infecting snails with miracidia hatched from treated eggs. We investigated the utility of square electroporation to deliver transgenes and macromolecules into Schistosoma mansoni eggs. Eggs were incubated with Cy-labeled siRNA and without electrop and Cy-signals were detected by microscopy in eggs and miria hatched from treated. Electrop was employed to introduce mRNA encoding firefly luciferase into eggs. Luciferase was detected 3 hours later, whereas lucifer was not evident in eggs soaked in mRNA. Schist eggs were exposed to Moloney leukemia virions ( ML ) pseudotyped with vesicular stomatitis glycoprotein ( V ). Proviral trans were detected by PCR in DNA from miria hatched virion-exposed, indicating trans in larval schosomes had been electorated. However, qPCR determined electrop virions resulted 2–3 times copies in schosomes compared to alone. In addition, qPCR indicated copy for proviral lucifer trans ∼20 copies 100 endogenous cathepsin.
Large macromolecular assemblies are important for many biological processes in cells, and allosteric communications between different parts of these machines play critical roles in cellular signaling. However, studies of the topology and fluctuation dynamics of coarse-grained residue networks do not provide characterization of the time-dependent behavior of macromolecular assemblies. Here, we develop a novel approach called Perturbation Markovian Transmission (PM) to study the dynamic responses of macrom assemblies. By monitoring responses of all residues (>8,000) across many (>6) decades of time from perturbation until equilibrium using Kry subspace projection, we show that this approach can yield rich information. With criteria of quantitative measurements of relaxation-time, flow change, and oscillation, this approach can identify residues important for macrom movement, messenger that mediate signal, and important for binding.
The nematode Caenorhabditis elegans is sensitive to the fungal galectin CGL2 from the mushroom Coprinus cinerea. When C. elegans is fed CGL2, its development is inhibited and it is ultimately killed. This effect is not due to the carbohydrate-binding activity of C2, but rather its interaction with a fucose-containing glycojugate. A screen of C2-resistant C elegans mutants identified the glycojugate as a Gal1, 4Fuc1, 6 modification of the nemode’s N-glycan core. This was confirmed by analysis of N-gcan structures in wild and C2-resistant C elegans and identification of a putative glycosyltransferase required for its biosynthesis. The X-ray structure of C2 bound to the Gal1, 4uc, 6lcNA trischar at 1. 5 Å resolution revealed the basis for this interaction. Our results suggest that fungal galectins play a role in defense against predators by binding specific glycojugates of these organisms.
Latent reservoirs of latently infected CD4+ T cells are a major barrier to curing HIV and have been extensively studied. However, the effect of these reservoirs on the evolutionary dynamics of the virus has received little attention. We present a within-host quasis model that incorporates a long-lived reservoir and nest it into an epidemiological model of HIV. For biologically plausible parameter values, we find that the presence of a reservoir severely delays evolutionary dynamics within a host, with longer delays associated with larger reservoir sizes and homeostatic proliferation of cells within reservoir. These delays change the dynamics of virus at epidemiological scale. In particular, the delay within evolutionary dynamics is sufficient for virus to evolve intermediate loads consistent with maximising transmission, as observed, not very high loads previous models predicted. This effect can be enhanced if viruses similar to those initiating infection are preferentially transmitted. Results depend on within characteristics such as reservoir size, with evolution observed only when dynamics sufficiently delayed.
Coxsackievirus B3 Inhibits Antigen Presentation In Vivo, Exerting Profound and Selective Effect on MHC Class I Pathway
Leprosy Type 1 reactions are a major cause of nerve damage and preventable disability. Lepros Type 1 reactions are treated with corticosteroids, but there are few data to support the optimal dose and duration of treatment. Lep Type 1 reactions have a Th1 immune profile with cutaneous and neural lesions expressing interferon-γ and interleukin-12. Methylprednisone has been used in Th1 mediated diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis to switch off the immune response. We investigated the efficacy of three days high dose (1 g ) intravenous methylprednisone at start of prednisone therapy in Lep Type 1 reactions and nerve impairment. Forty individuals were randomised to methylprednisone followed oral predone ( n ) or oral predone ( n ). There were no differences in rate of adverse events or improvement at completion of study. Individuals treated methylprednisone were less likely those predone to experience deterioration in function between 29 and 113 of study. The study demonstrated 50% Type 1 and nerve impairment required additional predone despite weeks corticoids.
Regulatory CD4+CD25highFoxP+ T cells (Tregs) have been shown to modulate CD8 T cell responses in HIV-negative settings by maintaining the balance between memory and effector CD8 T cells, at least in part through the PD-1/PD-L pathway. Here, we investigated the effects of Tregs on CD8 responses in chronic HIV infection. Tregs from HIV-infected patients (Treg/HIV) did not inhibit polyclonal autologous CD8 T function, suggesting a defect in suppressive capacity of Treg or lack of sensitivity of effector cells in HIV. However, Treg inhibited IFNγ expression of autolog CD8 cells stimulated with CMV/EBV/Flu (CEF) antigens, but not HIV-specific CD8 cells. In cross cultures, Treg inhibited differentiation of CEF- or HIV-specific CD8 cells from infected patients. PD-1 and PD-L expression was higher on HIV-specific CD8 cells compared to CEF CD8 cells, and did not change after Treg depletion or co-culture with Treg, unlike C-specific CD8 cells. We show a defect of Treg in modulating differentiation and expression of PD-1/P-L on HIV CD8 cells. Our results suggest this defect might contribute to exhaustion of HIV-specific responses.
Lymphatic filarial parasites, such as Wuchereria bancrofti, survive in the lymphatic vessels for years by adopting immunomodulatory strategies, including the release of glutathione-transferases ( GSTs ) that counteract oxidative radicals produced by the host. Since GSTs are critical for parasite survival, several studies have evaluated GSTs as vaccine candidates against schistosiasis, fascias and Seteria. However, the potential of GSTs of lymphatic parasites has not been evaluated. In this study, GST was cloned from the third larval ( L ) cDNA of Wucher bancroft and recombinant GST ( rWGST ) was expressed and purified. Serum from individuals living in an endemic area were analyzed for reactivity with rWGST. Results showed that sera from endemic individuals ( EN ) carried significant levels of anti-WGST IgG compared to microfilaremic ( M ) or clinical pathology ( CP ) subjects. Isotype analysis of anti-WGST Ig showed predominance of Ig1 and Ig3 in EN. Subsequent analysis of rGST showed that rGST retained enzymatic activity and EN sera could inhibit this activity. Similar results were obtained when antiGST raised in mice were used in neutral assay. Brug mal GST and WGST show significant similarity. To evaluate rGST potential, we used B mal L as parasites. rGST was evaluated by confirming human and mouse GST in antibody dependent cytotoxic ( AD ) assay. Subsequent vaccination in j showed approximately 61% protection against B L challenge in jirds immunized rGST. Results show rGST is a candidate against lymphatic.
CRISPR-Cas technologies have revolutionized genome editing of experimental organisms and hold immense therapeutic potential. Despite advances in understanding of the CRPR-Cas system, concerns remain over potential off-target effects. Recent studies have addressed these using whole-genome sequencing (WGS) of gene-ed embryos to search for de novo mutations (DNMs), which may represent changes introduced by editing. However, these studies used strain-matched but not pedigree-matched controls and were unable to distinguish generational or colony differences from DNMs. Here, we used a trio design and whole genome sequenced 8 parents and 19 embryos, 10 of which were mutised with well-characterised gRNAs targeting the coat Tyrosinase (Tyr) locus. Detailed analyses of these genome data allowed us to conclude that if CRPR mutagenesis were causing SN or indel off-target mutations in embryos then the number of these is not distinguishable from background DNMs due to other processes.
Stomatal aperture is a critical for photosynthesis and transpiration in plants. Stomata are located on the leaf epidermis and regulate CO2 uptake and water loss. Stomatal aperture affects photosynthesis, water use, and crop yields. Blue light is one of the environmental signals that regulates stomatal aperture and is perceived by blue/UV-A light-absor cryptochromes phototropins. The signal cascades that link light to stomatal response are largely unknown. We report two new players, Hypersensitive Red 1 ( HR1 ) and Proteinosphatase 7 ( PP7 ), and their genetic and biochemical interactions in stomatal control. Mutations in HR1 or PP lead to stomatal misregulation and reduce water loss under light. HR1 and PP are expressed in guard cells in response to light-dark or dark-light transition. HR1 interacts PP through N-terminal zinc finger motif and requires PP for stomatal response. HR1 is phosphorylated in vivo and PP dephosphorylates HR1. HR is dephosphorylated in 193 kDa complex in dark and light increases to 285Da. In PP mutant this shift is impaired and HR is phosphorylated. We propose HR modification by PP under light is essential for proper HR conformation or new components for HR complex.
The Mediator subunit MDT-15 plays a crucial role in regulating gene expression in response to ingested materials in Caenorhabditis elegans. MDT-15 is a component of the Mediator complex, a multisubunit that interacts with transcription factors such as the sterol response binding protein SBP-1 and the nuclear receptor NHR-49 to regulate fatty acid metabolism. Here, we show that MDT-15 has a broader role in integrating responses to ingested materials. Depletion of MDT-15 or mutation of the mdt-15 gene impairs induction of detoxification genes in response to xenobiotics and heavy metals, making animals hypersensitive to toxins. In contrast, MDT-15 does not affect other stress responses, such as thermotolerance. MDT-15 appears to selectively affect responses to ingestion, as MDT defects do not abrogate other stress responses. Together with previous findings that MDT:NHR-49 complexes coordinate the fasting response, we propose that MDT integrates several transcriptional pathways to monitor the availability and quality of ingested materials, including nutrients and xenobiotics.
The hippocampus is the brain region responsible for creating a mental map of an animal’s environment. It has been assumed that the hippocampus encodes geometric information such as distances and angles. However, the hippocampus consists of patterns of spiking activity across many neurons and downstream regions must be able to translate those patterns into information about an animal’s spatial environment. We hypothesize that the temporal pattern of neuronal firing, particularly co-firing, is key to decoding spatial information and since coiring implies spatial overlap of place, a map by coiring will be based on connectivity and adjacency, i. e. it will be topological. We test this topological hypothesis with a model of hippocampal activity varying parameters firing rate, place field size and number of neurons in simulations of rat in topologically and geometrically distinct environments. We find that patterns of neuronal coiring convey topological information about environment in biologically realistic time. Furthermore, simulations reveal a “learning” region that highlights interplay between parameters combining to produce hippocamp states more or less adept at map. For example, within learning a lower number of neurons can be compensated by adjustments firing or place size but beyond point formation begins to fail.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) production involves the assembly of virions on the surface of lipid droplets and envelopment at the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) in association with components of very low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) synthesis and egress via the secretory pathway. However, the cellular requirements and mechanistic understanding of HCV secretion are incomplete. We combined RNA interference (RNAi) analysis of host factors for HCV secretion with development of live imaging of H core trafficking to gain a detailed understanding of H egress. RNA studies identified components of the secretory pathway including endoplasmic reticulum (ER) to Golgi trafficking, lipid and protein kinases that regulate budding from trans-Golgi network (TGN), VAMP vesicles and adaptor, and recycling endosome. Our results support a model wherein HCV is infectious enveloped at ER and exits the cell via secretory pathway.
Loss of imprinting of the gene Grb10 promotes tumor formation in irradiated Nf1−/− mice. Imprinted genes are expressed from only one parental allele and heterozygous loss of the allele is sufficient to produce complete loss of expression. Genetic alterations are common in tumorigenesis but the role of imprinted genes in this process is not well understood. In this work, mice were mutagenized heterozygous for the Neurofibromatosis tumor suppressor gene (NF1) to model radiotherapy-associated malignant neoplas that arise in irradiated NF patients. Expression of cell lines established from mouse models identified Gr10 as absent. Gr10 is imprinted and polymorphism of lines and tumors demonstrates the allele commonly lost in NF mutant arising in mouse. We performed studies to test whether Gr10 restoration or loss alter fundamental features the growth. Restoring10 in mutant tumors decreases proliferation, soft agar formation and downregulates Ras. Conversely,10 silencing in untransform embryo significantly increased proliferation and Ras-G levels. Expression a constitutively ME rescued cells from10-mediated in colony. These reveal that10 can occur during tumorigenesis with consequence in untransform primary. In,10 loss promotes Ras hyperactivation which proliferation, feature of development.
Pavlovian fear conditioning is an aversive learning process in which animals learn to predict threat from environmental cues. The neural mechanisms supporting this process are not well understood. Different computational models give different predictions for the trial-by-trial dynamics of learning. We investigated autonomic nervous system ( AN ) responses to conditioned stimuli during Pavlov fear conditioning. We used a statistical framework for psychophysiological modelling to obtain precise, trial-by-trial, single-subject estimates of AN responses. We considered previously proposed non-probabilistic, probabilistic, and non-learning models as well as different observation functions to link models with AN activity. Across three experiments, both skin conductance ( SCR ) and pupil size ( PS ) responses were best explained by a probabilistic model. Notably, SCR and PS reflect different quantities of the model: SCR a mixture of expected outcome and uncertainty, while PS track expected alone. By combining psychophysiological modelling with computational theory, we provide evidence that Pavlov threat in humans may rely on probabilistic inference and estimation of uncertainty.
In the filamentous fungus Aspergillus nidulans, the septation network (SIN) plays a key role in cytokinesis and asexual reproduction. The SIN is composed of a conserved SepH (Cdc7) kinase cascade, while the mitogen-activated protein (MAP) pathway responds to stress and environmental factors via successive phosphorylation. In this study, we identified PomA as a negative regulator of septation and conidiation in A. The pom mutant is defective in septation and conidiation, while overexpression of pomA suppresses septation. Under normal conditions, Sep positively regulates phosphorylation of MAP-Hog, while Pom negatively affects this process. In the absence of Pbs, a putative upstream member of Hog, Pom and Sep are unable to affect Hog phosphorylation. Under osmotic conditions, phosphorylated Hog bypasses the requirement of Sep, a key in early cytokinesis, but not Mob/Sid, last in the SIN kinase cascade, indicating osmotic-induced septation bypasses Sep requirement but not SIN. Our findings demonstrate crosstalk between SIN and MAP pathways. Pom and Sep indirectly regulate Hog phosphorylation through Hog upstream kinases.
Leishmanias is a vector-borne disease endemic in Latin America that causes approximately 20 thousand cases per year. The pathogenesis of the disease is not fully understood. Clinical manifestations vary from cutaneous leishmanias ( CL ) to severe outcomes such as disseminated leishiasis ( DL ) mucosal leishias ( ML ) and diffuse cutaneous leishias ( DCL. Recent studies have reported that the presence of Leish RNA virus 1 ( LRV1 ) is an important factor associated with the severity of ML in experimental models. This study investigated the presence of LRV in 156 patients with leishias clinical diagnoses (109 CL; 38; ML; 5 CL+ML; DL and 1 DCL and molecular diagnoses. LRV was tested by RT-PCR and Leish species were determined by HSP PCR-RPL. LRV was detected in 71. 1% ( n 27 ) of mucosal lesions and 36.7 ( n 40 ) of cutaneous lesions. The ratio of LRV+ to LRV- was 2.93 ( CI 1.57–5.46; p<.001. LRV is associated with the occurrence of mucosal leishias, as previously described in animal models. LRV is not the only factor contributing to disease.
Type I interferon (IFN) plays an important role in the host defense against Streptococcus pneumoniae infection by counteracting the transmigration of bacteria from the lung to blood. We show that mice lacking the type I interferon receptor (Ifar−/− ) or treated with a neutralizing antibody against type interferon exhibited enhanced development of bacteremia following intranasal pneumoccal infection, while maintaining bacterial numbers in the lung. In contrast, treatment of mice with IFβ or IF-inducing synthetic double stranded RNA ( poly:C ) dramatically reduced development of bacteremia following intral infection with S pneumonia. IFβ led to upregulation of tight junction proteins and downregulation of pneumoccal receptor platelet activating factor receptor (PAF receptor ). In accordance with these findings, IF reduced pneumoccal invasion across epithelial and endothelial layers and If− mice showed enhanced lung permeability.
Spiking neural networks with a single layer employing reward-modulated spike dependent plasticity (STDP) are capable of learning simple foraging tasks. Here, we demonstrate pattern and continuous learning in a network of spiking neurons with multiple layers. The network utilized both reward-modulated and non-rewardulated STDP and multiple mechanisms for homeostatic regulation of efficacy, including heterosynaptic plasticity, gain control, output normalization of STDP, and limits on synaptic strength. We found that addition of a layer of neurons employing nonrewarded ST created that responded to specific combinations of inputs and performed basic classification of patterns. When combined with a layer implementing ST, the network was able to learn discrimination between rewarding and punishing patterns despite absence of labeled data. Synaptic noise allowed trial-and-error learning that identified goal-oriented strategies effective in solving task.
ELF5 drives metastasis in luminal breast cancer through recruitment of Gr1+CD11+ myeloid-derived suppressor cells.
Chromatin loops play a crucial role in determining the level of cell-to-cell variability in gene expression. The interaction between chromatin loops can be characterized by three factors: connection pattern, distance between regulatory elements, and communication. We propose a model that maps three fundamental patterns of interacting DNA loops into a 4-state stochastic model of transcription. We show that side-by-side loops enhance expression and reduce noise, whereas alternating loops have opposite effects. We compare the effects of facilitated and direct looping on gene expression and find that the former performs better than the latter in controlling expression and reducing noise. However, this control is distance-dependent and remarkable for moderate loop lengths, there is a limit such that the difference between the two forms almost disappears.
Metabolic engineering is increasingly dependent on RNA technology to rewire the metabolism to maximize production. To this end, riboregulators allow dynamic repression of gene expression without the need of potentially burdensome coexpressed protein like Hfq small RNAs and clustered interspaced short palindrom repeats. Despite this advantage, no general principles are available to develop repress ribg, limiting the availability and development of these ribg. To overcome this lack of knowledge on repress ribg, translation inhibiting RNAs were developed from scratch. These ribg explore features related to thermodynam and structural factors attributed to translation modulation. A library of 12 structural and therm features were defined from which six were retained after correlations from in silico generated ribg. From this library, 18 ribg were selected using design and constructed coexpressed with two untranslated regions to link inhib RNA features to functionality. The ribg in design showed repression to% of original expression, which could be explained by ordinary squares model. To allow forward engineering, squares model was constructed and validated to link properties rib to repression. This model both structural and therm features important for efficient repression by rib.
Transient associations among neurons are thought to underlie memory and behavior. However, little is known about how such associations occur or how they can be identified. Here we recorded local field ( LFP ) activity at multiple sites within the cortex of awake monkeys and organotypic cultures of cortex. We show that when the activity of a neuronal group exceeds threshold, its pattern, reflected in LFP, occurs without distortion at other cortex via synaptic transmission. These large-amplitude LFPs, which we call coherence potentials, extend hundreds of milliseconds and mark periods of loss-less spread temporal information like action potentials single-cell.
Although the size of the nucleus is correlated with the size of the cell, the mechanism by which this correlation is achieved is not well understood. To identify the factors involved in this process, we performed a systematic screen of yeast deletion mutants. The screen identified 25 factors that are essential for nuclear size, and our analysis implicated RNA processing and LINC complexes in size control. This study has revealed both smaller and larger nuclear phenotypes and identified global processes and structural components important for size.
Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is an effective treatment for neurological disorders such as Parkinson’s disease and essential tremor (ET). Presently, DB involves delivering a train of pulses with constant frequency via electrodes implanted in the brain. Closed-loop approaches deliver stimulation according to ongoing brain activity, potentially improving efficiency and reducing side effects. Success depends on devising a strategy that minimizes neural oscillations associated with motor symptoms. A step towards this is constructing a mathematical model describing how oscillations change when stimulation is applied. We use coupled oscillators to represent neurons generating pathological oscillations. A reduced Kuramoto model is used to analyse how patients respond to stimulation when oscillations have a given phase and amplitude, provided conditions are satisfied. For patients, the best strategy should be phase specific and stimulation should have greater effect when oscillation amplitude is lower. This is compared with data from ET patients. In light of this, we propose a new strategy combining phase-locked and adaptive DB.
Schistosomias is one of the most common parasitic diseases affecting over 230 million people worldwide. Schistoma mans is the main species causing intestinal and hepatic schosiasis and fresh water pulmon snails of the genus Biomalaria are best known for their role as intermediate hosts of the parasite. We developed a new molecular assay for large-scale screening of snails from transmission to detect the presence of schosomes. Our work focussed on developing and evaluating a LAMP assay with a simple DNA extraction to detect S mans in experimentally infected snails as diagnostic for field conditions. We designed a LAMP using a set of primers targeting S mans ribosomal intergenic 28S-18 rRNA. The limit of LAMP was 0. 1 of mans DNA at 63°C for 50 minutes. L was evaluated by S mans in B sn experimentally exposed at different times post-exposure: prepatent period before cercarial shedding, infections sn exposed a number of miria and detection sn in pooled samples within group uninfected sn. DNA LAMP was obtained using commercial kit or simple NaOH extraction. We detected mans in all sn using no complicated procedure for obtaining. Our assay, Biom-LAMP, is specific, rapid and potentially cost-effective for screening intermediate hosts with mans in snails and pooled samples. It is suitable for large-scale surveys schos campaigns in endemic areas.
Dengue has been reported as a public health problem in Sri Lanka since the 1960s and has become a priority for public health authorities. The Ministry of Health is responsible for controlling deng and other outbreaks and associated health care. Involvement of large numbers of health staff in deng control year-round and provision of free care to deng patients at secondary hospitals places a financial burden on the health sector. We estimated public costs of deng control and hospitalizations in Colombo, the most urban district in Sri Lanka, during epidemic 2012 from Ministry’s perspective. The costs borne by health agencies and hospitals collected using tools designed for study and retrospectively analysed using combination of activity and costing approaches. Total of deng control and hospitalizations estimated US$3.45 million (US.50 capita in Colombo 201. Personnel accounted largest of costs deng control (79% ) and hospitalizations (46% ). indicated capita of US0.42 deng control. Hospitalization ranged betweenUS–609 for pediatric andUS–866 adult according disease and treatment.
European Y-chromosome haplogroup R1b1b (R-M269) is the most common Y-chromosome lineage in Europe, carried by approximately 110 million men. Previous studies suggested a Paleolithic origin, but we show that the geographical distribution of microsatellite diversity is best explained by spread from a single source in the Near East via Anatolia during the Neolithic. This indicates that most European Y-chromosomes originate from the Neolithic expansion.
Motor learning is a complex process that can be influenced by a variety of factors. While it has been suggested that movement variability can increase the speed of motor learning, we use computational modeling to show that it can have both positive and negative effects on learning. Experimentally, we find that variability can also have decelerating effects on learning. However, through a meta-analysis of published papers, we find that across a wide range of experiments, movement has no statistical relation with learning rate.
RelA, a member of the NF-κ family, interacts with transcriptional co-activators CREB-binding protein ( CB ) and its paralog p300 to activate transcription. The Rel:CB/p300 complex is comprised of two components: the DNA-binding domain of Rel interacts with the KIX domain of CB/p300, and the transcription activation domain (TAD) of Rel binds to the TAZ domain of CB/p300. Phosphorylation of conserved Rel (Ser276) is required for the interaction to occur. The role of Rel:CB/p300 in Rel-activated transcription is unclear. Here, we provide the structure of the latter component of the Rel:CB complex by NMR spectroscopy. The structure reveals folding of Rel–TAD upon binding to TAZ through conserved hydrophobic sites on the TAZ surface. Mechanistic studies coupled with mutational and isothermal analyses allowed design of Rel-mutants that selectively abrogated the components of Rel:CB/p300. Detailed studies of Rel mutants using cell techniques, modeling, and genome-wide expression showed a set of Rel-activated genes is affected by this interaction. We show RelCB/p300 controls NF-κ response through negative loop of NF-κ pathway. Additionally, chromatin analyses Rel target promoters showed constitutive recruitment of CB300, indicating role of CB300 in recruitment Rel to sites.
Time-course Gene Set Analysis (TSA) is a novel method for analyzing gene expression data from longitudinal studies. It is an extension of gene set analysis, which has been applied to cross-sectional studies. The method is based on random effects modeling with maximum likelihood estimates and can use all available measurements while dealing with unbalanced data due to missing at random (MAR) measurements. It is a hypothesis-driven method that identifies a prior-defined gene sets with significant variations over time, taking into account heterogeneity within sets. When comparing biological conditions, it indicates if patterns of sets differ according to conditions. We illustrate the method with two real datasets: an HIV vaccine trial (DAL-1) and a study on influenza and pneumococcal vaccines. In the DAL-1 trial, TSA revealed significant change in expression over 69 gene sets during vaccination, while univariate gene analysis and Gene Set Enrich Analysis (GSEA) failed to detect any pattern over time. When applied to the second dataset, TSA identified 4 sets linked to influenza, although associated with pneumoccal in previous analyses. Our study exhibits TSA good statistical properties and increased power compared to other methods for analyzing time-course gene sets. The method is available through an R package.
Malaria caused by the parasite Plasmodium vivax (P. vivax) is less well understood than P. falciparum and represents a barrier to control and elimination strategies. We present the first global map of P. viv endemicity. We updated the geographical limits of P. viv transmission to 2010 and used 9,970 geopositioned P. viv parasite rate (PvPR) surveys (1985–2010) with a spatiemporal Bayesian geostatistical model to estimate endemic age-standardised P. viv rate (Pv1–99) within 5×5 km grid squares. We incorporated Duffy phenotype to suppress endemic predictions, particularly in Africa. P viv was predicted within a narrow range throughout the world, rarely exceeding 7% P1–99. The Americas contributed 22% of global P viv risk, but high areas were sparsely populated and contributed 6% of 2.5 billion people at risk (PAR). Africa was constrained to Madagascar and parts of Horn, contributing 3.5% global PAR. Asia was home to 82% PAR with high areas coinciding dense populations India and Myanmar. South Asia contained highest endemic Indonesia and Papua New Guinea contributed 9% PAR.
Staphylococcus aureus is a pathogenic bacterium that causes skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs) and expresses a number of cell wall-anchored proteins that mediate adhesion and invasion of host cells and tissues, contributing to its virulence. The cell-anchored protein clumping factor B ( Clf ) has been shown to facilitate S. aureus nasal colonization through high affinity interactions with the cornified envelope in the nares. However, the role of Clf during SIs has not been investigated. This study reveals a novel role for Clf during SIs. Clf is crucial in determining abscess structure and bacterial burden in early infection and is dependent on interaction with loricin, a ligand expressed in abs tissue. Clf is a promising target for future SST vaccines.
To achieve the UNAIDS 90-90 goal, the number of new HIV infections needs to decrease to approximately 500, 000 by 202. One of the five pillars to achieve this goal is pre-exposure prophylaxis ( Pr ). Currently, Truv ( emicitabine-tenofovir ) is the only approved medication for Pr, but it is costly and requires a once-daily regimen. To improve Pr, next-generation regimens, including long-acting formulations are investigated. However, preclinical testing may not guide candidate selection since it fails to translate into clinical efficacy. We developed an efficient stochastic approach to predict prophylactic efficacy as an example with dolutegravir ( DT ). Combining population pharmacokinetics of DT with the framework, we predicted plasma concentrations of 145.18 and 722.23M prevent 50 and 90% sexual transmissions respectively. We predicted reduction in infection when DT was used in Pr, Pr ‘on’ and post-exposure prophylaxis ( P ) before/after exposure. Once Pr with 50 oral DT prevented 99–100% and 85% when 50% dosing were missed. ‘on’ Pr prevented 79–84 and P >80 when initiated 6 after virus and continued as possible.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) induces autophagy to enhance its replication. However, how HCV regulates the autophagic pathway remains unclear. In this report, we demonstrated that HCV could induce the expression of Rubicon and UVR, which inhibited and stimulated the maturation of autophagosomes, respectively. The induction of Rub by HCV was prompt, whereas induction of UVR was delayed, resulting in accumulation of autagosomes at early points of viral infection. The role of Rub in inhibiting maturation of autag in H-infected cells was confirmed by siRNA knockdown and overexpression of Rub, which enhanced and suppressed maturation of autag, respectively. Rub played positive role in H replication as suppression of its reduced H and overexpression enhanced H. In contrast, overexpression of UAG facilitated maturation of autag and suppressed H. H subgenomic RNA replicon, expressed only nonstructural proteins, also induced expression of Rub and accumulation autag. Further analysis indicated H NSB protein sufficient to induce Rub and autag. Our results indicated H, by differentially inducing Rub and UVR, temporally regulated autagic to enhance replication.
Cyclin-like 1 (Cny1) is a newly identified member of the cyclin family that is highly similar in sequence to Cyclin Y (ny. We found that Cny1 was most abundantly expressed in the testis of mice and was about seven times higher than the level ofny. Cny1-/- mice were infertile, whereas male and femaleny/- mice displayed normal fertility. These results suggest thatny1, notny, is indispensable for fertility. Spermatzo obtained fromny/- mice displayed impaired motility and a thinned annulus and/or head. We found the protein, not mRNA level of cyclin-dependent kinase 16 (CD16) was in the test ofny/- mice. Further demonstrated thatny interacted with CD16 and this increased the stability of two. Moreover, increased the activity of CD16. In addition, observed alteration of CD16 in the presence ofny. We identified phosphorylation of CD by mass spectrometry and that several modifications on the-terminal of CD were indispensable forny binding and modulation CD16 activity.
Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHE) causes diarrhea and hemolytic uremic syndrome resulting from toxin-mediated microvascular endothelial injury. HE hemolysin (HE-H), a member of the RTX repeats-toxin family, is an HE virulence factor of increasing importance. The toxin exists as HE-H and HE associated with outer membrane vesicles (OMVs) released by HE during growth. We demonstrate that OM-associated HE-H does not lyse target cells but triggers apoptosis in human microvascular endothelial (HBMEC) and intestinal epithelial (Caco-2) cells. OM-associated HE is internalized via dynamin endocytosis and trafficked into endo-lysosomal compartments. Upon acidification and pH drop, HE is separated from OM and escapes lysosomes via pore-forming activity and targets mitochondria. This results in mitochondrial transmembrane potential decrease and cytochrome translocation to cytos, indicating HE-mediated permeabilization of membranes. Subsequent caspase and casp activation leads to apoptotic death evidenced by DNA fragmentation and chromatin condensation in intoxicated cells.
Transcription elongation by RNA polymerase II (RNAPI ) is accompanied by conserved patterns of histone modifications. Histone modifications have established roles in transcription initiation, but their functions during elongation are not well understood. Histone H2 ( H2ub ) mono-ubiquitylation plays a role in coordinating co-transcription histone modification by promoting histone H3 methylation and regulates gene expression through an unidentified methylation-independent mechanism. Here, we reveal bidirectional communication between H2ub and Cdk, the ortholog of metazoan transcription elongation factor ( PTEb, in fission yeast Schizoscharomyces pombe. Chemical and genetic analyses indicate lowering Cdk activity or preventing phosphorylation of its substrate, transcription factor Spt, reduces H2ub in vivo. Conversely, mutations in H2ub impair Cdk recruitment to chromatin and Spt phosphorylation. Moreover, Spt phosphorylation-site combined with deletion histone H3 Lys methyltransferase Set phenocopies morph and growth due Hub loss. Surprisingly, mutation histone H2 ubiqu-acceptor relaxes Cdk activity in vivo anddk mutations suppress cell defects Hub-deficient. Genome analyses chromatin immunoprecipitation demonstrate opposing Cdk and Hub on transcribing RNAPI.
Yellow fever virus (YFV) is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in South America. To understand the evolutionary history of this emerging pathogen, we performed a phylogenetic analysis of the largest YF data set compiled to date, representing the prM gene region from 133 isolates sampled from 22 countries over 76 years. We estimate that currently circulating YV strains arose in Africa within the last 1, 500 years and emerged in Americas following slave trade approximately 300–400 years ago. These viruses then spread westwards across continent and persist to this day in jungles South America.
Streptococcus pneumoniae is a leading bacterial pathogen that causes disease in humans. We studied a virulent isolate of this pathogen in an infant mouse model of colonization and disease transmission, with and without influenza A virus (IAV) co-infection. This model was used to identify bottlenecks in pneumocococcal pathogenesis. We found that in the setting of IAV co-infection, the pathogen must pass through single bottlenecks during invasion from the nasopharynx into the host and between hosts. Passage through these bottlenecks was not associated with genetic adaptation of the pathogen. The bottleneck occurred between exit from one host and establishment in another, explaining why number of organisms in secretions is critical to overcome.
Leishmania donovani is the causative agent of visceral leishmaniasis in Eastern Africa and is transmitted by the sand fly Phlebotus orientalis. During feeding, the female sand fly salivates into the skin of the host and the saliva contains a variety of proteins that elicit specific antibody responses in the host. To evaluate exposure to sand fly bites in human populations from endemic areas, we tested sera from volunteers against recombinant P. orient salivary antigens. Recombinant proteins from P orient secreted salivary proteins were produced using either bacterial or mammalian expression systems and tested as antigens for detection of anti. orient Ig in human sera. Using these recombin proteins, sera from Sudan and Ethiopia were screened by ELISA and immunoblot to identify markers of exposure to orient bites. Two recominant proteins m5 and mY1 were identified as promising antigens showing high correlation and specificity to whole fly saliv gland homogen. Combination of proteins increased correlation as well as positive and negative values of orient exposure. This is the first report of screening sera for anti orient antibodies using recominant saliv proteins. Recombinant saliv proteins mY1 and m5 proved valid for screening sera from Sudan and Ethiopia for orient bites.
Salmonella genomic island 1 (SGI) is a mobile genetic element that is frequently associated with multidrug-resistant clinical isolates of pathogenic Enterobacteriaceae. It is mobilized by IncA and Inc plasmids (A/C plasmids) following its excision from the chromosome, an event triggered by the transcriptional activator ACD encoded by these plasmids. Although SGI is not self-transmissible, it carries genes tra,NS, traHS and tra, coding for distant homologs of the mating pore subunits TraNC,HC and TraGC encoded by A plasm. We investigated the regulation of tra and tra and the role of these genes in transibility of SGI. Expression of tra and tra is inducible by ACD. Mating experiments using combinations of mutants SGI and helperC plid pCR revealed interactions between these mobile elements. tra and tra are essential for plasm transfer, whereas SGI could rescue mutants of each gene, revealing thatNS,HS and are functional. Complementation of tra and mutants showed thatNSHS replaceNC/GC in the pore encoded by plasm and thatHS are required for optimal SGI transfer. Remodeling of the pore by SGI was found to be essential to enhance transfer of S over helper. Furthermore was found to be crucial to allow transfer between cells bearing helper plasmids, suggesting that S disables an entry mechanism. Hence facilitate invasion of by S of populations bearing plasm.
In Saccharomyces cerevisiae polo-like kinase Cdc5 promotes adaptation to DNA damage in addition to its roles in mitotic progression. We report that CDC5 is required for adaptation and its overexpression promotes adaptation, indicating that high levels of Cdc modulate the ability of the checkpoint to inhibit the cell cycle. To pinpoint the step in the pathway at which Cdc acts, we overexpressed CDC from the GAL promoter in damaged cells and examined key steps in checkpoint individually.dc overproduction had little effect on early steps to Rad activation. The sensors,dc ( member of the 9-1 complex ) anddc ( member thedc/Mec complex ) properly localized to damage.dc appeared active since Rad retained its phosphorylation, and the damage-induced interaction between phosphorylated and Rad remained. In contrast, Rad hyperphosphorylation was reduced, consistent with loss of cell arrest during adaptation. We conclude C acts to attenuate the damage through loss of Rad hyperosphorylation to allow cells to DNA.
Many neurological conditions, such as seizures and stroke, are associated with changes in ion concentrations in the extracellular space ( ECS ) of the brain. To understand the mechanisms that govern ECS dynamics, it is necessary to keep track of both ion and electric potential in the brain. This is currently unfeasible experimentally, but can be achieved with computational models based on biophysical principles. Previous models have been limited to small spatiotemporal scales ( micrometers and milliseconds ) or simplified 1-D transport on larger scales. We present the 3-D KirchhoffernstPlan ( K ) framework to explore electrodiff effects on large spatiemporal scales. By assuming electroneutrality, K circumvents charge-relax processes on spatiemp scales nanometers and makes simulations feasible on spatiemp scales millimeters on a standard computer. We use the 3-D K framework to simulate ion and electrical surrounding a morphologically pyramidal cell. In addition to elucidating electro effects in ECS, the simulation demonstrates the 3-D framework.
The U. S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention ( CDC ) proposal to cut funding for mosquito-borne disease surveillance has the potential to leave the country ill-prepared to handle emerging and existing diseases. We evaluated the impact of delayed responses to deng epidemics in an urban environment. We used a mathematical model to generate scenarios of delayed responses to deng introduction in Cairns, Queensland, Australia, and coupled the results with surveillance and management costs to estimate cumulative costs. Our results show that halting surveillance can increase epidemic management costs by an order of magnitude compared to sustained surveillance and early detection. The total costs of preparedness through surveillance are lower than needed to respond to vector-borne pathogens, even considering human lives and well-being.
Dengue is an important cause of acute febrile illness in children and adults in Nicaragua. In Managua, the capital of Nicaragua, suspected deng has been documented but unsuspected deng among children and adults with undifferent fever has not. A prospective study was conducted in semiurban and rural Nicaragua to determine the cause of acute febrile illness. We enrolled 740 consecutive patients ≥1 years presenting with feile illness from Monday to Saturday. We tested sera for deng IgG and IgM and deng virus using reverse transcriptase PCR. We found 63. 5% were seropositive for deng at enrollment. The seroprevalence increased with age and reached 90% in people over 20. We identified deng serotypes 1 and 2 in 5.1% patients. Only 8.1% of cases were clinically suspected. Dengue is an important and largely unrecognized cause of fever in western Nicaragua. Since Zika is transmitted by the same vector and associated with severe congenital infections, the population is at risk for Zika.
Plant-parasitic nematodes are major agricultural pests that cause billions of dollars in losses annually. Effective plant defense against these pathogens relies on the recognition of pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) by surface-localized receptors, leading to the activation of PAMP-triggered immunity (PTI). While PT has been extensively studied in various plant-pathogen interactions, little is known about PT in roots and plant-nemat interactions. Here, we show that nematode-derived elicitors are capable of inducing PT in Arabidopsis in a manner dependent on the immune receptor BAK. Consistent with the role of BAK, we identified a leucine-rich receptor-like kinase, NIL1 that is regulated upon nemat infection. We show that NIL1 is essential for PT responses to nematodes and NIL1 loss-of-function mutants are hypersusceptible to broad nematodes. To our knowledge, NIL1 is the first immune receptor involved in induction of basal PT in plants or animals to nematodes.
Schistosoma mansoni is a parasitic flatworm that causes schistosomiasis, a major public health problem in tropical and subtropical regions. Milteine is an anti-cancer drug that has been repositioned for treatment of Leishmaniasis and has shown promising effects against Schos spp. This study examined the effect of treating Schos mansoni adult worms with miline on exposure of worm surface antigens in vitro. In an indirect immunofluorescence assay, anti-S mansoni adult homate and anti-S mans infection antisera gave strong immunofluorescence of S mans adult surface after miline treatment. The latter antiserum had previously been shown to synergistically enhance schosidal activity of prazantel. Antibodies that recognised surface antigens on miline-treated worms were recovered by elution in low pH buffer and used in immunoblot to identify antigenic targets in homate of adult worms. Four antigens reacting in immunob were purified and proteic analysis ( MS ) combined with immunob indicated they were S proteins: fructose-1 6phosphate aldolase, Sm 6, alkaline phosphatase and malate dehydrogen. These antibodies also bound to surface schosula and induced agglutination, suggesting a role in immune protection.
Bacillus cereus is a human opportunistic pathogen that has evolved multiple systems to acquire iron from various sources in order to overcome its low solubility and bioavailability. While iron acquisition from heme and hemoglobin has been extensively studied, little is known about iron acquisition from ferritin, a 24-mer protein able to store thousands of iron atoms within its cavity. Here we demonstrate that IlsA, a surface protein of Bacillus cereus, acts as a ferritin receptor causing ferritin aggregation on the bacterial surface. Isothermal titration calorimetry data indicate Ils binds several types of ferritins through interaction with subunits. UV-vis data show significant enhancement of iron release from ferritin in the presence of Ils. We propose a new model of iron acquisition in Bacillus that involves binding of Ils to ferritin followed by siderophore assisted uptake. Disruption of siderophore bacibactin production drastically reduces ability of Bacillus to utilize ferritin for growth and results in attenuated virulence in insects.
The circadian clock in the cyanobacterium Synechocystis elongatus is driven by a phosphorylation cycle of three proteins: KaiA, KaiB, and KaiC. KaiC forms a homohexamer with two domains, CI and CII. CI and CII can bind and hydrolyze ATP, but only CII can be phosphorylated at two residues in a well-defined sequence. We present a thermodynamically consistent statistical-mech model of the clock. The model is based on two ideas: i ) ATP hydrolysis in CI provides thermodynamic force for clock switching Kai between active and inactive conformation; ii ) phosphorylation in CII provides timer for hydrolysis in CI. The model explains how KaiA stimulates phosphorylation of KaiC by acting as nucleotide factor and how differential affinity of Kai for different KaiC phosphforms generates temporal order of phosphorylation. As phosphorylation in CII rises, release of AD from CI slows, making inactive conformation of Kai stable. Inactive Kai binds KaiB, stabilizing state and sequestrating Kai, leading to dephosphorylation.
Hepatitis B virus (HB) suppresses innate immunity to establish persistent infection. Although HB is a DNA virus, its pregenomic RNA (pgRNA) can be sensed by RIG and activates MAV to mediate interferon (IF) synthesis. Despite activation of R-MA axis by pgRNA, the mechanism explaining HB fails to induce interferonα (IF) synthesis remained uncharacterized. We demonstrate that HB induces parkin to recruit linear ubiquitin assembly (UB) complex to mitochondria and attenuate IF synthesis. Parkin interacts with MAV, accumulates unanchored polyubiquitin on MAV via UB to disrupt MAV signal and attenuate IR activation.
Crohn’s disease is a chronic inflammatory bowel disease that affects the gastrointestinal tract and is associated with an abnormal immune response to enteric bacteria. A superantigens are bacterial proteins that stimulate T-cells and are associated with Crohn’s disease. Here, we report the structure of pfi, a superantigen from Pseudomonas fluorescens at 1.7Å resolution and its interaction with human class II MHC. Both pfi and its homolog PA5 bind to mammalian cells and stimulate proliferation of human lymphocytes. Binding was inhibited by anti-class II M HLA-DR antibodies and to a lesser extent by HLA-D and DP, indicating class II MHC specificity. pfi efficiently precipitated both endogenous and purified recombinant HLA-DR, indicating direct interaction with HLA-DR. Competition studies revealed pfi and superigen Mycoplas arthritidis mit ( M ) competed for HLA, indicating overlapping binding sites. Structural analysis established pfi belongs to Tet-family DNA-binding regulators. The pfi structure indicates a new family of T superigens.
Nanog is a key regulator of pluripotency in embryonic stem (ES) cells and exhibits a disperse distribution in vivo and in vitro. The role of Nanog heterogeneity in stem cell fate decisions is supported by increasing evidence. Recently, allelic control of the Nanog gene was reported in mouse ES cells. We developed a multiscale stochastic population equation framework to understand how this mode of regulation influences observed heterogeneity of Nan in stem populations. In addition to allelic control, we considered gene expression noise and partition at cell division. As a result of allelic Nan expression, Nanog exhibited three states. When combined with transcription noise, the profile became bimodal. Regardless of allelic pattern, uniform ES populations gave rise to same Nan heterogeneity within ten cycles. Depletion of Nanog in cells was slower than accumulation of intracellular Nan after at least one allele on. This points to Nan state-dependent dynamics. Allelic of Nan also raises issues in ES with reporter genes knocked in single locus. Significant divergence was observed in reporter and native profiles depending on half-lives insertion in one or both alleles. In populations with restricted Nan, allelic facilitates maintenance of self-renew cells with sufficient Nan to prevent aberrant pluripotency. Our findings underline role of allelic Nan as determinant of stem population heterogeneity and warrant further in specification and reprogramming.
The cost of protein expression is balanced by evolution through the expression of unused proteins that have no benefits in the current environment. However, expression of unused proteins incurs a quantifiable costs on cellular growth rates. The magnitude and variability of unused protein expression in natural settings is largely unknown due to the challenge in determining environment-specific proteome. We address this challenge using absolute proteomics and a genome-scale model of Escherich coli that computes environment-specific cost and utility of proteome on a gene basis. We show that nearly half proteome is unused in certain environments and accounting for cost of this protein explains >95% of variance in growth of Escheria coli across 16 environments. Furthermore, reduction in protein is shown to be common mechanism to increase growth in adaptive experiments.
Recent genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified multiple loci that harbor genetic variants associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D), many of which encode proteins not previously suspected to be involved in the pathogenesis of T2. Most GWAS for T2 have focused on populations of European descent, and GW conducted in populations with different ancestry offer a unique opportunity to study the genetic architecture of T2. We performed genome-wide association scans for T2 in 3,955 Chinese (2,010, cases,1,945 ), 2,034 Malays (794,1,240 ) and 2,146 Indians (977,1,169 ). In addition to searching for novel variants in T2, these multi-ethnic cohorts assess the transferability and relevance of previous findings from European populations in the three ethnic of Asia, comprising half the world’s population. Of SNPs associated T2 in previous GW, only CDAL and HXIDE/KIF showed strongest association T2 in meta-analysis including all ethnic. However, consistent effect was observed many other SN in study and carried out European. Examination associations at CDAL and HXIDE/K loci provided evidence locus and allelic heterogeneity relation T2. We also detected variation disequilibrium between populations most loci previously identified. These factors, with limited power may contribute failure detect associations populations diverse.
In Cryptococcus neoformans is a basidiomycous yeast that undergoes nuclear division in the daughter cell. During mitosis, kinetochores cluster and the nucleus move to the bud. We show that the evolutionarily conserved Aurora kinase I1 (I1) localizes to the nucleus upon nuclear envelope breakdown during mitosis in C. neoans. I1 is required for timely nuclear envelope breakdown and is essential for microtubule stability. Microtub stability is compromised upon I1 depletion, delaying kinetochore clustering and nuclear migration. We propose that cytoplasmic microtules and cortical dyneins promote nuclear division in C. neoans by generating an in silico model of mitosis. We improve the model by introducing additional parameters and predict that cortical generated by cytoplasmic dyin and dyin regulate kinet clustering and nuclear migration. In vivo alterations of dyin or dyin delay nuclear migration. In silico and live imaging suggest I1 spatio-temporally influences dyin and dyin with microtub to ensure timely division.
Synonymous mutations are a type of genetic change in the DNA sequence of a gene that do not alter the amino acid sequence of the protein encoded protein. They are often considered to be “silent” because they do not change the amino acid sequence of the protein. However, they can affect the expression of the gene. In this study, we investigated the role of a synonymous mutation in the RET gene in medullary thyroid carcinoma ( MTC ). RET is a gene that encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase involved in the development of MTC. In this study, we found that a synonymous mutation in the RET gene increased the expression of the protein. We found that the mutation created a new splicing enhancer motif that increased the recruitment of splicing factors to the mutant allele, leading to more efficient maturation of the pre-mRNA and increased abundance of mature mRNA encoding a constitutively active receptor. This is a novel mechanism by which synonymous mutations can contribute to cancer.
Metagenomic sequencing is a powerful tool for diagnosing human infections by capturing all DNA or RNA from pathogenic organisms in a sample. Accurate characterization and identification of pathogens depends on the availability and quality of genomes for comparison. Thousands of genomes are available, and growing, increasing the power of metagen sequencing for diagnosis. However, recent studies have exposed contamination in published genomes used for diagnosis, increasing the risk of wrong pathogen identification. To address this, we developed a bioinformatics system to eliminate contamination and low-complexity genomic sequences in draft eukaryotic pathogen genomes. We applied this software to remove human, bacterial, archaeal, and viral sequences in a comprehensive database of sequenced eukotic pathogen genomes. We also removed low-complex genomic sequences, another source of false positives. Using this pipeline, we produced a “clean” eukotic pathogen database for bioinformatics analysis. We demonstrate that when finding eukotic pathogens in metagen samples, this database provides better sensitivity than original genomes while reducing false positives.
Trypanosoma brucei is the causative agent of Human African Trypanosomiasis (HAT), a major public health problem in Uganda. While the disease is declining on the continent, it remains a major problem in Uganda. We investigated the genetic diversity of T. brucei in Uganda and its implications for the epidemiology of sleeping sickness. We genotyped 269 T. brucei isolates from different regions in Uganda and southwestern Kenya at 17 microsatellite loci and checked for the presence of the SRA gene that confers human infectivity to T. rhodesense. We used Bayesian methods and Discriminant Analysis of Components to partition T brucei isolates into three genetic clusters. Cluster 1 and 3 include isolates from central and southern Uganda, while cluster 2 contains mostly isolates from southwestern Kenya. These clusters are not sorted by subspecies ( T. bruce vs. T. rhense ) or date of collection. Our analyses show genetic admixture among clusters and long-range dispersal, suggesting recent gene flow between them. We show the expansion of disease to new foci in central Uganda occurred from northward spread of T. rhense and emergence of human infect strains from non-infect T. br strains of different backgrounds. Our results confirm the importance of cattle as reservoir and shape the epidemiology of sleeping sickness in the region.
Thioredoxin-interacting protein (TXIP) is a multifunctional protein involved in tumor suppression, cell proliferation, and apoptosis. However, its role in the inflammatory process remains unclear. Here, we show that TXIP−/− mice are significantly more susceptible to lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced endotoxic shock. In response to LPS, TX−−/− macrophages produce significantly higher levels of nitric oxide (NO) and inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS), and iNOS inhibitor rescues TX−−− mice from endotoxic-induced death, demonstrating NO is a major factor in TXIP-mediated endotoxic shock. This susceptibility of TX−−− mice occurs despite reduced IL-1β secretion due to increased S-nitrosylation of NLRP3 compared to wild-type controls.
In Caenorhabditis elegans, we have identified ZTF-8 as a novel protein involved in the repair of both mitotic and meiotic DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) as well as in meiotic DNA damage response. ZTF-8 mutants exhibit sensitivity to γ-radiation and hydroxyurea, mitotic arrest at S-phase accompanied by activation of the ATL-1 and CHK-1 DNA checkpoint kinases, as well as accumulation of mitotic and meiotic recombination intermediates. This indicates that ZTF-8 functions in DNA double-strand break repair (DSBR). However, impaired meiotic DS progression fails to trigger the CEP-1/p53-dependent damage checkpoint in pachene, supporting a role for ZTF-8 in meiotic DNA damage response. Z-8 partially co-localizes with the 9-1 complex and interacts with M-2/R1, a component of this complex. Human RH rescues the phenotypes in z-8 mutants, suggesting conservation across species. We propose that Z-8 is involved in promoting repair of stalled replication forks and meiotic DS by transducing damage signaling via the 9-1 pathway. Our findings define a conserved function for 8/RHINO in genomic stability in the germl.
During the development of the neural tube, neural progenitors differentiate into motor neurons (MN) at a faster rate than other progenitors. We used single cell transcriptomics to define the transcriptional changes associated with the transition of neural progenitors into MNs. We found that the transcription factor Olig is pivotal just before MN differentiation. Olig represses the Notch signaling effectors Hes1 and H5. Olig repression of H5 appears to be direct, via a conserved element within the H5 locus that restricts expression from MN progenitors.
Influenza viruses are a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The role of T cells in protecting humans against influenza remains unclear. Here, we show that cross-reactive T cells play an important role in early clearance of the 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza virus (H1Npdm ) in nonhuman primates. We first infected rhesus macaques with a seasonal HN1 isolate. These animals developed cellular and antibody responses against H1 but no neutralizing antibodies against H1p. Four months later, we challenged the “primed” animals and naive controls with H1p. In naive animals, CD8 T cells appeared in blood and lung 5–7 days post inoculation ( p. i. ) with H1p and peaked 7–10 days. In contrast, T cells were recruited lung as early as 2 p. i. in “prim” animals and peaked blood and lung 4–7 p. Interferon (IF )γ Elisp and intracellular cytokine staining showed virus-specific response peaked and reached higher in “prim” than naive animals. This involved CD and CD T cells. Strikingly, “prim” cleared H1p from upper and lower respiratory tract before appearance H1p-neutralizing antibodies. Our results suggest cross-react T can mediate clearance antigenically novel influenza in primates. Vaccines capable of inducing cross-react T may protect humans against severe caused by emerging influenza viruses.
Q fever is the most common zoonotic disease and domestic animals are the most common source of transmission. It is difficult to distinguish from other febrile diseases because of lack of specific manifestations in humans and difficult to identify in disease-carrying animals because of lack of identifiable features. Conventional serodiagnosis requires sera from acute and convalescent stages of infection, which are unavailable at early diagnosis. In this study, we developed Loop-Med Isothermal Amplification ( LAMP ) assay to identify C burnii rapidly and sensitively. A universal LAMP set was designed to detect the repeated IS1 of the htp gene of burnii using Primer V software. The sensitivity of LAMP was evaluated using known quantities of reference plasmids containing targeted. The specificity of developed LAMP was determined using 26 members of Ricketiae and 18 common pathogens. The utility of LAMP was compared with real PCR by examination of 24 samples including 6 confirmed and probable fever cases diagnosed by IFA and PCR. In addition,126 samples from 4 including 97, 7, 18, 3, and 1 were compared by these methods. The detection of LAMP for h gene was copy. The specificity of LAMP was 100% and no cross-reaction was observed among bacteria in study. The rate of febr patients was 33. 3% for LAMP and 8.3 for real PCR. The rate of animals was 7.9 for LAMP and 0. for real
Embryonic Stem (ES)-Specific Enhancers Specify the Expression of ES Genes in Cancer  
Embryonic stem (ES)-specific enhancers (ESs) are a class of regulatory elements that control the expression of genes in hematopoietic cells. We found that ESs are prone to DNA methylation, indicative of their chromatin activity. Strikingly, ES methylation is associated with transcriptional activity in cancer. Methylated ESs are hypermethylated in cancer relative to normal cells and co-local with silenced genes, whereas unmethyl ES tend to be hypomethyl in cancer and associated with reactivated genes. Constitutive hematopoietic stem-specific enhancers do not show these trends, suggesting selective reactivation of ESs in cancer. Further analyses of hypomethyl ES downstream the VFA gene revealed a regulatory circuit affecting VFA transcript levels across cancers and patients.
The role of population subdivision in crossing fitness valleys and plateaus in a rugged fitness landscape is investigated in this study. The effect of subdivision on the time it takes to cross a fitness valley or plateau is quantitatively investigated. A generic and minimal model is used that includes subdivision of a population into demes connected by global migration, and does not require significant changes in deme size, environmental heterogeneity or geographic structure. The optimal speedup of valley crossing that can be gained by subdivision is determined, if the process is driven by the dem that crosses fastest. We show that demes have to be in the sequential regime for subdivision to significantly accelerate crossing. Using Markov chain theory, we obtain expressions for the conditions under which optimal speed is achieved: valley crossing by the subdivided population is as fast as its fastest dem. Our predictions are verified through stochastic simulations. We demonstrate that subdivision can accelerate crossing of fitness valleys and plateaus in a wide range of parameters. The effect of subdivision degree of population is studied, and the trade-off between magnitude of speedup and width of range it occurs. Our results for fitness and plateaus also hold for weak beneficial mutations. Finally, we extend to the case of population connected by migration to several islands. Our results demonstrate subdivision with migration can accelerate fitness and plateaus, and conditions necessary for this occur.
Arboviruses such as dengue, chikungunya and yellow fever are transmitted to humans by the mosquito Aedes aegypt. These viruses replicate and disseminate from the midgut, the primary site of infection and transmission. The metabolic environment within the midut plays a crucial role in these processes. Since these viruses are enveloped, replication and assembly occur on cellular membranes through manipulation of host metabolism. Interfering with the virus-induced metabolic environment is detrimental to replication in human and mosquito cell models. Here, we present the first insight into the metabolic environment during arboirus replication in Aedes aegypt. Using high-resolution mass spectrometry, we analyzed the metabolic perturbations following deng virus infection of the midut. This is the primary site of infection and replication, preceding systemic dissemination and transmission. We identified metabolites that exhibited a dynamic profile across early, mid- and late-infection points. We observed a marked increase in lipid content. An increase in glycerospholipids, sphingolip and fatty acids was coincident with viral replication. Elevation glycerolip levels suggested diversion of resources from energy to synthetic pathways. Elevated acylcarnines were observed, signaling disruptions in mitochondrial function and diversion of energy. A central in the sphingip pathway that influenced dihydroamide to ceramide ratios was critical for the virus cycle. This study resulted in the reconstruction of the sphip pathway in Aedesegypt.
Cardiac arrhythmias are a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Elucidating the mechanisms of arrhythmias requires integration of electrophysiological experiments, models, and theory. Existing models of the transmembrane action potential ( AP ) are complex, resulting in overparameterization and varied leading to dissimilar predictions. Thus, simpler models are needed to elucidate the “minimal requirements” to reproduce significant phenomena using few parameters as possible. Here, we develop a parsimonious rabbit AP model that is mathematically identifiable, combining a Hodgkin-Hux formulation of INa with a phenomenological model of repolarization similar to IK. The model was calibrated using experimental data from rabbit under physiological conditions: I-V relationships during the APstroke; recovery of excitability during the refractory period; and steady IN in voltage clamp. Simulations reproduced important phenomena including alternans rates >250 bpm, reentrant waves, and spiral breakup.
During the sexual cycle of the ciliate Parameum, the assembly of the somatic genome involves the precise excision of tens of thousands of short, non-coding germl sequences ( Internal Eliminated Sequences or IES ), each flanked by TA dinucleotides. These genome rearrangements are initiated by developmentally programmed DNA-strand breaks ( DSBs ), which depend on domesticated transposase PigMac. The DSBs exhibit a characteristic geometry with 4-base 5′ overhangs centered on conserved TA and may align and undergo ligation with minimal processing. However, the molecular steps involved in the final assembly of somatic genes remained unknown. We demonstrate that Ligase IV and Xrccp, components of non-homous endjoining (HE ) are required for repair of I excision sites and circularization of excised IES. Transcription of LIG and XR4 is induced during sexual cycle and Ligp-GFP accumulates in developing somatic nucleus by I excision takes place. RNA–mediated silencing either results in persistence of free ends apparently against resection.
Chagas disease is the most common cause of death in patients with heart failure. However, this information comes from a period before the introduction of drugs that changed the natural history of heart failure. We sought to study the mode of death in patients with heart failure caused by Chagas disease comparing with non-Ch cardiomyopathy. We examined the REMHE trial and grouped patients according to etiology ( Chagas vs nonagas ) and mode of death. The primary end-point was all-cause, heart and failure and sudden mortality; 342 patients were analyzed and 185 ( 54.1 ) died. Death occurred in 56.4 Chagas patients and 53.7 nonagas. The cumulative of allcause mortality and heart failure was higher in Chagas compared to nonagas. There was no difference in the cumulative of sudden mortality between the two. In the Cox model Ch etiology ( HR 2.76; CI 1.34–.69; p=0.006 ) LVED ( 1.07 CI1.04.10; p0.001 ) creatinine (.98 CI.97.99;=0.006 ) and amiodone (3.05 CI1.47.34;=0.003 ) were associated with failure.VED (1 CI1.01.07;=0.005 ) and beta-blocker (0.52 CI.34.94=.014 ) were associated sudden. In Chagas disease, failure is the most mode of death.
