Plant cells have evolved complex defense mechanisms to counteract viral infections. Here, we show that the N1-interacting kinase (NIK) pathway is involved in plant defense against geminiviruses. However, the mechanism by which N1 activates antiviral response is unclear. We identified rp10, a ribosomal protein, as a specific substrate of N1 that acts downstream of N1 response. Phosphorylation of cytoplasmic rp10 by N redirects it to the nucleus where it may modulate viral infection. N1 or hyperactive mutant promotes accumulation of phosphorylated rp10 within nuclei, while inactive N fails to redirect to nuclei of co-transfected cells. Likewise, rp10 defective for N phosphorylation is not redirected to nucleus. Loss of rp10 enhances susceptibility to gemivirus, similar to nik null alleles. We also show gemivirus directly interferes with N1-mediated localization of rp10 as countermeasure. However, N1 defense neither activates silencing nor hypersensitive but inhibits plant growth.
Paracoccocidioides brasiliensis is a human pathogenic fungus that survives inside the host by adapting to different conditions, including oxidative stress imposed by the immune cells. In this study, we evaluated the role of alternative oxidase (AOX), an enzyme involved in intracellular redox balancing, during host-P brasiliensis interaction. We generated a mitotically stable P brasiliensis AOX (PbAOX) antisense RNA (RNA) strain with 70% reduction in expression. We evaluated PbX during conidia and yeast interaction with IF-γ activated macrophages in a mouse model of infection. Additionally, we determined fungal viability and PbX in presence of H2. Interaction with IF-γ macrophages induced higher PbX expression in conidia than yeast. PbXRNA conidia and yeast had decreased viability after macroph interaction. Moreover, in mouse infection model, we showed absence of wild-type PbX in brasili resulted in reduced fungal burden at weeks 8 and 24 post-challenge and increased survival. In presence H2, we observed Pb yeast increased PbX and presented higher viability with PbRNA cells. These data support that PbX is important in defense against oxidative stress by cells and relevant in virulence brasili.
Place cell remapping by CA3 recurrent attractors is thought to support episodic memory. Episodic memory is thought to be supported by attractor dynamics in the hippocampus. A possible neural substrate for this mechanism is remapping, which the spatial map of cells encodes contextual information through firing variability. To test whether memories are stored as multimodal attractors in populations of cells, experiments morphed one context into another while observing the responses of CA cell ensembles. Average activity in CA was reported to transition gradually rather than abruptly from one context to the next, suggesting lack of attractors associated with the representations. On the other hand, cells showed a mix of gradual and abrupt transitions different along the sequence and displayed hysteresis which is signature attractor. To understand these conflicting results commens with attractor theory we developed a network of CA with attract for both position and contexts. We found memories in overlapping ensembles within a single map position-dependent attract transitions at different along the sequence. Smooth curves arose from averaging the while heterogeneous was observed on the unit. In contrast, led abrupt and on both and unit as observed when remapping two independent maps. Strong feedback a hysteretic on the which diminished the amount in the. These suggest context-dependent can be by overlapping within a map CA cells.
Entamoeba histoly, a microaerobic enteric protozoan parasite, causes ameb colitis and intestinal abscesses in millions of inhabitants of endemic areas. Troozo of E. histoly are exposed to a variety of reactive oxygen and nitrogen species during infection. Since. hist lacks key components of canonical eukotic anti-oxid defense, alternative strategies have been postulated to operate in. We investigated metabolic responses in E. hist to H2O2 and paraquat-mediated oxidative stress by measuring metabolites by capillary electrophoresis and time-of-flight spectrometry. Oxidative caused drastic modulation of metabolites in glycol, chitin biosynthesis and nucleotide amino metabolism. Oxid resulted in inhibition of glycol as result inactivation of several enzymes leading redirection of flux towards glycer production chitin bios and nonoxidative branch pentose pathway. Oxid resulted in repression of gly evidenced by accumulation of intermediates upstream pyru and reduced levels nucleotide triosph. We showed presence of gly biosynthetic in E as evidenced by production glyol 3-phosphate gly upon oxidative.
IKAR is a critical regulator of hematopoietic cell fate and its dynamic expression is required for proper hematopoiesis. IKAR collaborates with the nucleosome remodeling and deacetylase ( Nu ) complex to promote gene repression and activation. However, it remains unclear how IKAR can support activation while associated with the HD-containing Nu complex. IKAR also binds the positive transcription elongation factor ( PTEb ) at promoters. Here, we show that Nu and Pb are assembled in a complex that can be recruited by IKAR to specific genes. IKAR expression influences recruitment of the NuPb complex to gene regions and facilitates transcription by transferring phosphatase 1 (PPα), an IKAR-binding Pb activator, to CD9. We show that IKAR mutant unable to bind PPα cannot sustain expression and impedes normal differentiation of hematopoietic progenitors. Finally, knockdown of the Nu subunit reveals that occupancy of Nu at transcribed regions favors relief of II promoter proximal pausing and promotes transcription.
Rabies is an emerging public health problem in the Americas. The Caribbean island of Trinidad experiences periodic outbreaks in the livestock population. We performed molecular characterization of rabies virus (RV) and used a phylogeographic approach to investigate the extent to which outbreaks are result from in situ evolution versus importation of virus from the nearby South American mainland. Our results show that Trinidadian RV are bat variant and clustered with Desmodus rotundus (vampire bat) sequences. They fall into two temporally defined lineages: I and II. The I includes sequences from 1997–200 (all from northeast of the island ) and is most related to RV from Ecuador (2005,7), Frenchiana (1990) and Venezuela (3,4). II comprises sequences from southwest of the island which cluster into two: IIa and IIb. IIa includes one from 0 and 7 and IIb all 0. II are most related to Brazil (9,4) and Uruguay (7,8). Phyloge analyses support three RV introductions from mainland which each of Trinidadian lineages arose. Estimated introductions and subsequent expansions suggest in situ evolution within Trinidad following each introduction. These also indicate co-circulation IIa and II during 0. In light these findings and likely bat origin of Trinidadian RV, further studies should investigate RV spatiemporal dynamics and bat ecology, particularly between mainland and Trinidad.
The development of the mammalian cerebral cortex is characterized by the emergence of functionally distinct areas, each of which is dependent on the expression of specific genes along the anterior-posterior axis. The genes Fgf, Em2, Pax, Coupfi, and Sp8 play a strong role in specifying areal identity. However, the interactions between these genes that lead to their confinement to particular spatial patterns are currently not well understood. We used a computational model of interactions between these five genes to determine which interactions and combinations of interactions occur in networks that reproduce the anterior-posterior patterns observed experimentally. The model treats expression as Boolean, reflecting the qualitative nature of the data available. We simulated expression patterns by all networks containing the five genes of interest. Only networks were able to reproduce the experimentally observed patterns. These all lacked interactions and combinations including auto-regulation and inductive. Many higher combinations of interactions never appeared in networks that satisfied our criteria for performance. While there was diversity in the structure of networks that performed, analysis of each interaction gave indication of which are likely to be in the network regulating area. We found that repressive interactions are more than inductive, but mutually repressive are not for correct functioning. Our model illuminates the design of the network regulating area and makes predictions that can be tested.
Polycomb group (Pc) proteins play a crucial role in regulating gene expression during development by modifying chromatin structure. PRC1 and PRC2 proteins achieve this through histone modifications: PRC2-mediated H3K27me3 and PRC-mediated H2A ubiquity. B1 is a key component of P1 and has been shown to be critical for H2 ubiqulation. Here, we report the genome-wide localization of B1-dependent H2 in mouse embryonic fibroblast (MEF) cells using ChIP-Seq. We find that H2 peaks at the transcription start site (TSS) of well-annotated genes, enriched at promoters with H3me3 and low-expressed genes in MEF. We also identify regions of H enrichment throughout the genome, almost 700 promoters. Genes with H peaks have lower expression than those without peaks. We show that genes with peaks have increased expression upon B1 knockout. Importantly, H is not limited to regions with H3me3. We find enrichment at high CpG promoters and suggest that methylation may be linked H at these regions.
Pregnancy-induced non-coding RNA (PINC) and retinoblast-associated protein 46 (Rap46) are upregulated in alveolar cells of the mammary gland during pregnancy and persist in alve cells that remain in the regressed following involution. We show that INC is enriched in luminal and alve progenitors in the post-pubal mammary gland. INC levels increase throughout pregnancy and decline in lactation when alve cells undergo terminal differentiation. INC is significantly decreased when mammary epithelial cells are induced to differentiate and produce milk. This reduction in INC levels may be necessary for lactation as overexpression of INC in HC11 cells blocks differentiation while knockdown of INC enhances. We demonstrate that INC interacts with RAp, as well as other members of the polycomb repressive complex 2 (PC2), and identify targets of INC that are differentially expressed following modulation of INC levels. Our data suggest that INC inhibits terminal differentiation of alve cells during pregnancy to prevent milk production until parturition.
PML/TR19 is a member of the tripartite motif (TR) protein family and is mainly expressed in the nucleus, where it forms structures known as PML bodies that recruit proteins such as Sp100 and Dax. While P/TR19’s role in antiviral defense is well documented, its effect on HIV-1 infection is unclear. We show that HIV-1 and other retroviruses trigger PML cytoplasmic body formation as early as 30 minutes post-infection. P cytoplasmic bodies last approximately 8 hours with a peak at 2 hours post-infection. P localization is blocked by reverse transcription inhibitors and not observed following infection with unrelated viruses, suggesting it is triggered by retroiral reverse transcription. We show P interferes with early retroiral infection since P knockdown increases reverse transcription efficiency. P does not inhibit retroiral but acts through stabilization of Dax. In presence P cytoplasmic Dax is found near HIV-1 capsids and inhibits reverse transcription. Dax inhibits exogenous and endogenous retroviruses, identifying Dax as cellular reverse inhibitor.
Proteins are the building blocks of all living organisms and are composed of long chains of amino acids that fold into complex three-dimensional structures. These structures are crucial for their function. However, there is no consensus on how proteins should be aligned when they are similar but not identical. One approach is fragment chaining, where short parts of proteins are aligned optimally and then chained together. Recently, it has been suggested that flexibility may help model proteins better. We introduce Matt, a fragment chaining algorithm that allows small translations and rotations to bring fragments closer, even if impossible under rigid transformations. After dynamic programming, consistency is restored before output. We tested Matt against other programs on the Homstr and Smark datasets. Matt is competitive on Homstr but outperforms on Smark, a benchmark of proteins with distant homology. On both, Matt better aligns α-helices and β-strands, important for structural library construction. We considered whether Matt can distinguish homologous from non-homologous proteins. For this, a score based on core length and root mean squared deviation is shown to separate homologs from nonhomologs in Smark. We postulate Matt's performance comes from modeling conformation states and backbone distortions in distantly related proteins.
Cell entry into mitosis is triggered by the activation of cyclin-dependent kinase (Cdk) and inactivation of its counteracting phosphatase protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A)/B55. Greatwall, a kinase that inactivates PP2/B by phosphorylating its substrates Ensa and AR19. Both Great and En/AR19 are regulated by phosphorylation, but the regulation of Great activity and phosphatases that control Great kinase and its substrates are poorly understood. We used a combination of mathematical modelling and experiments and phospho-specific antibodies to monitor Great, En/AR and Cdk phosphorylation during mitotic entry and exit. We show that PP2/B is required for Great dephosphorylation at the Cdk site Thr194. En/AR deosphorylation is mediated by the RNA polymerase II C-terminal phosphatase F1. Surprisingly, inhibition or depletion of F1 or PP/B does not block deosphory of the bulk mitotic Cdk substrates during mitotic exit. Our results suggest a hierarchy of phosphatases coordinating Great, En/AR and Cdk deosphory during mitotic exit.
Escape from autologous neutralizing antibodies in acute/early subtype C HIV-1 infection requires multiple pathways. Escape from autolog neutralizing antibodies (Nab) is a major goal for an HIV vaccine to limit replication of diverse viruses and prevent new infection establishment. We demonstrate that escape occurred despite high titer autolog ab in two subjects with acute/early subtype C infection. Escape was driven by multiple pathways in two subjects. In one subject, escape was driven by changes in gp120 V3-5. In the second, escape was driven by V2. Escape pathways oscillated and required cooperation between V2 and gp41 ectodomain. In the second subject, escape was driven by V2 and retained over time. This was reflected in virus ability to escape two monoclonal antibodies from same patient via single N-linked glycosylation in V2. Sequence changes in gp120 suggested selective pressure on same Env regions in subjects, though Env domains drove escape different. Together, findings argue single pathway not sufficient to escape early C-1 infection and support model multiple strategies including glycan shifts, epitope sequence alteration, and Env conformational masking to evade neutralization.
Positive and negative selection vary across different parts of the plant genome. We sequenced the genomes of 13 Capsella grandiflora individuals and estimated selection across the genome. Selection is strong in coding regions but weak in most non-coding regions, except for 5′ and 3′ untranslated regions ( UTRs ). However, selection on noncoding conserved across the Brassicaceae family shows strong signals. We see reductions in diversity around substitutions in both coding and conserved noncoding regions, indicating recent sweeps at these sites. Using tissue expression data, we show that highly expressed genes experience stronger negative selection but comparable positive to low expressed genes.
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) transforms resting B lymphocytes into proliferating lymphoblasts to establish latent infections that can give rise to malignancies. EBNA2, an EBV-encoded transcriptional regulator, drives the cooperative and combinatorial genome-wide binding of two master regulators of B-cell fate, EBF and RBPκ. Previous studies suggest that B-cell factors are statically bound to target promoters. In contrast, we show that EB2 induces the formation of new binding sites for Rκ and EBF, many of which are in close proximity to the cellular and viral genome. These induced sites are co-occupied by EB2-κ EBF and correlate with transcriptional activation of genes important for Blymphoblast function.
Aedes aegypt is the primary mosquito vector of the four deng virus serotypes (DENV). Previous studies have shown that Ae.egypt populations differ in their ability to transmit deng viruses. In Mexico, we found that the intersection of the Neovol axis (N) with the Gulf of Mexico in the state of Veracruz acts as a barrier to gene flow among Ae.egpt populations north and south of N. We also found that Ae.egpt populations north and south of N differ in their vector competence (VC) for deng serotype 2 (DENV2). The average VC for Ae.egpt from north of N was 0.55, while the average VC for Aeeg from south of N was 0.20. Most of this variation was due to midg infection barriers. In.eg north of N, 21.5% failed to develop midg infections and 30.3% of those with midg infections failed to develop disseminated. In contrast, south of N, 45.2% failed to develop midg and 62.8% of those with midg failed to develop disseminated.
Replication in Escherichia coli is driven by the Dna protein, which cycles between an active ATP-bound and inactive ADP-bound form. It has been suggested that Dna is the main controller of initiation frequency. Initiation is thought to occur when enough ATP-Dna accumulates. We performed cell cycle analysis on cells with a surplus of ATP-Dna and asked whether initiation occurs earlier. It does not. Cells with more than 50% increase in concentration of ATPna showed no changes in timing of replication. We suggest that ATPna is the actor in initiation of replication, but its accumulation does not control timing. It is the motor that drives initiation, but other factors are required for exact timing in response to environment. We investigated in vivo roles of Dna-dependent Dna inactivation (DA) and Dna-binding protein Dia. Loss ofDA affected cycle only during slow growth and made sensitive to Dia protein. This indicates cycle machines perform less robust.
Interactions in the Frequency Domain: Uncovering Oscillatory Interactions with Partial Grangerality  
    Oscillatory activity is a ubiquitous in biological processes, from subcellular to organismal and network levels, involving many interacting elements. We introduce partial Granger, a novel method to reveal patterns in multivariate data with exogenous and latent variables in the frequency domain. We test Granger with toy models and apply to experimental datasets: (1) microarray data of HeLa cell cycle; (2) in vivo multi-electrode array (MEA) local field potentials (LFPs) from inferotemporal cortex of sheep; (3) in vivo LFP from right hemisphere of macaque.
Many methods have been proposed for inferring local ancestry at each locus in the genome of admixed individuals, such as those of Latino descent. However, most are designed for use with genotyping arrays and fail to make use the full spectrum of data available from sequencing. In addition, haplotype-based approaches are computationally demanding, requiring large computational time for large sample sizes. We present new methods for local ancestry inference that leverage continent-specific variants (CSVs) to attain performance over existing approaches in admixed genomes. Our approach incorporates admixed genomes with public datasets, such as 100 Genomes, to improve accuracy of CSV. We show that our approach attains accuracy to widely used haplotype-based approaches with decreases in runtime. Our method recovers local ancestries as 100 Gen consensus in admixed from 100 Project. We extend to account for low-coverage and show that local inference can be attained at sequencing. Finally, we generalize to subcontinental-specific (sCSV) and show that it is possible to determine sub-ancestry for chromosomal on basis sCSV.
Circadian oscillations in gene expression have been described in the hypothalamus and multiple peripheral tissues in mammals, with 10–15% of genes oscillating in a daily rhythm regulated by an intrinsic molecular clock. However, statistical analyses of periodicity are limited by small datasets and high levels of stochastic noise. We propose a new approach applying digital signal processing algorithms to each group of genes oscillating in the same phase, combined with statistical tests for periodicity. This method identifies circadian oscillation in almost all expressed genes. Consequently, circadian oscillation in expression should be evaluated in any study related biological pathways. Changes in expression caused by mutations or environmental factors such as photic stimuli or feeding should be considered in context of changes in amplitude and phase of oscillations.
Recombination is a key process that generates genetic diversity and drives evolution. While the outcome of recombination can be detected by the inheritance of alleles in pedigreed families, the precise location of crossover and non-crossover events has been difficult to determine. We performed whole-genome resequencing at high coverage of a three-generation collared flycatcher pedigree to localize recombination with high resolution. We identified 325 crossovers at 1. 4 kb, with 86% in <10 kb. Observed crossover rates were in agreement with linkage data, 52% higher in male ( 3.56M ) than female (2.28 ) and increased towards chromosome ends in male but not female. Crossovers were non-random in the genome with distinct hotspots and concentration in genic regions, highest in promoters and CpG. We identified 267 non-crosso whose location was associated with crosso. We detected significant bias 0.18 in favour ‘’ over ‘ at nonrosso, providing evidence for process in avian.
Repeat-proteins are a class of proteins that consist of repeated stretches of 20–40 amino acids that fold into non-globular, elongated architectures. These proteins are stabilized by interactions within each repeat and between adjacent repeats, but lack contacts between distant residues in sequence. The inherent symmetries in sequence and three-dimensional structure are reflected in a folding landscape that can be analyzed as a quasi-one dimensional problem. We present a description of repeat-protein energy landscapes based on an Ising-like treatment of elementary interactions between foldons, whose ensemble are treated as spin variables. The folding properties of a complete domain ( stability and cooperativity of repeating ) can be derived from this description. The one-dimensional nature of the model implies simple relations for experimental observables: folding-energy ( ΔG ) and cooperativity denaturation (m-value ), which do not apply for globular proteins. We show how parameters for coarse-grained description in foldon variables can be extracted from detailed simulations on funneled landscapes.
Hepatitis, obesity, and alcoholism are major risk factors for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). Although these conditions lead to integrated stress response (ISR) or unfolded response (UPR) activation, the extent to which these pathways influence HCC pathogenesis has not been tested. Here we show that the ISR-regulated transcription factor CH promotes liver cancer. CH is upregulated in human and mouse models of HCC. CH-null mice are resistant to chemical carcinogenesis and exhibit attenuation of apoptosis and proliferation. CH-null mice are also resistant to fibrosis, a key factor for H. Gene profiling suggests deletion of CH reduces basal signaling in the liver. Our results are consistent with a model whereby CH contributes to carcinogenesis by promoting, fibrosis cell death and compensatory proliferation. CH is a factor in the development of H in a variety of liver diseases.
Cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) caused by Leishmania aethopica is a significant public health problem in Ethiopia, with severe cases such as diffuse cutaneous leishmaniasis (DCL) and mucocutaneous leishiasis (MCL) requiring treatment. However, evidence-based treatment guidelines are lacking. We conducted a systematic review of clinical studies on treatment outcomes of CL due to Lethopica to identify potentially efficacious drugs for clinical trials. We identified 24 records on 506 treatment episodes of CL due to Lethica. The most used drugs were antimonials (201), pentamidine (150) and cryotherapy (103). There were 20 case/series with poor study quality. Only two small, poor quality randomized trials were conducted long ago. Two non-randomized studies reported cryotherapy, antimonials and pentidine. Cryotherapy cure rates were 60–80%, 69–85 with antimonials. Pentidine was effective against CL also cases non-responsive antimonials. All studies suffered methodological limitations.
In vitro circadian oscillators can be reconstituted with purified KaiA, KaiB, and KaiC proteins that display salient properties of circadian rhythms, including self-sustained 24-h periodicity that is temperature compensated. We analyzed the biochemical basis of this oscillator by quantifying the time-dependent interactions of the proteins by electron microscopy and native electrophoresis to elucidate the timing of complex formation among the proteins. The data were used to derive a dynamic model that reproduces the rhythms of Kai complexes and KaiC phosphorylation and is consistent with biophysical observations of individual protein interactions. We used FRET to confirm monomer exchange among Kai hexamers. The model demonstrates that monomer exchange may maintain synchrony among hexers in the reaction, sustaining high-amplitude oscillation. We applied perturbations to the oscillator using temperature pulses to reset the phase of Kai, testing resetting characteristics of this circadian oscillator.
It is well known that there is considerable trial-to-trial variability in both in brain activity and behavioral output, even under identical task conditions. Most event-related potential ( ERP ) studies investigating the relationship between trial-to-trial fluctuations in brain activity and behavioral have only tested a monotonic relationship between them. However, it was recently found that across-trial variability correlates with behavioral independent of trial-averaged activity. This predicts a U or inverted- relationship between trial-trial brain activity and behavioral, depending on whether larger variability is associated with better or worse behavior. Using a visual detection task, we provide evidence from electroencephalography ( EEG ) for an inverted brain-behavior relationship. When fluctuation in broadband EEG activity is closer to the acrossial mean, hit rate is higher and reaction times faster. Importantly, this relationship is present in both post-stimulus-evoked brain and pre-stim spontaneous activity, suggesting anticipatory brain dynamics.
Sexual reproduction is a key innovation in the evolution of eukaryotes. In many species, sexual reproduction involves interaction between compatible partners that can undergo cell fusion and subsequent steps including meiosis. In fungi, sexual compatibility is governed by the mating ( MAT ) loci. In basidiomycetes, the ancestral state is hypothesized to be tetrapolar, with two unlinked MAT loci containing homeodomain factor ( HD ) and pherone and pherone genes ( P ), respectively. Alleles at both loci must differ between partners for completion of sexual development. However, there are basidiomyc with bipolar systems, which arise through linkage of HD and P loc. In the Tremales, bipolarity is found only in the pathogenic Cryptoccus. Here, we describe MAT loci from 24 species of Trichporales, a sister to Tremales. In all species, MAT loci are fused with a single HD gene in each type, similar to pathogenic Cryptoccus. However, HD and P allele combinations in Trichporales differ from pathogenic. This and existence of tetrap in Tremales suggests fusion of HD and P occurred independently Trichporales and pathogenic, supporting convergent evolution towards fused regions.
Chagas disease is the most important vector-borne disease in Latin America. Initiatives based on residual insecticide spraying have successfully controlled domiciliated vectors in many regions. However, nonomiciliated vectors remain responsible for significant transmission and control is now a key for disease. A mathematical model was developed to predict temporal variations in abundance of nonomic vectors inside houses. Demographic parameters were estimated by fitting the model to two years of field data from Yucán Peninsula, Mexico. The model was tested on independent data and examined efficacy of control strategies based on insecticide, screens, and bednets. The model accurately predicted data in absence and presence of insecticide. Pyreth spraying was effective when 50 mg/m were applied within two-month matching immigration season. >80% reduction in abundance was not by larger doses or more interventions, and decreased different timing and frequencies. Alternatively, screens reduced abundance proportionally to immigration rate.
Feathers in birds are arranged in a precise pattern on the skin. They first appear in a row along the dorsal midline, with new feather buds added sequentially in a wave. We show that feather patterning relies on fibroblast growth factor (FGF) and bone morphogenetic protein (BMP) signalling together with mesenchymal cell movement in a coordinated reaction-diffusion system. This system is partly mechanochemical with mechanical-chemical integration through positive feedback on FGF20, which induces aggregation, compressing epidermis to intensify F20. The wave of feather formation is imposed by expanding Ectodysasin (DA) which initiates F20. DA spreads across mesenchym cell gradient, triggering formation by lowering mesench threshold to begin feather bud. These waves and feather primord arrangement are lost in flightless ostrich and emu, though different routes. Ostrich retains general bird arrangement but lays primord without wave, like mammalian hair follicle formation. Embryonic em lacks cells to enact formation, causing failure, instead entire skin gains primord through later.
Since the 2013–2015 Ebola outbreak, there was an unprecedented transmission of the virus within urban environments and thousands of survivors. In 2014, the World Health Organization stated that there was insufficient evidence to give definitive guidance on which body fluids are infectious and pose a risk to humans. We report a systematic review of evidence on the presence of filoviruses in body fluids of infected and survivors. We screened scientific articles for information on filirus in human fluids. The aim was to find primary data that suggested a high likelihood of active filirus in human fluids ( RNA ). Eligible infections were Marburg ( MARV or RAV ) and Zaire, Sudan, Taï and Bundibug species of Ebola. Cause of infection had to be confirmed in laboratory ( tissue culture or RT-PCR tests ) or evidenced by clinical history with subsequent filirus positivity or inflammatory factors. Data were extracted and summarized. We found 683 unique articles, and after screening 33 were eligible. Most fluid types had insufficient patients to draw conclusions and prevalence was highly variable. Fluids taken >16 days after onset were usually negative. The six studies that used both RTPCR tests for filirus RNA gave positive results about 4 times more often than culture. Filirus was in most fluid types but not every sample from otherwise confirmed patient.
Neuronal Spike Adaptation Described with a Fractional Leaky Integrate-and-Fire Model  
Neuronal spiking activity can be characterized by multiple timescales that arise from correlated membrane conductance processes. These processes result in power-law behavior that cannot be described by a single time constant. The emergent effect of these correlations is a non-Markovian process that can be modeled by a fractional derivative. A fractional derivative is a non-local process where the value of the variable is determined by integrating a weighted voltage trace, also called memory. Here, we developed a fractional leaky integrate-and-fire model where the exponent of the derivative varies from 0 to 1, with 1 representing the derivative. As the exponent decreases, the weights of the trace increase. Thus, the value is increasingly correlated with the trajectory of in the past. By varying the exponent, our model reproduces upward and downward adaptations found in cortical pyramidal and tectal neurons in vitro. The model also produces spikes with longer latency and inter-spike variability and power-law distribution.
Paracoccoides is a pathogenic fungus that must be able to defend itself against reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced by host cells to survive. To counteract these radicals, Parocoides expresses different antioxidant enzymes, including superoxide dismutases (SODs). In this study, we identified six SOD isoforms encoded by Parocoides genome. We determined expression levels of SODs in three phylogenetic lineages of Paroces (PS1, PS2 PS3 and Pb01 ) using quantitative RT-PCR. We analyzed SOD expression in yeast, mycelia, mycel-to-yeast transition and yeast-to-myc germination as well as under oxidative treatment and phagocytic interaction. We observed increased expression of PbOD1 and Pb3 during transition, exposure to oxidative agents and phagoc interaction, suggesting these proteins assist in combating superoxide radicals during host-pathogen interaction. Using Pb1 Pb3 knockdown strains we showed these genes are involved in response against host cells, particularly oxidative stress, in mouse infection model.
Intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) are highly susceptible to proteolysis in vitro, but surprisingly show no enhanced degradation in vivo. We hypothesize that IDPs preferentially interact with chaper proteins in the cell, which may protect them from degradation by proteases. To test this, we analyzed pairwise interaction data from high-throughput studies to see if disorder correlates with chaper binding. Our major finding is that predicted disorder by IUP correlates negatively with chaper binding in E. coli, S. cerevisiae, and metaz species. Since disorder correlates with partner binding in the interactome, the difference between chaper-binding and non-binding proteins is even more pronounced when normalized to their tendency to be involved in proteinprotein interactions. We argue that chaper binding is primarily required for folding of globular proteins, as reflected in preference for chones with at least Pfam domain.
In Drosophila melanogaster wing imaginal discs are regulated by the Decapapentaplegic (Dpp) signalling pathway. The spalt (sal) and spalt-related (salr) genes encode Zn-finger transcription factors required for cell survival and proliferation in the central wing disc and vein patterning in lateral regions. To understand the genetic control of wing growth and patterning by Dpp, we need to identify direct Salm and Salr target genes and study their functions. We identified candidate Salm/Sr targets by comparing sal/sr knockdown wing discs with control discs in microarray experiments. We studied the expression of genes whose mRNA levels varied by in situ hybridization and uncovered a complex transcription landscape regulated by Spalt in the disc. Candidate Salmr targets include genes whose expression is turned off and genes whose expression is positively regulated by Salmr. Loss-of-function analysis of these genes indicates that a fraction of them are required for wing growth and patter.
Protein phosphatase 1 Regulates ZYG-1 Levels to Limit Centriole Duplication in Caenorhabditis elegans.
Visceral leishmanias in an environmentally protected area in southeastern Brazil: Epidemiological and laboratory cross-sectional investigation of phbotine fauna, wild and canine hosts. Leishmanias is a rapidly expanding zoonosis that shows increasing urbanization. Concern exists regarding the role of wildlife in visceral leishiasis ( VL ) transmission, due to natural or anthropogenic environmental changes that facilitate contact between wildlife, humans and their pets. The municipality of Campinas, in southeastern Brazil, initially recorded VL in 2009, when the first autochthon case was confirmed in a dog living in an upscale condominium, inside an environmentally protected area ( EPA ). Since then, disease remains restricted to dogs inhabiting two geographically contiguous condominiums within EPA. We conducted cross-sectional study of VL to investigate Leish spp. infection in domestic, wild mammals and sand flies using molecular and serological techniques. Canine seroprevalences 1. 5% and 1.2% were observed in 2013 and 2015, respectively. Six species, confirmed or suspected vectors or transmitters of Leish, were identified. Two of the main L. (. ) infant vector in Brazil, Lutzia longipal, were captured in EPA. Natural by L. (. infant was recorded in Expill firm and Pintia montola. Natural by L. infant and Leish subannia was also detected in white-eared opossum Did albivent, known VL reservoir.
Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is an oncogenic virus that is closely associated with nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC), a highly metastatic type of tumor frequently reported in Asia. Previous studies have shown that several viral proteins promote the migration and invasiveness of NPC cells. However, not all tissues express viral oncoproteins, suggesting that other mechanisms may contribute to aggressive behavior of tumor cells. In this study, we investigated the effect of EBV-encoded microRNA miR-B9 in EB-negative and EB-positive NPC cells using gain and loss-of-function approaches. We found that mi-B9 promotes migration and invas of NPC cells. The promatory activity in vitro was manifested as metastatic ability in vivo. Computational analysis revealed that mi-B9 may target E-cadher, a protein pivotal in cell junctions and epithelial phenotype. Biochemical and functional analysis confirmed that mi9 inhibits Ead to induce mesenchymal phenotype and promote migration NPC cells.
Gash is a command-line tool for visualizing splicing events across multiple samples. Given a genomic region, gash creates sash plots for individual RNA-seq experiments as well as aggregated plots for groups of experiments. This is a unique feature of gash. Compared to existing programs generating sash plots, gash uses popular bioinformatics file formats, is annotation-independent and allows visualization of splicing events for large genomic regions by scaling down genomic segments between splice sites.
Comparative analysis of cis-regulatory modules (CRMs) across species has emerged as a powerful tool for understanding their evolution and prediction. However, reliable sequence alignment remains challenging for conserved non-coding sequences. Existing models of DNA evolution do not explicitly treat properties of CRMs. We propose a probabilistic model of CRM evolution that captures modes of transcription factor binding sites (TFBS) and background sequences. A novel aspect is a probabilistic model of TFBS gains and losses, recognized as part of regulatory evolution. We present a computational framework that uses this model to solve CRM alignment and prediction problems. Our method is similar to statistical alignment but uses conserved sites to improve alignment. Our CRM method deals with uncertainties of binding annotations and alignment in a probabilistic framework. We demonstrate our program improves alignment and prediction over state-of-the-art methods in simulated and real data. Our alignments are used to study genome-wide binding of transcription factors in Drosophila blastod, with results: ( i ) factor-bound sequences are under evolutionary constraints if neighboring genes are not expressed in blastod ( ii ) distal sites tend to be more conserved than proximal.
Transposons and other selfish DNA elements are found in all eukaryotes and their mobilization can compromise genome integrity. The piRNA (PIWI-interacting RNA) pathway silences transpos in the germline, but it is unclear if this pathway has additional functions during development. Here we show that mutations in Drosophila piRNA genes, armi, aub, ago, andhi lead to extensive fragmentation of the zygotic genome during cleavage stage embryonic divisions. Additionally, aub and arm show defects in telomeresolution during meiosis and cleavage divisions and mutations ligIV, which disrupt nonhomologous end joining suppress fusions. By contrast ligIV mutations enhance chromosome fragmentation. Chromatin immunoprecipitation studies show aub and arm mutations disrupt telom binding of HO, a component of telomere complex and expression of subpopulation 19-22ntelomeric piRNAs. Mutations rhi and ago do not block HO binding or production of theseRNAs. These findings uncover genetically separable functions for DophilaRNA. Theub, arm,hi, andago silence transpos and maintain chromosome during cleavage embryonic divisions. However,ub and arm have additional in assembly telomere complex.
Since 2000, Zaire and Sudan ebolaviruses have been responsible for large hemorrhagic fever (HF) outbreaks with case fatality rates ranging from 53% to 90%. In contrast, a third species, Côte d'Ivo ebolavirus caused a single fatal case of HF. In November 2007, HF cases were reported in Bundibyo District, Western Uganda. Laboratory investigation of the initial 29 suspect blood specimens by classic antigen capture IgM and IgG ELISA and recently developed random-primed pyrosequencing identified the outbreak to be associated with a newly discovered ebolavirus ( Bundibyo ebavirus ) distantly related to Côte dvo ebolavirus in western Africa.
Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a complex neurodegenerative disorder characterized by a wide variability in disease progression rates among patients. Previous studies have reported differences in rates of progression, but there has been no quantitative assessment of the degree of heterogeneity in AD. To evaluate the results of clinical studies, it is essential to obtain a reliable measure of progression rates and variances among patients for each stage of AD. The Global Deteration Scale (GDS) and Functional Staging (FAST) procedures characterize seven stages of AD from normal aging to severe dementia, each with published mean durations but unknown variances. We used statistical analysis to reconstruct DS/FAST durations in a cohort of 648 AD patients with an average follow-up of 4.78 years. Calculations for DS/FAST stages 4–6 revealed that standard deviations for durations are comparable to mean values, indicating large variations in AD progression among patients. This heterogeneity in AD progression is consistent with the existence of several subgroups of patients differing by decline patterns.
Recent studies have shown that adult neurogenesis in the hippocampus is important for memory encoding and responding to changes in input statistics. Here, we extend this work to include realistic spatial input patterns from grid cells in the entorhinal cortex. We compare three adaptation strategies: synaptic plasticity, where the network is fixed but connectivity is plastic; neuronal turnover, where the network is fixed but units may die and be replaced; and additive neurogenesis, where the network starts with fewer units but grows over time. We show that additive neurogenesis is superior with realistic spatial patterns. We also show that a biologically plausible neurogenesis, incorporating cell death and plasticity of granule cells, has better performance than individual strategies. This rule can be tailored for short or long-term memory. We examine neurogenesis over lifetime under different rearing conditions. These profiles have features that could be tested experimentally. Finally, we show that place cells emerge in our model as a result of dentate gyrus sparsification.
Trypanosomes express three identical cytosolic glutathione peroxidase (Px)-type enzymes that detoxify lipid-derived hydroperoxides. In bloodstream Trypanosoma brucei lacking mitochondrial PxIII display a weak and transient proliferation defect, whereas parasites lacking cytosolic PxI and PxII undergo rapid lipid peroxidation and lysis. The phenotype is rescued by supplementing with α-tocopherol derivative Trolox. We show that the lysosome is the origin of cellular injury. Feeding PxII knockout parasites with Alexa-conjugated dextran or LysoTracker in presence of Tro yields discrete lysosomal staining. Upon Tro withdrawal, the signal spreads over the cell and is lost. T. bruce acquires iron by endocytosis of transferrin. Supplementing with iron or transferrin induces whereas ironchel deferox and apo-transferrin attenuates lysis of PxII cells. Immunofluorescence with Mito and lysosomal marker p67 reveals disintegration precedes mitochondrial damage. In vivo experiments confirm negligible mitochondrial role: PxIII cells display only slightly delayed disease compared to wild-type. Our data demonstrate that in bloodstream tryosomes, the lysosome is the primary site of damage and cytos Px protect the lys from iron-induced peroxidation.
Melanophilin (PM) is an amyloid protein expressed in pigment cells that forms intracellular fibrils within melanosomes early in the melanin deposition process. It is conserved among vertebrates and allelic variants in several species are associated with reduced melanin in epidermal tissues. However, it is unclear whether allelic variants reflect gain-of-function or loss-of-function and no PM loss-of-function has been reported in mammals. We generated a mouse line in which the PM gene has been inactivated (PM−/−). These mice are viable, fertile and display no developmental defects. Melanosomes in PM−− melanocytes are spherical in contrast to the elongated shape present in wild-type. This was documented in primary cultures of skin-derived melanocytes as well as retinal pigment epithelium and uveal melanocytes. Inactivation of PM has a mild effect on the coat phenotype in four genetic backgrounds with the clearest in mice carrying brown/Tp. This phenotype is similar to observed in spontaneous mice, suggesting other described alleles in vertebrates with striking effects are dominant mutations.
Vector control remains the primary method to prevent deng infections. Environmental interventions are sustainable and safe with limited risks of contamination and toxicity. We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis of the effectiveness of the following environmental methods for deng vector control: (1) container covers with insecticides, (2) waste management and clean-up campaigns, and (3) elimination of breeding sites. Nineteen studies were eligible for review, sixteen contributed to meta-analysis. Quality was highest for container covers with insecticides, followed by waste without direct collection and elimination of breeding. Both review and meta showed weak effect on larval populations with no differences between methods. For meta, container without insecticides (BI: -7.9, DOE-5 ) and waste with collection (BI: -8.83, DOE-6.2 ) achieved strongest BI reductions, whereas P results were opposite with covers (P: -.83, 0.09 ) and elimination (P: -.95, -.83 ) showing strongest.
Small molecules that inhibit protein synthesis by selectively stalling the ribosome constitute a new strategy for therapeutic development. Compounds that inhibit the translation of PCSK9, a major regulator of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol, have been identified that reduce LDL in preclinical models and affect the translation of only a few off-target proteins. Here, we used a genome-wide CRISPR screen to identify proteins and pathways that modulate growth in the presence of high doses of a PCS9 translational inhibitor, PF-06303 ( PF3 ). The most potent genetic modifiers of fitness in the presence of PF3 were the ubiquitin binding proteins ASC2 and helicase3, which bind to the ribosome and protect cells from toxic effects of high concentrations of the compound. Surprisingly, translation control proteins Pelota and H1 sensitize cells to PF3 treatment. In genetic experiments, helic3 acts together with ASC2 and functions downstream of H1. These results identify new connections between ribosome control pathways and provide insights into selectivity of compounds that stall translation.
Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is known to induce widespread destruction of cellular mRNAs in order to block host gene expression and evade immune detection. The viral protein SO is responsible for this phenotype, but the mechanism of SO-induced mRNA turnover has remained unknown, given its lack of intrinsic ribonuclease activity. Here, we report that SO stimulates cellular mRNA turnover via a novel mechanism involving aberrant polyadenylation. SO-expressing cells exhibit extended poly ( ) polymer II-generated poly A tails and polyaden-linked mRNA turnover. SO-induced polyadenylation correlates with RNA turnover, and inhibition of poly A tail formation blocks SO activity. Both nuclear and cytoplasmic poly A binding proteins are critical for SO function, the latter of which undergoes striking nuclear localization by SO.
Bacterial pathogens Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa induce the production of type III interferon (IFλ) in the lung. IFλ is essential for host defense against some viral pathogens, but its role in innate response to bacterial pathogens is unknown. IFλ receptor (IL-28) is abundantly expressed in the respiratory tract. In mice lacking IL-28, clearance of bacteria from the lung was significantly reduced compared to controls. Clearance of bacteria correlated with reduced lung pathology and increased ratio of anti-inflammatory to pro-inflammatory cytokines in the airway. In human epithelial cells, IFλ inhibited miR-21 via STAT, resulting in upregulation of PDC4, a protein promoting inflammatory signaling. In vivo, following infection with either pathogen, mi-21 was reduced and P4 increased in lungs of wild type mice compared IL-28 null. Infection of P4 null mice with USA resulted in improved clearance, reduced pathology, and inflammatory cytokine production. These data suggest that during bacterial pneumonia IFλ promotes inflammation by inhibiting mi-21 regulation of4.
In the Democratic Republic of Congo, we conducted a retrospective study on 781 naïve cases of advanced stage-2 sleeping sickness between 1989 and 2012 at the National Center for African Trypanosomiasis. The outcome was death, and predictors were age, gender, duration of disease, location of trypanosomes in body fluids, cyach, protach, clinical status on admission, and treatment. Death proportions were 17. 2% in the standard melop schedule, 12.1 in the short melop, 5.4 in first-line eornine, 9. in NECT, and 36 in the group with severely affected patients. After adjusting for treatment, death ratios were: 10.40 for clinical dysfunction on admission,2. for protach,.99 for presence in CSF and.1 for cyach. Multivar analysis retained clinical on admission and protach as predictors of death.
Drosophila melanogaster is a powerful model organism to study social behavior. Isolation profoundly influences social behavior in all animals, and has serious effects on health in humans. However, analysis of social behavior in Dophila is hampered by the lack of effective and reliable tools. We built a new arena and improved tracking algorithm to follow a large number of flies simultaneously. Next, we designed an algorithm to quantify changes in social network in response to isolation based on automatic classification and graph analysis. We observed that isolation significantly enhanced individual and local network parameters near-neighbor relationships. We explored genome-wide molecular correlates of these changes and found that behavior changed throughout six days of isolation, gene expression occurred largely one day. These occurred mostly in metabolic genes and verified by increase of lipid in isolated flies.
The World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines for diarrheal disease management were adapted into a smartphone tool to improve clinical adherence in resource-limited settings. A pilot study was conducted in rural Bangladesh to evaluate the tool’s impact. The tool included a modality for age-based weight estimation, which was developed with end-user input and evaluated in a resource-limited district and sub-district hospital during the 2015 cholera season. Both hospitals lacked scales, necessitating weight estimation. The study consisted of a 6 week pre-intervention and 6 week intervention period with 10-day post-discharge follow-up. Standard care was maintained with the exception of admitting clinicians using the tool during intervention. Inclusion criteria were patients two months of age and older with uncomplicated diarral disease. The primary outcome was adherence to guidelines for intravenous (IV) fluids, antibiotics and zinc. A total 841 patients were enrolled (325 pre-intervention; 516 intervention ). During intervention, the proportion of prescriptions for IV fluids decreased at both district and subistrict hospitals (p<0.001) with risk ratios (RRs) of 0.5 and 0.2, respectively. However, when IV fluids were prescribed, volume adhered to recommendations. Proportion for recommended azithromycin increased (p<0.001; district p=0.035 subistrict) with RR of 6.9 and 1.6 while prescriptions for other antibiotics decreased; zinc adherence increased.
Host-parasite interactions are complex systems that are difficult to predict how they will respond to climate change. In particular, host and parasite traits such as survival and virulence may have distinct temperature dependencies that must be integrated into models of disease dynamics. Using experimental data from Daphnia magna and a microidian parasite, we fitted a mechanistic model of within-host parasite dynamics. The model comprised host mortality, parasite growth, virulence, and abundance parameters arising from the metabolic theory of ecology. The model effectively predicted survival, parasite growth, and cost of infection across temperatures using less than half the parameters compared to modeling discretely.
GABAergic interneurons play a crucial role in shaping the activity of excitatory pyramidal cells (PCs). However, the contribution of various inhibitory cell types to neuronal processing is not resolved. Here, we propose a functional role for a network motif consisting of parvalbumin (PV), somostatin (SOM) and vaso intestinal peptide (VIP)-expressing interneurons. We suggest that PV and SOM interneurons control the distribution of somatic and dendritic inhibition onto PCs. Moreover, we propose that mutual inhibition between SOM and VIP interneurons translates VIP inputs into changes of somato-dendritic inhibition of PCs. Using a computational model, we show that neuronal and synaptic properties support this hypothesis. We demonstrate that the SOM-VIP motif allows inputs to persistently switch the circuit between two modes, in which top inputs onto apical dendrites of PCs are either integrated or cancelled.
Microbiome-wide association studies are widely used to investigate the relationship between microbial communities and host phenotypes, including disease. These studies compare microbial abundances between two groups of samples to link specific microbes to phenotypes. However, abundance differences reflect not only direct associations with the phenotype, but also indirect effects due to microbial interactions. We found that interactions can easily generate a large number of spurious associations that provide no mechanistic insight. We developed a method to remove indirect associations using techniques from statistical physics and applied it to the largest dataset on pediatric inflammatory bowel disease. Our method corrected the inflation of p-values in standard tests and showed that only a small subset of associations is directly linked to disease. Direct associations had much higher accuracy in separating cases from controls and pointed to immunomodulation, butyrate and brain-gut axis as important in inflammatory disease.
Dengue virus (DENV) and West Nile virus (WNV) replication and transmission in Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are studied using three Wolbachia infection models: naturally infected Wolbach hosts, transinfected Wolbach (stably maintained infections ) and transiently infected Wolbach hosts. These models have been used to study the effect of Wolbach on transmitted pathogens such as DENV, WNV and Plasmodium. The interaction between Wolbach and pathogen is influenced by host-Wolbach interaction and infection model. Some studies suggest Wolbach can enhance pathogen infection under specific conditions. This study compares Wolbach effects in two models ( transected and transiently infected ) on DENV and WNV (Kun strain ) replication, infection and transmission rates. Results show Wolbach similar blocking effects in both stable and transient models, but lower magnitude in transiently infected Wolbach. Importantly, no enhancement of DENV or WNV (un strain ) infection found in Wolbach infected Ae.egypt.
Cilia are microtubular organelles that mediate signal transduction and are organized into structurally and functionally distinct compartments: the basal body, the transition zone ( TZ ), and the shaft. In vertebrates, the protein Invers localizes to a portion of the shaft adjacent to the TZ, termed the Invers compartment ( Inv ). The mechanisms that establish and maintain Inv are unknown. In C. elegans, the shafts of amphid and phasm sensory cilia are subdivided into regions by different microtub structure: a proximal doublet adjacent to TZ and dist singlet. We show that Inv is conserved and distinct from double region. n-2 ( Invers hom ) and double genes,,, and are redundantly required for cili. Inv and double can be sorted into modules—+ and — which are antagonized by deacetyl. The genes modulate the sizes of Inv and double. Glutamylation is not required for ciliary of Inv and double components; rather, is modulated by, and. The restricted localization does not require TZ, and Inv-associated genes. does require its domain for Inv.
Myelination and remyelination in the central nervous system (CNS) is a complex process that requires profound changes in oligodendrocy shape to initiate myelin sheath formation. Here, we show that the polarity protein Scribble is required for CNS myelination and remyination. Scribble is expressed throughout oligodendrogl development and is upregulated in mature oligodrocytes where it is localised to developing and mature myelin sheaths. In cultured oligodroglia, Scribble knockdown results in disrupted morphology and myelination. In myelinating glia of transgenic mice where Scri is conditionally eliminated, myination in CNS is disrupted during development and following demyelination, and myelin sheath extension is disrupted. At later myination stages, Scri acts to regulate myelin and suppresses the extracellular signal-related kinase (ER)/mitogen-activated protein (MAP) pathway, localising to noncompact myelin flanking the node of Ranvier where it is required for paranodal axo-glial adhesion.
Streptolysin S (S) is a bacteriocin-like hemolytic and cytotoxic virulence factor that plays a key role in the virulence of Group A Streptococcus (GAS), the causative agent of pharyngitis, impet, necrotizing fascitis and streptoccal shock. Although it has been thought that SLS and related peptides are produced by GAS and streptocci only, there is evidence to suggest that number of most Gram-positive pathogenic bacteria, including Listeria monocytogen, Clostridium botulin and Staphlococcus aureus, produce related peptides. The distribution of L monocogen cluster is noteworthy in that it is exclusively found among subset lineage I; i. e., responsible for majority of outbreaks of listiosis. Expression of these genes results in production of hemolytic and cytotoxic factor, Listerin S, which contributes virulence of pathogen assessed by murine and human polymorph neutrophil–based studies.
Mycetoma is a chronic granulomatous inflammatory disease that can be caused by fungi or bacteria. The disease is characterized by the formation of macroscopic structures called grains, which are surrounded by a massive inflammatory reaction. The mechanisms leading to this reaction and the immunophenotypic characteristics of mycetoma granuloma are unknown. We hypothesised that the expression of interleukin-17 ( IL-17 ) and matrixloproase-9 ( MMP-9 ) in myetoma was correlated with the severity of the disease and this was independent of the causative agent responsible for the reaction. To determine IL-17 and MMP-9 in myet lesions, we conducted a study at Myet Research Centre, Sudan. Surgical biopsies from 100 patients with myet were obtained and IL-17 and MMP9 in myet granoma evaluated immunohistochemically. IL-17 was mainly expressed in Zones I and II, and less in III. MMP-9 was mainly in II and III, and least in I. MMP-9 was highly expressed in Actinadura pelletii and Streptomyces somalis biies compared to Madura myetatis biies. MMP-9 was directly proportional to IL-17 ( p 0. 001 ). Only association between MMP9 and patients’ characteristics was disease ( p 0.001 ). There was no correlation IL-17 and patients’ characteristics.
Molecular recognition by intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) often involves specific contacts that induce disorder to order transitions. However, some IDPs remain disordered in the bound state, a phenomenon called “fuzziness”, characterized by ID polyvalency, sequence-insensitivity and dynamic disordered bound-state conformations. Besides general features, specific biophysical models for fuzzy interactions are lacking. The transcription activation domain of Ewing Sarcoma oncoprotein (E) is an ID that exhibits fuzziness with multiple E aromatic chains driving recognition. We hypothesized that E-target binding involves polyc-π contacts between disordered E residues and basic on target. We evaluated the pol-π hypothesis via functional and theoretical interrogation of E variants. The effects of E sequence variations, including aromatic number, density and perturbations support the model. Moreover, trends are captured by a coarse-grained E model and based on between E aromatics and cations of a generic target. E-target binding is driven by balance between E conformation and favorable c-π contacts.
Borrelia burgdorferi, the etiologic agent of Lyme disease, has two putative ATP-dependent Lon homologs, Lon-1 and Lon-2. Previous studies have shown that lon-1 is upregulated by blood in vitro while lon-2 is not. This study aimed to clarify the functional roles of these proteases in B. burgorferi. Phylogenetic analysis revealed that lon-1 and lon-2 cluster separately due to differences in the NH-terminal binding domains. Recombinant lon-1 manifested ATP-dependent chaperone-prote activity in vitro but did not complement E. coli mutant, while lon-2 corrected characteristic lon-mut phenotypes. We conclude that B burgorferi lon-1 and lon-2 have distinct functions. lon-2 functions in a manner consistent with Lon, engaged in cellular homeostasis. lon-, by virtue of blood induction, may be important in host adaptation from arthropod to warm-blood host.
Human Immunodeficiency virus-1 (HIV-1) evades antibody-dependent phagocytosis. Antibody-dependent phagocytosis (ADP) is a function of the Fcγ receptor (FcR)-mediated antibody that plays a role in preventing other viral infections, but its role in HIV is unknown. We measured the ability of HIV-specific polyclonal and monoclonal antibodies (Abs) to mediate the internalization of HIV-1 virions and HIV-1-decorated cells by phagocytes. We used a green-fluorescent protein-expressing molecular of HIV-1JR, R, an R5 clinical isolate, in combination with polyclonal HIV or Abs to capture and neutralize HIV-1. THP and U937 cells, as well as freshly isolated monocytes from healthy individuals were used as phagytic effector cells, and uptake of virions was measured by cytometry. We found minimal AD of virions with any Abs. However, after virions were coated with gp41 or gp-derived peptides, gp41 ( but not gp120 ) Abs efficiently phagocytosed. We estimated a minimum of few gp41 were needed for phagytosis, similar to the number of envelope on viruses that are phagytosed ( e. g. influenza ). Employing fluorescence spectroscopy, we found a association between virus and AD. In contrast virions, vir-decor cells were targets for AD orgocyt in presence HIV Abs. Our findings indicate AD of vir may not play in preventing infection due paucity of trimers and inability vir-bound to cross FcRs phocytes. However, AD orocyt could play in HIV-infected cells verge.
Hookworm infection is a major public health problem in many countries around the world, but its global health and economic impact is not well known. We developed a computational model to estimate the economic and health burden of hookworm infection in every country, region, and globally in 2016 from a societal perspective. Globally, hook infection resulted in 2, 126, 280 disability adjusted life years ( DALs ) using 200 disability estimates and 4, 087 803 DALs using 201 estimates ( excluding cognitive impairment ). The total productivity losses varied from $7.5 to $138.9 billion annually using gross national income per capita as a proxy for wages and from $2.5 to $43.9 billion using minimum wage as proxy.
Hypoxia Disrupts Vertebrate CNS Pathfinding through EphB2 Rescued by Magnesium. Hypoxia is a major cause of chronic neurodevelopmental impairments, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Recent work in invertebrate Caenorhabditis elegans has shown that hypia causes axon pathfinding errors in certain neurons. We found that hypia disrupts pathfinding of forebrain neurons in zebraf ( Danio rer ), leading to errors in commissural axons failing to cross the midline. The defects result from activation of the hypia-inducible transcription factor (h1) pathway and are mimicked by chemical inducers of h1 or expression of constitutive h1α. Further, we found that blocking hα prevented the defects. We identified ephrinB2 as a target of h activation, showed knockdown of ephB rescued the defects and that ephA is expressed in a pattern to the misrouting axons. By targeting constitutive ephB to neurons we found eph mediates via reverse-signaling. Finally, magnesium protects against errors by preventing eph upregulation.
Paracococciidioidomycosis (PCM) is an endemic fungal disease of pulmonary origin caused by Paracoccioides brasiliensis (Pb). This study aims to define the patterns and intensity of lung lesions in experimentally infected mice by comparing High Resolution Computed Tomography (HRCT) and histopathological findings. Male BAL/c mice were intranasally inoculated with 3×106 Pb conidia (n=50) or PBS (n=50). HRCT was done every four weeks to determine pulmonary lesions, lung density, and structure. Lungs were also analyzed by histology and histometry. Three patterns were evidenced by HR and histology: nodular-diffuse, confluent and pseudo-tum. Lesions were mainly around the hilus and frequently affected the left lung. At 4 weeks post-challenge HR showed 80% Pb-infected had peri-bronial consolidations with significant increase in lung density compared to controls (−263±25 vs −42210HU p<0.001). After 8 and 12 weeks consolidation progressed to middle regions. Histology revealed consolidation by HR as confl granulomatous reaction while nodules corresponded compact granomas. At 16 weeks confl granomas formed pseudooral masses obstructing bronchi. Discrete fibrosis was around granomas but only evident histology.
Leishmania donovani is a protozoan parasite that causes visceral leishmaniasis (VL), a major public health problem in the Indian subcontinent. In endemic areas, a large number of individuals are infected but remain asymptomatic. We propose interferon-gamma release assay (IF-RA) as a novel marker for latent L. donov infection. We modified a commercial kit (QuFERON) with five leishmania antigens to detect cell-mediated response in VL. We evaluated the assay on venous blood samples of active VL patients (13), cured patients (15), non-endemic controls (11) and endemic controls (19). The assay based on soluble leishmania antigen (SL) had 80% sensitivity (95%CI=54.81–92.95) and 100% specificity (95%CI=74.–100). Our findings suggest a whole-blood SL-based QuFER assay can measure cell-mediated response in L.ov infection. The IF- response to leish antigen in VL patients was contradictory to conventional non-proliferative antigen response of blood mononuclear cells.
Yersinia pseudotuberculosis is an enteric pathogen that causes gastrointestinal infections that can become persistent and complicated by relapsing enteritis and severe autoimmune disorders. To establish a persistent infection, the bacteria have to cope with hostile surroundings when transmigrating through the intestinal epithelium and colonizing underlying gut-associated lymphatic tissues. Here we show that the CNFY toxin enhances translocation of antiphocytic Y effectors, inducing inflammatory responses. This results in extensive tissue destruction of the intestinal microbiota and bacterial clearance. Suppression of CNFY function, however, increases interferon-γ responses comprising non-inflammatory antimicrobial activities and tolerogenesis. This is accompanied by preprogramming the pathogen’s transcription towards persistence, giving bacteria a fitness against responses and establishment of commensal life.
In this article, we describe a novel pathogenic gene, DES1, in the rice blast fungus Magnaporthe oryza that suppresses basal defenses of the host plant. We identified DES1 by screening for pathogenic-defective mutants in a T-DNA insertional library. Bioinformatic analysis revealed that DES1 encodes a serine-rich protein with unknown biochemical properties and homologs conserved in filamentous Asycetes. Targeted deletion of DES1 had no effect on morphogenesis, vegetative growth, conial germination, appressium formation, and appium-mediated penetration. However, conial size of Δdes mutant was smaller than wild type and Δdes displayed no defects in cell wall integrity. Δdes mutant was hypersensitive to exogenous stress and activity and transcription of extracellular enzymes including peroxides and lases was severely decreased in Δdes. In addition, ferrous leakage was observed in Δdes. In interaction with susceptible rice, Δdes mutant exhibited strong defense responses by brown granules in infected cells, accumulation of reactive species (ROS), generation autofluorescent materials and PR induction in tissues. Δdes displayed significant reduction in hyphal extension and caused decrease in pathogenicity. Notably, suppression of ROS by DPI, inhibitor of NAD oxidases resulted in significant reduction in defense in tissues challenged Δdes. Furthermore, Δdes recovered normal growth in DPI-treated tissues.
Schistosomiasis is a parasitic disease caused by Schistosoma haematobium that is a major public health problem in Ghana. To determine where control programs should operate, it is essential to map the distribution of schosiasis. However, it is impractical to assess infection in every potentially endemic community, so model-based geostatistics (MB) is increasingly used to predict prevalence and determine intervention strategies. We evaluated the accuracy of MB predictions for Schos haobium in Ghana by comparing empiric values from 79 school surveys with values derived from published MB predictions. Schools were categorized according to WHO guidelines to determine practical implications of differences. Using predicted values alone, 21 of 25 empirically ‘high’ schools requiring praziquel would have been undertreated and almost 20% of remaining would have been treated despite empirically-determined absence of infection. This translates to 28% of children in 79 schools undertreated and 12% receiving treatment in absence of demonstrated need. Using current MB for Ghana as decision tool, aggregating prevalence to district level was not adequate for national program, but assessing each school in potentially endemic areas is not feasible; MB must be complementary to empiric assessments.
In the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans, the mechanisms that guide motile sperm through the female reproductive tract to the oocytes are not well understood. We have shown that C. elegans oocytes synthesize sperm-guiding prostaglandins from polyunsaturated fatty acid ( PU ) precursors provided in yolk lipoprotein. Here we use genetics and electrospray ion tandem mass spectrometry to delineate F-series prostland metabolism. We show that omega-6 and omega-3 PUFAs, arachidonic and eicosentaenoic acids are converted into more than 10 structurally related F prostagland, which collectively and largely redundantly promote sperm guidance. Disruption of omega-3 PU synthesis triggers compensatory upregulation of prostagland derived from omega-6 PAs. C eleg prostagland synthesis involves biochemical mechanisms distinct from mammalian cyclooxygen-dependent pathways, yet PG2α stereomers are synthesized. A comparison F prostagland in C eleg and mouse tissues reveals shared features. Finally, we show conserved cytochrome P enzyme whose human hom is implicated in Bti Crystine dystrophy negatively regulates prostland synthesis.
Immunogenicity is a major bottleneck in the development of biotherapeutic pipelines. To overcome this, there is a need for improved deimmization technologies. We have developed an algorithm that simultaneously optimizes proteins for reduced T cell epitope content and high function. In silico analysis of this dual objective space reveals that there is no single optimum with respect to deimmization. Instead, mutagenic epitope deletion yields a spectrum of designs that trade between immunogenic potential and function. The edge of this space is the Pareto frontier, i. e. undominated for no single design better in both criteria. We have constructed and experimentally evaluated the Pareto of a therapeutic enzyme. Various measures of performance were found to map functional space that correlated with predictions.
Meiosis is a fundamental process of sexual reproduction in eukaryotes that depends on reciprocal exchange of DNA between homologous chromosomes, known as crossovers ( COs), to ensure proper chromosome segregation. The frequency and distribution of COs are regulated by intrinsic and extrinsic factors. Here, we show that elevated temperature induces meiotic hyper-recombination in Arabidopsis thalian and use genetic analysis of mutants in different recombination pathways to demonstrate that extra COs are derived from the Type I interference pathway. We also show that heat-induced COs are not the result of increase in double-strand breaks and the hyper-recomant phenotype is likely specific to thermal stress rather than a generalized response.
Biomedical Discovery Acceleration with Applications to Craniofacial Development: A Novel Computational Approach to Navigating the Rapidly Evolving Terrain of Biomedical Literature and Experimental Data  
Biomedical discovery is a rapidly evolving field, with an explosion of new results in the literature, particularly in molecular biomedicine. Even experienced researchers can benefit from computational tools that help navigate this vast and rapidly evolving terrain. We describe a novel approach to this challenge, a knowledge-based system that combines reading, reasoning, and reporting to facilitate analysis of experimental data. This system extracts information from external resources, either by parsing structured data or biomedical processing to extract information from unstructured, and tracks provenance. Reasoning enriches results from reading, for example, noting genes annotated to the same ontology or database. Reasoning also combines sources into a network that represents all relationships between pairs of genes, and calculates reliability. Reporting combines network with congruent constructed from data and visualizes in tool that facilitates knowledge-based analysis of data. We demonstrate this approach, called Hanalyzer, on large gene array dataset relevant to craniofac development. The tool was critical in creation of hypotheses regarding genes never characterized in cranfac development; each validated by further work.
Helminth pathogen Fasciola hepatica secretes extracellular vesicles (EVs) that can be internalised by host cells to modulate the immune response. While the cargo of EVs has been characterised in many parasites, little is known about the surface-exposed molecules that participate in ligand-receptor interactions with host cells to initiate vesicle docking and internalisation. We describe 380 proteins on the surface of two EV subpopulations (15 and 120 EV) released by adult F. hepatica, including virulence factors, transport proteins and molecules in EV biogenesis/trafficking. Proteomics and immunohistochemical analysis show that 120 EV have endosomal origin and may be released via the protonephial excretory system whilst larger 15 EV are released from gastrodermal epithelial cells lining the fluke gut. Lectin microarray profiling of surface oligosaccharides of fluorically labelled EVs shows lectin profiles corresponding to glycoconjugates on 15 and 120 EV are identical but distinct from parasite tegument and predominated by mannose. F hep EVs are resistant to exo and endoglycosidase but glycosidase remodels surface oligoschar and blocks uptake by macrophages.
The Arabidopsis thaliana CDF2 transcription factor is involved in the regulation of microRNA (miRNA) transcription and processing. miRNAs are first transcribed as stem-loop primary miRNAs (pri-miRNAs) by RNA polymerase II and then cleaved in the nucleus into mature miRNAs by Dicer-like 1 (DCL1). CDF2 interacts with D1 and regulates the accumulation of a subset of miRNAs. C2 binds directly to the promoters of some miRN and acts as a transcriptional activator or repressor of these miRNA genes. C2 preferentially binds to pri-miRNAs regulated by itself and affects D1-mediated processing of these priiRN. C2 genetically works in the same pathway as miR156 or mi172 to control flowering. We conclude that C2 regulates a group of priiRNAs at both transcriptional and post-transcription levels to maintain proper levels of mature miRN to control plant development.
Folliculogenesis is a complex and highly regulated process that is essential for providing ova for later in life. It requires bidirectional communication between the oocyte and granulosa cells. This communication conveys signals from the oocyte to granosa that regulate their proliferation and metabolites from granosa to the o for biosynthesis. However, the underlying mechanism of this communication is largely unknown. Here we report that oocyte geranyl diphosphate (GG), a metabolic intermediate in geranylation, is required for oocyte-granosa communication. GG and geranyliphosphate synthase (GPPS) levels in oocytes increase during early follicular development.
