GG depletion in oocytes impairs granosa proliferation, primary follicle transition and female fertility. Mechanistically, GG depletion inhibits Rho geranylation and its activity, responsible for accumulation of junction proteins in ocytoplasm and failure to maintain o-granosa connection. GG also blocks Rab geranylation, which accounts for impaired secretion o materials such as GDF. Moreover, GG restores defects o-granosa contact, granosa proliferation and primary follicle in PP depletion mice. Our study provides evidence that GG-mediated geranylation contributes to o-granosa communication and regulates primary follicle, a phase of essential for reproductive function.
The RNA polymerase II (Pol II) is a eukaryotic enzyme that catalyzes the synthesis of messenger RNA using a DNA as a template. Despite numerous biochemical and biophysical studies, it remains unclear whether the secondary channel is the only route for NTP to reach the active site of the enzyme or the main channel could be an alternative. We have built a structural model of Pol II with a complete transcription bubble based on multiple sources of existing structural data and Molecular Dynamics (MD) simulations to shed light on NTP pathways. We found that both channels have enough space to allow NTP loading, but the percentage of conformations with enough space for NTP through the secondary channel is twice that of the main. Further MD simulations with NTP in channels revealed that diffusion through the main is greatly disfavored by electrostatic repulsion between N and the highly charged backbone of nucleotides in non-template DNA.
Dengue is a reportable disease in Thailand and Cambodia, but the true burden of the disease is unknown due to underreporting. We estimated the magnitude of deng underrecognition and established more accurate burden estimates for these countries by calculating deng incidence from laboratory-confirmed outpatient and inpatient cases in prospective cohort studies. Cohort studies were conducted among children <15 years of age at deng field sites over at least 2 deng seasons. In Thailand, 14,627 person-years of cohort data were obtained from two provinces and 14,493-years from one in Cambodia. The average annual incidence of laboratory-confirmed deng was 23/1,000 and 25/1,000 in Thailand and 41/1,000 in Cambodia. Calculated age-specific factors (MF) varied by age and year (0.4–29). Average age-specific MF were applied to country-level data and indicated that in Thailand 229,886 (210,612–331,236) deng cases occurred annually 2003–2007 and 111,178 (80,452–357,135) in Cambodia. Average underrecognition of inpatient deng cases was 8.7 and 2.6 in Thailand and 9.1 and 1.4 in Cambodia. In 2007, >95,000 children in Thailand and >58,000 in Cambodia were estimated hospitalized due deng.
Natural Killer Cells Promote CD8 T Cell Responses against Murine Cytomegalovirus: A Novel Mechanism of Immune Defense against Viral Infection  
Natural killer (NK) cells are known to directly control viral replication, but their role in orchestrating global antiviral defense is largely unknown. We used congenic mice and genetically engineered viruses to examine the consequences of NK cell defects on antiv CD8 T responses against murine cytomegalovirus (MCMV). Our results demonstrate, for the first time, that NK cells accelerate CD8 T responses against viral infection in vivo. We identify the mechanism as the ability of NK cells to limit IFNα/β production, which is immunosuppressive to the host. This is achieved through early control of cytgalovirus, reducing activation of plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) for cytokine production, preserving conventional dendritic cells (DC) and accelerating antiv CD8 T responses. Conversely, exogenous IFα administration ablates DCs and delays CD8 T activation in the absence of NK control of viral replication. Our data demonstrate that NK responses to cytgalovirus critically contribute to the balance of innate responses, dampening immunopathology and promoting initiation of antiv CD8 T responses.
In plants, rRNA genes are organized in tandem arrays that can range from hundreds to thousands of copies. Although not all copies are transcribed under normal growth conditions, the mechanisms controlling expression of specific rRNA variants are unclear. Here, we report four rRNA variants in Arabidopsis thalian. Interestingly, transcription of one variant is induced while others are repressed or unaltered in A. thalian plants with disrupted nucleolin-like gene Auc1. The most representedRNA variant, inactive in WT, is reactivated inuc1 mutants. We show pre–RNAs originate from Pol I transcription are accurately processed. Moreover, Atuc1 induces loss of symmetrical DNA methylation without histone epigenetic marks r genes.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a member of the herpesvirus family that causes a range of diseases in humans. In this report, we have investigated the role of histone deacetylase 1 (HDAC1) in the context of CMV infection. We identified several CMV-coded proteins that interact with HD1, including UL38 and UL29. We confirmed the interaction of UL38 and UL29 with HD1 by reciprocal immunoprecipitation. HD1 is part of the NuRD complex, which is involved in chromatin remodeling and deacetylation. UL38 and UL29 associated with the MTA component of Nu, and RNA-mediated knockdown of RBP and CHD constituents of Nu inhibited CM immediateearly RNA and DNA accumulation. This suggests that multiple Nu components are needed for efficient CM replication. Consistent with a positive role for Nu during replication, growth of UL29- or UL38 deficient viruses could not be rescued by treating cells with the deetyl inhibitor trichostatin. Transient expression of UL29 enhanced the CM majorearly promoter in a reporter assay regardless of UL expression. Importantly, induction of the majorearly reporter by UL29 required Nu components, consistent with inhibition of RNA within cells after knock of RBP and CH4. We propose that UL29 modifies the Nu complex to stimulate accumulation of early RNAs.
Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is a major cause of pneumonia among infants and young children. Here, we elucidated the antibody repertoire following RSV infection and its evolution through adolescence and adulthood. We used whole-genome fragment display libraries to identify linear and conformational epitopes in the RSV fusion (F) and attachment (G) proteins. Epitope profiling of infant sera prior to and following RSV infection revealed modest changes in anti-F epitopes and a 100-fold increase in G-reactive epitopes spanning the N- and C-terminus of G ectodomain along with increased reactivity to conserved domain (CCD). Panels of F and G antigen sites were synthesized to evaluate sera from children (<2yr), adolescents (14–18yr) and adults (30–45yr) in real-time assays. A steady increase in RSV epitopes from children to adults was observed using peptides and proteins. Importantly, novel epitopes were identified in pre-fusion and immunodominant in F27. In all groups, antibody to preusion was 2–3 higher than postusion. For RSV, responses were high following infection in children but declined in adults using proteins or peptides.
Filariae are parasitic nematodes that cause diseases such as lymphatic filariasis and elephantiasis and river blindness in millions of people in tropical and sub-tropical countries. Current drugs are ineffective against adult filariae macrofilar. Emodeide, a veterinary anthelmint, has been reported to have macroilaridal effects. Here, we explore its mode of action on Brugia mal, a species causing lymphatic filariasis. Emide potently inhibits worm motility by activating voltage-gated potassium channels, with males being more sensitive than females. RNAi suggests emide targets S-1 channels. We expressed slo-1 isoforms with alternatively spliced exons at the RCK domain in Xenopus lavis oocytes. The slo-1 iso found in males is more sensitive to emide than slo-1a found in females. Selective RNAi of slo-1 in females increased emide potency. In Onchercavolus, causing river blindness, has two isoforms in females with homology to B-S-1 and B-F at R1. In silico modeling identified emide binding in same R1 of species affected by splicing. Our results show emide has potent macroidal effects and splicing in R1 affects potency.
The Global Program to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis (LF) relies on rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) to determine where mass drug administration for LF is required and when it can be stopped. These tests detect Wuchereria bancrofti glycoprotein in the blood of infected persons via a carbohydrate moiety recognized by monoclonal antibodies AD12 and DH.5. Recently, Loa loa cross-reactivity with RDTs has been recognized as a serious obstacle to LF elimination in Loa-endemic areas. To understand the nature of this cross-reactivity, we used DH. 5 to immunoaffinity purify Loa antigens from the sera of individuals with positive DT to Loa. Immunlot analysis revealed many AD/DH.5-reactive antigens and proteomic analysis identified multiple Lo proteins in RDT-positive Loa sera. These included secreted and somatic proteins, suggesting they may be released by Loa adult and/or microfilar. Unlike the high molecular W bancft circulating filarial antigen present in blood of persons bancft, Loa antigens appeared only transiently in blood of subset Loa.
Defects in primary cilia cause inherited disorders such as retinitis pigmentosa and Bardet-Bied syndrome (BBS), affecting multiple physiological and developmental processes across organs. Cilia formation and function depend on intraflagellar transport (IFT), which is driven by kinesin-2 and IFT-dyne motors and regulated by the Bardet-Bied syndrome (BS) cargo adaptor complex, Bome. To identify new cilium-associated genes, we employed the nematode C. elegans, where ciliogenesis occurs within a short timespan during embryogenesis when sensory neurons differentiate. Using whole-organ RNA-Seq, we discovered a signature profile highly enriched for ciliary transcripts, including FAM161, CC104, and RP1, which are cilium-localised in worms. From 185 candidate ciliary genes, we identified orthologues of MAP, Y, CC149, and R28 as conserved cilium components. Further analyses of C elegans R-28, associated with autosomal-recessive cone-rod dystrophy, reveal that this GTPase is exclusively expressed in ciliated neurons where it associates with IFT. R-bound R-28 displays no I movement and diffuse localisation, GTP-activated R-28 concentrates at periliary membrane in Bome-dependent and undergoes bidirectional I. Functional analyses reveal that cilium, sensory and I are normal in rab-28 allele, overexpression of GDP or GTP variants R-28 perturbs cil and sensory morphogenesis.
The brain is able to represent the world around it, but it is unclear how it does this. The brain can only rely on neural responses and does not have independent access to external stimuli in order to “decode” those responses. We investigate what can be learned about the space of stimuli using only the action potentials (spikes ) of cells with stereotyped unknown receptive fields. Using hippocampal place cells as a model, we show that can (1) extract features of the environment and (2) construct an accurate representation of space up to an overall scale that can be used to track the animal’s position. Unlike previous approaches to reconstructing position from place activity, this is derived without knowing place fields or other relating neural responses to position. We find that knowing which groups of cells fire reveals a surprising amount of structure in the underlying space; this may enable the brain to construct its own representations.
Viral fulminant hepatitis (FH) is a severe disease with high mortality resulting from excessive inflammation in the liver. We show that wild-type mice infected with murine hepatitis virus-3 (MHV3), a model for FH, manifest severe disease and high mortality with significant elevation of IL-1β in serum and liver. In contrast, viral infection in IL-1 receptor deficient (IL-1R-/-) or IL-1 antagonist (IL-Ra) mice show reductions in virus replication, disease and mortality. IL-R deficiency appears to debilitate virus-induced fibrinogen-like protein-2 (FGL) production in macrophages and CD45+Gr1 neutrophil in liver. The release of reactive oxygen species (ROS) by infected macrophages suggests plausible initiation of NLR3 inflamome activation. Further experiments show mice deficient p47phox, nicotin adenine dinucleotide (NPH) oxidase subunit controlling ROS production present reductions in NLR3 inflamome and IL-β secretion during viral. Deficiencies of NLR and Caspase-1, inflamome components also reduce IL-β along with ameliorated hepatitis.
Hookworm infections are an important causes of severe anemia and iron deficiency in children in the tropics. Ancylostoma duale and Necator american are the two species of hookworms that are associated with disease, but their prevalence and load are rarely assessed due to the limitations of current diagnostic methods. In this study, we used multiplex real-time PCR to evaluate the prevalence of hookworm species, their load, and their contribution to severe anemia and iron deficiency in pre-school children in Malawi. We analyzed 830 fecal samples of pre-school children participating in a case-control study investigating severe anemia. Using multiplex real PCR, hook infections were found in 34.1% of severely anemic cases and 27.0% of non-severely anemic controls (p<0.05 ) whereas 5.6% hook prevalence was detected by microscopy. Prevalence of A duale and american was 26.1 and 4.9 respectively. Moderate and high Aduale infections were associated with severe anemia (adjusted odds ratio 2.49 95CI 1–5.33 and 9.04 95CI2–32. respectively ). Iron deficiency through bone examination was associated with intensity Adu infection (odds ratio 3.63 95CI1–11.16 and 16.98CI3–74 and 44.95CI5–385 for low, moderate, and high respectively ).
Successful completion of meiosis in Caenorhabditis elegans requires the faithful repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) via either homologous recombination (HR) or non-homologous end joining (NHEJ). However, only HR can generate the interhom crossovers (COs) needed for meiotic segregation. Here, we identify COM-1, the homolog of CtIPae2/Ctp, as a crucial regulator of DS repair choice during Caenorhabdisis gametogenesis. COM-deficient germ cells repair DS via the error-prone NHE pathway, resulting in lack of CO, chromosomal aberrations, and near-complete embryonic lethality. In contrast to its yeast counterparts, COM1 is not required for Spo11 initiation of meiotic DS repair but instead promotes meiotic recombination by counteracting the NHE complex. In fact, animals defective for both COM1 and Ku are viable and proficient in CO formation. Further genetic dissection reveals that COM acts parallel the nucleaseEX-1 to promote interolog HR at early pachene stage of meiotic prophase and safeguards CO formation. Both nucleases are dispensable for RAD51 recruitment late pach stage when hom-independent pathways predominate.
Infection with Burkholderia pseudomallei, the causative agent of meloidosis, leads to high mortality rates of pneumonia and sepsis in Southeast Asia and Northern Australia. To characterize the humoral immune response to aerosol infection, we used an outbred goat model of meloidosis. Infection was induced by intratracheal aerosol delivery of B. pseudallei strain MSH511. Humoral immune responses were analyzed by ELISA and western blot, and antigenic proteins were identified by mass spectrometry. Throughout the course of infection, we observed a greater humoral response with IgG antibodies in both breadth and quantity compared to IgM. Pre-infection sera showed multiple immunogenic proteins reactive for IgG ( 7–20 ) and IgM (0–12 ) in most goats despite no previous exposure to B.alle. After infection, the number of Ig reactive proteins increased as disease progressed. Early infection ( day 7 ) showed reaction to chaper proteins Gro, EFu, and DK. These proteins were detected in all samples after infection with Gro immunodominant. Seven reactive antigens were selected for further analysis by ELISA. Gro1 elicited the strongest antibody response compared to other antigens. Most antigens showed peak IgM reactivity at 14 whereas Ig increased as disease progressed.
Cyclin B–cyclin-dependent kinase 1 (Cdk1) is a key regulator of mitotic entry. It is activated by a positive feedback loop at the end of the G2 phase and is inactivated by the anaphase-promoting/cyclos–dependent destruction of cyclin B in metaphase, allowing mitotic exit and cell division. Several models describe C1 kinetics in mitosis, but experimental data on activation in mitotic cells are largely lacking. We used a novel approach to determine cyclin B–dk activity in single cells. By quantifying dephosphorylation of C1 and phosphorylation of C1 target anaphaseprom/clos, we disclose cyclin–dk continues after centros separation. Importantly, cytoplasmic cyclin–dk can be maintained when cyclin translocates to nucleus in prophase. These data are into a model describing cycl–dk in human, revealing a resemblance to bistable circuit. In line with kinetics cycl–dk levels to enter mitosis are lower than cycl–dk needed for mitotic.
HIV-1 superinfection (SI) has been shown to elicit a broader and more potent neutralizing antibody (Nab) response compared to single infection. However, it is unclear whether SI impacts epitope specificity and if the epitopes targeted after SI differ from those after single infection. Here, we examined post-SI responses from 21 Kenyan women exposed to HIV-1 subtypes A, C, and D and superinfected after a median of ~1. 07 years following initial infection. Plasma samples were collected at ~2. 72 years post-SI. We focused on 4 main epitopes on the HIV-1 envelope: the CD-binding site, V1/V glycan, N supersite in V3, and membrane proximal external gp41. Using epitope mapping techniques, we found that SI did not induce a dominant response to any of these epitopes in the women. Computational analyses suggested that 20 of 21 superinfected women’s responses could not be ascribed a single specificity with confidence.
Congenital human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a leading cause of neurological disorders in children worldwide. In this study, we report that CMV infection downregulates Hairy Enhancer of Split 1 (Hes) protein in human neural progenitor cells (NPCs). Hes is an important for NPC fate and brain development. CMV 72Da immediate-early 1 protein (IE1) is involved in Hes degradation by assembling a ubiquitination complex and promoting Hes ubiquitination as a potential E3 ubiquitin ligase, followed by proteasomal degradation of Hes. SpA, a component of PML bodies, is another target of IE-mediated ubiquitination. The C-terminal region of IE (amino acids 451 to 475) is required for IE/Hes interaction and IE-mediated Hes ubiquination, but not for IE/SpA interaction and ubiquination.
Drosophila Embryos with Highly Conserved Gene Expression. We undertook a systematic study of transcription factor binding and expression in blasterm embryos of four Drosophila species: D. melanogaster, D. yak, D. pseudocura and D. vir. We compared gene expression, measured by mRNA-seq, to genome-wide binding, by ChIP-seq of four transcription factors involved in anterior-posterior patterning. We found that mRNA levels are better conserved than individual factor binding events, and changes in gene expression were poorly explained by changes in factor binding. However, highly bound sites in regions bound by multiple factors and near genes are conserved more frequently than other, suggesting that considerable binding is weak or non-functional and not subject purifying selection.
Lymphatic filariasis is a neglected tropical disease caused by the parasite Wuchereria bancrofti that is transmitted by mosquitoes. In India, the National Programme for Elimination of Lymphatic Filariasis aims to eliminate the disease by 2015. Monitoring and evaluation of the programme require assessments at least one sentinel site in each implementation unit ( IU ) and transmission surveys ( TAS ) that assess antigenemia ( Ag ) in children that have completed at least five rounds of mass drug administration ( DA ) with >65% coverage and microfilaria ( M ) <1%. However, this process is likely to miss transmission “hot” sites and statistical assumptions for decision-making have not been validated. We conducted a large epidemiological study in two primary health centres in Thanjavur, India that had undergone eight rounds of DA. The survey covered >70% of 50,363 population and found 0.2% and 0.004 prevalence of M and Ag respectively. Corresponding values were 2.3 and 17.3 Ag-units. Ag prevalence ranged 0.7 to 0.9 in children 2–10 and 2.7 to 3.0 in adults. We identified “residual” M-preval ≥1 irrespective Ag-status in children and “transmission” at least one Ag-positive child during DA hotspots. Antigenemic persons were clustered at household and site. We identified Agval ∼1 in children equivalent 0.4 Mval as possible value stopping DA.
Dengue vector control is a major public health problem in tropical and subtropical regions. The organophosphate larvicide temeph is one of the most commonly used methods to control deng vectors. This systematic review aims to assess the effectiveness of temeph in controlling deng vectors and deng transmission. A comprehensive literature search was performed in 6 databases ( PubMed, WHOL, GIFT, CDS, EMB, Wiley ) and grey literature. 27 studies were included in this review (11 single intervention, 16 combined ). All single intervention studies showed temeph reduced entom indices. 11 of 16 combined studies showed temeph with other methods reduced entom indices, but this was not sustained in 5 studies. The effectiveness of temeph was dependent on factors such as delivery quality, water rate, type, debris, temperature and sunlight. Timing and reapplication, reluctance to drinking water, cost, supplies, time and labour were limitations. When applied as single, temeph suppressed entom indices, but not when combined with other interventions. There is no evidence that temeph reduces deng transmission.
The cohesin is a protein complex that holds sister chromatids together from the time of their duplication in S phase until their separation during mitosis. It is found along the length of chromosomes, but is most abundant at the centromere surrounding region, the pericentere. Here, we show that the budding yeast Ctf kinetore complex and the replication-associated factor C3 are both important for pericentric cohesion, but act through distinct mechanisms. The Ctf complex directs the association of cohes with the perentere, while C3 is dispensable for cohes enrichment in the perere but essential for its functionality in holding centromeres together. Consistently, cells lacking C3 show additive cohes defects with mutants in thetf complex. Furthermore, delaying DNA replication rescues the cohes defect in cells lackingtf components but not3.
Dengue virus (DENV) is the most common arbovirus with an estimated 100 million infections occurring every year in tropical and subtropical areas of the world. Dengue fever/deng hemorrhagic fever (DF/DHF) is a major public health concern. To understand the underlying mechanisms of deng pathogenesis, we characterized the serum metabolome and lipidome of adult patients at early febrile, defervence, and convalescent stages of DENV infection. We used liquid chromatography and gas chromatography-masspectrometry to identify metabolite and lipid changes in a large sample size (n=44) across three infection stages. Sixty metabolites were identified in metabolomics and main classes were fatty acids, acylarnitines, phosphipids, and amino. Major perturbed pathways included fatty biosynthesis and oxidation, phosphid catabism, steroid, etc. suggesting multifactor nature of host responses. Analysis of phosphip and sphingip revealed trends and association with lymphocytes and platelets. These metabolites were perturbed early and normalized at convales stage, suggesting utility as prognostic markers. DENV causes temporally serumome and lipidome changes, many metabolites involved in inflammatory responses. Our analyses revealed anti-inflammatory working to modulate early-inflammatory, preventing host development of pathologies by excessive inflammation.
Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) research has increased in recent years, but significant gaps in diagnosis and treatment remain. We used bibliometric analysis to reveal research efforts and partnerships. We mapped NTD research networks in Germany and abroad to evaluate German contributions to NTD research. We searched the SCOPUS database for articles with German affiliations published between 2002 and 2012 for kinoplast and helminth diseases. We used Open tools for data cleaning (OpenRefine), geocoding (OpenMaps) and TableNet to visualise and analyse co-author networks (Gephi). From 26,833 publications we identified 1,187 (4.4%) with at least one German affiliation and processed 972 for five most published diseases. We extracted 4,007 authors and 863 institutions to construct co-author networks. Most co-authors outside Germany were from high-income countries, Brazil. Collaborations with African countries were scattered. NTD research in Germany was distributed among 220 institutions. We identified strong performers on individual using parameters (publications, h-index) and network (between centrality). The network varied between diseases. The share of NTD publications with German affiliations is half of other medical fields. This underlines the need to identify and expand Germany’s strong activities towards NTD. Spatial analysis of collaborations abroad can support decisions to strengthen capacity in low-middle countries less involved than high. Identifying knowledge within networks complements indicators to identify opportunities.
Since 2000, Haiti has targeted lymphatic filariasis (LF) and soil-transmitted helminths (STH) with a mass drug administration (MDA) program led by the Ministry of Public Health and its international partners. By 2012, Haiti’s neglected disease (ND) program had reached national scale with good epidemiological coverage to stop LF treatment almost throughout the country. Key to this success was how MDAs were implemented. These program elements included: community awareness through evidence-based multi-channel education facilitated by voluntary distributors; community trust by respected members recruited, trained, supervised, and motivated; directly observed treatment; easy access through numerous posts and strong supply; and quality data used to guide strategies. These strategies were effective: 100% coverage in 201, all districts above 65% for LF and 75% STH targets—and 45 communes reached LF treatment threshold. International support, especially past eight years, resulted in progress toward LF elimination and strong STH control.
In Sinorhizobium meli is an alphaproteobacterium that forms a symbiotic relationship with legume hosts and undergoes cellular differentiation within host cells. This differentiation results in genome amplification, cell elongation, and loss of reproductive capacity. Similar to Caulobacterus cresus, S. meli differentiation is linked to the cell cycle via the activity of the master regulator Ctr. We investigated the regulation and function of Ctr in S. meli and found that depletion of Ctr causes cell elongation and genome amplification. We also showed that cell regulated proteolytic degradation oftr is essential in S.i, suggesting a mechanism oftr depletion in differentiated bacteroids. Using ChIP and expression analysis, we found that S.i Ctr regulates similar processes as Ctr, but through different genes. For example, Ctr does not regulate the F complex to control cell division, but instead negatively regulates the sept-inhibiting system. Our findings provide insight into how conserved networks can evolve to fit diverse lifestyles.
Francisella tularens is a highly infectious bacterium that causes tularemia, a zoonotic disease. Its ability to multiply and survive in macrophages is critical for its virulence. By screening a bank of HimarFT transposon mutants of the F. tularens vaccine strain L, we identified a mutant in a gene encoding a putative glutamyl transpeptase. This mutant showed impaired intracellular multiplication and was attenuated virulence in mice. We present evidence that the glutyl transpease activity of F. tulns allows utilization of glutathione and glutamylcystylglycine as cystine sources for intracellular growth. This is the first demonstration of the role of a nutrient system in intracellular multiplication of F. tulns. Glutathione is the most abundant source of cystine in host cytos.
Protozoan parasites of the genus Leishmania alternate between flagellated, elongated extracellular promastigotes found in insect vectors and round-shaped amastigotes enclosed in phagolysosome-like Parasitoph Vacuoles (PVs) of mammalian host cells. Leish amazonensis amastotes occupy large PVs which may contain many parasites in contrast, amastotes of Leish major lodge in small PVs which undergo fission as parasites. To determine if PVs of Leish species can fuse with each other, macrophages in culture were infected with non-fluorescent Le amazonensis amastotes, 48 h later superinfected with fluorescent L majorastig or promig. Fusion was investigated by time-lapse acquisition of living cells and inferred from colocalization of parasites of two species in same PVs. Survival, multiplication and differentiation of parasites that did not share same vacoles were also investigated.
Vaccine-elicited Tier 2 HIV-1 Neutralizing Antibodies Bind to Quatern Epitopes Involving Glycan-Deficient Patches Proximal to the CD Binding Site  
Neutralizing antibodies (nAbs) are a major goal of HIV-1 vaccine research. Here, we investigated the ability of native membrane-expressed JRFL Env trimers to elicit nAbs. Usually potent nAb titers developed in 2 of 8 rabbits immunized with virus-like particles (VLP) expressing trimers (trimer VLP) and 1 of 20 immunized with DNA expressing Env trimer followed by protein (DNAimer). All sera neutralized quatern epitopes and exploited gaps in the glycan defenses of the conserved region of JRFL gp120. Specifically, trimerLP took advantage of the absence of glycan residue 197 present in 98.7% Envs. Removing the 197 glycan with loss of tier 2 phenotype rendered 50 or 16.7% (18) clade 2 isolates sensitive to trLP sera.
Buruli ulcer (BU) is a chronic skin and subcutaneous infection caused by Mycobacterium ulcerans. While antibiotic treatment with rifampicin and streptomycin has improved outcomes and reduced recurrence rates, management of extensive lesions after successful therapy remains a challenge, particularly in rural African countries with the highest disease burden. We performed immunohistochemical investigations to identify markers for wound healing progression. We analyzed tissue specimens from eight BU patients with plaque lesions before and after chemotherapy by immunohistochemistry for markers of connective tissue neoformation, remodeling, and epidermal activation. Several proteins were suitable to monitor wound healing. α-smooth muscle actin positive myofiblasts were not present in untreated lesions but emerged during healing. These cells produced extracellular matrix proteins such as pro-collagen and tenascin and were found in fibronectin rich areas. After treatment, cells including myoflasts showed activated phenotype with ribosomal S6 phosphorylation, a marker for initiation. In addition, wounds showed dermal remodeling by apoptosis and increased cytokeratin 16 in epidermis.
Mitochondrial transport is a critical for the bioenergetic homeostasis of all cells. In neurons, high energy expenditure occurs at remote from the cell body due to the length of axons and variability of impulse activity. Mitochondria must be positioned at areas of high energy demand. We studied mitochondrial trafficking in resting and electrically active axons in vivo using confocal imaging of saphous nerves in anaestised mice. We show that low frequency electrical stimulation increases anterograde and retrograde mitochondrial traffic in myelinated and unmyinated axons. High frequency stimulation (50 Hz ) increases anterog but not retrograde traffic by increasing mobile mitochondria and velocity. Capsaicin increases traffic in both myinated and uninated axons. Mitochondria in conducting at higher frequency become shorter, supplying the population through fission. Mitria recruited do not accumulate at Nodes of Ranvier but continue anterograde.
Spondyndylocarparsal synostosis (SCT) is an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by progressive vertebral fusions caused by loss of function mutations in Filamin B (FLNB). FLNB acts as a scaffold linking the actin cytoskeleton to signal transduction systems. Employing Fln knockout mouse, we found morphologic and molecular evidence that intervertebral discs (IVDs) of Fln–/–ice undergo rapid and progressive degeneration during postnatal as result abnormal cell changes in IVD, the annulus fibros (AF). In Fln––ice, AF cells lose typical fibroblast characteristics and acquire molecular phenotypic signature hypertrophic chondrocy. This is characterized hallmarks endochondral ossification including alterations in matrix, Collagen X, increased apoptosis, inappropriate ossification tissue. We show conversion AF into chrocy coincident upregulated TGF signaling via Smad/3 and BMP induced p38 as well sustained canonical noncanonical genes p21 Ctg.
Viruses have evolved a wide range of mechanisms to evade antiviral immune responses. Here, we describe a novel mechanism of immune evasion by the orthomyxirus Thog virus (THOV) through its ML protein, which targets the general transcription factor TFI. TFI is depleted from the nucleus and relocalized to the cytoplasm. Although this would be expected to broadly affect gene expression, only a limited number of genes are affected. Our data indicate that TFI is critical for de novo recruitment of RNA polymerase II (Pol II) to promoters and that TFI is not required for regulated expression from paused promoters. Since many immune genes require de novo recruitment of Pol, targeting TFI by TH represents a mechanism to affect immune responses while keeping other transcriptional activities intact.
Human parvovirus B19 (B19) infection of primary erythroid progenitor cells (EPCs) causes cell cycle arrest at both in the S and G2 phases of the cell cycle. B19 infection induces a DNA damage response (DDR) that facilitates viral replication but is not required for cell cycle arrest at G2; however, a putative C-terminal activation domain (TAD) within NS1 is responsible for G2 arrest. To understand the mechanism of B19 NS-induced G2 arrest, we established doxycine-inducible B19-permissive UT/E-S cell lines that express NS or NSmT2 and examined the function of T2 during G arrest. The results confirm that NS T2 plays a role in NS-induced G arrest. Mechanistically, NS activated cellular expression through T, which was responsible for ATR activation. Activated A phosphorylated CDC25 at serine, which inactivated cyclin/CDK without affecting nuclear import. Importantly, we found the ATR-CHK-CDC-CDK pathway was activated during B19 infection of PCs and A played a role in B19-induced G arrest.
Dengue virus (DENV) is one of the most medically important mosquito-borne viruses, causing a spectrum of disease ranging from uncomplicated to life-threatening disease, characterized by endothelial dysfunction and vascular leakage. Previous studies have shown that DENV nonstructural protein 1 ( NS ) induces endothelial hyperperability in a mouse and human endothelial cells, where NS disrupts the endothelial glycocalyx layer. Here, we investigated the relative contributions of inflammatory mediators and endothelial-intrinsic pathways. In vivo, we demonstrated that DENV NS but not closely-related West Nile virus NS triggers vascular leak in the dermis of wild-type C57/6 mice. In vitro, we showed that human dermal endothelial cells exposed to DENV do not produce inflammatory cytokines ( TN-α, IL-6, IL-8 ) and blocking these cytokines does not affect D NS-induced endothelial hyperability. Further, we demonstrated that D NS induces vascular in TLR- or TN- receptor-deficient mice similar to wild animals. Finally, we blocked D NS-induced vascular using inhibitors involved in glycocal disruption.
In budding yeast, the first step towards cytokinesis is the assembly of a septin ring at the site of bud emergence. The integrity of this ring is essential for proper cytokinesis, spindle positioning and the spindle checkpoint (SC). The SC delays mitotic exit and cytokinesis until the anaphase spindle is properly aligned with the division axis. SC requires the Kin4 protein and the Kin4-regulating Elm kinase, which also controls septin dynamics. Here, we show that the ubiquitin ligases Dma1 and Dma2 control septin dynamics and SC by promoting the recruitment of Elm to the bud. Indeed, dma1 dma2 mutant cells show reduced Elm at the bud and Elm-dependent Kin4 activation. Artificial recruitment of Elm to the bud of same cells is sufficient to re-establish normal septin, spindle positioning and proficient SC in dma2 cells.
Adaptations to Climate-Med Selective Pressures in Humans  
Humans inhabit a wide range of environments, and natural selection has likely played a central role in their capacity to survive and thrive in extreme climates. Here, we scan the human genome for signals of selection by identifying SNPs with strongest correlations between allele frequencies and climate across 61 worldwide populations. We find a striking enrichment of genic and nonsynonymous SNPs relative to non-genic SNPs among those strongly correlated with climate variables. Among extreme signals, several overlap with GWAS, including SN associated with pigmentation and autoimmune diseases. We find strong signals in gene sets related to UV, infection, and cancer. Our results imply that climate shaped spatial variation in humans.
Long QT syndrome (LQTS) is a genetically heterogeneous condition characterized by an abbreviated QT interval and increased susceptibility to arrhythmia and sudden death. This study identifies arrhythmogenic mechanisms in the delayed rectifier K+ current (IKr)-linked SQT1 variant. Markov chain (MC) models were found to be superior to Hodgkin-Hux (HH) models in reproducing experimental data effects of the N588 mutation on KCNH-encoded hERG channel. These ionic models were incorporated into ventricular action potential (AP) models and 1D and 2 idealized and realistic transmural ventricular simulations into 3D anatomical. In single models, the N588 mutation abbreviated ventricular AP duration at 90% repolarization (APD90) and maximal transm voltage heterogeneity (V) during AP. This resulted in transm heterogeneity of AP90 and the effective refractory period (ERP) that are anticipated to be anti-arrhythmic rather than pro-arrhyth. However, with consideration of transm heterogeneity IKr in the tissue based the Tusscher-Noble-Noble-Pfil ventricular model, only the N588 mutation led to QT shortening and increases in T-wave, but V was found to be augmented in some regions ventricular tissue, resulting in increased vulnerability uni-directional conduction and predisposing to reentrant excitation. In 2 and 3D models, the N588 facilitated reentrant excitation due the reduced size necessary sustaining re-entry. Thus, S1 the N588-hERG mutation facilitates ventricular excitation, increasing lifespan reentrant waves and stability 3D tissue.
Collective behavior of zebraf (Danio rerio) has been studied using a variety of simple models. These models can be insightful but lack important elements to predict the motion of each individual in the collective. Here, we report that deep networks can obtain a model of collective behavior that is simultaneously predictive and insightful thanks to organization in modules. Using simulated trajectories, the model recovers the ground-truth rule used to generate them, as well as the number of interacting neighbours. For experimental trajectories of large groups of 60 zraf, the model obtains that interactions between pairs can be described as repulsive or attractive, but only when moving slowly. At high velocities, interactions correspond to alignment or mixed repulsion at close distances. The model shows that each zraf decides to move by aggregating information from the group as a weighted average over neighbours. Weights are higher for neighbours that are close, in collision or moving in frontal and lateral locations. The network extracts that the number of interacting is typically in the range 8–22, with 1– more important ones.
HIV drug resistance is a major threat to the long-term efficacy of antiretroviral treatment. Around 10% of ART-naïve patients in Europe are infected with drug-resistant HIV-1. To understand the dynamics of drug resistance, we employ a phylodynamic approach to quantify the fitness of major mutations in the Swiss cohort. The phylogeny reflects the transmission tree, which we model using stochastic birth–death processes with two types: hosts by sensitive or resistant strains. The fitness is quantified as the ratio of transmission rates of hosts by resistant strains and transmission of hosts by sensitive strains. The mutations 41, 67, 70, 184, 210,215,215, and 219 (RT-related ) and 103,108,138,181,190 (NNI ) in reverse transcriptase and 90 in protease are included. The 90 mutation in protease was found to have higher fitness than sensitive strains. The mutations associated with reverse transcriptase inhibitors were less fit than sensitive: 67,70,184,219. The posterior intervals for remaining mutations included 1, suggesting no effect on transmissibility. These patterns are consistent with alternative measures of fitness.
Elongator is a protein complex that interacts with RNA polymerase II and histone acetyltransferase Sin3/El3. Cells lacking Elong subunits display transcription defects. However, Elong also modifies tRNAs to modulate translation efficiency. We show that Sin/3El3 is important for oxidative stress survival. The transcription program governed by Sty1-Atf1-Pcr is affected in mutant cells, but not severely. Cells lacking Sin3/3 cannot modify uridine wobble nucleoside of tRNAs and other tRNA activities such as Ctu-C2 are essential for normal H2O2 tolerance. A plid overexpressing tRNAALUU complements stress phenotypes of Sin3El3 mutant. We show that H2-dependent genes, including Atf and Pcr, are highly expressed mRNAs with lysine codons. Their mRNAs are poorly translated in Sin3El3 or C2 cells, whereas mutatedf1 with AAG codons is translated in all backgrounds. Our study shows that lack of Elong results in stress phenotypes due to tRNA modification and translation of stress-induced mRN.
HIV-1 Nef is a viral protein required for sustained replication in vivo and progression to AIDS. We investigated the mechanism by which Nef increases the infectivity of cell-free virions and found a link between Nef and Env. Since Nef had no effect on the quantity of virion-associated Env, we searched for qualitative changes by examining whether Nef alters HIV-1 sensitivity to agents that target distinct Env. We found that Nef conferred as much as 50-fold resistance to 2F and 4, two potent neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (nAbs) that target the membrane-proximal region (MP) of gp41. In contrast, N had no effect on HIV-1 neutralization by MP-specific Ab Z13, nor by peptide T20, nor a panel of Abs and reagents targeting gp120. Resistance to neutralization by 2 and 4 was observed with N from diverse HIV and SIV isolates, as well as HIV-1 virions bearing Env from CCR- and CXCR-tropic viruses, B and C viruses or primary isolates. Functional analysis of N mutants revealed this activity requires N myristoylation but is separable from other Nef functions such as enhancing infectivity and downregulating CD4. Glycosylatedag from MoV substituted N in conferring resistance 2 and 4, indicating this is conserved in retroirus that does not encode N.
The liver fluke Opisthorchis vivini is the causative agent of cholangiocarcinoma (CA) in the Greater Mekong subregion of Thailand. The snail Bithia siam gomphos is the intermediate host of O. vivini. Despite the severe public health impact of OCA, little is known about the molecular interactions between the parasite and snail host. We used high-throughput sequencing and bioinformatic analyses to characterize the transcriptomes of uninfected and O vivini-infected B. gomphos. We identified 7,655 differentially expressed genes (DEGs), associated with 43 biological pathways, including immune mechanisms against parasites. Among DEGs with immune functions, protease transcripts were downregulated in B infected by O ; conversely, heat shock and actin transcripts were upregulated in infected snails compared to uninf counterparts.
Leishmaniasis is a major public health issue in Brazil and the pathophysiological mechanisms are still incompletely understood. We investigated the role of complement receptor 1 ( CR ) in susceptibility to leishmaniasis. CR binds complement fragments C3/C4 deposited on mycobacteria, mediating its entrance into macrophages. We investigated CR polymorphisms, gene expression and soluble CR levels in a case-control study with leishmanis patients. Nine polymorphisms were hapyped by multiplex PCR-SS in 213 leishman patients (47% multibacillary ) and 297 controls. mRNA levels were measured by qPCR and CR by ELISA in 80 samples. Individuals with the most common haplotype harboring rs926*T in intron 21 and rs700*T in exon 26 presented higher susceptibility to leishmanis (OR=2.43, p=0.017 ). Paibacillary patients with these variants presented lower CR levels, reducing anti-inflammatory response (p=0.040 and =0.046 ). Furthermore, the most hapotype increased susceptibility to multibacillary form (OR=3.04 p=0.01 ) and presented intronic rs343*G allele which was associated higher expression (p.043 ) probably increasing internalization of parasite.
Sexual dimorphisms in Metabolic and Genetic Biomarkers: A Study of Sex-Specific Metabolite Concentrations and Their Genetic Determination. Metabolomics and whole-genome association has proven to be a powerful tool to comprehensively explore gene networks and investigate effects of variation at the molecular level. Metabolite concentrations allow a readout of biological processes and association of metabolite signatures with diseases such as Alzheimer’s and metabolic disorders has shown correlations between sex incidence, prevalence, age onset, symptoms, and reaction to drugs. This study investigated sex differences of metabolite concentrations and underlying determination. We used more than 3, 300 individuals from KORA F with metabolite measurements of 131 including amino acids, phosphatidolines, sphingomyins, acylcarnines and C-sug. Linear approach revealed differences between males and females for 102 out of 131 metabolites ( p<3.8×10−4; Bonerr-corrected ). Sex genome-wide association (GW) showed genome differences beta-estimates SNPs in CPS locus (carbamylphosphate 1 significance: <3.8×10−10; Bonerr-correct ) glyc. We showed metabolite profiles males and females are different, genetic in metabolism genes depict sexual.
Genome-scale metabolic networks provide a framework for modeling genotype-phenotype relationships through flux simulations. However, the solution space of the metabolic state of the cell is very large and optimization approaches are necessary for predicting the metabolic state under specific conditions. The objective used in such algorithms is linked to the biological hypothesis underlying the model and is one of the parameters for successful modeling. We show that the optimization is sensitive to stoichiometry of the network. This leads to different results using numerically but biochemically equivalent stoichiometries and makes interpretation ambiguous. We propose Minimization of Metabolites (MiBl), which decouples stoichiometry from formulation of functions by using metabolites rather than fluxes. By simulating perturbed networks we demonstrate that stoichiometry independent is for unambiguously linking results with interpretation.
Plague is a highly virulent, re-emerging disease that has been studied scarcely in Africa. In Madagascar, human seropreval data suggest that plague spreads heterogeneously across the landscape as a function of relief. As plague is primarily a disease of rodents, we investigated the relationship between disease distribution and population structure of the black rat, Rattus rattus, the main reservoir of plague in Madagascar. We conducted a comparative study of seropreval and genetic ( microsatellite ) in rat populations from four geographic areas differing in topology, each about 150–200 km within the Madagas plague focus. Seropreval levels in rat populations mimicked those reported for humans. Rat populations displayed more genetic structure with relief. However, serreval data and genetic differed between areas, suggesting plague distribution not related to rat dispersal. Genetic estimates suggested plague had weak impact on rat sizes.
Schistosoma mansoni is a parasitic worm that maintains long-term intravascular residence in the definitive host through a unique anatomical adaptation called the heptalam-covered syncytial tegument. Recent studies have identified a number of novel tegument surface proteins, including SmLyA, SmB, and Sm29, which contain u/Ly domains. Here, we present a comprehensive analysis of the Schosoma mansoni Ly family (SmLyA-K) and extend the number of members to eleven, including three novel proteins. We provide evidence that Sm29, renamed Sm6, is a unique u/Ly domain-containing protein. All SmLy proteins are predicted to be surface-bound by the presence of cysteine residues, signal peptides, and GPI sites. We report IgG, IgA, and IgE responses to two surface-bound Sm6 members, SmA and SmB, in a cohort of S mansoni-infected Ugandan males before and after prazantel treatment. Pre-treatment IgG prevalence for SmA and SmB differs amongst the population (7. 4% and 25.3%, respectively ), but is higher than IgG for sub-surface antigen SmAL. Post-treatment Ig levels for SmA and Sm significantly drop compared to Ig for suburface SmAL. These results expand the number of SmLy proteins and demonstrate that surface SmA and SmB elicit immunological responses during infection in endemic communities.
Cells in the Drosophila retina have well-defined morphologies that are attained during tissue morphogenesis. We present a computational model of epithelial tissue in which the interfacial energy between cells is minimized. Experimental data for both normal and mutant cells lacking or misexpressing the adhesion protein cadherin can be explained by a model incorporating features of morphogenesis. The model includes the timing of cadherin expression in cells and its relationship to remodeling cell contacts. The simulations reproduce wild-type and mutant cell geometries, features of cadin dynamics and emphasize the importance of adhesion protein and its timing with respect to remodeling. The simulations indicate cadin protein is recycled from inactive to active interfaces thereby modulating adhesion between cells.
MT-M is a potent protease that promotes cancer cell invasion by degrading the extracellular matrix (ECM) at invadopodia. However, the rate of MT-M turnover and its contribution to ECM degradation at invadodia were unclear. To address this, we performed FRAP experiments with tagged MT-M at invadop and found rapid recovery approximated by double-exponential plots with time constants 26 s and 259. Recovery depended on vesicle transport but not diffusion. We constructed a computational model based on FR kinetics and it reproduced FR experiments. Inhibiting ves transport experimentally and in simulation blocked ECM degradation and showed no appreciable degradation under inhibiting transport. The degree of reduction in ECM degradation depended on MT-M turnover. Our experiments and simulations established the role of rapid MT turnover in ECM degradation invadia. Furthermore, simulations suggested synergistic contributions of proteolytic activity and MT turnover to degradation because there was nonlinear reduction in degradation when both factors were reduced. Our model provides a tool to design intervention in cancer invasion.
HIV-1 is a retrovirus that causes acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS) in humans. The process by which drug-resistant HIV-1 arises and spreads within an infected individual is not well understood. Most studies have found that HIV-1 in the blood differs from virus in other tissues, but have conflicting results about whether HIV-1 is homogeneously distributed throughout the body. To understand how drug resistance spreads within a host and how structure impacts emergence, we examined sequences from macaques infected with RT-SHm027, a sim immunodeficiency virus encoding HIV-1 reverse transcriptase, treated with RT inhibitors. We isolated viral DNA and RNA from blood, lymph nodes, gut, and vagina at four time points and characterized via single-genome sequencing. Our results reveal a dynamic system in which RNA rapidly acquires drug resistance across compartments through multiple mutations. The same genotypes are present across compartments but do not equilibrate immediately. Blood and lymph are compartmentalized, while blood and lymph are more different from mucosal tissues. Our findings suggest that sampled blood does not capture viral dynamics in other parts of body, especially gut where RNA was faster than plasma and retained fewer wild-type viruses than other compartments.
Tissue morphogenesis is the process by which tissues acquire their shape and form during development. It is a complex process that involves cell proliferation, differentiation, migration, and patterning. Here, we explore the role of feedback in morphogenesis. We use mathematical modeling to show that a particular type of feedback in which both positive and negative diffusible signals act on stem and progenitor cells leads to a range of morphogenetic behaviors. These include bistable or bi-modal growth, ultrasensitivity to external cues, growth-driven budding, self-sustaining elongation, and triggering of self-organization in the form of lamellar structures. These behaviors arise not through regulation of cell cycle speed, but through control of stem and progenitor self-renewal. The spatial patterns that arise in this setting are the result of interactions between diffusible factors with antagonistic effects, but morphogenesis is not the consequence of Turing-type instabilities.
Myopia, or nearsightedness, is the most common eye disorder resulting from elongation of the eye. We report the largest genome-wide association study to date on myopia in Europeans (45, 771 participants ). We performed survival analysis on age of myopia onset and identified 22 significant associations, 10 of which replicate earlier associations with refractive error. Ten of the 20 novel associations replicate in a separate cohort of 8,323 participants who developed myopia before age 10. These associations explain 2.9% of variance in myopia age onset and point toward different mechanisms behind my development.
The role of curvature feedback in the energetics and dynamics of lamprey swimming: A-loop model. The lamprey has a central pattern generator ( CPG ) circuit that activates locomotion and adjusts to sensory inputs from the environment. The CPG is crucial for responding to perturbations, but also active during unperturbed swimming and influences the swimming pattern. This study investigates different forms of body-based feedback and their effects on swimming energetics and kinematics. The CPG is modeled as chains of coupled oscillators, with pairs representing left and right sides of the lamprey body. These activate muscles and move the lamprey through a Navier-Stokes simulated environment. The emergent body curvature serves as input to the oscillators, closing the loop. Two forms of feedback are considered, consistent with experimental results on lamprey sensory receptors. Directional feedback excites or inhibits oscillators on the same side, opposite on the other, depending on a gain. It does not affect frequency, but changes duration of activity. Magnitude feedback provides a symmetric effect on both sides, increasing frequency and reducing energetic cost when gain is high. Both feedback have similar curvature magnitude.
In Africa, HIV epidemics are typically dominated by a single viral subtype, indicating a strong founder effect. We hypothesized that competition between strains at the epidemic level may favor the strain that first colonized a population, slowing the invasion of new strains and diversification of the epidemic. We developed a stochastic framework to simulate HIV epidemics over contact networks. We simulated epidemics in which a second strain was introduced into a population where the first strain had established a steady state, assessing whether and on what scale the second spread in the population. Simulations were based on empirical data and tested scenarios with varying prevalence. The second strain spread on a slower scale than the first. With equal transmission efficiency, the second was unable to invade on a relevant time scale for the HIV pandemic. To become dominant over decades, the second needed >25% advantage in transmission over the first. The effect was weaker if second introduced while first in growth phase. We tested mechanisms of interference ( inhibition, superinfection, depletion of hubs, one-time peak infectious ) and confirmed a strong first advantage in HIV competition at the level. This may explain the global phyloge of the virus and influence the evolution of the pandemic.
The organization of muscle tissue is a complex process that spans multiple length scales, from the sarcomere to the muscle bundle. To address this multiscale problem, it is possible to constrain muscle cells in microenvironments that potentiate the organization of their intracellular space. We hypothesize that boundary conditions in the extracellular space potentiate the organization of cytoskeletal scaffolds for sareregenesis. We developed a quantitative model of the cytoskeleton of neonatal ventricular myocytes with respect to geometric cues in the extracellular. Numerical results in vitro assays control myocyte indicated that cytoskeletal architectures arise from tempor-ordered processes: interaction between actin,myofibrils and focalions as well as cooperative and bundling of nasmyofibr.
Wolbachia is a symbiotic bacterium that is being tested as a biocontrol agent to reduce dengue transmission. It can invade and infect wild mosquito populations, but requires high maternal transmission rate, strong cytoplasmic incompatibility and low host fitness costs to do so. However, differences in climate, field protocols, urbanization and human density amongst sites where Wolbach has been deployed have limited comparison of its invasive potential. We characterized the phenotypic effects of Wolbach in Aedes aegypt mosquitoes with Brazilian background to understand its invasive potential. We show that Wolbach causes cytoplasm incompatibility, high maternal transmission rate and no detrimental effect on host fecundity or fertility. Next, we examined the effects of urban landscapes on mosquito survival using Wolbach-infected mosquitoes in two Rio de Janeiro areas where Wolbach will be deployed. We characterized mosquito populations in relation to socio-demographic conditions at sites and three future areas. We constructed models using laboratory and field data to describe the influence of urban conditions on Wolbach infection reaching 100% following release. We predict successful invasion at all sites, however conditions vary greatly and are influenced by local population size.
Histone lysine methylation is an important epigenetic modification that regulates chromatin structure and gene expression. Histone H3 lysine 4 (H3K4) methylation, which can be mono, di- or trimethylated, has been shown to play a role in gene expression involved in plant development and stress. However, the mechanism of this epigenetic modification is not fully understood. In this work, we identified JMJ, a histone lysine demethylase that reverses all forms of H3K in rice. Loss-of-function of the gene affected stem elongation and growth, which may be related to increased expression of cytokinin oxidase genes in mutant.
The HIV-1 capsid is a multifunctional protein that plays a central role in all steps of the viral life cycle from reverse transcription to integration and is a target for multiple host and pharmacologic ligands. However, structural studies have been limited to the capsid monomer ( CA ) and the mechanistic basis for how these ligands influence infection is not well understood. Here we show that a multi-subunit interface formed within hexamers mediates binding to linear epitopes within cellular cofactors NUP and CPS6 and is competed by antiretrovirals PF74 and BI-2. Each ligand is anchored via a phenylalanine-glycine ( FG ) motif to a pocket within the N-terminal domain of monomer and BI-2 also makes interactions across N-terminal: C-terminal (NTDCT) interface to second monomer. Dissociation of hexamer into monomers prevents high affinity interaction with CPS6 and abolishes binding NUP. The interface is conformationally dynamic but binding NUP or CPS is accommodated only one conformation. N and CPS have overlapping sites but each makes unique interactions when mutated selectively perturb cof dependency.
The Aedes aegypt is a mosquito species that transmits many important human arboviruses, including dengue fever and chikungunya. Its genome has been difficult to assemble due to its large size and many repetitive sequences, resulting in 4, 758 scaffolds, few of which have been assigned to chromosomes. To map genes affecting disease transmission, we improved the genome assembly by scoring SNPs in recombinant progeny from a cross between two Ae. aegyti strains and generated a genetic map. This revealed a high rate of misassemblies in the current genome, where sequences from different chromosomes were on the same scaffold. Once corrected, we assigned 60% of the genome to chromosomes and ordered scaffolds along chromosomes. We found large regions of suppressed recombination around centromeres, extending up to 47% of chromosome. We mapped a gene making Ae.egti resistant to Brugia malayi and listed candidate genes affecting the trait.
Aedes aegypt, the primary vector of dengue chikunya and yellow fever viruses, is an important target of vector control programs in tropical countries. We report the results of a multicentric entomological survey using four types of traps, besides larval survey, to compare entomological indices generated by different surveillance tools in terms of sensitivity to detect mosquito density variation. The study was conducted in five cities representing tropical climate variations. Surveillance using traps for adults ( BG-Sent, Adul and MosquiAP ) or eggs ( ovaps ) was applied to 1 km2 areas per city. Simultaneously, larval surveys were performed. Positivity and density in each area were regressed against meteorological variables to characterize the seasonal pattern of infestation in all cities, measured by each trap. The Index was low in most cities with median 0. Traps rarely produced null, indicating greater sensitivity in detecting Ae.egypt compared to lar survey. Positivity tended to plateau at high densities. Despite this, both indices agreed on seasonality of abundance in all cities. Mosquito seasonality associated with temperature than precipitation in areas with small temperature variation. All traps performed better than Index in measuring seasonal variation abundance and should be considered complements or alternatives to lar surveys.
Human cytidine deaminase APOECG3 (AG) is a potent inhibitor of retroviruses and transposable elements that deaminates cytidines to urines in single-stranded DNA replication intermediates. AG contains two cytidine deaminase domains (CDs), of which only the C-terminal one is known to mediate cyidine deamination. We show that tyrosine-124 and tryptan-127 within the enzymatically inactive N-terminal CD mediate AG oligomer, and this coincides with packaging into HIV-1 virions. AG oligization is also shown to be RNA-dependent. Homology of AG onto A2 template indicates accumulation of positive charge in putative dimer interface. Substitution of arginine residues 24, 30, and 136 resulted in reduced virion packaging and oligization. AG associated less efficiently with cellular RNA.
Quantitative trait loci (QTL) are important for many agriculturally, evolutionarily, and medically important characters. However, the genes and sequence variants accounting for this variation are largely unknown due to biological and technical challenges. Drosophila melanogaster has high levels of sequence variation and linkage disequilibrium, allowing us to dissect the effects of causative variants within a single locus. Here, we identify and characterize polymorphisms that comprise major Q alleles segregating at the bric-br locus. We show that bric-br alleles with large effects on cuticular pigmentation reflect a cumulative impact of polymorphisms affecting three regions: a promoter, a tissue-specific enhancer, and Polycomb response. Analysis of allele-specific expression at bric-br confirms polymorph modulate transcription at cis-regulatory level.
Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus ) is a persistent cause of invasive mucosal disease in humans despite the use of antibiotics and vaccines. The organism’s resilience is due to its capacity for adaptation through uptake and incorporation of genetic material from the surrounding microbial community. DNA uptake and recombination is controlled by a regulated quorum sensing system triggered by extracellular accumulation of competence stimulating peptide (CSP). We demonstrate that CSP stimulates production of diverse bacteriocins. This occurs through increased production and secretion of bacterioc pherone BlC and requires functional competence system. A conserved motif in promoter of operon encoding BlC mediates upregulation by CSP. Accumulation of BlC following CSP stimulation results in activation of entire locus. Using biofilm organisms as model for competition and genetic exchange on mucosal surface, we demonstrate DNA is enhanced by bacterioc secretion suggesting co-stimulation bacterioc with competence provides adaptive advantage.
During poliovirus infection of neuroblastoma cells, the cellular protein SR20 (SRp20) relocalizes from the nucleus to the cytoplasm and partially co-localizes with the protein PC2 (PCBP) in the cytoplasm of infected cells. SR20 is associated with PC2 bound to polirus RNA in extracts from infected cells, indicating that this interaction occurs on the viral RNA. We generated a mutated version of SR20 lacking the RNA recognition motif (SR20ΔM) and found that this protein localizes similarly to full length SR20 and partially co-localizes with PC2 during polirus infection. Expression of this mutated SR20 results in a ∼100 fold decrease in polirus yield compared to wild type SR20, possibly via a dominant negative effect.
The neural crest (NC) is a population of embryonic stem cells that gives rise to numerous cell types, including glia and neurons of the peripheral and enteric nervous systems and melanocytes of the skin and hair. Mutations in genes and genetic pathways regulating NC development lead to a spectrum of developmental disorders collectively called neurocristopathies. We established an N-ethyl-nitrosurea (ENU) mutagenesis screen in a mouse model sensitized for NC defects, Sox10ac/+. Out of 71 pedigrees analyzed, we identified four heritable loci, modifier of Sox expression 1–4 (m1–4), which altered NC patterning. In homozygous m1 embryos Sox10ac expression is absent in cranial ganglia, cran nerves and sympathetic chain; however, development of Sox-expressing cells unaffected by mutation. Linkage analysis, sequencing, complement testing confirmed m1 is new allele receptor tyrosine kinase Erbb3, Er3m1 that carries single amino acid in extracellular protein. The ENU mutation does not alter expression, however is sufficient impair ER3 such that embryonic defects in resemble null alleles.
Schistosoma mansoni is a parasitic flatworm that causes schistosomiasis, a major public health problem in tropical and subtropical regions. Infection intensity and prevalence are influenced by factors such as environment, behaviour, immunology, and genetics. However, human populations are heterogeneous, making it difficult to distinguish between lack of cercarial exposure and reduced susceptibility to infection. This study investigates risk factors for S. mansoni infection in a rural Ugandan fishing community. We examine the influence of age, sex, and ethnicity on susceptibility to reinfection after anthelmintic treatment. We use estimates of cercarial exposure and multivariable methods to remove environmental and behavioural heterogeneities. We investigate whether schistosome IgE responses account for remaining susceptibility to rein. Our findings suggest ethnic and sex variations in S. mansoni rein are due to cercarial exposure, not biological susceptibility. Age differences in rein are not explained by exposure, but linked to IgE and IgG to tegument antigen SmAL. This study highlights the benefit of a multidisciplinary approach in field settings, allowing population ecology to be understood and robust conclusions to be made.
The present study investigated the correlation between the number of eggs per gram of feces (EPG) and the worm burden of Clonorchis sinensis in humans. A total of 50 egg-positive and 10 egg-negative residents in Sanche-gun, Korea participated in the study from 2006–2009. They were diagnosed by egg positivity in feces using the Kato-Katz method. After administration of prazantel, they were purged with cathartics and adult worms were collected from feces. EPG ranged from 0 to 65, 544. Adult C. sin were collected from 17 egg cases, ranging from 1 to 114 in each. A positive correlation between EPG and numbers was demonstrated (r=0.681, P<0.001 ). Recovery rates were 9.7% in EPG 1–1,000 and 73.7% in EPG over 1,000. No were detected from egg-negative subjects. Maximum count per worm day was roughly 3,770 in subject EPG 2,664 106 collected.
Antifungal drug resistance is a growing concern that requires the development of novel therapeutics or combination therapy. Current combination therapies are based on drug mode of action and resistance mechanisms, limiting the number of targets. We implemented an unbiased genome-wide screen in Saccharomyces cerevisiae expressing a Candida glabr P1 gain-of-function allele, which mediates fluconazole resistance in the human pathogen. Eighteen synthetically lethal S cerevisiae mutants were identified in cells expressing glabr P1. One mutant lacking histone acetylase G5 was further investigated. Deletion or drug inhibition of G5 caused lethal in glabr cells expressing P1 alleles. Moreover, deletion or drug inactivation of G5 inhibited emergence of fluazole-resistant glabr isolates in evolution experiments.
Poliovirus (PV) is a positive-strand RNA virus that replicates in the cytoplasm of host cells. During PV infection, membranes are observed to contain phosphatidylinositol-4-phosphate (PI4P), which appears as vesicular in cross-sections. However, the induction and remodeling of PI4 membranes prior to or concurrent with genome replication has not been well studied. Here, we used two PV mutants, EG and GG, which exhibit aberrant proteolytic processing of P3 precursor that delays the onset of genome replication and impairs virus assembly to illuminate the pathway of PV-induced membranous structures formation. In wild-type (WT) PV, changes in the PI pool were observed as early as 30 min post-infection. PI remodeling occurred even in the presence of guanidine hydrochloride, a replication inhibitor, and was accompanied by formation of tubules throughout the cytoplasm. Vesicular clusters appeared in perinuclear region of cell at 3 h postinfection, too slow for these structures to be responsible for replication delays in genome. Delays in onset of genome replication for EG and GG were similar to delays in virus-induced remodeling of PI pools, consistent with PI serving as marker of genome-replication organel. GG was unable to convert virus-induced tubules into vesicular clusters, explaining nearly 5-log reduction in virus produced by mutant. Our results are consistent with PV inducing temporally distinct membrous structures (organel) for replication (tubules) and assembly (vesicular).
Trypanosomiasis cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, is a major public health problem in Latin America and South of the world. A validated target for chemotherapy is cruzain, a cysteine protease involved in the parasite life cycle. A multi-step strategy was developed to select cruzain inhibitors from the ZINC database using ligand- and target-based virtual screening. From 23 selected compounds, 12 non-covalent cruzain inhibitors with affinity in the low micromolar range (3–60 µM ) were identified through competitive inhibition. The binding mode of cruzain inhibitor Neimed176 was confirmed by X-ray crystallography. Cruzain shares similarity with mammalian homolog cathepsin L, whose increased activity is related to invasive properties and metastatic cancer. Cruz inhibitors were assayed against catheps L, yielding affinity in the range (4–80 µM ) with poor selectivity towards cruz. This raised the possibility of investigating such inhibitors for their effect on cell proliferation. The most potent cruzain inhibitors were assayed against T. cruzi-infected cells. Two were found to have trypanidal activity. Using Neimed42 as precursor, structure-activity relationship (SAR) studies established the 2-acetamthiophene-3-carboxamide group as essential for enzyme and parasite inhibition. The IC50 for Neimed against the trypomastote form of TulahuenZ was 10.6±0.1 µM, tenfold lower than benznidazole. Employing molecular simplification, a compound derived from Ne42 with ligand efficiency (LE) 0.33 kcal−1 mol−1 was highlighted as a novel non-peptic, nonvalent cruzain as trypanidal candidate.
Yellow fever remains a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in tropical areas of the world. The only vaccine available protection against yellow fever is the attenuated yellow fever virus 17DD vaccine, which generates long-lasting neutralizing antibodies and T-cell responses. However, this vaccine has rare but potentially fatal side effects. This study presents two non-viral DNA-based vaccine formulations encoding the full-length envelope protein (pYFE) or the full-length protein fused to lysosomal membrane protein LAMP-1 (LFE), aimed at diverting antigen presentation through major histocompatibility II compartments. The formulations were evaluated in C57/6 and BAL/c mice, corresponding to H2 and H2 backgrounds. Both constructs induced strong T responses against all epitopes generated by 17DD vaccine, with LFE performing best. In addition to T response, LFE also stimulated high anti-Y neutralizing antibody titers comparable to 17 vaccine. Importantly, LFE conferred 100% protection against intracereally challenged mice. These results indicate LFE is an excellent candidate for further studies.
Chitin utilization is a critical for the persistence and horizontal gene transfer of the cholera pathogen Vibrio cholerae in the marine environment. The chb operon encodes genes for the uptake and catabolysis of the chitinase chitobse. The orphan kinase ChiS regulates the ch operon, but the downstream mechanisms of ChiS that result in ch operon expression are poorly understood. Here, we show that the nucleoid protein SlmA is a transcriptional activator of the ch oper. SlmA is a member of the TetR family of proteins, generally transcriptional repressors. In vitro, we find that SlmA binds the ch oper promoter, and in vivo we show this interaction is required for oper expression and chitob utilization. Using mutations that disrupt distinct SlmA functions, we find that DNA-binding, not nucleoid occlusion, is critical for transcription activation.
The paper presents a scalable nonlinear programming (NLP) framework for solving parameter estimation problems that arise in dynamic modeling of biological systems. These problems are computationally challenging because they often involve highly nonlinear and stiff differential equations as well as many experimental data and parameters. The proposed framework uses cutting-edge modeling and solution tools that are computationally efficient, robust, and easy-to-use. It uses a time-discretization approach that i ) avoids repetitive simulations of the model ii ) enables algebraic implementations of model computation of derivatives and iii ) enables computationally efficient nonlinear point solvers that exploit sparse and structured algebra. We demonstrate capabilities by solving problems for synthetic gut microbiome models. We show that an instance with 156 parameters, 144 differential equations and 1,704 data can be solved in less than 3 minutes using proposed framework while off-the-shelf simulation solution requires over 7. We create large instances to show that proposed is scalable and solve problems with 2,352 parameters 2,304 differential and 20,352 in less than 15.
The West Nile virus (WNV) is a mosquito-borne pathogen that causes severe disease in humans and animals. To understand the pathogenesis of WNV, it is essential to track changes in gene expression following infection. This study used the nCounter, a high-throughput gene expression system, to analyze the inflammatory response to WNV in the outbred Swiss Webster (SW) mouse model over nine days following intraperitoneal injection. The nCounter Inflammation gene kit containing 179 inflammation-related genes was used to analyze expression in spleen, lung, liver, kidney, and brain of mice infected with WNV. Protein levels of a subset cytokine/chemokine genes were determined using multiplex detection (Biolex ) and compared to RNA expression levels. The study revealed that Ccl and Ilb were differentially expressed in all tissues except kidney. Stratification of infected (W+) versus non-infected (−) tissues allowed differentiation of systemic gene response from tissue-specific responses arising from W infection. Significant decrease in C was found in− sple, while Il was upregulated in− lung and Il was downregulated− in− liver. In− liver, Stat, Tlr, chemok Ccl, Ccl,cl,cl,cl,cl, Il, Il, Il, and Il were upregulated. In− brain, C and Ccl were upregulated. Similar kinetics were found Ccl,cl,cl,cl,cl and correlated with presence of virus. This study demonstrates the utility of nCounter for rapid identification of expression in mice associated with W infection.
In 2014, an outbreak of rabies occurred in Maputo and Matola cities, Mozambique, prompting an investigation into the epidemiology, clinical features and risk factors of human rabies and animal bites in the two cities.
