Between April and August 2014, 14 cases of human rabies were detected in Maputo ( n = 10 ), Matola ( n = 3 ) and neighbouring Bo district ( n 1 ), all of whom had a recent history of dog bite. Only one of the 14 rabid dogs had been immunized. A total of 819 animal bites were registered, with 64. 6% ( 529/819 ) from Maputo and 97. 8% (801/819 ) from dogs. However, only 27. 0% (126/467 ) of dogs were immunized. Factors associated with human rabies were: age <15 years ( p = 0.05 ), bite by stray dog ( =0.002 ), deep wound ( = 0.02 ), bite in head ( = 0.001 ), by unimmun dog ( = 0.01 ), no soap and water ( 0.001 ) and no post-exposure prophylaxis ( 0.01 ).
The SCN9 gene, encoding the Nav1. 7 subunit of voltage-gated sodium channels, has been identified as a potential cause of febrile seizures ( FS ) in a large Utah family with significant linkage to chromosome 2q24. A highly conserved amino acid mutation, p. N641, in the cytoplasmic loop between transmembrane domains I and II was found in 21 affected family members and absent in ethnically matched controls. To establish a functional role for this mutation in seizure susceptibility, the mutation was introduced into the murine Sc9 ortholog using homologous recombination. Homozygous Sc9N641/N641 mice exhibited reduced thresholds to electrically induced clonic and tonic-clonic seizures and increased corneal kindling rates. These data support SCN9 p. N641 as a disease-causing mutation in this family. In a collection of 92 unrelated FS patients, highly conserved Nav.7 missense variants were identified in 5%. One child with FS later developed Drav syndrome ( severe mylonic epilepsy of infancy ) and SCN1 was sequenced, identifying a heterozygous frameshift mutation. Subsequent analysis of 109 Drav patients yielded Nav.7 missense in 8%, all highly conserved amino. Six Drav patients with SCN9 missense also harbored miss or splice SCN1 mutations and three had SCN1 mutations.
Biologists have long sought to understand how complex tissue shapes arise through growth. In many cases, this involves preferential growth along particular orientations, raising the question of how these orientations are specified. Two possibilities exist: orientations are specified through stresses in the tissue (axiality system ) or independently through molecular signalling (polarity system ). The axial system has been recently been explored through computational modelling. Here, we develop the polarity system, which we call Growing Tissue (PT ). We treat tissue as a continuous material within which regionally expressed factors under genetic control may interact and propagate. Polarity is established by signals that propagate through tissue and are anchored in regions termed polarity organisers that also under genetic. Rates of growth parallel or perpendicular to polarity may be specified through a network. The growth depends on how specified patterns interact within constraints of connected tissue. This leads to emergence of features not specified by networks. Result growth feeds to influence spatial and orientations of tissue, allowing shapes to emerge from simple. Moreover, asymmetries emerge through polarity fields. We illustrate PT for morphogenesis by applying to growing flower and how underlying may be tested by simulation. We propose combinatorial between orientations and growth, feature of polarity, have been exploited to generate observed shapes.
During the early stages of HIV infection, multiple CD8+ T cell responses are elicited and exert strong selective pressure on different parts of the HIV genome. This leads to the emergence of mutations that are beneficial to the virus. Some studies have shown that the rate at which these mutations emerge and go to fixation decreases over time, a pattern known as the escape rate decline (ER). We investigated how interference between concurrent mutations affects escape rates in multiple epitopes and whether it is a source of the ER pattern. We developed a multilocus Wright-Fisher model of HIV dynamics with selection, mutation, and recombination as a null model for interference. We also derived an interference-free model assuming neutral evolution before immune elicitation. We found that interference between several advantageous mutations can generate the ER pattern. We found that the number of loci and recombination rates affect ER. This can be explained by the exponential decline of escape rates over time. We found that the ER pattern in HIV infected individuals is consistent with both interference-free and interference effects. Our results confirm that interference should be considered when analyzing escape mutations.
Title: In Silico Oncology: Quantification of In Vivo Antitumor Efficacy of Cisatin-Based Double Therapy in Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer (NSCL) through Multiscale Mechanistic Model
Bacterial biofilms are known to exhibit high levels of tolerance to antibiotics. However, the molecular mechanisms leading to this tolerance are not well understood. In this study, we used transposon mutagenesis to identify biofilm mutants that are tolerant to fluoroquinoloneloxacin in Escherichia coli. We demonstrated that starved biofilms are more tolerant toloxacin than their planktonic counterparts and that this tolerance is dependent on the SOS response to amino acid and carbon starvation and partially dependent on the stringent response leucine starvation. We further showed thatloxacin tolerance does not involve SOS toxin–antitoxin systems previously associated with tolerant persister formation. We demonstrated thatlox tolerance increases with biofilm age and is dependent on SOS. Our results show that SOS in nutrient-deprived biofilm microenvironments is a mechanism leading tolox tolerance.
Plasmodium falcumeroites invade human erythrocytes by interacting with host receptors and parasite ligands localized in micronemes, apical organelles. We show that cAMP is a key regulator of micron secretion enabling receptor engagement and invasion. In a low K+ environment, typical of blood plasma, a bicarbonate-sensitive cytoplasmic adeny cyclase raises cytosolic cAMP and activates protein A, regulating micron secretion. c also regulates meroite cytosolic Ca2 via Ep pathway and increases in both c and Ca2 are essential for micron secretion.
Strongyloides stercoris, a soil-transmitted worm, is one of the most neglected tropical diseases (NTDs). We reviewed studies from the last 20 years on S. stercis global prevalence in populations and risk groups. A literature search was performed in PubMed for articles between 1989 and 2011. Articles presenting information on infection were included. A Bayesian analysis was carried out to obtain country-specific prevalence and compare disease ratios in groups taking into account diagnostic sensitivities. A total 354 studies from 78 countries were included for prevalence, 194 (62.4%) were community studies, 121 (34.2%) were hospital, and 39 (11%) studies on refugees and immigrants. World maps with data are provided. In Africa, Asia, and South America, information on Sercis is lacking. The analysis showed an association between HIV/alcoholism and Sercis (OR:2.17;CI:1.18–4.01;OR:6.69;CI:1.47–3.38). Our findings show high prevalence in selected countries and regions. Sercis prominent in risk groups.
Stochastic noise is a fundamental to circadian oscillations, influencing how groups of cells entrain to external cues and generating cell-autonomous rhythms. However, few studies have investigated how clock perturbations affect stochastic noise. This is due to the difficulty in measuring cell-autonomous noise, which requires careful collection and processing of single-cell data. Here, we show that damping of population bioluminescence can serve as an accurate measure of stochastic, applicable to high-throughput circadian screens. Using fibroblast data, we show that higher single-cell noise results in faster population damping. We further show that damping can be changed by small molecule modulators in a dose-dependent fashion, and that such change can be explained by single-cell using a model. We demonstrate that our method can be applied to genome-wide siRNA, revealing that stochastic is altered from period and phase. Finally, we hypothesize that unperturbed clock is optimized for robust, few perturbations capable of increasing amplitude and lowering noise.
Bacterial cell division is a promising target for the development of new drugs to combat antibiotic resistance. The bacterial protein Fts is essential for cell division and has been identified as a target for drug development. Recent work on the allosteric inhibitor PC723 has shown in vitro and in vivo activity against Staphylococcus aureus. However, the mechanism of action and effect on Fts in other species is unclear. Here, we examine the structural environment of PC723 binding using PocketFEATURE, a method that scores similarity between small-molecule binding sites based on 3D structure and molecular dynamics. We find that species and nucleotide state have significant impact on the site, with disparate environments for species not in the Staphlocus genus. Based on Pocket analysis of S aureus bound to GTP with mutations that confer PC723 resistance, we predict PC strongly binds Staphlocus in nucleotide state. Simulations of dimer indicate polymer may enhance PC binding. Our results demonstrate that the pocket can vary across species, genetic and polymer states, important for further development ofts inhibitors.
Lentiviral integrase (IN) is a viral enzyme that enables lentiviruses, such as HIV, to integrate their genetic material into the host cell genome. The cellular protein LEDGF, also known as PC4 and SFR1 interacting protein 1 (PSIP1) transcriptional coactivator 75, is a binding partner of IN and is required for efficient lentiviral replication. Here, we present the crystal structure of the N-terminal and catalytic core (NTD) of HIV-2 IN in complex with the binding domain (IBD) of LEDGF. This structure extends the known IN–LED interface and reveals charge interactions between the NT of IN and IB. The NT of IN contains a constellation of acidic residues characteristic of lentiviruses and mutations of positively charged residues on IB affect interaction with lentiruses. We show that NT–IB contacts are critical for stimulation of lentiral DNA integration by LED in vitro and during early steps of HIV-1 replication. Furthermore, the structure enabled us to engineer a mutant HIV-1 IN that functions only with a complementary LEDGF mutant. These findings provide structural basis for lentiral IN–LED interaction and pave the way for LED-based therapies.
Tumors arise from cells that have an intrinsic set of kinetics that dictate their behavior. These kinetics are inherited by cancer cells and determine the initial and progression of the tumor. However, genetic and epigenetic alterations can change the kinetics of cancer cells and increase their fitness and accelerate progression. We investigated the intratumoral heterogeneity of cancer and the evolutionary trajectories of cell-intrinsic kinetics that yield aggressive growth. We developed a cellular automaton model that tracks the evolution of the malignant subpopulation of cancer stem cells (CSC), which are exclusively able to initiate and sustain tumors. We explored cell traits including migration, invasion, spontaneous death due to genetic drift of deleterious mutations, symmetric stem cell division that increases the cancer pool, and telomere erosion as a counter for non-stem cancer proliferation. Our study suggests that proliferation is the strongest modulator of growth. Early increase in proliferation yields populations of non-stem cells that compete with CSC and inhibit division, while reduction loosens inhibition and facilitates CSC division. The subpopulation of stem itself is highly heterogeneous dictating dynamics that vary from dormancy to progression. Our study suggests that diversity in single samples represents only a proportion of total phenotypes.
Many zoonotic infectious diseases, such as influenza A (H5N1), appear as sporadic and spatially restricted outbreaks in humans. Adaptation is key for sustained human-to-human transmission. We use mathematical models to describe adaptation scenarios with reference to human population heterogeneity. We present expressions for emergence probability and time to successful event. We derive results for emergence properties, including outbreak size distribution. We compare with computationally studied stochastic model. Our results suggest weak effect of heterogeneity on outbreak size and emergence risk for typical connections between communities. For example, a village connected to a city by ten commuters is effectively part of the city for emergence and outbreak distribution. We present commuting data showing most communities are at least well interconnected. For plausible ranges, heterogeneity effects are likely dominated by host adaptation biology. We discuss implications for emerging infection surveillance and control.
Influenza A Virus Migration and Persistence in North American Wild Birds. Wild birds have been implicated in the emergence of human and livestock influenza. However, the prediction of viral spread and emergence, as well as formulation of preparedness plans have been hampered by a lack of knowledge of viral movements between host populations. Here, we analyze genomic data from 287 newly sequenced avian influenza A (A) virus samples over 34 years of continuous surveillance of North American migratory birds. We use Bayesian framework to test hypotheses of viral migration, population and genetic reassort patterns. Our results show that despite high prevalence of Charadriiform in Delaware, this host does not significantly contribute to North AIV diversity in Aniform. In contrast, viruses sampled Aniform in Alberta are representative of AIV in North Aniform. A may be restricted to migratory flyways over time, but large-scale analysis shows long-term A persistence is independent of fly with between populations throughout North.
Influenza A viruses are classified into 16 distinct subtypes (H1–16) based on their hemagglutinin (HA) proteins. Each subtype has little cross-reactivity to other subtypes, and it is generally believed that neutralizing antibodies are not cross-reactive among subtypes. We generated a novel monoclonal antibody (MAb), MAb S/1, which showed heterosubically cross-reactive neutralization and hemagutination of influenza A viruses. MAb S/1 reacted with many subtypes (1, 2, 3, 5, 9, and 13) in enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays and showed neutralization and hemutination activities against subtypes 1, 2, 3, and 13. Mutants that escaped neutralization by MAb S1 were selected from Aichi/2/68 (2), Aachi2/57 (2), and A/N/33 (1) and sequence analysis of HA genes revealed amino substitutions at 156, 158, and 193. Molecular study showed these amino acids located on globular head of HA and formed conformational epitope adjacent to receptor-binding domain. Passive immunization of mice with MAb S1 provided heterosubic protection.
Control of Strongyloides stercoralis infection in an endemic community may be possible by pharmacological means: Results of a three-year study. To assess the effect of ivermectin on the prevalence of S. stercis in an Australian Aboriginal population over three years, and to assess the validity of using a lower ELISA cut-off in diagnosis. A three-year study of 259 Australian Aboriginals in a remote northern community. Sercis was diagnosed by ELISA and a lower threshold for treatment than recommended. Follow up at 6 months and 3 years following ivermect treatment.ivermect was highly effective and resulted in a fall in prevalence in the group (35.3% to 5.8%, McNem’s2 = 56., p<.001. ). Results suggested use of lower EL threshold for treatment was valid in this setting. Follow identified a group with persistently positive EL serology despite treatment. Control Sercis in this cohort appears to be using pharmac treatment alone.
Prion diseases are caused by a misfolded isoform of the prion protein PrP. Prion strains are hypothesized to be encoded by strain-specific conformations of PrP and can interfere with each other when a long-incubation strain blocks the conversion of a short-incation strain. However, it is unknown if long-incation strains can interfere with each other. Here, we show that co-infection of animals with combinations of longation strains failed to show evidence of interference. To exclude the possibility that inability to interfere in vivo was due to failure to infect common neurons, we used protein misfolding cyclic amplification interference (PMCI). Consistent with animal studies, CI indicated both strains were amplifying independently, suggesting lack of interference is not due to failure to target same cells but an inherent property of strains. Importantly, CI reactions seeded with longation strains contained higher levels of Pr compared to seeded with shortation. Mechanistically, we hypo abundance of Pr not limiting in vivo or in resulting strains with low conversion to amplify independently.
Allosteric proteins are proteins that undergo a conformational change in response to ligand binding. Intrinsic disordered proteins/regions (IDPs/IDs) are prevalent in alloster proteins and were previously thought to be favorable for alloster coupling. We propose a comprehensive model to compare the roles of order-order and disorder transitions in alloster effect. The Monod-Wy-Wyman-Change (MWC) pathway, which involves an order transition, has a higher probability of alloster than the Monod-Wy-Wyman-Change (AM) pathway, which involves disorder. This suggests that IDPs/IDs have a complicated role in alloster regulation. We derive an analytic formula for maximal alloster coupling and show that too stable or unstable states are unfavorable for alloster. This is helpful for alloster drug design.
Prostate cancer is a major cause of death in the world, but few genetic alterations that drive cancer initiation and progression have been identified. βaten is essential for many developmental processes and has been implicated in tumorigenesis in many tissues, including prostate. However, studies on human cancer samples are unclear the role this protein plays in disease. Here, we extend our understanding of βaten in normal and neoplastic prostate using in vivo studies in the embryo and adult. Our analysis revealed that epithelial βaten is required for embryonic prostate growth but is dispensable in adult. During development, βaten controls number of progenitors in epithelial buds and regulates discrete genes, c-Myc and Nk3. Deletion βaten in Pten model of castration-resistant cancer demonstrated is dispensable for disease in this setting. Complementary experiments, in vivo showed βaten promotes squamous epith during development in absence andens.aten overexpression with Pten was able to drive invasive carcinoma with squamous metaplas. These demonstrate βaten essential for prostate and inherent high levels in epithelia drive squamous differentiation.
In developing countries where disease burden is high, there is an increasing need for biomedical research. Understanding the role of local factors is important for undertaking research in developing countries. We explored factors relating to information and communication during the process of informed consent, and the approach that should be followed for gaining consent. The study was conducted prior to a family-based genetic study among people with podoiosis (non-filar elephantiasis ) in southern Ethiopia. We adapted a method of rapid assessment in The Gambia. The methodology was entirely qualitative, involving focus group discussions and in-depth interviews. Discussions were conducted with podoiosis patients and non-patients in community, field workers, researchers, staff of local-government organisation ( NGO ) working prevention and treatment podoiosis and community leaders. We found that the extent of use everyday language, the degree which of expectations of participants were addressed, and techniques of presentation information had considerable impact on comprehension of information about research. Approaching podoiosis via trusted individuals and preceding consent with community sensitization were considered optimal of communication.
Cell proliferation is a common to all biological systems and is essential for the maintenance of body integrity through the continuous production of diversified lymphocytes in the thymus. This process involves proliferation, differentiation, selection, death, and migration of lymphocytes to peripheral tissues where proliferation also occurs upon antigen recognition. Quantification of cell proliferation requires experimental and mathematical methods. Here, we investigate the impact of genetics and aging on the immune system through the dynamics of proliferation of lymphocytes across thymus and spleen in mice. Our investigation is based on single-cell multicolour flow cytometry revealing the incorporation of thymidine analogue during pulse-chase-pulse experiments in vivo versus DNA content. A mathematical model simulates the evolution of single cell behaviour through Ordinary Differential Equations ( ODE ) during various durations of labelling. It allows us to fit our data, deduce proliferation and cell cycle durations in sub-populations. Our model is simple and validated with other pulsease experiments. Our results show that cell proliferation is highly heterogeneous with a specific signature that depends on genetic, specific cell stages in thym and sple and altered with age.
Mitochondrial tRNA mutations are a common cause of disease in humans, with about half of pathogenic mutations occurring in tRNA genes. These mutations are of particular interest because they can have different penetrance among patients and can be excellent examples of evolution and fixation of mitochondrial tRNA. We report the generation and characterization of the first pathogenic mitochondrial tRNA mutation in mice, m. 373G>A in the mt-T gene. This mutation recapitulates the molecular hallmarks of disease-causing mutations in humans, m 0T>C in the mt gene. We determined that the pathogenic mechanism of both mouse and human mutations is abnormal folding of tRNA that cannot be charged with isoleucine. We show that cells harboring mouse or human mutant tRNA have exacerbated mitochondrial biogenesis triggered by increase in ROS as compensatory response. We propose that pathogenic mechanism combined with compensatory can explain penetrance of this mutation.
In mammals, dosage compensation is achieved by doubling the expression of X-linked genes in males and X inactivation in females. However, the regulation of the active X chromosome may be controlled by DNA-based or epigenetic mechanisms that double the output in response to autosomal factors. To determine whether X expression depends on ploidy, we used expression arrays to compare X-linked and autosomal expression in human triploid cells. We found that the average X:autosome ratio was about 1 in diploid cells, but was lower (0.81–0.84 ) in triploid cells with one active X and higher (1.32–1.4 ) in triploid with two active X’s. Overall, X-linked expression in triploid does not strictly respond to autosomal nor is it adjusted to perfect. The unbalanced X:aut ratios could contribute to abnormal phenotypes with triploidy. Autosomal expression per gene was similar in triploid versus diploid, indicating no global effect on autosomal. In trip with two X our data support doubling X-linked expression. However, in trip with single X expression is upward presumably by epigen that senses ratio between X and autos. Such may act on subset whose expression in relation autos may be critical.
The ratio of non-synonymous to synonymous substitution rates (dN/dS) is a widely used to quantify evolutionary pressures on proteins. It was originally developed for distantly diverged sequences, but is often applied to samples from a single population. We study the expected dN/d ratio in a single population under selection and find that it is insensitive to the selection coefficient. The hallmark of positive selection, dN/d>1, is violated within a population. The relationship between selection and d/d does not follow a monotonic function, making it impossible to infer pressures from d/d.
While a major goal of evolutionary biology is to understand how natural selection has shaped patterns of genetic variation across genomes, the effect of selection on neutral divergence between species remains ambiguous. Previous studies have reported correlations between divergence and recombination, interpreted as evidence for selection reducing neutral divergence, but theory argues otherwise, especially for species that have diverged long ago. Here, we examine whether selection can affect divergence between closely and distantly related species. We find that divergence between closely related species ( e. g. human-primate ) is negatively correlated with functional content and positively correlated with recombination. We also find divergence between distantly related species ( e. g. humanrodent ) is negatively correlated with functional and positively with estimates of background selection from primates. These patterns persist after accounting for confounding factors of hypermutable Cp sites, content, and biased conversion. Coalescent models indicate that when the contribution of ancestral polymorphism to divergence is small, selection in the ancestral population can explain a large proportion of variance in divergence across the genome, generating correlations. Our findings show that, contrary to previous intuition, selection can indirectly affect divergence between closely and distantly related species. We cannot exclude the possibility that purifying selection drives some patterns, but this would require more of the genome to be under purifying than believed. Our work has implications for the evolution of genomes and interpreting genetic variation.
In Drosophila, CK2 phosphorylates and destabilizes the PER and TIM proteins, which inhibit CLOCK (CLK) transcriptional activity. Here we show that CK also phosphorylates and downregulates the activity of the catalytic α subunit of CLOCK (CLK). Downregulation of CKα induces CLK degradation, even in the absence of PER and TIM. Unexpectedly, the regulatory β subunit of the CK holoenzyme is not required for regulation of CLK stability. In addition, downregulation of CKα decreases CLK phosphorylation and increases PER and TIM transcription. These results indicate that CK inhibits CLK degradation while reducing its activity. Since CK promotes CLK degradation, we suggest that CLK stability and transcription activity result from counteracting effects of CK and CK.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the causative agent of Chagas disease, is a protozoan parasite that has a complex life cycle involving mammalian and invertebrate hosts. Cysteine peptidases, such as cruzain, are involved in several aspects of the parasite life cycle and host-parasite relationships. However, little is known about the factors that contribute to the parasite-insect interaction. Here, we investigated whether cruzain could be involved in the interaction of T cruz with the invertebrate host. We analyzed the effect of treatment of T cruz epimastigotes with anti-cruzain antibodies or a panel of cystepeptid inhibitors ( cystatin, antain, E-64 leupept, iodetamide or CA-074-OM ) on parasite adhesion to Rhodnius prolix midut ex vivo. All treatments, with exception of CA-OM, significantly decreased parasite adhesion to R prolix midut. Cystatin presented dose-dependent reduction in adhesion. Comparison of adhesion among T cruz isolates revealed the isolate which possesses low active cruzain adhered less than D28 and CLner isolates. Transgenic epimastotes overexpressing endogenous cruzain inhibitor (CH )agasin adhered less than wild-type parasites. adhesion CH parasites was partially restored by addition exogenous cruzain. In vivo experiments revealed low CH parasites compared to wild after passage in insect presented drastic in expression cruzain.
Cytoplasmic dyne is a microtubule-dependent protein that plays a crucial role in mitotic processes including centrosome separation, metaphase chromosome congression, anaphase spindle elongation and chromosome segregation. It also functions during interphase for vesicle transport and organel positioning. To understand the mechanisms that regulate this microtub motor, we screened a Caenorhabditis elegans cytoplasm dyin heavy chain mutant at semmissive temperature with a genome-wide RNA interference library to reduce gene functions. We isolated and characterized twenty dyin-specific suppressors that reduce dyin mutants but not other conditional loci. Twelve of the twenty suppressors do not exhibit sterile or lethal phenotypes when reduced in wild-type worms. Many suppress proteins, including dyin chains, localize to subcellular sites that overlap with dyin heavy chain. Knocking down any of four putative dyin accessory suppresses the heavy mutants, suggesting some chains regulate heavy function. We also identified 29 genes that when reduced suppress not only dyin but loci for unrelated processes.
During somatic differentiation in the ciliate Paramecium tetra, physiological DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) drive programmed genome rearrangements (PGR), which are safeguarded by DNA repair pathways. Because of their unique nuclear dimorphism, ciliates are powerful unicellular eukaryotic models to study GR mechanisms. At each sexual cycle, the germline nucleus is transmitted to progeny but somatic nucleus, essential for expression, is destroyed and new somatic differentiates from gerine copy. In P. tetra, somatic nucleus development involves massive GR including elimination of at least 45,000 gerine sequences (Internal Eliminated Sequences, IES). IES excision proceeds cut-and-close mechanism: domestic transposase PigMac is essential for cleavage and DSB at repair excision involves Ligase IV, component of non-homous endjoining (NHE) pathway. At genome level, huge number of DS must be repaired to allow assembly of functional somatic chromosomes.
Prion diseases are characterized by a long preclinical incubation period during which the infectious prion particle propagates in the brain. During this time, abnormal neuritic sprouting and synaptic deficits are apparent, but gross neuronal loss is not detected until the onset of clinical disease. The molecular mechanisms of early neuronal damage and death remain obscure. We used laser capture microdissection to isolate hippocampal CA1 neurons and determined their preclinical transcriptional response during infection. We found that gene expression in these neurons is dynamic and characterized by distinct phases of activity. A major cluster of genes is altered preclinically, returning to basal or undergoing reversal during clinical. This cluster contains a signature of N-methyl-aspartic acid ( NMD ) receptor and neuroprotective pathways. Genes in neuronal and dendrite development are altered, culminating in decline of synaptic proteins. Deregulated miRNAs follow concomitant patterns. This is the first study describing preclinical response of hippocal neurons to prion replication. Our findings suggest prion results in stimulation of a response, at least by NMD receptor, promoting survival and neurite remodelling. However, this is terminated prior to clinical in hippocampus, pointing to a juncture in disease.
Leishmaniasis is an infectious disease caused by the protozoan parasite Leishmania donovani that leads to the accumulation of inflammatory cells in the liver, forming granulomas, which eventually eliminate the parasite. To understand granuloma formation and function, we developed an in silico Petri model that simulates granuloma development throughout infection. The model was validated with experimental data from mice and robustness was assessed by sensitivity analysis. The model recapitulated disease progression and predicted changes in granuloma composition over time. We conducted in silico experiments to identify granul diversity in anti-lemanial activity and simulated IL-10 deficiency in lymphoid and myeloid cells. Our data suggest IL-10 produced by Kupffer cells at the granoma core has a dominant regulatory role.
Transcriptional regulation of a gene can be viewed as a computational device with transcription factor concentrations as inputs and expression level as output. We show that different parameterizations of a simple kinetic model of transcription regulation are able to approximate four standard arithmetic operations: addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division, as well as equality and inequality operations. These approximations depend on sets of parameters and are independently tunable. We demonstrate that networks of “arithmetic” genes can be combined to accomplish more complicated computations by simulating a network that detects significant elevations in time-vary signal. We also show that analytic functions can be approximated by allowing transcription factor binding on promoter.
Chikungunya virus (CHV) is an RNA virus from the Togaviridae family that is transmitted by mosquitoes in both sylvatic and urban cycles. In humans, CHV infection leads to a febrile illness denominated Chikunya fever (CHF), commonly associated with intense and debilitating outcomes. CHV arrived in Brazil in 2014 through two independent introductions: the Asian/Caribbean genotype through the North and the African ECS genotype through the Northeast. Following their introduction, both genotypes established their urban cycle among naive populations causing several outbreaks in the Americas. Here, we sequenced CHV genomes from a recent outbreak in the Northeast of Brazil employing an in-house Next-Generation Sequencing (NGS) protocol capable of detecting multiple CHV genotypes from clinical samples. Our results demonstrate that both Asian/ibbean and ECS genotypes expanded their range reaching cocirculation in Northeast Brazil. In addition, NG data supports findings of simultaneous infection by these genotypes suggesting coinfection might be more common than thought in highly endemic areas.
Horizontal gene transfer (HGT) is a process by which bacteria acquire new genes from other bacteria. This increases their diversity and ability to colonize new niches, including the human host. However, it is unclear how this new DNA interacts with the cell's regulatory networks. Here, we show that the global regulator H-NS discriminates between horizontally acquired and core genes. It silences horizontally acquired genes in response to environmental stimuli such as osmolarity and temperature. In contrast, core genes are modulated by HNS homodimers. The presence of a helper protein, Hha, is required for differential regulation of core genes by chromosomal HNS. Silencing of horizontally acquired DNA is accomplished by HNS-H complexes. In contrast, core genes are modulated by H homodimers. Remarkably, H-like proteins are restricted to Enterobacteriaceae. In addition, conjugative plasmids encoding HNS variants have been isolated only from members of this family. Thus, the H system in Enterobacteraceae presents unique features. The ability to discriminate between core and horizontally acquired DNA may help maintain horizontally acquired genes silent and give bacteria a competitive advantage in adapting to new environments, including host colonization.
Leishmania species are a group of parasites that cause a range of diseases in humans and animals. They have a highly conserved gene content and synteny across the genus, but only a small number of genes are differentially distributed between the three sequenced species: L. major, L. infant and L. brazili. It is not known how many of these genes are expressed in disease-promoting intracellular amastigotes or whether conserved genes are differentially expressed in the host. We used custom oligonucleotide microarrays to confirm that all differentially distributed genes are expressed in intracellular amastotes, with few subject to regulation at the RNA level. In the first large study of gene expression in L brazili, we show ∼9% of genes are regulated in RNA during L braz life cycle, consistent with other Leish species. Comparing amigote expression between species confirms Leish undergo little regulation, but identifies conserved genes regulated differently in host. We also investigated host influence parasite expression by comparing RNA profiles L amigotes from wild-type BAL/c or immunocompromised Rag−/−− mice. While dissemination from site is enhanced in Rag−−− genetic, RNA profiles are unperturbed.
Amphimeris is a fish-borne disease caused by the liver fluke Amphimerus spp that has recently been reported as endemic in the Pacific side of Ecuador with a high prevalence in humans and animals. The current diagnosis is based on stool examination to identify parasite eggs but lacks sensitivity, and the morphology of eggs may be confounded with other liver and intestinal flukes. No immunological or molecular methods have been developed to date. To address this, we developed a novel loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP) assay to detect Amphimer sp DNA in human stool samples. We designed a LAMP targeting the internal transcribed spacer 2 region of Amphimer sp and optimized the assay using DNA from adult worms recovered from animals. Conventional PCR was performed using primers F-B3 to verify amplification of Amphimer sp DNA sequence. LAMP was optimized and set up as LPhimer. We evaluated the sensitivity and specificity of both PCR and LAMP. The detection limit was 1 pg genomic DNA. Field testing was done using 44 stool samples from localities where fluke is endemic. Twenty-five samples were microscopy positive for Amphimer sp eggs. In molecular testing PCR-B was ineffective when DNA from fecal was used. When all stool samples included in study, diagnostic parameters for sensitivity and specificity were calculated for Limer assay, which were 76. 67% and 80.77, respectively. We have developed a specific and sensitive LAMP for Amphimer sp in stool. The procedure has been named Limer and has potential to be adapted for diagnosis and surveillance in amphias-endemic areas.
In Drosophila, the SNARE protein Ykt plays a non-canonical role in autophagosome-lysosome fusion. Ykt forms a complex with Sy17 and Snap29 to promote autophagosome-lysosome formation. However, loss of Ykt leads to a large accumulation of autophagosomes that are unable to fuse with lysosomes to form autolysosomes. In contrast, loss of Sy5, the partner of Ykt in ER-Gol trafficking, does not prevent autolys formation, suggesting a direct role of Ykt in fusion. Ykt localizes to lysosomes and autys and forms a SN complex with Sy17 and Snap. Interestingly, Ykt can be outcompeted from this complex by Vamp, and overexpression of V rescues the fusion defect in Ykt loss of function cells. A mutant Ykt with an R amino acid change in the zeroionic layer retains normal autagic activity and restores viability, whereas palmitoylation or farnesylation mutant Ykt does not. Ykt and V7 are both required for autag-lys fusion and are mutually exclusive subunits in Sy17-Snap complex. These data suggest V7 is directly involved in membrane fusion andkt acts as a non-conventional SNARE in this process.
Neisseria Haemophilus (NTH) is a commensal inhabit of the human nasopharyngeal mucosa and is commonly associated with opportunistic infections of the upper and lower respiratory tracts. NTH virulence is partly due to its ability to avert the bactericidal effects of host-derived antimicrobial peptides (AMPs). We previously determined that the periplasmic protein SapA bound AMPs and was required for NTH virulence in vivo. Here, we demonstrate that Sap functions directly counter AMP lethality during NTH infection by neutralizing AMP in vivo. We hypothesize that Sap delivers AMP to the inner membrane for transport into the cytoplasm. We show that AMPs localize in the cytoplasm of parental NTH and are susceptible to cytoplasmic peptase activity. In contrast, AMP accumulate in the perasm of bacteria lacking functional Sapase. These data support Sap-mediated AMP import, a novel strategy to reduce perasm and inner accumulation of host peptides.
Active degradation of MarA controls its coordination of downstream targets. MarA is a transcription factor that controls a variety of stress response genes in Escherichia coli. It has an unusually short half-life compared to other cellular proteins. We investigated the role of degradation in how Mar coordinates its downstream targets. We modified Mar’s half-life by knocking down the protease that targets it via CRISPR or by engineering Mar to protect it from degradation. Our results indicate that degradation impacts both the rate of coordination and maximum that downstream targets can achieve. In the context of multi-gene regulation, trade-offs between these properties show that perfect fidelity and coordination cannot coexist.
Leishmaniasis major is a protozoan parasite that causes cutaneous leishmaniasis in humans. We have previously shown that mice deficient in MAP kinase phosphatase 2 (MK-2 ) are unable to control infection with Leishmania mexicana. In contrast, the present study shows that MK-2 deficient mice are able to control infection with L. major, similar to their wild-type counterparts, as measured by lesion size and parasite numbers. Following infection, MK- mice have a reduced TH response compared to wild-type mice, with lower levels of IFN-γ and TN-α producing CD4 and CD8 T cells, and lower stimulated spleen IF-γ production. However, they also have reduced levels of IL-4 in spleen and lymph node cells, as well as reduced parasite-specific IgG in serum, indicating a general cell hypo-respons. The TH1/TH balance is unaltered in MK- mice compared to wild-type. Although MK- macrophages are more permissive to L growth than wild-type macrophages, LPS/IF-γ is equally effective at controlling growth in both MK- and wild-type macroph. Consequently, the absence of change in TH/TH balance in MK mice does not alter disease phenotype.
The development of the pancreatic ductal network in the mammalian pancreas is a complex process that has been poorly understood on both at the microscopic and macroscopic levels. The pancreas is a branched organ that does not exhibit stereotypic branching patterns similar to other glands. However, it contains a network of ducts that undergo a transition from unconnected micromen to a mesh of interconnected ducts and finally to a treelike structure. In this study, we quantify the network properties at different developmental stages and find that the pancreas exhibits stereotyp traits at each stage. The network properties change with time toward the most economical delivery of exocrine products into the duodenum. Using in silico modeling, we show that the steps of pancreatic development can be deconstructed into simple rules likely conserved for other glands.
Kines motor proteins drive intracellular transport by coupling ATP hydrolysis to conformation changes that mediate movement along microtubules. Here we report a comprehensive analysis of 114 experimental structures and results of conventional and accelerated molecular simulations that map the structural dynamics of the kines motor domain. All structures were found to reside in one of three conformation clusters: ATP-like, ADP-like and Eg5-bound. These differ in the orientation of key elements, notably microtub binding α–α8, loop subdomain and α2–β–β–β motor tip. Group membership did not correlate with the nature of the bound nucleotide in a structure. However, groupings coincided with distinct necker orientations. Accelerated molecular simulations of ATP, AD and Eg indicate all could sample majorlogically observed conformations. Differences in dynamic of dist sites were evident. In ATP simulations, necker, loop and α–5 display motions absent in AD bound. Dissection of these couplings provide evidence for network between active, microub-binding and necker via loop and loop. Simulations indicate mutations in loop reduce flexibility and couplings. Our results indicate ATP and AD conformations kines are intrinsically regardless nucleotide and support model where necker leads to tighter microub and nucleotide regions. Simulations highlight critical conformation and alloster between dist sites.
Bioluminescent reporters, based on the bacterial Lux system, are widely used as gene expression reporters. They are fast, sensitive, and non-destructive, allowing for high frequency measurements. Originally developed for bacterial cells, they have been adapted for eukaryotic cells and can be used for whole biosensors or in real time in live animals without euthanasia. However, interpretation of bioluminescent data is limited because biolumcence is different from gene expression due to nonlinear and molecular dynamics of the Lux system. We have developed a computational approach that allows users of Lux assays to infer gene levels from the output. This approach is based on a new model for Lux activity that includes LuxAB, LuxEC, and Fre with improved mechanisms for reactions as well as synthesis and turnover of Lux. The model is calibrated with experimental data for LuxAB and Fre from Photorhabus lumcens—the source of modern reporters—while literature has been used for Lux. Importantly, data show evidence for previously unreported inhibition for LuxAB. Model simulations show that biolumcent profiles can be different from changes in expression with peaks of light similar to output seen in experimental sets. By incorporating the model into a Bayesian scheme we can engineer promoter from biolumcence.
Enterovirus 71 (EV71) and coxsackievirus A16 (CVA) are major causes of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) in children. The capsid binder G3 (G3) can inhibit replication of these viruses. Here, we present the crystal structure of CVA in complex with G3, which clarifies the role of key residues in interactions with the inhibitor. Based on this structure, in silico docking was performed to investigate interactions with next-generation capsid binders NLD and AL, which are potent inhibitors of a panel of enteroviruses with interesting pharmacological properties. A meta-analysis was performed to obtain deeper insight into structural features required for capsid binders to interact and confer broad-spectrum anti-enterirus activity.
The immune response to fungal and Gram-positive bacterial infections in Drosophila melanogaster is regulated by the serpin inhibitor Necrot. Following infection, a proteolytic cascade is activated that signals through the Toll receptor, resulting in the synthesis of a range of antimicrobial peptides in the fat body and their export to the haemolymph. Necrot is synthesised in the fat body, but its site of degradation has been unclear. We demonstrate that Necrot is removed from the haemolymph by two groups of cells: glial cells and pericardial macrophages. Nec uptake is rapid, increased after 30 minutes and peaking at 6–8 hours. We show that Nec is processed through multi-vesicular bodies and delivered to the lysosome, where it co-localises with ubiquitin-binding protein H. Nec does not co-localise with Rab11, indicating it is not re-exported from macrophages. Instead, mutations blocking late endosome/lysosome fusion ( dor and car ) cause accumulation of Nec-positive endosomes even in the absence of infection. Knockdown of the Drosila orthologue of the mammalian LDL receptor with dsRNA identifies Lp1 as enhancer of the immune uptake of Necrot from the haolymph is blocked by chromosomal deletion of L1.
In sea urchins, Nodal signaling is known to prevent the formation of the left rudiment on the right side. However, the opposing pathway to Nodal signaling during left-right (LR) axis establishment is not clear. Here, we show that BMP signaling is activated in the left coelomic pouch, specifically in the veg2 lineage, but not in small micromeres. By perturbing BMP activities, we demonstrate that BMP signaling is required for the expression of left-sided genes and formation of left-sided structures. On the other hand, Nodal on the right inhibits BMP signaling and LR asymmetric separation and apoptosis of small miceres. Our findings show that BMP is positive for left-sided development in seaurch, suggesting that opposing Nodal and BMP roles in LR establishment are conserved deuteromes.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) infection is strictly synchronized with the host cell cycle. Infected cells in the G0/G phase support immediate early (IE) gene expression and proceed to the G1 phase where they arrest. In contrast, S phase cells can be infected but block IE expression and this is not relieved until cells have divided and re-entered G. During latent infection IE expression is also inhibited and for reactivation to occur this block must be overcome. We show that the block to IE expression during S phase can be overcome by genotoxic stress and inhibitors of DNA replication, pointing to involvement of checkpoint-dependent pathways in repression. Checkpoint rescue of IE strictly requires p53 and absence is mimicked by proteasomal inhibition in p-dependent manner. Requirement for cyclin-dependent kinase (CD) inhibitor p21 downstream p53 suggests pivotal role in IE repression in S and treatment of cells with CD inhibitor alleviates repression independently p. Importantly, CD also overcomes block during quiescent NT2 cells. Thus, timely CD activity not only secures specificity of cycle-dependent IE program but also prevents establishment of latent state.
Dendritic cells (DCs) from HIV-1 elite controllers (EC) rapidly produce type I interferons and upregulate interferon-stimulated effector genes upon exposure to HIV-1. This cell-intrinsic immune response is associated with the induction of SAMHD1 and LEDGF/p75 and accumulation of viral transcripts, but is inhibited by pharmacological blockade of reverse transcription or siRNA-mediated silencing of cytosolic sensor cG. Importantly, cell-intrinsic recognition of HIV-1 in DCs from EC translates into stronger ability to stimulate and expand HIV-specific CD8 T cells.
Drosophila larvae with increased levels of fat were identified using a buoy-based screening method. Sixty-six genes were found to be associated with increased fat storage. One of these genes was Sir2, a member of the sirtuin family. Siruins regulate carbohydrate and lipid metabolism by deacetylating key proteins. However, mammalian sirtins function in different tissues, making it difficult to define their role in energy homeostasis under normal conditions. Sir2 was knocked down in the larval fat body, resulting in increased fat levels. Using genetic mosa, we show that Sir restricts fat accumulation in individual cells of the body in a cell-autonomous manner. Consistent with this, changes in metabolic enzymes in Sir mutants point to a shift from catabism. Surprisingly, although Sir is upregulated under starvation, Sir mutants survive better than wild type under amino-acid starvation as long as sugars are provided.
Asymmetric cell division is an essential for generating cellular diversity in animals. In many species, the cleavage plane is perpendicular to the mitotic spindle, and spindle positioning dictates the size of daughter cells. We recorded the first embryonic division of 42 nematode species closely related to Caenorhabditis elegans, an excellent model for studying biophysical properties of spindle positioning. Our recordings of 128 strains from 27 Caenorhabis and 15 non-Caenorhabis species ( http://www. ensly. fr/LMCematCell/videos ) constitute a powerful collection of subcellular phenotypes to study evolution of cellular processes. We analyzed our collection to study spindle positioning. All strains underwent asymmetric division, but exhibited intra- and inter-species variations in degree of asymmetry and spindle parameters including oscillation, elongation, and displacement. Notably, these changed during evolution with no direction in species phylogeny, except spindle transverse oscillations evolved at base of Caenorhabis genus. These were unrelated to embryo size variations. Importantly, elongation, displacement, and oscillation evolved independently. This contrasts with C elegans studies and reveals unrecognized changes in spindle mechanics.
Salmonella Typhimurium and Escheria coli are two bacteria that have identical Omp proteins, a DNA binding protein that regulates gene expression. However, they have different responses to acid stress. In S. Tyimium, Omp expression is elevated at low pH, while in E. coli it is not. This is due to differences in the promoter regions of the omp genes. The E. coli promoter can be made acid-inducible by introducing sequences from S. Tyium. The Omp regulon in S. Tyium overlaps with E coli at 15 genes and includes horizontally acquired virulence genes E coli does not have. We found that O binds its targets more when DNA is relaxed, which occurs in S Tyium as a result of acid stress. This is required for optimal expression of virulence genes. The targets of O do not share a nucleotide consensus. We propose that O can recruit additional genes to its regulon from its modest specificity for DNA and preference for relaxed allowing it to modulate transcription in response to stress.
Chlamydia trachomatis is an intracellular pathogen that secretes a novel effector protein via a type III secretion mechanism. This effector is a SET domain containing protein that functions as a histone methyltransferase and has been named Nuclear Effector ( NUE). During infection, N is translocated to the host cell nucleus where it associates with chromatin. We demonstrated that N is expressed in mammalian cells and reconstitutes nuclear targeting and chromatin association in vitro. N is a histone methyltransfer that targets histones H2, H3, and H4 and also methylates itself (automethylates). Mutants deficient in automethylation have diminished histone methylation activity, suggesting that automethylation enhances enzymatic activity. This is the first description of a bacterial effector that directly targets mammalian histones.
Human height is a highly heritable trait with 80–90% of variation explained by genetic factors. Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have identified many common variants influencing height; however, little attention has been given to recessive effects. We investigated genome-wide recessive effects of inbreeding on adult height in 35,000 people from 21 populations. We found a highly significant inverse association between height and genome homozygosity, equivalent to a 3 cm height reduction in offspring of first cousins compared to unrelated individuals. This effect remained after controlling socio-economic status (χ2=83.89, df=1; p=5.2×10−20 ). However, there was heterogeneity among populations: the effect direction was consistent but size differed. This likely reflects true heterogeneity: effect depends on homozygosity in population and inheritance of recessive genotypes. These results predict multiple, rare variants influence height.
Malaria is an infectious disease caused by the parasite Plasmodium falciparum that is transmitted by the bite of an infected Anopheles mosquito. It is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in tropical and subtropical regions of the world. In this study, we investigated the phenotype and function of monocytes (MO), a type of white blood cell, in healthy individuals exposed to malaria and patients with acute uncomplicated malaria. We used flow cytometry to characterize the phenotype of MO and an in vitro antibody dependent cellular inhibition (ADC) assay to evaluate their function. We found that at the time of admission, the majority of patients had high percentages and absolute numbers of CD16+ and CCR2+CXCR1+ MO. Remarkably, expression of C2 and CR1 on the CDhigh MO subset defined two groups of patients that differed in their ability to limit parasite growth through ADC. The group with highest percentages and absolute of CDhiCCR+CX1 MO and highest levels of ADC activity had lower parasitemia (0.14±0.34%) than the second group (1.30±3%; p=0.005).
Schistosoma mansoni infection in Ugandan men is associated with increased abundance and function of HIV target cells in blood, but not foreskin: a cross-sectional study. Schistosoma mansoni infection has been associated with increased HIV prevalence in humans and SHIV incidence in primate models. We hypothesized that immune activation from gastrointestinal mucosa would increase HIV-susceptible CD T cell subsets in blood and fores through common mucosal homing. Fores tissue and blood were obtained from 34 HIV and malaria-uninfected Ugandan men who volunteered for elective circumcision, 12 of whom were definitively positive for S mansoni in stool and 12 definitively negative for S mans and worm. T and blood cell subsets were characterized by flow cytometry and immunohisto (IHC). Th and Th cells from both blood and fores expressed higher levels of CCR and were more activated than CD T cell. mans-infected men had higher of Th (22.9 vs.16.5% of CD T, p0.05, ) Th (2. vs.1.5,0.05, ) and Th (0. vs.0.3,0.01 ) than men. Additionally, Th in mans-inf men demonstrated enhanced (28. vs.16.3 producing cytokines =0.046 ). However, these alterations not observed in foreskin. mans was associated with increased of Th Th, Th and Th subsets in blood, but T differences did not extend fores. mans induced in cell immunology through mucosal are likely increase susceptibility in fores.
Filarial nematodes have a symbiotic relationship with the endosymbiont Wolbachia. Depletion of Wolbach results in profound defects in nemode development, fertility, and viability, and has promise as a novel approach for treating filarial diseases. Here, we demonstrate that Wolbach depletion induces apoptosis in the germline and somatic cells of embryos, microfilariae, and fourth-stage larvae ( L4 ). Surprisingly, apoptosis occurs in embryonic cells not infected prior to antibiotic treatment. In addition, apoptosis occurs in the hypodermis, which are populated with large numbers of Wolia, although disruption of the hypod cytoskeleton occurs following depletion. Apoptosis is non-autonomous, suggesting involvement of factors from Wolia in the hypod. The pattern of apoptosis correlates with nemode processes perturbed following Wolbach depletion, including embryogenesis and long-term sterilization. Our observations provide a cellular mechanism for sustained reductions in microilar loads and interruption of transmission following antibiotic therapy.
Plasmodium falciparum, the parasite responsible for malaria, requires extracellular pantoate for proliferation. It converts pantoate into coenzyme A ( CoA ) via five enzymes, with pantoate kinase ( PfK ) being the first. Anti-malarial panto analogues, such as pantoate and CJ-15, 801, kill the parasite by targeting Co biosynthesis. However, their mechanism of action is unknown. Here, we show that parasites treated with panto or CJ-801 become resistant to these analogues. Whole-genome sequencing revealed mutations in one of two putative PfK genes (Pf1 ) in resistant lines. These mutations significantly alter Pf activity, conferring a cost consistent with Pf coding a functional Pf that is essential for growth.
Genome-wide association studies of the PR interval in African Americans were performed to identify genetic determinants of the PR interval in individuals of African ancestry. The studies were conducted in four cohorts of African Americans (n=6,247) and genotyping was performed using the Affymetrix 6.0 microarray. Imputation was performed for 2.8 million single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) using YRI and CEU Hap II panels. We observed a strong signal (rs3924) within the gene encoding the sodium channel (SCNA) with genome-wide association (p<2.5×10−8) in two cohorts and meta-analysis. The signal explained 2% of PR variability in African Americans (β=5.1 msec per allele, 95%CI=4.1–6.1, p=3×10−23). This SNP was also associated with PR (β=2.4 per allele, 95CI=1.8–3.0, p=×10−16) in individuals of European ancestry (n=14,042) but with smaller effect (p<0.001) and variability (0.5%). Further meta-analysis identified genome-wide associations in SCN (rs10), ME1 (rs) and TBX (rs) that were correlated with SNPs in European and Asian studies. African was associated with PR (13.3 msec, p=0.009) in one cohort but not others.
Tomato mosaic virus (ToMV) is a positive-strand RNA virus that replicates its genomic RNA in replication complexes formed on intracellular membranes. Previous studies have shown that TOM1, a seven-pass transmembrane protein, is necessary for efficient MV replication. Here, we show that ARL8, a small GTP-binding protein, is co-purified with FLAG-tagged ToMV 180 replication protein from solubilized membranes of MV-infected Nicotiana tabacum cells. ARL is also co-purified with TOM in solubil membranes of MV-infected cells that expressed FLAG-tagged A8. The purified fraction showed RNA-dependent RNA polymerase activity transcribing MV RNA. In uninfected cells, TOM co-pur with FLAGged A8 less efficiently, suggesting a complex containing MV proteins, TOM, and ARL are formed on membranes in infected cells. In Arabidopsis thalian, ARL consists of four members. Simultaneous mutations in two A8 genes completely inhibited MV multiplication. In vitro MV RNA-replication system, lack of TOM or A8 inhibited production of replicative RNA, indicating TOM and ARL are required for efficient RNA synthesis. When MV180 protein was coexpressed with TOM and A8 in yeast, RNA5′-apping activity was detected in membrane. This was undetect or weak when 180 was alone or with TOM or A8.
In the olfactory system of the locust, two types of inhibitory motifs have been identified: feed-forward and feedback. Feed-forward inhibition is provided by a subset of lateral interneurons (LHNs) onto Kenyon cells (KCs) to maintain sparse firing, which is important for olfactory learning and memory. In contrast, feedback inhibition is mediated by a single inhibitory neuron, the GABAergic neuron (GN), which is the main source of inhibition in the mushroom body and is mediated by a feedback (FB) loop including KCs and GN. We used a model of the locust olfactory system to compare the effects of feed-forward and feedback inhibition. Both motifs were able to maintain sparse responses of KCs and provide optimal odor discrimination. However, only feedback inhibition was able to create a response consistent with in vivo data. These findings suggest that feedback is the primary source of inhibition onto KCs.
The diagnosis of lyssavirus infection, including rabies in animals and humans, is based on post-mortem laboratory confirmation using techniques such as direct immunofluorescence and virus isolation. However, molecular methods such as polymerase chain reaction ( PCR ) are increasingly used for diagnosing rabies in humans and for epidemiological analyses. We developed a combined real-time reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction ( RT-qPCR ) method for pan-lyssavirus detection. This method is based on two technologies: a probe-based TaMan RT-qPCR for detecting RAB species ( panAB RT-q ) and a second using intercalating dye SYBR to detect other lyss species ( panly-q ). We evaluated this assay with a large panel of animal samples covering almost all genetic variability at the species level and extended to all lyss species characterized to date. This method was also evaluated for human rabies diagnosis on 211 samples (76 positive and 135 negative ) including saliva, skin and brain biops. It detected all human rabies cases and confirmed sensitivity of skin biopsy (91. 5% ) and saliva (54 ) for intra-vit diagnosis of human rabies. Finally, this method was implemented in two rab reference laboratories in endemic countries ( Cambodia and Morocco ).
Tset-transmitted trypanosomiasis is a significant threat to pig farming in Ghana. In 2007, more than 50% of domestic pigs in the Eastern Region were lost to the disease. Insecticide-treated mosquito nets were tested as a control method. Two villages were selected: one as control with 14 pigies and one experimental with 24 pigies protected by insecticide-treated nets. The nets were 100 cm high, 150 denier polyester with 100 mg/m deltamethrin and UV protector attached to timber and planks. Tset densities were monitored bi-monthly with geoferenced traps. The protected village showed more than 90% reduction in two months and further 95% in subsequent months. The control village showed only seasonal variations. Fifty pigs from each village were ear-tagged and treated with diminazene acate 3.5 mg/kg after blood samples were taken. Initial trypan prevalence was 76% and 72 in protected and control, and 16% in protected and 84 in control three months. After six 8% protected were infected and 60 in control.
Biomedical articles published between 2000 and 2014 were assessed for reproducibility and transparency. The study found that only one article provided a full protocol and none made raw data directly available. Replication studies were rare ( n = 4 ) and only 16 had data included in a systematic review or meta-analysis. The majority did not mention funding or conflicts of interest. Between 200 and 201, the percentage of articles with no funding statement decreased from 94. 4% to 34.6 and the percentage reporting conflicts (0 in 200,15.4 in 201 ) or none (5.6 in200,50. in201 ) increased. Articles in clinical medicine were twice as likely to have no funding information and private funding compared to other fields.
Yersinia pestis is the causative agent of primary pneumonic plague, a highly lethal disease with mortality rates approaching 100%. The disease progression of pneumonic plague is biphasic, with an initial pre-inflammatory phase characterized by bacterial growth in the absence of host inflammation, followed by a pro-inflammatory phase marked by neutrophil influx, inflammatory cytokine storm and tissue destruction. Using a FRET-based probe to quantify effector protein injection by Y. pestis type III secretion system, we show that bacteria target alve macrophages early during mouse infection, followed by switch in host preference to neutrophils. We demonstrate that neutrophil influx is unable to limit bacterial growth in lung and is responsible for severe inflammation during pro-inflammatory phase.
Leishmaniasis is a disease caused by Leishmania parasites, transmitted by sandflies. One of the challenges in studying visceral leishmaniasis ( VL ) is diagnosing asymptomatic carriers. This study evaluated the performance of serological tests to identify asymptomatic VL in a cohort of 136 participants from an urban area in Southeast Brazil with a two-year follow-up period. Blood samples were collected from 136 participants ( 97 positive and 39 negative by PCR ) and clinically none progressed from asymptomatic to disease. Controls included blood from 22 healthy individuals and 8 patients with kala-azar. Molecular tests were performed: PCR with Leish generic primer followed by hybridization with L. infant probe and PCR with L donovani specific primer. Plasma were tested by ELISA with three antigens: L infant, amazon, and r39 recombin protein. The presence of Leishmania was confirmed by molecular in all kala patients and 117 ( 86% ) of the cohort. Kala patients showed high reactivity in ELISA whereas asymptomatic presented low reactivity against antigens tested. Compared to molecular, amazon and infant antigens showed higher sensitivity (49.6% and 41.% ) than r39 (26.5% ) ; however r39 had higher specificity (73.7 ) than amazon (52.6 ) and infant (36.8 ). There was low agreement among antig used (kappa0.10 ) Serological tests were inaccurate for asymptomatic compared molecular; this could lead misclassification in studies.
Retrotransposons are abundant in mammalian genomes due to their ability to amplify in pluripotent and germ cells. However, mechanisms that silence retrotransons in germ and pluripotent cells are important for limiting the accumulation of repetitive elements in the genome during evolution. Although silencing of individual retrotransons is relatively well-stud, many retrotransons are seldom analysed and silencing in germ, pluripotent or somatic cells remains poorly understood. Here, we show that cryptic repetitive probes present in Illumina and Affymetrix gene microarray platforms can accurately monitor retrotrans expression. This approach has allowed us to identify histone deetylase Hd1 as a component of retrotrans silencing machinery in mouse embryonic cells and determine retrotrans targets of Hd1 in these cells. We also identify retrotrans that are targets of retro silencing mechanisms such as DNA methylation, E-mediated histone modification and Ring1/E-containing polycomb repressive complexes in embryonic cells. Our analysis suggests that multiple silencing mechanisms target retrotrans in embryonic cells, different genomic copies of the same retro can be differentially sensitive to silencing, and define retro elements targeted by silencing machineries.
In Arabidopsis thaliana cryptochrome 2 ( CRY ) is a key regulator of flowering time in response to light. C1 ( CRY-interacting bHL 1 ) is a bHL protein that interacts with CRY in response to blue light to activate the transcription of FT (Flowering Locus T ). In vitro, C1 binds the canonical-box (CGT, also referred to G-box ) with higher affinity than non-canonical-box (CAN ) sequences. However, in vivo,1 binds the chromatin region FT promoter, which contains non-canonical sequences. We show thatRY also interacts with least1 in response blue, but not darkness or other wavelengths. Genetic analysis demonstrates1,1,2,4,5 act redundantly activate FT and are positive regulatorsRY mediated flowering. Importantly,1 and other form heterodimers and some heterodimers have higher affinity than homodimers non-canonical-box in vitro assays. This why1 and other bind canonical-box higher, whereas associated noncanonical FT vivo. Consistent hypothesis different play similarRY-miated light, expression regulated by light. Our demonstrates function redundantly regulatingRY-dependent, different formodimers interact noncanonical vivo.
Refugee arrivals to the United States from Asia are at risk of intestinal parasitic infections such as hookworm, Trichuris trich, Ascaris lumicoid, and Strongloides steral. These infections are rare in the United States and may be underdiagnosed or misagnosed, leading to serious consequences. This study examined the costs and benefits of overseas presumptive treatment of parasitic diseases vs domestic screening/treatment vs no program. An economic model was developed to estimate the cost and health impacts of four interventions on an annual cohort of 27, 700 U. S.bound Asian refugees: 1) “No, 2) “Domestic Screening and Treatment,3) “Overse Albazole Ivermect” presumptive, and 4 “se Albazole Domestic for Strongloides. The “No” option is the least expensive ($165,923 ) and least effective (145 outpatient,4 hospital,0 deaths over 60-year for one-year ). “se Albazole Iverect” ($418,824 ) is less than “Domestic Treatment ($3,832,572 ) “se Alb Domestic Stronglo ($2,182,483 ). The most effective option is “se Alb Iect, which reduces outpatient deaths hospital by 80% at estimated cost $458,718 per death averted $2,21924/QAL/year relative “No”. Overse presum treatment for U.bound refugees is cost-effective less expensive domestic programs. Addition of Iect to Alb reduces Stronglo and disseminated.
Microsporidian parasites are a type of obligate intracellular pathogen that infect nematodes, including Caenorhabditis elegans. Here, we report the discovery of a new microidian species, Nematoda displere, that displays a unique tissue tropism compared to previously described parasites of this host. Nematida displere can invade and replicate in multiple tissues of C. elegans, including the epidermis, muscle, and intestine. However, the majority of replication occurs in the epider and muscle, with little replication in the intestine. This is in contrast to two closely related species, Nematida paris and Nematida sp. 1, which exclusively invade and replicate in the intestine. We characterized the life cycle of Nemat displere, including pathogen entry, intracellular replication, and exit. The genome of Nemat displere was compared to Nemat paris and Nemat sp.1, revealing that Nemat displere is the earliest diverging species of the Nematida genus. Over 10% of proteins encoded by the Nemat displ genome belong to a species-specific family of RING-domain proteins of unknown function. These proteins may mediate interactions with the host. Altogether, this system provides a whole-animal model to investigate factors responsible for pathogen growth in different tissue niches.
Cockayne syndrome complementation group B (CS) is a protein essential for transcription-coupled DNA repair, and mutations in CS are associated with Cockayne syndrome, a devastating disease characterized by premature aging, sun sensitivity, and neurological and developmental defects. CS belongs to the SWI/SNF ATP-dependent chromatin remodeler family, but the extent to which CS remodels chromatin and whether this is utilized in repair is unknown. Here, we show that CS repositions nucleosomes in an ATP-dependent manner in vitro and this is greatly enhanced by N1-like histone chaper, which we identify as CS-binding partners. By mapping domains and analyzing CS derivatives, we demonstrate that chromatin remodeling by CS and N1-like chaper is required for transcription-cou repair. Moreover, we show that chromatin and repair mediated by CS are separable activities.
Genome-wide maps of epigenetic variation have not yet been fully elucidated in humans. We identified clusters of CpG dinucleotides with high inter-individual epigen variation, termed Variably Methylated Regions ( VMRs, in five purified cell types. VMRs preferentially occur at enhancers and 3’ untranslated regions (UTRs). The majority of VMRs have high heritability, but a subset of VMs show low herit and are correlated between cell types, enriched for transcription factor binding sites and biological pathways relevant to each tissue. For example, in T cells we identified a network of co-regulated VMs enriched for genes in T-cell activation; in fibroblasts a network of co-reg VM comprising four HO gene clusters for growth control; in neurons a network of VM enriched for synaptic signaling. We cultured genetically-identical fibroblasts under varying conditions and demonstrated that some VM networks are responsive to environment, with methylation at these loci changing in trans dependent on growth. These environmentally-responsive VM showed strong enrichment for imprinted loci (p<10−80 ). Our study provides a map of epigen variation in the genome showing both genetic and environmental causes this variation.
Dengue is a mosquito-borne viral infection that can be difficult to diagnose in the early stages of illness. Serological tests for IgM and IgG are used to differentiate between primary and secondary infections. Dengue virus nonstructural protein 1 ( NS1 ) is an early marker for acute deng and is present between days 1–9 post onset of illness. However, seroconversion can be difficult to detect in serum. To evaluate the performance of a newly developed Panbio Dengue Early Rapid test for NS1, we determined if it can improve sensitivity when used in combination with a commercial Ig/Ig test. We evaluated the performance of Deng Early in Vietnam with 198 laboratory-confirmed positive and 100 negative samples, and in Malaysia with 263 laboratory-confirmed and 30 samples. In Vietnam, the test had 69. 2% sensitivity (95% CI 62.8 to 75.6 ) and 96. % specificity (95 CI 92.2 to 99.8 ). In Malaysia was similar with 68.9 sensitivity (95 CI 61.8 to 76.1 ) and 96.7 specificity ( CI 82.8 to 99.9 ) compared to RT-PCR. Importantly, when Deng Early was used with Ig test sensitivity increased to 93. When tests were compared each day post onset of illness, there was differentiation between antigen and antibody.
Trans is a new computational method for detecting conserved helices of functional RNA structures, including transient, pseudo-knotted and alternative structures. Unlike existing RNA prediction methods, which assume a unique functional structure and do not predict features required for folding in vivo, Trans aims to understand how functional structures form in vivo. It is based on the hypothesis that evolutionarily related genes fold similarly in vivo. We have developed Trans to detect conserved helices of high statistical significance. We present a comprehensive evaluation showing that Trans can predict structural features of reference structures, including pseudo-kotted ones and alternative configurations. It can also identify unstructured subsequences bound by molecules and provide evidence for new helices defining folding pathways. This supports the notion that homologous sequences do not only assume similar structures but also fold similarly. Finally, we show that Trans predicted features differ from thermodynamic ones. Unlike existing folding methods, Trans works in a comparative way. This has the advantage of highlighting conserved features and not requiring detailed cellular knowledge but the disadvantage of not predicting function over time.
The Arabidopsis thaliana, a model plant species, has a complex immune network that protects it from pathogenic microbes. This network must function even when components are targeted by pathogen effectors. We used a network reconstitution strategy to study the immune network that mediates Pattern-Triggered-Immunity. We disassembled and reassembled the Arabidopsis immune network step-by-step and resolved systems-level mechanisms underlying the transcriptome response to flagellin-22 ( fl22 ). We found widespread interactions among sub-networks, called sectors, in the fl22-responsive transcriptome. Many of these interactions result in buffering. Regulatory mechanisms show how jasmonate ( JA ), ethylene ( ET ), phytoalexin-deficient 4 ( PAD ) and salicylate ( SA ) sectors control transcriptional response to fl22. We show that many regulatory mechanisms are not detectable by traditional single-gene null-mut analysis. Similar to pathogenic perturbations, nullut effects on signaling can be buffered by the network.
In Drosophila, the central nervous system develops from a monolayered neuroepithelial sheet. In a first step, patter mechanisms subdivide the uniform epithelia into domains, allowing for an increase in neuronal diversity in a tightly spatial and temporal manner. The neuroepith patterning of the embryonic optic placode gives rise to the larval eye primord, consisting of two photoreceptor ( PR ) types, primary and secondary, as well as the opticobe prim, which develops into prominent ganglia during lar and pupal stages. Here, we characterize a genetic network that regulates the balance between lar eye and optic precursors, as well as primary and secondary precursors. The proneural factor Aton ( A ) specifies lar precursors, while the orphan receptor Tailless ( T ) is crucial for specification of prec. The Hedgehog and Not signaling pathways act upstream of A and T to coordinate specification in a timely manner. The placement of the boundary between A and T is required to control the number of primary and secondary precursors.
