Not signaling also controls a cell decision, acting in a cascade of transcription interactions to define PR identity.
Human β-defensin 1 (hBD1) is a ubiquitously expressed endogenous antimicrobial peptide that exhibits qualitatively distinct activities between its oxidized (h1ox) and reduced (red) forms. Here, we explore the antimicrobial mechanisms of h1. Using electron microscopy, we detected a previously unknown net-like structure surrounding bacteria treated with the reduced but not oxidized form of h1. A transmigration assay demonstrated that h1-derived nets capture bacteria and inhibit bacterial transmigration independent of killing. The presence of nets completely prevented migration of h1-resistant pathogens and were stable in the presence of human duodenal secretion with a high amount of proteases. In contrast, cysteines are necessary for net formation. This redox-dependent serves as an additional mechanism of action for h1 and differs from formation by other defensins such as Paneth-derived human-defin 6 (h6). While h1red and hox have distinct antimicrobial functions, only the form provides additional protection by entrapping bacteria in extracellular structures preventing invasion.
Lowe syndrome and Dent-2 are genetic disorders caused by mutations in the inositol 5-phosphatase OC1 (OCRL1) gene. While the cellular functions of OC1 are well understood, the molecular basis for the renal tubulopathy seen in both disorders, characterized by low molecular weight proteinuria, is unknown. Here, we show that OC1 deficiency causes a defect in endocyt in the zebraf pronephric tub, a model for the mammalian renal tub. This coincides with reduced levels of the scavenger receptor megal and its accumulation in endytic compartments, consistent with reduced recycling within the endytic pathway. We also observe reduced numbers of early endytic compartments and enlarged vacuolar endosomes in the sub-apical pronephric cells. Cell polarity in the pronephric tub is unaffected in mutant embryos. OC1-deficient embryos exhibit mild ciliogenesis, but this cannot account for observed endocytic defect. Catalytic activity of OC1 is required for renal endytic and endytic can be rescued by suppression of P5. These results indicate that OC1 is required for endytic in vivo and support hypothesis that endytic defects are responsible for renalulopathy in Lowe and Dent-2. Moreover, our results indicate P5 as potential therapeutic for Lowe and Dent disease.
Rift Valley fever (RV) is a zoonotic disease transmitted by ticks that affects livestock and humans. In recent years, evidence of RV transmission during interepid periods has been reported in parts of Africa. We studied the presence and determinants of interepid RV transmission in the Kilom river valley, Tanzania. A cross-sectional serosurvey was conducted in cattle and sheep from May to August 2011, approximately four years after the 2007 RV outbreak in Tanzania. The presence of RV virus (RVV) was determined using ELISA kits detecting IgM and IgG antibodies in serum. Information about determinants was obtained through interviews with herd owners. Overall seroprevalence was 11. 3% ( n=168 ); 5.5% in animals born after the 2007 outbreak and 22.7% in present during the outbreak. There was a linear increase in prevalence in postepid cohorts. Nine ELISA positive samples were also positive for RVV IgM indicating recent infection. The distribution of serreval exhibited hotspots. There was no difference in serreval in animals after the epidemic (6.1% vs.4% for females and males, p.158 ) whereas it was significant during the outbreak (26.%.% for females and males,<.001 ). Animals >15 km from the plain were more likely to have antibodies than <5 (1.92;.04–.56 ). Species, breed, herd, grazing and altitude were not associated with seros. These findings indicate postepid transmission of RVV in the area.
Trypanosoma cruzi, the etiologic agent of Chagas disease, is an obligate intracellular pathogen that has conserved a contractile vacuole complex ( CVC ) to regulate osmolarity. We used a combination of genetic and biochemical approaches to delineate the contribution of the CVC to the traffic of glycosylosphatidylinositol ( GPI )-anchored proteins to the plasma membrane of the parasite and promote invasion. T. cruzi Rab11 ( GFPcTab11 ) localized to the C, while a dominant negative mutant ( GFPcTabDN ) localized to the cytosol and epastigotes expressing this mutant were less responsive to hypo- and hyperosmotic stress. Parasites were still able to differentiate into metacylic forms and infect cells. GPI-anch transialase ( TTS ) of the 60–200 KDa family and trypastigote surface antigen (TSS II ) co-localized with GFPcTab to the C during intramastigote to trypastote transformation. Parasites expressing GFPcTabDN prevented TS, but not other proteins, from reaching the plasma and were less infect compared to wild cells. Incubation of mutants in presence of exogenous recombin active TS and sialic donor before infecting cells partially rescued infectivity trastotes.
A phase III clinical trial was conducted to compare the immunogenicity and safety of a purified chick-embryo cell rabies vaccine (PCV) administered according to a shortened post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) 4-site/1-week intradermal regimen with the currently recommended 2-site Thai Red Cross (TR) regimen. The trial enrolled healthy individuals ≥1 year of age and randomized into four groups to receive intradermal PCV according to one of the two regimens or without human rabies immunoglobulin (HR) administration at visit in adults. Rabies virus neutral antibody (RV) concentrations and percentages of participants with RV concentrations ≥0. 5 IU were assessed up to day (D) 365 post-vaccination. Noninferiority of the 4-site/week regimen to 2/TR was demonstrated at D49, the lower of the 95% confidence interval (CI) for difference in percentage participants with RV concentrations was-5. Of 443 participants receiving 4/week, 88 received HR; 442 received 2/TR (88 HR ). All achieved RV concentrations D14. At49, difference percentage with RV concentrations between 4/week and 2/TR was-1 (95CI-2–0 ; thus noninferior was concluded. RV geometric concentrations IU in 4/week and IU in 2/TR at14, subsequently declined all. RV concentrations were lower with HR administration than without. The regimens had similar profiles Of 15 adverse reported 4/week and 19/TR, none were vaccination.
The salience network (SN), anchored in the anterior insula and the anterior cingulate cortex, plays a crucial role in the detection of goal-relevant events and facilitation of access to appropriate cognitive resources. We investigated the spatiotemporal organization of the SN using subsecond resolution multisession fMRI data from the Humanome Project and graph-theoretical techniques. The SN demonstrated the highest flexibility in time-vary connectivity with the frontopari network (FPN), cing–opular network (CON), and ventral and dorsal attention (VAN) networks. Functional interactions of the SN were the most spatially varied in the brain. SN maintained a consistently high level of centrality over time, indicating it is a hub for facilitating cross-network interactions. Connectivity profiles of SN were distinct from other prefrontal control systems. Temporal flexibility of SN uniquely predicted individual differences in cognitive. These results were also observed in a second dataset, demonstrating robustness of findings.
Viral particles of the non-enveloped virus Simian virus 40 (SV40) are released from the host cell by a poorly understood process. The virus assembles in the nucleus and must be released from the cell without being encapsulated by cellular membranes. This process appears to involve the insertion of viral proteins into cellular membranes, making them permeable to large molecules. A newly identified SV40 gene product, VP4, is expressed late in the viral cycle and corresponds to the time of cell lysis. We investigated the role of this protein in viral release by expressing VP as a GST fusion protein in bacteria. Purified VP was found to bind membranes and disrupt them. VP perforated membranes by interacting with the bilayer demonstrated by assays and release of markers into unilamellar vesicles or liposomes. The hydrophobic domain of VP was essential for binding and disruption. VP displayed preference for membranes of lipid composition of plasma over nuclear membranes. Phatidylethanol, found in bacterial membranes, inhibited membrane activity of VP. Disruption of membranes by VP involved formation of ∼3 nm pores in mammalian cells including permissive SV host. These results support a role of VP as virop in perforation of membranes to trigger SV release.
Dengue virus (DENV) is a major public health problem in tropical and subtropical regions of the world. Current control of the disease is hampered by the absence of antivirals or vaccine, resulting in an estimated half of the world population at risk of infection. The immune response to DENV is not fully understood and better knowledge of it is recognized as main challenge for vaccine development. We previously reported that a DNA vaccine containing the signal sequence from human plasmin activator (tPA) fused to DENV NS1 gene (pcANS) induced protection against DENV in mice. We aimed to elucidate the contribution of cellular and humoral responses elicited by this candidate for immunity. pcANS induced robust protection against DENV, considerable levels of anti-NS antibodies and cell responses. Passive immunization with anti-NS antibodies conferred protection in mice with low virus load (4LD50), which was abated with increase of viral dose (40LD50). pcANS also induced CD+ and CD+ T cells. We detected production of IF-γ and cytotoxic by CD+ T induced by vaccine, although contribution in protection not evident compared CD+. Depletion CD+ in mice completely abolished protection. Transfer experiments revealed animals receiving CD+ cells with anti- antiserum, both from vaccinated, survived infection with rates not different pcANS-immunized.
Streptocococci are Gram-positive bacteria that rely on cell-to-cell communication to regulate important processes such as sporulation, conjugation, and virulence. They use extracellular signaling peptides to elicit a response, either by triggering a two-component phosphore or by binding to cytoplasmic effectors. The latter comprise the RNPP family ( Rgg, Rap, Npr, Prg and Plc ), whose members regulate important processes such as sporulation, conjugation and virulence. RNPP are increasingly considered as targets for new antibacterial agents. These proteins are characterized by a TPR peptide-binding domain, except Rap proteins also contain an N-terminal H-type DNA-binding domain and display transcriptional activity. Here, we elucidate the structure-function of ComR, a new member of the RNPP, which controls competence for natural transformation in streptocci. Com is activated by the binding of its pheromone XIP, the form of the Com/sX-inducing-peptide ComS. The structure of Com from Streptoccus thermus combined with mutational and in vivo assays allows us to propose an original mechanism of Com regulation. XIP induces release of the sequestered H domain and Com dimerization to allow DNA binding. Importantly, we bring evidence that this mechanism is conserved and specific to Com orthologues, demonstrating Com is not Rap as proposed, but instead a member of the RNPP. In addition, identification of X and Com residues important for activation constitutes a step towards antagonistic strategies to control exchanges streptocci.
The pentameric ligand-gated ion channel ELIC is a member of a large family of ligand-gated ion channels that has recently been characterized at high resolution by X-ray crystallography. However, detailed investigation of its function has been hampered by the lack of knowledge of its activating ligands. Here we describe the characterization of ELIC by electrophysiology and X-ray crystalraphy. We show that ELIC is activated by a class of primary amines, including the neurotransmitter GABA, at micromolar to millimolar concentrations. These ligands bind to a conserved site and evoke currents that slowly desensitize over time. The protein forms cation channels with properties that resemble the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. The single channel conductance and comparably simple behavior make ELIC an attractive model to study mechanisms of ion conduction and gating in this family of neurotransmitter receptors.
Atopic dermatitis (AD) is a common skin condition that often precedes the development of asthma in individuals. However, the mechanism underlying progression from AD to asthma is unclear. Here, we show that mice with skin-barrier defects develop AD-like skin inflammation and are susceptible to asthma. Furthermore, thymic stromal lymphopoietin (TSL), overexpressed by skin keratinocytes is the systemic driver of bronial hyperresponsiveness. In an AD-like model, mice with keratin-specific deletion of RBP develop high levels of TSL. Antigen challenge to the lung of RBP–deficient mice resulted in asthmatic phenotype seen in wild-type littermates. Elimination of TSL signaling blocked the march, demonstrating high TSL levels required to sensitize lung to inflammation. Furthermore, K-TSL mice maintained high TSL without skin pathology. Importantly epidermal T was sufficient to trigger march, sensitizing lung to allergens in absence epicutaneous sensitization.
The genome of Thermotoga marima, a phylogenetically deep-branching, hypermophilic bacterium, has been characterized using an approach that integrates multiple omics data with bioinformatics tools. Experimental data were generated for whole-genome resequencing, transcription start site (SS) determination, transcriptome profiling, and proteome profiling. These datasets were analyzed in combination with bioinformatics tools to improve gene annotation, elucidate transcription units (TUs), identify putative noncoding RNAs (ncRNAs), and determine promoters and ribosome sites. The analysis revealed distinctive properties of T. marima genome relative to other bacteria. The genome has a high number of genes per TU (3. 3), a paucity of putative ncRNAs (12), and TUs with multiple SS (3.7% ). Quantitative analysis of promoters and ribosome sites showed increased conservation relative other. The 5′UTRs follow atypical length comprised “short”5′Rs (11–17) and “common”5′Rs (26–32). Transcription regulation is limited by lack intergenic space for majority TUs. Lastly, a fraction annotated genes expressed independent growth and linear mRNA/protein observed (Pearson r=0.63, p2×10−16-test ).
Visual perception is highly susceptible to contextual influences. In this study, we investigated how contextual bars affect the perception of a target bar at the center of a display. Observers judged whether a bar was present at the center of a display given a weak or strong contrast at the target location with or without other bars. We found that observers are more likely to perceive a target when the context has weak rather than strong contrast. When the context perceptually groups with the target, weak contextual bars bias observers to perceive target relative to without context, as if filling the target. Meanwhile, high-contrast bars, regardless of grouping with target, bias observers to perceive no target. A Bayesian model of visual inference accounts for the data, illustrating that context influences perception in two ways: (1) biasing observers’ prior that target should be present according to grouping principles, and (2) biasing observers’ model of likely contrasts caused by target. According to this model, our data suggest context does not influence perceived contrast despite bias to perceive target, suggesting areas beyond primary cortex are responsible for inferences.
Defectors can sometimes create conditions that rescue cooperation from defector-induced destruction. This is counterintuitive because cooperation is vulnerable to exploitation by defectors, which enjoy a fitness advantage by consuming the common good without contributing. However, defector-induced population collapse can lead to small population size, which is known to favor cooperation. This is because small size increases variability in cooperator frequency across locations. Individuals in cooperator locations grow more than in defector locations, allowing cooperators to outgrow defectors globally. This raises the possibility that defectors can lead to conditions that rescue cooperation from defector destruction. We demonstrate this using an individual-based model of birth, death, migration, and mutation. During defector collapse, def occasionally go extinct before cooperators by chance, allowing cooperators to grow. Empty locations, either pre-existing or created by def-induced extinction, favor cooperation because they allow cooperators but not defectors to grow. These factors lead to the counterintuitive result that initial defectors allow better survival of cooperation compared to defectors absent.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic pathogen that causes infections in patients with altered epithelial barriers. In this study, we show that P. aeruginosa interacts with polarized epithelium and adheres almost exclusively at multi-cellular junctions, where it attaches to extruded apoptotic or apoptotic cells. This tropism is independent of cell death type, as P aerugin also binds necrotic cells. We further show that aerugin is internalized through efferocytosis, a process in which epithelial cells engulf and dispose of extruded apoptotic cells. Intracellularly, along apoptotic cell debris, aerugin inhabits eocytic phagosome that acquires lysosomal features and is killed. We propose that elimination of aerugin through eocytosis is part of host defense mechanism.
During Drosophila embryonic development, the gonad is formed from two cell types: primordial germ cells (PGCs) and somatic gonadal precursors (SGPs). PGs form at the posterior of the blastoderm and are carried inside the embryo during gastrulation. To reach SGs, PGs must traverse the midgut and migrate through the meserm. We investigated the role of the hedgehog (hh) pathway shifted (sh) in PG migration. sh encodes a secreted protein that transmits Hh through the proteoglycan matrix after release from basolateral membranes of H expressing cells in the wing disc. sh is expressed in gonadal meserm, and loss and gain-of-function experiments show it is required for PG migration. The hmg-dependent isoprenoid biosynthetic pathway generates the PG attractant by SGs and other tissues when hmg is ectically expressed. We show that this attract depends on sh as well as a second pathway g1. The PG attractant is linked to H by showing that ectopic hmg in the nervous promotes release of H from cells into the mesermal layer where H contacts PGs. H potentiation of H by hmg depends on cholesterol.
Vaccines are being developed to protect against HIV infection and control the virus replication in the body. To understand how these vaccines work, it is important to know how the immune system fights HIV. In people who control HIV for a long time, the immune cells that kill HIV-infected cells are more active than those who progress to disease. Here, we measured how well immune cells kill HIV-infected cells in people who got a vaccine and compared to those who are HIV-negative and those who progress to disease. The vaccine was based on adenovirus type 5, a common virus that infects humans. We measured how well immune cells killed HIV-infected cells in people who got the vaccine and compared to those who are HIV-negative and those who progress. We found that people who got the vaccine had immune cells that killed HIV-infected cells, but not as well as those who control HIV for a long. However, people who got vaccine and had HLA class I alleles B27, B57 or B58 had immune cells that killed HIV-infected cells better than those who progress. These alleles are associated with controlling HIV in people who are infected.
Shared intentionality is a key factor in the evolution of humans’ unique cognitive abilities. We model the coevolution of intentional behavior and cumulative culture, showing that rapid technological advance goes hand in hand with emergence of ability to participate in intentional behavior. In absence of opportunities for significant technological improvement, ability to undertake intentional behavior is selected against. We provide unified mechanism for emergence of shared intentions and collaborative behavior in humans, as well as cause for species diversity in prevalence of such behavior.
Oligoastoteratozoospermia and Infertility in Mice Deficient for mi-34/c and mi-449 Loci.
Escherichia coli Nle 191 (EcN) is a bacterium that has been used therapeutically for over a century, but the determinants of its probiotic properties remain elusive. Ec produces two siderophore-microins (Mcc) that are responsible for antagonistic activity against other Enterobacteriaceae. Ec also synthesizes the genotoxin colactin encoded by the p island. Colactin is a virulence factor and putative proarcinogenic compound. We aimed to decouple antagonistic activity of Ec from genotoxic activity. We demonstrated that p-encoded ClP, peptase that activates colactin is required for antagonistic activity of Ec. Analysis of ClP mutants revealed that activity is linked to transmembrane helices of ClP and not periplasm peptase domain, indicating transmembrane domain is involved in aspect Mcc biosynthesis or secretion. Single amino substitution in ClP inactivates genotoxic but maintains antagon activity. In vivo salmonelis model, this mutant reduced clinical signs and fecal shedding of Salmonella similarly wild type, whereas ClP mutant could not protect nor outcomp pathogen. ClP-dependent antibacterial effect also observed in vitro other Ec strains carry truncated form M gene and p island. In such, siderore-M synthesis also required glucosyltransfer I involved salochelin production. This interplay colact, salochelin, and biosynthetic pathways suggests genomic were co-selected played role evolution Ec from phyroup.
Cryptococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that causes cryptococcal meningitis and is responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths annually. Cryptoccal glycans are required for survival in the host and pathogenesis. Most glycans are synthesized in the secretory pathway, although precursors are made in the cytosol. Nucle sugar transporters solve this problem by exchanging nucleotide sugars for nucleoside phosphates. The major virulence factor of C. neoans is anti-phoc capsule that is displayed on surface; capsule is also shed and impede host response. Here we show that U1 and U2 transport UDPxy, although exhibit distinct localization patterns and parameters. Both also transport UDPgalactose. U1 and U2 are required for xylose incorporation into capsule and necessary for C to cause disease in mice, although not for viability in context.
Neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) are a major public health burden in developing countries. To control and eliminate NTDs, disease risk estimates are key to target interventions and monitoring. However, currently, there is a lack of a global database providing access to NTD data that is constantly updated and can be utilized by researchers and disease managers. We describe the development of a georeferenced database that can be employed for disease modeling and control of NTDs. We searched the literature and contacted Ministries of Health and institutions in schistosiasis-endemic countries for location-specific data. Data were extracted, geferenced, and stored in a database with a web interface allowing free access and management. Our database contains more than 12, 000 gefer schosomiasis locations from 35 African countries available at http://www.nt. org. The database is expanded to include other NTDs, e. g. soil-transmitted helthiasis and leishiasis. An open, spatial NTD database offers opportunities for disease modeling, control, monitoring, and surveillance. Moreover, it allows detailed analyses of disease distribution in space and time. We demonstrate the establishment of a global NTD database is feasible and should be expanded.
Helminth Infections Do Not Exacerbate Mycobacterium tuberculosis Infection in Cotton Rats  
Helminth infections are known to induce a Th2 immune response and immunoregulatory environment, which can suppress Th1 immunity necessary for Mycobacterium tuberculosis ( MT ) control. We hypothesized that helminth infections may exacerbate MT infection. Co-infections were conducted in cotton rats, the natural host for filarial nematode Litomoides sigmodis and excellent model for MT. Immunological, histological, and mycobacterial studies were performed two months after MT challenge in cotton with and without L sigmodis. Sple cell proliferation and interferon gamma response to purified derivative were similar between coinfected and MT animals. In contrast to our hypothesis, MT loads and lung granuloma size were not increased in coinf animals. These findings suggest that filaria infections do not exacerbate MT in cotton model.
In the fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster, the DEG/ENa channel family represents one of the largest families of ion channels. Although the physiological functions of these proteins are poorly understood, we found that the DE/ENa channel pp23 is expressed in a subpopulation of sexually dimorphic gustatory-like chemosensory bristles. These bristles are distinct from those expressing feeding-related gustatory receptors. Disrupting pp23 or inhibiting activity of pp23-expressing neurons did not alter gustatory responses. Instead, blocking pp23-positive neurons or mutating pp23 delayed the initiation and reduced the intensity of male courtship. Furthermore, pp23 mutations altered the response of males to the female-specific pheromone 7, ( Z ) 11 ( Z )Heptadiene. These data indicate that pp23 and cells play an important role in the sensory system that determines sexual behavior inrosila.
Mitochondrial tRNAs are imported from the cytosol into mitochondria to ensure proper translation. This process is conserved across diverse phyla, including protozoa, fungi, plants, and humans. However, the mechanisms of tRNA import are not well understood. In the unicellular alga Chlamdomonas, a correlation was found between mitochondrial cod usage and the amount of imported tRNAs. This led to the hypothesis that tRNA import might be dynamic and adapt to the mitochondrial content. To test this, we modified the Chlamdomonas mitochondrial genome by introducing mutations in cod usage. This resulted in reduced levels of translation as well as decreased activities of respiratory complexes. These effects were linked to limitations of tRNAs in mitochondria. This suggests that tRNA import cannot rapidly respond to genetic changes and is not dynamic. Rather, steady levels of tRN in mitochond result from co-evolution between tRNA import and translation machinery.
Diabetes is a major public health problem affecting nearly 30 million people in the United States, 10% of the population, and 84 million are prediabetic. Current methods for quantifying blood glucose dysregulation in diabetes and predabetes are limited by single-point measurements or average measures of overall glycemia. We used continuous glucose monitoring ( CG ) to evaluate the frequency of postprand glucose elevations, types, and patterns between individuals given an identical challenge. Measurement of insulin secretion highlights that underlying physiology is highly variable between individuals. We developed a framework to group individuals according to specific patterns called “glucotypes” that reveal heterogeneity within traditional categories of regulation. Importantly, individuals considered normogc by standard exhibit high variability using CG, with levels reaching predabetic and diabetic 15% and 2% of time, respectively. We show that dysregulation by CG is more prevalent and heterogeneous than thought and can individuals considered normc by standard, and patterns reflect underlying physiology. The interindividual variability in responses to meals highlights the nature of regulation. We developed a model for identifying mechanisms of dysulation and a web for visualizing user-uploaded profile and classifying into glucotypes.
Plant innate immunity is regulated by mitogen-activated protein (MAP) kinase (MAPK) signaling cascades. The Raf-like MAP kinase kinase (MAPK) EDR1 negatively regulates plant defense and cell death responses. Here, we show that EDR1 negatively regulates the MK4/MK5PK/MPK3/MP6 MAPK cascade in Arabidopsis. We found that edr mutants have highly activated MPK/MPK activity and higher MP/MPK protein levels than wild type. EDR physically interacts with MK4 and MK5, and this requires the N-terminal domain of EDR. E1 also affects MK4/5 protein levels. In addition, mpk, mkk and mkk mutations suppress edr-mediated resistance and overexpression of MK or MK causes edr-like resistance and mildew-induced cell death.
Infectious diseases are a major cause of mortality worldwide, resulting in millions of deaths annually. To develop effective prevention and control strategies, it is necessary to have reliable computational tools to understand disease dynamics and predict future cases. These tools can be used by policy makers to make informed decisions. In this study, we developed a computational framework based on Gaussian processes to perform spatiotemporal prediction of infectious diseases. We exploited the structure of similarity in our formulation to obtain an efficient implementation. We tested our framework on the problem of Crimean–Congo–hemorrhagic fever cases between 2004 and 2015 in Turkey. We showed that our Gaussian formulation obtained better results than frequently used machine learning algorithms ( i. e., random forests and boosted trees ) under temporal, spatial, and spatiemporal scenarios.
Rift Valley fever (RV) is a mosquito-borne viral zoonosis that causes significant morbidity and mortality in humans and livestock in Africa and the Middle East. Outbreaks of RV are sporadic and associated with both seasonal and socioeconomic factors. Here, we propose a three-patch model to investigate the transmission of RV virus (RVV) among ruminants with spatial movements. Our findings indicate that in Northeast Africa, human activities associated with the Eid al-Adha festival along with climatic factors such as rainfall and hydrological variations contribute to the transmission and dispersal of the pathogen. Moreover, sporadic outbreaks may occur when two events occur: 1 ) abundant livestock are recruited into areas at risk of RV due to demand for the festival and 2 ) abundant mosquitoes emerge. These factors have impacts on severity of RV outbreaks. Our results present the dynamics of the pathogen over short and long periods, particularly during festival time.
Anthrax is a zoonotic disease caused by the bacterium Bacillus anthracis anthracis that affects both humans and animals. In Azerbaijan, we assessed the spatio-temporal changes in human anthrax occurrence from 1984 to 2010. We analyzed data on livestock anthrax outbreaks, vaccination efforts, and human anthrax incidence during the Soviet and post-Sov governance periods. We used spatial analysis, cluster detection, and weighted least squares regression to evaluate changes in the spatio-temporal distribution of anthrax. Our results showed a 11. 95% increase in annual incidence from 1984 to 1995, followed by a 35.24% decline after the initiation of livestock vaccination in 1996. We also found geographic variation in the distribution of cases; they were primarily concentrated in the west in the early period and shifted eastward as time progressed. After the dissolution of the Soviet Union, the distribution of anthrax in Azerbaijan underwent marked changes. Despite decreases in incidence, continued control measures in livestock are needed to mitigate its occurrence.
Polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFAs) have been shown to modulate the activity of voltage-gated potassium (KV) channels, which are proteins that respond to changes in membrane potential by allowing K+ ions to cross the membrane. PUFAs can induce channel opening by modifying the voltage-sensitivity, providing a potential treatment for refractory epilepsy through a ketogenic diet. While PUFs have been reported to influence the gating mechanism by electrostatic interactions with the voltage-sensor (VSD) domain, the exact PUFA-protein interactions are still unknown. Here, we report the interactions between the Shaker KV channel in open and closed states and a PU-enrich lipid bilayer using microsecond molecular simulations. We determined a putative PU binding site in the open state of the channel at the protein-lip interface in the vicinity of the extracellular halves of the S and S helices of V. The PU tail covered a wide range of non-specific hydrophobic interactions in the hydroobic core of the proteinip interface, while the carboxy head displayed specific interactions to polar/charged residues at the extracellular of the S and S helices encompassing the S-S linker.
Cryptosporidiosis is a disease caused by the protozoan parasite Cryptosporidium parum that is responsible for a significant burden of disease in children in developing countries. In addition, it can result in chronic and life-threatening enteritis in AIDS patients. Current drugs lack efficacy in treating these conditions. The discovery of novel anti-cryptporid therapeutics has been hampered by the poor tractability of this pathogen. The genome effort has identified new targets including inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase ( IMPDH ). We have developed a pipeline to accelerate in vivo screening of C. parum IMP inhibitors. We engineered the related parasite Toxoplas gondii as a model of C. parum infection for the screen. This provides target validation and a large window not possible in C. parum assays. We established a fluorescence assay of cell proliferation and C. par growth that utilizes automated imaging for throughput. We used these assays to evaluate C par IMP inhibitors from our chemistry and identified a subset 1, 2, 3-triazole that exhibit in vivo selectivity in T gondii and anti-cryptid activity.
Tooth development is a highly heritable process that interacts with the development of the entire craniofacial complex. Abnormalities of tooth development are common, with tooth agenesis being the most common developmental anomaly in humans. We performed a genome-wide association study of time to tooth eruption and number of teeth at one year in 4, 564 individuals from the 196 Northern Finland Birth Cohort ( NF196 ) and 1, 518 from the Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSP ). We identified 5 loci at P<5×10−8 and 5 with association P<5×−6. The loc included several genes with links to tooth and other development ( KCNJ,DA, HOXB, RADL51, IGF1, HM2 MS3 ). Genes at four of the identified loci are implicated in development. A variant within the HO gene associated with occlusion requiring orthodontic treatment by 31.
Down syndrome (DS) is the most common human aneuploidy caused by trisomy of chromosome 21 (H21). In contrast, complete monomy of H21 is lethal and only partial or mosaic monomy of H21 is seen, leading to variable physiological abnormalities with intellectual disability, locomotor deficits, and altered muscle tone. To identify dosage-sensitive genes involved in DS and M21 phenotypes, we created two mouse models: TsY carrying a tandem duplication and MsY carrying a deletion of the Hspa-App region syntenic with 21. 11-q21. We report that trisomy and monomy of this region alter locomotion, strength, muscle mass, and balance. Expression of skeletal muscles revealed changes in regulation of genes in energetic, mitochondrial activity, and biogenesis. These are downregulated in TsY mice and upregulated in MsY mice. The shift in muscle metabolism correlates with change in proliferation without alteration in function. However, reactive species (ROS) from I decreased in MsY mice while permeability of TsY mitochondria slightly increased.
G protein-gated potassium channels (GIRK; Kir ) are activated by Gβ subunits derived from Gi/o proteins and regulate heartbeat and neuronal excitability and plasticity. Both neurotransmitter-evoked (evoked ) and neurotransmitter-independent (basal ) GIRK activities are physiologically important, but mechanisms ofbas and its relation toev are unclear. We have previously shown for heterologously expressed GIRK/2, and now for native GIR in hippocampal neurons thatbas andev are interrelated: the extent of activation by neurotransmitter ( Ra ) is inversely related tobas. We have developed a quantitative model of GIRK/2 function. We characterized single-channel and macroscopic GIR/2 currents and surface of GIR2 andβ in Xenopus oocytes. Our model recapitulatesbas andev in Xen o, HE293 and hippocal neurons; predicts dose-dependent activation of GIR2 by coexpressedβ and accounts for inversebas-Ra correlation. Modeling indicates 3–4β dimers are available for GIR2 under all conditions and different expression levels. In contrast, decreases from ~ to less than per GIR2 as increases. The persistentβ/channel but not α/channel support association GIR2 withβ, consistent with recruitment to surfaceβ but notα by GIR2. Our suggests stoichiometry 4β but only per GIR2.
Plant pathogenic Xanthomonas bacteria secrete transcription activator-like effectors (TALEs) into host cells, where they act as transcriptional activators on plant genes to support bacterial virulence. LEs have a modular DNA-binding domain composed of tandem repeats. Two amino acids within each repeat, termed repeat-variable diresidues (RVDs), bind to contiguous nucleotides on the DNA and determine specificity. We propose a novel approach for LE prediction to identify potential virulence targets. Our approach accounts for recent findings concerning LE targeting, including frame-shift by repeats of aberrant lengths and the flexible orientation of target boxes relative to the start of the downstream gene. The model accounts for dependencies between RVD positions. Parameters are learned from a wealth of quantitative data generated over the last years. We benchmark the novel approach, PredTA, using RNA-seq data Xanthas infection in rice and find an improvement in performance compared to previous approaches. PredTA is able to predict several putative virulence targets. We also observe that no genes are predicted by any tool for several LE, termed orphan for this reason. We postulate one explanation for orphan LE are incomplete annotations, hence propose promoter-wide genome scans for boxes. We demonstrate targets from promoter-wide scans may be by genome-wide, the latter combined with RNA-seq detect putative of existing annotations.
Mitochondrial non-synonymous variations are changes in the mitochondrial DNA that do not alter the encoded amino acid sequence of a protein. However, the vast majority of these changes have not been functionally evaluated, and their pathogenicity has been assessed in silico by software. These tools have been shown to be incongruent. We have developed APOEE, a machine-learning algorithm that outperforms existing methods in estimating the harmfulness of mitochondrial non-syn variations. APOEE was trained on a manually curated set of 189 non-syn variants that have been functionally evaluated in the laboratory. The algorithm was tested on a test set of 189 variants that have not been functionally evaluated. AEE outperformed existing methods in predicting the harmfulness of these variants. AEE was also able to predict the harmfulness of variants that were not in the training set. AEE was able to predict the harmfulness of variants that were not in the training set. AEE was able to predict the harmfulness of variants that were not in the training. AEE was able to predict the harmfulness of variants that were not in the training.
Dengue virus (DENV) is the most common mosquito-transmitted viral infection, causing a range of diseases from self-limiting deng fever to life-threatening deng hemorrhagic fever and shock. Thrombocytopenia is a characteristic of both mild and severe deng disease and correlates with disease progression. Previous studies have shown that DENV nonstructural protein 1 (NS1), secreted into patients’ blood, can stimulate cells via Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4) and cause endothelial leakage. However, it is unclear whether DENV NS can induce platelet activation or thrombocytopenia during DENV infection. Here, we show that DENV but not Zika virus culture supernatant induces P-selectin expression and phosphatylserine (PS) in human platelets, abolished when NS is depleted from D supernant. Similar results are found using recombinant NS from four D serotypes and effects blocked by anti-NS F(ab)2, antiTLR antibody, TLR antagonist Rhobacteroid lipopolyscharide (LPS), and TLR inhibitor (AK242), but not polymyxin (PS inhibitor. Activation of plate by DENV promotes adenos diphosphate (AD)-induced aggregation and plate adhesion to endothelial cells and phagocyt by macrophages. Finally, D-induced thromocytopenia and hemorrhage are attenuated in TLR knockout and wild-type mice when NS is depleted from D supernant.
Vascular blood pressure homeostasis is a complex physiological process that involves the interaction of multiple regulatory systems to maintain blood pressure and volume. We performed a mathematical analysis of the dynamic loops that regulate vasotone of vascular smooth muscle, blood, and mean arterial pressure, which include the arginine vasopressin ( AV ), atrial natriuretic peptide ( ANP ), and renin-angiotin-aldosterone ( RAAS ) systems. Our analysis of the AV-AN-RA system revealed the presence of two mechanisms that perform the same function: one affects pressure by vasoconstriction, the other by volume. Both are oscillators consisting of negative feedback of monotone systems, admitting a single equilibrium that can be stable or rise to oscillatory.
Thromboembolic disease is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In this paper, we identify a novel mechanism of thrombus formation related to the formation of a fibrin cap, an important component of thrombus. We studied protein transport through the fibr network by integrating experiments with simulations. Our results show that network permeability and diffusivity are important for protein transport through the fibr network. Previous in vivo studies in mice have shown that non-occluding thrombi are covered by a fibr network (fibrin cap). Simulations, using microfluidic devices and accounting for the permeable structure of fibr cap, demonstrated that thrombin inside thrombus was washed through fibr network, limiting exposure of platelets on throm surface throm. Moreover, restricting approach of platelets in flowing to throm core, fibr impaired platelets from regions high throm concentration necessary for plate activation and throm growth.
Invariant natural killer T (iNKT) cells are known to be activated during Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) infection, but their role in limiting microbial growth is not well understood. We investigated how iN cells control intracellular Mtb replication when co-cultured with infected macrophages. We found that iN cell activation, as measured by CD25 upregulation and IFγ production, was primarily driven by IL-12 and IL-18. In contrast, i cell control of M growth was CD1-dependent and did not require IL-12, IL-18, or IFγ. This suggests that conventional activation markers do not correlate with i cell effector function during M infection. We also found that i control of M replication was independent of TN and cell-mediated cytotoxicity. By dissociating cytokine activation from CD1-restricted effector function, we identified a novel mediator of i cell antimicrobial activity: granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF). i cells produced GMF in vitro and in vivo during M infection in a CD1-dependent manner, and GMF was both necessary and sufficient to control M growth. GMF is a novel i cell antimicrobial effector and may play a role in cell immunity against M.
The opportunistic fungal pathogen Candida albicans is a common component of the human intestinal flora. To gain insight into C. albicans colonization, we studied the genes expressed by fungi grown within the host. The EF1 gene, encoding a putative transcription factor, was highly expressed during growth of C. albicans in the intestinal tract. In contrast, an ef1 mutant exhibited increased colonization of the murine intestinal tract, a model of commensal colonization, whereas EF1 overexpressing exhibited reduced colonization of the intestinal and oral cavity of athym mice, the latter modeling mucosal candidiasis. When inoculated into the bloodstream mice, both ef1 and EF1 overing strains caused lethal infections. In contrast, mutants attenuated in virulence following intravenous inoculation exhibited normal levels of intestinal colonization. Finally, expression of several genes dependent on factor E1 during growth was observed in laboratory, but E1-independent expression during growth within murine tract.
Immunization with irradiated sporozoites is the most effective strategy against liver stages of malaria. However, the mechanisms underlying this success are unknown. We show that CD8 T cell responses require prolonged antigen presentation. Using TCR transgenic cells specific for the circumsporozoite protein, we found sporozoite antigen persists over 8 weeks after immunization. This is remarkable since irradiated sporozoites are incapable of replication and do not differentiate beyond liver stages. Persisting antigen is detected in lymphoid organs and depends on CD11+ cells. Prolong antigen enhances CD8 T response in several ways. Firstly, primed CD8 cells exposed to antigen in vivo severely reduce final memory population size. Secondly, memory cells expand in immunized mice but not transferred naïve. Finally, persist antigen primes naïve cells, including thymic emigrants, to become effector capable eliminating parasites in liver.
Leishmanias is a neglected tropical disease caused by Leishmania parasites transmitted by sandflies. Most treatments require hospitalization and present side effects or parasite resistance. To overcome these barriers, we tested the potential of polymyxin B to kill Leishmania amazonensis. Polymyxin B was adsorbed in PBC nanoparticles ( PBCp ) to augment its internalization in infected macrophages. PBCps were fabricated by anionic polymerization and analyzed by Dynamic Light Scattering ( size, ζ potential ), Nanoparticle Analysis ( size/concentration ) vertical cell diffusion ( rate drug release ) drug incorporation indirect protein determination and cell viability. Nanoparticles with polymyx B (BCpB ) presented adequate size 261. 5 ± 25.9 nm low polydispersity index 1.79 ± 0.17V stable for 45 days. The drug release from BCpB was 6 times slower than free polymyx, favoring a prolonged release profile. In vitro, polymyx alone reduced amastigote infection in macrophages 10 μg/mL without complete elimination at higher concentrations. However, this limits its application as adjuvant leishic therapy or antimicrobial coating. The nanocar BCp also presented leishic effect surpassing polymyx activity but no antimicrobial was detected. Polyx maintained activity against E. coli Pseudomonas and Klebsella adding antimicrobial to nanoparticles.
Visceral leishmanias (VL) is a major public health problem in Brazil, with high lethality. This study investigated prognostic factors for death from VL in Belo Horizont, Brazil. The study was based on data from the Report Disease Information System-SAN ( Brazilian Ministry of Health ) relating to clinical manifestations of the disease. The study included two periods: 2002–2009 and 2007–2009. During the first period, the SIN platform changed from Windows to Net-version, differing in some parameters. Multivariate regression models were performed to identify variables associated with death from VL and included in prognostic score. In the first period, variables associated with greater risk of death from VL were weakness, Leishmanias-HIV co-infection, and age ≥60 years. In the second period, variables associated with death were bleeding, other infections, jaundice, and ≥60 years. The prognostic score was developed using variables associated with death from the latest version of SIN. The performance was evaluated by sensitivity 71. 7%, specificity 73.7%, positive predictive values 28.9% and 94.5, and receiver operating curve 75.6.
Plants rely heavily on receptor-like kinases (RLs) for the perception and integration of internal and external stimuli. The Arabidopsis thaliana regulatory leucine-rich receptor kinase (LRRK) BAK1 is involved in steroid hormone responses, innate immunity, and cell death. Here, we describe the differential regulation of three BAK-dependent pathways by a novel BAK allele, bak1-5. bak-5 mutants are severely impaired in innate signaling mediated by the BAK-dependent RLKs FLS and EFR. bak-5 mutants are not impaired in BR signaling or death. We show that the non-kinases FLS and EFR have low kinase activity and are unable to phosphorylate BAK in vitro. Furthermore, kinase activity is dispensable for ligand-induced heteromerization of F or E with BAK in planta. The suppression of F and E-dependent signaling in bak-5 is due to BAK-5 interaction with the respective ligand RK but requires BAK kinase activity. Our results demonstrate phosphorylation-dependent control of growth, immunity and death by the RL BAK.
Antiproliferative response to anticancer treatment is a complex process that cannot be captured by current methods. The proposed computational approach uses time-lapse cell microscopy and flow cytometry data to render the proliferative process through the cell cycle and subsequent generations during treatment. The effects of treatments are modelled with modules describing the activity of main pathways causing arrest, repair and death in each phase. A framework is created to apply different types of modules in each phase and test at the complexity justified by data. The method is challenged with time-course measures in parallel with flow cytometry and timeapse cell microscopy in X-treated human ovarian cancer cells spanning a range of doses. The most model of treatment including dose-response effect is progressively built combining modules with a strategy fitting all data of different doses and platforms. The model gives the first complete in silico rendering of the process following X-ray, providing quantitative measures of dose-dependence of G1, S, and G2 checkpoint in subsequent.
Coenzyme Q (Co) is a critical electron carrier in the mitochondrial respiratory chain that has been implicated in a wide range of human diseases. Its biosynthesis involves a multi-step process that requires enzymes encoded by PDSS and PD2 genes. Mutations in either of these genes in humans lead to severe neuromuscular disease with nephrotic syndrome in PD2 deficiency. We show that renal disease in mice with missense PD2kd genotype is due to Co biosynthetic defect. Co9 and Co10 levels in kidney homogenates from PD2kd mutants were lower than controls. Disease originates in glomerular podocytes, as seen in Podin/Pd2 mice but not in tubular epithelial or hepatocyte conditional knockouts. Liver PD2/Alb mice have no disease despite undetectable Co9, impaired capacity and altered metabolism.
Although phenotypic robustness, the ability of an organism to maintain its phenotype in the face of environmental and genetic perturbations, is important for all forms of life. Development has long been viewed as a key component of robustness, but the underlying mechanism is unclear. Here, we report that the determinative developmental lineages of protostomes and deuterostomes are structured such that the cellular composition of the organism is only modestly affected by cell death. Several features of the lineages, including shallowness, topology, early ontogenic appearance of cells, and non-clonality of cell types, underlie the robustness.
EmbryoPhenomics is an open-source, high-throughput platform for phenomics in embryos. It comprises an Open Video Microscope ( OpenIM ) that captures high-resolution videos of embryos under controlled conditions. These videos are then analysed by Embryo Computer Vision ( EmbCV ), which extracts phenomic data for morphological, physiological, and behavioural traits during embryonic development. We demonstrate Embryoenomics in a series of experiments assessing chronic, acute, and multistress responses to environmental ( temperature and salinity ) in > million embryos of two species with different patterns of development—the snail Radix bica and the amphod Orchestia gammellus.
Malaria parasites (Plasium spp. ) undergo dramatic changes in metabolism during their complex life cycle between mosquito and human hosts. These changes are associated with a shift from glycolytic metabolism in asexual stages to increased dependence on tricarboxy acid (TCA ) metabolism in mosquito stages. We used stable isotope labelling, targeted metabolomics and reverse genetics to map stage-specific changes in Plasium berghei carbon metabolism. We show that glutamine is the predominant input into TCA in both asexual and sexual stages and is important for gametogenesis. Glutamine catabol, as well as reactions in intermediary metabolism and CoA synthesis are essential for ookin toocyst transition in mosquito.
Many biological signaling pathways exhibit the ability to differentiate between pulsatile and sustained signals in the regulation of gene expression. While the underlying networks are diverse, they are built around a common motif, the incoherent feedforward loop (ILFIL), where an input simultaneously activates an output and an inhibitor of the output. This motif can exhibit temporal adaptation, where the system is desensitized to a sustained input. Here, we examine another property of IFLs—the ability to process oscillatory signals. Our results indicate that the system’s ability to translate pulsatile signals is limited by two constraints. The kinetics of IFL components dictate the range for which the network is able to decode pulsatile dynamics. In addition, a match between network and signal characteristics is required for optimal counting.
Orientia tsutsugamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is a leading cause of serious febrile illness in Southeast Asia. It is an obligate intracellular bacterium that can only be cultured in mammalian cells and requires specific methodologies for propagation and analysis. Here, we describe improved methods for quantification, propagation, purification, and long-term storage of O. tsugamushi. We cultured O. tsamushi in mouse embryonic fibroblast ( L ) cells and measured bacterial growth using O. tsamushi-specific qPCR. We monitored the effect of various conditions on bacterial viability and growth in mammalian cells. We present a standardised method for comparing O. tsushi viability after purification and propagation under different conditions. Our data support improved techniques for propagation, purification, and storage of this important human pathogen.
Schistosoma haematobium Infection in 1–5 Year Old Children: Safety and Efficacy of Antihelmin Drug Prazantel (PQ)  
Schistosomiasis is currently controlled by treating schistosome infected people with the antelminic drug prazantel (PQ). Children up to 5 years are excluded from schist control programs due to lack of PQ safety data in this age group. This study investigated PQ safety and efficacy in Zimbabwean children aged 1–5 (n=104) treated with P tablets. Side effects were assessed by questionnaire administered to caregivers within 24 hours of P. Efficacy was determined 6 weeks after P through schosome counts in urine. The change in infection in children 1–5 (n=100) was compared to 6–10 olds (n=435). Pre-treatment S haobium infection in 1–5 was 14.6 eggs/10 urine and prevalence 21%. Of 104 children 3.8% reported side effects within 24 hours P. These were stomach ache, loss of appetite lethargy and inflammation of face and body. P treatment reduced schosome levels 1– with egg rate 99% and cure 92%. This was comparable efficacy P in 6– olds where was 96 and 67. P is safe and efficacious in 1– olds as in 6 olds whom is drug for sch control.
A genome-wide RNAi screen in Drosophila identifies Tetrasin 29b as an evolutionarily conserved suppressor of Ras-driven epithelial tumorigenesis. Ras oncogenic mutations in the GTPase contribute to ~30% of human cancers, but are insufficient for tumorigenesis. Therefore, it is paramount to identify cooperating cancer-relevant signaling pathways. We devised an in vivo genome-wide RNAi screen in Drosila and discovered multiple evolutionarily conserved pathways controlling Ras-driven epithelial tumenesis. Human orthologs of the hits were significantly downregulated in thousands of primary tumors, revealing novel prognostic markers for epithelial tumors. Of the top 100 candidate suppressor genes, 80 were validated in secondary Drosila, identifying known and novel genes that cooperate with Ras-driven tumenesis. Low expression of the hits significantly correlated with KRAS12 status and poor prognosis in pancreatic cancer.
Meiotic drivers are selfish alleles that subvert meiosis to increase their transmission into progeny at the expense of the rest of the genome. In Schizosaccharomyce pombe, we discovered that wtf13 is a meiotic driver that kills spores that do not inherit it by generating a diffusible poison and spore-specific antidote. We show that w13 is suppressed by another w gene, wtf-2, that arose in the lab and only makes antidote. w-2 does not indiscriminately prevent spore destruction, instead rescuing only spores that inherit w-2. This establishes a novel paradigm for meiotic suppressors and provides insight into mechanisms of drive systems.
Genome-wide association studies have identified many genetic variants that are correlated with gene expression changes across individuals. However, the ability of these variants to predict expression in unseen individuals has rarely been evaluated. We present an algorithm that predicts expression of genes in unseen individuals given their genotype in the genomic vicinity of the gene, using training and expression data from a set of individuals. The predictions are remarkably robust and agree between training and test sets, even when the sets consist of individuals from distinct populations. The number of genes that can be predicted is relatively small, as we ignore effects such as environmental and sequence variation. The robustness of predictions means that the identity and degree of genes that can be predicted in advance is known. We also present an extension that incorporates different types of genomic annotations to weigh the importance of variants. Assigning higher weights to variants with annotations such as proximity to genes and high GC content improves predictions. Genes that are successfully predicted have higher expression and variability across individuals, providing insight into characteristics of genes that can be predicted from cis variation.
Plasmodium falciparum infections are genetically diverse, leading to competitive interactions between parasite strains. This study investigates the cause of competitive suppression of an avirulent Plasmodium falciparum clone (AS) by a virulent clone (AJ) in immunocompetent and immunodeficient mice. We use dynamical based Bayesian inference to test whether suppression is caused by clone-specific differences in one of the following processes: adaptive clearance of meroites and parasitised red blood cells (RBCs), loss of meroites and parasised RBCs, RBC preference, R infection rate, burst size, and within-R interference. These processes are parameterised in dynamical mathematical models and fitted to experimental data. We find that just one parameter, the ratio of loss rate of meroites to invasion of mature RBCs, needs to be clone-specific to predict data. This parameter is the same for both clones in single infections but different between clones in mixed infections. The size of difference is largest in immunocompet mice and smallest in immunodef. This explains why suppression is alleviated in immunodef mice. We find that suppression acts early in infection, even before day of parasitaemia.
DNA replication errors are a major driver of evolutionary changes in the genome, from single nucleotide polymorphisms to large copy number variations (CNVs). Here, we propose a replication-based model to explain the generation of interstitial inverted duplications. The model—Origin-Dependent Inverted-Repeat Amplification ( ODIR )—proposes that replication at short, interrupted, inverted repeats in genomic sequences generates an extrachromosomal, dimeric, autonomously replicating intermediate; subsequent integration of dimer yields CN without loss of distal chromosomal sequences. We tested the feasibility of the proposed error and its consequences on chromosome in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. In vitro, we show that ligation of leading and lagging strands to “closed forks” can occur at short, inverted repeats. Removal of molecules with closed forks results in hairpin duplex that replicates in vivo to create dimer plasmid that integrates into genome by homologous recombination, creating inverted. Our model can explain generation of human, de novo invertedamplicons with 2:1 mixture of sequences from homologues—a feature by plasm intermediate from one homologue integrates into other prior meiosis.
Influenza virus infection in mammalian cells can initiate translation at non-canonical start codons in response to stressful stimuli. Recent studies suggest that viral infection and anti-viral responses alter translation initiation sites and lead to novel epitope production. Here, we investigate the extent and impact of alternate initiation in cells infected with influenza. We show that selection against non-canonical initiation at CUG codons in influenza lineages adapted to mammalian hosts. We use ribosome profiling with lactimidycin to delineate initiation sites in human epithelial cells infected with influenza. We identify candidate alternate initiation sites in influenza mRNAs, all at AUG codons downstream canonical. One candidate truncates 14 amino acids N-terminus N neuraminidase, resulting in loss cytoplasmic tail and transmembrane domain. This truncated neuraminase is expressed on surface during infection, enzymatic and conserved in N1 line. We do not detect higher alternate initiation host transcripts upon infection or antiiral response, but subset induced by antiiral is enriched alternate.
Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (E. coli ) is a foodborne pathogen that causes severe diarrhea and potentially fatal hemolytic uremic syndrome. E. coli and other enteric pathogens utilize a type III secretion system ( TSS ) to inject virulence effectors into host cells. In this study, we present evidence that E. coli O157:H7 Nle1 and N2 genes encode TSS effectors that bind human ribosomal protein 3 ( R3 ), a subunit of nuclear factor kappa-light-enhancer activated B ( NF-κ ) transcription complexes. N1 and N2 localize with R3 in cytoplasm but not nuclei. The N-terminal of N1 and N2 binds to N-terminus of R3. N1 and N2 are autophosphorylated Ser/Thr kinases but binding to R3 is independent of kinase activity. N1 but not N2 reduces nuclear R3 abundance without affecting p or p65 NF-κ subunits or phosphorylation/abundance of inhibitory NFκ chaperoneα N1 represses transcription of R3/NF-dependent reporter but not R3-independent. In contrast N2 stimulates R3 transcription as well as AP-dependent. We identified region N1 (40-45 ) responsible for inhibitory activity toward R3. Deleting N from E. O:H produced hypervulent phenotype in gnotic pig model Shiga toxin E infection.
Transcription factor (TF) binding to its target DNA is a fundamental regulatory interaction. The most common model used to represent TF binding specificities is the position specific scoring matrix (PM), which assumes independence between binding positions. However, in many cases this simplifying assumption does not hold. Here, we present feature models (FMs), a novel probabilistic method modeling TF–DNA interactions based on log-linear models. Our approach uses features to represent TF specificities, where each may span multiple positions. We develop the formulation of our model and devise an algorithm for learning structural features from binding data. We also develop a discriminative finder which discovers de novo Ms enriched in sets compared to background sets. We evaluate on synthetic and the widely used chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) dataset of Harison et al. We then our algorithm to high-throughput TFIP from mouse and human, reveal features present in specificities and show Ms explain better thanMs.
Adrenergic αC receptor 2 (AD2C ) is an inhibitory modulator of the sympathetic nervous system. Mice lacking this gene show physiological and behavioral alterations associated with the fight-or-flight response. We find that AD2 expression is lower in humans and chimpanzees than in other primates. On the basis of three-dimensional chromatin structure, we identified a cis-regulatory region whose sequences have been accelerated in humans and chimpanze. This region has active histone marks in rhes macaque but repressive marks in human and chimpanzee. This region contains neuron-restrictive silencer (NRS ) motifs, each harbouring a polymorphism. Our genotyping of population data indicate that both polymorphic alleles have reached fixation in humans and chimpanze but not bonob, whereas the ancestral allele is present in macaque. CRISPR/C9 genome and reporter assays show that derived alleles repress AD2, likely by increasing NRS binding. In addition, we detected signatures of positive selection for lower AD2 in humans. Our findings indicate that there has been selective pressure for enhanced sympathetic activity in humans and chimpanze.
C4 photosynthesis is one of the most remarkable examples of convergent evolution in plants, with at least 60 independent origins in monocotyledons and dicotyled species. It is associated with a 50% increase in productivity in tropical and subtropical areas. We developed a new informatics framework to compare gene expression in species lacking reference genomes. We compared gene expression in two C4 lineages ( Cleomeynandra and Zea mays ) that diverged ∼140 million years ago. We identified 3, 335 conserved genes in leaf and photosynthetic development. We show that C cycle genes are recruited into photosynthesis networks. Despite independent origins, we report homologous transcription factors induce C photosynthesis and specific expression. We define a molecular signature shared by angiosperms derived from common ancestor. We show that deep comparisons can reveal insight into complex phenotypes and evolution of transactors underpinning C photosynthesis.
During the 2013–2016 Ebola virus (EBOV) epidemic in West Africa, the virus spread to Europe and North America, infecting several Health Care Workers (HC). To develop new countermeasures and understand EBO infection in different body compartments, we longitudinally explored EBO-specific negative sense RNA (neg-RNA) and positive RNA (posRNA), including replication (intermediate-RNA) and messenger (mRNA) molecules in upper and lower respiratory tract compared to plasma in HC infected with EBO in Sierra Leone, hospitalized at the National Institute for Infectious Diseases “Lazz Spallani” (INMI), Rome, Italy. We observed posRNA and negRNA in longitudinally collected lower respiratory specimens after viral clearance from plasma, suggesting local replication.
Hemorrhagic fever (BHF) and Argentine hemorrhagic fever (AHF) are caused by Machupo virus (MAC) and Jun virus (JUN), respectively. We previously reported that a recombinant chimericMAC (rMAC/Cd1-G) expressing glycoprotein from the Candid1 (Cd1) strain of JUN is attenuated in a murine model and protects from lethal challenge with MAC. Here, we investigated the role of different domains of Cd1 glycoprotein (G) in attenuation of MAC. We rescued rMAC expressing the ectodomain of G from Cd1 alone (MC1), with the transmembrane domain (TMD) F438 substitution (MC2), or the TMD of Cd1 (3). All rMAC exhibited similar growth in cultured cells. In mice, MC1 displayed significant reduction in lethality compared to rMAC. MC1 was detected in brains and spleens of MC-infected mice and was associated with inflammation. On the other hand, all survived MC2 and MC3 infection without detectable virus in organs while producing neutralizing Cd1 antibody. Our data suggest the indispensable role of each G domain in full attenuation and immunogenicity of rMAC/Cd1G.
Mutations in the centromere histone CEN3 induce postzygotic lethality and uniparental inheritance. The centrom histone CEN3 is essential for the segregation of sister chromatids during mitosis and meiosis. To define the functional constraints of CEN3, we complemented a null allele in Arabidopsis with a variety of mutant alleles, each inducing a single amino acid change in the conserved residues of the histone domain. Many of these transgenic lines displayed wild-type growth and fertility on self-poll, but exhibited postzyotic death unipal inheritance when crossed with wild-type. The failure of centrom marked by these mutations in the histone domain of C3 reproduces the genome syndromes with chimer C3 and C3 from diverged.
Alternative splicing plays a crucial role in the differentiation of human embryonic stem cells (hESCs) into cardiac precursors. The role of alternative splicing in self-renew, pluripotency, and lineage specification of hESCs is largely unknown. We modified the H9 hESC line to allow selection of pluripotent hES by neomycin resistance and cardiac progenitors by puromycin. Exon microarray expression data from undifferentiated hES and cardiac precursors were used to identify isoforms with cardiac-restricted or common/neural differentiation patterns. Splice events corresponded to cytoskeletal, RNA, muscle, and cell cycle control as well as ser/threon kinase and helicase. Using AltAnalyze, we identified changes in protein and microRNA binding architecture that affect function and expression. These included isoforms that oppose cell arrest in hES and promote signaling and development in prec. Our data suggest mechanisms that may influence commitment and maintenance at the level of isoforms and regulation.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis (M. tuberculosis ) is a major human pathogen for which causes tuberculosis (TB). Trehalose biosynthesis is considered an attractive target for the development of antimicrobials against M. The most biosynthetic route involves trehal-6-phosphate (TP) synthase A and TP phosphatase B that generate trehalose from AD/UDP-glucose and glucose-6-phosphate. In order to assess the drug potential of TP phosphat, we generated a conditional mutant of M allowing regulated silencing of the TP phosphat gene B. We found that B is essential for growth of M in vitro as well as the acute phase in mice following aerosol infection. By contrast, B is not essential for chronic phase mice, highlighting remodelling of trehal metabolism by M. Blocking B resulted in accumulation of TP, which appears to be toxic leading to self-poison of cells. Accordingly, blocking TP in ΔA mutant abrogated B essentiality. TP accumulation elicited upregulation of more than 800 genes which might result from increase in RNA stability by neutralization of ribonuclease activity. Surprisingly, overlap with stress caused by accumulation another sugar molecule maltose-phosphate was minimal.
Trypanosoma cruzi is a protozoan parasite responsible for Chagas disease, a life-threatening illness affecting 11–18 million people. Current treatments have limited efficacy and safety profiles. Recent studies have identified T cruzi proline racemase ( TPR ) as a candidate for chemotherapeutic intervention. Conformation changes associated with substrate binding to TPR are believed to expose residues eliciting a mitogenic host-cell response, contributing to parasite persistence and immune evasion. Characterization of TPR conformation states requires long-time motions currently inaccessible by standard simulations. We describe accelerated molecular dynamics that extend simulation time and capture large motions of relevance. Conservation and fragment analyses identified conformation epitopes in vicinity of transient binding pockets. Newly identified TPR conformations revealed along with knowledge of interconversion mechanism advance understanding of TPR function.
Inducible and reversible gene expression is a powerful approach for uncovering gene function. We have established a method to efficiently produce reversible and inducible knockout (iKO) and rescue in mice. The system, named iKO, allows the target gene to be turned on and off by treating mice with doxycycline. This method combines two genetically modified mouse lines: a) a KO line with tetracycline-dependent transactivator replacing the endogenous target, and b) a line with tetrcline-inducible cDNA of target inserted into tightly regulated (TRE) genomic locus, providing low expression and high inducibility. This locus occurs infrequently in the genome. We developed a method to introduce genes into TRE of mouse embryonic stem (ES) cells by recombinase-mediated insertion. Both KO and TRE lines have been engineered for high-throughput, large and cost-effective production of iKO mice. As proof of concept, we created iKO in apolipoprotein (apoE) gene, allowing sensitive and quantitative phenotypic analyses. Results demonstrated reversible apo transcription, plasma levels, atherosclerosis, and regression.
Trypanosoma cruzi is a parasite that causes Chagas disease and can be transmitted congenitally from mother to offspring. Little is known about the genetic response of the placenta to this infection. We studied the response of the placenta in mice infected with two strains of T. cruzi: K98, a non-lethal strain, and V, isolated from a human congenital case. We analyzed the placenta of infected and uninfected mice by microarray to see which genes were differentially expressed. We found that the “secretory granule” pathway was downregulated in both groups, but “inmate response” and “to interferon gamma” were upregulated in V but not K. We also found that metabolic processes and macromolecular transport were downregulated in infected placentas and some signaling pathways had opposite regulation: overpresent in V and downregulated K. We found that V had stronger tropism to the placenta by detection of parasite DNA and RNA. Our study is the first to describe the genetic response of placenta to T. cruz in mice and suggests a strong parasite-dependent immune response to detriment of cellular metabolism that may prevent congenital transmission.
Sindbis virus (SINV) is a mosquito-borne virus that causes polyarthritis and rash. It was first recognised in northern Europe about 50 years ago and is known as Ockbo disease in Sweden and Pog disease in Finland. SINV is mainly occurs in tropical and sub-tropical countries, and in Europe it is suggested to cause regularly recurring outbreaks. Here, we evaluated mosquito and SINV prevalence in vectors from an endemic area in Sweden. Mosquitoes were collected in the Riveräl floodplains before, during, and after the hypothesised 2002 year outbreak and assayed for virus on cell. Obtained isolates were partially sequenced, and nucleotide sequences were analysed using Bayesian clade and median network. Only SINV was recovered in 200, and 4 in 200, while 15 were recovered in 200 with increased infection rates in both enzotic and bridgeectors. In 200, Maximum Likelihood infection rates were 10.0/100 in enotic Cx torrent/piens and 0.62/100 in bridge A cinus compared 4.9/100 and 0.0/100 in200 and 0.0/100 and.0/100 in200 Sequence showed all belonged to SINV-I. Genetic analysis revealed four S-Iades in Riveräl over years.
In the locust olfactory system, neural circuits transform odor information from the antennal lobe (AL) into a sparse representation in the mushroom body (MB), a region associated with memory. We investigated the interaction of multiple coding mechanisms in this system. In vivo recordings from the MB demonstrated highly specific responses to odors in Kenyon cells (KCs). Typically, only a few Cs from the recorded population responded reliably to a specific odor. Different odors induced different responses in Cs. We explored the possibility that synaptic plasticity controls the specificity of Cs responses to familiar odors. We found that plasticity at AL-MB synapses efficiently regulated the delicate tuning to selectively filter the AL output and condense to a sparse in MB. Activity-dependent plasticity drove the specificity, reliability, and persistence of odor representations. This suggests a role for plasticity in processing and making testable predictions about plasticity at AL-MB synapses.
The Stockholm Atherosclerosis Gene (ST) study aimed to identify functionally important genes for the development of coronary artery disease (CAD) by analyzing transcriptional profiles of liver, skeletal muscle, visceral fat, and atherosclerotic and unaffected arterial wall tissues from patients undergoing coronary artery bypass surgery. Using two-way clustering, a total of 60 clusters (395 genes ) were identified from 15,042 mRNA signals in each tissue. In the second step, atherosclerotic and visceral clusters segregated patients into two groups differing in coronary stenosis extent (P=0.008 and P=0.000 ). Associations with atherosclerosis were validated by carotid expression profiles. Remarkably, one cluster relating caridosis (P=0.04 ) and 27 genes relating coronaryenosis were confirmed (P<−27−10−30 ). Genes in transendothelial migration leukocytes (TE) were overrepresented in all atherosclerosis clusters, referred to as A-module. In a second step, A was found enriched in CAD by 1.8-fold (P0.004 ) in three independent cohorts. The co-factor LIM binding 2 (L2) was identified as potential regulator of A, supported by subnetwork, cellular and expression of L2, and expression of 13 TE genes in L2–deficient wall. Thus, A appears important for atherosclerosis, with L merits further CAD research.
In the circadian clock of the cyanobacterium Synechocystis, the KaiC protein plays a central role in the regulation of the circadian rhythm. Our studies have shown that KaiC is involved in both the activation and repression of its own transcription. During the 24 hours, KaiC undergoes different phosphorylation states during the day. It has remained unclear which phosphorylation state of KaiC promotes kai expression and opposes transcriptional activation. We have systematically analyzed various combinations of positive and negative transcriptional regulation by introducing a combined transcriptional/translational feedback loop (TT/PT) model that considers all four phosphorylation states of Kai and transcriptional/translational feedback. Only one particular two-loop mechanism out of 32 tested is able to reproduce experimental observations, including effects of knockout or overexpression of kai genes. Here, threonine and phosphorylated Kai hexamers activate unphosphorylated Kaiam suppress kai transcription.
