Our simulations suggest that the peak ratio of positive and negative components of kai expression is the factor for how two-loop models respond to removal or overexpression of k genes.
Human immunodeficiency virus type 2 (HIV-2) has a low pathogenic and replicative potential compared to HIV-1. We investigated whether HIV-2 reservoirs follow the same distribution as HIV-1/SIV infections, i. e. limited infection of central-memory CD4 T lymphocytes (TCM). Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) were sorted into monocytes and CD T-cell subsets (naive, central, transitional, effector-memory ). HIV-DNA was quantified by real-time PCR. HIV-DNA was undetectable in monocytes from all individuals and quantifiable in transitional-memory (TM) cells from 4 individuals (median:2.25×10^6 cells) but in central-memory (TCM) from only 1 individual (1.75×10^6). HIVDNA in PBMC (median:1.94×10^6) correlated with TM (r=0.66,p=0.01) but not TC. HIV-activation was observed in cells from only 3 individuals. The CCR5 co-receptor was similarly distributed in populations from individuals and donors.TC had lower expression of CX6 transcripts (p=0.002) than TM and higher of TR5 (p=0.004). Thus HIV-2 reservoirs differ from HIV-1 by lack of monocytic infection and limited TC associated with lower expression of CX6 and higher of TR5.
Visual attention is known to modulate the activity and selectivity of cortical neurons. However, spiking neuron models that can reproduce a wide range of these effects remain elusive. We present the Attention Routing Circuit (ARC) model, a mechanistic description of selective attention processing in cortex. The model is mathematically implemented at the level of spiking neurons, with computations for selective attention mapped to specific neuron types and laminar circuit. The model is used to simulate studies in macaque and is shown to quantitatively match several forms of attentional modulation. Specifically, ARC demonstrates that shifts of attention may exhibit shrinking of receptive fields, increases in responses without changes in selectivity for non-spatial features ( i. e. response gain ), and that the effect on contrast functions is better explained as response-gain than contrast-gain. Unlike past models, ARC embodies a single mechanism unifying forms of attention modulation, consistent with a wide of available data and makes specific quantifiable predictions.
Atrial fibrillation (AF) is the most common sustained cardiac arrhythmia in humans. AF is a complex and multifactorial disease, and genetic factors are thought to contribute to susceptibility. However, the contribution of coding variation to AF remains poorly understood. We performed whole exome sequencing in a large sample of 1, 734 individuals with AF and 9, 423 without AF from the Framingham Heart Study, Cardio Health, Atherosclerosis in Communities, and NHLBI Exome Sequencing Project. We also examined genetic variation in 37 suspected AF genes in cases versus controls. The mean age ranged from 59 to 73; 8, 656 (78 ) were European. None of 99, 404 common variants was associated with AF after adjusting for multiple testing. The most associated variant was a common missense in SYN2 (rs3819, pPro707,odds 1.27, CI 1.13–1.43, P.6x10-5 ) at a known AF locus and in linkage disequilibrium with a marker from prior analyses. We did not observe associations between rare variants and AF in gene-based tests. Individuals with AF did not display significant enrichment for common or rare variation in previously implicated genes. We did not observe associations between coding variants and AF, suggesting large-effect variation is not predominant underlying AF. A variant in SYN2 requires further evaluation to determine causality to AF. Efforts to identify biologically meaningful variation underlying AF may require large samples or populations with large effects.
Between 1990 and 2011, a total of 121 human cases of alveolar echinoccosis (AE) caused by Echinoccus multilocis were detected in Poland. The cases were verified by clinical, epidemiological, and laboratory criteria. Among them, 83 ( 68. 6% ) were classified as confirmed, 16 as probable and 22 as possible. During the two decades, a continuous increase in detection rate was noticed. The mean age at diagnosis was 47.7 years and sex ratio M/F was 0.86/1. AE was fatal in 23 ( 19% ) patients with mean age at death 54.1 years. The disease was found in 4 foci involving 9 patients. Seventy of the cases were diagnosed in an advanced stage. In all cases the liver was the primary location of AE. In 30 ( 24.8 ) patients spread to other organs was observed. Ninety of patients were treated with albendazole. In 73 ( 60 ) a surgical operation was performed, including 15 transplantations.
Zinc homeostasis is essential for the survival of both beneficial and pathogenic microorganisms. To understand how microorganisms respond to dynamic changes in zinc availability, we investigated the molecular mechanism of the zinc-sensing zinc uptake regulator (Zur) in Escheria coli. We solved the structure of zinc-loaded Zur bound to the PnuABC promoter and found that this metalloregulatory protein represses gene expression by cooperative binding of two dimers to the core element of each Zur-regulated promoters. This cooperativity requires a pair of salt bridges between Arg52 and Asp′ that connect independent dimers. The protein-DNA interface led to the discovery of a new Zur-regulated gene, pliG, which is directly regulated by Zur in a zinc-dependent manner. The plG promoter forms complexes with either one or two dimers with less cooperativity than other Zur-reg promoters. We compared in vitro Zur-DNA binding at each Zur-reg promoters and found a 10,000-fold variation in ZurNA constants. The degree of repression in vivo parallels this trend, with a 100-fold difference in transcript copy number between wild-type and Δur strains. We conclude that the number of Fur dimers that bind any promoter varies and the thermodynamic profile of Zur-D interactions correlates with physiological response at different promoters.
Rift Valley fever (RV) is a vector-borne zoonotic disease that causes high morbidity and mortality in ruminants. In 2008–2009, RV affected the whole island of Madagascar, including Anzobe district in the highlands. Entomological survey showed absence ofedes among potential RV virus (RV) vector species in this area and overall low mosquito abundance due to unfavorable climatic conditions during winter. No serological nor virological sign of infection was observed in wild terrestrial mammals, suggesting absence of RV virus (RV) reservoir. However, three serological virological follow-up in cattle showed recurrent RVV circulation. This study aimed to understand key determinants of this recurrent transmission. A spatial deterministic discrete metapulation model combined with cattle network was designed to reproduce local conditions using observational data. Three scenarios explained RVV circulation: (i) RV overwintering thanks to direct transmission between vemic cows, vectors absent during winter, (ii) low vector circulation thanks residual population without direct transmission, (iii) combination both. Multi-model methods resulted in incorporating low RV winter-borne transmission and direct between animals. Predictions satisfactorily reproduced field, 84% infections attributed to vectororne, 16 to direct. These appeared robust sensitivity analysis.
The Asian tiger mosquito, Aedes albopictus, is an invasive and aggressive daytime-biting mosquito species that is a major public health threat throughout its expanding range. We used 13 microsatellite loci on 911 individuals and mitochondrial COI sequences to gain a better understanding of the historical and contemporary movements of Ae. albictus in the Indo-Pacific region and characterize its population. Our results show that Ae.ictus was most likely introduced to New Guinea via mainland Asia before colonizing the Solomon Islands via Papua New Guinea or Asia. We also show that the recent incursion into northern Australia’s Torres Islands was seeded from Indonesia. For the first time in this species, we provide evidence of a recently colonized population in the Torres Islands that has undergone rapid changes in its genetic makeup. This could be the result of genetic drift or represent a secondary invasion from an unknown source. There is high genetic structure and gene flow between geographically distant populations. The species’ structure in the region tends to be driven by human movements.
Infection with Schistosoma mansoni has a negative impact on quality of life, but not physical fitness in schoolchildren in Mwan Region, North-West Tanzania: A Cross-Section Study. Infection with Schistoma mans negatively affects children’s health and may influence their general well-being. The aim of this study was to investigate the effect of S mans infections on morbidity with emphasis on quality of life (PQL) measured in four dimensions and physical (VO2max) among 572 schoolchildren aged 7–8. Prevalence S mans was 58.7% with an arithmetic mean (95% CI) among positives 207.3 (169.–245.4) epg. Most were light 56.5% while 16.4 had heavy infections. Girls had higher mean intensities (95 CI) than boys 247.4 (189–305.2) vs 153. (110–195.6); P.004. A total 30.1 were anaemic with no difference. Stunting and wasting found less than 10% population. There was no association mans prevalence intens and parameters: anthropometry, anaemia, or spleen pathology neither univar nor multivar analyses. However, analyses children mans had lower score PQL (95 CI) than uninfected 77.3 (74–80.1) vs82. (79–85.5); P.033 and had higher VOmax (95) compared uninf 51.4 (51–51.8) vs.50 (50–51.3);.042 In multivar analyses, age, mans, haemoglobin and VOmax were predictors PQL while predictors VOmax were PQL, height and haem mans was not retained analyses VOmax.
Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by the spiroch Leptira. The main reservoirs of Leptira are wild rodents, such as the brown rat (Rattus norvegicus ), which present asymptomatic infection. Experimental studies of Leptira colonization in rats have used intraperitoneal inoculation. However, knowledge of ratat transmission requires a natural inoculation route, such as mucosal or subcutaneous. We investigated the effects of subcutaneous and mucosal inoculation compared to intraperinal Leptira infection in adult rats. Infection was studied using Leptira isolation, serology, and histological analyses. Leptira was asymptomatic in each inoculation and caused similar antibody production regardless of colonization. Renal colonization rates were 8/8, 5/8, and 1/8 for intraper, mucosal subaneous and subcut inoculation, respectively. Mucosal inoc was more efficient for renal colonization with urinary excretion than subcut and induced slower infection than intraper.
Seps is a life-threatening disease characterized by excessive inflammation, tissue injury, and organ dysfunction. Currently, there are limited therapeutic options for this disease, so understanding the molecular mechanisms of seps may help develop effective treatments. Here, we identify a novel role for Annexin A2 ( AnxA ), a multifunctional protein, in modulating inflammatory response during seps. In polymicrobial sepsis models, AnxA-/- mice showed increased inflammatory cytokines and neutrophil infiltration, but decreased bacterial clearance and survival. In addition, AnxA deficiency led to increased ROS and IL-17. Using site-directed mutagenesis, we found that cystine 9 of AnxA was the most important site for ROS regulation. Furthermore, ROS appears to be responsible for elevated IL-17 and subsequent inflammatory response. Depletion of IL via CRISPR/Cas KO downregulated inflammation and conferred protection against seps in An-/- mice. Our findings reveal a previously unknown function for AnxA in inflammatory response polymicrobial se models via AnxA-IL-17 axis, providing insight into pathophysiology of seps.
HIV-1 infection of macrophages plays a key role in viral pathogenesis and progression to AIDS. Polyinosine-polycidylic acid ( poly I:C ), a synthetic analog of dsRNA, and lipopolysaccharide ( LPS ), ligands for Toll-like receptors TLR3 and TLR4, respectively, are known to decrease HIV-1 infection in monocyte-derived macrophages ( MDM ). We found that poly I:C and L-stimulation of MMs abrogated infection by CCR-using macrophage-tropic HIV and vesicular stomatitis glycoprotein-pseudyped HIV-1 virions, while TLR TLR or TLR agonists only reduced infection to varying extent. Suppression of infection did not correlate with differential effects on CD or CCR expression, type interferon induction, or pro-inflammatory cytokine production. Integrated viruses were detected in unstimulated TLR and T9-stimulated cells, but in TLR or T4-stimulated MMs, suggesting alteration of post-entry preintegration events. We found increased microRNA mi-155 levels in M upon TLR4 but not T-stimulation, and mi-155 inhibitor partially restored infectivity in poly I-stimulated MMs. Ectopic mi-155 diminished HIV-1 in primary M and cell lines. Furthermore, poly I-stimulation and mi- expression did not alter early RT products but resulted in accumulation of late products and undetectable or low levels of integrated viruses and 2TR circles. Reduced mRNA and protein levels of HIV factors involved in trafficking/import preintegration (AD10, TN3,up, N153 LED/p75 ) were in I-stimulated mi-trans M, and reporter suggested authentic mi targets.
Most organisms use daily light/dark cycles to control many physiological processes. In plants, growth of the embryonic stem ( hypocotyl ) is maximal at different times of the day, depending on external photoper and internal circadian. However, the interactions between light, circadian, and growth-promoting hormone in growth remain poorly understood. To determine the transcriptional component of rhythmic growth, we analyzed the Arabidopsis thaliana seedling transcriptome under multiple conditions and backgrounds. We show that a group of hormone-associated genes are coexpress at the time when hypocyl growth is maximal. This correlates with overrepresentation of cis-acting (CAT ) in hormone promoters, which is sufficient to confer diurnal and circadian patterns in vivo. Using circadian and signaling mutants, we show that both internal hormone capacity and coincidence with darkness are required for wild-type growth. We argue that the circadian controls growth by permissive of hormone levels to the time of day.
Genetically modifying the gut microbiota of the insect vector Rhodnius prolixus to control Chagas disease may be achieved through systemic RNA interference (RNAi) technologies. Here, we used Escherichia coli HT115(DE3) expressing dsRNA for the Rhodni heme-binding protein (RHBP) and catalase (CAT) to modify the gut microbiota of nymph and adult stages. RHBP is an egg protein and CAT an antioxidant expressed in all tissues by developmental stages. The RNA interference was systemic and temporal. Concentrations of E. coli115(DE) above 3.35 × 10^7 CFU/mL produced significant RHBP and CAT knockdown in nymphs and adults. RH expression in the body was reduced by 99% three days after feeding, returning to normal levels 10 days after. CAT expression was reduced 99% and 96% in ovary and posteriorgut, respectively, five days after ingestion. Mortality increased 24-30% in first instars fed RHBP and CAT. Molting were reduced 100% first and 80 third instars fed bacteria RHBP or CATRNA. Oviposition reduced 43% RH and 84% CAT. Embogenesis arrested 16% RH and 20% laid. Feeding 105 CF/mL natural symbion Rhodoccus rhodii transformed to express RHBP hairpin RNA reduced RH expression 89 and oviposition.
Malaria was the leading cause of death in pregnant women in refugee camps on the Thai-Burmese border in the 1980s. However, with the introduction of artemisinin combination therapy, the incidence of malaria in the population has significantly decreased. Despite this, the causes of fever in pregnancy are not well documented. Pregnant women attending antenatal clinics, where screening for malaria is routine, were invited to have a comprehensive clinical and laboratory screen if they had fever. Fever occurred in 5. 0% (409 ) of pregnant women attending anten clinics from January 2004 to May 2006. Malaria was the cause in 55.5% (227 ) of febrile episodes. A cohort of 203 women had detailed investigations and follow up. Arthrop-borne diseases, ricketial infections, dengue and zoonotic leptpirosis accounted for nearly half of febr illnesses, 47.3 (96 ). Coinfection was observed 3.9 (8 ) of women, mostly malaria ricketia. Pyonephritis 19.7 (40 ) was also a common cause of fever. Once malaria pyoneph and respiratory illness were excluded by microscopy/or clinical findings, one-third of febr infections were caused by ricketia or leptpi. Scrub murine typhus was associated with poor outcomes including stillbirth and low birth weight.
Recombination is the process by which genetic material is exchanged between homologous chromosomes during meiosis. In humans, recombination has been associated with aneuploidy. Here, we examine the relationship between maternal age and recombination in humans. We used a panel of 69 French-Canadian pedigrees genotyped with over 600, 000 markers to localize recombination events in 195 maternal meios. We observed a general pattern of variation in fine-scale recombination rates previously reported in humans. However, we found a significant decrease in recombination with advancing maternal age in humans. This effect appears to be chromosome-specific and localized to the middle of chromosomal arms and subtelomeric regions. We propose that for some chromosomes, protection against non-disjunction provided by recombination becomes less efficient with advancing maternal age, contributing to higher aneuploidy in older women.
Cryptocococcus neoformans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that causes disease in immunocompromised patients. Vaccines against this pathogen are difficult to develop as most patients at risk of disease are deficient in adaptive immunity. Here, we describe an experimental strategy to induce innate immunity in macrophages in vivo. Unlike current models of trained immunity, we present an innate-like phenotype in macrophages that is maintained for at least 70 days post-immunization and results in complete protection against secondary challenge in the absence of adaptive cells. Macrophages were primed with IF-γ in vivo and challenged with C. neoans 70 days later. RNA-seq analysis revealed upregulation of IF-γ and STAT1 pathways following challenge. Enhanced cytokine responses were pathogen-dependent and correlated with increased STAT binding to promoter regions of genes associated with anti-fungal immunity. Thus, we demonstrate an alternative to induce macroage innate immunity in vivo that facilitates pathogen-specific vaccine responses.
Polycomb repressive complexes (PCs) are involved in transcriptional regulation and developmental processes in both plants and animals. In Arabidopsis thaliana (Arabidopsis), depletion of different members of PC causes both overlapping and unique phenotypic defects. Here, we show that CURLY LEAF (CL), a catalytic subunit of PC2, coordinates with members of PC1 in suppression of distinct developmental programs. We found that expression of flower development genes is repressed in seedlings preferentially via non-redund role of CL, which is associated with LIKE HETCHROMATIN PROTEIN1 (LHP). In contrast, expression of embryo development is repressed by PC-catalytic subunits AtBMI and AtRING in common with PC-catalytic CL or SWINGER (SW).
The RNA polymerase II is a multisubunit enzyme that plays a central role in eukaryotic transcription. It has a trigger loop ( TL ) that is involved in substrate selection, catalysis, and translocation. To understand the structure and function of TL in Saccharomyces cerevisiae RNA polymerase II, we quantitatively phenotyped nearly all TL variants at the individual residue level. We found three classes of mutants with distinct phenotypes linked to transcription defects or stress. Mutations in the intra-TL hydrophobic pocket, proposed to provide a mechanism for substrate-trigger TL folding through destabilization of the catalytically inactive state, conferred phenotypes consistent with pocket disruption and catalysis. Furthermore, allele-specific interactions among TL and TL-proimal residues support the contribution of the funnel and bridge helices ( BH ) to TL dynamics.
Rabies virus (RV) infections are usually caused by bites or scratches from rabid carnivores or bats. The virus spreads to the central nervous system (CNS) via retrograde transport within the neuronal network, replicating in neuronal somata and infecting other neurons via transynaptic spread. We speculate that in addition to neuronal transport, hematogenous spread from the site of infection to the brain might represent an alternative way for RV to invade the CNS. To determine whether RV variants can invade the CNS from the periphery via hematogenously, we infected mice intramuscularly (i. m. ) or intravenously ( i. v ) with dog-associated DOG or silver bat-associated SB. We monitored the progression of clinical signs of rabies and followed the spread of virus from infection to brain using immunohistochemistry and quantitative reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). In contrast to i. m. infection, both variants caused lethal encephalopathy, only i. v infection with SB resulted in lethal infection. RT-PCR did not reveal differences in virus loads in spinal cord or brain at times after i. m or i. infection of SB. Immunohisto analysis showed only i. administered SB directly infected the brain. The earliest affected regions were hypothalamic nuclei connected by neurosecret fibers to circumventricular neurohypophysis and medianence. Our data suggest hematogenous SB can lead to fatal encephal through direct invasion of CNS at neuro interface of hypothalamus-hypysis.
Since 1918, the H1N1 subtype of the influenza A virus has been responsible for substantial morbidity and mortality in humans, with the most notable being the global pandemic of 1918. However, the evolutionary history of the H1N1 virus is not well understood, particularly the virological basis for several epidemics of unusual severity in the 1940s and 1950s. In this study, we show that segmental reassortment has played an important role in the evolution of H1N1 since 1918. We demonstrate that an H1N1 isolate from 1947 acquired novel PB2 and HA genes through intra-subtype reassortment, which may explain the abrupt antigenic evolution of this virus. Similarly, the 195 influenza epidemic may have been associated with reassort H1N1 viruses. Intra-subtype reassortment appears to be more important in the evolution and epidemiology of HN1 influenza virus than previously realized.
Nicotine acts on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) to stimulate dopamine (DA) release from the ventral tegmental area (VTA), but the mechanism of action is debated: direct stimulation of DA cells through nACh activation or inhibition through desensitization of nA on GABAergic interneurons. We used a computational model of VTA circuitry and nCh function to shed light on this issue. Our model shows that α4β-containing nChRs on DA or GABA cells mediate acute nicotine effects. We account in vitro and in vivo data and predict conditions for direct or inhibition to be origin of DA increases. We propose experiments to disentangle both mechanisms. We show that endogenous acetylcholine crucially determines evoked DA for both mechanisms. Our results delineate mechanisms by which V mediates acute properties of nicotine and suggest acetylcholine hypothesis for nicotine.
Leishmanias is a disfiguring skin disease caused by Leishmania tropica infection. It is often complicated by bacterial and/or fungal infections. We studied a novel concept to prevent superinfections, accelerate wound closure, and improve cosmetic outcome. From 2004 to 2008, we performed a randomized, double-blinded phase II trial in Kabul, Afghanistan. Patients with L. trop CL were treated with high-frequency electrocauterization ( EC ) followed by daily moist-wound-treatment ( MWT ) with polyacrylate hydrogel ( group I ) or without ( II ) pharmaceutical chlorite ( DAC-055 ). Patients below 5, facial lesions, pregnancy, or comorbidities were excluded. The primary outcome was time for complete epithelialization. Biops were taken before EC, after wound closure, and after 6 months. The mean time for wound closure was short in both groups (59.1 d and 54.2; p =0.83 ). DAC-055 caused more rapid epithelial in patients with Leish-positive biops (37.2 vs.58. p=0.08 ). Superfections occurred in both groups (8.8% ). Except one, ulcers (10.2 in I 18.5 II; p=0.158 ) were in cases with persistent parasite after healing. In vitro, DAC-055 showed leishicidal effect on amastigotes. Compared to intraional injections, EC plus M led to rapid closure and lower relapse rate.
RAS is a small GTPase that is one of the most prevalent oncogenes. It transmits proliferative signals in normal and cancer cells through the evolutionarily conserved RAF-MEK-MAP module, which is one of the main conduits downstream of R. Over the last two decades, genetic and biochemical studies have uncovered a small set of factors regulating R/MAP signaling. Most of these were found to control RAF activation, suggesting a central role for this event. However, whether additional factors are required at this level or further remains open. To obtain a comprehensive view of elements functionally linked to R/MK, we conducted a genome-wide RNA screen in Drosila cells for factors impacting R-mediated MAP activation. This led to the identification of 101 validated hits, most of which were previously associated with this pathway. Epasis experiments were carried out on individual candidates to determine their position to core components. This revealed new factors acting at different steps along pathway, including a protein modulating RAF activation. However, most hits work downstream ME and influence MAP expression. These consist of constitutive splicing factors and suggest splicing plays role in establishing MAP levels.
Cryptocococcus neoformans and Cryptococcus gattii are two species of the Cryptococcus neoformans/C gatt complex that cause cryptococcosis in humans and animals. In Thailand, a retrospective study of 498 isolates from clinical, environmental, and veterinary sources was conducted. The majority of the isolates ( 68. 9% ) were from males with a mean age of 37.97 years, and 88.5% of C neoans and 37.5 of gatt were from HIV patients. The majority of the isolates (94.8% ) were C neo molecular type V regardless of source (94.6% clinical, 98.8% environmental and 86.2 veterinary ). In addition, types II (2.4% clinical and 33. veterinary ), IV (0.% environmental ), I (0. clinical ) and II (2. clinical ) were less frequent. Multilocus Sequence Type ( ML ) analysis identified 20 types in Thailand. The isolates are part of the global population with 30 for gii and 82, 83 137 141 172 and 173 for neo being unique. Most gii were ST7VGb, identical to the virulent Vancouver outbreak. The study revealed greater diversity and major types than previously reported.
Transcription factors (TFs) are proteins that regulate gene expression by binding to cis-regulatory elements in the genome. The evolution of cis-regulatory networks is thought to underlie much of the phenotypic variation observed across organisms. We analyzed the evolution of the largest class of metazoan TFs, Cys-His2 zinc finger (CH-ZF) TFs, across 12 Drosophila species spanning ~45 million years. We found that a significant fraction of CH-Z TF 1-1 orthologs in flies exhibit variations that affect their DNA-binding specificities. In addition to loss and gain of CH-Z domains, we found diverging DNA-contact residues in ~44% of domains between D melanaster and other species. These diverging residues, found in ~70% of D melan CH-Z genes and ~26% all melan TFs, show evidence of constraint: conserved across phylogen clades and evolve slower than diverging residues. These variations were rarely found as polymorphisms within D melan flies, indicating rapid fixation. The specificities of these domains change gradually across phylogen distances suggesting stepwise trajectories for TF divergence. Further, proteins with conserved CH domains are enriched in developmental functions, those varying exhibit no enrichments.
Salmonella enterica serotypes Typhi and Paraty A are the causative agents of typhoid and paratyphoid fevers. However, the lack of typing sera and the need for culture in some cases hinders diagnosis. To overcome this, serotype-specific PCR assays are required. However, the sensitivity and specificity of such assays must be demonstrated on large collections of strains representative of the targeted serotypes and other bacterial populations with similar clinical symptoms. We developed a conventional multiplex PCR and EvaGreen-based real-time singleplex assays for detection and differentiation of serotypes Typhi and Paraty A using a new family of repeated DNA sequences, CRIS (clustered regularly interspaced palindromic repeats) as a serotype target. We achieved 100% sensitivity and specificity for each assay after validation on 188 serotype Typhi and 74 ser Paraty A strains from diverse genetic, geographic and time origins and 70 strains of frequently encountered in bloodstream, including 29 Salmonella serotypes and 38 other species.
Leishmaniasis is an intracellular protozoan parasite that causes leishmaniasis in humans. The immune response to this parasite involves the differentiation of IFγ-secreating CD+ T helper 1 (Th1) cells. Notch receptors are known to regulate cell differentiation, but their role in Th1 polarization is not well understood. Here, we investigated the role of Notch in Th1 differentiation following infection with Leishmania major. We generated mice with cell-specific deletion of Notch1 (N1), Notch2 (N2), or both (N1N2CDCre) and infected them with Leish major. Mice lacking both Not1 and Not2 (N2) developed unhealing lesions and uncontrolled parasitemia. This correlated with impaired secretion of IFγ by draining node CD4 T cells and increased secretion of IL-5 and IL-13. In contrast, mice with single deletion of Not1 or Not2 were resistant to infection and developed a Th1 response. We show that Notch is required for IFγ secretion by Th1 cells. This effect is independent of CSL/RBPκ, the major effector of Notch, since mice with deletion of RBPκ in T cells were able to develop IFγ-secre Th and kill parasites. Collectively, we demonstrate a crucial role for RBPκ-independent Notch in Th1 differentiation following Leish infection.
Schistosoma mansoni Infection Increases Susceptibility to Systemic SHIV Clade C Infection in Rhes Macaques after Muc Virus Exposure. Infection with the parasitic worm Schistoma mansoni is common in sub-Saharan Africa, where 10% of the world's population lives and 2/3 of all HIV/AIDS cases occur. We tested the hypothesis that pre-existing infection with this worm increases susceptibility to HIV-1 in a relevant in vivo model. We infected rhesus monkeys with Schistoma mansoni and challenged them with decreasing doses of R-tropic simian immunodeficiency virus (SHIV-C). Systemic infection occurred in parasitized monkeys at doses that remained sub-infectious in normal hosts. The 50% infectious dose of SHIV-C was 17-fold lower in parasitized animals compared to controls (P<0. 001 ). Coinfected animals had higher viral loads than controls (P0.001 ) as well as viral replication in CD4 central cells (0.03 ).
Acetylcholine (ACh) is a key regulator of neural excitability and one of the neurochemical substrates of sleep. We demonstrate in a biophysical model how changes in neural excitability and network structure interact to create three functional regimes: localized, asynchronous, traveling, and synchronous. Our results qualitatively match those observed experimentally. Cortical activity during slow sleep (SWS) differs from that during REM or waking states. During WS there are traveling patterns of activity in cortex; in other states stationary patterns occur. Our model is composed of Hodgkin-Hux type neurons with M-current regulated by ACh. Regulation of ACh can account for dynamical changes between regimes. Reduction of this current recreates reduction in spike-frequency adaptation (SFA) shift from type 2 to type 1 phase response curve (PRC) in presence of A. When S is minimal in waking or REM state high A, patterns are localized and easily pinned by network inhomogeneities. When S is present (decreasing A) traveling of activity arise. Further in A leads high degree of synchrony within waves. We show level A determines network sensitive activity to heterogeneity.
Esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) is a cancer that develops in an inflammatory microenvironment with reduced microbial diversity. We hypothesized that mutations in the Toll-like receptor (TLR) pathway could disrupt innate immune signaling and promote a microenvironment that favors tumenesis. We found that non-synonymous mutations affect the TLR pathway in 25/171 ( 14. 6%, Path p = 8.7x10-5 ) tumors. TLR mutant cases were associated with more proximal tumors and metastatic disease. We validated our findings in an external dataset with non-syn TLR pathway mutations in 33/149 ( 22.1%, Path = 0.05 ) tumors and other tumor exposed microbiomes in COSMIC (10, 318 samples ) including uterine endrioid carcinoma 188/320 (58.8% ) cutaneous melanoma 377/988 (38.2 ) colorectal adenarcin 402/151 (26.5 ) and stomacharcin 151/579 (26.1 ). TLR was most frequently mutated with eleven in 10/171 (5.8 ) E tumors. TLR mutants 439, 570, 703 and 787 had impaired reactivity to lipopolyscharide with reductions in signaling by lucifer assays.
Taste is a critical for animal survival, but the development of taste cells is still largely unknown. We used a novel approach to investigate the molecular regulation of taste development in mice by combining in silico and in vivo analyses. We found that taste receptor molecules (TRMs) colocalized within developing circumvallate papillae (CVP) and used computational analysis to investigate the possibility of a common regulatory network for TRM transcription. We identified Hes as a likely regulatory factor and examined its function in vivo. Expression analyses revealed that decreased nuclear H1 correlated with type II taste cell markers. After E18, the VP of H1−/− mutants displayed 5-fold more TRM-immunactive cells than the VP of wild-type littermates. Our analyses suggest that H1 plays a role in orchestrating taste cell differentiation in developing buds.
Rice is an important monocotyledonous crop that differs from the dicotyledonous Arabidopsis in many aspects. In Arabidopsis, ethylene and auxin act synergistically regulate root growth and development. However, their interaction in rice is unclear. We report that transcriptional activation of OsIL on expression of Y8RE7 and indole-3-pyric acid (IPA)-dependent auxin biosynthesis is required for ethylene-inhibited root elongation. Using inhibitor of Y activity, which regulates auxin biosynthesis via conversion of IPA to indole-3-acetic acid (IAA), we show that eth-inhibited root elong is dependent on Y-based auxin biosynthesis. By screening of seedling root from mutagen libraries following ethylene, we identified eth-insensitive rein-1, which YRE7 is truncated at C-terminus. Mutation Y7 reduced auxin biosynthesis in, while Y overexpression enhanced eth sensitivity in roots. Moreover, catalyzed conversion of IPA to A, truncated Y resulted in significant reduction of enzymatic, indicating Y is required for IPA-dependent auxin bios and eth-in elong in seedlings. Further indicated eth induced Y expression and promoted accumulation in roots. Addition of low rescued eth response in, strongly that elong depends on-dependent auxin bios. Genetic revealed Y-mediated auxin function downstream OsIL, which directly expression.
The first nationwide epidemiological study of non-tuberculous mycobacterial (NTM) diseases in Saudi Arabia was conducted over a period of 24 months. A total of 527 NT isolates were collected with a higher proportion of Saudi citizens (76.5% ), elderly patients >60 years (34.2% ) and male (65.3 ) respectively. The majority of isolates (75.1% ) were pulmonary with 44.7% proven clinical significance. A total of 34 NT species including 17 rare were identified, in addition to 8 undefined isolates. M. simiae (22.6 ) M. fortuit (18.1 ) and. absus (17.8 ) were predominant. Interestingly, 27 new cases of clinically relevant M.iyense were noticed. The study showed rare events such as mycobacteremia, abscess, peritonitis and ascites caused by. wolii,. hatic, duii and monence respectively. Diabetes mellitus (P-0.04 ) and history of tuberculosis (P-0.001 ) were risk factors associated with NT diseases.
Upon starvation, yeast cells exit the mitotic cell cycle and acquire characteristics of quiescent cells to ensure longevity. Little is known about the molecular determinants that orchestrate quies entry and extension. Using starvation-specific reporters, we screened a subset of the deletion library representing genes encoding signaling proteins. Apart from previously characterised Rim15, Mck and Yak1 kinases, the SN1/AMP complex, cell integrity and cycle regulators were necessary for quies establishment and extension of chronological lifespan (CLS), suggesting quies requires integration of starvation signals via multiple pathways. CL correlates with the amount of carbohydrates but not cell cycle status. Combined removal of glycogen and trehalose biosynthetic genes, especially GSY and TPS, abolishes accumulation and severely reduces CL. Concurrent overexpression of GSY and T1 or supplementation trehal to medium ameliorates CL defects by rimΔy1 orΔmckΔ. We reveal that intracellular ROS are cooperatively controlled by Yak, Rim and Mck, and mediate TOR-regulated accumulation and CL extension. Our data support that metabolic reprogramming to accumulate stores and activation of antioxidant systems are coordinated by Yak, Rim and Mck to ensure quies and extension in yeast.
Influenza A virus hemagglutinin glycosylation compensates for antibody escape fitness costs. Antigenic evolution enables the persistence of seasonal influenza A and B viruses in human populations despite widespread immunity. The mechanisms that enable antigenic evolution are critical for designing durable vaccines and therapeutics. Here, we reveal an unexpected role for hemagglutinin ( HA ) glycosylation in compensating for fitness defects resulting from anti-HA neutralizing antibody escape. Antibody-free propagation of antigenic escape viruses selected for mutations that modulated receptor binding through addition of N-linked glycans to the HA globular domain.
Cardiac arrhythmias are often caused by drugs that prolong the cardiac action potential (AP) in a way that is dependent on the heart rate. This means that arrhythmia suppression is reduced at fast heart rates and increased at slow rates. The opposite property, forward dependence, would overcome these problems, but forward dependent antiarrhythmics remain elusive. Moreover, there is evidence that reverse dependence is an intrinsic property of perturbations to the AP. We performed a comprehensive analysis of ventricular myocyte models to address the possibility of forward dependence. By simulating populations of myocytes with varying properties and analyzing results, we predicted the rate-dependent effects of changes in multiple parameters. We tested 40 parameters in each model and assessed AP duration at slow (0. 2 Hz ) and fast (2 ) rates. We identified a variety of forward dependent current perturbations and specific mechanisms. For example, an increase in L-type current is forward when accompanied by indirect rate-dependent changes in delayed rectifier potassium. We compared predictions across models and identified inward rectifier current and sodium-potassium pump as the most likely to produce forward prolongation. Finally, a statistical analysis demonstrated that models with minimal rate changes in AP have little capacity for perturbations, whereas models with large changes have considerable potential. This can explain differences between species and ventricular types. Overall, this study provides new and general insights into determinants of AP dependence and illustrates a strategy for beneficial antiarrhythm drug design.
Phenome-Wide Association Studies (PAS) is a method that investigates whether genetic polymorphisms associated with a phenotype are also associated with other diagnoses. In this study, we have developed methods to perform PW based on ICD-10 codes and biological results, and use a quantitative trait as criterion. We tested our approach on thiopur S-methylase (TPM) activity in patients treated thiur drugs. We developed two methods for ICD-10 codes: I-10 hierarchy and mapping to existing I-9M PW codes. Eleven biological results were analyzed using discretization algorithms. We applied methods in patients with TP activity from clinical warehouse of a French hospital between 0 and 3. Data initiation thiur treatment were analyzed and groups compared according to TP level. A total records were analyzed representing, I-10 codes and, biological results. The I-9 PW codes and I-10 codes were concord. Cross-validation biological results allowed to validate phenotypes. Iron-deficiency anemia and mellitus were with very TP activity ( = .4 and =.5, respectively.
Spinal cord injury (SCI) is a devastating condition that causes substantial morbidity and mortality for which no treatments are currently available. Stem cells offer some promise in restoration of neurological function. We conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis to study the impact of stem cell biology and experimental design on motor and sensory outcomes following stem treatments in animal models of SCI. One hundred and fifty publications using 45 different stem preparations met our inclusion criteria. Only one used autologous stem cells. Overall, allogenic stem treatment appears to improve both motor (effect size 27.2%; 95% CI 25.0–29.4%; 5 comparisons in 628 animals ) and sensory (effect 26.3%;% CI 7.9–44.7%;23 in 473 animals ) outcomes. For sensory outcome most heterogeneity between experiments was accounted by facets of stem biology. Differentiation before implant and intravenous delivery favoured better outcome. Cell implant did not appear improve sensory in females and was enhanced by isofurane anaesthesia. Biological plausibility supported by dose–response. For outcome facets had little effect. Instead heterogeneity explained by experimental and outcome used. Location, method injury and immunosup all had impact.
Soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infections, caused by Ascaris lumbricoid, hookworm, and Trichuris trura, affect more than a billion people worldwide. Preventive chemotherapy, or repeated administration of anthelmint drugs to at-risk populations, is the main control strategy. However, this does not prevent reinfection. We performed a systematic review and meta-analysis to assess patterns and dynamics of STH reinfection after treatment. We searched PubMed, ISI of Science, EASE, Cochr Database Systematic Reviews, China Knowledge Infrastructure, Wanang Database, Chinese Journal, and Scholar. From 154 studies, 51 were included and 24 provided STH rates pre- and post-treatment, whereas 42 reported determinants of predisposition to rein. At 3, 6, and 12 months post-treatment, A. lumbroid reached 26% (95% CI:16–43 )%, 68 (95% CI:60–76 ) and 94 (95 CI:88–100 ) of pretreatment levels. T. trura reached 36% (95 CI:28–47 ), 67 (95 CI42–100 ) and 82 ( CI62–100 ), and hookworm 30 (95 CI26–34 ) 55 ( CI34–87 ) and 57 (49–67 ). Prevalence and intensity of rein were positively correlated with pretreatment status. STH reinfections occur rapidly after treatment, particularly A lumbr and Tura.
Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is a spectrum of metabolic disorders ranging from simple steatosis to complex nonalcoholic steatohepatitis. To identify deregulation of metabolic processes at the molecular level that give rise to various NAFL phenotypes, algorithms such as pathway enrichment analysis (EA) can be used. However, these analyses are subject to biases associated with different pathway annotations and cannot capture complex interactions of genome-scale metabolic networks (Gs). Here, we introduce Minimum Enrichment Analysis (MiA) that applies to Gs to generate all possible minimal networks (Ms) composed of reactions pertaining to metabolic subsystems that synthesize a target metabolite. We applied MiA to deregulated Ms to identify regulators in NAFL phenotypes, such as fatty liver and inflammation in humans and mice by integrating transcriptomics data from liver samples. We identified deregulations in synthesis of cholesteryl esters, cholesterol, and hexadecate in humans and mice, and found regulators of hydrogen synthesis were differently regulated in humans and mice. We identified Ms that demonstrate characteristics of different NAFL phenotypes. MiA is applicable to any G and any metabolite, making it flexible to study metabolism for any disease or organism.
Olfactory discrimination is a challenging because of the large number of odors that need to be identified independent of their intensity. Primacy coding, where the odor identity is encoded by the earliest responding receptors, provides a compact representation that can be efficiently interpreted by the brain. We show that primacy information depends on the number of receptors in the representation, but only weakly on the size of the repertoire. The representation is independent of odor intensity and the information is useful for olfactory tasks close to experimentally measured. Interestingly, we find that smaller repertoires are advantageous for discriminating odors. The model suggests that overly sensitive receptors dominate the response and make the array useless, allowing us to predict receptor adaptation to environmental changes. We show that primacy is more useful than binary and normalized because sparsity is independent of odor statistics, in contrast to alternatives.
HIV broadly neutralizing monoclonal antibodies (bnAbs) are a promising candidates for HIV therapy and vaccine design. However, some bnAbs occasionally display unusual neutralization profiles with non-sigmoid slopes and plateaus at <100% neutralization. Here, we investigated the extent of non-sigmoid slopes and plateaus <100 for bnAbs. We used a panel of 278 pseudoviruses in a CD4 T-cell assay and 117 viruses in the TZM assay. We found that bnAbs targeting the V2 apex of Env and gp41 had neutralization profiles that plateaued at <100. Conversely, bnAbs targeting high-mann epitopes were less likely to show this behavior. CD4 binding Abs showed this behavior infrequently. We also observed incomplete neutralization in a PBMC-grown virus panel from patient swarms. In addition, we compared bnAbs against 18 virus clones produced in 293 cells and PBs and assayed in TZM cells. Plateaus <90 were seen with both types of virus with no consistent patterns. Our results suggest that incomplete neutralization and nonigmoid neutral curves are possible for all bnAbs against a range of viruses in both cell and primary cells. This has implications for use in therapy and vaccine design.
The Warburg effect is a metabolic trait of cancer cells that involves the production of lactate from glucose in the presence of oxygen. In addition to this, cancer cells utilize glutamine extensively and have impaired mitochondrial electron transport. It is unclear how these metabolic rearrangements contribute to a selective advantage for cancer cell proliferation. To understand how glucose and glutamine are converted to energy and biomass, we used a model of human metabolism. We simulated cells with different glutamine and glucose uptake rates and observed that in proliferating cells fermented glucose to lactate in the presence of oxygen. At high glutamine utilization, glucose oxidation was decreased and lactate production from glutamine was enhanced. This was only observed when carbon exceeded the amount that could be oxidized by oxygen. Flux Analysis indicated that this pattern is optimal for biomass and ATP production. It requires a branched TCA cycle and glutamine-dependent reductive carboxylation for lipid and protein production. It is sustained by redox-controlled reactions. We experimentally validated glutamine metabolic changes in a K-ras transformed cell line. These findings offer new understanding of metabolic reprogramming that underlies cancer growth.
Prion protein (Pr) is a misfolded protein associated with neurodegenerative diseases such as scrapie and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. The cellular environment in which Pr is converted to its disease-associated isoforms is not well understood. In this study, we investigated the interactome of Pr in a cell culture model permissive to prion replication. We extended our study to Doppel (PrPND) and Shadoo (Spr), mammalian Pr paralogs. We found that all three prion family members interact in neuroblastoma cells. Furthermore, we confirmed interactions between Pr and the cell adhesion molecule laminin, Na+/K ATPases, and protein disulfide isomerases (PDI), reconciling previous findings. We also found that Pr interactions with PDIs may extend beyond the endoplasmic reticulum and play a role in PrSc accumulation. We propose that Pr organizes its environment by binding adhesion molecules with immunoglobulin domains, which recognize oligannose-bearing membrane proteins.
Respiratory virus infections, such as influenza, induce a robust type 1 pro-inflammatory cytokine response. However, the production of type 2 cytokines has been observed. Type 2 cytokine production during respiratory infection is linked to asthma exacerbation; however type 2 cytokines may also be protective. Interleukin ( ) is a prototypical type 2 cytokine that is essential for eosinophil maturation and egress of the bone marrow. Using a mouse model of influenza infection, we found a transient release of IL-5 into airways along with a significant accumulation of eosophils into the lungs during the recovery phase of infection. The source of IL-5 was group 2 innate lymphoid cells (IL2 ) infiltrating the lungs. The accumulation of eosoph following clearance is reflected in the expansion of c+ IL-5 IL2. Enhanced IL-5 production by IL2 is concomitant with expression of the IL-33 subunit, by IL2. NKT cells and alveolar macrophages (AM ) are sources of IL that enhance IL-5 from IL2.
Invasive nontyphoidal Salmonella (NT) infections are an important cause of morbidity and mortality in children and HIV-infected adults in sub-Saharan Africa. However, the epidemiology and clinical manifestations of NT disease in Asia are not well documented. We retrospectively identified 102 cases of NT infections in an infectious disease hospital in Southern Vietnam between 2008 and 2013. Clinical records were accessed to evaluate demographic and clinical factors associated with NT infection and identify risk factors with death. Multi-locus typing and antimicrobial testing was performed on all organisms. Of 102 NT patients, 71% were HIV-infected, >90% were adults,71% were male and 33% reported intravenous use. Twenty-six/92 (28%) patients had known outcome; HIV was associated with death (p=0.039). Enteridis Sequence (ST)11 (48%,43/89) and Typhimium (ST19,34,44) (26%,23/89) were most identified serovars. Tyim was more common in HIV-infected (p=0.003). Isolates HIV-infected were more likely reduced against trimethoprim-sulfamox than HIV-negative (p=0.037).
Bacteriophages play a crucial role in the survival and pathogenicity of their hosts via lysogenic factors and nutrient redistribution via lysis. Analyses of phage and viral genes in environmental samples provide insights into the impact of viruses on microbial communities and human health. However, phage ORFs are extremely diverse, with over 70% dissimilar to genes with annotated functions in GenBank. Better identification of viruses would aid in disease detection, vaccine development, and physiological understanding of environment. In contrast, viral structural proteins are challenging to detect from sequence data due to low conservation, few conserved catalytic sites, and limited data. We designed a method to predict phage protein sequences using Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs). First, we trained ANNs to classify structural proteins using amino acid frequencies, correctly classifying a large fraction with high specificity and sensitivity. Subsequently, we added isoelectric points as a feature to ANNs classifying specialized proteins, namely capsid and tail proteins. Expectedly, these ANNs were more accurate than structural ANNs. We experimentally validated ANN predictions by examining ORFs with no similarities to sequences that ANN-predicted proteins by transmission microscopy. Some self-assembled structures resembling virion structures. Our ANNs are new tools for identifying phage and prophage proteins difficult to detect by bioinformatic analysis.
Kaposi’s sarcoma herpesvirus (KSHV) is an oncogenic virus that encodes more than 85 proteins, including both unique and conserved herpesviral proteins. KSH ORF20 is a member of the herpesiral UL24 family, but its function and role in the viral life cycle is not well understood. OR20 encodes three largely uncharacterized isoforms that are predominantly localized in the nucleus and nucleolus. We found that OR20 interacts with the interferon-stimulated gene product oligoadyl synthase-like (OL) protein, which has antiviral activity against some viruses, but its role in gammaherpesviruses is unknown. Characterization of OL partners by quantitative affinity purification coupled to mass spectrometry (q-APMS) identified a similar interactome to OR20. Both OR20 and OL copurified with 40S and 60 ribosomal subunits and associated with polysomes. OR20 did not have a global effect on translation, but enhanced RIG-induced expression of endogenous OL in an IR3-dependent but IFN-independent manner. We show that OL and OR20 expression were induced after reactivation of latently infected HuLT-KSH.219 cells. Interestingly, we found that OL enhanced KSH infection. During KSH OR20 mutant infection, however, OL-dependent enhancement was lost. Our data suggest that OR20 usurps the function of OL to benefit KSH infection.
Lassa fever (Lassa virus disease ) is an important cause of undifferentiated fever in children in endemic areas. In Nigeria, there is a dearth of data on the prevalence and clinical presentation of Lassa fever in febrile children. This study aimed to determine the prevalence and presentation of Lassa fever in feile children with and without convulsions. This was a prospective study of consecutive feile children ≥1–15 years admitted to the Children’s Emergency of Irrua Specialist Hospital over 1 year. Feile children with convuls (Cases ) were compared with those without convuls (Controls ). Lassa was defined by positive Lassa virus RT-PCR. Rates were compared between groups using χ2 or Fisher’s tests and p<0. 05 taken as significant. Of 913 feile admissions, 373 (40.9% ) had fever. Of these, 108 (29% ) presented convuls. The overall prevalence of Lassa was 13/373 (3.5%; 95% CI 1.9, 5.7 ) in feile, 3/108 (2.8 ) in Cases and 10/265 (3.8 ) in Controls. Only vomiting and bleeding were significantly associated with increased prevalence of Lassa.
Arabidopsis thalian is a model organism that is widely used to study plant biology. Drought is a major factor that reduces crop yields worldwide. We identified the karri receptor KINSENSITIVE2 ( KAI2 ) as a factor that regulates drought resistance in Arabidopsis. Karrins are butenol compounds found in smoke that promote seed germination and improve seedling growth under stressful conditions. We found that mutations in K2 result in hypersensitivity to water deprivation. We performed transcriptomic, physiological, and biochemical analyses of k2 plants to understand the basis for K2-regulated drought resistance. We found that k2 have increased rates of water loss and drought-induced cell damage, enlarged stomatal apert, and higher cuticular permeability. In addition, k2 have reduced anthocyan biosynthesis during drought and are hypersensitive to abscic acid ( ABA ) in stomatal and cotyledon assays. We identified genes that are associated with the physiological and biochemical changes through genome-wide transcript analysis of k2 under well-water and dehydration. These data provide evidence for cros between A- and K2-dependent pathways in drought responses. We compared the stract receptor mutant DW14 to k2 and found that stract also contribute to drought, although not affecting cuticle. Our findings suggest that chemical or genetic of K2 and14 may improve drought resistance.
Schistosoma japonicum is a parasitic flatworm that causes zoonotic schistosomiasis in China and the Philippines. To understand the role of insulin signaling in its growth and reproduction, we have focused on the insulin receptor ( SIR ) of S. japonicum, which we previously cloned and characterised. We show that human insulin binds to the insulin binding domain of recombinant SIR1 and SIR2 ( SLD1 and SLD2 ) produced in Drosophila cells. We used RNA interference to knock down SIR in S. japon in vitro and found that in addition to reduced SIR transcription, other insulin pathway genes associated with glucose metabolism and schistosome fecundity were also impacted. Furthermore, SIR-knockdown worms had reduced glucose uptake compared to luciferase controls. In vaccine experiments, we found that SLD and SLD depressed growth, intestinal granuloma and faecal production in S japon in mice with low dose infection.
Lymphatic filariasis (LF) is a leading cause of disability in the Pacific region, where >96% of 1.7 million people are at risk of LF infection. Current mass drug administration (MDA) has reduced LF prevalence, but vector biology complicates MDA. In some regions, LF elimination cannot be attained via MDA alone. Obligate mosquitoes provide additional targets for breaking the LF cycle, but existing methods are ineffective for Aedes aegypti in the Pacific. We demonstrate that interspecific hybridization and introgression results in Aedes aegypt strain ‘CP’ that is stably infected with endosymbiotic Wolbachia fromedes albopictus. The CP strain is bi-directionally incompatible with naturally infected mosquitoes, resulting in female sterility. Laboratory assays demonstrate CP males are competitive, resulting in elimination when introduced into wild Aedes aegpt populations.
Trypanosomias is a vector-borne disease that is fatal if left untreated. In Tanzania, it is a major public health and socio-economic problem in affected communities. This study estimated the burden of rhodes H in terms of Disability-Adjusted Life Years (DALs) and costs in a highly endemic area of Tanzania. Data was obtained from 143 patients admitted in 2004 for treatment at Kali Health Centre, Uram District. The direct and indirect costs incurred by patients and health services were calculated. DALs were estimated using the Global Burden Project methods and previous rhodes H estimates, assuming 45% under-reporting. In Uram District, DALs were 215.7 (95% CI 155.–287.5 ) and 281.6 (95% CI 209.–362. ) respectively. With 45% under-reporting, results were 622.5 (95 CI 155–109.9 ) and 978.9 (95 CI 201–187.8 ). Treating 143 patients cost US$15,514, patients paid US3, and health US11,. Indirect costs for 143 were US9.
Deficiency of the cytoplasmic N-gly-glycosidase enzyme Ng1 (Ng1) is embryonically lethal in C57BL/6 mice. However, additional deletion of the gene encoding endo-β-N-acetylglucosidase (Eng), another de-N-glycosidating enzyme that leaves GlcNAc at glycosylated Asn residues, partially rescues the lethality of Ng1-deficient mice. We also found that changing the genetic background of C57/6 mice by crossing with outbred ICR mice partially rescues embryonic lethality of Ng1-deficient mice. Viable Ng1-deficient mice in C57/6 and ICR background, however, show a severe phenotype reminiscent of symptoms of Ng1-deficiency. Again, many defects are strongly suppressed by deletion of Eng in C57/6 and ICR background. Defects in Ng1Eng-deficient C57/6 and Ng1-def mice C57/6 ICR resemble some symptoms of patients with Ng-deficiency.
In Drosophila embryos, the activation of the hunch ( hb ) gene is regulated by a maternally-derived gradient of the Boid ( B ) protein. This process is one of the classic systems for studying spatial patterning in development. However, gene expression is subject to intrinsic noise which can produce variability. This variability must be constrained in the highly reproducible and coordinated events of development. We identify how noise is controlled during expression by characterizing the dependence of hb mRNA and protein output on promoter structure and transcriptional dynamics. We use a model of the hb promoter in which the number and strength of B and H ( self-regulatory ) binding sites can be varied. Parameters are fit to data from WT embryos, self-reg mutant hb14, and lac reporter constructs using different portions of the promoter. We corroborate model predictions experimentally. The results indicate that WT self-regulatory hb output is dependent on transcription and translation of its own expression rather than B fluctuations. Constructs lacking self-reg indicate that multiple B sites in the promoter and their strength also play a role in buffering. The model is robust to variation in B site number across species.
Neanderthal introgression is the process by which Neanderthals interbred with modern humans, leaving Neander alleles in the genomes of many modern humans. After interbreeding, natural selection appears to have removed Neander alleles from the human population. To understand this process, we need to quantify the strength and causes of selection against Neander ancestry. Here, we develop a new method to estimate the genome-wide strength of selection and density of selected sites using Neander allele frequencies in modern humans. We find that East Asians have more Neander ancestry than Europeans, even after accounting for selection. Most selection against Neander is due to weak deleterious alleles. These alleles were neutral in Neander, but became selected in humans. They had small effects, but imposed a heavy load on early hybrids. This suggests differences in population size may play a larger role in introgression than thought.
HIV-1 gene expression is controlled by the viral promoter within the long terminal repeat (LTR), which orchestrates the viral life cycle from gene expression to replication and establishment of latency. After integration into the host genome, stochastic gene expression is amplified by the Tat feedback loop, contributing to a productive or inactive state. In a fraction of cells harboring HIV-1 provirus LTR-GFPRESat, bimodal expression is dynamic, continuously switching between active (Bright) and inactive (Off) modes. These dynamics contribute to establishment and maintenance of latency, as viral expression is delayed before transactivation. The HIV-1 promoter contains cis-acting Sp and NF-κ elements that regulate expression via recruitment of activating and repressing complexes. We hypothesized that interplay of positive and negative factors modulates Bright and Off stability and viral expression sensitivity to fluctuations in Tat loop. Using lentivirus variants with Sp and NF-κ mutations, we employed flow cytometry, mRNA, pharmacological perturbations and chromatin immunoprecitation to reveal contributions to viral regulation. Sp sites apparently stabilize both Bright and Off, mutation promoting noisy expression and histone acetylation deacetylation. NFκ sites exhibit distinct properties, κ I serving stronger role than II. Moreover, Sp site plays role in recruitment of p300 and Rel to promoter. Analysis of 362 clonal populations revealed mutations yield 6-fold higher frequency bifcation compared to wild-type. Thus, Sp and NFκ differentially contribute to regulation, Sp functionally “en” transcription noise and modulate viral latency.
Accurate genome-wide identification of orthologs is a central problem in comparative genomics, reflected by the numerous orthology projects developed in recent years. However, only a few have compared their accuracy, and, recent efforts have not been systematically evaluated. We collected the results of nine orthology projects ( CO, KOG, Inanoid, OrthM, Ensembl Com, Homene, Round, EggG, OMA and ) and two standard methods ( bidirectional best and smallest ) and compared their predictions with respect to both phylogeny and function, using six tests. This required the mapping of millions of sequences, handling of hundreds of millions of predicted orthologs and computation of tens of thousands of trees. We find that OMA and Homene perform best in phylogen and functional analysis. At lower specificity but higher coverage, OrthM outperforms Ensembl and to extent Inan. Egg can be of interest for broad functional but not phylogen or detailed analyses. In terms methodology, we observe that En Com was outperformed by pairwise approaches even in phylogen tests. Furthermore, bidirectional often outperforms projects with complex.
Schistosomiasis is a highly prevalent and chronic disease caused by parasitic helmin infection, with three species of the genus Schistos infecting humans. Currently, a single drug, prazantel, is available to treat all infective species, but its use in mass administration is leading to signs of drug-resistance. To meet the challenge of developing new therapeutics against this disease, we developed an innovative drug repur pipeline supported by phenotyp screening. The approach highlighted protein kinases as new targets for schosiasis as they play an essential role in parasite’s biological processes. We report the elucidation of the kinome of Schos japonicum, as well as updated kinomes of S mansoni and haobium. In comparison with human kinome, we explored kinomes to identify targets of inhibitors unique to Schos species, allowing us to identify targets and suggest drugs that might inhibit them.
Transcription factors are central components of intracellular regulatory networks that control gene expression. Here we study the folding and binding of the pID domain of the transcription factor CREB to the K domain of the coactivator CB. Our simulations of a topology-based G-type model predict a coupled folding and binding mechanism, and the existence of partially bound intermediates. We find that the transition state resembles the unstructured state in solution, implying that CREB becomes structured only after committing to binding. The change of structure following binding is reminiscent of an induced mechanism and contrasts with models in which binding occurs to prestructured conformations that exist in the unbound state. Interestingly, increasing the amount of structure in the unbound pID reduces the rate of binding, suggesting a “fly-casting-like” process. We find that inclusion of non-native interactions results in formation of non-specific complexes that enhance the rate of binding but do not change the mechanism. Our study explains how unstructured can confer an advantage in target recognition.
Schistosomiasis Prevalence and Intensity Infection in Latin America and the Caribbean Countries, 194-2014: A Systematic Review in the Context of Regional Elimination Goal. In 2012, the World Health Assembly adopted WHA 65.21 on the elimination of schosomiasis, calling for increased investment in schomias control and support for countries to initiate programs. This study aims to analyze the prevalence and intensity of Schomia mans infection in children in Latin America and the Caribbean countries (LAC) at the second administrative level. A systematic review of schomias prevalence and intensity was conducted by searching PubMed, LACS, and EMBASE. Experts on the topic were consulted and institutional pages reviewed (PA/WHO, Ministries of Health). Only infection among children was registered because it can be ‘pro-indicator of recent by time the study is conducted. One hundred thirty full-text articles met the criteria and provided 1,242 prevalence and intensity data points. Most were from Brazil (69.7%). Only published after 200 showing ‘hot’ with prevalence Brazil, Venezuela, Suriname and Lucia need to update the epidemiological status of schomias to re-design national programs and target elimination Schia mans by 202. Antigua and Barb, Republic, Guadelpe, Martinique, Montserrat and Rico schias transmission may be interrupted. However, compilation and follow surveys per WHO, are needed to verify status. Hence, burden may still present even in countries have transmission.
Heterosexual transmission of HIV-1 is characterized by a genetic bottleneck that selects a single viral variant, the transmitted founder (TF), during transmission events. To assess viral characteristics influencing HIV-1 transmission, we sequenced 167 full-length viral genomes and generated 40 infectious molecular clones (IC) including TF and non-transmitted (NT) HIV-1 C variants from six heterosexual transmission pairs at the time of transmission. Consensus-like genomes sensitive to antibodies were selected during transmission in six pairs. However, TF variants did not demonstrate increased viral fitness in terms of infectivity or replicative capacity in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) and monocyte-derived dendritic cells (MDC). In addition, resistance of TF to antiviral effects of interferon-α (IF-α) was not significantly different from nonmitted variants from same pair.
Lymphangiogenesis and Lymph Remodeling Induced by Filarial Parasites: Implications for Pathogenesis. Lymphatic dilatation and dysfunction occur in filarial infections, even in the absence of an adaptive immune response in murine models. However, severe lymphedema and elephantiasis appear to require an intact adaptive response in human infections. To understand how filarial parasites and antigens influence lymphatics, human lymphatic endothelial cells (LEC) were exposed to filarial antigens, live parasites, or patient serum. Live parasites or antigens induced significant LEC proliferation and differentiation into tube-like structures in vitro. Moreover, serum from infected patients (microfilar positive ) and those with chronic lymphatic obstruction significantly increased LEC proliferation compared to uninfected. Differentiation of LEC into tube-like structures was associated with increased matrix metalloproteases and decreased TIM inhibitors (tissue of metalproteases ). Comparison of gene expression by live parasites LEC to parasite-exposed LEC demonstrated filarial altered expression of genes involved in cellular organization and junction pathways that decreased transendothelial transport assessed FIT-Dextr.
Since only a small fraction of environmental bacteria can be cultured in the laboratory, there is great interest in sequencing genomes directly from single cells. The Multiple Displacement Amplification (MDA) method can provide sufficient DNA for sequencing from a single cell, eliminating the need to develop culture methods. Here, we used a microfluidic device to isolate Escherichia coli and amplify genomic DNA by MD in 60-nl reactions. Our results show that reduced MD reaction volume lowers nonspecific synthesis from contaminant DNA and unfavourable primer interaction. The quality of amplification was assessed by qPCR and compared to single-cell amplifications in standard 50-μ volumes. Amplification was greatly reduced in naniter, providing more representation of all sequences. Single amplicons from microliter and naniter provided high-quality data by high-throughput pyrosequencing, demonstrating a route to genomes from cells.
Hantaviruses from the genus Orthohant are known to cause severe disease in humans and are mainly transmitted by Sigmodinae rodents in the tropical forests, savannas, and wetlands of South America. These rodents can shed different hantaviruses, such as the emerging Arquara orthantavirus. We tested the effect of landscape structure on the proportion of hant rodent hosts in the Atlantic Forest using 283 rodent capture records and geographically weighted models. We also assessed the correspondence between hant host proportions in rodent communities and human vulnerability to havirus infection across the Atlantic Forest. We found that hant host proportions were more influenced by landscape diversity than habitat or agricultural type. Small mammal diversity positively influenced pathogenic hant host proportions, indicating plasticity to habitat quality may be more important than competition with native species. Sugarcane plantations positively influenced rodent proportions, whereas defaunation did not correlate with pathogenic havirus genotypes. The match between hotspots and human vulnerability was 17%, coldspots 20. We found strong land change influences hant hosts across the Forest. Our findings suggest disease surveillance must be reinforced in southern and southeastern regions where h host and vulnerability match. Importantly, our analyses suggest complex rodent dynamics with disease than hypothesized.
Flaviviruses such as Japanese encephalitis virus (JEV), Dengue virus (DENV), and Zika virus (ZIKV) induce apoptosis in infected cells via the mitochondrial pathway. We show that BCL, a pro-surv BCL protein, is required for the survival of cells infected with flaviviruses. BCL suppresses the expression of MCL, another pro-sur BCL protein, thereby preventing apoptosis. Treatment with BCL inhibitors or deficient BCL expression induces BAX/BA-dependent apoptosis upon flavivirus infection. Flavivirus infection reduces protein synthesis of short-lived proteins such as MCL. BCL inhibition increases phagocytosis of virus-infected cells by macrophages, suppressing viral dissemination and chemokine production. We also show that BCL is required for survival of JEV-infected cells in vivo. BCL deficiency or BH mimetic compounds increase survival after JEV infection and suppress inflammation.
The economic burden of canine rabies in Viet Nam from 2005 to 2014 was estimated to be $719 million. The largest portion of this cost (92% ) was due to post-exposure prophylaxis ( PEP ). Canine rabies resulted in 36, 560 to 45,700 disability adjusted life years ( DALs ) and 914 human deaths over the study period. The cost per dog vaccinated was $1.75.
The assembly of the Type II Secretion System (TSS) in Vibrio cholera depends on a novel pilot protein called Asp. The TSS is a molecular machine that secretes fully-folded proteins across the bacterial outer membrane. The secretin, a multimeric outer membrane protein, is a key element of the machinery that forms the secretion pore. We have distinguished three forms of TSS based on the characteristics of their secretin pores. The Klebsella-type and Vibrio-type TSS are further distinguished by the pilot that mediates their transport and assembly into the outer membrane. We have determined the crystal structure of the novel pilot Asp from Vibrio cholera. The structure shows that Asp is functionally equivalent yet structurally unrelated to pilotins found in Klebsella and other bacteria. Asp binds to a specific sequence in the Vibrio secretin and enhances the kinetics of secretin assembly. Homologs of Asp are found in all species of Vibrio as well as few strains of Escherichia and Shella that have acquired Vibrio TSS.
Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease caused by pathogenic Leptira spp., which are shed in the urine of reservoir hosts and transmitted to susceptible hosts through skin abrasions or mucous membranes. The ability of Leptira to adhere to cell surface and extracellular components is crucial for dissemination and colonization of host tissues. In this study, we elucidate the roles of transmembrane outer proteins Omp36 ( LIC66 ), O37 ( LIC63 ) and O47 (50 ) recently identified on Leptiral surface. We determine the capacity of these proteins to bind host components by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay. O37 binds preferentially, exhibiting dose-dependent saturating binding to human skin (104 nM ) and aorticin (152M ). It also binds fibrin (244M ) fibrin fragment (132 ) plasmaectin (359M ) and murine (410M ). The binding to skin by recombinant O and Leptira is enhanced by antiser for O, suggesting involvement in Lept binding and possibility that host-generated antibodies promote rather than inhibit adherence to elastin-rich tissues. We also demonstrate O is recognized by acute convalescent sera and Leptira-infected hamster sera. Finally, is detected in pathogenic Lept and not saprophy Lept. Thus, is a novel elastin-binding of pathogenic Lept that may promote attachment to host tissues.
Antibodies 4E10 and 2F are two broadly neutralizing antibodies isolated from HIV-1 infected individuals that recognize epitopes in the membrane-proximal region (MP) of gp41. These epitopes are transiently exposed during viral entry. We present a model to calculate the probability that an antibody will disable trimeric gp41 before fusion is complete. When 4E or 2F bind the MP, a conformational change results in a stable complex. The model predicts that for these antibodies to be effective, the time to disable epitope must be shorter than the antibody remains in conformation, about five minutes or less for 4E and 5. We investigate the role of avidity in neutralization and show that 2F is more effective than 4. We attribute this to 2 interacting more stably with viral. We use the model to elucidate parameters that determine ability to disable and propose an extension to analyze neutral data. The extended model predicts dependencies for neutral on constants that characterize binding, rate of gp41, and number of gp bridging virus and cell at start prehair.
Onchocercias Elimination with Ivermect Treatment in Endemic Foci in Africa: Final Results of a Study in Mali and Senegal. A longitudinal study was undertaken in three hyperendemic foci in Mali and Senegal with 15 to 17 years of annual six-month ivermect treatment to assess residual levels of infection and transmission and whether treatment could safely be stopped. Skin surveys were undertaken in 131 villages where 29,753 people were examined and 492,600 blackflies were analyzed for Onocerca volulus lar using a DNA probe. There was a trend in infection and transmission after the treatment. In two sites prevalence microfilar and vector rate were zero to years after treatment. In the third site infection were high before treatment there was also a decline to very low years after treatment. All indicators were below thresholds for elimination. The study established that onocercias elimination withiverm treatment is feasible in some foci in Africa.
Human rhinovirus is a non-enveloped virus of the picornavirus family, which causes the common cold and includes other significant pathogens such as poliovirus and foot-and-mouth disease. During cell entry, the myristoylated capsid protein VP4 is released from the virus and interacts with the cell membrane to deliver the viral genome into the cytoplasm to initiate replication.
