In this study, recombinant C-terminal histidine-tagged rhinovirus VP4 was produced and shown to induce membrane permeability in liposome model membranes. Size-exclusion studies, crosslinking and microscopy demonstrated that VP4 forms a multimer membrane pore with a channel consistent size for single-stranded RNA transfer. The permeability induced by recominant VP was influenced by pH and comparable to that induced by infectious virions.
Tularemia is a highly infectious disease caused by the Gram-negative bacterium Francisella tularensis ( Ft ), which is classified as a class A select agent by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Human isolates of Ft produce lipid A similar to that of Francisella novicida ( Fn ), a pathogen of mice. We identified three enzymes required for lipid carbohydrate modification of Ft A, specifically the presence of mannose ( flF1 ), galactosamine (F2 ) or both ( flK ). Mutants lacking galosamine (2 ) or galosamine/mannose (K ) were attenuated in mice by both pulmonary and subcutaneous routes of infection. In addition, aerosolization of mutants fl2 and flK provided protection against challenge with wild-type Fn, whereas subaneous administration of flK provided protection from challenge Fn. Furthermore, infection of alveolar macrophage line by flK induced higher levels of tumor necrosis-α (TN- ) and macrophage inhibitory-2 (M- ) compared to infection with Fn. Bone–derived macrophages (Bø ) from Toll receptor 4 (T4 ) and TLR/4 knockout mice infected with flK produced higher amounts of interleukin-6 (IL ) and M- than Bø infected Fn. However, production IL and M was undetectable in Bø from My− mice infected either. My− mice were also susceptible toK infection.
The ribosome-associated GTPase (RA-GTP) is a conserved across all domains of life and acts as a molecular switch to coordinate ribosome assembly. In Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus ), we previously identified the RA-GTP Era as a target for the stringent alarmone ppGpp, leading to inhibition of GTP activity. Here we show that Era is not essential in S. aureus but important for 30S ribosomal subunit assembly. Era interacts with the 16S rRNA endonuclease Y and the DEAD RNA helicase C. Era and C are required for growth at suboptimal temperatures and rRNA processing. Era and C also interact with the ppG synthase Rel, with Rel positively impacting Era GTP activity but negatively C helic activity. In its G-bound form, Era acts as a hub on the ribosome to direct enzymes involved in rRNA degradation and ribosome assembly to their site. This is impeded by components of the stringent response, contributing to slowed growth synonymous with this stress pathway.
Anthrax lethal toxin (LT) causes vascular insufficiency in experimental animals through unknown mechanisms. In this study, we show that neuronal nitric oxide synthase (NOS) deficiency in mice causes strikingly increased sensitivity to LT, while deficiencies in other NOS isoforms (iNOS and eOS) have no effect on LT-mediated mortality. The increased sensitivity ofN−/− mice was independent of macrophage sensitivity to toxin or cytokine responses and could be replicated inN-sufficient wild-type (WT) mice through pharmacological inhibition of with 7-nitroazole. Histopathological analyses showed LT-induced changes in heart morphology ofN−− mice with rapid appearance of inter-fiber spaces but no apoptosis of cardiomyocytes. LT-treated WT mice had no histopath observed at light microscopy. Electron analyses of LT-treated mice revealed pathological changes in hearts of both−− and WT mice varying in severity. Endothelialap necrosis and degeneration interocyte edema myament and mitochondrial degeneration and sarcoplasmic reticulumistae were observed in LT-treated and− mice. Furthermore, biomarkers of cardiac injury myoglobin cardiac tropon-I and heart acid protein were elevated LT-treated rapidly by 6 h after injection and reached rarely in mice. Cardiac protective therapy allopurin did not have effects LT-treated mice. Surprisingly, nitric scavenger carbox-PT showed some effect LT. Echocardiography LT-treated indicated reduction in fraction following treatment in− and WT, indicative of contractile in heart.
Parasitic nematodes infect over 1 billion people worldwide and cause some of the most common neglected diseases. However, the biology of parasitic nematodes has been limited by the lack of tools for genetic intervention. Here we report the development of a method for introducing CRISPR-C9-mediated gene disruptions in the parasitic nematode Strongyloides stercalis. We disrupted the S. steralis twitch gene-22, resulting in nematodes with severe motility defects. The S-22 mutations were resolved by homology-directed repair when a template was provided. Omission of a template resulted in deletions at the locus. S-22 mutations were heritable; we passed S-22 mutants through a host and recovered mutant progeny. Using a similar approach, we also disrupted the gene of the parasitic nemode Strongloides ratti. Our results demonstrate the applicability of CRPR-C9 to parasitic nemodes and enable future studies of function in medically relevant but previously intractable parasites.
Ribosome drop plays a crucial roles in translational accuracy and nutrient responses during stress. When cells are under stress, such as amino starvation or aminoacyl-tRNA depletion due to high recombinant protein expression, ribosome drop can affect protein expression efficiency. We introduce a model that describes ribosome drop effects on ribosome density along mRNA and conitant synthesis. Our results show that ribosome premature termination leads to non-intuitive ribosome profiles, such as rib density increases from 5’ to 3’ end. Importantly, the model predicts rib drop effects on translation are mRNA-specific and quantify resilience to drop, showing mRNAs with ribosomes are less affected than those without. Moreover, among mRN without ribosomes, resilience to drop correlates with elongation, so fast codons are less affected by drop. This is consistent with genome-wide S. cerevisiae, under favourable conditions mRN coding proteins involved in machinery, highly cod biased fast cod, are resilient to drop. Moreover, physiological conditions mRN coding stress proteins are resilient to drop.
The World Health Organization’s current strategy to control soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infections in children is based on morbidity control through routine deworming of school and pre-school children. However, transmission continues to occur due to persistent reservoirs of infection in untreated individuals and environment. In many settings, this strategy needs to be continued for extended periods or until social and environmental conditions result in interruption of transmission. There is discussion on accelerating interruption using alternative strategies of mass drug administration (MDA). However, the feasibility of achieving interruption using MD remains uncertain due to challenges in sustaining MD coverage across communities. The DeWorm trial tests the feasibility of interrupting STH transmission. In Deorm, three years of treatment will be followed by two years of surveillance. Given reinfection rates, two years is regarded as adequate to assess bounce or interruption. This study investigates criteria to determine interruption can be defined earlier. A stochastic individual-based model simulates Deorm community cluster-randomized trial. This compares control (annual treatment of children with MD) with intervention (community-wide biannual MD). Simulations were run for both Ascaris lumbricoides and hookworm (Necator american). Prevalence at six months after last MD and MD levels were evaluated to assess likelihood of bounce or elimination.
Cholera is an infectious disease caused by the bacterium Vibrio cholerae. Protective immunity against cholera is serogroup specific and is determined by the O-specific polyscharide ( OSP ) of lipopolyschar ( LPS ). Generally, polyschar are poorly immunogenic, especially in children. Here, we report the evaluation of a cholera conjugate vaccine ( OSP:Tc ) made from Vibrio cholera O1 Ogawa OSP and recombinant tetanus toxoid heavy chain (Tc ). Mice were immunized intramuscularly on days 0, 21, and 42 with OSP:Tc or OSP only, or with dmLT, a non-toxigen immunoadju derived from labile toxin Escherich coli. We detected significant serum IgG responses targeting OSP following immunization in mice receiving OSP:Tc or without adjuvant. Anti-LPS Ig responses were detected following immunization in these cohorts. No antiOSP or anti-L Ig responses were detected in animals receiving unjugated OSP or immunoadjuvant, and animals immunoadju alone. Responses were highest immunization adjuvant. Serum-OSP Ig were detected mice OSP:Tc or immunoadjuvant, and unconjug OSP. Serum-L Ig and vibocidal responses were all cohorts except immunoadju alone. No Ig antiOSP or anti-L responses any group. Administration OSP:Tc adju also induced memory cell targeting OSP and 95% protective lethality cholera model.
Candida albicans inhibits the virulence of Pseudomonas aeruginosa through suppression of pyochelin and pyoverdine biosynthesis. In a neutropenic mouse model of gastrointestinal colonization, we show that C. albicans suppresses P. aeruginosa virulence by inhibiting pyelin and pyd gene expression, which plays a critical role in iron acquisition and virulence. Deletion of P. aerugin pyelin and pyd genes attenuates P aerugin virulence. Heat-killed C albicans has no effect on P aerugin, whereas C albicans secreted proteins suppress pyd and pyelin expression and inhibit aer vir in mice. Interestingly, deletion of pyelin and pyd genes has no effect on aer’s ability to colonize the GI tract but decreases aer’s cytotoxic effect on colonocytes. Finally, iron supplementation restores aer vir in aer and alb colonized mice. Our findings provide insight into bacterial-fungal modulation of virulence in the intestine.
HIV-1 and Simian Immunodeficiency Virus (SIV) mutants that evade CD8+ T cell recognition are frequently observed following infection. These mutants are often less replicatively fit compared to wild-type (WT) virus, as demonstrated by reversion to WT upon transmission to a naive host and association with lower viral load in vivo in HIV-1 infection. However, the rate of reversion is highly variable. We quantified reversion to WT of a series of SIV and SHIV viruses containing minor amounts of WT in pig macaques using PCR. Infection with mixes of EM and WT containing ≥10% WT results in rapid outgrowth of WT at SIVag CD8 cell epitopes within 7 days of infection. In contrast, biologically passaged SHIV229 viruses with smaller proportions of WT or molecular pure EMIV239 demonstrated delayed re. WT was not detectable ≥8 days after inoculation and ≥ weeks to become dominant quasis. Delayed re was associated with lower loads.
Natural populations of yeast collected from the Dead Sea of Evaporation (EC), Israel, exhibit extremely high tolerance to the heavy metal cadmium. We found that cadmium resistance is primarily caused by enhanced function of a metal efflux pump, PCA1. Molecular analyses demonstrate that this enhancement is largely due to mutations in the promoter region, while mutations in the coding region have minor effect. Reconstruction experiments show that single nucleotide substitutions in PCA promoter quantitatively increase its activity and enhance cells' cadmium resistance. Comparison among yeast species shows that critical nucleotides found in EC are conserved and functionally important for cadmium resistance in other species, suggesting they represent ancestral. However, nucleotides diverged in Saccharomyces cerevisiae populations, which gave growth advantages under cadmium low or absent.
Gastric cancer (GC) is the second leading cause of cancer-related death worldwide. GC is characterized by a high degree of heterogeneity in the deregulation of different oncogenic pathways. In this study, we sought to identify the major oncogenic pathways in GC with significant relationships to patient survival. Using gene expression signatures, we devised an in silico strategy to map patterns of oncogenic activation in 301 primary gastric cancers. We identified three oncogenic pathways ( proliferation/stem cell, NF-κ, and Wnt/β-caten ) deregulated in the majority (70%) of gastric cancers. We functionally validated these predictions in a panel of gastric cancer cell lines. Patient stratification by oncogenic pathway showed reproducible and significant differences in multiple cohorts, suggesting that pathway interactions play an important role in disease behavior. Individual GC can be taxonomized by oncogenic activity into biologically and clinically relevant subgroups.
In this study, we investigate the distribution of stress-induced DNA destabilization (SIDD) sites in the Escherichia coli K12 genome. We find that strongly destabilized sites occur preferentially in intergenic regions that are known or inferred to contain promoters, but rarely in coding regions. We then investigate whether genes in different functional categories have characteristic SIDD properties in their upstream regions. We find that strong S sites in E. coli12 are statistically overrepresented in the upstream of genes encoding transcription regulators. In particular, the upstream of genes that respond to physiological and environmental stimuli are more destabilized than those that do not. We also find that if a pathway is controlled by a transcription regulator whose gene has a destabilized 5′ flank, the genes in that pathway usually have strongly destabil S sites in their 5′ flanks. This association is observed in 38 of 43 free-living bacteria, but only 4 of 18 endosymbion or obligate parasitic bacteria. We propose that S sites in 5′ genes may be involved in transcriptional responses to changes that transiently alter superhelicity.
Podospora anserina, a filamentous ascomyc fungus, contains 12 HMG-box transcription factors that play a role in the regulation of genes involved in developmental and metabolic pathways. Systematic analysis of the eight uncharacterized HMG genes indicated that none were essential for viability, but seven were involved in sexual cycle. PaMG5, an ortholog of Ste11 from Schosaccharomyces pombe, is a pivotal activator of mating-type genes in P.serina, whereas PaMG9 is a repressor of several specific to stationary phase, notably hyph anastoses. PaMG5 is at the hub of a network of H-box factors that regulate mating-type and mating target genes. This network also controls fertility genes not regulated by mating transcription factors. PaMG and Ste11 are conserved regulators of mating genes in P.ser and S.pom, although they diverged 550 million years ago. Two H-box genes SO9 and its regulator RY also play a role in sex determination in mammals. Pser and Spom mating genes and their upstream factor form a module of H-box analogous to SRY/SOX, revealing commonality of sex regulation in animals and fungi.
During the 2013–2016 West African Ebola epidemic, there was an unprecedented number of cases and survivors. Prior to the epidemic, there was limited data on the persistence of Ebola virus in survivors’ body fluids and the risk of transmission, including sexual transmission. An observational study was implemented during the epidemic response in Sierra Leone to determine the persistence of Ebola in survivors’ body fluids. The study was conducted in two phases. The first phase, initiated within five months of protocol discussions, assessed the persistence of virus in semen of 100 adult men. The second phase assessed the persistence in multiple body fluids ( semen, vaginal fluid, blood, breast milk, urine, rectal fluid, sweat, saliva, tears ) of 120 men and 120 women. Data informed national and global guidelines in real-time and demonstrated the need for semen testing among Ebola survivors. The study accelerated implementation of programs in affected countries and informed persistence of Zika studies.
Chemotaxis is the process by which bacteria sense and respond to chemical stimuli in their environment. Chemotaxis is mediated by sensory systems that respond to certain properties and transmit this information through biochemical pathways. In this study, we use FRET experiments to characterize the chemotaxis system of Escherichia coli and predict the chemical gradients they encounter in their natural environment. We use Weber’s law and its generalizations to predict average gradients experienced by cells and information theory to obtain full distributions of gradients. We consider limitations of transmission from both internal and external noise. Our results show broad distributions of gradients lead to log-normal stimuli and maximal velocity.
The lifespan of hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs), which give rise to all blood cells, has been thought to be indefinite due to their self-renew capacity. However, there is increasing evidence that genetically identical HSCs differ in lifespan and that the lifespan of HSC is predetermined and H-intrinsic. We present a new model based on reliability theory to account for the diversity of lifans of Hs. Using clonal repulation experiments and computational-mathematic modeling, we tested how small, molecular failures are dissipated at the H population level. We found that the fit of the data is provided by a model where repulation kinetics of H are largely anti-persistent or mean-reverting processes. Thus, failure rates increase during population division events are counteracted by repair processes. In the long, a crossover from anti-persistent to persistent occurs. This is due to an increase in mean failure rate of selfnew leading to clonal extinction. We show that lifespan of H depends on amplitudes and frequencies of fluctuations in failure kinetics. Short and longer lived Hs differ in ability to dissipate perturbations.
Helminth infections affect approximately one-third of the world's population, with no vaccines currently available. Antibodies and alternatively activated macrophages ( AAM ) are important components of protective immunity against helmin infections, but the mechanisms by which antibodies target helmin remain obscure. We demonstrate that helmin-specific antibodies induce the trapping of migrating helmin larvae and prevent tissue damage following infection with the murine parasite Heligomosomoides polygyrus bakeri ( Hp ). In the absence of antibodies (J−/− ) or activating Fc receptors (cγ/− ), larvae were highly motile and caused extensive tissue damage and accumulated Arginase-1 expressing macrophages around the larvae. Antibodies induced Fcγ and complement-dependent adherence of macroph to larvae in vitro, resulting in complete immobilization. Antibodies with helmin reprogrammed macro to express wound-healing genes, including Arginase, and Arginase product Lornine impaired larval motility. Antib-induced Arginase in vitro and in vivo occurred independently of IL-α signaling.
Chromosome breakage is a major threat to genome integrity and the most accurate way to repair DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) is homologous recombination (HR) with an intact copy of the broken locus. However, the mobility of the broken DNA has been seen to increase during the search for a copy. To observe chromosome dynamics during the early steps of HR, mainly resection from DS ends that generates recombinogenic strands, requires a system that does not interfere with the process and is relative to few kilobases of DNA that undergo processing. We have developed a new non-invasive method that uses oligomerization rather than multiplicity to form visible foci. By applying it to cleavage of the MAT locus on Saccharomyces cerevisiae chromosome III, we provide the first-time analysis of resection in living cells.
Trypanosoma cruzi is the causative agent of Chagas disease, a major public health problem in Latin America. People living in areas with active vector-borne transmission have multiple contacts with T. cruzi and can become reinfected. Although reinfections are thought to increase the risk of chronic disease manifestations, little is known about their frequency and timing in humans. We used stochastic models to estimate re-infection rates in humans and assess reinfections during acute and chronic disease stages according to alternative hypotheses on adaptive response following primary infection. We fitted models to epidemiological data from Argentine villages with mixed T. cruz genotypes in 56% of humans. The best model predicted 0. 032 ( 0.008–.042 ) annual reinfections per individual with 98.4% in chronic. Parasite escapes immune response after primary infection in 20% of re-infections. Annual reinfection rates during chronic disease are 14% (4%–18 ) and 60 (21–70 ) after 5 and 30 years with individuals reinfected 1–3 overall.
Dengue virus (DENV) infection is a major public health concern due to the global expansion of all four DENV serotypes (DENV-1, DENV-2, DENV-3, and DENV-4). While most DENV infections are subclinical, epidemiological studies suggest that cross-reactive immunity can influence disease outcome in subsequent infections. However, the mechanisms controlling differential clinical outcomes remain poorly defined. In this study, blood samples were collected from a cohort of school-aged Thai children who experienced subclinical DENV infection or developed deng illness. Peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) collected prior to infection were stimulated in vitro with DENV and secretion of 30 cytokines was measured using multiplex bead-based array. Significant differences were found in cytokine production based on the type of D used for stimulation and occurrence of illness. Secretion of IL-15 and MCP-1 was significantly higher by PBMC of subjects who developed symptomatic D infection. In addition, IL-6 was produced by PB from subjects who developed symptomatic infection versus 59% who had subclinical. Secretion of IL-12, IL-2, MIP-α, RANT, GM-CSF and TNα was lower by PB from subjects with symptomatic infection.
In Drosophila wing imaginal discs, Hedgehog (H) forms an extracellular gradient that organizes patterning along the anterior–posterior axis and specifies at least three different domains of gene expression. The prevailing view is that H functions in therosila wing disc as a classical morphogen, but a direct correspondence between the borders of these patterns and H concentration has not been demonstrated. Here, we provide evidence that interpretation of H signaling depends on the history of exposure to H and that a single concentration is sufficient to support multiple outputs. Using mathematical modeling, we predict that steady, only two domains can be in response to H, suggesting that the boundaries of or more gene patterns cannot be specified by static H gradient.
Ethanol is one of the most widely used anesthetics in the world. However, the mechanisms by which it influences the nervous system are poorly understood. Here, we describe the cloning and characterization of a new mutation in mice that disrupts the homolog of the Caenorhabditis elegans ( C. eleg ) unc-79 gene. This mutation, Lightweight ( Lwt ), was isolated in an Nethyl-nitrosourea ( ENU ) mutagenesis screen for animals with enhanced locomotor activity. Lwt/L homozygotes are perinatal lethal, while Lwt heterozygotes are dramatically hypersensitive to acute ethanol exposure. Experiments in C. elegans demonstrate conserved hypersensitivity to ethanol in unc-79 mutants and extend this observation to related unc-80 and nca-1;n-2 mutants. L heterozygotes also exhibit altered response to anesthetic isoflur, reminiscent of unc-vertebrate mutant phenotypes. In addition, heterozygotes are hyperactive in novel environment and smaller than wild-type. They also exhibit increased food consumption and lean body composition. Interestingly, heterozygotes consume more ethanol than wild-type littermates.
Anopheles gambiae has been identified as a potential source of anti-Plasmodium mechanisms to control malaria transmission. One such mechanism is the Imd pathway, a conserved signaling pathway with anti-P. falcum activity. Silencing cas, a negative regulator of Imd, or overexpressing rel, an I-controlled NFappaB transcription factor, confers resistant A. gambiae with an array of effector genes. Using RNA interference to silence cas and other Imd components, we identified genes in the anti-Plmod module regulated by cas, each a potential target for pathway overactivation. We found Imd most potent against the parasite’s ookin stage, with activity against early oocysts and lesser against lateocysts. Cas silencing alone induced a robust anti. falcum response even in the absence of gut microbiota. We established the relevance of Imd components TEP, APL, and LR1 in infection-dependent defense, shedding light on laboratory versus natural intensity.
Bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stem cells (BMMSCs) have been proposed as a potential therapy for treating fibrotic diseases. In this study, we investigated the anti-frotic effect of BSCs in a mouse model of pulmonary fibrosis caused by infection with Paroccidioides brasiliensis. BSCs were isolated from BAL/c mice and mice were inoculated with P. brasiliensis by intranasal infection. At 8 weeks post-infection, BSCs were administered intravenously. An additional group was treated with itraconazole (ITC) 2 weeks before BSC administration. Animals were sacrificed at 12 weeks post-infection. Histological examination, fibrocy counts, soluble collagen, and fibrosis-related genes in lungs were evaluated. Additionally, fibroblasts were treated with homogenized lung supernatants (HLS) to determine collagen expression. Histological analysis showed increased granulomatous areas in BSC-treated mice. Fibcy count, soluble collagen-α, T-β, MMP-8, and MMP-15 expression increased in BSC-treated mice. Combined BSC/IT therapy decreased TIM- and MMP-13 expression in infected mice. Fibrobl stimulated with HLS from infected BSC-transplanted mice showed higher collagen expression.
Leishmanias caused by Leishmania infantum is transmitted by phlebotine sand flies in the Mediterranean region. Climate change is thought to be responsible for the recent expansion of leishmanias vectors in this area. Sand fly activity is typically seasonal and sensitive to climate variations. In 2011–2013, a consortium of eight Mediterranean countries carried out entomological investigations in sites where L. infant transmission was recently reported. Sand flies were collected by CDC traps and sticky traps. Collections were replicated for more than one season to reduce weather effects. Data from 99,000 specimens were analyzed, resulting in the description of seasonal dynamics of 56,000 sand flies belonging to L. infant vector species in a wide area, namely P. periciosus ( Portugal, Spain and Italy ), P.ri ( France ),.neglectus ( Greece ),.bbi ( Cyprus and Turkey ),.balicus and.kakii ( Georgia ). Time of fly appearance/disappearance differed between sites and densities varied. Significant correlations were found between latitude/annual temperature and i ) first fly appearance (April–June; ii ) density trend (July–September. A novel 3-modal trend was recorded for.bb in Cyprus. Adults ended activity from September–November without correlation with latitude/annual temperature. The period of exposure to L infant in the subregion, inferred by adult densities, was a bell-shaped curve with peak July–September and May–October. No risk took place from December–March. Nocturnal females peaked 11–2 am. Annual collections provided homogeneous patterns of lemanias vectors, which may represent sentinel areas for future. In the years, higher risk L infant in the Mediterranean was June–October (97% density ), however risk was not equally distributed, since waves occurred earlier and more in southern territories.
Orientalia tsutsamushi, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is an obligate intracellular bacterium that mainly infects endothelial cells. We demonstrate here that O. tsugamushi also replicates in monocytes isolated from healthy donors. In addition, O. tsamushi alters the expression of more than 4, 500 genes, as demonstrated by microarray analysis. The expression of type I interferon, interferon-stimulated genes and genes associated with M1 macrophage polarization was significantly upregulated. Otsamushi induced the expression of apoptosis-related genes and promoted cell death in a small percentage of monocytes. Live organisms were indispensable to the type I interfer response and apoptosis and the expression of M-associated cytokines. These data were related to the transcription changes in mononuclear cells from patients with typhus. Here, microarray analyses revealed the upregulation of 613 genes, including interfer-related and features of M polarization in patients, similar to what was observed in Otsamushi-stimulated monocytes in vitro. This is the first report that monocytes are clearly polarized in vitro and ex vivo following Otsamushi exposure.
Ants are able to learn and follow complex routes through natural environments by using visual memory. However, the neural basis of this capability is unknown. The mushroom body, a key part of the insect brain, has been shown to be important for memory, but its function has been mostly studied in simple tasks such as smell. Here we show that a model of the mushroom body, originally developed to describe fruit fly memory, can also explain how desert ants learn to follow routes through complex environments. We also show that the key principles of this circuit, including one-shot learning of sparse codes, enable the mushroom body to store hundreds of images.
Plants have an innate immune system to protect themselves from disease. They have a number of unique defense mechanisms, particularly at the physiological level. One of these mechanisms is pathogen-triggered abscission, a process by which leaves are shed in response to infection. We studied pathogen-triggered abission in Arabidopsis thaliana leaves infected with Pseudomonas syringae, a bacterial pathogen lacking a functional type III secretion system. Pseudas syring failed to elicit abission, suggesting abission is a novel form of immunity triggered by effectors. We found that HAESA/ESA-like 2, INFRESCENCE DEFICIENT ABSCI, and NEVERED are required for pathogen-trigger abission to occur. We also found that phytoalexin deficient 4, disease 1, sallic acid-deficient 2, and senescence-associated 101 plants with mutations in genes necessary for bacterial and sallic acid signaling and NahG transgenic plants with low sallic fail to abise leaves normally. Bacteria that contact abission zones trigger abission, but long signals are also sent from distal tissue to abission, alerting abission of danger. We propose a model regulating leaf defense where minor infections are handled by bacterial growth, but when infection is out of control, leaves are shed.
Retinal starburst amacrine cells (SACs) play a major role in the detection of motion direction in the retina. They generate larger dendritic Ca2+ signals when motion is from their soma towards their dendrites than in the opposite direction. To study the mechanisms underlying direction selectivity (DS) in SACs, we measured responses to expanding and contracting circular visual stimuli via somatic whole-cell recordings and quantified using Fourier analysis. We found that fundamental and especially harmonic frequency components were larger for expanding stimuli. This persists in the presence of GABA and glycine receptor antagonists, suggesting that inhibitory interactions are not essential. The presence of harmonics indicates nonlinearity, as the relationship between harmonic amplitudes and potential indicates is likely due to activation of voltage-gated channels.Ca2+ changes in SACs evoked by steps monitored by two-photon microscopy suggest that distal dendrite is tonically depolarized relative to soma, in part by resting mediated by tonic glutamgic synaptic, and high-voltage–activated Ca+ channels at rest.
Parasites are a diverse group of pathogens that cause a wide range of diseases in humans. The number of parasites required to infect a host, termed the infective dose, varies dramatically across species. It has been predicted that the infect dose depends on the mode of action of molecules used by the parasite to infect. Specifically, parasites that use locally acting molecules require a lower infect dose than those that use distantly acting molecules. It has also been predicted that distantly acting modulators may be more virulent because they have a large number of cells in the inoculum, which cause more harm to host cells. We tested these predictions for the first time using data on 43 parasites from a range of taxonomic groups with diverse life histories. We found that locally acting parasites have lower infect doses but are not more virulent than distantly acting. Instead, we found virulence was negatively correlated with infect dose and higher in parasites infecting skin compared to ingested or inhaled.
Schistosomes are parasitic helminths that cause schistosomiasis, a disease that affects approximately 200 million people, primarily in underprivileged regions of the world. Schistos mansoni is the most experimentally tractable schosome due to its ease of propagation in the laboratory and high quality of its genome and annotation. In this study, we investigated the role of microRNAs (miRNAs) in the developmental processes of schistosomes. We used the bioinformatics tool Sanger to analyse the 3’-UTRs of transcripts differentially expressed between juvenile and adult worms. We found that the miR-277/498 family is significantly enriched in the transition from juvenile to adult worms. We also identified a novel miRNA, sma-mi-498 that is proximal to smi-277, suggesting they form a miRNA cluster. We propose hairpin structures for both miRNAs compatible with the miRNA pathway. We found that smi-277/498 are upregulated in adults while their predicted targets are downregulated in adults but remain unchanged in immature females. Finally, we show that smi-498 is expressed in tegument cells proximal to oesophagus and throughout male body.
Since 2005, a number of SARS-related coronaviruses (SARS-CoV) have been detected in horseshoe bats in different areas of China. However, these SARS-Co show differences from SARS (SARS-CoV) in genes and are unlikely to be the direct progenitor of SARSV. Here, we report the findings of 5-year surveillance of SARS-Co in a cave inhabited by multiple horsesh bats in Yunn Province, China. The full genomes of 11 newly SARS-Co strains, together with previous findings, show that S-Co circulating in this location are highly diverse in OR3 and OR8. Importantly, strains with high similarity to S-Co in hyperviable N-terminal (NTD) and receptor-binding domain (RBD) of S gene OR3 OR8 were discovered in this cave. In addition, we report the discovery of S-Co highly similar to S-Co in OR3 and OR8. Moreover, S-Co from this cave are more related to S-Co in non-structural genes OR1 and compared to those elsewhere. Recombination analysis shows frequent recombination events in gene around OR8 between S-Co. We hypothesize the progenitor S may have originated after recombination between precursors S-Co.
Soil-transmitted helminth (STH) infections are controlled by mass drug treatment of people in endemic areas with benzimidazole and imthiazole drugs. However, high levels of resistance have developed in roundworms of livestock. To monitor drug efficacy in humans, the faecal egg reduction test (FECRT) measures faecal output pre- and post-treatment. We examined the impact of density dependent fecundity on ECRT. In canine hookworms, density dependent egg production shows a dynamic response to treatment. This affects drug efficacy and resistance measurements. Surviving worms may respond to relaxation of density constraints by increasing egg output compared to pre-treatment levels. This underestimates drug efficacy in ECRT. The degree of underestimation depends on worms’ ability to increase output, which depends on extent output prior to treatment. Worms in humans will be at different densities prior ECRT, so effects may vary within groups. Measurement may be improved by ensuring consistent underestimation in groups. This may be achieved by omitting heaviest cases from ECRT as they may increase output upon removal of density constraints. This highlights the need for new resistance methods examining drug effects on worms in vitro or changes in genotypes.
Epithelial heparan sulfate (HS) plays a crucial role in regulating Sonic Hedgehog (SHH) signaling during lung development. SHH is a key regulator of branching morphogenesis, the process by which the mammalian lung acquires its tree-like structure. In this study, we show that deletion of HS synthet1, the enzyme responsible for HS synthesis, results in abnormal lung development. Lungs with Ext1 mutant mice have expanded branching tips and reduced branching, as well as mesenchymal defects. We further show that fibroblast growth factor 10 (FGF10) expression and signaling are increased in Ext1 mutant lungs, suggesting a non-autonomous mechanism. This is consistent with reduced SH signaling, which suppresses F10 expression. Moreover, reactivating SH signaling in mutant lungs rescues the tip phenotype and attenuates F signaling. Importantly, reduced SH activity is not due to decreased Shh expression or protein stability, but rather reduced biologically active SH proteins in both Ext mutant epithelium and wild type mesenchym cells.
Paired-end sequencing has emerged as a powerful tool for detecting genome rearrangements and structural variations on a genome-wide scale. This technique is particularly useful for detecting copy-neutral rearrangements, such as inversions and translocations, which are common in cancer and produce novel genes. Rearrangement breakpoints are difficult to detect because they are rare and often small. We derive a formula for the probability that a fusion exists in a genome given a collection of paired-end sequences. We use this formula to compute fusion probabilities in breast cancer samples and find that we can accurately predict genes with a small number of fragments. We demonstrate that fusion detection depends on gene length distribution and evaluate how sequencing parameters impact breakpoint detection, localization, and gene detection in the presence of false rearrangements.
Chemotaxis is the process by which cells move in response to chemical stimuli. It is composed of three interrelated processes: motility, sensing, and polarization. We propose that these processes are mediated by separate modules that account for each process individually and, and when combined, recreate chemotactic behaviors. Here, we describe a mathematical model where these modules are implemented in terms of reaction-diffusion equations. Migration and accompanying changes in cellular morphology are demonstrated in simulations using a mechanical model of the cell implemented in the level framework.
Tudor Domain Containing 6 (TDR6) is a male germ cell-specific protein that is essential for the formation of the chromatoid body and elongated spermatid, as well as male fertility. In meiotic prophase I spermatocytes, DR6 interacts with protein arginine methyltransferase 5 (PRMT5), which is involved in splicing. DR6 also associates with spliceosomal protein Sm in the absence of RNA and in an arginine methylation dependent manner. In DR6 deficient spermatocytes, PR5 association with Sm and arginine methylation of Sm are reduced. DR6 deficiency impairs assembly of spliceosomes, resulting in 3.5-fold increased levels of U snRNAs in the nucleus. These deficiencies in spliceosome maturation correlate with decreased numbers of SMN-positive bodies and Cajal bodies involved in snRNA maturation. Transcript analysis of DR6 deficient spermatocytes reveals high levels of splicing defects such as aberrant intron and exon usage as well as aberrant splice junctions.
Bacterial populations that colonize a host can play important roles in health by serving as reservoirs for transmission to other hosts and from which invasive strains emerge, emphasizing the importance of understanding rates of acquisition and clearance of colonizing populations. Previous studies of colonization dynamics have been based on assessment of whether samples represent a single or distinct colonization events. However, this approach is often inadequate to account for the diversity of the underlying within-host population, the time between consecutive measurements and the uncertainty in estimated rates. Here, we present a Bayesian model that provides probabilities of whether strains should be considered the same, allowing to determine acquisition and clearance from sampled over time. Our method models the within-host population using genetic simulation and is done using a combination of Approximate Bayesian Computation ( ABC ) and Markov Chain Monte Carlo ( MCM ). We validate the method with simulations and demonstrate its use by analyzing a collection of methicillin resistant Staphlococcus aureus ( MRSA ) isolates from a longitudinal study.
Plants generate new organs through the activity of stem cell populations called meristems. The shoot apical meristem initiates leaves, flowers, and lateral merist in highly ordered, spiralled or whor patterns via a process called phyllaxis. Auxin transport plays a major role in this process. Current hypotheses propose that hormone transporters of the PIN family create auxin maxima at precise positions, leading to organ initiation. To explain how transporters create distinct auxin fluxes within the plant, different concepts have been proposed. Canalization suggests transporters amplify and stabilize existing fluxes, which could be initiated by diffusion. This explains organized auxin flux during vein formation, but shoot apical meristem requires a second hypothesis where hormone is transported towards areas with highest concentrations. This implies two different mechanisms for PIN in the membrane, based on sensing flux and concentration. Because patterning requires hundreds of cells, it is impossible to estimate if a scenario is plausible. Therefore, modelling provides a means to test this type of hypothesis. Using a computer tool, we show that flux polarization is able to explain auxin at shootistem, providing a unifying concept for auxin control in the plant.
Visceral leishmanias (VL) is a parasitic disease caused by Leishmania parasites transmitted by sandflies. Early detection and monitoring of the disease are required for effective treatment. Previous studies have shown that IgG1 is a potential biomarker for VL, but crude antigen ( CL ) used in rapid diagnostic tests ( RDTs ) may not be sufficient. Here, we combined bioinformatic tools with wet lab experiments to develop improved RDTs. We identified L.ovani protein as a potential antigen by immunoblot, which was confirmed by mass spectrometry. We searched for proteins with constitutive expression and antigenic domains accessible to B-cells, and selected candidates with linear epitopes predicted in silico. Epitopes from shortlisted proteins were screened in peptide arrays, and the most promising was tested in RDT prototypes. Over 90% of proteins from immunoblot did not satisfy selection criteria and were excluded from epitope mapping. Screening predicted epitopes from shortlisted identified the most reactive, with 84% (95% CI 60–97 ) sensitivity for Ig1 in Sudan VL sera RDT. None from nonendemic healthy controls were positive. We employed sil searches to reduce lab experiments, focusing on candidates with selected features. By predicting epitopes inico we screened large peptides, identifying the most promising for Ig1 sensitivity and specificity. This proof-of-concept strategy can be applied to RDT development for clinical status in VL.
Cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) is a zoonotic disease caused by Leishmania parasites transmitted by sandflies. Caseating granulomas are often associated with mycobacterial infections such as tuberculosis (TB) and are thought to be rare in CL. However, no large series have documented the incidence of caseating granomas in CL. We reviewed a multiregional cohort of 317 patients with CL from Syria (157), Pakistan (66), Lebanon (47), Saudi Arabia (43), Ethiopia (2) and Iran (2). All cases were confirmed by PCR followed by restriction length polymorphism analysis and were negative for other organisms. Granulomas were identified in 195 (61. 5%) of CL cases and were divided into caseating (25.2%), suppurative (4.6%) and tuberculoid without necrosis (70.%). Caseating and tuboid granoma groups were different in terms of geographical source with more cases in Saudi Arabia (p<0.000). Histologically both groups were different in distribution of Ridley’s pattern (p<.000) with doubling 3 in caseating granomas (31%) vs 5 in tuboid granoma (38%). Time to achieve healing was shorter in tuboid vs case group (4.0 vs.6.2 months. Parasitic index, species and other variables did not differ between granoma groups. In multiregional cohort, notable 18.2% of CL cases harbored caseating granomas; CL should be considered in differential for cases with caseating granomas in endemic regions.
Polygenic type 2 diabetes in mice is associated with obesity and results from a combination of adipogenic and diabetogenic alleles. Here we report the identification of a candidate gene for the diabetogenic effect of QTL NiddJ, contributed by the SJ, NON, and NZ strains in cross with New Zealand Obese ( NZ ) mice. A critical interval of distal chromosome 4 ( 2. 1 M ) conferring the diabetic phenotype was identified by interval-specific congenic introgression of SJ into diabetes-resistant CBL/6, and subsequent cross with NZ. Analysis of 10 genes in the interval by sequencing, q–PCR, and RT–PCR revealed a striking allelic variation of Zfp encoding zinc finger transcription factor 69. In NZ and C57/6, a retrotranson ILTRa in intron 3 disrupted the gene formation of a truncated mRNA lacking the coding for KR ( Krüpp-associated ) and Znf2 domains of Zfp, whereas diabetogenic SJ, NON, and NZ generated a normal mRNA. When combined with B–Lob background the diabetic ZfpSJ allele produced hyperglycemia, reduced gonadal fat, and increased plasma and liver triglyceride levels. mRNA of human orthologue Zfp, Z642 were significantly increased in adipose from patients with type 2 diabetes. We conclude Zfp is most likely the candidate for diabet effect of Nidd, and retrotranson ILTRa contributes to genetic heterogeneity of strains. Expression of transcription in adipose may play a role in pathogenesis type 2.
In this paper, we propose an integrated model of the regulatory network and signalling pathways controlling cell differentiation in the vertebrate hematopoietic system. We use a formalism to perform dynamical analyses of the available qualitative data. To cope with the size and complexity of the network, we use an original reduction approach with a stable identification algorithm. We assess the effects of heterogeneous environments on cell differentiation by performing a series of simulations considering prototypic environments. We identify stable states corresponding to Th1, Th, Th and Treg subtypes that coexist with transient cell types coexpressing combinations of Th, Th, Treg and Th markers in an environment-dependent fashion. Our analysis highlights the nature of these types and their relationships with canonical subtypes.
Transcription factors are proteins that regulate gene expression during animal development by binding to thousands of genomic regions. However, the forces that determine where, when, and to what extent they bind remain poorly understood. Here, we use a thermodynamic model of transcription factor binding to evaluate the contribution of biophysical forces to the binding of five regulators of early embryonic-posterior patterning in Drosophila melanogaster. The model predicts binding based on DNA and protein affinities achieves a correlation of ∼0. 4 with experimental measurements in vivo. Incorporating cooperativity and competition among the factors and spatial patterning in every nucleus has little effect on accuracy. A major source of error is the prediction of events that do not occur in vivo, hypothesized to reflect reduced chromatin accessibility. We test this by incorporating measurements of genome-wide DNA into our model, restricting binding to regions of chromatin. This improves predictions to ∼0.6–.9 for various factors across target genes. Finally, we use our model to quantify the roles of DNA, accessibility, and cooperativity. Our results show that in chromatin, binding can be predicted by the sequence of individual factors, with minimal for interactions.
In Drosophila imaginal discs, the transcription factors Daughterless (Da) and Extramacchaetea (Em) are the only members of the basic helix-loop-helix (bHL) protein family that regulate cell proliferation. These factors are frequently deregulated in cancerous cells. We show that Em controls the G2/M transition and proliferation in epithelial cells of imaginal discs via Da. The main activator of this transition is the Cdc25 phosphatase string. We show that ectopic expression of string in cells with reduced Em or high Da rescues the proliferative defects in mutants. Moreover, we present evidence that Da is a transcriptional repressor of string. Our findings define a mechanism through which Em controls proliferation by regulating Da, which transcriptionally represses string.
In this study, we propose a comprehensive pipeline for analyzing phosphoproteomics data from interventional experiments to identify key proteins in signaling pathways, protein-protein interactions and infer signaling networks. Phosphoproteomics differs from proteomics by limited sampling due to few detectable sites per protein. We used SILAC ( Stable Isotope Labeling Amino acids in culture ) with interventional kinase-dead experiments. The pipeline includes phosphopeptide meta-analysis, network analysis and causal discovery. We applied it to interventional phosphorylation underlying filamentous growth in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We identified 5 proteins from meta-analysis and 19 from correlation ( P2 and H were both ), all involved in stress. Nine have direct or indirect involvement in filament growth. We tested four predicted N, P, P, P and R by interphenotypic experiments, all present differential growth, validating our approach.
In Drosophila melanogaster, males have one X and one autosomes, while females have two X and one autos. The evolution of heteromorphic sex chromosomes has led to the evolution of two kinds of chromosome-specific regulation: dosage compensation and meiotic inactivation. Dosage compensation is the equalization of X gene expression in males and females, while meiotic inactivation is the silencing and heterochatinization of the X during meiosis in the male or female gerine. In Drosila, the X is regulated in the male germline is unclear. Here, we report three findings concerning X expression in Drosila testes. First, X-wide dosage compensation is absent in most Dila male germl. Second, microarray analysis provides no evidence for X-specific inactivation during meiosis. Third, we confirm that expression of reporters driven by autos spermatogenesis promoters is strongly reduced when inserted on X versus autos; this difference is established premeiotic and persists meiotic.
Enteropathogenic E. coli (EPEC) is a major cause of diarrheal disease in humans and can be modeled by Citrobacter rodium infection in mice. The pathogenesis of both species depends on their ability to form epithelium-adherent microcolonies, also known as “attachment/effacement” (A) lesions. These microcolonies must be dynamic and able to self-renew by continuous re-infection of the regenerating epithelium. We show that colonic epithelial A microcolonies are clonal populations and depend on local growth to persist. In wild mice, microies are established within 18 hours of infection. These events shape intestinal geography and severity of infection despite presence of virulent luminal bacteria. Mechanistically, resistance to A lesion formation is mediated by TLR-My88/Tr-dependent and induced by virulent C. rodium in vir-dependent manner. Our data show that C rodium pathogenesis in vivo is restricted to short window that determines disease and severity.
Measuring the overlap between two populations can be done directly by counting the number of shared objects upon fully sampling both populations. However, in practice, only a fraction of each population’s objects are likely to be sampled due to data collection or sequencing limitations. Although methods exist for quantifying overlap under subsampled conditions, their bias is well-documented and the uncertainty of their estimates cannot be quantified. Here, we derive and validate a method to rigorously estimate population overlap from incomplete samples when the number of objects in each population is known. This is a special case of the general β-diversity problem, particularly relevant in ecology and epidemiology of malaria. By solving a Bayesian inference, this method takes into account subsampling rates and produces unbiased Bayes-optimal estimates of overlap. In addition, it provides a framework for computing the uncertainty of its estimates and can be used in planning by quantifying the tradeoff between sampling and uncertainty.
Protein kinases are a family of enzymes that regulate most cellular functions by phosphorylating proteins. They have a conserved catalytic core that oscillates between open, intermediate, and closed conformations. However, the intramolecular interactions that regulate these conformational changes are not well understood. Using cAMP-dependent protein kinase as a model, we identified a set of conserved electrostatic and hydrophobic interactions that regulate the active state. These include a salt bridge between lysine from β-strand and glutamate from α-helix as well as electrostatic interaction between phosphorylated loop and α-helix and hydrophobic residues of Regulatory Shell.
American Samoa conducted seven rounds of mass drug administration (MDA) for lymphatic filariasis (LF) from 2000–2006 under the Global Programme to Eliminate Lymphatic Filariasis. The World Health Organization recommends systematic post-MDA surveillance using Transmission Assessment Surveys (TAS) for epidemiological assessment of recent LF transmission. We compared the effectiveness of two survey designs for post-M surveillance: school-based survey of children aged 6–7 and community-based survey of people ≥8. In 2016, we conducted a school-based TAS in all elementary schools (N=29) and a survey in 28 villages on two main islands of American. We collected information on demographics and risk factors using electronic questionnaires, and geo-locations of schools and households. Blood samples were collected to test for circulating filarial antigen (CFA) using Alere Filasis Strip. For positive, we prepared slides for microscopic examination microfilar and provided. Descriptive statistics were performed for variables. Data were weighted to account for design and sex both surveys and age in community. The school TAS (n=114) identified antigen-positive children and overall C prevalence 0.7% (95%CI:0–.8) Of positive, we identified microilar 7-year-old. The survey (n=7,711) identified antigen people and overall C prevalence 6.% (95%CI4–.6) Adjusted village prevalence ranged –. C prevalence increased age and was in males. antigen community from whom slides prepared 25.% were microilar. School TAS had sensitivity range– and predictive value range– but specificity range and value– for identifying villages ongoing. The TAS failed in 201, survey identified higher numbers antigen people. School was logistically simpler sampling larger population but results did not overall prevalence older groups and not identifying foci transmission. survey, although operationally identified individuals ages and foci high. Both confirmed recrudence transmission.
Sex determination in zebraf is a complex and polygenic trait, influenced by multiple genetic and environmental factors. The role of germ cells, particularly oocytes, in sex determination is well established, as animals lacking germ cells or oocytes develop exclusively as males. However, oocytes are also required throughout adult life to maintain the female phenotype. We report a novel role for the oocyte-produced molecule Bmp in maintaining female differentiation in zraf. Females lacking Bmp develop normally but switch sex during mid to late juvenile stage and become fertile. We also show that estrogen is necessary for female development and that Bmp function in sex maintenance is linked to regulation of estrogen biosynthesis via promoting development of estrogen-producing granulosa cells in oocyte.
Hox proteins are key regulators of morphogenesis along the anterior–posterior body axis of animals by controlling distinct sets of target genes within their broad expression domains. Individual Hox proteins control cell diversification and patterning and target gene expression in a highly localized manner, sometimes only in a single cell. To achieve this high regulatory specificity, it has been proposed that Hox proteins co-operate with other transcription factors to activate or repress their targets in a highly context-dependent manner in vivo. Here, we describe the regulation of the cell death gene reaper (pr ) by the Hox protein Deformed (fd ). We show that activation ofpr in the anterior part of the maxillary segment is achieved through a combinatorial interaction offd with at least eight functionally diverse transcriptional regulators on a minimal enhancer. This suggests that context-dependent combinations of H proteins and other factors on small, modular H response elements (HREs ) could be responsible for the spatio-temporal expression of H targets.
Plant innate immunity is mediated by the recognition of pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) at the cell surface and inside the cell. Pathogen effectors (virulence factors) are monitored by intracellular nucleotide-binding leucine-rich repeat (NB-LRR) proteins in plants. Here, we study the genetic requirements for defense responses of an autoactive ADR1-L2, an Arabidopsis coiled-coil (CC)-NB-LRR protein. ADR-L functions upstream of salicylic acid (SA) accumulation in several defense contexts and can act as a helper to transduce specific activation from sensor NB-LRs. This activity does not require an intact P-loop. ADR-L and two closely related NB-L members are required for propagation of unregulated cell death in l1 mutant. We demonstrate that in this context A-L function is P-dependent. We generated an autoactive missense A1-LD484 in a homology motif M. Expression of A-LD leads to dwarf plants with increased resistance and constitutive high SA. The phenotype also requires intact P, suggesting A-LD phenotypes reflect canonical NB activation. We used A-LD to define requirements for signaling. Signaling from A does not require NAD oxidase and is negatively regulated by E1 and MC. Transcription of A is correlated with phenotypic outputs; these are SA-dependent and-independent. The requirements resemble SA-dependent signal amplification of death observed in absence. Importantly A autoactivation is controlled by E and SA separable but linked.
In Arabidopsis thaliana, two components of the RNA-directed DNA methylation (RdDM) pathway, SUVH and ID2, interact with MOR6 to mediate transcriptional silencing. SUV2 and SUV9 can act in the same pathway as MOR6 or synergistically with MOR6 to mediate silencing, while ID2 interacts with MOR6 to mediate silencing of a subset of MOR target loci. Other RDM components, including IV, V, R2, and DRM2, are also required for silencing at a subset of MOR6 loci. MOR6 was previously shown to mediate silencing through heterochrom condensation. We demonstrate that SWI/SNF chromatin-remodeling components SWI, SWI, and SW interact with MOR6 as well as SUV9 to mediate silencing. These results suggest that RDM components are not only involved in methylation but also in MOR6-mediated heterrom condensation. This study illustrates how methylation is linked to heterrom condensation and enhances silencing at methylated regions.
Heat shock protein 90 (Hsp90) is a molecular chaperone that has been shown to buffer genetic variation in phenotypes in both flies and plants. In vertebrates, the protective role of H90 could account for the variable penetrance and severity of some developmental malformations. We used zebraf as a model to study the effects of H90 inhibition on development. In wild-type zraf, H90 inhibition did not induce a heat shock response or perturb phenotype. However, H90 inhibition increased the severity of the recessive eye phenotype caused by the paxb mutation and decreased the severity of the eye phenotype caused by the su mutation. In addition, H90 inhibition uncovered a previously unobserved spectrum of severe eye malations reminiscent of anophthalmia, microphthalm, and nanthalmia in humans. Inbreeding of offspring from unaffected parents led to elevated malformation frequencies and revealed the oligogenic nature of this phenotype. Unlike Drosoph, H90 inhibition decreased developmental stability in zraf, as indicated by increased presentation of anophthalm, microphthalm, nanthalm and sunrise phenotypes. Analysis of the paxb mutation suggests a molecular mechanism for buffering by H90. The zraf studies imply that mild perturbation of H90 at developmental stages may underlie the penetrance and expressivity of developmental anomalies where genotype and environment interact.
N-terminal acetylation is a post-translational modification in which the N-terminus of a nascent polypeptide chain is co-translationally acetylated after the removal of the initiating methion residue. In Drosophila melanogaster, we identified more than 1, 200 mature N-terminally acetylated proteins and found that N-terminal acety occurs with similar frequency to humans. We extracted the X PX rule as the sole determinant of N-terminal acety, indicating that acetylation occurs under all circumstances. This rule was used to engineer proteins to study the biological relevance of acetylation by generating a generic assay to probe the importance of N-terminal acety. We applied the assay by expressing mutated proteins in cell lines and flies. We present a strategy to systematically study the relevance of N-terminal acylation in cells and organisms.
The ability of RNA polymerase III (RNAP III) to recycle from termination to reinitiation is essential for abundant tRNA production during cellular proliferation and development, as well as in cancer. However, the mechanisms of termination used by RN III are incompletely understood, and its link to high transcription output is unclear. We used tRNA-mediated suppression to screen for RNAP mutants with gain and loss of termination phenotypes in Schizosaccharomyces pombe. 122 mutants were mapped to the recently solved 3. 9 Å structure of yeast RN III elongation complex (EC) ; they cluster in the active bridge helix and loop, as well as the pore and funnel, the latter indicating involvement of the cleavage domain of the C subunit in termination. Purified RN III from a readthrough (RT) mutant exhibits increased elongation rate. The data support a kinetic model in which elongation rate is inversely related to termination. The mutants exhibit correlations of RT in vitro and in vivo, as well as amounts in vivo. Because in vivo can be confounded by parameters, we used a tRNA with a processing defect and strong terminator. ruling out differences in RNA rates, the indicate mutants with RT phenotype synthesize more than wild type, and can be accounted by increased rate. Finally, increased by mutants appears unrelated to III repressor. The results show the elements of III active, including, are determinants of termination and some activate III for transcription.
Many protein-protein interactions remain uncharacterized by current experimental methods. We developed a method to predict SH2-mediated protein-protein interactions using the structure of SH-phosphopeptide complexes and the FoldX algorithm. We show that our method performs similarly to experimentally derived consensus and substitution matrices for known in vitro and in vivo targets of SH domains. We used our method to predict a set of high-confidence interactions for human SH domains with known filtered secondary structure and phosphorylation state. We validated predictions using literature-derived SH interactions and a probabilistic score from naive Bayes integration of coexpression, conservation of interaction in other species, shared partners, and functions.
Accumulation of amyloidogenic proteins is a hallmark of neurodegenerative disorders. In tauopathies, such as Alzheimer’s disease ( AD, aberrant accumulation of microtubule associating protein ( MAP, tau ) into toxic oligomers and amyloid deposits is a primary pathology. Tau is an intrinsically disordered protein, enriched with proline residues that regulate secondary structure and aggregation. The orientation of proline residues is regulated by cis peptid-proly isomerases ( Pases. Here, we show that cyclophil 40 ( Cy40 ), a Pase, dissolves tau amyloids in vitro. Additionally, Cy40 ameliorated oligomeric tau in a mouse model of accumulation, preserving neuronal health and cognition.
Heteroc differentiation in cyanobacteria filaments is one of the simplest examples of cellular differentiation and pattern formation in multicellular organisms. However, the knowledge of the genetic circuit underlying the behavior of a single cyanobacter under nitrogen deprivation is still unknown. Here, we explore heteroc differentiation under the paradigm of systems biology. We formulate the dynamical ingredients of the genetic circuit of a cyanacter into a set of differential equations describing the evolution of the concentrations of the molecular products. We study the behavior of a cyanacter under external conditions, emulating nitrogen deprivation and simulate the dynamics of cyanacteria by their respective circuits via diffusion. This allows us to understand the principles by which heteryst can be generated and sustained. Our results show that including diffusion and external conditions in the model, we can reproduce the features of formation and sustainment of heteryst in cyanacteria as observed experimentally.
Despite the success of the Community Directed Treatment with Ivermect (DTI) program in the fight against oncherciasis in Africa, onchias prevalence remains above the transmission threshold in Cameroon after more than 15 years of mass treatment. This study aimed to explore the association between people’s perceptions of onchias and DTI, and adherence toiverect in three regions of Cameroon. A cross-sectional survey was carried out in three districts with high onchias prevalence. Participants were randomly selected in 30 clusters per district. Adherence toiverect was comparable in Bang and Bafia (55. 0% and 48.8%, respectively, p>.05 ) and lower in Yab (40.7%. Among factors related to program and disease representations, perceptions of the program were most determinant of adherenceiver. People with a “not” opinioniverect campaigns were less compliant than those with a positive opinion (40% vs 55 in Bang, 48 vs 62 in Bafia p.01, as well as those with negative appreciation of distributors’ commitment (22 vs 53 in Bang 33 vs 59 inafia 27 vs 47 Yab p.01. The most common misconception waschias transmission was lack of hygiene, especially inafia and Yab. In Bang, high proportions believedchias due to sugar consumption (31 vs less inafia and Yassi p.001. There are frequent misconceptions aboutchias transmission in Cameroon. Perceptionsiverect campaigns are strongly associated with adherence.
The contribution of DNA methylation and genetic variants on protein biomarkers for human diseases was investigated in this study. We combined DNA methylation and genetic data with protein biomarkers for cancer and cardiovascular disease to investigate the relative contribution of genetic and epigenetic variation on biomarker levels. A total of 121 protein biomarkers were analyzed in relation to DNA methylation at 470,000 positions and over 10 million SNPs. We performed epigen-wide study (EW) and genome-wide study (GW) analyses, and integrated biomarker DNA and methylation data between 698 and 103 samples depending on availability. We identified 124 loci with effect up 0.22 units change per 1% DNA methylation and up four units per copy allele in EW and GW respectively. Most GW loci were cis-regulatory whereas EW loci were trans. Eleven EW loci were associated with multiple biomarkers, one with NL5 associated CX11, CX9,12, and levels. All EW signals overlapped with GW locus were driven by variants and EW signals were confounded by smoking. While cis SNPs for biomarkers had effect on methylation, SNPs for methylation did not affect biomarkers. We present associations between biom and methylation at loci in the genome.
Natural killer (NK) cells are important effectors of the innate immune response against varicella zoster virus (VZV) infection. We demonstrate that VV potently impairs the ability of NK cells to respond to target stimulation in vitro, leading to loss of cytotoxic and cytokine responses. This impairment is not only observed in VV infected NK cells, but also in V negative NK cells exposed to virus in culture. The impairment is dependent on direct contact between NK cells and VV infected cells. Profiling of NK surface receptors by multiparameter flow cytometry reveals that receptor expression is predominantly stable. However, NK cells are still capable of releasing cytotoxic granules when stimulation is bypassed, suggesting that V paralyses NK from responding. Examination of the degranulation signalling cascade reveals perturbation following VV culture. In addition to inhibiting degranulation, IF-γ and TN production are repressed by VV culture, most strongly inV infected NK. Interestingly, closely related herpes virus simplex type 1 (HSV-1) also efficiently infects NK in cell-associated manner and renders NK unresponsive to target stimulation. However, HSV differentially targets cytokine production compared VV.
Apparent motion (AM) is a phenomenon in which two alternately presented stimuli at different locations evoke a perception of a stimulus moving between the locations. The neural mechanism underlying AM is thought to be increased activation of primary visual cortex (V1) neurons tuned to locations along the AM path. However, evidence remains inconclusive. AM masking, which refers to reduced detectability of stimuli along AM, has been taken as evidence for AM-related V1 activation. AM-induced responses are thought to interfere with responses to physical stimuli along path and impair perception of these stimuli. However, AM can also be explained by predictive models, predicting responses to stimuli on AM are suppressed when match spatio-temporal prediction of stimulus along path. In this study, we find AM has distinct effect on detection of gratings, limiting performance at high levels. This is strongest when target is identical to orientation of inducers. We developed V-like model of early processing based on standard normalization. We find AM-related in V is too small to cause masking or perceived motion. Our instead predicts suppression early during AM consistent with predictive framework.
Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV-1) oncoprotein Tax plays a key role in the transformation of CD4+ T cells by promoting cell proliferation and survival, mainly through the activation of the NF-κB pathway and induction of NF-κB target genes. To understand the underlying mechanism of HTLV-1-mediated transformation, it is critical to elucidate the mechanism of Tax-induced NF-κB activation. Current studies have suggested multiple controversial mechanisms regarding Tax-induced IK activation mainly due to blending of primary Tax-induced IK events and secondary IK events induced by cytokines secreted by Tax-induced IK-NF-κ activation. Here, we reconstituted Tax-stimulated IK activation in a cell-free system to dissect the essential components for IK activation by Tax and the underlying biochemical mechanism. We found that Tax is a putative E3 ubiquitin ligase, which, together with Ubc2, U5, or U7 catalyzes the assembly of mixed-link polyubiquitin chains. These mixed-link polyubitin chains are responsible for IK activation by binding to the NEM subunit of IK. Our studies revealed the biochemical function of Tax in IK activation which utilizes minimal ubiquitination components for NF-κ activation.
Species invasions: A Meta-Analysis of the Propagule Pressure Effect. The success of an alien species appears to depend on the number of individuals introduced to a population (propagule pressure). However, the form of this relationship has been largely unexplored. We present the first quantitative review of this, using meta-analytical methods. The relationship between propagule pressure and success has been evaluated for a range of taxa including invertebrates, herbaceous plants, long-lived trees, and aquatic vertebrates. We found a positive effect of propagule pressure on success in every hypothesis tested. However, success most depended on propagules in the range of 10–100. Heterogeneity in effect was associated with analytical approaches, with evidence of larger sizes in animal than plant introductions. No variation was accounted for by scale ( field to global ) or methodology ( observational, experimental, proxy ).
Interleukin 17 (IL-17) is a cytokine implicated in chronic and severe inflammatory diseases that enhances the production of pro-inflammatory mediators by attenuating the decay of encoding mRNAs. The decay of these mRNAs depends on AU-binding proteins (AUBPs) that target AU-rich elements in the 3′-UTR of mRNAs and facilitate either decay or stabilization. Here, we show that AUB and target mRNAs assemble in a ribonucleoprotein complex in the presence of microRNA (miR16), leading to degradation of target mRNAs. Notably, IL-17 attenuates miR expression and promotes binding of stabilizing AUB over destabilizing AUB, reducing decay. These findings indicate miR independently of sequence directs competition between degrading and stabilizing AUB for mRNAs. Since AUB affect about 8% of human transcriptome and miR is ubiquitously expressed, IL- may in addition to inflammation affect other cellular processes.
Sleeping sickness, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense and Trypanosoma brucei brucei, is a major public health problem in Uganda. The disease has two forms: acute and chronic. Acute sleeping sickness is considered to be restricted to the southeast of the country, while the chronic form is confined to the northwest. However, acute sleeping has been spreading to new areas, linked to the movement of infected cattle. Cattle are long-term reservoirs of human infective T. brodesense, showing few signs of morbidity yet posing significant risk to human health. This paper examines the relationship between cattle and human T brucei infection in villages in Kaberido and Dokolo Districts, Uganda. The study was undertaken in villages that had a case of sleeping in the six months prior to sample and those that never had a case. Sleeping status of villages had a significant effect on odds of infection in cattle from case than non-case villages for brucei (OR 2. 94, 95%CI 1.38–6.24 ). Cattle age had a significant effect on the likelihood of bruce infection within cattle between 18–36 (OR 3.51,95CI 1.63–7.51 ) and over 36 (4.20,95CI 2.08.67 ) had higher odds of bruce than under 18 months. Village sleeping status had a significant effect on detection of br in cattle, with higher likelihood in case villages (25,95CI 1.2–520.71 ). Overall higher bruce prevalence >16.3 in a herd was associated with higher br being detected in a herd (25,95CI 1.2–520.71 )
In Drosophila, the major histone H4 lysine 16 (H4 ) acetyltransferase MO is involved in the regulation of X-chrom and autosomal genes as part of the MSL and NS complexes. While the function of MSL as a dosage regulator is well understood, the role of NS in gene regulation is poorly characterized. Here, we report a comprehensive Ch–seq analysis of four NS members (,,,,, and ) throughout the D melanogaster genome. Strikingly, 85% of NS-bound genes are constitutively expressed across cell types. We find an abundance of H4ac, H3me, H3, and H9 in promoter regions characteristic of NS-target genes. Furthermore, these genes have well-defined nucleosome region and broad initiation patterns. By Ch– analyses of RNA polymerase II ( II ) in NS1 and NS3-depleted cells, we show that both are required for efficient II recruitment to NS promoters. II reduction coincides with binding of TBP and TIB to promoters, indicating the NS is required for optimal recruitment of the-initiation on genes Moreover, that undergo most loss upon NS tend to be enriched Replication Element ( ).
Facioscapulhumeral dystrophy (FD) is a progressive muscular dystrophy caused by decreased epigenetic repression of the D4 macrosatellite repeats and ectopic expression of DUX, a retrogene encoding a germline transcription factor encoded in repeat. Individuals generally have more than 10 repeats in the subtelomeric region of chromosome 4, whereas the most common form of FD (FD1) is caused by contraction of array to fewer than 10, associated with decreased epigen repression and variegated DUX in muscle. We have generated transgenic mice carrying D4 arrays from FD allele and a control allele. These recapitulate epigen and DUX expression seen in patients and controls, respectively, high DUX levels in germline ( ), incomplete epigen repression somatic, and FD-specific varieg DUX in sporadic muscle associated D4 chromatin.
Malaria vaccine candidate Apical Membrane Antigen-1 (AMA1) induces protection, but only against parasite strains closely related to the vaccine. Overcoming AMA1 diversity will require understanding the basis of cross-strain inhibition. A vaccine containing diverse AMA1 proteins (AMA1adv) elicited polyclonal antibodies that inhibited invasion of vaccine and non-vaccine strains of Plasmodium falciparum. Comparing polyclonal AMA with strain-specific monoval AMA revealed AMAadv induced higher inhibitory antibodies associated with conserved domain-3 and reduced domain-2 responses. Inhibitory monoclonal (m) against AMA reacted with cross-reactive epitope at hydrophobic domain-1; this epit mapped conserved AMA and encompassed 1-loop. m binding 1-loop (10, 8 and 11) were ∼10 more potent than previously AMA-inhib m and mode of 1-loop m was inhibition AMA binding to ligand RON. Unlike epit of previously 7-specific m, the 1-loop was conserved across strains. Another m, which bound domain, was broadly inhib and blocked proteolytic processing AMA. By m was weakly inhibitory but synergized previously, strain-transending m, which close hydroobic on cons and inhib RON binding AMA. Novel susceptible and epitopes identified can improve antigen breadth and inhibitory of AMA vaccines. Vaccination diverse proteins provide universal by immune towards conserved.
Asymmetric spindle positioning of the mitotic spindle during cell division is important for many cells to divide unequally.
