Recent studies have begun to unveil the molecular mechanisms of mitotic spindle displacement, but little is known about how spindle displacement is precisely timed. A conserved mitotic mechanism is known to time events in dividing cells, but this has never been linked to spindle. Here we show that anaphase-promoting complex ( APC ), its activator C20/Fizzy, its target cyclin, and cycl-dependent kinase ( CD ) comprise a previously unrecognized timer for spindle. In Caenorhabditis zygote mitotic spindle displacement begins at precise time after chromosomes congress to metaphase. We found that reducing function of proteasome APC or C20/Fizzy delayed spindle. Conversely inactivating CD in metaphase caused spindle to displace early. Experimentally unlinking spindle from this mechanism caused displacement of incompletely assembled mitotic components. We conclude that in this system spindle is normally delayed until APC inactivates CD, ensuring spindle does not begin until fully assembled. This is first demonstration that mitotic times spindle in asymmetric division of animal.
Human populations living in high-altitude regions, such as the Andean Plateau and Tibetan Plateau, have evolved unique physiological adaptations to cope with low oxygen levels. However, the genetic basis of these adaptations remains unknown. We performed a genome-wide scan to identify genes showing evidence of adaptation to hypoxia. We looked at each chromosome to identify regions with unknown function with respect to high-altitude phenotypes. We also examined groups of genes involved in oxygen sensing to test the hypothesis that particular pathways have been involved in adaptation to altitude. We applied four genetic statistics to detect signatures of natural selection and identified candidate genes and regions in two populations ( Tibetans and Andeans ) separately. The patterns of genetic adaptation are largely distinct between the two populations, with evidence of selection in different genes or regions. Interestingly, EGLN ( PH2 ) shows evidence of selection in both Tibetans and Andans, but with different patterns of variation. Our results indicate key H-regulatory and targeted genes are responsible for adaptation in Andans and Tibetans, and several chromosomal regions implicated in response to selection. These data suggest a role in high-altitude adaptation and provide basis for future studies to confirm candidate and regions in adaptation to altitude.
Double-strand breaks (DSBs) are a type of DNA damage that can be caused by environmental factors or errors during DNA replication. Repairing DSBs is essential for cell survival, but faulty repair can lead to genetic instability, making the choice of DSB repair pathway important. Here, we show that inverted repeats (IRs) near DSBs can channel repair into a pathway that leads to gene conversion instead of break-induced replication (BIR) that leads to instability. IRs ability to form unusual DNA structures when present in single-strand (ssDNA) formed by DSB resection explains their effect. We demonstrate that IRs can form two types of structures and the choice between these depends on the length of IRs. IRs separated by long spacer (1kb) are involved in intermolecular single-strand annealing (SSA) leading to formation of dimers; IRs by short spacer (12bp) participate intramolecular SSA leading to formation of fold (FB) structures. Both structures interfere with accurate DSB repair by gene conversion and channel DSB into BIR that promotes genomic destabilization. We report that different complexes participate in processing of FB containing short (12bp) versus long (kb) ssDNA. Specifically, FBs short are processed by MRX-Sae complex whereas Rad1-Rad10 is responsible for processing of long. Our studies uncover mechanisms of genomic destabil resulting from re-routing DSB into pathways by IRs.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic pathogen capable of causing both acute and chronic infections in susceptible hosts. Chronic P. aerugin infections are thought to be caused by biofilms, which are highly structured, multicellular microbial communities encased in an extracellular matrix that enable long-term survival in the host. To study P aerugin biofilms in vivo, we developed an animal model using Drosila melanogaster. At 24 h post infection, P. aerugin biofilms localized and were visualized in dissectedrosila crops. These biofilms had a characteristic structure and extracellular matrix composed of DNA and exopolysacide. aerugin cells recovered in vivo biofilms had increased antibiotic resistance relative to planktonic cells. Biofilm formation was dependent on expression of exopolyside genes, as pel:: mutant failed to form biofilms. The:: mutant was more virulent than PA1, while hyperbio strain (Z3 ) demonstrated less virulence than PA1, indicated by survival of infected at 14 postinfection. Biofilm formation by PA1 andZ3 in crop was associated with induction diptericin,ecin A androsycin antimicrobial gene expression 24 postin. Infection with nonbio strain:: resulted in decreased gene expression.
Vasopressin 1 receptor 1 (Av1 ) is a gene involved in mediating vasopress-mediated social behaviors and exhibits remarkable differences in expression patterns between and within species. Previous studies have suggested that the proximal 5′ flanking region and polymorphic microsatellite element of the Av1 gene are associated with variation in V1 receptor (V1R ) distribution and behavior, but have not been causally linked. Here, we used homologous recombination in mice to reveal that the proximal 5′ flanking sequences contribute to species differences in V1R distribution and confirm that V1R impacts behavior in the forced swim test. We also show that the Av1 microsatellite contributes to Av1 expression in the amygdala, thalamus, and hippocampus, mirroring a subset of inter- and intra-species differences in V1 patterns in voles. This is the first evidence that polymorphic microsat elements near behaviorally relevant genes contribute to diversity in brain expression, providing a mechanism for generating diversity at the individual and species level. However, our results suggest that many species-specific patterns are mediated by elements outside the 5′ flanking region of the gene.
Transcription of the switch (S) regions of immunoglobulin genes in B cells generates stable loops that are targeted by Activation-induced cytidine deaminase (A), triggering class switch recombination (CSR), as well as translocations with c-MYC responsible for Burkitt’s lymphomas. In Saccharomyces cerevisiae, stable-loops are formed co-transcriptionally in mutants of TH, a conserved complex involved in mR biogenesis. Such-loops trigger genome instability and deamination by A. To understand the mechanisms that generate genome instability by mR biogenesis and A, we devised a chromosomal system based on segments of mammalian S and cYC for analysis of chromosomal rearrangements in wild-type and TH mutants. We demonstrate that A acts in heterologous and cYC transcribed leading to double-strand breaks (DSBs) which cause chromosomal translocations via Non-hologous Joining (NJ). A–induced translocations were enhanced in TH mutants, consistent with that A–mediated DS depend on-loop.
During cell division in E. coli, the coordination between cell division and chromosome segregation is essential for producing viable progeny. In the commonly accepted view, E. coli achieves this coordination by positioning its division apparatus relative to the nucleoids. However, E. coli can still propagate without proper positioning. Here, we describe how E. coli partitions its chromosomes during asymmetric divisions. Using time-lapse imaging, we show that translocase Fts can pump up to 80% ( 3. 7 Mb ) of the chromosome between daughters at 170±800 bp/s. DNA translocations are rare and we did not observe reversals at experimental scales of minutes. The majority of movement occurs at late division when Zip has dissociated from the septum and the septum has closed to a diameter smaller than 250 nm. Our data suggest the constriction is necessary for translocation by Fts.
The development of epitope-based vaccines (EVs) is based on the knowledge of specific antigens from immunogenic peptides, called epitopes, which are key components of EVs. Due to regulatory, economic, and practical concerns, the number of epitopes that can be included in an EV is limited. Furthermore, the major histocompatibility complex (MHC) binding epitopes is highly polymorphic, every patient possesses a set of MHC I and II molecules differing specificities. A combination effective for one person can be completely ineffective for another. This renders optimal selection of epitopes important. We present a mathematical framework based on integer linear programming (ILP) that allows formulation of various EV design and identification of optimal sets of epitopes from a user-defined set of predicted or experimentally determined epitopes. The framework selects the set with maximum likelihood of eliciting a broad potent immune response. Our IL approach allows formulation of numerous EV design variants. We show how immunological requirements for good EV ( e. g., coverage of epitopes from antigen, coverage of M alleles in set, avoidance of epitopes with high rates ) can be translated into constraints or modifications within IL framework.
Sexual transmission of HIV-1 to the cervico-vaginal mucosa is the most common route of HIV infection in women. Semen is not only a carrier of HIV-1, but also contains biological factors, including cytokines that may affect HIV-1 transmission. We investigated the role of IL-7 in HIV-1 vaginal transmission in an ex vivo human cervico-vaginal tissue system. We simulated in vivo HIV-1 deposition on cervicoaginal tissue in combination with IL-7 concentrations measured in semen of HIV-1-infected individuals. IL-7 significantly enhanced HIV-1 replication in cervicoaginal tissue and lymphoid tissue explants. Analysis of infected cells showed IL-7 reduced CD4 T cell apoptosis, evidenced by decrease in apoptotic marker APO2.7 and increase in anti-apoptotic protein Bcl-2. Also, IL-7 increased CD4 T cell cycling, evidenced by Ki-67 staining.
Zika virus (ZIK) infection in Aedes aegypt cells triggers the production of virus-specific small RNAs that are loaded into the exogenous small interfering RNA (exo-siRNA) pathway. The exo-si pathway is considered the key antiviral response in mosquitoes. In Aedes aegpt cells, ZIK-specific siRNAs are produced and loaded into the exo-si pathway effector protein Argonaute 2 (Ago2), but Ago2 knockdown does not enhance virus replication. Enhanced ZIK replication is observed in Ago2-knock cells, suggesting the exo pathway is involved in antiv response. ZIK-specific piRNAs are produced but lack the characteristic piRNA ping-pong motif and are bound to Ago3 but not Piwi or Piwi. Silencing of Pi proteins indicates Ago, Piwi, or Piwi knockdown does not enhance ZIK replication and only Pi displays antiv activity. We also report that ZIK capsid protein amplifies replication of a reporter virus; unlike yellow fever protein, it does not inhibit exo pathway. Our findings elucidate ZIK-mosquito RNA interactions important for its spread.
Sporotrichosis in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil: Sporothrix brasiliensis Associated with Atypical Presentations  
Sporotrichosis is an infectious disease caused by the fungus Sporothrix schenii. In Rio de Janeiro, Brazil is one of the most endemic areas of sporrichosis in the world. Recently, there have been changes in the taxonomy of Sporoth schenii and new clinical aspects of sporrichosis have been observed. This study aimed to determine the Sporrix species associated with both classic and unusual sporrich manifestations in Rio de Janeiro. We performed a cross-sectional study in which Sporrix isolates from 50 patients with different manifestations were analyzed by phenotypic and genotyp methods. We found that Sporrix brasili was associated with disseminated cutaneous infection, mucosal infection, and hypersensitivity reactions, whereas Spor schii sensu stricto was associated with severe localized disease similar to previously described sporrich cases. Patients with brasili required shorter itracon treatment (16 weeks ) compared to those with schii (24 weeks ). These findings suggest that Sporrix species are linked to different sporrich manifestations and brasili is effectively treated with itracon.
Most of the mammalian genome is transcribed than can be accounted for by annotated genes, but the quantity and nature of the additional transcripts remains unclear. We used data from single and paired-end RNA-Seq and tiling to assess the quantity and composition of transcripts in Poly+ RNA from human and mouse tissues. Relative to tiling, RNASeq identifies many transcribed regions “seqags” outside known exons and ncRNAs. Most seqags are introns, raising the possibility they are fragments of preRNAs. The chromosomal locations of the majority of intergenic seqags in RNASeq data are near genes, consistent with alternative splicing and polyadenylation usage, promoter and terminator transcripts or new exons. Indeed, reads identified 544 new exons, affecting 554 genes. Most remaining seqags correspond to reads that display characteristics of random sampling from low background or several small transcripts ( median=111 bp ) present at higher levels, also display sequence conservation and originate from open chromatin. We conclude that while there are bonaide intergenic transcripts, their number is generally low compared to exons and the genome is not pervasively transcribed as previously.
The ability to engineer thermost proteins is a promising for the development of novel bioreagents. In this work, a combined computational and experimental method was developed to increase the thermostability of the flavin mononucleotide based protein Bacillus subtilis YA LO domain by 31°C, thus extending its applicability in thermophilic systems. The method includes five steps: (1) in silico screening to identify thermost mutant candidates, (2) experimental evaluation to confirm positive selections, (3) computational redesign around therable regions, (4) experimental reevaluation, and (5) multiple combination of mutations. The method is simple and effective, can be applied to other proteins where other methods have difficulties, and provides a new tool to improve thermost.
Leishmanias is a protozoan disease transmitted by sand flies of the genus Lutzia in the New World. Within the Panama Canal watershed, the cutaneous form of leishmanias is a health threat for residents and tourists. We report the results of a screening of sand fly species for Leish and Wolbachia in the understory of Barro Island, Republic of Panama. We used DNA sequences to determine the diversity and phylogenetic relationships of Phleominae in the area. The CO1 gene supported 18 species determinations and revealed two “cryptic” species, Lu. sp. vespilion and Lu. gzi. We detected Leish DNA in 43. 3% Lu. trapi, 26.3 Lu.zi and 0% other species using ITS-1 primers. The ITS-1 sequence was obtained from Leish Lu. trapi and.zi which was 93% similar to Leish. naiff in GenBank. Dist Wolia were detected in three species including Lu. trapi, which frequently co-occurred with Leish. Two species were found to carry Leish at high frequency and are likely vectors of leishias to humans or mammals. A single Leish species identified as. naiff was carried by both. naiff is known to cause cutaneous leish in South America but has not been reported in Panama. The occurrence of Leish and Wolia in. trapi identifies it as a target for Wolia sweeps.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) reactivation in dendritic cells (DCs) is associated with devastating clinical consequences. Here, we show that mitogen- and stress-activated kinases (MSK) act cooperatively with cAMP response element binding protein (CREB) to induce CMV immediate early gene expression from latency. CRE binding to the viral major early promoter (MP) provides a target for MS recruitment. MS-mediated phosphorylation of histone H3 is required for histone demethylation and subsequent CMV exit from latency. Importantly, CRE binding to MP is necessary for MS recruitment of kinase activity to initiate chromatin remodeling at MP for reactivation.
Ribosome biogenesis is an essential for all living organisms. However, defects in ribosome production cause a group of diseases called ribosomies. We previously found that the protein NOL11 is important for ribosome production in human cells. Here we show that N11 is also important for ribosome production and craniofacial development in vertebrates. N11 is found in the developing cranial neural crest of amphibians and mammals. We knocked down N11 in Xenopus and found that ribosome production was impaired, cells died, and craniofacial cartilage was abnormal. Inhibiting p53 rescued the craniofacial defect but not the ribosome defect. This shows a conserved mechanism to remove ribosome-impaired craniofac cells. Excessive activation of this mechanism impairs craniofac development. Our findings show that N11 is important for craniofac development and provide insight into ribosome proteins and cranfac cell survival.
Leptospirosis is a zoonotic disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The lack of an adequate diagnostic test is a major barrier for diagnosis, especially during the early stages of illness, when therapy is most effective. Therefore, there is a need for an efficient test for this life-threatening disease. In order to identify new targets that could be used as markers for leptospi, we constructed a protein microarray comprising 61% of Leptira interrogans proteome and investigated IgG from 274 individuals, including 80 acute, 80 convalescent patients and 114 healthy subjects from regions with endemic, high, endemic and no transmission of leptpi. We found 16 antigens that discriminate between acute and healthy individuals from region with high transmission of leptpi, and 18 that distinguish convalescent cases. Some of the antigens identified, such as Lip32, non-identical domains of Lig, Gro, and Lo22 are known to be recognized by sera from patients, thus proof-of-concept for serodi antigen discovery. Several novel antigens were identified, including hypothetical LIC15 which showed good sensitivity and specificity for both acute and convalescent patients. Our study is the first large evaluation of immunodominant antigens associated with acquired leptiral infection, as well as known serodi leptiral antigens recognized by sera leptpi cases.
Mosquito immunity against entomopathogenic fungi, such as Beauveria bassiana, remains poorly understood. We used Anopheles gambia as a model to investigate the role of melanization, a potent effector of arthropod immunity, in defense against B. bassiana. We monitored fungal growth in mosquitoes injected with B. bass conidia and found that melan formed on all stages, including conidia, germ tubes, and hyphae. However, melan rarely aborted growth of these stages and mycelium continued despite melanization. Silencing T1 and CL8, key regulators of Plasmod and melanization in A. gambia, abolished melan on hypha but not germinating conidia or tubes. A layer of hemocytes surrounded germinating conidia but not hypha suggested melanization of early stages is cell-mediated, while late is humoral dependent on T1 and CL8. Microscopic analysis revealed association of T with hypha surfaces and requirement of both T and CL8 for phenoloxidase recruitment to these. Finally, proliferation was more in T and CL8 knockdown mosquitoes which exhibited increased sensitivity to B infections than controls.
Dengue virus factors (DENVFs) are essential for the completion of the infection in both mosquito and vertebrate hosts. Here, we investigated whether known mammalian DENV inhibitors could influence infection in the arthropod vector Aedes aegypt. We evaluated the potency of bafilomycin (BAF), myopholic acid (M), castanospermine (CAS), and deoxojirimycin (DN) in blocking DENV infection of the mosquito midgut using various methods. Injection of BAF (5µM) and M (25µM) prior to feeding on virus-infected blood inhibited DENV in the midut at 7 days post-infection by 56% and 60 and in the saliv gland at 14 post-in by 90 and 83, respectively. Ingestion of B and M through sugar or blood meal also resulted in virus inhibition. RNA-mediated silencing of vPase subunit and IMP gene resulted in reduced DENV, indicating B and M-mediated inhibition likely occurred through inhibition of DENVFs. The route and timing of B and M administration was essential and after exposure diminished antiviral effect. We provide proof-principle that chemical or RNA-mediated depletion of DENV vPase and IMP can suppress D in adult.
Seizure spreading and depression and anoxic depolarization are two pathological states of the brain that are poorly understood. We know little about the role of cell volume in these states. Here, we studied the effects of cell volume on neuronal dynamics. We combined cell swelling with ion concentrations and oxygen into Hodgkin-Hux type spiking dynamics. We found that cell swells and contracts in response to changes in osm pressure. This leads to spontaneous transition between seizure and depression states. We used volume as a parameter to separate seizure from depression and depression, and depression from anoxic depolar. Our model highlights the role of glial buffering against seizures and depression, and provides insights into anoxic depolar and cell swelling during ischemia. We argue that seizures, depression, and anoxicolar lie along a continuum of the neuron that can be understood when ion, oxygen, homeostasis, and swelling are taken into consideration. Our results provide a framework for a range of behaviors that may be important in understanding and developing interventions for these states.
Paracococcidioides brasiliensis is the causative agent of paracoccidiomycosis (PCM), the most prevalent systemic mycosis confined to Latin America. In this study, we investigated the role of the pro-inflammatory cytokine IL-1β in host defense against this opportunistic fungal pathogen. We found that murine bone marrow-derived dendritic cells responded to P. brasiliensis yeast infection by releasing IL-1β in a spleen tyrosine kinase (Syk), caspase-1 and NOD receptor (NLR) member NLR3 dependent manner. P brasiliensis-induced NLR3 inflamome activation was dependent on potassium (K+) efflux, reactive oxygen species production, phagolysosomal acidification and cathepsin release. Using mice lacking IL-1 receptor, we demonstrated that IL-1 signaling has an important role in killing P brasili by murine macrophages.
Toxoplas gondii is a brain-tropic parasite capable of infecting nucleated cells, including astrocytes and neurons in vitro. However, in vivo, Toxoplas is primarily found in neurons. In vitro studies have shown that interferon-γ-stimulated astrocytes, but not neurons, clear intracellular parasites, suggesting that neurons are persistently infected in vivo because they lack the ability to clear intracellular parasites. To test this theory, we used a novel Toxoplas-mouse model capable of marking and tracking cells that interact with parasites, even if interaction is transient. We found that Tooplas shows a strong predilection for interacting with neurons throughout CNS infection. This predction remains in the setting of IF-γ depletion; infection with parasites resistant to the mechanism by which murine astrocytes clear parasites or when directly injected into the brain. These findings, in combination with prior work, suggest that neurons are not incidentally infected but rather Tooplas’s primary in vivo target.
To understand the behavior of cells undergoing lamellipodial motility, we explore a free-boundary model of actin-myosin contractility. The model consists of force-balance and myosin transport equations that account for isotropic contraction proportional to myin density, viscous stresses in the actin network, and constant-strength viscous adhesion. This generates a spatially graded centripetal actin flow, which reinforces contraction via myin redistribution and causes retraction of the lamipodial boundary. Actin protrusion at the boundary counters retraction, and the balance of protrusion and retraction shapes the lamipodium. The model shows that initiation of motility depends on three dimensionless parameters: myosin-dependent contractility, characteristic adhesion length, and rate of actin protrusion. When contractility is sufficiently strong, cells break symmetry and move steadily along straight or circular trajectories, and motility is sensitive to boundary conditions.
Protein-protein interaction (PPI) networks are a key to understanding biological processes, but experimental methods such as yeast-2-hybrid (YH), tandem affinity purification (T) and high-throughput protein-protein (PI) detection produce large amounts of data with high levels of noise and incompleteness. For example, Y screens have a false positive rate of up to 64% and false negative rate of 43–71%. T experiments have comparable levels of noise. We present a novel method to assess confidence in PI networks from experimental studies. We use it to predict new interactions and guide future experiments. This is the first to use the best model for PI networks, geometric graphs. Our method achieves 85% specificity and 90% sensitivity. We assign confidence to protein-protein interactions in the human PI network from BioGRID. Using our method, we predict 251 interactions in human PI, a significant of which correspond to pairs sharing GO. Moreover, we validate a of our interactions in HPRD and BioGRID.
Myotonic Dystrophy Type 1 (DM1) is a neurodegenerative disease caused by expansion of non-coding CTG repeats in the DMPK1K gene. Recent studies have shown that many genes have antiense transcripts, raising the possibility that human trinucle expansion diseases may be pathogenic due to both sense and anti-sense expanded transcripts. We established a Drosila model for DM1 and tested the role of interactions between expanded CTG and CAG transcripts. These studies revealed dramatically enhanced toxicity in flies co-expressing CT and CAG repeats. Expression of the transcripts led to pathogenesis with generation of dcr-2 and ago-dependent 21-nt repeat-derived siRNAs. These small RNAs targeted expression of C-containing genes such as Ataxin-2 and TATA protein (TBP), which bear C repeats in fly and man. These findings indicate that generation of repeat-derived siRNAs may enhance toxicity in repeat diseases with anti-s transcription.
Soft rot is one of the most devastating bacterial diseases affecting plants worldwide. We present insights into the phylogeny and virulence of the soft rot pathogen Pectobacterium sp. SCC3, which was isolated from a diseased potato in Finland in the 1980s. Genomic approaches, proteome and genome comparisons of sequenced soft bacteria revealed that SCC3, previously classified as Pectacterium carov, can be accurately classified as Pobacter wasiae. The revised phylog of P. carov and increasing studies on.ab indicate that.ab has been present in potato fields worldwide. A combination of genomic and in planta experiments identified features that SCC3 and other.ab strains differ from other soft bacteria, such as the absence of type III secretion contributing to virulence of other soft species. Experimentally established virulence determinants include the putative regulator Sir, two redundant type VI systems and horizontally acquired clusters Vic1 and Vic, containing vir genes. Genome also revealed traits related to life in planta or specific conditions, such as a benzoic/sicylic acid carbox methylase of eukary origin. Our findings indicate that soft bacteria have unknown traits that may be utilized in poorly understood in planta. The genomic comparison of SCC3 to sequenced Pacter strains, including.ab, provides a basis for further investigation of virulence and phy of soft bacteria, and potentially other bacteria.
Mitochondrial dysfunction is a hallmark of a wide range of human diseases. Mitochondrial proteins are encoded by both nuclear and mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA). However, little is known about how nuclear-encoded mitochondrial proteins (mtome) change when mtDNA is depleted. This study used network analysis of gene expression data to investigate mtDNA-depleted (ρ) mitochondria. We quantified proteomics data into functional networks and analyzed systemic properties of mt dysfunction. We found that upregulated and downregulated proteins were organized into two subnetworks with distinct biological processes. Downregulated modules were involved in typical mt functions, while upregulated proteins were responsible for mtDNA repair and protein expression transport. Furthermore, proteome and transcriptome comparisons revealed that ρ cells attempted to compensate for mtDNA depletion by modulating protein expression and transport. Our results show that protein composition remodels mt networks in response to dysfunctional states.
Proteins are the building blocks of life and their synthesis is a complex process that involves numerous steps such as association and dissociation, chemical reactions, and mechanical movements. The rates of these steps can be measured in vitro, but not in vivo. Here, we develop a method to deduce in vivo rates from in vitro values. The method has two components. First, we introduce the kinetic distance, a concept to compare kinetics in different environments. The distance depends on rates and can be interpreted in terms of energy. Second, we minimize the distance between in vitro and in vivo, imposing that deduced rates reproduce a global property such as in vivo speed. We apply to protein synthesis by ribosomes, a process of expression. We describe by a cod-specific model with three pathways corresponding to binding cognate, near-cognate and nonognate tRNA. We determine individual rates in vitro and predict in vivo by minimization. We validate rates by independent in vivo data for speeds, dynamics and frequencies.
Helicobacter pylori is a bacterium that infects the stomach lining of the human host and causes chronic gastritis, peptic ulcers, and gastric cancer. The evolution of Helicobacter pylori during infection in a single host and within families is not well understood. In this study, we estimated the short-term mutation and recombination rates of Helicacter pylori by sequencing 39,300 bp in 78 gene fragments from 97 isolates. The isolates included 34 pairs of sequential samples taken at intervals of 0.25 to 10.2 years and 29 single isolates from 10 families. We found that the accumulation of sequence diversity increased with time in a clock-like manner in sequential isolates. We used Approximate Bayesian computation to estimate the rates of mutation, recombination, length of recombination tracts and diversity in tr. The results indicate that the short-term mutation rate is 1.4×10−6 ( isolates ) 4.5×10−6 ( isol ) per nucleotide per year and three times more substitutions are introduced by recombination than by mutation. The long-term rate over millennia is 5–17-fold lower due to removal of non-synonymous mutations by purifying selection.
Melanopsin contributes to irradiance coding in the thalamocortical visual system. Photoreception in the mammalian retina is not restricted to rods and cones but extends to a subset of retinal ganglion cells expressing the photopigment melanin (RGCs). These RGCs are known to drive light responses such as circadian photoentrainment and pupillom movements. We show that RGC projections are more extensive than previously thought and extend to the lateral geniculate nucleus (LGN), origin of thalamortical neurons. This input supports physiological responses in the GN and cortex in mice lacking rods+cones, a model of retinal degeneration. Using chromatic stimuli to isolate melanin-derived responses in mice with an intact system, we reveal melanin to ∼40% of GN neurons show activation to light. Melanin input supports irradiance increases in firing of these neurons. Melanin is required to encode irradiance using melanin knockout mice. Our data establish melanin-based photoreception as a source of input to thalamortical visual, providing irradiance and allowing responses to be retained in absence rods+con.
HIV-1 infection is associated with a profound depletion of mucosal CD4+ T cells, a population that plays a crucial role in regulating the transport of antibodies across the epithelial barrier. We investigated whether this depletion results in altered humoral responses to antigens at mucosal surfaces in HIV-1-infected individuals. A comprehensive analysis of systemic humoral responses to intestinal microbiota revealed reduced IgG responses to antigens from Proteobacteria and Firmicutes but not Bacteroidetes. Importantly, antiretroviral therapy-treated HIV-1-infected individuals exhibited elevated IgM and decreased Ig/Ig and Ig/Ig ratios to a variety of microbial and food antigens. These findings indicate reduced mucosal B cell competence to switch from IgM to other isotypes, limiting their capacity to react to gut antigens. Decreased microbiota-specific Ig and Ig may be an important factor in microbial translocation across the mucosal barrier and systemic dissemination that drives chronic inflammation in HIV-1-infected individuals.
Species populations in ecosystems are often limited by the availability of resources in their environment. This means that the growth of one population needs to be balanced by a comparable reduction in populations of others. In traditional models of biodiversity, all populations are assumed to change incrementally due to births and deaths of individuals. Here, we propose a new mechanism of redistribution driven by a severe reduction in size of the population of a single species freeing resources for others. This mechanism may be relevant for communities of bacteria with strain collapses caused by bacteriophages or other ecosystems where diseases play an important role. The emergent dynamics of the system is characterized by cyclic ‘diversity’ waves triggered by collapses of globally dominating populations. The diversity peaks at the beginning of each wave and decreases exponentially afterwards. Species abundances have bimodal time-aggregated distribution with the peak formed by recently collapsed or newly introduced species and the peak that has not collapsed in the current wave. In waves both peaks are composed of smaller peaks. This self-organized peak has long memory transmitted across waves.
Chemotaxis of Escherichia coli is one of the most thoroughly studied paradigms of simple behavior. Chemaxis confers a significant competitive advantage to bacteria and is expected to be strongly optimized. Bacteria follow gradients by performing temporal comparisons of chemector concentrations along their runs. Concentration differences are detected by a sensory system and transmitted to modulate rotation of flagellar motors, decreasing the probability of tumble and reorientation if the concentration during a run is positive. Such regulation of tumble probability is sufficient to explain chemactic drift of a population up the gradient and is commonly assumed to be only mechanism of chemactic E coli. coli.
Medullary thymic epithelial cells (mTEs) play a crucial role in establishing tolerance by presenting self-peptides to autoreactive thymocytes and/or thymocytes, diverting them into the regulatory T cell lineage. The NFκB signaling pathway is essential for TE maturation and proliferation in the medullary region. Here, we show that the Stat3 pathway also plays a role in TE development and homeostasis. Expression of a constitutive Stat3 in the TE compartment increases TE cellularity and bypasses the requirement for positively selected thymocytes to drive medull formation. Conversely, deletion of Stat disrupts medull architecture and reduces TE. Stat does not affect TE proliferation, but promotes survival of immature MHCloCDlo TE precursors. In contrast, alterations in TE do not affect cortical cellularity or organization.
Clostridium difficile is an emergent pathogen and the most common cause of nosocomial diarrhea. In an effort to understand the role of noncoding RNAs (RNAs) in C difficile physiology and pathogenesis, we used an in silico approach to identify 511RNA candidates in intergenic and coding regions. In parallel, RNA–seq and 5′- RNA–seq were used to identify C difficileRNAs and their transcription start sites at three growth conditions: exponential phase, stationary, and starvation. This approach identified 251 putative RNAs including 94 transregulators in intergenic, 91antisense RNAs, and riboswitches. Expression of RN was confirmed by gene-specific approaches. Some RN, including antisense may be involved in C autolytic activity showed growth-dependent profiles. Expression of 16 c-diMP riboswitches was observed, and evidence for their role in motility and biofilm formation was obtained. Finally, RN encoded by C difficile CRPR loci were detected. These RN may be important C survival in bacteri-rich gut. Altogether, this identification provides a basis for future characterization and identification of mechanisms regulation in this emergent enterogen.
Hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a major cause of chronic liver disease and liver cancer worldwide. HCV is known to hijack the host cellular machinery to promote its replication and survival. Here, we show that the HCV core protein downregulates the abundance of miR-122, a liver-specific microRNA essential for liver development and metabolism, by promoting its destabilization via inhibition of GLD-2, a non-canonical cytoplasmic poly ( ) polymerase. The decrease in mi-122 results in dysregulation of its functions, including its proviral activity for HCV. We found that mi-122 is modified at its 3′ end by 3′-terminal nontemplated and templated nucleotide additions. The proportion of mi- bearing a single nucleotide tail decreased in liver specimens from patients with HCV. We found that singleucle-tailed mi- display increased mi activity and stability over prototype mi- and the 3-terminal extension is catalyzed by unique nucleotyl transfer activity of GL-2, capable of adding any ribonucle without preference to mi- end. The H core inhibited GL-2 and interaction with GL in cytoplasm was responsible for mi downregulation.
Trypanosoma brucei is the causative agent of sleeping sickness in humans and trypanosomiasis in livestock throughout sub-Saharan Africa. Although various species show evidence of clinical tolerance to trypanosomiasis, there has been no evidence of acquired immunity to natural infections until now. We discovered a distinct decrease in prevalence of T. brucei. infection in wild lions that is consistent with being driven by exposure-dependent increase in cross-immunity following infections with more genetically diverse T. congolense species. The causative agent of human sleeping sickness T. bruce rhodesi disappears by 6 years of age in response to cross-immunity from other trypanosomes including non-pathogenic species T brucei bruce.
The role of mechanistic mathematical modeling and systems in drug development remains uncertain. In this study, mathematical modeling and sensitivity analysis were used to explore the hypothesis that mechanistic models of human cascades, despite uncertainty, can be computationally screened for points of fragility and these mechanisms could serve as therapeutic targets. We tested this hypothesis by screening a model of the well-stud coagulation cascade, developed from literature. The model, composed of 92 proteins and 148–protein interactions, was validated using 21 datasets from different in vitro coagulation models. Simulated plate activation and thrombin generation in the presence and absence of anticoagulants were consistent with measured values, with mean 0.87 correlation across trials. Overall sensitivity, which measure robustness fragility a mechanism, were calculated using Monte strategy. In absence anticoagul, and surface factor Xactivated factor (X ) thrombin platelet activation were fragile while IXIX andVIII activation activity robust. Both antiXa and thrombin inhibitors important anticoag classes; example antiX inhibitors have approval for prevention venous thromboemb following surgical and treatment deep venous thromosis pulmonary embol. In vitro and vivo evidence support prediction IXIX activity robust.
Bacteriophage therapy is the use of bacteriophages as antimicrobial agents for the control of pathogenic and other bacteria. Successful application of phage therapy requires a good understanding of the non-linear kinetics ofage–bacteria interactions. Here, we combine experimental and modelling to make a detailed examination of such kinetics for the food-borne pathogen Campylobacteruni and a virulent phage in vitro. We find that ph-insensitive populations C. jej arise, as far as we are aware this is the first phage study to test, in vitro, models ph–bacteria incorporating ph-insensitive bacteria. We find that an apparently simplistic model fits the data well and confirm that so-called inundation and proliferation thresholds are likely of considerable importance to ph therapy. We fit the model to time series to estimate thresholds and rate directly. A comparison of the for each reveals density-dependent features of infectivity worthy of further investigation.
Schistosomias is a devastating disease caused by parasitic flatworms of the genus Schistos that affects over 260 million people worldwide, especially in tropical and sub-tropical regions. Schosomes must undergo larval development within specific snail intermediate hosts, a trait shared among all digenatrematodes. Here, we report the first functional characterization of a snail Toll-like receptor, BTLR, which plays an important role in the immune response of snail Biomphalaria glata following Schistoma mansoni challenge. BTL was identified as part of a screen of snail immune surface proteins that differed in abundance between B. glata sn that differ in compatibility to S. mans. The S mansoni-resistant strain of B. glata ( BS-90 ) displayed higher levels of BTL compared to the susceptible ( M ) strain. Transcript of BTL was very responsive in BS sn when challenged with S, increasing 27 fold relative to β-actin ( non-immune control ) ; expression in susceptible sn was not increased. Knock of BTL in BS via siRNA oligonucleotides resulted in alteration of resistant phenotype, yielding infections in 43% of normally resistant sn, which shed S mansoni cercaria 1-week before susceptible.
Mosquitoes of the species Aedes aegypti and Aedes polensis are major vectors of infectious diseases in French Polynesia. Aedes aegypt transmits dengue chikunya and Zika, while Aedes polensis is the primary vector of Bancroftian filariasis and a secondary vector of arboviruses. However, there is a lack of tools to assess the risk of disease transmission and measure the efficacy of vector control programmes. A promising approach to quantify human-vector contact is through the detection and quantification of antibodies against mosquito saliva proteins. We developed an ELISA test to detect and quantify IgG against salivary gland extracts ( SGE ) of Ae.egypt and Ae.ynensis in human populations exposed to either species. We conducted a cross-sectional study in Tahiti and Moorea where Aeegpt and Aeensis are present, and found that 98% and 68% of individuals had IgG against Aeegpt and AeensisGE, respectively. In contrast, EL tests on a cohort from metropolitan France not exposed to these mosquitoes showed 97% had no Ig against S of either species. Analysis of cohorts from different entomological contexts showed no Ig cross-reactivity between Aeeg and AeGE. The Ig response to saliv gland extracts is a valid biomarker of human exposure to bites of Aeeg and Aeensis. This immuno-epidological tool will enhance understanding of exposure to bites, identify areas of high disease risk and evaluate novel control strategies in Pacific and tropical settings.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis is a successful pathogen because of its ability to adapt to the intracellular environment of human macrophages. We investigated whether this adaptation requires interference with the host cell’s metabolic machinery. Temporal profiling of metabolic flux in macrophages infected with virulent mycobacterial strains confirmed that this is the case. Subsequent analysis identified a subset of host reactions targeted by mycobacteria. We found that the goal of regulation is to integrate macrophage survival pathways with mycobacterial sustenance. Interestingly, this provided an axis where host and pathogen factors converge to determine pathogenicity.
Crossover recombination and chiasma formation are essential for the proper segregation of homologous chromosomes during the first meiotic division in Caenorhabditis elegans. We show that ZHP-3, the C. elegans ortholog of the budding yeast ZIP3 gene, is required for crossover recombination. During meiotic prophase, ZHP-3 protein is highly dynamic, shifting from the length of the synaptonemal complex ( SC ) to an asymmetric localization on the SC and eventually becoming restricted to foci that mark crossover events. A zhp-3::fp transgene complements a null mutation and reveals a separation of function; although the fusion can promote wild-type levels of recombination, aneuploidy among progeny is high, indicating defects in meiotic segregation. The structure of bivalents is perturbed in this mutant, suggesting that the segregation defect results from an inability to properly remodel chromosomes in response to crossovers.
Aedes albopictus is an invasive mosquito species that has colonized temperate regions of Europe and the US in the last few decades and has become a public health concern due to its ability to transmit arboviruses and its aggressive daytime biting behavior. This study investigated the effects of eco-climatic factors on Ae. albictus abundance in metropolitan and sub-urban areas in Rome, Italy, which is one of the most infested metropolitan areas in Southern Europe. Adult mosquitoes were monitored along a 70 km transect across the metropolitan area and two fine spatiotemporal datasets were used to analyze the effect of climatic and socio-environmental variables on Ae. albict abundance. Results showed that Ae. albict is highly associated with anthropized habitats in both metropolitan and sub-urban areas, with “green” islands” corresponding to hot spots of abundance in metropolitan areas and bimodal dynamics with a peak in autumn due to heavy rains and permissive temperatures.
Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) is a major virulent pathogen that invades host macrophages early in the course of infection. Phthiocol dimoceros (DIM) are major virulence factors of Mtb that are involved in this process, but their cellular and molecular mechanisms of action are unknown. Here, we show that DIM are required for receptor-mediated phagocytosis of Mtb and prevention of phagosomal acidification. Using Mtb mutants deleted for genes involved in DIM biosynthesis, we demonstrate that DIM are necessary for efficient phagocytosis and prevention of phagos acidification. The effects of DIM require changes in membrane fluidity, as demonstrated by experiments with cholesterol-depleting drugs that abolished differences in phagocyt efficiency and phagos acidification between wild-type and mutant strains. Insertion of a cholesterol probe in living cells shows that the hydrophobic core of the membrane changes upon contact with Mtb, whereas lateral diffusion of cholesterol is unaffected. This effect is dependent on DIM and consistent with observed in model. We propose that DIM control invasion of macroph by M by targeting lipid organisation in host membrane, thereby modifying biophysical properties. The DIM-induced changes in lipid favour efficiency of receptor-mediated phocytosis of M and contribute to control of phagos pH driving bacilli in protective niche.
Neural circuits composed of a small number of neurons are difficult to study with mean-field approximations. These approximations are powerful for large networks, but do not describe small networks well. Many problems in neuroscience involve mesoscopic networks of tens of neurons. However, methods for small networks are rare, preventing progress in understanding dynamics at these scales. We develop a systematic analysis of small networks of homogeneous excitatory and inhibitory neurons. We study bifurcations of activity with an analytically tractable approach and numerically determine global bifurcations. For strong inhibition, networks give complex dynamics through spontaneous symmetry-breaking of neural equations. This is a finite effect of the network, revealing differences between mesoscopic and mean-field. The most important consequence of symmetry is the ability to regulate heterogeneity. This is thought to reduce detrimental effects of noise on cortical processing.
Leishmanias is a parasitic disease caused by Leishmania protozoa transmitted by sandflies. The clinical and epidemiological significance of Leish in extralesional sites is obscured by the uncertainty of whether the DNA derives from viable parasites. To examine the dissemination of Leish during disease and the potential of human infection, Leish 7RNA was exploited to estimate viability and parasite burden in extraional sites of dermal leishiasis patients. In this study, the feasibility of discriminating parasite viability by Leish 7RNA was evaluated in relation with luciferase activity of transfected intracellular amastigotes in dose-response cytotoxicity assays. Monocytes, tonsil swabs, and skin aspirates of 28 cutaneous and mucocutaneous leishias patients were screened by DNA amplification/Southern blot. Positive samples were analyzed by quantitative PCR of Leish 7RNA genes and transcripts. Le 7RNA amplification coincided with lucifer activity, confirming parasite viability. Of 22 patients presenting DNA in extraional samples, Leish 7RNA genes or transcripts were detected in one or more DNA samples 100% and 73%, respectively. Gene transcript number from extraional tissues were comparable to lesions. 7RNA were detected in 13/19 ( 68 ) monocytes, 5/12 ( 42 ) tonsil sw, 4/11 ( 36 ) skin aspir, and 22/25 ( 88 ) lesions were quantifiable 15/19 ( 79 ) monocytes 12 ( 92 ) tons sw 8 (73 ) skin.
Chromatin modifications (HMs) and chromatin binding proteins (CBs) are fundamental for the faithful progression of DNA replication in metazoan cells. However, no single HM is strictly indispensable for origin, suggesting that HMs may act combinatorially in analogy to the histone code for transcriptional regulation. Here, we investigated the combinatorial potential of 95 CBs and HMs for predicting DNA replication timing in Drosila using statistical models. We found that combinations of CB exhibit moderate predictive power for replication, while pairwise between HMs lead to accurate genome-wide predictions that can be further improved by CB. Independent importance analyses led to a biologically interpretable model of the relationship between chromatin and replication reaching 80% of full accuracy using six terms. Finally, pairwise HMs predict differential replication across cell types.
Dengue virus is a major public health problem in tropical and subtropical regions, infecting 390 million people and causing at least 25,000 deaths annually. In Brazil, we investigated the spread of three dengue virus serotypes ( DENV-1, DENV-2, and DENV-3 ) by analyzing their complete genome sequences. We found that new lineages of all three serotypes were introduced within 7-10 year intervals. These lineages were most likely introduced from the Caribbean to the North and Northeast regions of Brazil, and then dispersed at a rate of approximately 0.5 km/day. Our analysis of evolutionary, epidemiological and ecological data indicates that human and/or mosquito transportation, rather than Aedes aegypti infestation rates or geographical distances, determine dengue spread in Brazil.
Neurons in the brain are not independent of each other but are correlated with each other. These correlations are ubiquitous and have a strong impact on neural coding. We investigated how differences in the antagonistic center-surround receptive field (RF) organization across three sensory maps influence correlations between electrosensory pyramidal neurons. We used a model based on anatomical differences in RF center size and overlap to predict large differences in correlations. However, in vivo electrophysiological recordings showed that electrosensoryram neurons in all three segments displayed nearly identical correlations. To explain this result, we incorporated the effects of RF in our model. By varying the RF surround size relative to the center, we found multiple structures gave similar correlations. Incorporating physiological differences in RF between maps in our model gave similar correlations. Our results show that center alone does not determine correlations, which is important for understanding how structure influences correlated activity.
In this work, we investigate the impact of noise correlations between neurons on the ability of a population of neurons to encode a stimulus. We consider a general setting for population coding, in which allows us to investigate how information varies as a function of noise, while keeping other aspects of the problem, such as tuning curves and heterogeneity, fixed. Our results are summarized in the form of theorems and illustrated with numerical examples involving neurons with diverse tuning curves. We show that if correlations between pairs of neurons have opposite signs to their signal correlations, then coding will improve compared to the independent case. This holds for different metrics of performance and arbitrary levels of heterogeneity. We also show that the sign rule does not provide a necessary condition for good coding, and that a set of correlation structures can improve coding, many of which violate the rule. These correlations are experimentally observed. We prove that optimal correlations must lie on the boundary of the set of possible correlations. Finally, we provide a set of necessary and sufficient conditions under which performance in the presence of noise will be as good as if there were no noise at all.
Staphylococcus aureus (S. aureus ) and Pseudomonas aeruginosa ( P. aeruginosa ) co-infections frequently fail to respond to antibiotic treatment, leading to significant morbidity and mortality. The impact of interspecies interactions on S. aureus antibiotic susceptibility is poorly understood. This study demonstrates that P.ugin alters S.us susceptibility to bactericidal antibiotics in a strain-dependent manner and identifies 3 interactions responsible for antagonizing or potentiating antibiotic activity against. aure.ugin Las endopeptase potentiates vancomycin activity by facilitating proton-motive-independent uptake and 2-hepty-4-hydroquinoline Noxide ( HQ ) induces multidrug tolerance through respiratory inhibition and ATP reduction. Production of these factors varies between isolates and corresponds to capacity to alter S.us susceptibility. We demonstrate that vancom treatment of S. aure mouse infection is potentiated by Las-producing Pugin population. These findings demonstrate that susceptibility is complex and dependent on genotype of pathogen and interactions with other microorganisms in environment.
Dengue virus (DENV) infection is associated with thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) and platelet dysfunction, contributing to complications such as bleeding and plasma leakage. The etiology of deng thrombocytopenia is multifactorial and includes increased platelet clearance. Here, we show that binding of the coagulation protein von Wille factor (VWF) to the platelet membrane and removal of sialic (desialylation) are novel mechanisms of platelet clearance in deng infection. In two cohort studies in Bandung and Jep, Indonesia, patients with deng had higher plasma VWF antigen and active VWF, and platelets bound more V to their membrane. Platelet-VWF correlated with plate count. Sial in deng patients was reduced as assessed by Sambucus nigra lectin (SNA) and Maack amureis lectin II (MAL). Sial on platelet membrane is neuraminid-labile, but deng virus has no neuraminase activity. No neuraminase was present in deng plasma and desial was not found in plasma transferr. Platelet sial was not altered by exposure to DENV nonstructural 1 or cultured DENV. In contrast, VWF binding to glycoprotein 1 on plate using V-activ protein resulted in removal of plate sial by translocation of neuraminase to plate. Neuramin inhibitor oseltiv reduced V-induced platelet desial. Our data show that V binding to plate ineng results in neuramin-mediated plate desial and clearance.
Many genes in the human genome are regulated by bidirectional promoters, which are located between two genes that are transcribed in opposite directions. These promoters are often associated with genes involved in DNA repair and have the potential to contribute to cancer development. We identified the most complete set of human genes regulated by bidirectional promoters using spliced expressed sequence tags ( ESTs ) and found that many function as alternative promoters or novel transcripts. We show that bidirectional promoters are highly enriched in genes implicated in cancer, including many in breast and ovarian cancer. This promoter structure is repeated in the genome and could regulate co-expression among groups of genes. We verified regulatory networks among genes controlled by bidirectional promoters using microarray data from 79 human tissues. Some promoters have similar transcription factor binding sites, including conserved ETS sites in ERBB, FCD, and BRCA.
Sex determination in Diptera (flies, including Drosophila melanogaster, is determined by heteromorphic sex chromosomes. However, the karyotypes of Diptera are superficially similar, concealing the extent of sex chromosome variation. We used whole-genome analysis of 37 Dipt species from 22 families to uncover hidden sex kary diversity. We identified over a dozen sex configurations, with the small dot chromosome used as the sex chromosome, presumably the ancestral kary of Dipt. However, we found species with undifferentiated chromosomes, others with the dot replaced as sex or up to three elements incorporated into sex, and others with female heterog ( Z sex ) chromosomes. Transcriptome analysis shows dosage compensation evolved through upregulation of single X in males. X chromosomes show deficiency of genes with male-based expression, possibly sex-specific pressures.
Zika virus (ZIK ) is an emerging mosquito-borne pathogen that has been linked to the development of severe fetal abnormalities, including spontaneous abortion, stillbirth, hydranenceph, and microaly. In the United States, ZIK outbreaks have been recorded. Recently, the first congenital ZIK infection in the United States was demonstrated. This study investigated blood samples from mothers who gave birth to babies with microaly and mothers who gave birth to healthy babies in Hawaii between 2009 and 2012. We tested maternal blood for the presence of ZIK IgM and IgG antibodies using commercially available ZIK IgM and IgG ELISA kits. Blood from mothers who delivered babies with microaly tested positive for ZV IgM (16. 6% ) and from mothers tested positive for ZV IgG (50% ). ZV showed a trend with microaly.V IgG positive mothers were more likely to deliver babies with micro than mothers who were negative for IgG (OR = 11., CI =0.–147.9, p.083 ). Similarly, IgM positive mothers were also more likely to deliver babies with micro than mothers who were negative for IgM (OR =.8, CI =.–.195. ).
Mycobacterium ulcer (MU) infection, the causative agent of Buruli ulcer (BU), has been associated with slow-moving water bodies. However, the mode of transmission is still unknown. Ecological studies suggest Variable Number and Repeat (VN) typing as a useful tool to differentiate MU from other Mycobacteria. To determine the genetic relatedness of clinical and environmental isolates, we attempted to source MU infections to specific water bodies by matching VN profiles of MU in human samples to those in the environment. Environmental samples were collected from 10 water bodies in four BU endemic communities in Ashanti, Ghana. Four VN loci in MU99 genome were used to genotype MU environmental isolates and those from 14 confirmed BU patients in the same area. Length polymorphism was confirmed by sequencing. MU was present in three types of water, significantly higher in biofilm. Four genotypes W, X, Y, and Z were typed in both human and environmental samples. Other genotypes were only found in water. An animal was identified with characteristic BU lesion, confirmed MU infection. Our findings suggest patients may have been infected from community water bodies. Further, evidence that small mammals within communities could be susceptible to MU.
Alien species are a major component of human-induced environmental change and their numbers in different areas depend on a combination of anthropogenic and environmental factors. We explore the global drivers of alien bird species richness using an extensive database of alien birds. We demonstrate that the origin and identity of alien birds were largely driven by European (mainly British ) colonialism, but recent introductions are wider, involving more species and countries, driven by economic activity. Globally, alien species richness is highest at mid-latitudes and determined by anthropogenic effects, notably the number of species introduced (colonisation pressure ). Environmental drivers are also important, with native and alien richness strongly positively associated. Our results show colonisation is key to alien richness, areas of high native species are resistant to alien at global, and highlight ongoing threats from species introductions.
Upstream Binding Factor (UBF) is a multi-ZF-box protein that acts as a co-factor for RNA polymerase I (Pol I) transcription. However, its poor DNA sequence selectivity and ability to form nucleosome-like complexes suggest a more generalized role in chromatin structure. We previously showed that UBF depletion reduced the number of actively transcribed ribosomal RNA (rRNA) genes, but had little effect on rRNA synthesis or cell proliferation. Here, we show that UBF is essential for embryonic development beyond morula. Conditional deletion in cells reveals that UBF is also essential for rRNA transcription and defines chromatin conformation of both gene and enhancer sequences. Loss of UBF prevents SL/TIFB initiation and recruitment of Rrn/TIF complex. It is accompanied by H3K9me3, histone H1 and HPα, but not de novo methylation. Further, genes retain p-acetyl4 and H2Z, suggesting rRNA can maintain potentially active state. In contrast histone H1 binding is dependent U, suggesting it plays positive role. Unexpected, rRNA arrest does not suppress 5,RNA or snRNA, nor several mRNA implicated ribosome. rRNA activity does not coordinate expression ribogenesis. Loss U also induces formation of large nuclear structure resembling nucleolar body (NPB) of oocytes and embryos. These somatic NPB contain synthesis factors but not with rRNA loci.
Wnt signaling plays a crucial role in cell proliferation and fate specification in metazoans, and its dysregulation underlies the development of the majority of colorectal cancers. The conventional model of Wnt signaling suggests that the secretion and movement of Wnt ligands from their source are essential for long-range patterning in tissues. However, this model was recently challenged by the finding that replacement of wild-type Drosophila Wingless with a membrane-tether form produced viable adults with normal morphology, suggesting that Wnt secretion and movement are dispensable for patter. Here, we tested this principle in the adult intestine, where Wnt gradients coincide with major compartment boundaries. We find that Wingless is required for intestinal development, including regulation of target gene expression, boundary formation, stem cell proliferation, epithelial cell specification, muscle differentiation, gut folding, and signaling with the Decapentapic pathway.
Group A streptococcus (GAS) is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The ability of GAS to accumulate plas at the cell surface is central to its pathogenesis. However, the role of host plasogen activators in this process is poorly understood. Here, we demonstrate that ukinase plasogen activator (uPA) contributes to plmin recruitment and invasive disease initiation in vivo. In the absence of host plasogen activators, streokinase (S) was required to facilitate surface plmin acquisition by GAS. However, in the absence of S, host activators were sufficient to promote surface plmin acquisition by GAS during incubation with plasogen or human plasma. GAS also mediated a significant increase in activation of zym pro-uPA in human plasma. To assess the contribution of PA to invasive disease, a transgenic mouse model of infection was employed. C57/BL/6 and AlbG mice expressing human plasogen were more susceptible to invasive disease than PA−/− mice. The decrease in virulence in PA−− mice was found to correlate with decrease in dissemination and reduced surface plmin by GAS.
Helicobacter pylori Exploits a Unique Repertoire of Type IV Secretion System Components for Pilus Assembly at the Bacteria-Host Interface.
Bovine tuberculosis (bTB) is a chronic disease of cattle caused by Mycobacterium bovis, a member of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis group of bacteria. Vaccination of cattle offers a long-term solution for controlling the disease, and development of a vaccine against bTB is a priority. We hypothesized that global gene expression analysis could identify in vitro predictors of protection to facilitate vaccine development. Cattle were vaccinated with BCG or a heterologous BCG adenovirus vectored subunit boosting. Protective efficacy was determined after M bovis challenge. RNA was prepared from P-stimulated PBMC from vaccinated-protected, vaccinated-unprotected and unaccinated control prior to bo challenge. Gene expression was determined by RNAseq. We identified 668 genes differentially expressed in vaccinated-protected compared to vaccinated-unacc and unacc control. Cytokine-cytokine interaction was the most related to this dataset with IL22 identified as dominant besides INFγ. Expression of these genes by RNAseq was evaluated by RTPCR in independent PB samples from BCG vaccinated and unacc. This confirmed importance of IL as predictor of vaccine.
Centrosomal microtubule organizing centers (MTOCs) are found in most differentiated cells, but their role in microtubule organization is largely unknown. We developed a tissue-specific degradation system to test the role of the centrosomal microtub nucleators γ-tulin ring complex (γuRC) and AIR-1/Aurora at the apical MOC, where both localize in Caenorhabditis elegans embryonic intestinal epithelial cells. We found that the core γu component GIP-1/G3 is required to recruit other γu components to the apical MOC, including MT-1/MT1, characterized for the first time in animal. In contrast, AIR-1 and MT were required to recruit γu to centrosome but not centrioles or apical MOC. Surprisingly, microtules remain organized at apical MOC upon γu and AIR-1 depletion and other micro regulators TP-1/2, ZG-9/TO, PTR-1/CAP, NO-1ine. However, loss of G-1 removed a subset E-1 microtules and remaining grew faster.
Many human genomes are diploid, inheriting one set of chromosomes from the father and one homologous set from the mother. However, most sequencing initiatives ignore this fact and do not delineate the nucleotide content of the maternal and paternal copies of the 23 chromosomes ( i. e., do not phase the genome ) because of costs and complexities. We compared 11 approaches to phase human genomes using the GIAB version of the NA78 genome as a standard. The strategies included laboratory assays that prepare DNA to phase and computational approaches that reconstruct from sequencing reads or population haplotype information. We used metrics such as switch rates, haplotype lengths, proportion of phase-resolved genes, phasing accuracy and pairs of SNVs to assess the approaches. A hybrid approach that leverages population phasing, genome sequencing data and haplotype frequencies provides a fast way to produce highly phase-resolved genomes. We found that population phasing performance is enhanced with genome data; e. g. shotgun and RNA sequencing. Inclusion of parental data in phasing can reduce errors by ten-fold. A voting scheme combining multiple predictions enhanced performance and coverage. We identified signatures associated with phasing errors in regions of polymorphism or SNV.
Type-III secretion systems are utilized by Gram-negative pathogens to secrete virulence effectors and structural components of the flagellum from the cytoplasm into host cells. The flagellar type-III secretion system utilizes both the proton motive force and ATP hydrolysis to energize substrate unfolding and translocation. We report the formation of functional flagella in the absence of type-III ATPase activity by increasing the proton motive force and flagellar substrate levels. Additionally, we show that increased proton force bypasses the requirement of the Salmonella pathogenic island 1 vir-associated type-III ATPase for secretion. Our data support the role of type-III ATPases in enhancing secretion efficiency under limited substrate concentrations and reveal the dispensability of ATP activity in type-III export.
Bistability in gene regulatory networks (GRNs) is a key to many biological functions, including differentiation and cell cycle control. However, establishing GRNs that exhibit bistability is challenging due to the large number of GRNs that exist for a small number of components. We used chemical reaction theory in silico to survey the capacity for bistability of more than 40, 000 simple GRNs formed by transcription factors and their proteins. We find that ∼90% of GR models are bistable, including those without cooperativity commonly associated with bistable systems, and most of which could only be bistable through subnetwork analysis. We sorted GRNs based on presence or absence of reactions and found eleven minimal bistable networks, i. e. bistable without smaller subnetwork. The large number of bistable GRNs suggests bistability arises easily and is not lost through evolution. We integrated protein-protein, protein-DNA, and expression data from Saccharomyces cerevisiae and identified GRNs predicted bistable.
Mutations in the HYAL2 gene, which encodes hyaluronidase 2, cause a syndrome of orofacial cleft and coratriatum sinister in humans and mice. Orofacial cleft is the most common birth defect, with both genetic and environmental components. Although numerous studies have been undertaken to investigate the complexities of the etiology of this condition, it remains incompletely understood. Here we describe mutations in HY2 as cause of orofacial syndrome. HY2 encodes hyaluronidase, degrading extracellular hyaluron, a component of developing heart and palatal matrix. Transfections demonstrated that mutations destabilize the molecule, dramatically reducing HY2 levels. Consistent with clinical presentation in affected, investigations of2/- mice revealed craniofac abnormalities including subucal cleft. In addition coratri sinister and hearing identified in proportion2 mice were incompletely penetrant features affected.
Inner hair cells in the inner ear are responsible for detecting sound. They have stereocilia that convert sound-induced forces into electrical signals. The tip of the stereocilia is connected to a link that conveys force to transduction channels. Current models suggest the link is composed of protocadherin 15 (PH15 ) at the lower end and cadherin 23 (CD23 ) at the upper end. However, links are subjected to forces throughout life and can be disrupted. Although hair cells can regenerate links and restore hearing, the molecular details of this process are unknown. We developed a method to visualize links and stereocilia using electron microscopy. We show that mechanotransducing links have at least two compositions, either PH/CD or PHPCD. During regeneration, links with equal amounts of PH at both ends appear first. Whole-cell recordings show these links mediate normal mechanotransduction currents but abnormal Ca+-dependent adaptation. The PH/CD link composition is established later, concomitant with adaptation recovery. Our findings provide a mechanism for regeneration and maintenance of mechanensory function in auditory hair cells and could help identify components of mechanotrans machinery.
Dengue virus (DENV) is the most prevalent arbovirus leading to an estimated 100 million symptomatic deng infections every year. It causes a spectrum of clinical manifestations ranging from mild deng fever (DF) to more threatening forms such as deng hemorrhagic fever (DHF). The symptoms of DH become evident at the critical phase of infection (5–7 days after onset of fever), yet the mechanisms that trigger transition from DF to DH are not well understood. We performed mass spectrometry metabolomic profiling of sera from adult DF and DH patients at critical and recovery phases of infection. We identified 29 differentially expressed metabolites between DF and DH at the critical phase. These include bile acids, purines, acylcarnines phospholipids and amino acids. Bile acids were up to 5 fold higher among DH compared to DF patients and correlated with higher levels of aspart transamin (AST) and alan transamin (ALT), suggestive of liver injury among DH. Uric acid, most abundant in blood, was 1.5 fold lower among DH compared to DF. This results in decreased capacity of endogenous defense and elevated stress among DH patients. In recovery, eight metabolites were still higher or lower among DH, including chenodeoxycocholic acid, one of bile acids at critical. This indicates prolonged impact on liver due DENV in DH patients.
Trypanosoma brucei, the causative agent of African trypanosomiasis, has a distinct guanosine 5’monophosphate reductase ( GMP ) compared to its mammalian and bacterial counterparts. GMP catalyzes the conversion of guanosine 5’monophosphate ( G ) to inosine 5’monophosphate ( IMP ), a key step in purine nucleotide metabolism. We identified GMP in T. bruce and found it localized to glycosomes in T. bri bloodstream forms. We characterized recombinant T. bruce GMP and found it to have an insertion of cystathion β synthase ( CBS ) domain absent in mammalian and bacterial GMPs. The recombinant T br GMP catalyzed conversion of G to IMP in the presence of NAD and showed affinities for G and NAD different from mammalian Gs. Addition of monovalent cations such as K and NH4 increased T br GMP activity, whereas none mammalian Gs were unaffected. Monophosphate purine analog ribavir inhibited T br GMP, whereas mammalian Gs showed little inhibition.
Voltage-gated sodium channels play a crucial role in controlling electrical excitability in cells and are targeted by drugs to treat conditions such as epilepsy and cardiac arrhythmia. To develop next-generation drugs that selectively target one of nine sodium channel types expressed in the body, it is essential to understand how current blockers work. Here, we use the crystal structure of the bacterial voltage-gated sodium channel NavAb and molecular simulations to elucidate how drugs benzocaine and phenyin bind to the protein and enter the channel. We show that both drugs have two binding sites in the pore characterised by nonspecific hydrophobic interactions: one above the activation gate and at the entrance to the lipid fenestrations. Three independent methods find the same sites and suggest binding to the gate is slightly more favourable than the fenration. Both drugs can pass the fenestr into the lipid with small energy, suggesting this can be the posited hydroobic route for drugs.
MyD signaling in dendritic cells and the intestinal epithelium controls immunity against intestinal infection with Citrobacterium. MyD-mediated signaling downstream of Toll-like receptors and IL-1 receptor is involved in the induction of protective responses against infections. MyD-deficient mice are highly susceptible to a wide range of bacterial infections, but the cell-specific contribution of MyD in protecting against intestinal infection is poorly understood. We employed a novel murine knock-in model for MyD that enables cell-specific reactivation of MyD expression in My-deficient mice. We report that MyD signaling in CD11+ cells is sufficient to activate dendritic cells (DC) and induce group 3 innate lymphoid cell (ILC) response as well as colonic Th17/Th response to infection with intestinal pathogen Citrobacterium. In contrast, My signaling in other cell types, macrophages (MO), T or IL3 did not induce intestinal responses upon infection. We observed My expression in intestinal epithelial cells (IEC) partially protected mice during infection, associated with epithelial integrity and expression of antimicrobial peptideRegγ and acute proteinS1 by epithelial. Together, our data suggest My signaling in DC and IE is essential to induce host responses upon infection with Citrobacter.
Onchocerciasis is targeted for elimination in Africa through annual or biannual iverectin mass drug administration (MDA). An immunodiagnostic test based on the detection of IgG antibodies in the blood to Oncherca volulus-specific antigen Ov16 is one of the tools for determining whether transmission is interrupted and treatment can stop. The relationship between post-M Ov16 antibody prevalence in children 1 year after the last MDA and duration of M, prevalence in the population, and probability onchercias is eventually eliminated is explored through mathematical modelling. The ONOS model was extended with new Ov antibody output. Seroconversion is assumed to be triggered by first worm in host, serconversion either before maturation after maturation or start of mf. We are interested in serconversion in children and ignore possibility serversion to simplify. Yearly M leads to strong reduction in parasite in humans. This reduces serconversion in newborns and children who serconverted before start remain positive. Both microfilaria prevalence in aged 5 and Ov antibody in under 10 declined with increasing M. The association between these indicators and model-predict probability was not influenced by assumed coverage but depend on endemic levels, regarding trigger serconversion and diagnostic ( sensitivity specificity ).
Prions are infectious proteins that can change their properties when propagated in different environments. For example, swainson-sensitive 22 prions became drug-resistant when propagated in PK1 cells in the presence of swain. We propose that prions are quasi-populations comprising a range of variants with different properties, and the fittest are selected in a particular environment. Prion populations are heterogeneous even after cloning, indicating that mutation-like processes occur at the conformation level. Brain-derived 22 prions are naturally swain-resistant, so it was not surprising that pr became swain-sensitive after propagation in cells could revert to resistance.
