RMLions, both propagated in brain or PK cells, are swain-sensitive, so we investigated whether it was possible to select swain-resistant by propagation in presence of drug. Interestingly, this was not possible with standard PK cells, but certain PK sublines selected swain-resistant, even swain-dependent ( i. e. propagated rapidly in presence drug ). Once established, could be passaged in PK, even absence drug, without swain dependence. Misfolded pr ( Pr ) associated with swain variant was rapidly cleared PK than drug-sensitive counterpart, indicating structural differences misfold Pr underlie prion properties.
Metabolic evolution takes place in a vast space of possible genotypes and phenotypes. The structure of this space defines the evolutionary potential and limitations of an evolving system. Metabolism is one of the most ancient and fundamental systems, sustaining life by extracting energy from extracellular nutrients. Here we study metabolism’s potential for innovation by analyzing an exhaustive genotype-phenotype map for a space of 101 metabolisms that encodes all possible subsets of 51 reactions in central metabolism. Using flux analysis, we predict the viability of these metabolisms on 10 different carbon sources which give 102 potential phenotypes.
Trypanosoma cruz, the causative agent of Chagas disease, is transmitted by triatomine bugs of the Triatoma dimata complex. The genetic diversity and phylogeography of T. dimata haplogroups were analyzed in Mexico and across the Neotropics. Two fragments of the ND4 gene were sequenced to determine haplog specificity. At landscape, regional, and biogeographic scales, T. dimata genetic diversity was lowest where there was greatest anthropic modification, and T cruz infection was highest. cruz prevalence was higher in haplog 1 and 3, lower in haplog 2. DT and DTI frequencies differed in hap 1 and 3, but not in 2. All Neotropical haplog had moderate to high haplotype diversity, greatest differentiation between 1 and 3 ( FST = 0.868, p <.000 ). Divergence from MRCA was 0.97 MY (0.55–1.53 ) and 0.85 MY (.42–1.5 ) for ND4 and concatenated, respectively, with 2 and 3 diverging from MRCA. Effective population size 1 and 2 increased 0.02–.03 MY.
Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) is a rod-borne disease caused by hantaviruses in China: Hanta virus and Seoul. Environmental factors significantly affect the risk of contractingant infections, primarily through their effects on rodent dynamics and human-rod contact. We aimed to clarify the environmental factors favoring rod-to-human transmission to provide evidence for effective HFR prevention and control. We analyzed 10-year (2006–2015 ) field data on rod hosts for havirus, epidemiological and environmental data from satellite and meteorological stations, and rod-human rates to quantify relationships among environmental, rod species and FR occurrence. The study included 709 HFR cases. Rodent species in Chhou, havirus hotspot comprised Rattus norveicus, musculus, R flavius and others (lose and Microtus fortis calamorum ). Rod species played different roles across land types, all associated with transmission. Some were with FR occurrence in forest and water, norveicus and flavius in grassland, mus and flavi in built. Rod community was associated with environmental variability. Predictive models based on these factors were validated by good fit: cultivated land predicted highest FR incidence accords 201–201.
Activating mutations in codon 12 of the HRAS proto-oncogene are a common cause of Costello syndrome (CS). Mutations in codon 12 are frequent in cancers, but rare in CS, where they are associated with a severe, early lethal phenotype. We report an unusual germline mutation c.35_36GC>T in a 12-year-old boy with attenuated CS. Analysis of HRAS cDNA showed high levels of exon 2 skipping. Using wild and mutant HRAS minigenes, we confirmed c.35_36>T results in exon 2 skipping by disrupting a critical Exonic Splicing Enhancer (SE ) and Exonic Splicing Silencer (SS ). We show that HR exon 2 is vulnerable to splicing due to a weak 3’ splice site, making exon 2 dependent on splicing proteins like SRS. The majority of cancer- and CS causing mutations are located here and affect splicing differently. Our results show that CS and somatic cancers are not only determined by different mutant HRAS potentials but also by exon 2 inclusion efficiency from HR. We show a splice oligonucleotide (SO) that blocks criticalSE causes exon skipping and halts cancer proliferation. This unravels a potential for anti-cancer therapies based on SO-mediated HR exon 2 skipping.
Methyltransferase-like 3 (METTL3) is a key factor in the formation of N6-methyladenosine (m6A) RNA methylation, the most abundant modification of mRNAs. In mammals, the function of MET3 and m6 modification in development is unclear. Here, we show that inactivation of MET3 in the nervous system causes severe developmental defects in the brain. MET3 knockout (KO) mice manifest cerebellar hypoplasia caused by enhanced apoptosis of cerebellar granule cells (CG) in the external granular layer (EGL). MET3 depletion-induced loss of mA causes extended RNA half-lives and aberrant splicing, leading to dysregulation of transcript-wide expression and CG death.
Transcription factors are proteins that regulate gene expression by binding to cis-regulatory sequences such as promoters and enhancers. In embryonic stem (ES) cells, the binding of transcription factors OCT4, SOX2 and NANOG is essential to maintain the capacity of cells to differentiate into any cell type of the embryo. In this study, we show that combinatorial binding is strongly associated with co-localization of the transcription coactivator Mediator H3Kac and increased expression of nearby genes in ES cells. We observe that loci bound by Oct, Nanog and Sox in ES frequently drive expression in embryonic development. Comparison of mouse and human ES cells shows that less than 5% of individual binding events for OCT, SO2 and NANOG are shared between species. In contrast, about 15% of combinator binding events and 53–63% of combinator binding at enhancers active in early development are conserved.
Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is initiated by the AML/ETO oncogenic transcription factor, which is generated by a reciprocal translocation involving chromosomes 8 and 21. AML/ETO recruits co-repressor complexes to DNA and interferes with the function of its wild-type counterpart, AML, by targeting AML binding sites. However, A/ETO’s transcriptional regulation probably relies on a more complex network since it interacts with other transcription factors, such as E-proteins, and targets other DNA sites. Genome-wide chromatin immunoprecipitation and expression profiling were used to identify A/dependent transcriptional regulation. A/ was found to co-localize with, demonstrating the fusion follows the binding pattern of the wild protein but does not primarily displace it. The binding of E-protein H was grossly rearranged upon A/ expression, and was found to co-local with both and H on many regulated targets. Furthermore, the level of H was increased in primary and cell lines expressing.
In Leishmania donovani is a protozoan parasite that causes leishmaniasis, a major public health problem in tropical and subtropical regions. In this study, we investigated the role of histone acetyltransferase H2 (H2) in cell cycle regulation. We found that H2 is constitutively acetylates histone H4 on lysine10 (H4K10) in vitro and in vivo, and is essential for cell growth and survival. H2-depleted cells displayed cell cycle defects and poor survival in host cells. We found that downregulation of cyclins CY4 and CY9 were responsible for S and G/M phase defects in H2-depleted cells. CY4 and CY9 are coordinately transcribed in polyc units with other genes, but their expression was reduced in H2-de cells without downregulation of other genes in the unit. We found that CY4 and CY9 have their own promoters and are activated in cell cycle-dependent manner. CY4 and CY were transcriptionally activated from their promoters at specific cell stages. This suggests two tiers of regulation: transcription of polyc units initiates at divergent switch regions (dSRs), likely constitutively, and a subset of genes have own promoters, some of which are activated cell cycle-dependent. This second tier is sensitive to H10 acetylation, resulting in downregulation in H-de cells.
Inferring the intentions of others is a fundamental problem in many social transactions. To investigate the underlying mechanisms, we applied computational modeling to behavioral data from an economic game in which 16 pairs of volunteers were randomly assigned to “player” or “adviser” roles interacted. The player performed a probabilistic learning task, receiving information about a binary lottery from a visual chart. The adviser, who received more information, issued a recommendation. Critically, the game was structured such that adviser's incentives to provide helpful or misleading information varied in time. Using a meta-Bay modeling, we found that players' behavior was best explained by deployment of hierarchical learning: they inferred adviser's intentions to optimize predictions about advice validity. Volatility also affected trial-by-trial variability: participants were more likely to rely on estimates for choices when believed adviser's intentions were stable. Our model predicted players' interpersonal reactivity ( IRI ) scores, advisers' helpfulness ratings and advisers' self-reports strategy.
Scrub typhus is an endemic in Asia and has traditionally been considered a rural disease. However, indigenous urban cases have been reported in Seoul, the largest city in South Korea. Scrub tyus may have a significant impact because of large population. Scrub tyus was epidemiologically identified in Seoul using national notifiable disease data from 2010 to 201. Patients from one hospital were selected and compared to a control group. Chigger mites were collected in the city and identified using phenic and 18 rDNA analyses. Infection with Orientia tsugushi was confirmed by 56-kDa antigen. Eighty cases of scrub tyus were in Seoul. Sites of infection were mountainous (56.8%), parks (20.5%), vicinity of own residence (17.%) and rivers (5.7%). Eighty chiggerites were collected in Gwan mountain, one of suspected sites in Seoul and seventy-six (87.4%) were identified as Helenula miagawa and eight (9.2%) as Leotridium scell. Pooled DNA from miagites yielded O tsugushi Bong. Twenty-six patients showed low APACHE score (3.4±2.7), low rate (3.%) and no hypalemia.
In Caenorhabditis elegans, the HEN1 homolog HENN-1 is involved in the methylation of 3′ ends of small RNAs. This process is part of the RNA interference (RNAi ) pathway, which affects gene activity by recruiting Ago proteins to target mRNAs. Here, we describe the effects of HENN-1 on two RNAi pathways that employ methylated RNAs: the 26 and 21 pathways. We find that in the germline, 21 RNAs are only mildly affected by loss of methylation and introduction of artificial 21 target does not destabilize non-methylated 21 RN. In contrast, most 26 RN display reduced stability and respond to loss of H-1 by increased 3′uridylation. Within 26, we find that ERGO-1-bound 26 are modified by H-, while ALG/AL4-bound 26 are not. Global expression analysis of h- mutants reveals mild effects, including downregulation of gerine-expressed genes. Our data suggest that apart from direct effects on 26 levels, most effects on expression are indirect.
Genomics Meets Glycomics: The First GWAS Study Identifies HNF1α as a Master Regulator of Protein Glycosylation  
Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) and high-throughput glycomics analysis of 2,705 individuals in three cohorts identified common variants in the Hepatocyte Nuclear Factor 1α (HNF1α) and fucosyltransferase genes FUT6 and F8 that influence N-glycan levels in human plasma. We show that NFα and its downstream NF4 regulate the expression of fucyltransfer and fucose biosynthesis genes. Moreover, we show NFα is both necessary and sufficient to drive expression of these genes in hepatic cells. These results reveal a new role for NFα as a transcriptional regulator of multiple stages in theucylation.
Centromeres are the points of attachment between the genome and the cytoskeleton, where kinetochores bind to spindles and move chromosomes. Paradoxically, the DNA sequence of centeres has little role in perpetuating kinetocho. We show that RNA transcribed from centeres remains within the kinetoch region and is part of the epigenetic marking system. We carried out a genetic and biochemical study of maize CEN, a key kinetoch protein. We show that DNA binding is conferred by a region of 122 amino acids and is exquisitely sensitive to single-stranded RNA. Long single-stranded nucleic acids promote binding of CEN to DNA, and types of RN that stabilize match size and character of RN present in kineto in vivo. Removal of the module with HIVase domain causes partial delocalization ofEN in vivo.
Genetic variants associated with birth weight (BW), childhood obesity (CO), and body mass index (CBMI) have been identified in genome-wide association studies (GWAS). The placenta plays a critical role in fetal development and postnatal health. We investigated the role of the placental transcriptome and expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) in mediating the genetic causes of BW, CO, and CBMI, and applied integrative analysis of colocalization and MetaX. GW loci associated with BW, CO, and CBMI were substantially enriched for placental eQTL (6.76, 4.83, and 2.26, respectively). Importantly, compared to eQTL of adult tissues, placental eQ contribute significantly to anthropometric outcomes at birth (BW) and childhood phenotypes (CO/CBMI). Eight and six transcripts colocalized with BW, and CBMI risk loci, respectively. Our study reveals that placental transcription in utero likely plays a role in determining postnatal size, and may hold new possibilities for interventions to prevent childhood obesity.
Kala-azar is a chronic disease caused by the parasite Leishmania donovani and transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. Kala-azar visceral ( VL ) is the most severe form of the disease, but Kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis ( PKDL ) is a chronic form of the disease that generally does not require much attention. PKDL is relevant in the context of VL elimination. There is no standard guideline for diagnosis and treatment of PKDL. A study was conducted in Malda district, West Bengal, India to determine the disease burden, compare diagnostic tools for PKDL detection and pattern of lesion regression after treatment. PKDL was determined by active surveillance and confirmed by PCR diagnosis. Patients were treated with sodium stibogluconate ( SSG ) or miltefosine and followed for two years to observe lesion regression. Twenty PK cases were detected with a prevalence of 27.5% among leishmanial antibody positive cases. PCR was highly sensitive 88.46% for confirmation. Majority of skin lesions persisted after treatment and disappeared 6–12 months post treatment. Reappearance noted in two cases after 1.5 years milteine treatment. A number of PK patients remained undiagnosed without active surveys. Such surveys are required in other areas to attain VL elimination.
Competence is an inducible program in Streptococcus pneumoniae that enables genetic transformation and horizontal gene transfer. Competence development in liquid cultures is synchronized within the whole population and depends on exported Competence Stimulating Peptide ( CSP ), which generates a positive feedback loop. However, it is unclear how this CSP-dependent population switch is coordinated. We monitored competence in real time during growth of four distinct pneumocococcal lineages and found that competence relies on a self-activated fraction that arises via growth-dependent mechanism. CSP remains bound to cells during this event and competence rate corresponds to propagation between activated and quiescent cells. We validated two-step contact mechanism by measuring development during co-cult of strains altered to produce or respond CSP. Finally, membrane protein Com retains CSP, limiting diffusion in medium.
Human papillomavirus type 16 (HPV) is a DNA virus that infects epithelial cells. The L2 protein of HPV acts as a chaper to transport the viral genome (vDNA) from endosomes to the trans-Golgi network (TGN) and eventually to the nucleus, where replication occurs. To reach the nucleus, the L2/DNA complex must cross intracellular membranes. We developed a system based on subcellular compartmentalization of BirA and its substrate to detect translocation of L2 from incoming virions. We find that L translocation requires transport to TGN and is strictly dependent on entry into mitosis, coinciding with mitotic entry in synchronized cells. Cell cycle arrest causes retention of L/DNA at TGN; only release and progression G/M enables translocation across limiting membrane and infection. Microscopy of Ed-labeled vDNA reveals a rapid and dramatic in vDNA localization during mitosis. At G2/earlyphase vgress from TGN to pericent location, accumulating prometaph where it begins to associate with condensed. By metaphase and anaphase v is bound to mitotic, ensuring distribution into daughter. Mutations in defined chromatin binding of L block trans, suggesting trans dependent on chromatin promet. This represents first virus to functionally couple penetration limiting membranes to mitosis, explaining part tropism for mitotic keratinocytes.
Influenza transmission is a major public health problem worldwide. The relative transmissibility of one strain of influenza compared to another is important in three contexts: (1) emergence of antigenically novel strains, (2) pandemic, and (3) emergence of drug-resistant strains due to neuraminidase inhibitors (NAIs). We present a mathematical framework to estimate the relative transmiss of one strain compared to another using data from competitive experiments in which animals are co-infected with a mixture of two strains. We observe the mixture in each animal over time and multiple generations of transmission. We use data from ferret experiments to demonstrate the approach. The framework also estimates the size of the transmitted inoculum. The transibility of two strains is critical in determining the epidemiology of an outbreak or the impact of an intervention such as NAI. The method has applicability beyond influenza to other viral and bacterial pathogens.
Plants integrate light and abscisic acid ( ABA ) signals to adapt to their environment and survive. We show that BBX21, a B-box protein that regulates seedling photomorphogenesis, is also involved in ABA signaling. BB21 acts upstream of ABA INSENSITIVE ( ABI ) and ELONG HYCOTYL 5 (HY ) in seed germination. HY acts as a direct activator of ABI5 and BB21 interacts with HY. BB21 negatively regulates ABI expression by interfering with HY binding to the ABI promoter. In addition, ABI activates its own expression and BB21 negatively regulates this activity by interacting with ABI. Our study shows that BB21 coordinates with HY and ABI on the ABI promoter and these regulators work together to integrate light and A signaling in Arabidopsis thaliana.
The Mediator is an essential co-regulator of RNA polymerase II that is conserved throughout eukaryotes. In the pathogenic fungus Candida albicans (C. albicans ), we investigated the functions of the Mediator subunits Med31, Med20, and Srb/Med13. We found that C. alb Med shares some roles with the model yeasts Saccharomyces cerevisiae ( S. cerevisiae ) and Schoscharomyces pombe ( S. pombe ), such as functions in response to certain stresses and the role of Med31 in expression of genes regulated by the activator Ace2. However, C. alb Med also has additional roles in transcription of genes associated with virulence, for example genes related to morphogenesis and families enriched in pathogens, such as adhesins. Consistently, Med31,20, and S9/M13 contribute to virulence attributes of C. alb, filamentation, biofilm formation, and ALS1 is biologically relevant of Med for biofilm development. Furthermore, Med affects virulence of. alb in the infection model. We found that Med and S9/M13 in expression of genes encoding wall adhes are different between S cere and C : are repressors of F genes in S cere are activators of ALS in C. This suggests Med subunits regulate adhesion in a manner between two distantly fungal species.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa biofilms are known to be more tolerant to antibiotics than their planktonic counterparts. To understand the degree to which the biofilm state and its genetic determinants contribute to this tolerance, we used genome-wide profiling of a complex Pseudomonas aeruginosa MPA1 biofilm and plankic population with tobramycin to quantify the contribution of each locus to tolerance under these conditions. We identified sets of mutations that contribute to tolerance predominantly in the biofilm or plankic setting, providing insights into the differences and similarities between biofilm and plankic antibiotic tolerance. Our mixed experimental design recapitulated the complexity of natural biofilms and revealed the emergence of quorum-deficient mutants. We found a substantial contribution of the biofilm state to antibiotic tolerance, providing a foundation for novel therapeutics against P. aerugin biofilm infections.
Most biological systems are difficult to analyze due to the multitude of interacting components and concomitant lack of information about the dynamics. Model selection algorithms that evaluate the performance of a multitude of models against experimental data provide a useful tool to identify model structures. However, algorithms addressing complex systems are often compare preselected models or rely on exhaustive searches that might be unfeasible. We developed an algorithm that performs selection on complex systems and searches large spaces in a dynamical way. Our algorithm includes local and non-local methods that prevent ending in local minima by accounting similar processes. We tested and validated on simulated data and showed flexibility handling different structures. We used to analyze experimental data on CD+ and CD+ cells cultured under different conditions. indicated changes within proliferation was reduced in 3D cultures compared to suspension.
In Bolivia, the National Program for Chagas was implemented in 2006 and led to a decrease in the number of Trypanosoma cruzi infections through vector control. Subsequently, treatment with benznidazole ( BN ) was initiated in seropositive school children living in vector control areas. We conducted a 12-month follow-up study with seven blood samples taken before and after treatment. Serology, conventional PCR, and quantitative PCR were performed. Plasma Th1/2/17 cytokines were also determined. Approximately 73% of seropitive children completed BN with three due to side effects. To evaluate treatment efficacy, PCR and PCR values during the final 6 months of follow-up were observed. Among 57 who completed follow, 6 (11% ) showed both PCR and PCR ( ), 24 (42 ) PCR but PCR ( ) and 27 (47 ) PCR and PCR. Within Th1/2/17 cytokines, IL-17 was higher in seritive before treatment compared to age-matched serative and decreased to normal one-year after. Moreover, IL-17 was positively related to parasite counts by PCR. At 12 months, IL-17 of non-reactive were higher than reactive or ambiguous suggesting IL-17 useful to determine BN reactivity.
Neisseria meningitidis, the causative agent of bacterial meningitis, has a genome that is rich in repetitive DNA. Almost 2% of the genome is occupied by a small transposon called Coria. Here we report a bioinformatic analysis of eight subtypes of Coria with four types of ends. Transcriptional analysis using PCR and lacZ reporter revealed that two ends encode strong promoters. The strongest promoter is dictated by polymorphism Y128 at the right end of the element. We highlight examples of elements that drive transcription of adjacent genes and others that express non-coding RNAs. Pairwise comparisons of three meningoccal genomes revealed that more than two-thirds of Coria maintain subtype at any locus. This is due to recombinational switching between elements in a strain. Upon switching, a new subtype is available to spread through population by natural transformation. This may represent a hitherto mechanism for variation in meningococcus. We conclude that strain-to-strain variability of Coria and number of strong promoters by them allows for widespread effects in population. By defining strength of promoters by subtypes Coria, we provide resource for transcription of subtype at locus to be predicted.
Chae and Vel regulate toxin production, virulence, oxidative stress, and development in the maize pathogen Cochliobolus heterostus. Chae and Vel are orthologs of Lae and Ve, which coordinate secondary metabolism and differentiation in response to light in Aspergillus spp. In Cochliobus heterus produces a wealth of secondary metabolites, including the selective toxin Txin, which promotes virulence in maize carrying Texas sterile cytoplasm Tms. Txin production is increased in the dark in wild type ( WT ), whereas Ch1 and Vel mutants are reduced in the dark compared to WT. Correspondingly, expression of Txin biosynthetic To1 is upregulated in the dark in WT, while dark-induced expression is reduced in Ch1 and mutants.xin and To expression are increased in Vel overexpression ( OE ) strains in the dark and in Ch1 strains in light compared to WT. These observations establish Chae and Vel as the first factors to regulate selective toxin production. Virulence of mutants and OE strains is altered on Tms and normal cytoplasm maize, indicating Txin mediated virulence and pathogenicity affected. Deletion Ch or Vel reduces tolerance H2O. Expression CAT, one of three catalase genes, is reduced in Vel mutant. and mutants show decreased hyal growth, asexual sporulation and sterility. Vel OE are sterile while OE are more fertile than WT. Ch and Vel repress expression 8ihydroxynthalene ( DH ) biosynthesis, accordingly, melanization is in mutants and in OE. Thus Ch and Vel positively regulatexin biosynthesis pathogenic virulence, oxidative stress, development, hyal growth and negatively melan biosynthesis asexual.
Bacterial Nav channels have been characterized as functionally asymmetric, but the mechanism of this asymmetry has not been clearly understood. To address this question, we combined non-equilibrium simulation with two-dimensional unperturbed landscapes generated by umbrella sampling and Weighted Histogram Methods for ions traversing the selectivity of bacterial Nav channel. This provided new insight into the mechanism of selective permeation in bacterial channels. Non-equilibrium simulations indicate that two or three extracellular K ions can block the entrance of Nav in the presence of applied forces in inward, but not outward. The block occurs in an unstable minimum of the unpurbed free-energy of K that can be ‘locked in by modest forces. In contrast, Na move favor through as a unit in a “knock” mechanism in both inward and outward, and there is no minimum in two-dimensional free of Na for block.
Rabies is a fatal viral disease that affects the nervous system of mammals. It has two forms: furious and paralytic. In the furious form, the virus spreads rapidly to the brain. In the paralytic form, the virus spreads more slowly. This study compared the two forms in dogs. We measured the amount of rabies virus in the brain, spinal cord, and cerebrum of 5 dogs with furious rabies and 5 with paralytic rabies. We compared the amount of virus in cell bodies and processes. We found that the amount of virus in processes was less than in the paraly form. This was true at all levels of the brain and spinal cord. We also found that the virus spread more slowly in the paraly form. This might be because of differences in how the virus is transported inside cells. This could be because of inflammation, which is greater in the paraly form.
In Drosophila, CTC is a zinc-finger protein that has been studied as an enhancer-blocking factor in vertebrates, but has only recently been characterised in Dophila. To date, only one endogenous CTC binding site has been identified in the Doph genome, the Fab-8 insulator in the Bithax complex ( BX ). We used chromatin immunoprecipitation coupled with microarray analysis to identify CTC binding sites in representative regions of the D genome, including the 3-M Adh, BX, and Antennedia. CTC binding in vivo enabled us to construct a CTC binding consensus sequence. CTC sites in BX map to known insulators Mc, Fab-6, and Fab8. Other CTC sites correlate with boundaries of regulatory domains, allowing us to locate additional presumptive insulators “-, “, and “. With exception Fab7, our data indicate CTC is associated with all or predicted ins in BX, suggesting functioning involves common C-dependent mechanism.
The binding of a substrate to an enzyme is a fundamental process in biochemistry that often involves conformational changes in the active site to align reactive groups for catalysis and the transition state. The concept of adaptive recognition is well known, but has been poorly characterized at the structural level because of its dynamic nature. Here, we provide a detailed mechanism for the induced process at atomic resolution. We take advantage of a slow, tight inhibitor-enzyme system, actin-peptide deformylase. Crystal structures of the initial and final states were solved, as well as several intermediates captured during the process. Lig-induced reshaping of the hydrophobic pocket drives closure of the site, which is finally “zipped” by additional interactions. Together with biochemical analyses, these allow a reconstruction of the sequence from the complex to the state of the enzyme. The entire process can be extrapolated to catalysis.
Although the thalamus is the primary gateway that relays sensory information to the cerebral cortex, the influence of cortical feedback on thal relay remains largely ignored during sensory processing. Using dynamic-clamp techniques in thal slices, we combined theoretical and experimental approaches to implement a hybrid retinothalocort pathway. Cortical input was mimicked through injection of a stochastic mixture of excitatory and inhibitory conductances, resulting in a gradable level of afferent activity in thal cells. We studied the impact of cortical input on retocort signal efficiency and found a novel mechanism resulting from thal relay resonance. Transfer of sensory input depends on three features: i ) number of thalamocort cells, ii ) corticothal synaptic statistics and iii ) correlation between thal relay cells. Counterintuitively, retort efficiency increases when correlation between thal cells decreases. This suggests relay efficiency could be amplified when cells are desynchronized by cortical feedback.
Demethylase NMAD-1 plays a critical role in regulating DNA replication and repair during meiosis in Caenorhabditis elegans. Mutations in the nmad-1 gene result in reduced fertility and defects in prophase I of meiosis, leading to reduced embryo production and increased incidence of males due to defective chromosomal segregation. In nmad-1 mutant worms show disorganization of chromatin at the leptotene and zygot stages, mislocalization of the cohesin complex at diplot and diakinesis, and improper chromosome condensation or loss by diakinesis. RNA sequencing of nmad-1 germline reveals induction of DNA damage and repair genes during meiosis, coupled with delayed replication, impaired repair, and apoptosis of maturing oocytes.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a ubiquitous pathogen that can cause serious diseases in newborns and immunocompromised patients. The virus has a large genome with enormous coding potential and is equipped with complex glycoproteins that can infect a wide range of human cells. Despite multiple cellular interactions with viral glycoproteins, the mechanism of CMV infection remains a mystery. Here, we report the identification of adipocyte plasma-associated protein (AAP) as a novel modulator in the early stage of CMV infection. AAP is necessary for CMV infection in epithelial cells and fibroblasts; knockdown of AAP expression significantly reduced CMV infection in these cells. Interestingly, ectopic expression of AAP in cells refractory to CMV infection, such as MDCK and NIH/3T3, promoted CMV infection. Furthermore, reduction in viral early (IE) gene transcription at 6 post infection and delayed translocation of tegument pp65 at 4 post were detected in AAP-deficient but not wildtype cells. These results suggest AAP plays a role in early CMV infection. Biochemical studies of AAP and CM proteins suggest AAP could participate CM infection through interaction with g/g containing glycoprotein at pH and mediate translocation tegument pp.
Lineage commitment of hematopoietic progenitors is a complex process that involves both instructive and stochastic events. We propose a model that combines cell-extrinsic and cell-intrinsic elements to understand how these events inform commitment decisions. Our model suggests that cytokine-mediated receptor upregulation can induce a switch-like response to external stimuli during multilineage differentiation, providing robustness to bipotent and committed states while protecting progenitors from noise-induced decommitment. The model supports both instructive and stochastic theories of commitment: cell fates are driven by lineage-specific transcription factors, but cytokine signaling can bias commitment by regulating inherently noisy cellate decisions with complex behaviors such as ligand ultrasensitivity and multistability. Simulations show that differentiation kinetics to a mature state depend on progenitor as well as commitment route chosen. Our model agrees with lineage receptor kinetics from microarray experiments and provides a framework for both classical and alternative commitment in hematies observed.
Orthobunavirus is a genus of emerging viruses within the Bunyaviridae family that poses a threat to human and animal health. Despite its importance, little is known about its structure, which is essential for understanding virus assembly and entry. Here, we report the ultrastructure of Bunyamwera virus, the prototype member of this genus, using cryo-electron microscopy. Bunamwavirus virions are pleomorphic in shape but display a locally ordered lattice of glycoprotein spikes. Each spike protrudes 18 nm from the membrane and becomes disordered upon introduction to an acidic environment. Using subtomography, we derived a three-dimensional model of the trimeric glycoprotein spike at 3 nm resolution. The glycoprotein consists of putative class-II fusion glycop and exhibits a tripod-like arrangement. Protein-protein contacts occur at membrane-proximal and intra-spike at membrane-dist regions. This trimer deviates from previously observed glyprotein arrangements suggesting a greater repertoire of viral glyprotein oligomerization.
Primary angle closure glaucoma (PACG) is a leading cause of irreversible vision loss worldwide. The anterior chamber depth (ACD) is a key anatomical risk factor for PG. We conducted a genome-wide association study (GWAS) on 5,308 individuals of Asian descent to discover genes associated with PG. We found a genome-wide significant association with a variant in the ABCC5 gene (rs199). This variant was associated with an increased risk of PG in a separate case-control study of 4,276 PG cases and 18,801 controls (OR=1.13, 95%CI:1.06–1.22, P=0.00046). The association was strengthened when a subgroup of controls with open angles were included in the analysis (OR=1.30, P=7.45×10−3, 3,458 vs.3,831). Our findings suggest that increased PG risk could be mediated by genetic variants influencing anterior dimensions.
Although deuterostomes and protomes are two distinct animal clades, they share a common developmental toolkit of conserved transcription factors and signaling pathways. Previous studies have shown that patterning genes show similar expression and genetic interactions, suggesting a conserved regulatory apparatus. However, previous studies have found no sequence conservation between deuteromes and protomes. Here we describe the first enhancers conserved between deuteromes and protomes, which we call bilater conserved regulatory elements ( Bico ). Bico show conservation of sequence and gene synteny and conservation of Bico reflects conserved patterns of transcription factor binding. We predict that Bico act as response elements to signaling and show thatico are developmental enhancers that drive expression of transcription repressors in vertebrate nervous system.
Influenza virus diversity and antigenic drift have been well characterized on a global scale, but the factors that influence the virus’ rapid evolution within hosts are less clear. We used next generation sequencing of patient-derived viruses from a randomized, placebo-controlled vaccine trial to characterize the diversity of influenza A virus and define the impact of vaccine-induced immunity within populations. We used pre-hemagglutination and neuraminid inhibition titers to quantify vaccine immunity and assess its impact on intrah populations. We identified 166 cases of H3N influenza over 3 seasons and 511 person-years. We obtained genome data for 119 samples and used a stringent empirically validated pipeline to identify intrah single nucleotide variants ≥1%. Phylogen analysis of hemaglut and neuramin sequences showed no stratification by pre-HAI and Niter, respectively. We found that most intrah nucleotide variants were rare and few were found more than one individual. Most samples had fewer than 15 nucleotide across the genome and diversity did not vary by sampling day, vaccination status, or pre titer.
Leishmanias (VL) is a severe disease caused by the protozoan parasite Leishmania donovani. There is no effective vaccine against VL for any age group. Previously, we showed that genetically modified live attenuated L. donani (LC- ) induced a strong protective immune response in young mice. In this study, we analyzed LC- mediated immune response in aged (18 months ) and young (2 months ) mice. LC- infected bone marrow dendritic cells (BMDC) from young and aged mice showed enhanced innate effector responses and CD4+ Th cell function compared to LWT BMDC in vitro. Parasitized splenic dendritic cells from LC- infected young and aged mice induced pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-, IL-6, IF-γ and TN ) and down-regulated anti-inflammatory IL-10 compared LWT mice. LC- immunized young and aged mice displayed higher IgG2 antibodies, lymphoproliferative response, pro-inflammatory cytokines and splenocytes leishicidal activity with nitric production. Upon virulent. donani challenge, LC- immunized mice from both groups displayed multifunctional Th-type CD and cytotoxic CD T cells correlating reduced parasite burden in spleen and liver compared naïve. Interestingly, LC- induced response in dendritic cells was similar between aged and young; however, adaptive T and B cell activation in aged was reduced compared young correlating less protection in old compared young.
Enteroviruses (EVs) are a diverse group of viruses that cause a wide range of human pathologies. Despite their genetic similarities, EVs have different biophysical properties, such as acid sensitivity, optimal growth temperature, and tissue tropism, which determine their ability to replicate in the respiratory or gastrointestinal tract and are key to their virulence. To understand the cause of these differences, we generated chimeras at the capsid level between EV-D68, a respiratory EV and EV-D94, an enteric EV. Some chimeras were nonfunctional, but constructs with the capsid 2 protease of EV94 and caps of EV68 were viable. Using the latter, we performed several assays which indicated that caps proteins determine acid sensitivity and tropism in cell lines in respiratory, intestinal and neural tissues. Additionally, caps genes were shown to participate in determining optimal growth since EV94 adapted to temperature with mutations in VP1 while constructs with EV68 caps could not adapt to higher temperatures. Finally, we show that EV68 retains binding capacity after acid treatment despite loss of infectivity. In contrast, nonstructural proteins modulate the immune response in tissues.
Herpes Simplex Virus 1 (HSV-1) glycoprotein gEI is a transmembrane receptor found on the surface of infected cells and virions that binds human immunoglobulin G (Ig). gI can also participate in antibody bridging (ABB), a process by which antigen-binding fragments (Fab) of Ig bind viral antigen while Fc binds to gI.IgFc binds gI at basic, not acidic pH, suggesting Ig bound extracellular by surface gI would dissociate and degraded in acidic endosomes/lysosomes ifocytosed. We developed an in vitro system for ABB and investigated trafficking of ABB using 4-D confocal imaging of complexes with transferrin epidermal growth factor, characterized intracellular markers. Our data showed cells expressing gI and viral HSV-1 endocyted antiIg and in gI-dependent, resulting lysosomal localization.
Cysticercosis (CH) is a parasitic disease caused by the larval stages of the tapeworm Echinococcus granulosus that affects humans and domestic animals worldwide. The protoscoleces (Ps) are a component of the larval stages that interact with both definitive and intermediate hosts. Previous genomic and transcriptomic studies have provided an overall view of the parasite’s genome and development. However, how Ps subvert the host immune response and maintain metabolic adaptation remains unclear. This study used Roche 454 sequencing and in silico analysis to explore the transcriptome of Ps from E. granus and elucidate the functions of excretory-secretory proteins (ESPs) released by the parasite. A large number of non-redundant sequences were generated (26, 514), of which 22,910 (86. 4%) were mapped to the published E. granus genome and 17,705 (66.8%) were within coding sequence (CDS) regions. Of 2,280Ps predicted from the transcript, 138 were involved in carbohydrate metabolism and 124 in protein metabolism. Eleven were intracellular enzymes regulating glycolysis/glucone (GL) pathways and 44 antigenic proteins, molecular chaperones and proteases were highly represented. Many were also enriched in development-related pathways such as TGFβ and insulin. This study provides valuable information on parasite adaptation to hosts that can be used to develop novel targets for hydat treatment and control.
In Aspergillus nidulans, the transcription of nitrate assimilatory genes is regulated by the pathway-specific transcription factor NirA. In the absence of nitrate, NirA is predominantly cytosolic and inactive. However, in the presence of nitrate, NirA accumulates in the nucleus and is transcriptionally active. We found that in the absence of nit, NirA is oxidized at methion 169 in the nuclear export sequence ( NES ) to methion sulfoxide ( Metox ). This oxidation is dependent on Fmo, a flav-containing monooxygenase that uses methion and cystine as substrates, but not glutathione. The function of Fmo cannot be replaced by alternative F proteins present in A. nidans. In the presence of nitrate, Nir-Metox is rapidly reduced to Met169. This reduction is independent of thiorexin and classical methion sulfox reductases. Replacement of Met169 byoleucine, a sterically similar but not oxidizable residue, leads to partial loss of Nir activity and insensitivity to Fmo-mediated export. In contrast, replacement by alanine transforms Nir into a permanently nuclear active factor. Co-immoprecipitation and subcellular studies show that Met oxidation leads to Nir conformational change.
Voltage-gated sodium channels are essential for the propagation of action potentials in excitable cells. Since the 1950s, mathematical models by Hodgkin and Hux have suggested that sodium channel properties need to be tightly constrained for an action potential to propagate. However, there are nine mammalian genes encoding voltage-gated sodium channels, many of which are more than 90% identical in sequence. This similarity presumably corresponds to similarity of function, consistent with the idea that these properties are tightly constrained. However, the multiplicity of genes encoding channels raises the question: why there are so many? We demonstrate that the simplest constraints on sodium channel diversity—requirements of excitability and uniqueness of resting potential—directly constrain sodium properties. We compare these constraints with data on mammalian channel properties collected from the literature, including 172 sets of measurements from 40 publications, wild-type and mutant, under a variety of conditions. The data from all channels, including mutants, obeys the excitability constraint; on the other hand, channels in muscle tend to obey the constraint of resting, while in neuronal do not. Excitability alone distinguishes channels into four groups consistent with phylogen analysis.
Influenza virus polymerase is an attractive target for antiviral drugs as it can stop viral replication at an early stage. Recent studies on the heterotrimeric polymer, comprising subunits PA, PB1 and PB2, allow for a structure-based approach to optimise inhibitors of replication. The unique cap-snatching mechanism of transcription can be inhibited by targeting the PB cap-binding or endonuc domains. Here we describe high resolution X-ray coystal structures of the 2009 H1N1 PA enduc domain with a series of specific inhibitors, including diketo compounds and green tea catechin, which chelate two manganese ions in the active site.
Snakes are estimated to cause 1.8 million envenomings and 94,000 deaths annually, mostly in tropical countries. Specific antivenoms are the only effective therapy for these cases. Efforts are made to produce effective, affordable antiven for victims. The immunization process, rarely described in detail, is a step to be rigorously studied, especially regarding production of polyspecific antisera. The aim of this study was to produce polyspecific antisera against medically important Thai and neighboring snakes, namely Cryptelytrops alabris “White lipped viper”, Caloselasma rhodoma “Malayan viper”, and Dabo siensis “Russ’s viper”. Four horses were immunized with mixture of 3 venoms using “low dose, low multi-site” immunization protocol. Antisera showed rapid rise in ELISA titers against 3 venoms and plateau at 8 week post-immun. In vivo neutralization potency of antis against CA, CR, DS ven was 10.40, 2.42 0.76 mg/ml, higher than minimal limits by Queen Savab Memorial ( QI ). Corresponding values for QI monospecific antis against CA, DS ven were 7.28 3.12 1.50/ml. Polyspecific antis also neutralized procoagulant, hemorrh, necrotoxic activities of venoms.
Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium causes systemic infections that can persist for long periods of time despite a strong immune response. The bacteria can be transmitted to naïve hosts via the feces of chronically infected animals. We show that the effector protein Sse, translocated into host cells by the Salmonella Pathogenic Island 2 ( SPI ) type III secretion system, is required for Salmonella to maintain long-term systemic infection in mice. In vitro, S inhibits normal migration of primary macrophages and dendritic cells ( DC ) and requires the IQ motif containing GTPase protein 1 ( IQAP ), a regulator of cell migration. S binds IQAP and co-localizes with this factor at the cell periphery. The C-terminal of S is similar to PM/ToxA, a toxin with a cysteine residue critical for activity. Mutation of the corresponding in S eliminates S function in vitro and in vivo but not IQAP binding. Infection with wild-type S suppressed DC migration to spleen in S-dependent. Correspondingly, examination of spleens from infected with S revealed fewer DC and CD+ lymphocytes compared to infected Δ S.
Community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (CA-MRSA) is a highly virulent pathogen that causes severe disease in healthy individuals and is more virulent than hospital-associated methicillin-resistant Staphlococcus aureus (HA-MRSA). The molecular basis for the high virulence of CA-MRSA is not known. Here we report that the product of the psmec gene, located in the mobile genetic element SCCmec of HA-MRSA but not CA-MRSA, suppresses the expression of phenol-sol-soluble modulin α (PSMα), a cytolytic toxin of S. aureus. We show that psmec RNA inhibits translation of the agr gene encoding a transcription factor for PSα via specific binding to agr mRNA. Furthermore, 25% of 325 clinical MRSA isolates had a mutation in psmec that attenuated transcription and 9% had no psmec. Most of these psm-mutated or psmec-deleted HA-MRSA had increased PSα expression compared to strains carrying psmec and some produced high amounts of PSα comparable to CA-MRSA. Deletion of psm from HA-MRSA carrying psmec increased expression of Agr and PSα and virulence in mice. Thus p RNA suppresses MRSA virulence via inhibition of Agr translation and absence of p in CARSA causes high virulence.
Severe deng is a major public health problem in tropical and subtropical regions. Epidemiological studies have shown that babies born to deng immune mothers are at risk of developing severe disease upon primary infection with heterolog or homolog deng virus (DENV) serotype. This has been explained by the antibody-mediated disease (ADE) phenomenon, whereby heterolog antibodies bind to but fail to neutralize homolog DENV, allowing F-receptor mediated entry of virus-antibody complexes into cells. This results in enhanced replication and inflammatory responses. Here, we report a mouse model of ADE in type I interferon (IFN)-deficient mice. We show that 5-week-old IFN-deficient mice born to DENV-immune mothers succumbed to D2 infection within 4 days that was lethal in mice born naïve mothers. Clinical manifestations included extensive hepatocyte vacuolation, moderate vascular leakage, lymphopenia and thrombocytopenia. Anti-TNF therapy protected mice and correlated with healthy hepatocytes. In contrast, IL-6 did not impact titers or outcome. This model may help dissect ADE mechanisms and evaluate vaccine/therapeutic candidates.
Visceral Leishias in the Americas: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis  
   Visceraliasis is a disease caused by Leishmania parasites transmitted by sandflies. Despite more than 30 years of urbanization, little is known about the factors associated with its occurrence. This study is the first systematic review and meta-analysis of factors associated with Leishmanias in humans in the Americas. Fifty-one studies were reviewed after searching databases, reference lists, and expert consultations. Meta-analysis was used to pool information about each variable. Heterogeneity among studies was assessed with Q and I2 statistic. Male sex was associated with visceral leishias in studies using leishman skin test and clinical outcome, but opposite with serological diagnosis. Young were less frequently infected than adults but more prone to illness. Presence of dogs at home, higher seropositivity nearby, lower socioeconomic status, and vegetated areas were associated with Leish. This was not for presence of chickens and nutritional status.
Inhalation of Francisella tularensis (Ft) causes acute and fatal pneumonia. The lung environment favors Ft replication, but the mechanisms of acute pathogenesis and lethality remain unknown. In contrast to overwhelming bacterial burden or cytokine production, an innate cellular response to Ft drives pathology and host mortality. Leth infection with Ft elicits medullary and extra-medullary myopoiesis supporting large numbers of immature myeloid and MDSCs to the lungs. These fail to mature and lead to necrotic lung damage, loss of function and death partially dependent on Ly6+ cells. Acceleration of this process may account for rapid lethality with FtS4. In contrast, sub-lethal infection Ft the cellular response is characterized by mature neutrophils and monocytes required for protection, suggesting a threshold for lethal infection. Further eliciting mature phagocyte provides transient but dramatic protection against Ft4. This study reveals the nature of myoid response may be primary determinant of mortality versus survival following Francis infection.
Aedes albopictus, the Asian tiger mosquito, is an invasive vector of medically important arboviruses such as chikungunya ( CHV ), deng ( DENV ) and Zika ( ZIK ). We reconstructed the colonization pattern of this species using classical genetics and Approximate Bayesian Computation ( ABC ) to infer the demographic history of populations in Southeast Asia and recently colonized areas. In Southeast Asia, we found low differentiation and high coancestry among China, Thailand and Japan, indicating high connectivity and a common origin. China is the oldest population. Outside Asia, invasion in Réunion, America and the Mediterranean is supported by chaotic propagule distribution, maintaining high diversity in adventive populations. Our data suggest independent transcontinental introductions of Ae. albictus may have established adventive populations through admixture of unrelated genomes. Intra-population variability has been detected, likely extending to mechanisms controlling vector competence. In the context of invasion, ancestry and admixture may create conditions for efficient arvirus transmission and outbreak.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic pathogen that causes chronic and acute infections in humans. While much is known about acute pathogenesis, little is known about chronic infections. We sought to identify genes and functions that mediate fitness of Pseudomonas aeruginosa in chronic wounds. We found that clinical isolates from human chronic wounds were frequently defective in virulence functions and biofilm formation, and that virulence and biofilm genes were not required for fitness in experimental wounds. In contrast, genes involved in anaerobic growth, metabolic and energy, and membrane integrity were critical. These findings are consistent with fitness of some impaired mutants being represented by anaobic, oxidative, and membrane-stressed conditions ex vivo and comprehensively by high-density growth in the absence of a host.
Hydrocele is the most common manifestation of bancroftian filariasis, a disease endemic in 80 countries. In a prospective study, we evaluated the occurrence of intrascrot lymphangiectasia, appearance/consistency of test, and efficacy of complete excision hydrocele sac in patients living bancroian filasis endemic who underwent hydrolectomy at the Center for Teaching, Research Tertiary Referral for Bancroian Filasis ( NEF ). A total 968 patients with uni or bilateral hydrocele ( Group-1 ) and Comparison (CG ) of 218 patients from same area already undergone hydrocele-sparing hydrolect elsewhere were enrolled at NEF. Twenty patients from Comparison with hydrocele were reoperated at NEF constitute Group-2. In Group-1 total 128 hydrolectomies were performed ( mean age 30.3yr and follow 8.6yr [5–12] ). hydro recurrence in Group and Comparison ( age 31.5 ) were 0.3% and 19.% respectively (0.001 ) There was no recurrence Group ( age 25.1 and follow 6yr [–6.9 ]. surgically leaking or leakone dilated lymphatic vessels were in inner or outer hydro wall or surrounding tissue particularly retroicular in 30.9 and 46% patients Group and respectively (0.081. test were abnormal shape, volume in 203/128 (18% ) and 10/28 (35.7 ) patients Group and respectively (0.025.
Trichinella spiralis is a zoonotic nematode parasite that causes trichlosis, a disease found on all continents except Antarctica. During chronic infection, T. spir larvae infect skeletal muscle cells, severely disrupting their differentiation. To identify deubitinating enzymes ( DUBs ) in T. spir larvae, we used an activity-based probe, HA-Ub-V. Immunoblot and immunoprecipitation identified a number of Ds. Immunoprecipitated proteins were subjected to LC/MS, yielding peptides with homology to conserved Ds: UCH5, U3, HAP, OT 6 and Atin-3. The gene encoding putative UCH5 homologue, Ts37, was cloned and recombinant protein expressed and purified. Deubitinating activity was verified by Ub-AM assay. Coipitation of recomant Ts37 showed association with putative T proteome components, including yeastpn hom ADR1. In addition, inhibitor LD-44 exhibited specific inhibition of recomant Ts37 and reduced viability of cultured larvae. This study reports the first TUB, a cystine protease orthologous to human UCH5.
Cysteine protease cruzain is a validated target for therapeutic intervention in the treatment of Chagas disease, a parasitic disease caused by the protozoan Trypanosoma cruzi. In this study, we report the anti-tryosomal activity of a series of nitrile-based cystine protease inhibitors against the CLner strain of T. cruzi. The compounds were based on scaffolds known to be associated with cathepsin inhibition, a different from cruzain, the recombinant form of cruzain. The compounds showed anti-tryosomal activity in the 0. 1–1 μM range, with the two most potent compounds having EC50 values of 0.12 μM and 0.25M. These values were an order of magnitude lower than the Ki measured against cruzain in an enzyme assay, suggesting that anti-tryosomal activity may not be solely due to cruzain inhibition. This implies a putative polypharmac profile towards cystine proteases.
Maize (Zea mays) is one of the most important cereal crops and a model for the study of genetics and evolution. To better understand maize genome organization, we constructed a sequence-fingerprinted contig-based map that covers 93. 5% of the genome, of which 86.1% is aligned to genetic map. The fingerprint contig map contains 25,908 genic markers that enabled to align nearly 73% of maize genome to rice. The pattern of expressed sequence tags correlates to recombination in linear, 1 kb in rice corresponds to average 3.2 in maize, yet maize has 6-fold genome size. This can be explained by fact that most regions correspond two in maize as result of recent polyploid. Inversions account majority of chromosome variations during subsequent maize diploid. We find clear evidence of ancient duplication predating divergence of maize and rice progenitors.
Prions are infectious agents responsible for transmissible spong encephalopathies. They are composed of a misfolded version of the prion protein (PrPSc) that replicates in the body in the absence of nucleic acids by inducing misfolding of the cellular prion protein (Pr. The most common form of human prion disease is sporadic, which appears to originate from a low frequency of spontaneous misfolding to generate the first PrSc particle that propagates in the form of the disease. This study aimed to mimic the early etiology of sporadic disease by de novo generation of infectious PrSc in vitro. We analyzed the possibility of spontaneous generation of PrSc by protein misfolding amplification (PM) procedure. Under standard PM conditions, de novo generation of PrSc was not observed. However, we report that PM can generate PrSc in the absence of pre-existing PrSc in different species at a low rate. De novo PrSc was infectious when inoculated into hamsters, producing a new disease with clinical, neuropathological and biochemical features.
Bees are able to estimate their angular velocity (AV) during flight by using visual information from their compound eyes. We present a novel neural model for estimating AV in the bee brain that quantitatively reproduces experimental observations of visual odometry and corridor-centering in free-flying honeybees. The model is based on electrophysiological data and tested using behavioural data. We suggest that AV can be considered an extension of the optomotor response. The model is tested behaviourally in silico with the corridor-center paradigm, where bees navigate a corridor with gratings ( square or sinusoidal ) on the walls. When combined with an existing flight algorithm, the model reproduces the invariance of the flight path to the frequency and contrast of the gratings, including deviations from centering behaviour found in real bees. In addition, the response of the model to distance along the corridor is constant for a range of grating frequencies, demonstrating it can be used as visual odometer.
Trypanosoma brucei gambense, the causative agent of African trypanosomiasis (sleeping sickness), has long been considered invariably fatal. However, we report on a 15-year follow-up of 50 patients from the Ivory Coast who refused treatment after diagnosis. Among 11 who continued to refuse treatment, parasite clearance was observed using microscopy and polymerase chain reaction (PCR) in 10/11 subjects. These patients also displayed decreasing serological responses to trypanosome antigens (Li 1. 3, 1.5 and 1.6). In addition to the classic lethal outcome of African trypanosomiasis, we show two alternative progressions: (1) aparasitemic and asymptomatic infection with long-lasting serological responses and (2) spontaneous resolution with negative parasitological and PCR results and decreasing antibody titres.
Irradiation Selects for p53-Deficient Hematopoietic Progenitors: Identification and characterization of mutations that drive cancer evolution is a major focus of cancer research. The effects of irradiation are not limited to genetic loci that encode oncogenes and tumor suppressors, as irradiation induces a multitude of changes in cells and their microenvironment that could affect the effects of oncogenic mutations. p53 is a key tumor suppressor, loss of which provides resistance to multiple genotoxic stimuli, including irradiation. We hypothesized that increased p53-deficient cells contribute to the link between irradiation and induction of lymphoid malignancies. We sought to determine whether ion irradiation selects p-deficient hematopoietic progenitors in vivo using mouse models. We found that p53 disruption does not provide a selective advantage in unstressed hematopoietic or previously irradiated BM allowed to recover from irradi. In contrast, irradiation p53 confers a selective advantage, leading to long-term p-deficient clones and increased lymphoma. Selection for p-def cells is attributable to several factors: protection from irradi-induced ablation of progenitors, prevention of irradi-induced loss clonogenic capacity for progenitors, improved maintenance progenitor fitness, and elimination of p wild-type progenitors.
Schistosoma mansoni SmKI-1 serine protease inhibitor binds to elastase and impairs neutrophil function. Schistosoma mansoni is a parasitic flatworm that causes schistosomiasis in humans. SchosmKI-1 is a serine protease inhibitor that plays a role in parasite development and inflammation. SchKI-1 inhibits trypsin and neutrophil elastase ( NE ), an enzyme involved in inflammation and tissue injury. The KIz domain of SmKI binds to NE active site and blocks its activity. SmKI-1 also inhibits the capacity of NE to kill schistosomes. We knocked down SmKI-1 in S. mansoni larvae and observed a robust impact on parasite development in vitro and in vivo. We tested SmKI-1 in murine models of inflammatory diseases. In acetaminophen ( AP )-mediated liver damage, SmKI reduced neutrophil recruitment and elastase activity. In gout arthritis, SmKI reduced neutil accumulation, IL-β secretion, hyperiception, and pathological score. Finally, SmKI inhibited neutil recruitment in response to carrageenan.
Transmembrane helical (TM) proteins are a diverse group of proteins that perform a wide range of critical functions in the cell, but their high-resolution structures are largely uncharacterized. This is due to the lack of close structural homologues. We present a novel method for modeling TM protein structures from distant homologues with distinct TM conformations. We applied this method to the adenosine A2A and chemokine CX4 receptors and ranked first in the GPCRDOCK prediction contest in the receptor category. In a benchmark of 50 TM protein pairs with diverse topology (5–12 helices ), size (183–420 residues ) and sequence identity (15–70% ), our method improves starting templates and achieves near-atomic accuracy in membrane-embedded regions. Unlike starting templates, our models are suitable for computer-based engineering: redesigned and X-ray structures exhibit similar native interactions.
Listeria monocytogenes causes listeriosis, a foodborne disease that poses serious risks to fetuses, newborns and immunocomised adults. This intracellular pathogen proliferates in the host cytos and exploits the actin polymerization machinery to spread cell-to-cell and disseminate the host. Here, we report that during several days of infection in human hepatocytes or trophlast cells, L monocogen switches from active lifestyle to stage of persistence in vacoles. Upon cell spread, bacteria stopped producing actin nucleating protein Act and became in lysosome vacoles termed Lister-Containing Vacoles (Lis ). Subpopulations bacteria resisted inLis and entered slow-replicative state. During subculture of cells harboringLis, bacteria showed capacity cycle between vacolar and act-based motility.
Perceptual alternations between integrated and segregated percepts of an ABA triplets are studied using a neuromechanistic modeling and psychoacoustic experiments. The model comprises neuronal units with sensory dependent inputs that mimic the pulsatile responses to tones in A-BA triplets and embodies a computation for percept competition in primary auditory cortex (A1). Mutual inhibition, adaptation, and noise are implemented. Slow NMDA recurrent excitation for temporal memory enables linkage across sound from one triplet to the next. Percepts are identified in the firing patterns of the units. We predict that manipulations of the frequency difference between A and B should affect the durations of the stronger percept, the dominant larger fraction of time, than the weaker—a property that has been established and generalized across visual paradigms. We confirm the prediction with psychoac experiments and use behavioral data to constrain and improve the model, achieving agreement between experimental and results.
Schistosoma mansoni is a parasitic worm that causes schistosomiasis, a major public health problem in developing countries. Parasite-specific IgE is thought to correlate with protection against S. mansoni infection and re-infection. However, few molecular targets of the IgE response in S. mansoni infection have been characterised. To gain a better understanding of the mechanisms of anti-parasite immunity, we need to characterise S. mans allergens. This has implications for our understanding of allergy and the development of safe and efficacious vaccines against helmin parasites. Here, we describe a medium- to high-throughput workflow to translate S. mans proteins using wheat germate and assess potential allergity with humanised Ratophil Leukemia (RSAT8) reporter cell line. The method is based on cell-free translation within 90 minutes, generating sufficient amounts of paras protein for rapid screening of allergity without purification. Antigen integrity is demonstrated using Western blot. After incubation with individuals' serum, the RS8 reporter line is challenged with wheat translation mixture and luciferase activity measured, reporting cellular activation by suspected allergen. This method is suitable for characterisation of novel S mans allergens using well characterised and paras allergens such as Par 2, SmAL-1 and IgE factorSE/alpha-1 expressed in germate or E coli. coli. SmAL-1, but not SmAL2 used as negative, was able to activate reporter line. This method is accessible for assessment of allergity of helmin vaccine candidates and suitable for medium to high-throughput studies using individual sera. It is also for study of basis of allergity helmin proteins.
Transposable elements (TEs) are mobile genetic elements that proliferate during sexual reproduction, leading to rapid divergence between species. In hybrid dysgenic syndromes, a form of genomic incompatibility arises when TE abundance differs between parents. When TEs inherited from the father are absent in the mother’s genome, they become activated in progeny, causing germline damage and sterility. In Drosophila, dysgenesis occurs when paternal TEs are not matched with corresponding silencing PIWI-interacting RNAs (piRNAs) provided by the female germl. We used D. virilis hybrid dysgenesis as a model to characterize effects of TE divergence between parents on offspring. We show that TE divergence is associated with persisting germline expression in genetically identical females of reciprocal crosses, transmitted to the next generation. Chronic TE expression coincides with increased levels of genicpiRNAs associated with reduced expression. Gene expression is idiosratically influenced by differences in genicRNA of parents through polymorphic TE insertions.
Fragile X Tremor Ataxia Syndrome (FXT) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by a CG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the 5′UTR of the FMR1 gene. The CG repeat is thought to induce RNA toxicity and FXT patients have elevated F1 mRNA levels. Despite the critical role of F1 in disease pathogenesis, the basis for increased F1 expression is unknown. We show that overexpression of histone deacetylases (HD3, 6, or 11) suppresses CG repeat-induced neurodegeneration in a Drosophila FXT model. This is due to selective repression of the CG repeat-containing transgene. We found increased acetylation of histones at the F1 locus in patient lymphoblasts and fibrobls compared to control FX-derived lines. This correlates with elevated F1 expression in patient lines. Histone acetylase (H) inhibitors repress F1 to control levels in patient lines and extend CG repeat-expressing Dophila lifespan.
Host genetics play a critical role in controlling CD8 T cell function and immunopathology during chronic viral infection. CD8 T cells are essential for controlling chronic viral infections, but the host factors that contribute to the maintenance of effector CD8 T responses versus CD T cell exhaustion during chronic infection are not fully understood. In this study, we examined the impact of MHC heterogeneity versus non-MHC host genetics on the establishment of chronic viral infection. We infected F1 hybrids of B10. D2 x B6 ( DBF1 ) and BAL. B x BAL/c ( BCF ) mice with the clone-13 ( Cl-13 ) strain of lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus (LCV ). Following Cl-13 infection, both H-2xdB DB1 and BCF mice demonstrated increased viral control compared to homozygous mice. Strikingly, H-2xdB DB1 on C57 genetic background exhibited mortality following Cl-13 infection. CD T depletion prevented mortality in Cl-13-infected DB1 mice, indicating mortality was CD T-dependent. DB1 mice maintained CD T effector cytokine production and exhibited reduced expression of T exhaustion marker PD. In addition, DB mice induced larger T response than BCF and Cl-13 mortality in DB mice was dependent on T-mediated IF-γ production. Thus, following chronic infection, increased functionality of T response allowed rapid viral clearance at cost of immunology dependent on M diversity and host genetic background.
Anthrax is a re-emerging zoonotic disease endemic in China, especially in rural regions. This study describes the general characteristics of human anthrax outbreaks in northwestern China from 199 to 201 and the genetic characteristics of Bacillus anthracis isolated from 199 to 201. Using single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) and multilocus-number tandem repeat (MLVA) analysis with 15 markers, five sublineages/subgroups were detected: A. Br. 001, A. Br. Voll, A. Aust, A. Ames, and A. Br 009. All subgroups were found in Xinjiang, one in Shaanxi, two Gans, three Qinghai, and four Inner Mongolia. However, the distribution of B. anthrac populations exhibited different SNP characteristics from strains before 199 in China. In contrast, A. Ames was also observed in Inner Mongolia to other provinces. All strains were assigned 36 MLVA genotypes, 21 of which were first observed in this study. Anthrax in recent decade were classified subgroups A. Br.001 and A. Ames MLVA-, ML-, ML-, ML-, MLCH, MLCH and MLCH. By SNP and MLVA, MLVA genotypes and distribution of B anthrac populations is becoming balanced northwestern China.
Enterohemorrhagic Escherichia coli (EHEC) is a food and waterborne pathogen that causes severe diarrheal disease by attaching to the apical surface of intestinal epithelial cells (IEC) and colonizing the intestinal luminal surface. The host relies on immune-mediated changes in IE, including goblet cells to defend against these pathogens. These changes include a CD+ T-dependent increase in IE proliferation to replace infected IE, as well as altered production of the goblet-derived mucin Muc and goblet mediator REist-Like Molecule (REL)β. REL- is strongly induced in gob cells during infection and detected in stool as well as serum, but its role in host defense is unclear. REL-deficient mice (Retl-/-) were orally infected with EC and showed modestly elevated EC burdens, but increased mortality and mucosal ulcer due to pathogen penetration of colonic crypts. Immunostaining for Ki67 and BrdU revealed Ret- mice were impaired in infection-induced IE proliferation. Interestingly, REL did not directly increase IE proliferation, rather acted as CD+ T chemoattract. Ret- mice showed impaired CD+ cell to infected colons, along with reduced interleukin (IL-), a multifunctional cytokine that increased IE. Enema of REL to Ret- restored CD+ cell, concurrently IL levels and IE, while mucosal pathology.
Noroviruses are positive-sense single-stranded RNA viruses that cause gastroenteritis in humans. Noriruses do not have a 5 mG cap nor an internal ribosome entry site (IRES), so they use an unusual mechanism to initiate protein synthesis that relies on interactions between the VP protein attached to the 5- end of the viral RNA and eukary initiation factors (IFs) in the host. In murine norirus (MNV), we previously showed that VP binds to the middle fragment of IF4G (residues 652–113). We used pull-down assays, fluorescence anisotropy and isothermal titration calorimetry (ITC) to show that a stretch of ~20 amino acids at the C terminus of MN VP mediates direct and specific binding to the HE-1 domain within the fragment of IFG. Our analysis reveals that the MN C termin binds IF-1 via a motif that is conserved in all noriruses. Mutagenic mapping suggests the MN VP C termin may interact IF in a helical conformation. NMR spectroscopy was used to define the VP binding site on IF-1, which was confirmed by mutagen and binding assays. We found this site is non-overlapping with the site IF on IF1 by demonstrating norirus VP can form ternary VP-IF-IF complexes. The significance of VP-IF was shown by the ability of proteins containing the C-terminal of MN VP to inhibit in vitro translation of norirus but not cap or I-dependent.
The evolution of gene clusters in bacterial genomes is a phenomenon where genes encoding proteins in a common pathway are found near each other on the chromosome. Several explanations have been proposed to account for this, including natural selection and the selfish operon model. The selfish operon model suggests that clustered genes are more likely to be transferred to other species, thus improving the cluster’s prospects for survival. The persistence model proposes that genes in close proximity are less likely to be disrupted by deletions. We develop computational models to study the conditions under which gene clusters can evolve. First, we re-implement the selfish operon model and run it under a wide range of conditions. Second, we introduce a Moran process with natural selection for clustering and rearrangement by inversion. Finally, we develop a model with selection and inversion, tracking rearrangements. Surprisingly, clusters fail to evolve under a wide range of conditions. Factors that promote evolution include a low number of genes in the pathway, high population size, and selfish model, high transfer rate.
Plasmodium falciparum, the parasite responsible for malaria, causes significant morbidity and mortality in tropical regions of the world. Pregnant women are particularly vulnerable to severe consequences of infection due to parasite-infected erythrocytes adhesion in the placenta. This adhesion is mediated by PfEMP1, a parasite-encoded, hyper-variable antigen on the surface of infected erythrocytes. VARCS, a variant of Pf1, binds to chondroit sulfate on syncyotrophoblasts in the intervillous space of placenta. VARCS is only expressed in the presence of placenta, suggesting its expression is repressed in men or non-pregnant women. However, the mechanism of repression is not understood. We show that the gene encoding VARCS contains a small open reading frame that represses translation of mRNA, revealing a novel form of regulation in malaria parasites. This mechanism is reversible, allowing high levels of protein upon selection, potentially enabling parasites to upregulate this antigen in appropriate host tissue.
Infection with deng virus (DENV) leads to a spectrum of disease outcomes, and the pathophysiology of severe versus non-severe manifestations of DENV may be driven by host responses. We conducted genome-wide microarray analysis of blood RNA from 34 DENV-infected children in Nicaragua on days 3–6 of illness with different disease manifestations. We identified genes that are differentially regulated between clinical subgroups. The most striking differences were between DENV patients with and without shock, especially in expression of mitochondrial proteins associated with biosynthesis. In DENV hemorrhagic patients, a subset differentially expressed genes encode neutrophil-derived anti-microbial peptides with innate immunity. By meta-analysis of our dataset with previously published, DENV in vivo is associated with changes to protein and nucleic metabolism. In vitro leads to increased interferon signature, not observed in patient samples, suggesting transient interferon in vivo by days 3– of illness.
Herpesviruses are a group of pathogens that cause a wide range of diseases and are difficult to clear from the host. Entry of herpesviruses into the host is an important target for control of infection. While herpesviruses have been extensively studied in vitro, how they cross mucous epithelia in vivo is unclear. Here, we studied entry of Murid Herpesvirus-4 ( MuHV-4 ), a lymphotropic herpesvirus related to Kaposi’s Sarcoma Herpesvirus. Mu-4 virions spontaneously targeted the olfactory epithelium. Like herpesviruses, Mu-4 binds heparan sulfate ( HS ), and virions unable to bind HS showed poor entry. The respiratory epithelium expressed only basolateral HS and bound poorly incoming virions, but the epithelium also displayed apical HS on neuronal cilia and bound strongly. Incoming vir tracked the neuronalilia and either infected neurons or reached the microvilli of adjacent glial ( sustacular ) cells and infected. Thus the olfactory epithelium provides an important site of HS-dependent herpesvirus entry.
Salmonella enterica invasion of epithelial cells requires the expression of genes in the pathogenicity island SPI-1 (SPI-1). SPI-1 expression is tightly regulated and only activated under specific conditions.
