Here, we describe a new regulatory circuit involving CRP, a metabolic regulator, silencing SPI-1 under non-permissive conditions. CRP-deficient strains show strong upregulation of SPI-1 in mid-logarithmic phase. Genetic analysis reveals CR modulates the level of Hil, master regulator of Salmonella invasion. This occurs post-transcriptionally and requires a newly identified motif within hil 3’UTR. CR also represses Hfq-dependent sRNA Spot42. When repression is relieved, Spot42 exerts positive effect on Hil. In vivo and in vitro assays indicate Spot42 targets hil 3’R hil transcript.
Huntington’s disease (HD) and myotonic dystrophy 1 are caused by the expansion of CAG/CT repeats. These expansions are unstable in somatic tissues, which accelerates disease progression. We investigated the relationship between CAG instability, chromatin structure and transcription at the HD locus using R/1 and R2 transgenic mice. These mice express a similar transgene, integrated at different sites and recapitulate HD-specific instability. We show that instability is increased in R2 tissues compared to R1 samples. High transgene expression and chromatin accessibility correlate with increased CAG instability in R2. transgene and H3K trimylation at HD were increased whereas H3 dimethylation in R2 tissues relative R1. However, transgene and histone levels were similar in striatum and cerebellum, showing different C instability irrespective of line. Interestingly, elongating RNA II at HD but not initiating RNA II were tissue-specific and correlated CAG levels. H3 trimylation associated with transcription was increased at HD in striatum not cerebellum. Our data support that transcription modulates somatic CAG in vivo. Transcription elongation is tissue-dependent and contributes to tissue-selective C instability.
Enterovirus 71 (EV71) is one of the most virulent enteroviruses, but the molecular features that enhance its ability to disseminate in humans remain unknown. We analyzed the genomic features of EV71 in immunocompromised patients with disseminated disease according to different sites of infection. We compared five full-length sequenced genomes from respiratory, gastrointestinal, nervous, and blood specimens and found three nucleotide changes occurred within five days: a non-conservative amino change in VP1 within the BC loop (LR), considered an immunogenic and important in poliovirus host; a amino substitution in protein2 (38) ; and a silent in protein3 (175). Infectious clones were constructed using BrCr (A) and clinical (C) backgrounds containing one or both mutations. In vitro tropism and competition assays revealed the VP197Le to Arg substitution within BC conferred replicative advantage in SHY5Y neuroblast cells. Interestingly, this was associated in vitro with second nonervative (167 or167) in VP EF in neuroblast cells.
Streptococcus species are Gram-positive bacteria that can take up extracellular DNA through a process called natural transformation, which allows them to acquire new traits such as antibiotic resistance and pathogenicity. This process is regulated by quorum sensing ( QS ) mediated by peptide pherones. One such system, ComRS, consists of a peptide Com that is processed to XIP, secreted and imported into the cytoplasm where it binds ComR. Com then activates a positive feedback loop for Com and SigX expression. ComRS are present in most Streptoc species but ComS and XIP sequences diverge, suggesting species-specific communication. To study cross-talk between Streptoc species in competence, we undertook an interdisciplinary approach. We developed an assay to measure Com activity in response to cognate and heterologous XIP in vivo, revealing strict, intermediate, and promiscuous specificity among species. We solved the X-ray structure of Com from S suis to understand interaction with X and search for structural features in Com that explain X recognition. We probed the X-binding pocket by site-directed mutagenesis in test cultures and biochemically in vitro. Our results provide a model for X recognition and allow prediction of novel X peptides that induce Com activity.
In eukaryotes, centromes are maintained at specific chromosomal sites over many generations. In the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, centes are genetic elements defined by DNA that is both necessary and sufficient for function, whereas in most eukaryotes centes are maintained by epigenetic mechanisms in which DNA has less role. Here, we use the pathogenic yeast Candida albicans as model to study DNA properties of centric DNA. We determine the genome-wide replication program of C. alb genome and discover that each centere is associated with origin that fires first on respective chromosome. Importantly, epigen formation of new centere ( neocere ) is accompanied by shifts in timing such that neere becomes first and associated with origin complex (OR) components. Furthermore, changing level of centere-specific histone isoform leads to conitant change of OR with centere regions, supporting that centere determine origin activity. Finally, centere-associated DNA reveals replication pattern of constitutively active origins. This pattern is conserved with centere, among strains and species, in manner of DNA. Thus, inheritance centere is correlated with constitutively origin that fires early.
Back pain is the most common cause of years lived disability worldwide, yet little is known about the underlying biology. We conducted a genome-wide association study ( GWAS ) meta-analysis of back pain ( CB ) in adults of European ancestry from 15 cohorts in the Cohorts for Heart and Aging in Genomic Epidemiology (CHARGE ) and the UK Biob interim release. CB cases were those reporting back pain for ≥3–6 months, non-cases included as “controls”. Each cohort genotyped using commercially available arrays followed by imputation. GW used logistic models with genetic, age, sex, study-specific covariates, and substructure. The genome-wide significance threshold was p<5×10−8. Suggest (p<10−7 ) and genome (p<10−8 ) were carried forward for replication in UKob participants not in the sample. The sample comprised 158,025, including 29, CB cases. Genome-wide association was found for intronic rs105 in SOX (1.08, =7×10−10 ). This was replicated in 283, UKob not in the sample,50, cases (1.06 =5×−11 ) and exceeded genome-wide meta (1.07 =4×−19 ). We found associations three loci in the sample, two genome-wide meta: intergenic rs between CC and GSD (1.05 =4−13 ) and intronic rs in D (0.97 =2−10 )
Taenia solium cysticosis is an important zoonosis in many developing countries. In Cameroon, neurocystercosis is an important cause of epilepsy. However, it is largely underreported and there is a lack of data on the disease. This study was undertaken to calculate the impact of this zoonosis. Both cost and Disability Adjusted Life Year ( DAL ) estimations were applied. Parameters were collected and imported in software. Based on a prevalence of 3. 6%, the number of people with neuroystercosis-associated epilepsy was estimated at 50, 326 ( 95% CR 37,299–65, 924 ), representing 1.0% of the population. The number of pigs with cysticosis was estimated at 15,961 ( 95 CR 12,320–20,044 ), corresponding to 5.6% of the pig population. The total costs of T. solium cystosis in Cameroon were estimated at 10,255,202 Euro (95 889,048–14,754,044 ), with 4.7% due to losses in pig husbandry and 95.3 to direct and indirect losses by cystosis. The burden per case was Euro (95 147–253 ). The number of DALs lost was 9.0 per thousand per year (95 2.–.8–20.4 ) This study provides an estimation of the costs of T. solium cystosis using country-specific parameters and the burden of the zoon disease.
Staphylococcus aureus is a human commensal pathogen that produces a number of noncoding RNAs with poorly understood functions. Here, we demonstrate that the noncoding RNA Rsa represses the synthesis of the global transcriptional regulator Mgr by forming an imperfect duplex with the Shine-Dalgarn sequence and loop interaction within the coding region of the target mRNA. These recognition sites are required for repression. Consequently, Rsa causes enhanced biofilm formation and decreased capsule synthesis in several backgrounds. These phenotypes lead to decreased susceptibility to opsonophagoc killing by polymonuclear leukocytes compared to mutant strains lacking Rsa. In animal models, Rsa attenuates the severity of acute infections and enhances chronic catheter infections. Rsa is part of a regulatory network that contributes to S. aureus interactions with the host to moderate invasiveness and chronic infections. This is the first example of a conserved RNA in S. aureus functioning as a virulence suppressor of acute infections. Because S aureus is a commensal, we propose Rsa has been positively selected through evolution to support commensal and saprophytic interactions with the host.
HIV-1 uncoating is a critical step in the life cycle of HIV-1 infection, where the viral capsid is disassembled in the host cells. Here we report a novel strategy to visualize HIV-1 unating using a fluorescently tagged form of the caps-binding protein cyclophilin A ( Cyp-DRed ). Cyp-D is packaged into virions through high-avid binding to the capsid ( CA ) and remains associated with cores after viral membrane permeabilization. In vitro and in cells, C-D and CA are lost conitantly from cores. The rate of loss is modulated by core stability and accelerated upon reverse transcription initiation. We show that most cores lose C-D shortly after fusion, while a small fraction remains intact for hours. Single particle tracking at late post-infection reveals gradual loss of-D dependent on reverse transcription. Unating occurs both in cytoplasm and nuclear.
Oligonucle usage in archaeal and bacterial genomes can be linked to a number of properties, including codon usage, DNA-stacking, and structural conformation. We assessed the statistical potential of DNAword-sizes and how oligonucle frequencies differ in coding and nonoding regions. Oligonucle frequencies were used to investigate DNA composition and sequence change within and between proary organisms. We found that proary chromosomes can be described by hexonucle frequencies, suggesting proary DNA is predominantly short correlated, i. e., information in pro genomes is encoded in oligonides. Oligon usage varied more in AT-rich and host-associated genomes than GC and freeiving genomes, and this was mainly in nonoding. Bias in tetranucle usage correlated with GC, and regions were more than nonoding. Nonoding were found to be 5. 5 more AT-rich than regions, on average, in chromosomes examined. Pron compositional differences were found within and between AT and GC genomes. GC genomes were more similar in terms tetranucle nonoding than AT genomes. Differences between AT and GC may be attributed, since tetranucle within host-associated was, on average more and less than freeiving.
Meiotic recombination is a process that ensures the correct segregation of homologous chromosomes during gamete formation and contributes to DNA diversity through both large reciprocal crossovers and localised gene events, also known as noncrosso. While considerable progress has been made in understanding factors such as PRDM and variants that influence the initiation of recombination at human hotspots, little is known about factors acting downstream. To address this, we simultaneously analysed both types of recombinant in sperm at six highly active hotspots and looked for disparity in transmission of allelic variants indicative of cis-acting influences. We identified a novel form of biased transmission that is exclusive to the noncrossover class of recombin, which arises through differences between crosso and nonrosso heterodup formation and biased repair. This form of biased conversion does not influence hotspot activity as noted for SNPs that recombination initiation, but constitutes a powerful previously undetected source of recombination meiotic drive that may affect thousands of hotspots throughout the genome.
Many environmental chemicals and drugs can have negative effects on human health. To better understand the mechanisms of action of these compounds, it is necessary to determine the risk. We present a high-confidence protein-protein association network that integrates toxicology and systems biology. This computational model reveals uncharacterized connections between compounds and diseases, predicting which may be risk factors for health. The network can also be used to identify unexpected associations between chemicals and proteins. Examples are shown for chemicals associated with breast cancer, lung cancer and necrosis, and potential targets for diethylhexylphthalate, 2, 3, 8-tetrachloribenzo-p-diox, pirix acid and permethrin. These associations are supported by recent studies.
In the primary auditory cortex, neurons can be characterized by their spectrotemporal receptive fields, the dependence of their response on the spectral and temporal features of a sound. However, these fields do not capture the fact that the response of a neuron results from the complex network in which it is embedded. By fitting a nonlinear feedforward network ( receptive field ) to cortical responses to natural sounds, we show that primary cortical neurons are sensitive to a larger spectrotemporal domain than seen in their standard fields. Furthermore, the receptive, a parsimonious network of 1–7 subfields that interact nonlinearly, better predicts responses to auditory stimuli than standard fields. The receptive reveals excitatory and inhibitory subfields with different properties and interaction of the sub gives rise to operations such as gain and conjunctive detection. The conjunct effects where respond if several features are present enable selectivity for complex structures and constitute an important in sound recognition.
Circadian rhythms in mammals are generated by transcription-translation feedback loops of clock genes that drive the rhythmic expression of the transcriptome and allow the organism to anticipate the day. We show that casein kinase 2 (CK)-mediated phosphorylation of BMAL1 at serine 90 (BM1-P) plays a pivotal role in central and peripheral clocks. Using a novel CK inhibitor, we show that CK-mediated phosphorylation of BM1 is inhibited by CRY. Co-immunoprecipitation and real-time monitoring of protein-protein interactions show that C-mediated binding of CKβ to BM1 inhibits CKα-mediated phosphorylation of BM1. The FAD domain of C1, C-terminal BM1 domains, and BM1 lysine 537 acetylation/deacetylation by CLOCK/SIRT are critical for C-mediated BM1–CKβ binding. Recipally, BM1 phosphorylation is prerequisite for BM1 lysine 537 acetylation. We propose a negative feedback model in which C-dependent CK-driven posttranslational BM1–BM loop is part of the core oscillator.
Salmonella enterica adapts to survive in the presence of bile by employing multiple mechanisms. Bile salts disrupt bacterial membranes, denature proteins, and damage DNA, but the bacterium adapts to lethal concentrations of sodium deoxycholate ( DOC ). Adaptation is associated with changes in gene expression, including upregulation of the Rpo-dependent stress response and other stress responses. The role of the stress response in adaptation to bile is supported by the observation that Rpo mutants are sensitive to bile. While adaptation involves a response by the population, individual cells can become resistant to bile without adaptation: plating a non-adapt Salmonella culture on medium containing lethal DOC yields resistant colonies at frequencies of 10−6 to 10−7 per cell generation. Fluctuation analysis indicates such colonies derive from resistant cells present in the culture. A fraction of isolates are stable, indicating resistance can be acquired by mutation. Full sequencing of resistant mutants shows alteration of lipopolysaccharide transport is a cause of mutational resistance. However, selection on DOC also provides resistant isolates that are not mutants. We propose such derive from cells whose physiological state permitted survival upon DOC. This is supported by single cell analysis of expression using a microscope: batch of Salmonella contain stress genes in absence DOC.
Prophage Mu is organized as a stable chromosomal domain in E. coli. coli. The E. coli chromosome is compacted into 400–500 supercoiled domains by both active and passive mechanisms, such as transcription and DNA-protein association. We find that prophage Mu is organized as a stable domain bounded by the proximal location of Mu termini L and R, which are 37 kbp apart on the genome. The formation/maintenance of the Mu domain is dependent on strong gyrase site ( S ) at the center of Mu, Mu end MuB protein, and E coli proteins IH, F and H. The domain was observed at two different chromosomal locations. By contrast, prophage does not form an independent domain. The establishment/maintenance of Mu was promoted by low-level transcription from phage promoters, one of which was domain dependent. We propose that domain confers transposition to Mu by topological requirements of reaction and proximity of ends.
Primaquine (PQ) is the only licensed antimalarial that prevents Plasmodium vivax (Pv) relapses and also clears Plasium falciparum (Pf) gamocytes, thereby reducing postreatment transmission. This study investigated the effect of PQ on Pv and Pf gamocyte carriage after radical cure in a randomized treatment-reinfection cohort in Papua New Guan children. Children received radical cure with Chloroquine, Artemether-Lumeftrine plus PQ or placebo. Blood samples were collected 2-4 weekly over 8 months. Pv and Pf gamocytes were detected by reverse transcriptionPCR targeting pvs and pfs. PQ reduced Pv gamocyte incidence by 73%, comparable to PQ effect on blood-stage infections. 92% Pv and 79% Pf gamocyte infections were asymptomatic. Pv gamocyte positivity and density were associated with high-stage parasite densities. Multivariate analysis revealed Pv and Pf gamocytes were reduced in mixed-species compared single-species infections (ORv 0.39 [0.25–0.62]ORf 0.33 [0–.18.60]p<0.001). No difference between PQ and placebo was observed in Pv gamocyte density or Pv infections that carried gamocytes. First-stage infections after placebo likely caused reling hypnoite were equally gamet than first PQ infections likely by infective bite. Pv and rel new infections had similar gametaemia. Relapses contribute to Pv reservoir highlighting importance of anti-hypnoite for Pv control.
The Rho GTPases are a family of proteins that play a central role in cellular processes such as cell migration, cytokinesis, and endocytosis by regulating actin organization. Although Rho, Rac, and Cdc42 have different effects on actin remodeling, they share a common mechanism of targeting the plasma membrane and activation by GTP binding. We developed a computational framework to analyze experimental data for these systems, revealing details of GTP cycling between the membrane and cytosol. This analysis distinguishes between GDI-dependent and -independent mechanisms, including vesicle trafficking and association/dissociation of Gase with membrane molecules. We found that Rac has a lower affinity for RacGTP than RacDP due to faster dissociation from the membrane. Non-steady-state solutions for membrane Gase are presented in multidimensional charts. This methodology is used to analyze Rac cycling in pancreatic β-cells, illustrating the effects of Gs/Gs and affinities between Gases and membrane/GDI on membranease.
Schistosomiasis monitoring and evaluation (M&E) programmes are used to collect data to assess the impact of interventions and progress towards the World Health Organization (WHO) goals of morbidity control and elimination as a public health problem for schosomiasis. Prevalence and intensity of infection are typically collected from school-aged children (SAC) as they are easy to sample and likely to be infected by schosome parasites. However, adults are also likely to be infected. We used three age-intensity profiles of infection for Schos mansoni with low, moderate and high burdens of infection in adults to investigate how age of infection impacts mathematical model recommendations of preventive chemotherapy levels to achieve WHO. We find that moderate prevalence, regardless of burden in adults, SAC may achieve WHO goals. However, high prevalence with high burden in adults, is required to meet WHO. We show that optimal strategy for region requires consideration of burden in adults cannot be solely on prevalence in SAC.
Temporal lobe epilepsy (TLE) is a neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures. In drug-resistant cases, surgery is often considered. However, success rates are unpredictable, with many patients continuing to have seizures after surgery. This study applies a computational model of epilepsy to patient-specific connectivity derived from diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) of 22 individuals with TLE and 39 healthy controls. We validate the model by examining patient-control differences in simulated seizure onset and location. We investigate the model’s potential for surgery prediction by performing in silico resections, removing nodes from patient networks and comparing seizure likelihood post-surgery to pre-surgery. We find that patients tend to transition from non-epileptic to epileptic states more often than controls in the model. Regions in the left hemisphere, particularly temporal and subcortical, are the most frequent starting points for seizures in patients. Our analysis also implicates contralateral and frontal regions in seizure spreading or surgery resistance. Finally, the model predicts patient-specific resection areas chosen on individual, not predefined, may lead to better outcomes than current clinical procedure.
Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8) is a virus that interferes with the host cell’s innate antiviral defenses by interfering with interferon and apoptotic signaling. HHV-8 encodes four viral interferon regulatory factors (vIRFs) that function in a dominant negative fashion to block cellular IR activities and target IR-induced proteins such as p53 and TGFβ receptor-activated Smad transcription factors. Here, we show that vIR-1, one of the HHV-8 IRFs, targets the pro-apopt Bcl-2 family member Bim, a negative regulator of HH-8 replication, to inactivate it via nuclear translocation. v-mediated localization of B was detected in infected cells by immunofluorescence and western analysis of fractionated extracts, as well as in nuclei of lytically infected endothelial cells. In vitro co-precitation using purified v- and B revealed a direct interaction between the proteins, and B-binding residues of were mapped by deletion and mutagenesis. Generation of B-refactory v- variants revealed the importance of v:B interaction, specifically in prolication and anti-apopt activity of. Blocking the interaction with a cell-per peptide corresponding to the B-binding of v confirmed the relevance v:B association to v prolication. This is the first report of an IR protein interacting with acl-2 family member and sequestration of B or any member as a means of inactivation. The data reveal a novel mechanism by which HH-8 controls replication-induced apoptosis and suggest inhibiting v:B interaction may provide an antiral strategy.
The epithelial integrin αVβ6 plays a crucial role in maintaining the lung's steady state of immune readiness to respond to injury. It is upregulated during injury and modulates acute lung injury (ALI) through undefined mechanisms. We show that upregulation of αV6 during influenza infection is involved in disease pathogenesis. β6-deficient mice (βKO) have increased survival during infection due to limited viral spread into alveolar spaces leading to reduced ALI. Although βKO have normal lungs, they harbor constitutively activated CD11+ alveolar macrophages (AM) and elevated type IFN activity. This is due to loss of β-activated growth factor (TGFβ). Administration of exogenous TGFβ to βKO mice reduces CD11+ AM, type IF activity and protective phenotype during infection. Protection extends to other respiratory pathogens such as Sendai virus and bacterial pneumonia. Our studies show that loss of epithelial protein αV6 alters lung microenvironment during homeostasis and infection leading to reduced injury and improved survival.
Leishmanias is the most frequently implicated species of cutaneous and mucosal leishiasis in the Americas. Diagnosis is based on the identification of amastigotes in lesions, which is limited by low parasite burden. Leishin Skin Test (ST) is a tool for diagnosis based on delayed hypersensitivity to Leish antigens injected intradermally, used in endemic areas as complement to diagnosis. A retrospective analysis of individuals with first episode tegument leishiasis at reference center in Argentina during 2006–201 was performed to assess usefulness of ST as support in diagnosis of leishias. A total 733 cases met definition were included in analysis; 93% cutaneous, 7% mucosal and <1% disseminated. Diagnostic was reached in 65% cases through smears skin or muc, with 6 among this group negative ST. Among negative, were also negative ST, but 69 ST positive. Across age, ratios between smear and ST were similar. Lesions than 21-old found to correlate positive both smear and ST significantly than younger. These support use ST as complement for Cutaneous leishias across age in endemic. In this, correlation smear was high.
Lipid-induced epigenetic changes in macrophages identify a coronary artery disease-associated variant that regulates PP2B expression through altered C/EB-beta binding. Genome-wide association studies have identified over 40 loci that affect coronary artery disease (CAD) risk, but the majority of the causal mechanisms are unknown. Recent studies have suggested that many GW variants influence disease through altered transcription regulation in disease-relevant cell types. We explored changes in transcription regulation during a key pathophysiological event in CAD, the lipid-induced transformation of macrophages to lipid-laden foam cells. We used a combination of chromatin mapping with formaldehyde-assisted isolation of regulatory elements (FA-seq) and enhancer transcription mapping using chromatin immuno-precipitation (IP) in human macrophages before and after exposure totherogenic oxidized low-density lipoprotein (oxLD), with foam formation.LD-induced cell was associated with changes in a subset of chromatin and enhancers that correlated with expression of nearby genes.LD-regulated enhancers were enriched for transcription factors including CEB-beta, which has no documented role in foam formation.LD exposure upregulated CEB expression and increased binding, most around genes in inflammatory pathways. Variants CAD loci were significantly enriched in subset chrom altered byLD, including rs643 in LD-induced at PP2 locus.LD increased CEB binding to site and CEB binding were stronger with protective allele rs643. In addition, PP2 product L3 was present in foam human atherosclerotic plaques andLD upregulated L3 in macrophages in degradation pro-inflammatory mediators.
Trachoma is a neglected tropical disease caused by the parasitic worm Onchocerca volvulus. It is a major public health problem in sub-Saharan Africa. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that districts with trach prevalence ≥10% in 1–9-year-olds (TF-9) receive at least three rounds of azithromycin mass drug administration (MDA). However, given the large number of endemic districts and human resources required for surveys, this may not be practical. In Malawi, the Ministry of Health conducted one round of azithycin MDA in 8 districts with baseline TF prevalence of 5.0–9.9%, achieving ~80% coverage. We report the impact of this intervention. We conducted population-based trach surveys in 18 evaluation units of the treated districts at least 6 months after MDA. Each of the 18 evaluation units had TF-9 prevalence <5.0%. Our study demonstrates that in Malawi districts with TF 5.0–.9%, one round azithycin MDA with ~80% coverage reduces TF prevalence to <5.
Nucleotide-binding leucine repeat ( NLR ) protein complexes are key components of plant innate immunity that sense pathogen infections and trigger robust immune responses. In Arabidopsis thaliana, NLR proteins such as RPS and RPM are activated by pathogen effectors to launch immune responses, including programmed cell death (PCD), reactive oxygen species (ROS) production, and transcriptional reprogramming. We identified six closely related Arabidopsis Ca2+-dependent protein kinases (CPs) that mediate bifurcate immune responses activated by NLR proteins. The dynamics of CP1/2 activation by pathogen effectors controls the onset of cell death. Sustained CP4/5/6/11 activation phosphorylates WRKY transcription factors to regulate transcriptional reprogramming for N-dependent pathogen restriction, whereas CP1/2/4 phosphorylate plasma-resident NAD oxidases for ROS production.
Schistosoma infections are a major public health problem in sub-Saharan Africa and other parts of the developing world, infecting more than 500 million people in 77 countries. In Mali, the incidence of Schistos haobium is rising due to irrigation projects, shifts from nomadic to sedentary existence, and ineffective control programs. Despite the scope of these parasitic infections, less than 0. 5% of Schos sp investigations have attempted to predict their spatial and temporal distributions. In this study, we developed a parsimonious forecasting system for Schos haob in the district of Nion, Mali, using general exponential smoothing methods within a state-space framework. This method accommodates seasonal and inter-annual fluctuations in the time-series. We used data from 1996–2004 to generate contemporaneous on-line forecasts. Mean absolute error was circa 25% for 1 to 5-month forecasts. The exponential state-space framework produced accurate forecasts for S haob-induced hematuria incidence, capturing non-linear interactions between disease and exogenous covariates ( e. g. climate, irrigation, health interventions ). This framework could assist managing and assessing S haob transmission and intervention impact in Nion, and potentially elsewhere in the Sahel.
Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) is a herpesvirus that has evolved a mechanism of self-imposed restriction by the tegument protein pp150. This protein binds to cyclin A and prevents viral gene expression in the S/G2 phase of the cell cycle in fully permissive cells. Here, we investigate the physiological relevance of this restriction during productive CMV infection by employing a cyclin-binding deficient pp150 mutant. The consequence of viral expression in S2 was the induction of G2/M arrest. G-arrest but not mitotic cells supported viral replication. Cyclin destabilization by the viral product p21 was required to maintain virus-permissive G2rest. An HCM double mutant where both pp and p21 are disabled in cyclin interaction forced mitotic entry the majority of infected, with severe impact on cell and virus growth.
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease that results in progressive degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. Approximately 10% of ALS cases are familial, with the remaining 90% being sporadic. Genetic studies in familial cases of ALS have been informative in determining causative mutations behind ALS, as same mutations in familial ALS also cause sporadic. However, cause of ALS in approximately 30% familial and majority sporadic remains unknown. We undertook targeted sequencing of 169 candidate ALS genes in 242 sporadic cases and 129 controls to identify novel variants linked ALS. We found significant enrichment of novel and rare variants in cases versus controls, indicating likely disease mutations.
Interleukin-6 Is Critical for Influenza-Specific CD4+ T Cell Memory Recall  
Interleukin-6 (IL-6) has recently emerged as an important regulator of T cell proliferation and survival. Since IL-6 is abundant following influenza virus infection, we analyzed virus-specific T cell activity in both wild type and IL-6 deficient mice. Our studies highlight a novel role for IL-6 in the development of T memory to influenza. Specifically, we find that CD4+ but not CD8 T memory is critically dependent on IL-6. This effect of IL-6 includes its ability to suppress CD4CD25+ regulatory cells (Tregs). We demonstrate that influenza-induced IL-6 limits the activity of virus-specific Tregs, thereby facilitating virus-specific CD4 T. These experiments reveal a critical role for IL-6 in ensuring, within the timeframe of acute infection with cyathic virus that antigen-specific Tregs have no opportunity to down-modulate the response, thereby favoring pathogen clearance and host survival.
Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite that causes amoebic dysentery, an intestinal infection that can be fatal in immunocompromised individuals. In this report, we describe a new function of enolase, a glycolytic enzyme known to catalyze the conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenpyruvate. We show that enase acts as an inhibitor of Dmt2, a cytosine methyltransferase involved in DNA and RNA methylation. Enase is localized in both cytoplasm and nucleus of Enteba histolytica and its inhibitory activity is antagonized by 2-phosphoglycer, suggesting that glucose metabolism controls enolytic function. In glucose starvation, enase accumulates in nucleus and forms a complex with enol-E histolytic DNMT homolog ( Ehm ), reducing tRNA methylation in the parasite. We also show that enase inhibits D2 activity in E histoly expressing nuclear localization signal (LS)-enase. These results establish enase as the first Dmt interacting protein and highlight an unexpected role of glycolytic enzyme in modulating Dmt activity.
Mosquito saliva is a complex concoction of secretory factors that modulates the feeding process to enhance pathogen infection establishment. Multiple salivary factors have been identified that enhance pathogen infection. Here, we describe the first identification of exogenous microRNAs from mosquito saliva. MicroRNAs are short,18–24 nucleotide non-coding RNAs that regulate gene expression and are generally intracellular. However, circulating miRN have been described from serum and saliva of humans. Exogenous miRN have not been reported from hematophagous arthropod saliva. We sought to identify miRN in mosquito saliva and their role in Chikunya virus (CHV) infection. Next generation sequencing was utilized to identify 103 exogenous miRN in saliva of which 31 miRN were previously unidentified and designated. Several miRN were expressed only in CHV infected mosquitoes. Five miRN were tested for their potential to regulate CHV infection. Our results demonstrate their role in transmission and establishment during feeding on host.
Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is an independently maintained genome that encodes proteins required for cellular respiration. Deletions in mtDNA have been identified as causes of maternally inherited diseases and associated with cancers and neurological disorders. These deletions are often flanked by short repetitive sequences, suggesting they may result from recombination events. Our understanding of mtDNA maintenance and repair is limited compared to that of the nucleus. Many nuclear repair proteins localize to mitochond, but their function and mechanism remain unknown. This study investigated the contribution of double-strand break (DS) repair proteins Rad51, Rad52 and Rad59 to mtDNA repair. We found that both Rad51 and Rad59 localize to mitochondria and Rad51 binds mtDNA. A mitochondally-targeted restriction endonuclease (mt-KI) was used to produce a double-strand break (DSB) in mtDNA, allowing analysis of DS repair in vivo in Saccharomy cerevisiae. We found that loss of these proteins decreases spontaneous deletions and loss of Rad51 and Rad59 impairs repair of mtDSBs.
Acute rheumatic fever (ARF) and rheumatic heart disease (RHD) are major health problems among disadvantaged populations worldwide. These conditions are complications of Group A Streptococcus (GAS) infection and are acknowledged as diseases of poverty. However, the role of specific social and environmental factors in GAS infection progression to ARF/RHD is not well understood. This systematic review aimed to determine the association between social determinants of health and GAS, ARF, and RHD, and the effect of interventions targeting these. We conducted a systematic review using PubMed, Cochrane and Embase. Observational and experimental studies measuring crowding, dwelling, education, employment, income, nutrition, and socioeconomic status with GAS, AR or RHD were included. Findings were assessed against the Bradford criteria for evidence of causation. Study quality was assessed using a standard tool. We identified 1,164 publications, 90 met criteria, comprising 91 studies. The majority (50.5%) were poor in relation to the question. The proportion of studies reporting associations between socioeconomic determinants and GAS was 57.1% and AR/RHD was 50. Crow was most assessed (14 with GAS, 36 AR/RHD ) followed by socioeconomic (6, 36). Most studies assessing crow, dwelling, education, employment, and nutrition reported a positive association with GAS, AR/RHD. Crow and socioeconomic satisfied the criteria of association.
Bistability in the Pho/Pho Signaling Network Emerges from a Single Point Mutation in Phosphatase Activity. The Phosphatase activity of the sensor kinase Pho is abolished by a single point mutation. The mutant responds to stimulus in a bistable manner, as opposed to the wild-type, which has a graded response. Mutant cells are in on and off states have different morphologies and their state is inherited over many generations. External conditions that repress signaling in wild-type drive mutant to on state. Mathematical modeling suggests bistability depends on positive autoregulation of Pho and Pho.
Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) is a rare but devastating infection caused by the free-living amoeba Naegleria fowleri. The disease is characterized by a high mortality rate and a lack of established treatment options. In the absence of economic incentives for pharmaceutical companies to develop anti-AM drugs, antiAM drug discovery relies on drug repurposing. Similar to fungi, N. fleri has an essential requirement for ergosterol, a building block of plasma membranes. Disruption of sterol biosynthesis by small-molecule inhibitors is a validated strategy against fungal pathogens. N. fleri encodes the ster 14-demethylase CYP51, sharing 35% sequence identity with fungal orthologues. This similarity raises the possibility of repurposing anti-fungal drugs for AM. We assessed the impact of anti-fungal drugs triazoles on sterol biosynthesis and viability of N fleri trophotes. We identified the endogenous C51 substrate by mass spectrometry of fleri lipids. We analyzed interactions between recombinant C51 and trioles by UV spectroscopy and x-raylography. Collectively, these studies validated C51 as a potentially druggable target in fleri and trioles as candidates for assessment in AM.
Nematodes are parasitic worms that trigger a protective type 2 immune response in the host via the interleukin-4 receptor alpha (IL-4α). However, the role of IL-4α in maintaining type 2 responses after polarization is unknown. We used a mouse model where IL-4α can be deleted at any time to determine IL-α’s role after polarization. We show that IL-α is required to maintain type 2 responses and protective immunity against Nippostrongylus brasiliensis infection. We also show that deleting ILα before secondary infection with N. brasiliensis drives more efficient type 2 responses and parasite clearance.
Bartonella is a genus of bacteria that infects mammals and causes numerous human diseases. We analyzed the largest collection of Bartonella glA genotypes, including 67 new genotypes, to understand how this genus evolved and switched hosts in the past. Our results show that Bartonella likely originated as an environmental bacterium that infected insects before infecting mammals. Rodents and domestic animals serve as reservoirs or key hosts for most Bartonella genotypes in humans. We also found evidence of Bartonella exchange between phylogenetically distant domestic and wildlife animals, likely due to increased contact.
MALAT is a long noncoding RNA that is upregulated in cancer tissues and is associated with hyperproliferation. We show that MALAT levels are regulated during normal cell cycle progression. Genome-wide transcriptome analyses in human diploid fibroblasts reveal that MALAT modulates expression of cell cycle genes and is required for G1 and mitotic progression. Depletion of MALAT leads to activation of p53 and its target genes. The cell cycle defects in MALAT-depleted cells are sensitive to p53 levels, indicating that p53 is a major mediator of MALAT activity. Furthermore, MALAT-depleted cells display reduced expression of MYB, an oncogenic transcription factor involved in G/M, due to altered splicing of MY preRNA and aberrant splicing. In cells, MALAT promotes proliferation by modulating expression and splicing of cell–regulated transcription factors.
Juvenile hormone (JH) is a sesquiterpenoid produced by the corpora all that coordinates insect growth, metamorphosis and reproduction. While J action on the repression of larval metamosis has been well studied, the molecular basis of J in promoting reproduction has not been fully elucidated. Methop-toler (Met), the J receptor, has recently been shown to mediate J action during metamosis as well as vitelogenesis. We have now demonstrated that J stimulates DNA replication and increases ploidy in preparation for vitelogenesis in migratory locusts. Mc4 and Mc7, genes in the replication pathway were expressed in the presence of J. Depletion of Mc or Mc7 inhibited de novo synthesis and polloidy, and resulted in reduction of vitelogen mRNA as well as impaired oocyte maturation and ovarian.
Lepromatous leprosy is a chronic bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium leprae that can cause nerve impairment (NFI). The optimal duration of prednisone treatment for NFI has not been established. The “Treatment of Early Neuropathy in Lepros” (TENL) trial evaluated whether a 32-week predone course is more effective than a 20-week course in restoring nerve function. In this multi-centre, triple-blind, randomized trial, lepro patients with recent NFI (<6 months ) were allocated to predolone treatment of either 20 or 32 weeks. Predolone was started at 45 or 60 mg/day, then tapered. NFI was assessed by muscle testing and monofilament testing. The primary outcome was the proportion of patients with improved or restored function at week 78. Secondary outcomes were improvements between baseline and week 78 on the Reaction Scale, SAL Scale and Participation. Serious Events and additional predone treatment were monitored. We included 868 patients, 429 in the 20 arm and 439 in the 32 arm. At 78, the proportion with improved or restored function did not differ: 78.1% in 20 and 77.5 in 32 ( p 0.821 ). Secondary outcomes did not differ, except a higher Serious Events in the longer arm.
Male Rocky Mountain elk (Cervus elus nelsoni) and European Red Deer (Cervus elus elaphus) produce different types of vocalizations during the mating season. Elk produce high-frequency bugles, while Red Deer produce low-frequency roars. To relate sound production to anatomy and physiology, we developed a finite element model of the larynx and a wave model of the vocal tract based on elk morphology and biomechanics. The model can produce a wide range of fundamental frequencies. Low frequencies require low vocal fold strain, high lung pressure, and large glottal flow. High-frequency bugles require large vocal fold strain, high pressure, and least 10 dB more intensity. Glottal efficiency, the ratio of radiated power to aerodynamic power at glott, is higher in elk. This suggests an advantage in high-pitched signaling. The advantage is based on two aspects: lower aerodynamic power and acoustic radiation at higher frequencies. Both types are used by males during mating and serve as honest signals.
Chromatin immunoprecipitation followed by high-throughput sequencing (ChIP-seq) has become the preferred approach for mapping transcription-factor binding and chromatin modifications. Current analysis of ChIP-seq data relies on reads that map uniquely to the reference genome (uni-reads). However, this can lead to omission of up to 30% of alignable reads. We describe a method for utilizing reads that map to multiple locations on the genome (multi-reads). Our approach allocates multi-reads as fractional counts using a weighted scheme. Using STAT and GATA ChIP-seq datasets, we show that incorporation of multi-reads increases sequencing depth and leads to detection of novel peaks not identifiable with uni-read, and improves peaks in mappable regions. We investigate genome-wide characteristics of peaks detected by multi-read via computational experiments. Peaks from multi-read have similar characteristics to uni-read except majority reside in segmental duplications. We validate GATA multi-read peaks by quantitative ChIP and identify novel GATA target genes.
Neglected tropical diseases (NTDs) have been targeted for elimination by 2020 by the World Health Organization (WHO). We estimated the economic impact of meeting these targets for African trypanosomiasis, lepro, visceral leishmanis, and Chagas, NTDs controlled by innovative and intensified management (IDM). We combined information on productivity loss and out-of-pocket payments (OPPs) related to these NTDs with projections of the number of people suffering each NTD, country and year 2010–2010 and 2020–203. We compared an ideal scenario where WHO targets are met with a counterfactual scenario assuming no change from 1990. Economic benefit was the difference between the two scenarios. Values are in 2005 US, purchasing power-adjusted, discounted 3% annum from 0. Probabilistic analyses were used to quantify uncertainty around the estimate. The global productivity for IDM-NT was 23. 1 (15.9–34. ) billion 201–0 and 35.9 (25.–51. ) billion 203 (2.5–97.5 percent brackets ), corresponding 10.7 (7.–15. ) and 16.6 (11–.24 ) in OPP was 14 (6.7 ) and 18 (10.4 ) for the same periods.
Neurons in the auditory cortex have traditionally been thought to be more informative if they respond to a narrower range of sensory inputs. However, we found that the amount of information encoded by a population of neurons about a sound is determined by the total number of spikes in a read window, not the selectivity of individual neurons. Neurons are less selective immediately after a sound onset and become more selective in the sustained epoch, but the population conveys similar information in both epochs. This is contrary to the prevailing theory that the first epoch encodes the presence and the second the content of a sound. We found that inhomogeneous Poisson spiking is sufficient to account for this property.
Viral infections can be divided into two categories: acute and chronic. During acute infections, the immune system is able to clear the pathogen and the anti-viral T cell compartment contracts. In contrast, during chronic infections, the anti-viral T compartment needs to be maintained over a longer period of time to control viral replication and prevent spreading. Little is known about the stimulatory signals that allow the maintenance of antiiral T cells, but inhibitory signals such as PD-1 are known to limit T cell activity. Here, we show that the co-stimulatory molecule O40 (CD134) is required in the context of persistent LCMV 13 infection. Antiiral T cells express high levels of O40 in the presence of their cognate antigen and cells lacking O40 fail to accumulate. Moreover, the emergence of T dependent germinal responses and LCM-specific antibodies are impaired. Consequently, O-deficient mice fail to control LCM 13 infection over time.
Convergent Evolution of Mechanically Optimal Locomotion in Aquatic Invertebrates Vertebrates.
During the development of the cerebral cortex, neural stem cells (NS) divide to proliferate symmetrically and asymmetrically to generate neurons. Although faithful segregation of mitotic chromosomes is critical for NS divisions, the mechanism remains unclear. Condensins, a class of evolutionarily conserved protein complexes, are thought to be central to chromosome assembly and segregation in eukaryotes. We report the first genetic study of mammalian condins, demonstrating that two types of condin complexes, condins I and II, are essential for NS divisions and survival in mice. Simultaneous depletion of both condins leads to defects in chromosome assembly and segregation, causing DNA damage and p53-induced apoptosis. Individual depletions of condins I and II lead to loss of NS compared to simultaneous, but display distinct mitotic defects: chromosome missegregation is prominent in NS depleted condin II, whereas mitotic delays detectable in condin-depleted NS. NS depleted condin display hyperclustering pericentric heterochatin and nucleoli, indicating condin II, not condin, establishes interphase architecture. Intriguingly, defects persist in postmit neurons.
Schistosoma mansoni, a species of hermaphroditic trematode, is unusual since it has evolved gonochorism. In this species, sex is determined by a female heterogamic system, but phenotyp sexual dimorphism appears only after infection of the vertebrate host. To study the molecular basis of sex determination and sexual differentiation, we investigated the transcriptome of S. mansoni in a stage and sex-comparative manner. We performed RNA-seq on males and females for five developmental stages: cercaria, larvae, in vivo schosulum stages and adults. We detected 7, 168 differentially expressed genes between sexes in at least one stage, and 4,065 were functionally annotated. Transcript data were completed with H3K27me histone modification analysis using ChIP-Seq before in cercaria and after adults. We present candidate determinants of sexual differentiation, sex-based players of interaction with vertebrate host and dynamic of H3me histone mark between sexes as illustration of sex-based epigenetic landscapes.
Many large-scale annotation efforts involve multiple experts who may disagree with each other. We propose a method for modeling disagreements among experts that allows each annotation to have a confidence value, i. e., the posterior probability that it is correct. Our method computes certainty for individual annotations given annotator-specific parameters estimated from data. We developed two probabilistic models for this analysis and compared them using simulation. We tested each model’s performance on a large data set generated by human annotators for this study. We show that even when all annotators disagree, our method increases the probability of choosing correct annotation. We make available a corpus of 10, 000 sentences annotated according to dimensions from earlier work. The 10, 000 were 3-fold annotated by eight experts and 1, 000 further 5-fold by five.
Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS) is a severe and often lethal disease in South America caused by viruses such as Andes virus (AND) and AND-like viruses. Passive transfer of convalescent human plasma has shown promise as a possible treatment for HPS, but availability of convalescent plasma from survivors is very limited. Here, we explore the concept of using DNA technology to produce antiviral biologics, including polyclonal antibodies for use in humans. Geese produce IgY and an alternatively spliced form, IgΔ, that can be purified at high concentrations from egg yolks. Ig lacks the properties of mammalian Fc that make antibodies in horses, sheep, and rabbits reactogenic in humans. We vaccinated geese with an AND DNA vaccine encoding the envelope glycoproteins. Ge developed high neutralizing antibodies after the second vaccination and maintained high levels of neutral antibodies over 1 year. A booster resulted in high levels of neutral antibodies. Analysis of Ig and IgΔ by epitope mapping show highly reactive to amino sequences of AND envelope glyrote. We examined the efficacy of goose-derived antibody in hamster lethal model of HPS. α-AND immune sera or Ig/IgΔ purified from eggs were passively transferred to hamsters subcutaneously 5 days after challenge with AND (25LD50). Both immune and egg-derived Ig/IgΔ protected 8/8 and 7/8, respectively. In contrast, hamsters Ig/IgΔ from normal ge (8) or no-treatment (8) developed HPS.
Mutations in the Dnmta gene have been associated with leukemias and deletion of Dmta has been shown to promote tumor progression in a K-r–dependent lung cancer model. We used whole-genome bisulf sequencing to comprehensively characterize the methylomes of Dmta wildtype and Dmt-deficient lung tumors. Our results show profound methylation changes in K–induced lung cancer. Dmt wildtype tumors were characterized by large hypomethyl domains corresponding to lamina-associated domains. In contrast,mt-deficient tumors showed uniformly hypomethyl genome. Further analysis revealed thatmta is required for efficient methylation of active domains andmt-deficient tumors show moderate deregulation in these domains.
Songbird premotor cortex is a brain region that supports the generation of learned song sequences in songbirds. Here, we describe the spatial and temporal organization of the premotor cortical microcircuit that supports the generation of these sequences. We used multi-channel electrophysiology and calcium imaging to record neural activity in the premotor cortex of zebra finches. We found that neural activity in the premotor cortex is correlated over a length of 100 µm. Within this length, basal ganglia-projecting excitatory neurons fire at a specific phase of a 30 Hz network rhythm. These results show that premotor activity is inhomogeneous in time and space, and that a mesoscopic pattern underlies the generation of the sequences controlling song.
Evolutionarily conserved mechanisms that control aging are predicted to have prereproductive functions in order to be subject to natural selection. Genes that are essential for growth and development are highly conserved in evolution, but their role in longevity has not been previously assessed. We screened 2, 700 genes for Caenorhabditis elegans development and identified 64 that extend lifespan when inactivated postdevelopment. These candidate regulators are conserved from yeast to humans. Classification the regulators into functional groups identified the insulin and metabolic pathways but also enrichment translation, RNA, and chromatin.
During zebraf fin regeneration, the first step is the formation of a specialized epidermis from the underlying stump tissue. We performed a forward genetic screen for mutations that impair this process in zebraf fins and identified a temperature-sensitive allele of laminin beta 1 ( lamba ) that blocks regeneration. Lamb1, but not its paralog lambb, is induced in a subset of epithelial cells after amputation where it is required to establish and maintain a polarized epithelial layer. These events include expression of morphogenic factors shha and lef, basolateral positioning of phosphorylated Igf1, patterning of osteoblasts, and regeneration of bone. Lamb1 function is dispensable for juvenile growth, homeostatic adult maintenance, repair of split fins or renewal of geneticallylated osteoblast.
Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) are used to identify genetic variants associated with diseases. GWAS can be affected by population substructure and relatedness. Recently, linear mixed models (LMM) have been used to account for relatedness in GWAS. Several LMM software packages have been developed, but it is unclear how they differ from each other. Here, we compare several LMM approaches and implementations, including EMM, GenABEL, FaSTMM, Mendel, GEM, and MMM, via a GWAS of visceral leishmaniasis in 348 families ( 362 individuals, 197 genotyped ). LMM differ in methodology and user options, such as method and number of SNPs to estimate kinship matrix. We investigate sensitivity to these choices and success in controlling genome-wide error for both real and simulated phenotypes. We compare LMM to traditional family-based tests and alternative approaches in MQL, ROADIPS and MAST. We find strong concordance between LMM, all controlling genome error except when applied to longitudinal data with repeated measures. We find correlation between LMM and alternative approaches apart from transmission-based when SNPs small or non-existent. We conclude LMM perform well compared to competing approaches.
Trypanosoma cruzi is the causative agent of Chagas disease, a major public health problem in Latin America. Current treatments are toxic, have partial efficacy, and target only the acute phase of the disease. In this study, we developed a whole-cell assay for high-throughput screening of compounds that inhibit Trypanosoma cruzi infection of mammalian cells. A chemical library of 200 compounds was screened using recombinant T. cruzi ( Tulah strain ) expressing β-galactosidase. Three compounds were selected for high activity against T cruz and low toxicity to host cells in vitro: P1, NT1 and CX ( IC50: 54,190 and 23 nM, respectively ). Each compound has a different mechanism of action on intracellular T cruzi proliferation. CX shows trypanocidal activity, essential for chronic Chagas treatment where parasites are intracellular quiescent. NT has tryostatic effect, while P1 affects parasite division. These compounds also inhibit intracellular T cruz from Y and related species Leishmania major and amazonensis.
Lymphatic filariasis is a neglected tropical disease caused by filarial parasites transmitted by mosquitoes. Molecular monitoring of filariasis relies on PCR or real-time PCR detection of Brugia malayi, Brug timori and Wuchereria bancrofti in vectors. However, DNA extraction from mosquitoes is typically performed using silica-based technologies, which are time-consuming and costly, and testing requires expensive cyclers or real-time instruments. This presents challenges for laboratories in endemic areas. We present a novel molecular monitoring approach for filarial parasites in mosquitoes using a rapid NaOH DNA extraction coupled with a battery-powered PCR platform and strip-based detection. We evaluated the performance of rapid NaOH extraction for DNA from parasite-spiked mosquito pools and compared it to silica-based extraction. We also compared our strip detection to real-time PCR and conventional PCR with gel electrophoresis, demonstrating sensitive and specific detection of parasite DNA from mosquito pools. Finally, we compared laboratory thermal cycling with field miniaturized PCR, demonstrating potential for point-of-collection use. This platform is compact enough to fit into a backpack and eliminates reliance on expensive instrumentation without compromising detection sensitivity or specificity. It provides an alternative to column-dependent extractions coupled to methodologies requiring advanced infrastructure. This system should increase feasibility of molecular monitoring in B. malayi-endemic locations.
Elastomeric proteins are a class of proteins that have evolved independently multiple times through evolution. They are produced as monomers that self-assemble into polymeric structures with properties of stretch and recoil. These proteins are composed of an alternating architecture of elastomeric domains interspersed with cross-linking elements. The elastom domains provide elasticity and drive the assembly process, while the cross-link elements serve to stabilise the polymer. The number and arrangement of elastom and cross-link domains have been shown to significantly impact assembly and mechanical properties. Here we present a theoretical study that examines the impact of domain architecture on polymer assembly and integrity. We use a novel simulation model of diffusion limited aggregation to simulate the self-assembly of rod-like particles with alternating architectures. We apply the model to different architectures and generate a variety of aggregates that are subsequently analysed by graph-theoretic metrics to predict structural integrity. Our results show that the relative length and number of elastom and cross-link domains significantly impact the morphology and structural integrity of the polymeric structure. For example, the most connected polymers are constructed from rods with large cross-link elements interspersed with smaller elastom domains.
Ebola virus (EBOV) is a highly lethal zoonotic pathogen with a genome larger size than most non-segmented negative-strand RNA viruses due to the presence of long 5′ and 3′ untranslated regions (UTRs) in its seven transcriptional units. To date, the functions of these UTRs have not been assigned. Using reporter assays, we show that the EBO 5′-UTR lacks internal ribosomal entry function, but differentially regulates cap-dependent translation when placed upstream of a GFP gene. Most notably, the 5′-UT derived from the polymerase (L) mRNA strongly suppresses GFP translation compared to β-actin 5-UT. The 5-UT is one of four viral genes to possess upstream AUGs (uAUGs), and ablation of each uUG enhances translation of the primary open reading frame (ORF), most dramatically in the case of 5-UT. The uUG is sufficient to initiate translation, surrounded by a weak Koz sequence and suppresses OR translation in a position-dependent manner. Under conditions where eIFα is phosphorylated, the presence of uOR maintains translation of LOR, indicating uOR modulates translation in response to cellular stress. To address the role of uUG in replication, a recombinant EBO was generated in which uUG was mutated to UCG. Strikingly, mutating two nucleotides outside previously-defined protein and cis-regulatory sequences attenuates virus titers 10–100 lower than wild-type in Vero A549 cells.
Genome instability plays a key role in many biological processes and diseases, including cancer. Genome-wide mapping of DNA double-strand breaks ( DSBs ) is important for understanding chromosomal architecture and specific chromosomal regions DSB. We developed a method for precise genome-wide mapping of blunt-ended DSBs in human chromosomes, and observed non-random and DSB hot spots. These hot spots are scattered along chromosomes and limit 50–250 kb domains. We found that about 30% of domains ( denoted domains ) possess coordinately expressed genes that PAR1 and HNPA2B1 bind DNA at domain termini. Thus, our data suggest a novel type of regulation: coordinated transcription silencing of gene clusters by D hot spots as well as PAR1 and HN2B1 binding sites.
Trypanosomat diversity was studied in bats from two areas with different levels of degradation in the Atlantic Forest of Rio de Janeiro, Brazil: Reserva Biológica Guapia (REG) and Estação Florestal Atlântica (EFMA). A total of 181 bat specimens were analyzed, 24 (13% ) were infected with trypanosomatids. Molecular characterization using PCR targeting the 18S rRNA gene showed similar infection rates in both areas: 15% in REG and 11% in EF (p=0.46). Trypanosomaionii was the most frequently detected (54% ) followed by T. cruzi DTI and TIV and Tryosoma sp. Mixed infections were observed in Neotropical phlost bats. T cruz DTI and TIV are involved in acute cases of Chagas disease in Brazil and Tionii was recently found in heart tissue of an infected child. Crithia mellae, a putative monoxen parasite infecting vertebrate in Americas, was also described.
Ticks are the most common arthropod vectors of human and animal diseases in Europe, and Ixodes ricinus is able to transmit a large number of bacteria, viruses, and parasites. They may be coinfected with several pathogens, with a high likelihood of transmission to humans or animals. However, few data exist on coinfection rates and studies focus on well-known pathogens. In addition to pathogens, ticks carry symbionts that may play roles in tick biology and interfere with pathogen transmission. This study evaluated the prevalence of 38 pathogens and symbion coinfections as well as possible interactions between pathogens and symbion. A total 267 Ix ricinus female specimens were collected in the Ardennes and analyzed by high-throughput real-time PCR for presence of 37 bacteria and parasites, rRT-PCR for Tick-borne encephalitis virus, and nested PCR for symbion. Possible interactions between pathogens and symbion were statistically evaluated.
Hematopoietic eryth-myeloid lineage commitment is determined by a genetic switch involving the transcription factors PU.1 and GATA-1. Prior to lineage commitment, these genes are primed at low levels of expression. We develop a computational model for the hematopoietic eryth-myeloid decision, which is based on known interactions between these master genes, such as mutual antagonism and autoregulation. The system is bistable, a feature for robust lineage determination. We suggest a mechanism involving a cofactor regulated by one of the master genes to bind the antagonistic partner necessary for bistability and switch-like behavior. Suppression of cofactor through external means leads to loss of cooperativity and primed PU.1 GATA. The PU1–GATA switch also interacts with mutually antagonistic pair –G. The latter inherits state of upstream genes and reinforces decision through feedback, leading to irreversible commitment. The eryth-myoid lineage switch is an example of network that implements prim and committed by cooperativity through cofactor recruitment. Perturbing feedback between regulators and targets suggests reprogramming strategies.
Enterococcus faecalis is an opportunistic pathogen that is intrinsically resistant to lysozym, a key effector of the innate immune system. This high level of resistance requires a complex network of transcriptional regulators and several genes ( oat, pgA, dlt, and sigV ) acting synergistically to inhibit the enzym and cationic antimicrobial activities of lysozym. We sought to identify novel genes modulating E. faalis resistance to lyso. Random transposon mutagenesis in the quadruple oat/pgA/dlt/sig mutant led to the identification of several insertions in the chromosome. These were located in a locus referred to as the enteroccal polysacchar antigen (EPA) region downstream of conserved epAepaR genes proposed to encode a core machinery. The ep region was previously proposed to be responsible for EPA decoration, but the role remains largely unknown. We show that EPA contributes to resistance to antimicrobials and virulence in zebraf infection by conferring resistance phagocytosis. Our results indicate that production of the rhamopolysacchar backbone is not sufficient to promote E faalis infections and reveal an essential role of modification of this polymer for enteroc pathogenesis.
In this study, we developed RER (Regression of Combined Expression ), an integrative model that combines data from ENCODE and The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCG ) to predict gene expression in Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML). RER infers sample-specific regulatory activities of transcription factors (TFs) and microRNAs, which are then used to infer TF/miRNA interactions. This two-stage framework circumvents difficulties in integrating ENCODE data with sample-specific TCG measurements. We applied RER to AML data from TCG and ENCODE TF binding data in K562. We first verified RER by 10-fold cross-validation predicting gene expression. Next, we evaluated RER recovering known regulatory interactions and demonstrated superior statistical power over existing methods detecting miRNA/TF targets. We developed a feature selection procedure that identified 18 regulators whose activities clustered with cytogenetic risk. One selected regulator, miR-548, inferred targets were enriched for leukemia-related, implicating its role in AML pathogenesis. We used inferred activities as a potential AML prognostic marker. Our framework successfully integrated TCG and EN data revealing AML regulatory program at the global level.
Small RNA-based antiviral defense in the phytopathogenic fungus Colletotrichum higginsum. Although little is known about the biological roles of RNA silencing in fungi, the Colletum genus comprises species that are pathogenic for a wide range of crops worldwide. To investigate the role of RNA silencing in the ascomyc fungus Colotrichum higginsum, we generated knock-out mutants for RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (DR), Dicer (DCL), and Argonaute (AGO) proteins by targeted gene replacement. No effects were observed on vegetative growth for any mutant when grown on complex or minimal media. However, ΔCL, ΔCLΔCL, and ΔAGO strains showed defects in conidiation and conidia morphology. Total RNA and small RNA populations were analyzed in parental and mutant strains. The greatest effects on both populations were observed in ΔCL, ΔCL, andAGO, in which derepressed a previously uncharacterized dsRNA mycovirus Colotrich higginsum non-segment dsRNA 1 (ChV1). Phylogen analyses showed a close relationship between ChV and members of the Partitiviridae family. Immunoprecipitation of small RNAs with AGO showed abundant 5’-containing siRNA. higginsum and ΔCL strains cured ofV revealed conid and spore defects were primarily caused byV.
Histone acetyltransferase MOF is involved in all three waves of H2AX phosphorylation during meiotic prophase I in male mice. The first wave of HAX phosphorylation is ATM-dependent and occurs at leptotene, while the second and third are ATR-dependent and occur at zygotene and pachene stages, respectively. The third wave of HAX phosphorylation marks unsynapsed chromosomes. In this study, we report that MO is involved in all three waves of HAX phosphorylation. Germ cell-specific deletion of MO in spermatocytes caused loss of H4acetylation. In leptene and zgot spermatocytes of MO-deficient mice, HAX signals were only along chromosomal axes and chromatin-wide HAX phosphorylation was lost. In almost 40% of early-mid pachene spermatocytes from MO-deficient mice HAX and M1 were along unsyn axes of sex chromosomes but failed to expand, causing meiotic chromosome inactivation failure. Furthermore, though RAD51 was proficiently recruited to double-strand break sites, defects in repair and crossover were observed in MO-deficient spermatocytes, indicating MO facilitates meiotic repair after RAD51 recruitment.
Human T-cell leukemia virus type 1 (HTLV-1) infection has the potential to interfere with thymic T-cell development. We investigated the effects of HTLV-1 infection on human T-cell development in “Immune System” Rag-2/-γ- mice. These mice were infected with HT-1 at a time when three subpopulations of thymocytes have been detected. In all inoculated mice, HT-1 was found in thymocytes; proviral load increased with length of infection. In HT- mice, T development was altered, extent correlated with proviral load. In thym of HT- mice, single-positive (SP) CD4 and CD8 cells were most, at expense of immature double-positive (DP) thymocytes. These cells accumulated in spleen. Lymphocytes thym and spleen were activated, shown by expression of CD25. This was correlated with presence of mRNA and increased of NF-κB dependent genes such as bfl-1, anti-apopt gene in thym. Finally, lymphadenopathy and lymphoma/thymoma were observed in HT- mice months after infection.
Schistosomiasis remains a major public health concern in Sudan, particularly Schistosoma haematium infection. This study presents the disease reduction outcomes of an integrated control program for schosomiasis in Jabal locality of White State, Sudan from 2009 through 2011. The total population of the project was 482, 902, and the major group for intervention among them was 78, 615 primary school students. The prevalence of S. haematium and S. mansoni at baseline was 28.5% and 0.4, respectively. After 6–9 months post-treatment, the prevalence of S.ematium was reduced to 13.5 ( 95 CI=0.3310.462 ). A higher reduction was observed among girls, those moderately infected (20% ) and residents in rural, than boys, those high (40% ) and in urban. After education, awareness about schosias was increased. Also, a water facility was constructed at Hida village where infection was reduced compared to a neighboring village. However, no change was found in S mans infection between baseline and follow-up ( CI.9336.891 ). At the end, S haemat infection was reduced more than 50% with baseline. Approximately, subjects received prazantel therapy, education, or water.
Paramyxiruses are a family of viruses that replicate in the cytoplasm and bud from the plasma membrane. The matrix protein is the major structural protein in paramyxiruses that mediates viral assembly and budding. However, the matrix proteins of a few paramyxiruses have been found in the nucleus, and the biological function associated with this localization remains obscure. Here, we report that the nuclear-ctoplasmic trafficking of the Nip virus ( NiV ) matrix protein and post-translational modification play a critical role in matrix-mediated virus budding. NiV is a highly pathogenic paramyxirus that causes encephalitis in humans and is classified as a Biosafety Level ( BSL ) pathogen. During Ni infection, NiV was first detected in the nucleus at early stages before localization to the cytoplasm and plasma. Mutations in the putative bipart nuclear localization (LS ) and leuc-rich nuclear export (NES ) found in Ni impaired nuclear-ctoplasm trafficking and abolished Ni budding. A conserved lysine in LS served dual functions: positive for nuclear import and was also a site for monoubiquination regulating export. Overexpression of ubiquitin enhanced NiV budding whereas depletion in the cell via proteas inhibitors resulted in Ni retention and blocked budding.
Viruses are able to initiate infection by transferring their genetic material across the cell membrane and into the cytoplasm. However, the mechanisms by which non-enveloped viruses deliver their genomes are poorly understood. This is due to difficulties in visualizing viral delivery and distinguishing between productive and non-productive pathways caused by the high particle-to-plaque forming unit ratio of most viruses. Here, we combine an imaging assay that tracks viral capsid and genome in live cells with an infectivity assay for RNA release to characterize early events in poliovirus (PV) infection. Surprisingly, we observe that PV genome release is highly efficient and does not limit overall infectivity or infection rate. We define a pathway in which PV binds to cell surface receptors and enters by clathrin, caveolin, flotillin, and microtubule-independent, tyrosine-kinase and actin-dependent endocytic mechanism. Immediately after internalization of virus, genome release takes place from vesicles or sealed invaginations within 100–200 nm of plasma membrane.
Dengue continues to be a major public health problem in Cambodia with a significant impact on children. The National Dengue Control Program (NDC) delivers health education to communities and schools as a major means of prevention and control. Drawing on data collected in 2003–2004 as part of an ethnographic study in eastern Cambodia, we explore the approaches used in health education and their effectiveness to control dengue. Community education is provided through health outreach activities and campaigns of the DC, but is not systematically evaluated, under-funded and irregular; school education is restricted in terms of time and lacks follow-up in terms of practical activities for prevention and control. As a result, adherence is partial. We suggest the need for sustained education for deng prevention control and need approaches to ensure the translation of knowledge into practice.
Filarial nematodes are parasitic worms that cause chronic and debilitating diseases in humans and animals. In this study, we investigated the presence of circulating microRNAs (miRNAs) released by filarial nematodes into the host bloodstream. We used miRNA sequencing combined with bioinformatics to reveal over 200 miRNA sequences of nematode origin in Dirofilaria imis-infected dog plasma and Onchocerca volulus-infected human serum. Total RNA from D. imis-infected dog plasma was subjected to stem-loop RT-PCR assays to detect two miRNA candidates, mi-71 and mi-34. Additionally, Brugia pangi-infected dog samples were included in the analysis, as these miRNAs were previously detected in extracts from this species. The presence of mi-71 and mi34 discriminated infected samples from uninfected samples, with no mi amplification in uninfected samples. However, miRNA numbers were not correlated with microfilaria for either. This may be due to imprecision of mf to estimate infection or mi from unknown number of worms. Nonetheless, parasite-derived miRNAs were found in plasma or serum for species that do not live in bloodstream.
Tyrosine kinases of the Src family are large allosteric enzymes that play a key role in cellular signaling. The conversion of the kinase from an inactive to an active state is accompanied by substantial structural changes. Here, we construct a coarse-grained model of the catalytic domain incorporating experimental structures of the two stable states and simulate the dynamics of conformation transitions in activation. We explore the transition landscapes by constructing a structural network among conformations from simulations. From the network, two major ensembles of pathways for activation are identified. The first pathway involves a coordinated mechanism of interactions among the α helix, the-loop and β strands in the N-terminal of the catalytic domain. The second pathway conformation change is coupled to partial unfolding of the N-terminal region of the catalytic domain. We also characterize the mechanism of the helix and-loop in detail. Finally, we test a Markov model and its ability to account for structural in the context of conformation changes.
Lethality in interplo Crosses of Arabidopsis thaliana: The Role of the Maternally Expressed WRKY Transcription Factor TT2. In interplo crosses between diploid and tetraploid Arabidopsis thaliana can result in lethality in the F1 generation. We have identified the genetic basis of lethality in interplo crosses via QTL mapping. A large-effect QTL, DRANGEVE 1 ( DSL ) was identified, as well as two QTL with epistatic relationships to DSL. DSL affects the rate of postzyotic lethality via expression in the maternal sporophyte. Fine mapping placed DSL in an interval encoding the maternal transcription factor TT2. Maternal parents carrying loss-of-function mutations in TT2 suppressed F leth caused by paternal interplo crosses. The frequency of cellularization in the endosperm was similarly affected by natural and tt2 loss-function mutants.
Bats and rodents are natural reservoirs of many emerging zoonotic pathogens, including Bartonella and Leptira species. We conducted the first comparative host–pathogen coevolutionary analyses of these pathogens in bats and rodents. We used genetic data for 51 Bartonella genotypes from 24 bat species, 129 Bartonella from 38 rodents, and 26 Leptira from 20 species. We generated maximum likelihood and Bayesian phylogenies for hosts and bacteria, and tested coevolution congruence using ParaFit, PAC, and Jane.
