These networks display similar topological features ( e. g. structural ) and dynamics. We also reverse-engineered diseased brains (epileptic and schizophrenic ) with altered oscillatory activity. These networks show consistent alterations of connectivity and dynamics. Complexity, quantified by Tononi, Sporns and Edelman, is a good indicator of brain fitness since diseased brains display lower complexity than normal brains.
The United States is the largest Hispanic population in the United States is composed of individuals from many different countries of origin. The Multi-Ethnic Study of Atherosclerosis ( MESA ) is a study of 1, 374 Hispanic individuals from six countries: Central America, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Mexico, Puerto Rico, and South America. We used 60, 000 single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs ) to study the genetic structure of the MESA population. We found that the first two principal components ( PCs ) of ancestry were Caucasian and African, while the third and fourth PCs were Native American. The third PC also separated MESA Mexican and Central/South American samples. We used k-means clustering to define four subgroups of the MESA that agreed with self-identification: Dominican/Cuban, Mexican, Central/South, and Puerto Rican. We studied genetic association of triglycerides in the LPL and TR1 genes, previously associated with trigides in Caucasians but not in Hispanics. We found significant association in both genes and show the importance of considering population structure and genetic heterogeneity in studies of Hispanics.
The Elong Complex Interacts with PCNA and Modulates Transcriptional Silencing and Sensitivity to DNA Damage
Biomedical literature curation is a time-consuming and labor-intensive process that is necessary for building knowledge bases with precise and organized information. However, the process of retrieving relevant publications for curation, also known as document triage, is usually carried out by querying PubMed and often obtains unsatisfactory precision and recall. To address this, we propose a machine-assisted triage method. We collected curated publications from UniProt/SwissProt and NHRIEB GWAS Catalog and used them as a gold-standard for training deep learning models based on convolutional neural networks. We then used the models to classify and rank new publications foruration. We applied our method to the manualuration of UniProt/SissProt and GWAS. Our method outperforms current query-based triage, improves efficiency and enriches curated content. Our method achieves 1. 81 and 2.99 higher precision than current query-based triage UniProt/Siss and GWAS, respectively, without compromising recall. Our method retrieves additional publications query-based UniProt/Siss could not.
Short QT syndrome type 3 (SQT3), caused by gain-of-function mutations in the KCNJ2-encoded Kir2.1 channel, is associated with atrial fibrillation (AF). This study investigated the mechanistic link between QT3 mutations and atrial arrhythmogenesis using biophysically-detailed human atrial computer models. We modified the human atrial action potential (AP) model to recapitulate functional changes in IK due to heterozygous and homozygous forms of the D172 and E299 Kir2.1 mutations. Wild-type (WT) and mutant formulations were incorporated into multi-scale and heterogeneous tissue models. We quantified effects on AP duration (AP), conduction (CV), refractory period (ERP), tissue excitation threshold and rate-dependence, as well as wavelength re-entry (WL). The D and E Kir.1 mutations produced distinct effects on IK and AP shortening. Both decreased WL through reduction in ERP and CV. Stability of reentrant excitation in 2D and 3 tissue was mediated by changes in tissueability and AP in conditions. Combined block IK and IK was effective in terminating associated with heterozyous conditions, whereas IK alone may be safer for the mutation. Combined IK and produced a synergistic antiarrhythmic in both forms of QT. This study provides mechanistic into atrial prohythm with QT2.1 and highlights pharmacological for management of QT-linked AF.
Adipose tissue-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (ASCs) have been shown to protect mice infected with Trypanosoma cruzi from cardiac damage through modulation of anti-parasite immunity. Chagas disease, caused by the protozoan parasite Trypanosoma cruzi, is a complex disease endemic in Central and South America and has gained interest due to increases in non-vector forms of transmission, especially in developed countries. The objective of this work was to investigate if ASC can alter the course of disease and attenuate pathology in a mouse model of chagasic cardiopathy. ASC were injected intraperitoneally at 3 days postinfection ( dpi ) and tracking by bioluminescence showed that remained in the abdominal cavity up to 9 days after injection and most migrated to abdominal subcutaneous fat, an early parasite reservoir. ASC resulted in significant reduction in parasitemia, followed by decrease in cardiac tissue parasism and fibrosis at 30 dpi. At same point, analyses cytokine release in cells from heart exposed to cruz antigens indicated anti-inflammatory response in ASC-treated. In parallel, splenocytes exposed same antigens produced pro-inflammatory response important control parasite, placebo and ASC-treated. However, splenocytes ASC released higher levels IL-10. dpi, magnetic resonance imaging revealed right ventricular ( RV ) dilation prevented ASC-treated. In, injection ASC after cruz infection prevents RV remodeling through modulation responses.
Leishmania parasites are obligate intracellular pathogens that reside within parasitophorous vacuoles (PVs) in mammalian cells. We have previously shown that Retro-2, a retrograde trafficking inhibitor, reduces PV size and parasite numbers during Leishmania mexicana infections. This study aimed to determine if structural analogs of Retro-2 with superior potency in retrograde inhibition are also effective against Leish infections. In addition to PV effects, we show that two optimized analogs of Retro-2, DHZ36 and DHZ36, limit Leish infections in macrophages with EC50 of 13.63±2.58μM and 10.57±2.66M, respectively, which is lower than 40.15M EC of Retro-2. These analogs also reverse Leish suppression of IL-6 release by infected cells after LPS activation. In contrast to Retro-2, these analogs kill Leish parasites in axenic cultures.
The nucleosome is a fundamental component of chromatin that organizes the genome and regulates gene expression. We developed a computational method to predict nucleosome sensitivity for a transcription factors over a given genomic region. Sensitive factors are those with binding sites preferentially within nucleosome boundaries and lacking 10 bp periodicity. We applied this method to Acute Myeloid Leukemia-1 ( AML-1 ), a regulator of immune gene expression. AML-1 was predicted to be sensitive to nucleosomal regulation within the Ly49 gene family. This was confirmed using MNase-Seq to generate a nucleosome map of chromosome 6, where Ly49 is located. Analysis revealed depletion of nucleosomes at AML-1 binding sites in expressed LyA compared to silent Ly genes. Our data suggest nucleosome contributes to Ly expression. We propose this method to dissect the role of nucleosomes in general.
Cell cycle progression is orchestrated by cyclin-dependent kinases (CDs), which are activated by phosphorylation of their T-loop by CD-activating kinases (CA). In animals, the only known CA for CD2 and CD1 is cyclin-CD7, which is constitutively active. The critical step is dephosphorylation of inhibitory sites by C25 phosphatases rather than T-loop phosphorylation. CD4 and CD6 bound cyclins are integrators of mitogenic signaling cascades by inactivating the oncosuppressor p and cell commitment at the restriction point. In contrast to CD1 and CD2 cyclins, CD4 has a highly regulated T-loop phosphorylation at T172 determining activity. CD4 and CD6 phosphorylations are catalyzed by CD7, but this is unclear. We took a chemical-genetics approach using analogue-sensitive CD7 (as) mutant H116 cells, which CD7 can be inhibited by bulky analogs. CD7 inhibition prevented phosphorylation of CD6, but CD4 was partly dependent on p21. In response to CD7 inhibition, p-binding CD increased conitantly with disappearance of most phosphorylated p, catalyzed by CD and CD2. S130 of p prevented CD4 phosphorylation and CD7 inhibition impaired phosphorylations of p and CD-bound CD4. CD7 revealed: crucial indirect CD7 involvement in CD4 phosphorylation and existence CD-activating other than CD7; and CD-dependent feedback by p phosphorylation CD4 and CD2 to sustain CD activation and restriction.
Meiosis is an essential for sexual reproduction, producing haploid cells. In multicellular eukaryotes, entry into meiosis is triggered by transcription factors that activate a cascade resulting in sequential expression of early, middle, and late meiotic genes. However, these factors are not conserved and the mechanisms that ensure proper meiotic expression in multicellular eukotes are poorly understood. Here, we report that DUET/M1, a PHD finger protein essential for Arabidopsis meiosis, functions as a transcriptional regulator in meiosis. We show that DUET binds H3K4me in vitro and that this interaction is critical for meiosis. We also show that DU is required for microtub organization during me II independently of me I. Remarkably, DU shows stage-specific expression confined diplot. We identify TDM and J as critical for cycle and spindle organization in me, DU targets with TDM being direct. Thus, is required to regulate microt organization and cycle during me, and as direct activator of the meiotic TDM. Expression shows reduced expression of about 12% of known me genes in the mutant. Our results reveal as a transcription regulator during me in plants, and that meiotic is under stagewise in plants as yeast.
Fragile X-associated tremor ataxia syndrome (FXTAS) is a neurodegenerative disorder caused by the expansion of CGG repeats in the FMR1 gene. Previous studies have shown that CG repeats are sufficient to cause neurodegeneration and that CG-binding proteins α and hnRNP A/B can modulate CG-mediated neurotoxicity. To further explore the role of α in CG-mediated neurodegeneration, we took a proteomic approach and identified more than 100 proteins that interact with α. Of particular interest is R62, the Drosophila ortholog of p68 helicase, which modulates CG-mediated neurodegeneration. We show that CG repeats decrease R62 expression posttranslationally, leading to nuclear accumulation of Hsp transcript as well as additional mRNAs involved in stress and immune responses.
Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a paradigm organism for the study of biofilms. The extracellular polymeric substance of P. aerugin biofilms is an ill-defined mix of polyscharides, nucleic acids and proteins. Here, we directly visualize the product of the polyschar synthesis locus (slpolysacide ) at different stages of bio development. During attachment,sl is anchored on the surface in a helical pattern. This promotes cell–cell interactions and assembly of matrix, which holds bacteria in biofilm on surface. Chemicalation ofsl from the surface disrupted thesl matrix as well as bio structure. During maturation,sl accumulates on periphery 3-D microcolonies, resulting insl-free cavity in microcol center. At dispersion, cells appear in matrix. Dead and extracellular DNA are concentrated insl-free area. Deletion of genes control death affects formation matrix and microcol dispersion. These data provide mechanism how builds a matrix and subsequently cavity for portion cells seeding.
Patient-derived xenografts (PDX) and patient-derived organoids (PDO) serve as promising tools to identify new therapeutic strategies for pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC). To be effective, these preclinical models should recapitulate the molecular heterogeneity of PDAC and validate patient-specific sensitivities. We conducted a comprehensive assessment of the genetic landscape of 16 whole-genome pairs of tumours and PDX from PD and liver metastasis, including a unique cohort of 5 ‘trios’ of primary tum, PDX, and PDO. We developed a pipeline to score concordance between PD models and paired tumour for genomic events including mutations, structural variations, and copy variations. Tumour-model comparisons displayed single-gene concord across PD major driver genes but poor agreement across mutational load. Genome-wide chromosome analysis of structural (SV) events highlights concord across chromosomes that demonstrate SV events. We found ploidy presented a challenge when assessing copy changes; however, ploidy-correct copy suggest good agreement donor-model pairs.
Genome-Wide Association Study Identifies Novel Susceptibility Loci for Breast Cancer in East Asians  
Breast cancer is a leading cause of cancer death in women worldwide. Genetic factors play an important role in the etiology of both sporadic and familial breast cancer. We conducted a four-stage genome-wide association study ( GWAS ) in 19, 091 cases and 20, 606 controls of East-Asian descent including Chinese, Korean, and Japanese. We analyzed 690,947 SNPs in 2,918 cases and 2,324, and evaluated 5,365 SNPs in 3,972 and 3,852. We further evaluated 94 SNPs in 5,203 and 5,138, and finally 22 SNPs in 17,423 (7,489 and 9,934 ). We identified three SNPs associated with breast cancer risk: rs9482 near the TGF-activated kinase 2 gene in chromosome 6q25.1 (P=3.8×10−12 ), rs938 in intron 5 of the ESR gene (P=1.9×10−6 ), and rs710 at 11q24.3 (P=.6×10−7 ).
Cryptocococcal meningitis is a major cause of mortality in the developing world and little is known about the genetic factors underlying cryptococcal virulence and patient outcome. We studied a cohort of 230 Cryptococcus neoformans (C) isolates from HIV-positive South African patients with clinical follow-up using multi-locus sequence typing and in vitro virulence assays, correlating data with clinical and fungal markers of disease in patients. We found high levels of genetic diversity and variability in South African isolates compared to globally distributed types, and identified 50 sequence types within main types VNI, VNII and VNB, with 72% isolates in seven high frequency types. Spatial analysis of patients’ cryptoccal genotype was not geographically clustered, arguing against recent acquisition and in favour of latent infection. We found a relationship between genetic and clinical outcome, patients with VNB lineage having worse survival (HR 3. 35, CI 1.51-7.20, p0.003 ), maintained after adjustment for prognostic indicators and treatment. We compared genotype with in vitro (phagocysis lase activity and CSF survival ) on subset 89 isolates and found lineage-associated virulence, VN displaying increased lase activity (0.001 ) and ex vivo CS survival (0.000 ). These findings show Cryptoccus is phenotypically heterogeneous and lineage important in cryptocal virulence during infection.
Candida albicans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that exists in two phenotypes: white and opaque. The white phenotype is associated with virulence, while the opaque is associated with commensalism. The white phenotype is regulated by the pheromone response, a signal transduction pathway that is poorly understood. Here we have identified the transcription factor Tec1 as the last component of the pherone response pathway in the white phenotype of C. alb. We constructed an overexpression library of 107 transcription factors and performed mutational analyses to identify Tec1. The elucidation of Tec1 establishes a comprehensive description of the pherone pathway in the white phenotype of C. alb, providing insights into how signalduction pathways evolve. The pherone pathway appears to be composed of three portions, each derived from different ancestral programs in C. alb. The upstream portion, including receptors, trimer G protein, and MAP kinase, was derived from the opaque mating pathway. Tec, the transcription factor targeted by the MAP pathway, was from filamentation, and white-specific genes from biofilm. The evolution of the pherone pathway provides a paradigm for how signalduction pathways evolve.
Bacteria exhibit a wide variation in genomic GC content, ranging from less than 20% to more than 70%. This variation is thought to be due to differences in mutation patterns between species. Here, we test this hypothesis by examining patterns of synonymous polymorphism in 149 bacterial species. We find a large excess of GC→AT mutations over AT→GC mutations segregating in all but the most AT-rich bacteria, across a range of phylogenetically diverse species. This excess of GC→AT mutations is inconsistent with mutation bias, as it would imply most GC-rich bacteria are declining in GC-content; such a pattern is unsustainable. We show that patterns are not due to translational selection or gene conversion because optimal codons are AT-rich, and excess GC→SNPs are observed in datasets with no recombination. We conclude there is selection to increase GC-content in many species. Since GC-content is highly correlated with genomic-content, we conclude there is selection on genomic composition many.
Soil-transmitted helminth infections (STHs), such as hookworm, Ascaris lumbricoid and Trichuris trichi, are major public health problems in developing countries. To control these infections, accurate maps are required that provide recommendations for intervention at policy-relevant spatial scales. Here, we present a new approach for mapping the prevalence of STs in Kenya, using observed data from 106,370 individuals from 945 cross-sectional surveys between 1974 and 2009. We used Bayesian space-time geostatistical models to interpolate the probability that prevalence exceeded 20% across the country for 198 and 2009. Maps for each species were integrated to estimate combined STH prevalence using the law of probability and a correction for associations between species. Population data were combined with models to estimate the population at risk and requiring treatment in 200. Our results show that in 200, most areas had low endemicity below 20%, with areas ≥20% located around the shores of Lake Victoria and the coast. Comparison of predicted distributions for 198 and 200 show that STH prevalence has decreased over time. We estimated that 2.8 million school-age children live in districts warranting mass treatment. Our models suggest that a quarter of Kenya's school children live in areas of high prevalence warranting mass treatment.
Infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb) requires a coordinated response between the innate and adaptive arms of the immune system, resulting in a type 1 cytokine response, which is associated with control of infection. Innate lymphocytes contribute to immunity against Mtb, but their role remains controversial. We established an in vitro system to study this. We show that interferonγ is produced when splenocytes from uninfected mice are cultured with M-infected macrophages, and under these conditions, bacterial replication is suppressed. This control of bacterial replication is dependent on CD1-restricted NKT (iNKT) cells, and their activation requires CD1 expression by infected macrophages as well as IL-12 and IL-18. We show that NKT cells, even in limiting quantities, are sufficient to restrict M replication. To determine whether N cells contribute to defense against tuberculosis in vivo, we adoptively transferred N cells into mice. Primary splenic N cells from uninf mice significantly reduce the burden in the lungs of mice with virulent M by the aerosol route. Thus N cells have direct bactericidal effect even in the absence of synthetic ligands such as α-galactosceramide. Our finding N cells protect against aerosol M infection is first that CD-restricted N mediate against M in vivo.
In Bacillus subtilis spores are highly resilient because they are surrounded by a complex protein coat. The proteins in the coat are cross-linked by a transglutaminase (Tgl). Unlike other transglutases, Tgl is produced in an active form and efficiently catalyzes amine incorporation and cross-linking in vitro with no additional requirements. However, the absence of regulatory factors raises how Tgl activity is controlled during spore assembly. Here, we show that substrates assembled onto spore prior to Tgl production govern localization of T to the sp surface. We also show T residues important for substrate recognition are crucial for localization. We identified glutamyl (Q) and lys (K) docking sites and show residues on Q side of T are important for assembly than those on K. The first reaction step, interaction with substrates and formation acyl intermediate is determinant in localization of T. Consistent with T exerts “spoteld” activity, we show C is oblong hexamer in solution cross-linked into high molecular forms. Moreover, during reaction T becomes part of cross-products. We suggest dependency T on substrates is to control time, location and extent of activity directed coval fortification preassemblies at sp surface.
Opisthorchis viverrin is a foodborne trematode species that causes biliary disease and cholangiocarcinoma. In Laos, approximately 2. 5 million individuals are infected with O. vivini. However, epidemiological studies are scarce and the spatial distribution of infection remains to be determined. Our aim was to map the distribution of O. vivini in southern Laos, identify risk factors, and predict prevalence at non-survey locations. A cross-sectional parasitological and questionnaire survey was carried out in 51 villages in Champas province in 2007. Data on demography, socioeconomic status, water, sanitation, and behavior were combined with remotely sensed environmental data into a geographical information system. Bayesian statistical models were employed to identify risk and investigate the pattern of O vivini. Bayesian krig was utilized to predict risk at nonsurvey locations. The prevalence of O viv among 3, 371 participants with complete records was 61.1. Statistical models identified age, Lao ethnic group, educational attainment ( farmer, fisherman, animal breeder ), and unsafe water source as risk factors. History prazant treatment, access sanitation, and distance to freshwater were found to be protective. Spatial O viv were mainly governed by environmental with modeling identifying two profiles: low viv in mountains and high in Mekong. We present the first map viv infection in Champas, important for targeting efforts.
Lymphatic filariasis and malaria are major public health concerns in Dar es Salaam, United Republic of Tanzania, with Anopheles and Cule mosquitoes being the primary vectors. In Dar Sala has an extensive network of drains, mostly with inadequate flow and blocked by waste, which causes flooding after rainfall. The presence of Anophe and Cule larvae is common and likely to impact the transmission of lymphatic filari and malaria by the adult mosquito populations. However, the importance of drains as larval habitats remains unknown. In Dar Sala, more than 70% of larval habitats are human-made, with aquatic habitats associated with agriculture having the highest proportion of Anophe larvae and second of Cule larvae. The majority of aquatic habitats are drains (42% ), and 43% ( 1, 364/ 3 149 ) of all culicine and 33% (320 976 ) of anopheline habitats are drains. Compared to drains with normal water flow, the odds of finding Anophe and Cule larvae are 8.8 and 6.3 (p<.001 ) times larger in drains with stagnant water. There is a positive association between vegetation and mosquito presence (p.001 ). The proportion of habitats with larvae is spatially correlated. Restoring and maintaining drains in Dar Sala has the potential to eliminate more than 40% of all larval habitats currently treated with laricides by the Urban Malaria Control Program.
Dengue virus (DENV) is the most common mosquito-borne viral disease in humans. Previous studies have shown that changes in lipid metabolites in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) of DENV infected cells are associated with replicative formation. Here, we show that DENV infection increases the activity of HMG-CoA reductase (HMGCR) through the impairment of AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) phosphorylation. Using enzymatic assays, ELISA, and WB, we found a significant increase in MG activity in DENV infected cells associated with inactivation of AMPK. Metformin, an AMPK activator, declined MG activity suggesting that AMP inactivation mediates the increase in MG. MG and AMP co-localized with viral proteins NS3, NS4A, and E, suggesting a role in MG and AMP activity in replicative complexes. Metform and lovastatin, MG inhibitor, altered co-localization as well as replicative formation supporting active MG required for complexes. Metform prompted a dose-dependent antiviral effect in DENV cells while compound C, AMP inhibitor, augmented viral copies and percentage infected. PP2 activity, MG phosphatase, was not affected by D infection. These data show that elevated MG in DENV cells is through AMP inhibition not increase PP activity. Interestingly, inhibition showed antiv effect MG-independent.
The ribosome is a complex molecular machine responsible for protein synthesis. The process of tRNA translocation across the ribosome is a key step in this process. We used all-atom molecular simulation of the 70S ribosome (2. 1 million atoms; 1. 3 microseconds ) to study the kinetics of tRNA translocation. Starting from a prelocation configuration, we identified sets of residues that undergo conformational rearrangements implicated in ribosome function. We estimated diffusion coefficients along collective coordinates of translocation to convert between experimental and energy measures of the landscape. This analysis, in conjunction with previously reported rates of translocation, provides an upper estimate of free barriers with trans.
Medullary thyroid cancer (MTC) is a malignancy of the thyroid gland that is not yet fully understood, although some oncogenic mutations have been identified. To explore the genetic profiles of MTC, we assayed formalin-fixed, paraffin-embedded tumor tissues from M patients on the Ion AmpliSeq Cancer Panel. Eighty-four sporadic M samples and 36 normal thyroid tissues were successfully sequenced. We discovered 101 mutations in 18 genes in the MTC samples. The most common mutation was in the RET proto-oncogene, occurring in 47 cases, followed by mutations in HRAS (14), STK11 (11), KIT (6), MLH1 (4), KIT (3) and MET (3). We also evaluated anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK) rearrangement by immunohistochemistry and breakapart fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH). Two of 98 cases were positive for ALK FISH. To identify the genomic breakpoint and 5 fusion partner of AL, customized sequencing was performed using DNA from samples of two patients. Glutaminefructose-6-phosphate transaminase 1 (GF1)ALK and echodermicrotubule-associated protein 4 (4ALK) fusions were identified. Additional analysis by Sanger sequencing confirmed GF1ALK, indicating the fusion is result of intra-chromosomal translocation or deletion. Notably, a metastatic M case harboring 4ALK showed dramatic response to AL inhibitor crizotinib.
Asymptomatic Leishmanias in Kala Endemic Areas of Malda District, West Bengal, India: A Challenge to Visceral Leishias (VL) Elimination Initiative. Asymptomatic Leishias may drive the epidemic and important challenge to the goal of VL elimination taken by three Asian countries. The role of asymptomatic carriers in disease transmission, prognosis and rate of transformation to symptomatic Visc Leishias (VL) needs to be evaluated. Asympt cases were diagnosed by active survey in eight tribal villages detecting Leishial antibody using r39 based diagnostic kits followed for three years to observe pattern of seroconversion and disease. Out of 2890 population, 260 were screened. Leishial antibody detected in 185 of them 96 had VL/PK history and 89 without history. Seventy nine were classified as asymptomatic Leishias and 10 VL with ratio 7:1. Of 79 cases were lost to follow as moved other places. Amongstymptically infected, disease in 8 (10% ) and seroconversion 62 (80% ) were noted. Seven (9% ) remained serpositive after three. Progress to disease amongympt individuals took place up three years baseline. If no VL/PK cases two years, does not mean area free Leishias asympt may appear three.
Genome rearrangements (GCRs) and aneuploidy can lead to the development of diseases and cancer. In this study, we used Multiplex Ligation–dependent Probe Amplification (MLPA) to analyze Gs induced by the retrotranson Ty912 in Saccharomyces cerevisiae. We found that the distribution of translocations induced by Ty was nonrandom and the majority were mediated by six translocation targets on four chromosomes, even though there were 254 potential targets in S. cerevisiae. The majority of Ty-mediated trans resulted from RAD-dependent recombination, but we also observed nonrecipro trans mediated by RAD-independent between Ty elements. RAD-independent trans did not require Rad51 or Rad homologous proteins or Rad–endonuclease that process branched DNAs. We found that defects in ASF-dependent acetylation of histone lysine 56 resulted in increased Gs and whole-chromosome duplications and anup that tended to occur with Gs.
Protein docking is the process by which two proteins associate with each other is driven by a free energy funnel that is determined by favorable interactions in the neighborhood of the native state. We describe a docking method called semi-definite programming underestimation ( SD ) that minimizes funnel-shaped energy functions in the space of rigid body motions ( SE ( 3 ) while accounting for flexibility of the interface chains. SD employs a quadratic function to underestimate a set of local minima and uses the resulting underestimator to bias sampling. However, application to docking in rotational and translational space ( SE 3 ) is not straightforward due to the geometry of space. We introduce a strategy that uses independent variables for side-chain optimization, center-to-center distance of two proteins and five descriptors of relative orientations of molecules. The removal of center-center distance turns out to improve efficiency of search because five-dimensional space exhibits well-behaved energy suitable for underestimation. This explores energy surface spanned by complexes that correspond to local minima and shows model macromolecular association that proceeds series of collisions.
